title: Democracies and Their Police
description: Last year in South Africa, more than 550 people died at the hands of the police. Statistics for the apartheid era are weak, but the numbers indicate that the police are more deadly today than they were during most of the last 25 years of apartheid. The recent victims, of course, are criminal suspects, not political activists. But in newly democratic or newly peaceful nations, police often retain many of the habits of their predecessors, including shooting suspects or, less often, beating them to death. A new government, it seems, does not automatically bring new police practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALL, DR. MARION N.
description: CHALL-Dr. Marion N. Died on April 28, 2000 in Tel-Aviv, Israel. She fell ill while traveling in Egypt. A graduate of Barnard College and Cornell University Medical College, she was one of four women in the Class of 1954. She completed her residency at New York Hospital. Dr. Chall was Honorary Attending Physician at Beth Israel Medical Center where she had been Chief of the Teenage Service. She had served on the faculty of New York University and Mount Sinai Medical Schools. Noted for leadership in substance abuse treatment, she was for 35 years a member of the board and former Chairman of the Lower Eastside Service Center. Beloved wife for 47 years of Dr. George Chall. Dear sister of Ann Marie Hurd of Massapequa, Long Island. Visitation Tuesday, 7-9 PM, with funeral service at 8 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment private. title: Honduras Gives Meaning To a Meaningless Match

title: Greek Trilogy With a Grand Sweep
description: In its first season of rotating repertory the Pearl Theater Company is pairing ''The Way of the World'' by William Congreve with ''The Oresteia'' by Aeschylus, the three plays of the Greek trilogy presented as acts of a single production. Given the stature of the trilogy in the history of Western drama, this is somewhat like listing Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle as a one-day presentation in an opera repertory. ''The Oresteia'' is, of course, shorter than that. And, fortunately, ambition is not the only virtue to applaud in this rare undertaking.

title: Mr. Lott's Reform Charade
description: Hardly anyone outside Washington may have given a thought lately to Bradley Smith, a Republican nominee to the Federal Election Commission. But the battle over the Smith nomination is becoming an embarrassment to Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader and champion of Mr. Smith's cause. To Mr. Lott's consternation, more and more senators realize the foolishness of placing an ideological opponent of campaign finance reform laws in charge of their enforcement. Yet Mr. Lott persists, strong-arming Republican senators and telling Democrats he will hold up all presidential appointments until they let Mr. Smith through.

Chords were fully realized. Contrapuntal lines that in the original were disconnected dashes and strokes were spelled out from first note to last. Here at last, the thinking went, was everything Bach had meant to tell us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOFF, BURTON ''BUDDY.''
description: KOSSOFF-Burton ''Buddy.'' On April 29, 2000, at age 76 years. Beloved and cherished husband of Phyllis L. Kossoff, devoted and caring father of Mitchell and Pamela Kossoff and the late Stephanie Lynn Kossoff. Adored grandfather of Joshua, Alec, Noah and Jeremy. Treasured brother of Ira and Edie, Arnold and Esther and 'Laine. Extraordinary man and magnificent friend. As a young man, Buddy enlisted and served his country during WW II with extreme courage and valor. As first lieutenant in the Air Corps, he flew 36 missions in the Pacific and was awarded numerous commendations including the Distinguished Flying Cross. Burt was a graduate and honorary Trustee of Baruch College of the City of New York. He founded in 1949, as pioneer in the packaging field, the Burton Packaging Co, Inc, for which he served for over 50 years as President and CEO until the time of his passing. His loving and unique being imparted radiance and the joy of life overcoming challenges and bringing a rare enthusiasm to all facets of his endevors. In 1954 he, together with his wife Phyllis, were part of a smallband of parents who organzied, initiated and maintained the beginning effort in the now National Cystic Fibrosis Research and Care organizations. For over 45 years Burt was dedicated and esteemed member, director and currently officer of the Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York. A man of dignity and grace, Buddy touched all he met with his warmth and love of humanity. His strength of character, his keen intellectualism and his love of camaraderie embraced the myriad of his endeavors. A tennis enthusiast and avid handball player until the end, he participated with joy as many years President of the Businessmen's Club at the YMCA and with unbridled pleasure in loyal support and love with many of his friends in the handball ''Killers Club,'' and the American Legion of the NYAC. Burt was a past President of the Young Presidents Organization and benefactor of many causes giving generously and selflessly in these efforts, all with a never-ending smile and with a personal banner of ''Carpe Diem,'' he marched fearlessly through life. Buddy dearest, you will be with us always in the shelter of your strength, your kind and gentle warmth and your unfailing, sweet smile. We love you. Services will be held at 1:15 PM, Monday, May 1, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

Policy Management's shares jumped 41 percent, rising $5.375, to $18.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The E.D.S. offer values Policy Management at $640.6 million to $711.8 million. In March, Welsh Carson, a closely held investment firm, agreed to pay $14 a share, or $604 million, for as much as 93 percent of Policy Management. E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., said Policy Management had until the close of business today to respond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONEYHAM, RUSSELL
description: MONEYHAM-Russell. Brooklyn Heights, age 70, born Asheville, N.C. One of the most giving people to ever grace the human race has left the earth. Russ Moneyham who gave much more to all who knew him than he ever received has passed away. He loved small people. The people who could not fend for themselves. He loved Berea College for the chance it gave him in life and the chance it gave all the underprivileged who went there. He was a sports fanatic, always championing the underdog. He believed that everyone should have minimum wages so they could live in dignity. Over the past few years he adopted a number of young people from Bangladesh. He helped these people build a life. The kindness & love Russ exhibited is exactly what every religion espouses and really delivers. NYC will miss a truly good person.

Beloved and remembered as an autodidact of the finest sensibilities, a brilliantly sparkling and witty conversationalist, a self-possessed woman with a rare genius for life.

title: ING TO ACQUIRE RELIASTAR
description: The Dutch bank ING Group N.V. reached an agreement to acquire the Minneapolis-based life insurer ReliaStar for $54 a share, a total of $5.1 billion. It will also assume about $1 billion in debt. The move is part of ING's ambition of ''substantially increasing our presence in the U.S. and furthering our position as a financial services leader in North America,'' its chairman, Godfried van der Lugt, said. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: BLACKOUT OF ABC ON CABLE AFFECTS MILLIONS OF HOMES

title: A Chance for Modernists to Luxuriate

The two vocabularies of classical ballet and Ms. Tharp's squiggly modernism seldom merge in the ballet, performed by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. But they cohabit revealingly, giving the performers a newly burnished glow.

title: Haider's Shadow Falls to the East
description: Since Jorg Haider's far right Freedom Party entered the Austrian government, Western Europe has held fast with a rejection that is surprising for both its fervor and its unity. But even more surprising -- and alarming as well -- is the opposing unity of resistance that the European Union's sanctions against Austria have inspired in Austria's eastern neighbors. The move against Austria has cut close to home in post-Communist Central Europe, where calculated cooperation with extremists in parliamentary politics is, unfortunately, an everyday reality.

title: HOWMET REJECTS TENDER OFFER MADE BY ALCOA
description: Howmet International Inc., the largest maker of jet-engine castings, told its shareholders yesterday to reject a tender offer of $20 a share from Alcoa Inc. because the price was too low. Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum maker, wants to buy the remaining 15 percent of Howmet for about $300 million once it completes the purchase of Howmet's parent, Cordant Technologies Inc. Alcoa agreed in March to buy Cordant for $2.9 billion in cash and debt. Howmet is Cordant's biggest business. , makes alloys and titanium parts used in jet aircraft and in electric-power generation. Alcoa said it would continue the tender offer. Shares of Howmet, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., rose 43.75 cents, to $21.625, while Alcoa fell $1.4375 a share, to $63.4375.

He returned two years later to conduct Mahler's Fifth Symphony, and the critical reception that time was not good, and nothing he has done in New York since has equaled the Mahler Sixth. He is back with the Philharmonic, and the Friday morning performance of his program was once again curiously mixed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, NATHALIE G.
description: SCHLANGER-Nathalie G., Age 87, on April 29, 2000, at her home in Mount Vernon, New York. Mrs. Schlanger, the daughter of the late Asher and Miriam Gutkowsky Glickson, was born and raised in Norwalk, Connecticut. She graduated from Vassar College, and later from Columbia University. She married Dr. Samuel Schlanger in New York City in 1936, and was his loving and devoted wife until his death in 1987. She was a wonderful mother to her sons Robert (who predeceased her) and Michael, a wonderful grandmother to her grandsons Teddy, Nicholas and Ben, and a wonderful mother in-law to her daughter-in-law, Barbara. She is also survived by numerous cousins, nieces and nephews. For many years, Mrs. Schlanger was the Senior Psychotherapist at the Pleasantville Cottage School, where she helped generations of adolescent boys and girls progress to healthy adulthood. Mrs. Schlanger, who lived in the same house in Mount Vernon for 55 years, also devoted four decades of her free time to the performance of good works for the benefit of the Mount Vernon community, including service as the Chairman of the Mount Vernon Public Library, the Mount Vernon YM - YWHA, the Pennington School Parent-Teacher Association, and ad hoc boards and committees, including the one whose activities led to the building of Mount Vernon High School and to the consolidation of public high school education in the city. In lieu of flower, contributions can be made to the Mount Vernon Hospital, 12 North 7th Avenue, Mount Vernon, New York 10550.

title: CMS ENERGY CANCELS OFFERING FOR UTILITY SUBSIDIARY
description: The CMS Energy Corporation is canceling an initial public offering of Consumers Energy, its Michigan electric and natural gas utility, because of weak demand for utility stocks and says it will instead increase its asset sales by $700 million to reduce debt. Reversing a decision announced in February, CMS said yesterday that it had also decided to keep its annual dividend at $1.46 a share rather than cut it to 40 cents. The stock rose $1.0625 a share, to $20.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of CMS fell 21 percent on Feb. 1 after it said that it would cut dividends and that 2000 profits would miss forecasts. CMS wanted to sell 20 percent of Consumers Energy in order to raise money to reduce debt.

title: PLAYTEX PRODUCTS OFFERS TO BUY 10 MILLION SHARES
description: Playtex Products Inc., whose shares have dropped sharply in the last year, offered yesterday to buy as many as 10 million shares for as much as $180 million. The company, a maker of feminine-care products, plans a two-step transaction. Playtex offered to buy each share for $3 in cash and a newly issued Class B share. The company may then choose to buy back the Class B shares some time next year for $15 each, a combined value of $18. The stock of Playtex, based in Westport, Conn., rose $1.25 a share, or 12 percent, to $12.0625. If Playtex does not offer to buy back the Class B shares next year, the shares will convert into common stock.

title: GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE CAMERON ASHLEY

Under the agreement, Guardian will pay $18.35 a share in cash. Last month, Guardian offered $18.50 a share. Company officials were not immediately available to explain the decrease in the price. Cameron Ashley, a Dallas-based building products distributor, terminated an agreement to sell the company to CGW Southeast Partners IV and an affiliate of the Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. unit of Citigroup Inc. Guardian is a privately held fiberglass-insulation maker based in Auburn Hills, Mich. Shares of Cameron Ashley rose 50 cents each, to $18, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Peace Overtures in Colombia
description: With his decision to establish a safe haven for Colombia's second-largest guerrilla group, President Andres Pastrana is showing admirable persistence in trying to negotiate an end to his nation's 35-year-old civil war. The plan would draw the group, the National Liberation Army, into Mr. Pastrana's peace talks for the first time. Colombians have learned not to expect too much from periodic negotiations, and a peace agreement is still a long shot. But the inclusion of the National Liberation Army provides the best chance in recent history to negotiate an end to the activities of a guerrilla army whose kidnappings and bombing of oil production facilities have terrorized Colombians.

He was an AIDS counselor and a community activist. Born in Princeton, NJ, he had lived in NYC before coming to Monmouth Beach in 1970. He was founder of the 79th St. Block Association of NY. He was a well known West Side community activist. He was founder and director of the A-Team at Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, NJ, and was a recipient of the Chrystal Award on behalf of the people with AIDS and HIV. He was also facilitated with many support groups in New Jersey. He studied acting and was an actor in many of the New York City theaters. A veteran of the U.S. Air Force, he was predeceased by his brother Felix G., who died in March. Surviving are two brothers and three sisters-in-law, Angelo and Ann Cenerino, AZ; Manfred and Mary Cenerino, NJ; Violet Cenerino, FL; many nieces and nephews and many beloved friends. Relatives and friends may call at the Damiano Funeral Home, 3rd and Franklin Aves, Long Branch, NJ, on Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Service Wednesday 11 AM., at the funeral home . Interment St. Paul's Cemetery, Princeton, NJ, at 1:15 PM. Kindly omit flowers. Memorial donations to the Center of Asbury Park, PO Box 832, Asbury Park, NJ 07712. Messiaen's juxtapositions of soaring melodies and dissonant chordal blocks are not unusual in themselves, nor are his complex rhythmic systems. His stylized use of birdcalls, while certainly a thumbprint of sorts, often seems more a surface detail than a key to the soul of the music, although it gets one closer, in a roundabout way: it links Messiaen with St. Francis of Assisi, the subject of his only opera, and it is an aspect of his attraction to the mystical side of Roman Catholicism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRITTON, WRIGHT
description: BRITTON-Wright, age 74, died of pancreatic cancer, on Saturday, April 29, 2000. He bravely battled his formidable foe for six months, and the courage and dignity he brought to his last days reflected the values that he embodied throughout his extraordinary life. He received his Ph.D. in maritime history from the University of Pennsylvania and taught in the Department of American Civilization at Rutgers University and the Department of History at the University of Pennsylvania. He was an expert in high latitude sailing and wrote numerous articles for scholarly journals and sailing magazines. Among his many awards was the Blue Water Medal of the Cruising Club of America for his voyage to Greenland. He also sailed on flag-carrying expeditions for the Explorers Club and National Geographic. On many of his voyages he worked on research projects for Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Canadian and U.S. Hydrographic Departments and American Museum of Natural History among others. He raced his boat in the trans-Atlantic Yacht Race to Sweden, as well as in many other ocean yacht races. For many years he served on the House Committee of the New York Yacht Club. He was an Ensign in the U.S. Navy during World War II. We shall miss his warmth, wit and prodigious intelligence. He was a consummate gentleman and will always be remembered with enormous affection and a deep sense of loss. Survived by his loving wife of 40 years, Pat, and a brother, Mason Britton Jr., Southport, Maine. Contributions may be sent to The Hill School, Pottstown, PA 19464. A memorial service will be held at a later date. ''His life was gentle; and the elements so mix'd in him, that Nature might stand up, and say to all the world, 'This was a man.'''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMEO, DR. VINCENT D.
description: ROMEO-Dr. Vincent D. President and Chief Executive Officer of Nastech Pharmaceutical Company, Inc. in Hauppauge, NY died on May 1, after a long bout with leukemia. Dr. Romeo joined Nastech in 1985 as a Senior Research Scientist. He became Director of Research and shortly thereafter, Vice President of Research and Development. Following the sudden passing in 1991 of the Founder and Chairman of Nastech, Dr. Jeffrey Wenig, Dr. Romeo assumed the position of President and CEO. Dr. Romeo was well known and highly respected as a specialist in the area of nasal drug delivery, having played a key role in the formulation of drugs for nasal delivery, and in the design of clinical efficacy and safety studies leading to drug approval. He was also the author and co-author of numerous peer-reviewed articles and presentations. A registered pharmacist, Dr. Romeo received his B.S. (Pharmacy), M.S. and Ph.D. degrees from St.John's University College of Pharmacy and Allied Health Professions, where he currently served as Adjunct Professor of Pharmacology in the Graduate Division. Dr. Romeo was also appointed as Adjunct Assistant Professor of Pharamaceutics at the University of Rhode Island College of Pharmacy. Dr. Romeo was an active member of the American Association of Pharmaceutical Scientists where he served cochairman of the Nasal Focus Group. He was also a member of the American College of Clinical Pharmacology, the American Pharmaceutical Association, the Rho Chi Pharmaceutical Honor Society, and the New York Academy of Sciences. In 1993, Dr. Romeo became a member of Who's Who Worldwide Global Business Leaders. Dr. Romeo was an Eucharastic Minister, Lector and Coordinator of the Pre-Cana Marriage Council at Maria Regina R.C. Church in Seaford, NY, and a member of the Third Degree Knights of Columbus, Council #

title: Revolt of the Business Class

But there are not many parallels to the recent rebellion among wealthy businesses tired of being hit up by Democrats and Republicans for campaign donations. As Don Van Natta Jr. reported in The Times this week, at least 31 corporations that have given big soft-money contributions in recent election cycles appear to be boycotting the process this year. Most are backing off quietly, but a few have stepped forward to say that swearing off soft money has not brought retaliation from the political establishment. Their disgust with the excesses of fund-raising could be another impetus to enactment of campaign finance reform this year.

description: OPPENHEIM - Henry. Yeshiva University and its Sy Syms School of Business mourn the passing of a dear friend, a leader of the Jewish community who, with his late wife, Selma, was an SSSB Fellow. We extend heartfelt condolences to their sons, Steven-a YU Guardian and SSSB Founder who established a scholarship fund in their honor at the Business School-and Richard; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: 15 Are Held as Agents Crack Long-Running Cocaine Ring
description: Federal agents have broken up a cocaine ring that had been operating in New York City for 15 years and that used the attendants and dark corners of Midtown Manhattan parking garages to transfer millions of dollars in drug proceeds from one courier's car to another, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Husband of District Attorney Seeks to Defend Himself at Trial
description: Albert J. Pirro Jr., the real estate development lawyer who is scheduled to stand trial next week on federal tax-fraud charges, announced today that he wanted to add another lawyer to his high-powered defense team: Albert J. Pirro Jr.

title: Memo Shows Another Push for Clinton Inquiry
description: A Republican senator said at a hearing today that the former head of the Justice Department's campaign finance unit had unsuccessfully urged the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate President Clinton and a top executive of the Loral aerospace company.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SPUTTERS. The euro fell against the dollar yesterday, dropping under the record low that it hit last Friday. In late New York trading, the euro was quoted at 90.73 cents, down from 91.72 cents late on Monday.

title: Papa's To-Do List: Hunt, Fish, Drink. More of Same.
description: ''Michael Palin's Hemingway Adventure'' is an engrossing travelogue. But there are two things it is not. Even though Mr. Palin, the program's host and writer, is an alumnus of the Monty Python comedy troupe, this is no manic Pythonian romp. Nor is it a colloquy on the life and work of Ernest Hemingway.

title: The Bearable Lightness of Beating
description: POUNDCAKE is like brownies: a baker's challenge that sounds like child's play. The name itself is traditionally half the recipe -- a pound each of butter, eggs, sugar and flour -- but the technique is critical to producing a cake that is so tender it can stand alone but is still sturdy enough to hold up under a fruit compote, ice cream or sauce.

title: Errors and Poor Supervision Cited in Bonfire Collapse
description: In a highly critical report, a commission investigating the fatal collapse of a traditional Texas A&M University bonfire tower concluded today that students made fundamental mistakes in building the huge structure and that university officials failed to control the student-led project properly.

title: Jerusalem Journal; More Than One Way to Remember the Holocaust
description: At 10 a.m. precisely, air-raid sirens sounded throughout Israel today and the country froze in its tracks for two minutes to remember the victims of the Holocaust. Drivers stood at attention beside their cars, shopkeepers stepped onto the sidewalk and pedestrians halted in mid-stride, their heads bowed or defiantly upright.

title: It's Handel's Caesar but Fit for Wagner
description: Opera is many other things besides, but it can also be a parade of gorgeous voices, one after another, in thrilling and touching songs. Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' returned to the Met on Friday with most of the same outstanding principals it had last season.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil prices rose 3.9 percent on signs that OPEC's plan to keep prices within a fixed range is succeeding. In New York, crude oil for delivery in June rose $1.02 cents, to $26.89 a barrel.

title: Administration Steps Up Effort For Support of China Trade Bill
description: President Clinton and his top aides, acknowledging that they still lack the votes to pass a decisive China trade measure later this month, increased pressure on Congress yesterday by arguing that the decision is as much about global leadership and the fate of Chinese reformers as it is about the interests of American business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, ROBERT L.B.
description: TOBIN-Robert L.B. Robert and his mother, Margaret, were close friends of City Opera for years. He was a lifelong patron of the arts, especially opera, and he will be sorely missed. His commitment to the growth and development of opera will not be forgotten. Paul Kellogg, General & Artistic Director

description: Even though the world's greatest marathon runner cleared the last piece of government red tape to become an American citizen yesterday, there is considerable uncertainty about whether he will ever cross the tape at the finish line Oct. 1 at the Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a nature writer who is trying to save Southeast forests carried an erroneous dateline for the Georgia town where she was born. It is Baxley, not Baxter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ABE
description: MANDEL-Abe. Beloved music teacher, musician, husband, father, grandfather and friend, died on April 30 at Montefiore Hospital after a sudden stroke. He coauthored ''Abe and Malka's Patterns'', a guitar method book, with his wife Mickie (aka Malka). He was a cherished teacher at the Lucy Moses School, Lehman College and Columbia University Teachers College, where he cotaught with his wife. Together, they were inspiring teachers and leaders of music at The City Congregation for Humanistic Judaism. Age 57, he is survived by his wife Mickie Mandel, his children: Rama and her husband Rocco Mastronardi, Ava Aviva and her husband Michael Montana, and Ellana; and grandson Evan Mastronardi. He graduated High School of Music, and Art and attended Manhattan School of Music, received a Bachelor's degree from Hunter College and two Master's degrees from Columbia University Teachers College. Service Friday, May 5th, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island. A memorial tribute will be held June 4th, at 2:15PM in Merkin Concert Hall. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The City Congregation, in memory of Abe, c/o TBC, 110 W. 57 St., 3rd Flr, NY NY 10019.

title: Unisys Evaluating Possible Conflict
description: The Unisys Corporation is evaluating its relationship with the Bozell Group after eight years. Billings for the account of Unisys, a computer services supplier, were estimated at $20 million.

title: Done Counting, Now Let's Eat
description: ''One Lonely Sea Horse'' (Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic, $15.95) offers proof that there are apparently no limits to the imagination of Joost Elffers and Saxton Freymann, authors of ''Play With Your Food,'' who wrote this children's book in which the characters are made of food. It tells the story of Bea, a sea horse made of beets, and her friends: banana squid and dolphins, eggplant sharks, ginger crustaceans and bright bell-pepper tropical fish, which swim amid coral reefs made of hen-of-the-woods mushrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNES, ROBERT MCKINNY
description: BARNES-Robert McKinny, 79, in East Hampton, NY. He is survived by his four sons, Michael, of Sierra Vista, Arizona, Rush, of New York, NY, Robert, Jr., of Easthampton, NY, and Alexander, of Seoul, South Korea. He is also survived by four grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. The family will receive friends Wednesday from 7 to 9 P.M. at Williams Funeral Home, Newtown Lane, Easthampton. A Memorial Mass will be offered at the Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, Easthampton, 11 A.M. Thursday.

title: BRAZIL'S TRADE SURPLUS
description: In an indication of Brazil's strengthening economy, the country registered a trade surplus of $183 million in April despite a strike of customs workers that virtually paralyzed commerce at the beginning of the month. Brazil closed out the first four months of the year with a surplus of $209 million, compared with a deficit of $782 million a year earlier. Led by electronic transmission devices and soybeans, Brazil's average daily exports increased 18.7 percent last month over April 1999. Jennifer L. Rich

description: With catcalls, boos and groans, residents showed their displeasure, skepticism and anger last night toward a proposal to reduce traffic congestion on Interstate 287 by replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge, which links Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRESNER, RABBI SAMUEL H.
description: DRESNER-Rabbi Samuel H. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague, scholar and teacher. He was rabbi emeritus of Moriah Congregation in Chicago. As a congregational rabbi, he spearheaded the campaign for Jewish funeral reform and was an activist in the cause of civil rights, which led to his appointment as chairman of the Massachusetts State Human Relations Commission. A faculty member of the Jewish Theological Seminary since 1985, he is the author of numerous books and articles in the fields of Jewish mysticism and the American Jewish community as well as our publication, the Jewish Dietary Laws. We express our deepest condolences to his loving wife, Ruth, children, Hannah, Miriam, Drs. Nehama and Rachel and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Women Play More, but Coach Less
description: While the average number of women's collegiate teams per school is at a high, the percentage of women coaching them is the lowest ever, a study of intercollegiate athletics released on Monday said.

title: A Needless Showdown Over Vieques
description: The Clinton administration is preparing to evict dozens of protesters camped at the Navy bombing range on Vieques, an island off the coast of Puerto Rico. Instead of engaging in a fight now, Washington should wait until Vieques residents decide in a vote next year whether they want the Navy to continue to use the island. If the Navy is welcome after the vote, protesters can then be removed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, DAVID J.
description: MAHONEY-David J. The Board, Staff and entire membership of Research America honor the life of David J. Mahoney, Chairman and CEO of the Charles A. Dana Foundation. A visionary commited to making medical and health research a higher national priority, he leaves a legacy of inspiration and leadership for a stronger investment in research leading to the treatment, cure and prevention of disease-particularly neurological disorders. His forceful advicacy through the Dana Alliance for Brain Initiatives marshaled evidence for the designation of the 1990's as the Decade of the Brain and continued commitment to education and outreach via the annual celebration of Brain Awareness Week. We extend our condolences to his family. Honorable Paul G. Rogers, Chair Mary Woolley, President

description: It doesn't take a genius to handicap this one. The banged-up, skill-challenged, hungry Heat will starve to death against the Knicks on shots forced up as the 24-second clock winds down, on too many paint-by-number offensive possessions. On Miami's 2000 tombstone will read an inscription that could be the title of Pat Riley's next book.

title: Across the Atlantic, the Microsoft Case Attracts Curiosity
description: This university town has been transformed in the last decade by the arrival of companies like Microsoft, along with a bevy of start-ups hoping to follow in its footsteps. Now it is watching intently to see whether Microsoft's path will be divided.

title: Mr. Business-School Boom; What Jacobs Wrought, in a Quarter-Century, at Kellogg
description: Donald P. Jacobs jumps into a swimming pool every day at 6:30 a.m. and spends 45 minutes doing laps. During rainstorms, he sometimes dashes without an umbrella between buildings on the Northwestern University campus here, even as the wind off Lake Michigan musses his hair. When he gives public speeches, he often wears a sweatshirt. And when he finds something funny, he throws his head back, crosses his arms over his chest and guffaws.

title: Nepotism Admitted in Hiring of Supervisor at Site Where Brick Killed Girl
description: A highly placed secretary at the New York City School Construction Authority has admitted that she used her influence to get a job for her husband as a project supervisor at a Brooklyn elementary school where a falling brick killed a girl two years ago, officials at the city's Conflicts of Interest Board said yesterday.

title: Lush Wine From A Pacific Breeze
description: The Santa Ynez Valley stretches west through central Santa Barbara County, reaching toward this small city and the Pacific Ocean beyond. It's a land of relaxed beauty, where narrow roads curl through the knobby, windswept Santa Rita Hills, through rows of walnut trees and strawberry fields, past acres of cabbage and broccoli and, here and there, a few sparse vineyards. It's certainly not Burgundy, where grapevines are planted everywhere, right to the edge of the highway, or Napa Valley, where the wineries are as densely packed as a suburb full of split-levels, but make no mistake: this is wine country.

title: Cincinnati Takes Stock of a Laughingstock
description: Cross one of the bridges that spans the Ohio River and connects Kentucky to Ohio, and you will arrive in downtown Cincinnati, in view of a large construction site with huge cranes, slabs of concrete and busy workers blending like bees. It is a jungle down there. Paul Brown Stadium -- the Bengals' new $318 million home -- is nearly complete.

title: Certifying Liberal Arts Majors for a High-Tech World
Painting Contractor Charged With 1989 Murder in Queens
description: Eleven years after a Queens businessman was shot to death in his lavish Astoria home, the authorities yesterday charged the owner of a major bridge-painting company, which has worked on the Verrazano, Whitestone and Triborough bridges and has been linked to organized crime, with the murder of the Queens man, his former business partner.

title: Commercial Real Estate; As Law Firms Relocate, New Image for '82 Tower
description: The fire-engine-red escalators and stark black walls that once set the tone for the five-story atrium lobby at 875 Third Avenue in Manhattan are now a gentle, grayish off-white, and the cold granite elevator banks have been covered with a warm light-brown paneling of anegre wood from Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, RONDA ORMONT
description: BLUMBERG-Ronda Ormont. The fifth grade families of Trinity School are profoundly saddened by the loss of a wonderful woman and dear friend. Our thoughts are with you, Hank and Perri. Class of 2007 Trinity School

title: State Bidder Buys Relics For China
description: The confrontation between the Chinese authorities and Hong Kong's premier auction houses over the sale of looted imperial treasures has been defused, for now at least, by an unlikely source: a giant Chinese state-owned corporation that became the winning bidder on three of the four contested objects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, LOUIS L.
description: HOROWITZ-Louis L. Died on April 28, 2000 in Aventura, FL. Beloved father of Marcia Hochberg & Barbara Greenblatt. Dear father-in-law of Dr. Fred Hochberg and Philip Greenblatt. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey and David Greenblatt and Ian Hochberg, Elizabeth Hochberg and her husband Michael Schloff. Lou was a former owner and partner of Benjamin Horowitz Monument Works. Funeral and interment were in Florida. He will be missed.

title: TALKS ON ROVER RESCUE
description: A consortium seeking to acquire Britain's money-losing Rover Cars opened talks in London with BMW, Rover's owner, which has said it will close the automaker if it cannot find a buyer this month. The negotiations follow the collapse last week of a near-completed deal between BMW and a British venture capital firm, Alchemy Partners. The newest talks are with the Phoenix Consortium, led by John Towers, a former Rover chief executive. Alan Cowell

title: Auto Sales Keep to Torrid Pace Even as Loan Costs Rise
description: Rising interest rates, a volatile stock market and higher gasoline prices were expected to be slowing the American economy by now, especially the highly cyclical auto industry. Yet the stampede into the showrooms continues across the country, with every big domestic and foreign automaker announcing today that sales last month exceeded even last year's brisk pace.

description: Companies Ask U.N. for Help on Software System

description: Under increasing pressure, Time Warner restored the signals of ABC television stations to 3.5 million homes yesterday afternoon after agreeing to a temporary truce in its contractual impasse with the Walt Disney Company.

title: Jonah Jones, 91, a Master Jazz Trumpeter
description: Jonah Jones, a jazz trumpeter who played with some of the great swing bands and sold a million copies of his versions of ''On the Street Where You Live'' and ''Baubles, Bangles and Beads,'' died on Sunday. He was 91 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONATI, GRACE FOX
description: DONATI-Grace Fox. Age 36 on April 30 after a short illness. Beloved daughter of Robert and Georgia Donati of Scarsdale, New York, cherished sister of Sylvia & Ellen Donati. Freelance journalist. Graduate of Columbia Journalism School, Wesleyan University. Worked at Dow Jones, WNYC, Crains NY Business and international Center in New York. Memorial service at 11 A.M. on Saturday, May 6 at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, 6 Greenacres Avenue, Scarsdale, New York.

title: As Charter School Closes, Debate on Innovation's Limits
description: When they opened a charter school in a deserted warehouse here, Michael and Sarah Rennick had a clear vision of what it could be: a place where kids who did not fit the mold -- the geeks, the dropouts -- would flourish, a place where students might start their days later to accommodate their teenage sleepiness, a place where they would call teachers by their first names, and skateboard or play paintball in lieu of gym class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, SYLVIA LINDER
description: WEINSTEIN-Sylvia Linder. Beloved mother of three. cherished grandmother of four. Loving Aunt, wife, sister, cousin and devoted friend to many. Born on Lincoln's Birthday, 1912, teacher of English and French, graduated NYU Phi Beta Kappa, married to the late Dr. Mandel Weinstein for 41 years. She lived in Forest Hills, Atlantic Beach and Florida, travelled extensively, an amateur photographer who won many prizes, and achieved professional status with a walking book and a portrait of a Japanese warship in New York Harbor, which hangs in the Library of Congress. President of Hadassah and UJA in Queens and one of the original founders of the Forest Hills Jewish Center. Donations in her memory may be made to UJA, Hadassah, The Sierra Foundation and The Humane Society. Services will be held in the Schwartz Memorial Chapel, Thursday, May 4, 1PM, (718) 263-7600, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. She is survived by daughters Marion Weinstein, Ruth Klein and Bette Kaplan, sister Charlotte Lebowitz and grandchildren David, Brian and Benjamin Klein and Manda Kaplan. She continues to be an inspiration to us all.

Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to fly here the other day to address a group of Republicans (though he did squeeze in a round before his speech). It was the chance to do something a politician rarely does: praise another politician more than himself. The object of his affection was Gov. George W. Bush.

description: HAMADA-Dorothy, nee Fleishman, of West Caldwell, N.J. on Monday, May 1st, age 91. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Hamada. Devoted mother of Roslyn Gore of Clifton, N.J and Edwin Hamada. title: AXA BUYS STAKE IN SUN
description: The French insurer Axa S.A. agreed to pay $3.79 billion in cash for the 44.7 percent stake it did not already own in Sun Life and Provincial Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, valuing Sun Life at more than $8.2 billion. Sun Life shareholders will also receive a special divided equivalent to about 8 cents per ordinary share when the deal is completed. Sun Life said the offer represented a premium of 54.1 percent over its shares' closing price on March 23, before Axa and Sun Life announced they were in talks. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNIK, IRENE ''REN''
description: BERNIK-Irene ''Ren''. Suddenly on April 28, 2000. Beloved daughter of Roberto and Silvia. Loving sister of Jose and Lidia. She was an artist and graduate student who touched the lives of all who she met. She will be dearly missed. Rabbinical service Wednesday, 10:30 AM at Krtil Funeral HomeYorkville Funeral Service, Inc., 1297 1st Ave, NYC.

description: On the Internet, brokerage firms are starting to use stock trades the way banks used to use pens and lollipops: they are giving them away to lure people onto their Web sites.

title: The Changing Face of Terror
description: The first step toward combating international terrorism is to identify the places from which it springs, and the latest State Department report properly points to South Asia as a new hub of activity. Pakistan and the rigidly Islamist Taliban movement that dominates Afghanistan are providing safe haven and support for the loose networks of individuals and groups that seem to be replacing states as the primary source of global terror. The challenge for the United States and its allies is to devise a combination of diplomatic and economic pressure that will induce the leaders of Pakistan and Afghanistan to join the fight against terrorism.

title: NEW LEADERS AT JAPANESE BANK
description: Japan's largest lender by assets, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd., is shuffling its senior management, naming former Mitsubishi Bank managers in the positions of both chairman and president for the first time. Shigemitsu Miki, 65, current deputy president of Bank of Tokyo-Mitusbishi, will become president, while Satoru Kishi, 70, left, current president, will become chairman. The change is effective on June 29. For the first time since Bank of Tokyo and Mitsubishi Bank merged in 1996 former executives of one bank will dominate senior management.

title: ALBERTA ENERGY TO ACQUIRE MCMURRY OIL AND GREEN RIVER
description: The Alberta Energy Company said yesterday that its AEC Oil and Gas Inc. unit had agreed to buy the McMurry Oil Company for about $613 million. The deal gives Alberta Energy a major piece of a natural gas field in the United States Rocky Mountains as well as other private interests of McMurry, a closely held company based in Casper, Wyo. The company said its midstream division had also agreed to purchase 92.5 percent of the Green River Pipeline L. L. C., which owns the Jonah Gas Gathering Company, and has offered to acquire the remaining 7.5 percent, for a total of about $162 million. The stock of Alberta Energy, an oil and gas company based in Calgary, Alberta, rose $1.1875 a share, to $33.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

The biggest issues facing television teenagers of the 50's, 60's and 70's seemed to be borrowing the family car or finding a date for the prom.

title: Maybe They Should Just Send In a Camera Crew
description: Keystrokes and phone calls, log-ons and e-mail messages -- increasingly, these workday activities are falling under employers' scrutiny. The number of companies that engaged in at least one form of surveillance of workers surged to 66 percent this year from 45 percent in 1999, according to an American Management Association survey. When monitoring of Internet use, new to the survey, is added to the mix, the proportion of companies that snoop on employees leaps to 74 percent.

title: Apex Oil Raises Hostile Bid
description: The Apex Oil Company increased its hostile offer for the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation today, surpassing a bid by Rosemore Inc., a company controlled by relatives of Crown's chairman. Apex, which is based in St. Louis, offered $10 in cash for each of the Class A and Class B common shares it does not already own. Rosemore is offering $9.50 a share, also in cash. Apex's offer values Crown at about $100.7 million, and Rosemore's at $95.7 million. Crown announced a binding agreement to merge with Rosemore of Baltimore on April 10 and said it expected to complete the sale by midyear.

SWISS GOLD SALE STARTS
description: The Swiss central bank has begun to sell part of the country's gold reserves under a plan to dispose of some $10 billion of bullion in the next several years. The bank, which has the third-largest gold reserves, commissioned the Basel-based Bank for International Settlements to sell the first installment of an estimated 1,300 tons of gold slated for sale in the next five years. The first portion of 120 metric tons is equal to 3 percent of last year's world demand. The Swiss National Bank will divest itself of the gold gradually to to try to avoid depressing prices. Elizabeth Olson

title: An Elegant Haven for Elegant Food
description: ONE way to gauge the vibrancy of a city's restaurant culture is to count the number of three-star or four-star establishments. Like the Dow, however, this approach may yield a false result. It would put Las Vegas in the same league as San Francisco or Chicago. A more reliable measure -- call it the French scale -- is the number of restaurants that deliver good, well-executed food in a civilized atmosphere. They do not want to be hot. They will never develop a scene. In the republic of dining, they constitute the solid, tax-paying, law-abiding bourgeoisie.

title: Tofu Takes to Curry As Onions Take to Browning

title: A Warm Welcome, Good Food and No Foie Gras

Yet the sight of foie gras, once a relatively rare delicacy, proliferating on the menus of corner restaurants in some of the most unlikely neighborhoods strikes me as overkill. Far be it from me to deprive anybody of a slice of fattened liver, but the spread of foie gras seems both a triumph of pretension over modesty and a sign of the increasing homogenization of neighborhoods and restaurants.

title: LAMAR ADVERTISING WILL BUY 3 OTHER BILLBOARD CONCERNS

Buying the closely held Advantage Outdoor Company will add 5,100 displays in Texas. The two other companies whose names were not disclosed will add 1,400 displays and operations in Bridgeport, Conn., and Macon, Ga. The shares of Lamar rose $2.3125 each, to $43.9375. Lamar will pay 2 million to 2.3 million of its Class A shares for Advantage Outdoor, and it will assume as much as $79 million of Advantage Outdoor debt. Lamar operates 140 outdoor advertising companies in 39 states.

title: PUBLIC STORAGE SAYS SHURGARD DECLINES TAKEOVER BID
description: Public Storage Inc., the largest owner of self-storage properties in the United States, said yesterday that its rival, Shurgard Storage Centers Inc., had rejected its takeover offer. Public Storage, based in Glendale, Calif., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it offered to buy Shurgard at a premium to its net asset value, but the company said it had no interest. Shares of Shurgard, which is based in Seattle, fell $1.0625 each, to $24.6875. At that price the company's stock is worth $720 million. Public Storage was unchanged at $22.9375. Public Storage owns or has a stake in 1,323 self-storage properties in 37 states. Shurgard has interests in 380 self-storage properties in the United States and Europe.

title: And Chartreuse Dip?
description: What's new in potato chips? The color blue, a deep purply blue rimmed with lavender, in fact. They are from Olive Oil Potato Chips, which makes delicious crisp chips from potatoes fried in olive oil and seasoned with sea salt and rosemary, black pepper or garlic. The blue chips, made from blue potatoes, have an earthy flavor with hints of celery. Try them with a dip made with a half cup each of mayonnaise and plain yogurt. Add a large stalk of celery grated fine in a food processor, a tablespoon of minced dill and two to three tablespoons of prepared horseradish. This yields one and a half cups of dip, which should be enough for a five-ounce bag of the chips. The chips are $4.95 in many food shops.

description: I HAVE a history of addiction. I have never been able to pass a used-book store without feeling compelled to buy an armload. So I felt very virtuous about my ability to withstand the wiles of the flashy ad campaign staged last year by Alibris, an ambitious online bookseller.

title: When the Foster Care System Forgets Fathers
description: Daniel H. was 3 and Dawn was 4 when their mother took them and disappeared. Her estranged husband, a New York City limousine driver, searched obsessively for his children. He posted rewards, enlisted help from a retired police officer and hired a private detective, all to no avail.

title: Mrs. Clinton Stresses 'First'
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin her television advertising campaign tonight, with a 30-second ad called ''First.'' The campaign is spending $400,000 to buy time for the ad, with two-thirds of the money going upstate. The allocation is the latest sign of the emphasis the Clinton campaign is placing on upstate New York.

title: Hearing the Pulse of Nature Indoors
description: Anyone walking through Central Park to Carnegie Hall on Monday evening would have heard a tumult of bird songs, all gloriously out of time with one another or with the tempos of falling petals and shivering leaves. The ''pulse of nature'' belongs to the world of metaphor, but it was a metaphor vividly evoked inside the hall, when Wolfgang Sawallisch conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in Sibelius's Seventh Symphony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSAO, JOSEPHINE
description: TSAO-Josephine, C.P., age 39, died peacefully on Wednesday, April 26, 2000 at the University of Pennsylvannia Hospital in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania after a courageous battle with cancer. A native of Michigan, Josie held a B.A. in economics from the University of Michigan and a J.D. from the University of Michigan Law School. After moving to New York following law school, she became a specialist in executive compensation and employee benefits, with emphasis on compensation and benefits issues in mergers and acquisitions. She was an attorney at the law firms of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; was Vice President, Executive/International Compensation and Benefits, at J.P. Morgan; and finally, she served since September 1996 at IBM Vice President, Compensation and Benefits, at corporate headquarters in Armonk, NY. Josie was a member of the American Bar Association, the Conference Board Council on Execuitve Compensation, and the Cato Institute Project on Social Security Privatization Business Council. Josie is survived by her husband, Michael S. Katzke of New York, NY; her parents, Chia Kuei and Ying Lan Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; three siblings, Anna Tsao of Bowie, MD; Marilyn Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; and John Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; and by three nieces and three nephews. A memorial service and burial was held on Sunday, April 30 in Ann Arbor, MI. The family asks that remembrances be made in the form of donations to the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Metro New York, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, NY 11050, Phone: 516-944-6212.

title: Blithe on the Surface, Cerebral Deep Down
description: Trisha Brown's triumph at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last June with Monteverdi's ''Orfeo'' (she directed and choreographed the opera) has been followed up by a veritable creative jag.

description: The Cable Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission blamed Time Warner Cable yesterday for cutting off ABC television stations to 3.5 million subscribers, declaring that Time Warner's action had violated a federal regulation.

title: CASTLE HARLAN ACQUIRES GRAVOGRAPH FOR $100 MILLION
description: Castle Harlan Inc., a merchant bank, has bought Gravograph Industrie International S.A., a French maker of manual and computer engraving machines, from the closely held Financiere St. Luc for about $100 million in cash. Gravograph, which has plants in Troyes, France, and Atlanta, had $95 million in sales last year. Its 650 employees produce engraving machines and software under the Gravograph and New Hermes brands. Castle Harlan Partners III, a $630 million private-equity investment fund, completed the purchase last Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRINBERG, JANE FISHMAN
description: GRINBERG-Jane Fishman. Beloved wife of Efraim Grinberg, cherished mother of Margot and Sam. Beloved daughter of Annabelle and Bernard Fishman. Daughter-in-law of Sonia and Gedalio Grinberg. Sister of Mark and Jill Fishman, and Susan and David Kohen. Sister-in-law to Miriam and David Phalen, and Alex Grinberg. Jane was one of the most special people who was loved by everyone she touched. She gave so much of herself and never asked for anything in return. Funeral services Friday, May 5, 2000, 10:30 AM in Temple Sholom, 300 E. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. Interment May 5, 2000, 3:30 PM in Haym Solomon Memorial Park, Frazer, PA. The family requests that donations be made to the Jane F. Grinberg Breast Cancer Research Fund, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, New York, NY 10029.

title: College Education Seen as Essential
description: In a shift that experts attribute to the changing economy, higher education is increasingly seen as the ticket to the middle class, with 87 percent of Americans saying ''a college education has become as important as a high school diploma used to be,'' a new study has found.

title: A Chance for Better Primaries
description: In both the Republican and Democratic parties, the presidential primaries this year were intense, competitive and, as a practical matter, over very quickly. Especially on the Republican side, there was a feeling that a more leisurely schedule would have given voters a better chance to think about the dramatic contrasts in style and message presented by Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain. Now, a Republican Party commission led by Bill Brock, a former senator and party chairman, has put forward a plan to slow down the primary season so that it is more likely to last a full four months. This is a sound plan that ought to be adopted by the Republican National Convention this summer and copied by the Democrats, as well.

title: Giving Girls the Grace to Leave the Ground
description: I'LL show you the fun part, just 'cause it's fun,'' Abby Rosin, the dance teacher who's just gotten an award for her work with kids and who sounds like a kid herself, is saying.

title: Federal Regulators Give Approval to Viacom's Buyout of CBS
description: Federal officials today approved the largest broadcast merger in history -- Viacom's $30 billion acquisition of CBS -- just a day after two other media giants resolved a dispute that was, in large part, a byproduct of consolidation in the broadcasting and cable industry.

title: Birthrate Dips in Ex-Communist Countries
description: The collapse of Communism in 1989 produced a sharp drop in the fertility rate throughout Eastern and Central Europe that could reduce the region's population nearly 20 percent by the year 2050, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: Khannouchi Exit Leaves Blame for All
description: His legs overruling his heart a day after he became an American citizen, Khalid Khannouchi announced yesterday that he was too injured to compete in the Olympic marathon trials on Sunday in Pittsburgh.

title: Corrections

The lawyer is Joseph M. Alioto.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: Census Bureau Says Minorities' Replies Lift Response Rate
description: Helped by a surprisingly strong response from Hispanics and other minorities, the Census Bureau has halted a long slide in response rates and received answers from nearly two-thirds of the households that got a census form in the mail this year.

title: AGCO WILL CLOSE MISSOURI PLANT AND DISMISS WORKERS
description: The Agco Corporation, the farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would close its plant in Independence, Mo., and dismiss about 500 workers, or 5 percent of its work force, because of a decline in demand for farm equipment. The company, the maker of Massey Ferguson equipment, said it would take a charge of about $20 million to close the plant, which is expected to cut production costs by about $10 million a year. Manufacturing will be moved to Agco's plant in Hesston, Kan., or will be contracted to third-party manufacturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ELSIE
description: WIENER-Elsie. Oakland, CA. April 30, at 93. Born in Brooklyn, one year after her family immigrated from Mogilev, Russia, she lived in Brownsville with them behind her parents' candy store. Educated at City College, worked for the NYC Board of Education. Lived in Astoria and then Forest Hills. A member of the Brandeis Club, she and her husband, Philip L. Wiener, moved to CA. to be near their children and grandchildren. In the last years of her life, her wit revealed itself and kept us all in stitches. We are grateful that we had her with us and wish it had been longer. Survived by her sister, Lillian Gordon of Oakland, CA, children, Elizabeth Wiener of Oakland, Deborah Wiener, son-in-law W. Daniel Boone, grandchildren, Sarah and David of Berkeley, CA. Donations may be made in her name to VNA/Hospice Foundation, 1900 Powell St, Suite 300, Emeryville, CA. 94608.

title: Economic Scene; Changes in the earned-income tax credit are a success in the effort to fix welfare, but there's room for improvement.
description: THE 1990's began with a burst of intellectual and political energy in support of genuine welfare reform. By the beginning of the decade mainstream political opinion had finally coalesced around the idea that the welfare system based on Aid to Families With Dependent Children -- cash payments to nonworking single mothers -- was a failure. Welfare recipients remained very poor, the incentives the system gave them were horrible, and the lessons implicitly taught about responsibility and opportunity were destructive.

title: The East Meets the West With Jagr's Maneuvers
description: Both of his goals were nice, each in its own way, but neither was the best play of Jaromir Jagr's performance. His singular moment came on his assist -- what an assist! -- against the Philadelphia Flyers Tuesday night in Game 3 of the Pittsburgh Penguins' second-round series of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

There is one under the weather map, another on the masthead, still more at the top of the business and local sections.

description: A top Consolidated Edison official said today that the radioactive leak at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in February might have been avoided if the plant's most recent inspection had employed the kind of advanced technology that was available but not yet widely used by the industry.

title: Brokers Find a Niche Escorting Novices Into the World of eBay
description: LIZ PARELLA had a big problem. She needed to sell a Baldwin baby grand piano that was taking up too much space in her Manhattan apartment. She got in touch with an antiques dealer, but the dealer offered her only $1,000, far less than what she thought the piano was worth.

title: BRUNSWICK TECHNOLOGIES REJECTS TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Brunswick Technologies Inc., a maker of industrial and construction materials, rejected a $45.9 million takeover offer from Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest building-materials distributor. Brunswick said the $8-a-share offer, which was made last month by the Vetrotex CertainTeed Corporation, a unit of Saint-Gobain, undervalues the company and said it would immediately begin exploring other options to improve shareholder value. Brunswick's composite materials are used in boat, snowboard, railcar and offshore oil and gas production. Shares of the company, which is based in Brunswick, Me., rose 12.5 cents, to $8.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, GAIL COHEN
description: EDELMAN-Gail Cohen. 55, of Brooklyn, NY. Died on May 2, 2000 of complications from Multiple Myeloma. Survived by her husband Marvin, son Gabriel, daughter Aliza and fiance Sean Ross, father-in-law Mayer Edelman and sisters-in-law Susan Robbins and Betty Bennett. Also survived by her dear nephews, nieces and cousins and numerous friends. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Pratt Institute, she was an accomplished artist. Since 1972, Gail was a Professor of Art at Suffolk County Community College. A scholarship will be set up at Suffolk County Community College in her memory. Other memorial gifts may be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 2120 Stanley Hills Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90046. Funeral services will be held at Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway Brooklyn on Friday at 1:00pm.

description: President Clinton visited an elementary school here today to read ''Charlotte's Web'' with fourth graders and promote his latest plan to help states turn around failing schools.

description: Interest rates shot higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported that wages were rising across the country and investors wondered if that news would make the central bank more aggressive in its effort to slow economic growth.

description: SOLDIER OF FORTUNE does not simply push the envelope for computer-game violence. It seals the envelope, stamps it and posts it, then empties a clip into the mailbox for good measure.

description: In a fierce speech transmitted around the world, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today told American diplomats that protecting the nation's secrets was at the core of their mission and warned that enemies abounded even in a post-cold-war world.

title: American Topics : Court-Ordered Shame Makes a Comeback
description: Rebecca Escobar, who killed a woman in a drunken-driving accident, was sentenced to walk around the county courthouse in Wilkesboro, North Carolina, one day a month, holding a sign that reads, "I am a convicted drunk driver, and as a result I took a life." Richard Gorosh, a Michigan podiatrist convicted of health-care fraud, was ordered to advertise his guilty plea in two newspapers. In several cities, officials place derogatory signs before decrepit buildings to embarrass slumlords.

title: F.D.A. Says Researchers Failed to Report a Second Death Linked to Gene Therapy
description: Researchers at St. Elizabeth's Medical Center here failed to report the death of a patient in gene therapy experiments and might have contributed to the growth of cancer in another patient, whose condition was also reported improperly, investigators for the Food and Drug Administration have said.

description: KILROE-Marjorie. The Alumnae Association of the Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing, Inc., mourns the loss of its President, Marjorie Kilroe, Class of 1955, who died on May 2, 2000.

description: A powerful laser developed by Israel and the United States to shoot down rockets has passed its first test at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico, hitting a stationary target, American military officials said this week.

description: The coffins of livery-cab drivers, shipped back to this country from from New York nearly once a week during the city's recent spate of killings, have badly shaken this poor mountain town of 55,000, which for decades has sent its young men to drive the streets of New York in pursuit of a decent, if dangerous wage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, DAVID
description: MAHONEY-David. The faculty and staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of our esteemed friend, David Mahoney. Recognized throughout the country as an outstanding business leader and visionary in the field of Neuroscience, he had a profound influence in advancing brain research. His many outstanding contributions to medical education, research, and practice include his generous support of the David Mahoney Center for Brain and Behavior Research at Columbia University which is investigating the link between the molecular workings of brain cells and human cognition. A longtime friend and benefactor, he will be missed and his memory cherished. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Hildegarde, and the rest of the Mahoney family. Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Interim Dean for Clinical and Educational Affairs, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, David I. Hirsh, Ph.D., Interim Dean for Research, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO, New York-Presbyterian Hospital

description: Cardinal John O'Connor, the archbishop of the New York archdiocese's 2.37 million Catholics and the Vatican's most forceful spokesman in the United States, died last night at his residence around the corner from St. Patrick's Cathedral. He was 80 years old.

title: Mining the Show House, Where the Ideas Are Worth The Price of the Ticket
description: SURE, decorators are selling luxury,'' the designer Mario Buatta said. ''But for most visitors, a show house is like a reference library of terrific ideas.'' His distinctive style can be seen in an oval sitting room at the Kips Bay Decorator Show House (at 1 East 94th Street through May 21). In fact, visiting a show house is like visiting a think tank for design professionals like Charles Spada, a Boston decorator whose off-white study is also featured at Kips Bay. ''People should go to a show house to be inspired and to take ideas away with them,'' Mr. Spada said. So visit with pencil and paper in hand (and $20 for the price of a ticket) or try any of these 10 ideas -- and some less expensive sources -- from the 28th Kips Bay Show House.

Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: ELECTRONICS BOUTIQUE WITHDRAWS FROM FUNCO BIDDING
description: The Electronics Boutique Holdings Corporation, a video game retailer, said yesterday that it would not increase its offer of $21 a share, a total of $135 million, to buy the rival Funco Inc. The bid was topped last week by the Babbage's Etc. unit of Barnes & Noble, which agreed to pay $24.75 a share, or $161.5 million. The bidding war started in early April, when Funco of Eden Prairie, Minn., agreed to be acquired by Electronics Boutique of West Chester, Pa., for $17.50 a share. Barnes & Noble, based in New York, followed with an unsolicited bid of $135 million, an offer Electronics Boutique matched. Electronics Boutique had until yesterday to increase its offer.

title: HANOVER BUYING APPLIED PROCESS SOLUTIONS
description: The Hanover Compressor Company, which compresses natural gas to make it easier to ship and store, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Applied Process Solutions Inc., a maker of equipment for processing oil and gas, for about $67.5 million in stock. Hanover said it was expanding into gas processing, which removes impurities and other debris that come up from a well with gas, to attract more customers. Applied Process Solutions, based in Tulsa, Okla., works in North America, Europe and Asia. Applied Process Solutions expects about $95 million in sales this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMADA, DOROTHY
description: HAMADA-Dorothy, (nee Fleischmann). Died May 1, 2000 at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Edwin Hamada & Roslyn (Barry) Gore, grandmother of Adam (Kathy) Hamada, Jill Hamada, Audrey (Sean) Jacobs, Wendy (Bradley) Gordon, Matthew Hamada & Nikelle Hamada. Dear sister of the late Rose Wenig Bernard Fleischmann. Adored aunt, cousin and friend to many. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and Lauderdale Lakes, FL. ''Dotty'' worked alongside her husband, Joe, at Allied Button Corp. & ABC Button Co in N.Y.C., which they owned until their retirement in 1973. She inspired all who know her & will live in the hearts of her family and friends forever. Services were held May 3. Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ for information.

title: The King Of the Mile
description: The photograph is wedged into a corner above the fireplace. It is unlike the other framed items in Hicham el-Guerrouj's room, the autographs of 16 other men who have held the world record in the mile, the magazine cover proclaiming him the mile's new king, the fist-pumping joy at winning his second world championship in the metric mile. These are all tokens of victory. What el-Guerrouj keeps on equally prominent display is a reminder of forlorn defeat.

title: Spencer's Bat Takes Cone And Yanks Off the Hook
description: Among the quiet words Don Zimmer muttered to the manager sitting next to him in the Yankees' dugout tonight was a prediction: Shane Spencer will hit a home run, Zimmer told Joe Torre. It was Spencer's swing that made him feel this way.

title: Crown Heights Verdicts Challenged in Appeal
description: Lawyers for two men convicted in the death of a Hasidic scholar during the 1991 mob violence in Crown Heights challenged the verdict yesterday, questioning the trial judge's role in jury selection and the constitutionality of the federal law used to convict their clients.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; AZTECA IN PACT WITH NBC
description: Mexico's second-largest broadcaster, TV Azteca, and the NBC unit of the General Electric Company have dropped three-year-old suits charging breach of contract. TV Azteca agreed to pay NBC $46.2 million, while NBC will buy a 1 percent stake in TV Azteca, worth $26.2 million. NBC also agreed to invest in the Internet company Todito.com, which is 50 percent owned by TV Azteca. TV Azteca had accused NBC of failing to provide programming and management assistance agreed to in a three-year contract signed in 1994, while NBC said that TV Azteca never paid for programming it did receive. Dan Fineren (NYT)

Farmer was a kid from Atlantic City, a 17-year-old who mumbled so badly you could never be sure what he was saying. description: ''Come and have a go if you think you're hard enough'' is a popular taunt dispatched by English football fans. Oasis took the chant to heart on Monday at Radio City Music Hall, displaying a stalwart machismo that belied the band's failed conquest of the United States.

title: MetroStars Trade Joseph to Columbus
description: Miles Joseph, a midfielder who was one of the last original members of the MetroStars, was traded to the Columbus Crew yesterday for a second-round draft pick next year.

title: DOUBTS ON BAAN FINANCING
description: The shares of the unprofitable Dutch software maker Baan N.V. fell on concern that the company may not get 150 million euros ($135 million) in equity financing promised by the investment bank Bear Stearns & Company. Under the weight of seven straight quarterly losses, Baan agreed in March to sell shares to Bear Stearns over 18 months. But the company may have fallen below the unspecified minimum market price in the agreement.

title: Option Price Cut At Barnesandnoble
description: Having suffered a 70 percent drop in its stock price, Barnesandnoble.com halved the cost of nearly six million employee options earlier this year.

title: Devils Carry Play, but Leafs Carry the Day
description: Just when it appeared that the Devils and the Maple Leafs would be going into overtime, Tomas Kaberle of Toronto found himself alone with the puck on top of the left circle in the Devils' zone. Left without any pressure and with a crowd in front of Martin Brodeur, Kaberle fired a blistering shot that puckered the net with 1 minute 35 seconds left in the game to give the Leafs a 3-2 triumph tonight, tying the Eastern Conference semifinal series at two games apiece.

title: Sierra Leone Insurgents Kill 7 In U.N. Force and Capture 49
description: A United Nations attempt to take charge of security in the West African country of Sierra Leone has exploded in violence, with rebels killing seven peacekeepers, all Kenyans, and taking hostage at least 49 other peacekeepers and civilians, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUIDO, ANTOINETTE
description: GUIDO-Antoinette (nee Tuzza). On April 26, 2000 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Vincent C. Guido. She is survived by a son, Laurance J. Guido, MD, a daughter-in-law, Jane S. Guido, a granddaughter, Pia G. Murphy, a grandson, Laurance J. Guido, Jr., all of New York City, and a dear companion, Eva Edwards of Bridgeport, CT. A true feminist well before her time, she earned an undergraduate degree at CCNY and a Masters in Education at Hunter College. She worked as a teacher in the NYC Public School system for almost half a century. She was also a full time mother. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University on Sunday, May 7, 2000 at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name would be appreciated: Columbia College Annual Fund, Class of 1965, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 917, NY, NY 10115, att: D. Wittner.

title: If You Kibitz, Can You Spot the Pros and Amateurs?
description: Suppose that you are an experienced player and you wander into Honors Club in Manhattan while a pro-am event is in progress. Each of the 58 partnerships consists of one expert, perhaps a national champion, and one relatively inexperienced player, perhaps a near-beginner. If you sit and kibitz at a table with four players you do not know, you should quickly be able to determine which two players are the experts.

title: School Districts Given Option for Extra Summer Students
description: The Board of Education plans to allow each of the city's local school districts to decide whether to open its summer school program to students from private and parochial schools or to public-school students who want extra instruction, Harold O. Levy, the interim schools chancellor, said yesterday.

description: A seven-member committee met yesterday in Dallas to pick a new 15-member team to represent the United States in women's softball at the Sydney Olympics after a successful challenge to the selection process.

title: National News Briefs; Marines to Resume Osprey Test Flights
description: The Marine Corps will resume test flights of the V-22 Osprey airplane, though it has not yet determined the precise cause of the Osprey crash last month in Arizona, which killed 19 soldiers, a Marine spokesman said today.

title: Behind Korea Meeting, a Million Troops in a Standoff
description: For American and South Korean soldiers stationed in the demilitarized zone that divides the two Koreas, days begin with a blast of martial music and Communist propaganda blaring from gigantic loudspeakers that North Korea has erected just across the heavily fortified border.

title: WILLIAMS WILL PAY $150 MILLION FOR NATURAL GAS PLANT
description: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to pay Columbia Energy Group $150 million for its Cove Point liquefied natural gas plant in Lusby, Md. In the transaction, Williams will receive the largest liquefied natural gas import site in the United States, as well as 87 miles of pipeline that the company intends to connect to its Transco pipeline system. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., owns and operates a natural gas pipeline system and a fiber optic communications business that uses the pipeline system's rights of way. It had revenue of $8.59 billion in 1999.

title: Proposal to Shake Up the Primaries Is Met With Scrutiny and Skepticism
description: When Republican leaders proposed scrapping the current presidential nominating system, they immediately confronted a series of questions, ranging from their motives to their chance of success to whether their new idea would work as they hoped -- or at least work better than the system they wanted to replace.

description: HIS brilliantly colored asymmetrical vases, drunken decanters and hand-glazed tile coffee tables have become eminently collectible. Galleries in Europe and New York show his whimsically humanoid sculptures. He receives large-scale public commissions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about an effort by the heavy-metal band Metallica to prevent 335,000 fans from using Napster, a service for sharing music collections over the Internet, misspelled the surname of a band member. He is James Hetfield, not Hatfield.

title: Mexico's Biggest Bank Enters Contest to Acquire No. 2
description: Mexico's largest financial group, Banacci, said today that it had begun merger talks with Bancomer, the country's second-largest financial group, raising questions about the anticipated takeover of Bancomer by a Spanish financial group.
