description: It was a spellbindingly intense and brutal performance, and the concert hadn't even begun. Slipknot, an explosive rock nonet from Des Moines, was seething in a large holding room backstage at the Live Oak Civic Center just outside the city, warming up like a football team psyching itself for a particularly fierce playoff game.

title: DeVito/Verdi Hired By TheStreet.com
description: TheStreet.com in New York, which operates a financial and business news Web site, has named DeVito/ Verdi in New York to handle its account, executives involved in the selection said yesterday. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Snowmobiles and Bison
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhythms From a Railway, Fireworks From a Clay Jar
description: Indian drummers need more than just fast hands. They also need prodigious memories to hold complex compositions and the system of rhythmic cycles that underlies classical improvisation, quick tongues to vocalize the percussive syllables they play and an ear for the remarkable tones and timbres they draw from instruments as basic as a hand drum or a clay jar. At Town Hall on Saturday night, the tabla master Zakir Hussain and six other Indian percussionists harnessed all those skills for a concert of spectacular rhythmic fireworks.

title: Missile Defense, Then and Now
description: As President Bill Clinton prepares to decide whether to deploy a ballistic missile defense system or to wait for further testing to be completed, it may be useful to recall the history that has brought us to this point.

title: Group Invests in Real Estate Software
description: A group led by the Dallas buyout firm of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst said yesterday that it had invested $140 million to merge four companies that make software for real estate agents.

title: Jabs Fly in Presidential Ring Over Social Security's Future
description: In a sharp exchange that gave the presidential campaign the intensity of a day in late October, Vice President Al Gore accused Gov. George W. Bush today of devising a ''secret plan'' that could bankrupt the Social Security system. Hours later, Mr. Bush tartly questioned the vice president's honesty and predicted that Mr. Gore's attacking style would soon backfire.

title: Haute Sackcloth Hits Russia
description: Andrei Dmitriev says he is on a crusade to bring taste and style to Russian interior design. And in a move away from the usual Russian tendency toward overkill, he gutted a former printing house at the Russian Academy of Sciences to create a fashionable restaurant named Restoran. He removed the glass from some of the 18th-century mirrors, upholstered the furniture with sackcloth and covered the cavernous vaulted ceiling and walls with several layers of plaster -- but left them unpainted.

title: Testimony Clouds Proposal By Hearst to Buy Chronicle
description: San Francisco's two daily newspapers have made their names and reputations covering the sometimes arcane and often vindictive power struggles of their city, whose political fault zones have made the most commonplace business interactions unstable. Now the newspapers themselves have become front-page news.

title: Hospital Submitted No DNA So Rape Count Is Dropped
description: Anthony Jones was defiant last summer when the police arrested him and accused him of beating and raping a woman underneath the Coney Island Boardwalk. He spit at the officers, they said; he threw punches. It took six officers from the 60th Precinct to get him under control. Mr. Jones told them he knew nothing about the attack.

title: Microsoft Executive Decides To Make a Leave Permanent
description: Nathan P. Myhrvold, the chief technology officer of the Microsoft Corporation, announced his departure yesterday, joining a wave of executives and senior engineers who have left the company in the last year.

title: Murdoch Daughter Leaving Sky Broadcasting
description: The daughter of Rupert Murdoch, Elisabeth Murdoch, said today that she would quit the company her father controls, British Sky Broadcasting, at the end of June to start her own media venture here.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: May 4, 2000 The Dynamic Duo

title: Levity Prevails as Awards Are Handed to Magazines
description: The last year has not been the smoothest for the magazine industry. Publishers have been concerned that newsstand consolidation would slow sales. The Postal Service has proposed a significant increase in magazine mailing rates. Life, Mirabella and New Woman were closed. Details is on hiatus. And the future of some notable new magazines -- Talk; O: The Oprah Magazine; and Real Simple -- is not yet clear.

title: A Modern Masterpiece Becomes Child's Play
description: THEY hate Starbucks and the Gap, love flea markets and a good adventure, buy everything vintage except socks and underwear, own at least 8,000 books, and have collected 500 chairs and thousands of other Modernist artifacts. Now, with all their booty in tow, they're moving to New York from the San Francisco Bay Area to take up residence in a nine-story house that may be Manhattan's most eccentric and uninhabitable. They're the Boyds -- Michael, 40; Gabrielle, 35; Sam, 9; and Henry, 5 -- and they're as single-minded and iconoclastic as the dwelling they've just bought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESNIN, SONIA
description: CHESNIN-Sonia. Lincoln Square Synagogue mourns the passing of Mrs. Sonia Chesnin, Past President of our Sisterhood, a founding member of the Synagogue and former Trustee. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: TRIAL OF 2 ACCUSED IN PAN AM BOMBING FINALLY UNDER WAY
description: Nearly 12 years after a jumbo jet blew up in the skies of Scotland, raining bodies and flaming debris on the village of Lockerbie, the trial of two Libyans accused of planting a bomb on the plane got under way here today.

description: The day began as it always does in Mrs. Wetherbee's third-grade class at Willow Creek Elementary School, and it proceeded routinely, from the Pledge of Allegiance through reading, writing exercises, math, science, geography and phys ed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, GEORGE S.
description: MOORE-George S., 95, former Chairman and CEO of Citibank (now Citicorp), died April 21, 2000 at his home in Sotogrande, Spain. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:45AM, Monday, May 22nd at St. Vincent Ferrer's, 66th Street & Lexington Avenue, New York, NY.

description: Preparations for the Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, will take the United States women's national team to Europe for games in Germany and Norway.

Deborah Tascone, R.N., M.S., Executive Director Alan Mensch, M.D., Med Director Bruce Kappel, M.D., President, Medical/Dental Staff Jeffrey Haberman, M.D., President Elect, Medical/Dental Staff North Shore University Hospital at Plainview

description: The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges announced plans today for a merger as well as an alliance with the technology-heavy Nasdaq stock market of the United States. London and Frankfurt hope to build a pan-European trading heavyweight and a 24-hour global market in new-economy stocks -- both unthinkable prospects only a few years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKHOUT, F. CLAY
description: BUCKHOUT-F. Clay. On May 3, at Lexington, MA. Beloved husband of the late Martha Morgan; father of Anne Chase, of Wayland, MA, and Constance Poillon, of Cos Cob, CT. Also survived by nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, May 6 at 11AM at St. Francis Chapel, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHHAUSER, JERRY
description: HOCHHAUSER-Jerry. The Young Israel of West Hempstead mourns the loss of its beloved member, Jerry Hochhauser, husband of Renee and father of Laura, Adam, Richie, Seth and Kevin. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Paul M. Reinstein, President

title: Rowe Resigns as the Top Executive of the Nets
description: Michael Rowe resigned as president of the Nets yesterday and accepted a reassignment to the project the franchise hopes will result in a state-of-the-art arena in Newark for the 2003-4 season. Rowe, the Nets' president since 1995, will serve in a currently unspecified position with Newark Sports and Entertainment, a subsidiary of YankeeNets, on which Rowe is a board member.

description: WEINSTEIN-Abe Missing you and loving you. Your Girl

title: Disney Reports 66% Increase in Profit
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that profit in its most recent quarter had risen 66 percent because of higher advertising sales at the ABC television division.

title: Museum Sees Business as Usual In Strike but Halts Fund-Raiser
description: Officials at the Museum of Modern Art said yesterday that a strike by a union representing 260 workers has failed to turn away visitors, but it has had one noteworthy effect: it caused the museum to postpone a fund-raiser this week starring the singer Sheryl Crow.

title: A.D.P. TO BUY CUNNINGHAM GRAPHICS FOR $127 MILLION
description: The printing company Cunningham Graphics International Inc. agreed yesterday to be bought for $22 a share, a total of $127.6 million, by the payroll processor Automatic Data Processing Inc. The offer was for less than Cunningham Graphics' stock price on Tuesday, and the shares fell 50 cents each, to $22. Cunningham Graphics, based in Jersey City, provides printing services to financial companies. It has 1,300 employees in 18 production sites worldwide, and had $110.7 million in revenue last year. A.D.P., based in Roseland, N.J., had $4.56 billion in revenue in the nine months that ended on March 31. Its stock was down $1.0625 a share at $52.125.

title: Commission's Secretary-General and Spokesman Demoted to New Jobs : Prodi Shakes Up EU Executive Staff
description: BRUSSELS  The president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, announced a major shake-up Wednesday of senior staff members and the demotion of the commission's highest-ranking civil servant.

title: The Jets and Mo Lewis Agree To a Contract of One Year
description: In a move that gets one of the Jets' most important players into the fold, linebacker Mo Lewis accepted the current one-year tender for a franchise linebacker -- which is worth $4.187 million -- while negotiations will continue toward a long-term deal.

title: Night of the Living D.S.L.
description: JONATHAN TELLER resorted to an appeal to the chairman of Bell Atlantic. Denise Klarquist lost her telephone service entirely. Bill Hipps sent letters to his local newspaper. For weeks James Williams couldn't figure out why he was dropped at precisely the same time every night.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nasdaq takes another step toward its goal of global round-the-clock stock trading.
description: THE Nasdaq stock market took another step toward its goal of worldwide, round-the-clock trading yesterday with an alliance that is sure to intensify the already fierce competition between the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Ready to Remove Vieques Protesters
description: Backed by three warships reported to be carrying hundreds of marines, the Justice Department is ready to sweep into the Puerto Rican island of Vieques and remove demonstrators who oppose American military training there. Senior administration officials said today that the action could come as early as dawn on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SHEILA
description: SOLOMON-Sheila. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Sheila Solomon, and offer their deepest sympathy to her husband Michael, her children and the entire Solomon family. Alpine Country Club Harvey Nagin President

title: Metro Matters; An Aspiration Devoutly To Be Wished?
description: HAROLD O. LEVY, the interim schools chancellor, wants to elevate the level of discourse at the Board of Education. He wants the seven board members and others who toil in the school system to get culture. Study the universe. Appreciate music. Read poetry.

title: Cardinal John O'Connor
description: Cardinal John O'Connor, who died yesterday after 16 years as the voice of American Catholicism, was a strong-willed, conservative theologian whose views were tempered with a pastoral concern for the sick, the weak and the poor. For the two million Roman Catholics in the New York Archdiocese, the cardinal brought a return to a rigorous traditional Catholicism. He passionately opposed abortion, birth control, homosexuality, the ordination of women and even baseball on Good Friday. Such views stirred controversy among many New Yorkers and even some of his own parishioners, but he balanced them with a plea for those in need, even when the needy were at odds with his strong Catholic message.

title: AIR CANADA NARROWS LOSS
description: Air Canada posted a 16 percent gain in revenue to 1.6 billion Canadian dollars in the first quarter and trimmed its operating loss by two-thirds, to 5 million Canadian dollars. The Montreal-based airline's net loss was 34 million Canadian dollars, or 28 Canadian cents a share, compared with a loss of 6 million Canadian dollars, or 3 cents, a year earlier. The 1999 result includes a one-time gain of 39 million Canadian dollars. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: One Killed and One Hospitalized When Garage Collapses in Bronx
description: One man was killed and another was injured yesterday when a garage in the Bronx collapsed, showering them with concrete and bricks, Fire Department officials said.

title: Polaroid Account Is Consolidating
description: The Polaroid Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., has consolidated its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $100 million, at units of the B Com3 Group in Chicago.

title: New Video Game Glasses Do Your Blinking for You
description: Inveterate video game players now crave the kind of hard-edged realism you can find only by sitting in your parents' basement, staring at a monitor. Elsa Technologies has tried to introduce another dimension into the video game experience with the 3-D Revelator. The glasses use L.C.D. shutters that open and close over alternating eyes 120 times per second. That creates the mental effect of seeing the video image from two angles. (Otherwise the imageappears out of register.)

title: Both Friends and Critics of the Cardinal Recall His Courage and Devotion to Duty
description: As word spread late last night that Cardinal John O'Connor's protracted struggle with brain cancer had ended in his death, New Yorkers bid silent farewells to the controversial, ever visible archbishop, whose months of suffering had made them pray for his passing.

description: DIGITAL subscriber line service seemed like a minor miracle when it was introduced several years ago. D.S.L. seemed to appear out of nowhere, offering speeds as high as eight million bits per second over existing phone lines.

title: Ambitious Plans for Transit
description: With the first major expansion of the city's transit system since the 1930's set to go forward, this is a promising moment for public transportation in New York. The scheduled projects are a Second Avenue subway on Manhattan's Upper East Side, a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal and extension of a rail line to La Guardia Airport. To build these links, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is embarking on a $17 billion capital program that has been criticized as financially unsound and unduly influenced by Bear Stearns & Company as a financial adviser. The capital plan is important to the region and deserves to go forward. But Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and legislative leaders must take steps to ensure that it does not force undue fare increases in the future, and the M.T.A. should recruit an independent adviser to review the financing scheme and the role of Bear Stearns.

title: Kent's Homer Keeps Mets Skidding
description: The Mets gave three leads to their No. 1 starting pitcher today. They had four runners in scoring position after coming back to tie the score in the seventh inning. They used all but one of their position players -- Mike Piazza even played for the first time since Friday -- and all but two of their relievers.

title: Major Indexes Decline by More Than 2% on Rate Anxieties
description: Stock prices skidded yesterday as investors absorbed more troubling data on the rapid growth of the economy and braced for more such disappointment today and tomorrow.

title: After a Loss, Nassau Republicans Hope Voters' Anger Recedes by November
description: For Nassau Republicans, the problem is not just that they failed to regain control of the County Legislature in the special election that was held in Port Washington on Tuesday. The problem is also how far short of the goal they fell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, BARBARA R.
description: ROTH-Barbara R. Of New York, died on May 1, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Paul G. Roth, her daughter, Alexandra O'Mara and her husband, Kevin O'Mara, and three grandchildren, Nicholas, Ian and Peter O'Mara. Whether as a wife, mother or a friend, her generosity of spirit and love of life provided joy and comfort to all who knew her, from business colleagues to her students in after school literacy classes. She was the center of her family, with an endless capacity for patience and love. In return, she was much loved, and will be much missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LEWIS E.
description: MILLER-Lewis E. Beloved husband of the late Elayne (Terry) & the late Gladys. Devoted father of Alan Miller and the late Loretta Ann; father-in-law of Barbara. Loving grandfather of Terri Ann and Stacy. Dear brother of Dr. Harry, Dr. Newton, Robert and Gertrude. Graveside service 1PM Thursday at Mt Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, HARRY L.
description: KOENIG-Harry L. Esq. Of Lakewood, New Jersey, formerly of New York City, after a long and satisfying legal career died on May 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Edith (nee: Gutman); loving father of Bill, Ben, and Jake; stepfather of Susan Hassman. Devoted brother of Betty Carbone, Rose Rau, Dorothy Shilman and Frieda Faust. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Service will be 1 PM Friday at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, Route 70 and Vermont Avenue, Lakewood, NJ.

title: Liberty Huffs and Puffs at Training Camp
description: New York Liberty players were still talking about ''the shot'' yesterday at the opening of training camp.

title: The Author As Brand Name
description: Will the new Robert Ludlum thriller you'll be reading this summer really be a Robert Ludlum? Well, the book's jacket will have this wordy irruption: ''Robert Ludlum's 'The Hades Factor' by Robert Ludlum and Gayle Lynds.'' Will this be pure Ludlum, or something slightly vitiated? Actually, it will be what is called in the packaging business ''line extension,'' which is the attempt to come up with a variation on a known product to expand the franchise. Is a Ludlum a Ludlum if a Lynds did the writing? No, not really.

title: Harry Newman, 90, Who Led Giants to Title Game as Rookie
description: Harry Newman, who led the 1933 New York Giants to the National Football League's first championship game as an All-Pro quarterback one season after being honored as college football's top player, died Tuesday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 90.

title: TELEFONICA BOARD TO MEET
description: Spain's largest telephone operator, Telefonica, said it would hold a special board meeting to consider a merger with the Dutch telephone company Royal KPN. Executives close to the merger talks said Telefonica was considering paying about $54.4 billion for Royal KPN.

title: Suit by Democrats Attacks Republican's Fund-Raising
description: In a federal lawsuit filed today, Congressional Democrats accused Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip, of engaging in extortion, racketeering and money laundering in his aggressive fund-raising for Republican candidates and causes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EMC CORP., Hopkinton, Mass., the No. 1 maker of computer storage systems, said it would split its stock two shares for one on June 2 to shareholders of record as of May 19.

title: Gannett-ZapMedia Venture Is Planned
description: ZapMedia.com Inc. said this week that it had formed a $270 million partnership with the Gannett Company to provide interactive entertainment. The specific terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: TD WATERHOUSE BUYS DEALWISE, A DISCOUNT BROKER
description: TD Waterhouse Group, the third-largest United States online broker by trading volume, agreed yesterday to buy the British discount broker Dealwise Ltd. for $127.5 million. The New York-based TD Waterhouse said the deal would bring it 230,000 customer accounts, making it the largest discount broker in Britain. The brokerage firm, a subsidiary of Toronto-Dominion Bank of Canada, has completed eight acquisitions in the United States, Canada, Britain, Hong Kong and Australia, as well as joint ventures in Japan and India in the last three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORMONT, RHONDA
description: ORMONT-Rhonda. The members of the Career Development Specialist Network mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague. Carol Feit Lane, President, CDSN

description: Q. I would like to buy a digital camera but I find advertisements with terms like megapixels and resolutions confusing. What kind will take decent pictures?

title: For Business Travelers Who Still Use Paper
description: In an age when gadgets let e-mail and the Web follow people virtually everywhere, a portable fax machine and photocopier seems like a quaint idea. But Dave Faulkner, product manager for Thomson Multimedia, says business travelers are still addicted to paper. And by his calculations, at least, it's a costly habit. ''Most hotel chains throughout the U.S. charge quite a bit of money to make photocopies or send faxes,'' he said. ''It's a premium service.''

title: To Set Art Off From Any Wall
description: IT'S rare to find such a large selection of frames in a neighborhood shop,'' said Monica Rotaru, owner of Gallery 49 in Manhattan. For the last year Ms. Rotaru has had artwork for her gallery framed at Art:asap, a shop at 415 West 50th Street, where she says prices are at least 50 percent lower than at other stores she has tried.

title: At $500,000, Democrats Gala Ticket Tops Record
description: For its annual gala here on May 24, the Democratic Party is offering tickets ranging from an affordable $50 to a platinum price of $500,000, the highest amount either party has charged for admission to a fund-raising gala.

title: Vatican's Selection Method Is Shrouded in Secrecy
description: With the death of Cardinal John O'Connor, the question arises of who will succeed him as New York's ninth archbishop, spiritual head of 2.4 million Roman Catholics.

title: From One Pitcher to Another
description: When David Cone heard Tuesday that San Diego pitcher Woody Williams, his former teammate in Toronto, had developed an aneurysm, he called him and they spoke for 10 minutes.

description: Faced with lawsuits by 31 cities and counties, the nation's gun companies have broken off settlement negotiations, deciding to rely on their chances that state judges will prove sympathetic or that victory in November will go to George W. Bush.

description: ''When elephants fight,'' goes the African proverb, ''it is the grass that suffers.''

description: SOCHRIN-Samuel. Age 89, on May 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Helen for sixty-four years; father of Larry & Phyllis (Paul) Antis; grandfather of Susan (Bruce) Rudin and Sharon (Claude) Deprospo. Great-grandfather of Amanda, Jessica and Erica Rudin. Friend to all.

title: AOL and Coca-Cola Form Partnership
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it signed a multiyear agreement with America Online Inc. to develop online and offline marketing programs. Terms of the agreement, the first worldwide Internet marketing initiative for Coca-Cola, were not disclosed.

title: Cardinal to Lie in State
description: Cardinal John O'Connor's body will lie in state in St. Patrick's Cathedral until the funeral, which will likely be at 2 p.m. Monday, said Joseph Zwilling, the archdiocese spokesman. ''There will be opportunities for public mourning and for people to come and pay their respects,'' he said.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: The Cruelty of Childhood Returns to Haunt Adults
description: ''Spin the Bottle'' takes place in and around a creaky, isolated lakefront house somewhere in the wilds of Vermont. Four childhood friends, now in their late 20's, have been summoned to this lonely spot by another old acquaintance, a mysterious fellow named Jonah (Holter Graham), whom none of them have seen in more than a decade and who suffered hurt and humiliation at their thoughtless young hands.

title: Leafs Shift Plans and It Pays Off
description: Steve Thomas said Toronto's plan was to avoid falling behind the Devils in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference semifinals. After all, Toronto's lone victory came in Game 1, when it scored the first goal.

title: Raul Rettig, Head of Panel On Chile Killings, Dies at 90
description: Raul Rettig, who headed an official inquiry into political atrocities in Chile during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on Sunday at his house in Santiago, Chile. He was 90.

title: Corbis's Archive of Images Will Add Christie's Images
description: Corbis, the image archive company owned by William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, is adding to its collection yet again. The company announced today that it planned to put online thousands of digital images owned by Christie's, the art auction house.

title: Mayor Acknowledges 'Very Good Friend'
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that a woman who has accompanied him on public occasions and has frequently dined with him is ''a good friend, a very good friend.''

title: MANOR CARE SHARES DROP AFTER TAKEOVER REJECTION
description: Manor Care Inc. said yesterday that it would stay independent and publicly owned, two months after the company, a nursing home management concern, announced it was weighing competing offers from a management-led investment group and from its chairman, Stewart Bainum Jr. The decision, which accompanied an earnings report that fell below expectations, sent the company's stock tumbling. The stock closed at $7.50, down $4.625 a share. Manor Care, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, said its board had concluded that no proposal adequately reflected the company's long-term value. Manor Care operates about 300 nursing homes, along with about 200 assisted-living and outpatient facilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JEFFREY SHAINE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODSTUPKA, DOROTHY
description: PODSTUPKA-Dorothy. Died on May 2, 2000 in Driftwood, Texas. Dorothy was preceded in death by her parents, George and Beatrice Ginnis, and her husband, John Podstupka. Dorothy is survived by many cousins and friends who mourn her passing, but will forever hold her in their hearts. Dorothy was a beautiful person with a wonderful sense of humor, a giving heart, and a boundless zest for life. She will be sorely missed. A graveside funeral will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York at 2:30 P.M., Friday, May 5, 2000. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Deborah Hospital Foundation. Each dot represents a ZIP Code inhabited by a youth volunteer for the Streetwise Concepts and Culture street team, a fan volunteer network that assembled over the Internet for grassroots promotion for new rock bands.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's announcement last week that he has prostate cancer has forced undecided voters to look with new eyes at the man whose unyielding personality they thought they knew so well.

description: The Washington Wizards have had an informal conversation with St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis to gauge his interest in their head coaching job, but no formal interview has been arranged, according to a person familiar with the situation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDEL, CLARA
description: HENDEL-Clara, on April 27, 2000 at age 88 in Ann Arbor, Michigan (formerly of Manhattan). She leaves a daughter (Linda) and a son (Stephen), as well as 2 grandchildren (Elizabeth and Michael). She also leaves a loving sister, Beatrice (Lieberman) of Miami Beach, FL. Clara was predeceased by her husband and partner in life, Professor Samuel Hendel, of the City University of New York and Trinity College, who died in 1984. Clara was born in East Hartford, CT., but moved to New York at an early age. She was a New Yorker to her very core, and lived on West End Avenue until 1997, when she moved to Michigan to live near her son and his wife, Margaret. She will be missed by many people for many reasons, but by none more than her son Stephen. Clara was buried on Sunday, April 30, at Montefiore Cemetery next to her husband. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the near future.

title: Inside Slipknot: Music As 'World Domination'
description: Take away the rubber masks, the numbers that its members use instead of names (0 through 8) and the unlikely hometown of Des Moines, and Slipknot is still an impressive band. Live, all nine members are constantly in motion, beating on metallic percussion, scratching records, grinding death-metal guitar riffs, scream-singing, and proving themselves one of the most exciting and enigmatic of rock's current crop of new bands.

description: Like the proverbial rising tide that lifts all boats, the bustling economy that has buoyed activity in New York and New Jersey ports over the last three years has now brought an effort to hire additional longshoremen for the first time in nearly 30 years.

title: YAGEO TO BUY PHILIPS UNITS
description: The Dutch consumer electronics giant Philips Electronics N.V. said it planned to sell two units of its Philips Components division to the Yageo Corporation of Taiwan for $590.7 million. The sale of Philips's discrete and ferrite ceramics businesses includes 13 Philips warehouses and plants.

title: Buying Tupperware Online Lets You Skip the Party
description: Do you covet a Tupperware Egg-ceptional Server set (''a stylish server for deviled eggs and more'') but can't bear the thought of sitting through an actual Tupperware party to buy one? Tupperware now has a Web buying option. With a new service called My.Tupperware.com, you can do business with your neighborhood Tupperware representative while keeping your evenings free.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Friday about a lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against David E. Lipson, a former executive of Supercuts Inc., misstated the outcome. A federal jury found him liable for illegal insider-trading penalities. It was a civil case; Mr. Lipson was not found guilty of any charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERVINGTON, WALTER
description: SHERVINGTON-Walter W., MD. The National Medical Association lost its President, Walter W. Shervington, MD to cancer on Saturday, April 15, 2000. Dr. Shervington, a psychiatrist and hospital administrator in New Orleans, La., was a member of the NMA for over 30 years. He dedicated his career to serving the health care needs of African Americans, and in later years, became an influential national leader in mental health, particularly the mental health aspect of HIV/AIDS. Dr. Shervington is survived by his wife of 19 years Denese McFarlane Shervington, MD, their two daughters Shanga and Iman and two sisters Anne Shervington Davis and Carol Shervington Wright.

title: Revlon's Loss Narrows as Sales Show a Rise
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss had narrowed as sales rose for the first time in almost two years.

title: ASTRAZENECA'S EARNINGS RISE
description: Europe's largest drug company, AstraZeneca P.L.C., said its first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent. Pretax profit jumped to $1.1 billion from $971 million a year earlier. Dr. Thomas F. W. McKillop, the company's chief executive, said, ''The year has started encouragingly.'' But the company's shares fell over concern that the company does not have another blockbuster drug to replace its ulcer drug Losec, which loses its patent next year. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: More U.N. Troops Held
description: The number of United Nations peacekeepers held hostage by rebels in the West African nation of Sierra Leone rose to at least 92, including 23 soldiers from an Indian battalion. Secretary General Kofi Annan flew back to New York from Paris to decide on the next step in the crisis.

title: Mrs. Clinton Attacks Bush on His Proposals to Cut Taxes
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton finished her tour through each of the state's 62 counties today with a sharp attack on George W. Bush's tax cut proposals, leaving her mostly Republican audience in silence.

title: Detected in Asia, Computer Affliction Moved Swiftly and Crippled Big Systems : 'Love' Virus Hits E-Mail Worldwide
description: NEW YORK  An e-mail-based virus devastated computers around the world Thursday, stealing passwords, interrupting communications and destroying files for hundreds of thousands of users from the House of Commons in Britain to Ford Motor Co.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about reactions to the death of Cardinal John O'Connor reversed the phrases in the title of a book he wrote with Mayor Edward I. Koch. It was ''His Eminence and Hizzoner.''

title: Three in a Row For Hartmann
description: Rick Hartmann, who formerly played on the European Tour, two-putted for birdie on a par-5 first extra hole yesterday at the Cold Spring Country Club to defeat Michael Laudien and win the MasterCard Long Island P.G.A. Championship for the third straight year.

description: It is a 25-minute walk from Pacific Bell Park to the Westin St. Francis hotel, and Mike Hampton walked every step of it alone Wednesday night.

description: The news that the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges have agreed to merge is a warning to the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Giuliani Goes New York Native
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to begin broadcasting a 60-second statewide television commercial today called ''A New York Senator.'' The campaign says it is spending ''upwards of six figures'' to buy time for the ad. Mr. Giuliani's campaign advisers say the ad is evidence that the mayor is in the Senate race to stay.

title: Residential Real Estate; Harlem to Add 8 Rental Buildings in City Program
description: Eight vacant or partly occupied city-owned lots in Harlem are to be filled over the next two and half years with 726 mixed-income rental apartments under a new city program.

description: After a roller-coaster two weeks that saw a harsh crackdown on reformists, many Iranians have settled into a watchful uncertainty.

title: Police Union Begins Formal Talks With City
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, whose contract expires July 31, began formal talks with the city's Office of Collective Bargaining yesterday, the union said.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL IS BUYING McWHORTER TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Eastman Chemical Company, the world's biggest maker of plastics used in soda bottles, said yesterday that it was acquiring McWhorter Technologies for about $197 million, or $19.70 a share. It will also assume about $155 million in debt. McWhorter, based in Carpentersville, Ill., produces surface-coating resins and specialty colorants. It reported revenue of $450.9 million for the last 12 months. Shares of McWhorter soared 40 percent, jumping $5.625, to $19.50. The move is part of a strategy by Eastman, based in Kingsport, Tenn., to expand in specialty chemicals, which tend to have higher, more stable profit than bulk chemicals.

title: Foreign Affairs; Yellow Brick Geopolitics
description: Al Gore delivered a provocative foreign policy speech Sunday that raised an important question: Does George W. Bush have the experience, the gravitas and, by implication, the brains to run U.S. foreign policy?

title: WACHOVIA SAYS IT IS SELLING 19 OF ITS 700 BANK BRANCHES
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the third-largest bank in the Southeast, said yesterday that it would sell 19 branches in Virginia and North Carolina to focus on full-service banking in other locations. Wachovia is selling 15 Virginia branches to the F&M National Corporation of Winchester, Va., and 4 branches to Centura Banks of Rocky Mount, N.C. No jobs are expected to be lost, a Wachovia spokesman said. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has more than 700 branches in five states and has been pruning its branch network after buying Jefferson Bankshares and Central Fidelity Banks in 1998.

description: THE next time you step inside the Megacinema Plethoraplex, or whatever your local movie palace is called, you will most likely notice the myriad ways that Hollywood embraces Madison Avenue.

title: Penney Chief to Step Down Earlier Than Anticipated
description: Nearly a year after James E. Oesterreicher vowed to turn around the troubled department store giant J. C. Penney, he announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive earlier than expected and without fulfilling his promise.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NASHUA CORP., Nashua, N.H., an office copy and computer products company, said its shareholders had re-elected its current directors, fending off a challenge by Newcastle Partners, Dallas, an investment group holding about 2 percent of Nashua's stock.

title: SCOTTISH BANK EARNINGS RISE
description: An Edinburgh-based bank Royal Bank of Scotland Group P.L.C., which recently won a bidding war for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said profit rose 33 percent in the first half of the year as a result of Britain's growing economy. The bank said its net income rose to $:444 million, or $693 million, in the first half of the year from $:333 million a year earlier. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said on Tuesday that Kurt Landgraf, chairman and chief executive of its pharmaceutical unit for four months, had resigned after failing to find a major alliance to expand the business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCULLY, CHARLES G.
description: SCULLY-Charles G. Age 74, died suddenly on April 27, 2000 at home in Yonkers, NY. Born in Waldwick, NJ, a veteran of WWII, a sergeant in the U.S. Army serving in India. After the war Charles went into the broadcast industry as general manager and program director at radio station WPAT in Paterson, NJ. He later went to work for radio station WAAT in Newark, NJ as manager and program director. In 1952 he joined SESAC in station relations/PR department and was an executive vice president and director of public relations when he retired in 1992. Charles served on the Board and was a lifetime member of CMA (Country Music Association) and GMA (Gospel Music Association). He also served on the Board of AWRT (American Women in Radio and Television), the National Academy of Popular Music (The Songwriter's Hall of Fame). He was a broadcast pioneer and a long time member of the Friars Club. A deeply caring, kind and compassionate human being, ''Charlie'' shall long be remembered and sorely missed by all those who knew him and were fortunate to have shared in his warmth, wit and loyalty. Survived by his sister, Norma Miller, Lancaster, PA, his brother, Jack Scully, Rio Rancho, NM, several nephews and a niece, and long time dear friend, Fernando Esnarriaga, Yonkers, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice. Condolences may be sent to his family at 42 Inwood Street, Yonkers, NY 10704.

title: Steve Reeves, 74, Whose 'Hercules' Began a Genre
description: Steve Reeves, the bodybuilder turned movie muscleman whose 1959 film ''Hercules'' ushered in a cycle of sword-and-sandal epics, died Monday at the Palomar Medical Center in Escondido, Calif. He was 74 and had become a rancher and fitness guru after retiring from acting three decades ago.

description: Xavier LaBoulenne

title: Marvin L. Stone, 76, Editor
description: Marvin L. Stone, a former editor in chief of U.S. News & World Report and a former deputy director of the United States Information Agency, died on Monday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 76.

title: Sri Lanka Lists Tough New Controls on Speech and Property
description: After a series of humbling military defeats at the hands of Tamil rebels, the government of Sri Lanka, a democracy, has gone on a ''war footing.'' It announced today that authorities would now be able to confiscate private property, shut newspapers and prohibit public meetings, strikes and criticism of the president, if doing so is deemed necessary to the national security.

title: Israel and Guerrillas Exchange Reprisals
description: In reprisal for the fiercest cross-border attack since last June, Israeli warplanes bombarded two power stations and a guerrilla arms depot in Lebanon this morning.

title: By Jove, This Tuscan Sun, It's a Bit Dicey, Eh What?
description: The art critic Harold Rosenberg once remarked, apropos of Stanley Kubrick's ''Barry Lyndon,'' that ''the movies could make their maximum contribution to culture by recycling unread literature.'' In the quarter-century since, certain moviegoers have been treated to enough lavish costumes and exquisite diction to overwhelm every waste-transfer station in the New York metropolitan area.

title: New York's Vanishing Librarians
description: The three public library systems that serve New York City are just recovering from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, which left bookshelves empty, computer systems outdated and library buildings falling to pieces. Now the New York, Brooklyn and Queens library systems face a new problem -- the rapid departure of their professional librarians, who are leaving for better-paying jobs in the suburbs and other cities.

title: Softball Player Is Again Left Off the U.S. Team
description: For the second time in nine months, 15 players and five alternates were named to the United States Olympic women's softball team. For the second time, 31-year-old second baseman Julie Smith was not one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMIS, ESTHER
description: TAMIS-Esther. On May 3, 2000. Devoted wife of the late Jesse. Loving mother of Cliff and Sally, Don and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Stephen, Annie, Karen and Laurie. Private graveside service.

title: HOUSE TRADE BILL FOR THE CARIBBEAN AND AFRICA PASSES
description: The House today decisively approved legislation that grants more than 70 African and Caribbean countries broad new trading privileges by expanding duty-free access to American markets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a prominent composer who was scheduled to conduct a retrospective of his works last night at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan misspelled his surname. He is Sir John Tavener, not Taverner.

title: Spotlight Has Spared The Bush Girls So Far
description: Monday was Decision Day for many high school seniors choosing colleges, but it came and went without so much as a peep from the Bush campaign about the destinations of Gov. George W. Bush's twin 18-year-old daughters, Barbara and Jenna.

title: Lindros Is Injured Again in Workout
description: Even while the Philadelphia Flyers tried to even their second-round playoff series tonight, the focus of the franchise was divided. As the Flyers played the Penguins in Game 4 in the Mellon Arena, much of the conversation around the rink concerned Eric Lindros, Philadelphia's former captain, who has missed the playoffs with concussion symptoms.

title: MERCK IS BUYING PROVANTAGE HEALTH FOR $222 MILLION
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy ProVantage Health Services, a pharmacy benefit management company, for $222 million in cash, or $12.25 a share. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said it would fold ProVantage, based in Waukesha, Wis., into its benefits services unit, Merck-Medco Managed Care. ShopKo Stores, which owns a 65 percent stake in ProVantage, has agreed to sell its holding. ProVantage's stock soared 55 percent, rising $4.25, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Merck's shares fell $1.125, to $67.1875, also on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Metro Business; Car Firm Settles Bias Case
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Toyota Logistics Services, which unloads 150,000 cars a year in Port Newark, have signed a consent decree resolving a lawsuit charging the company with sex and race discrimination in hiring.

title: Bipartisan Commission To Review Education
description: Assembly Speaker Jack Collins announced yesterday that he was forming a bipartisan commission to review state education policies, particularly school financing. He noted that New Jersey had the highest spending rate per student in the country, with most financing coming from property taxes, which are also among the highest in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, EMANUEL
description: GREENBERG-Emanuel (Mannie). Beloved husband and lifetime best friend of Madeline (nee Rosenthal), loving father of David, father-in-law of Abby, grandfather of Jacob and Simon and brother of Saul. WWII Merchant Seaman and active union member. Writer of books and magazine articles about food and drink. Died May 3, 2000 at age 83 after a long and profoundly courageous fight with Parkinsons Disease. We have missed you for so long and will never forget you and your deep love for us. Services Sunday, May 7, 2:30 PM at Congregation Beth Elohim, 8th Ave. and Garfield Pl., Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROSHAK, MARILYN
description: HOROSHAK-Marilyn. On May 3, 2000 at age 64. Beloved wife of Eugene. Loving mother of Jackie Zirkman and Eric Horoshak. She also leaves behind a loving sister Sandra Guttenberg and daughterin-law Lori Horoshak. Funeral Friday, May 5 at ''The Riverside,'' 180 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue. She will be missed.

title: Numbers Add Up to a Sweep for the Giants
description: Twice this series, the benches at Pacific Bell Park emptied. Twice the San Francisco Giants scored six runs in an inning. Twice the Giants' Jeff Kent hit a home run to put a game away. Four times, the Giants beat the Mets.

title: Pataki Outlines Plan for Limits On State's Debt
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today released the details of his plan to restrict the state's ability to borrow, including a provision that would prohibit the state from using borrowed money for anything other than capital projects.

title: Such Good Friends, or So They Thought
description: The dreary ''Into My Heart'' is so willfully naive that one of its heroes picks up a Manhattan waitress -- played by the absurdly beautiful Claire Forlani, who breaks a new series of hearts whenever she bats her lush eyelashes -- the first time he lays eyes on her. Or in this case, eye: Adam (Jake Weber) lost an eye when he was 7, the fault of his best friend, Ben (Rob Morrow), as they played with bottle rockets. And that incident damaged Ben more than it did Adam. ''He's still carrying that around,'' Adam says, amazed. Adam is constantly amazed, as anyone lucky enough to get Nina (Ms. Forlani) should be.

title: All in the Family: Schiller Becomes Steinbrenner's Key Element
description: Harvey Schiller learned football from Al Davis at the Citadel, flew 1,200 support missions in Vietnam and ran the Southeastern Conference, the United States Olympic Committee and Turner Sports.

title: The Lessons of Sierra Leone
description: With one United Nations peacekeeping force under violent attack in Sierra Leone, the international organization moved ahead yesterday with plans to dispatch another to Congo. The juxtaposition clearly suggests a need to improve the planning and execution of such U.N. missions to ensure that peacekeeping forces do not become casualties in the conflicts they are supposed to help end.

description: Two Democratic senators today criticized Vice President Al Gore's approach to Social Security, saying his plan would make the retirement system dependent on general tax revenue.

description: IT sounds like the setup for some bizarre avant-garde reality show: take a dozen or so actors, put them on a bus for four months and see what happens.

title: China Cites Progress On Its Rights Record
description: China told a United Nations human rights panel today that it had made progress in preventing torture and in prosecuting officials suspected of such abuse but conceded that it could do more.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAHONEY, DAVID
description: MAHONEY-David. A memorial service for David Mahoney, Chairman and CEO of the Charles A. Dana Foundation, will be held on Wednesday, May 17, at 11AM at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, 184 East 76th Street (entrance at Lexington Avenue) in New York City. Mr. Mahoney died on May 1, 2000. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard-Mahoney Neuroscience Institute, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St, Boston, MA. 02115

title: Stanton and Nelson Enjoy Status as Setup Men for Rivera
description: Joe Torre reaches to take the baseball from them, but they don't want to share. At that moment on the mound, when the competitive part of their personalities are most evident, Mike Stanton and Jeff Nelson often appear to be barely suppressing fury, the way a frustrated kid does just before flipping a Monopoly board.

title: New York Threatens to Hand Over Its Airports to British Company
description: New York City officials escalated their fight against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday, announcing that they would hire the operator of London's airports to monitor the agency's management of Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, and possibly to take them over.

title: Maryland Banking Deal
description: The Provident Bankshares Corporation, one of Maryland's largest banks, said today that it had agreed to buy Harbor Federal Bancorp Inc. for about $32 million in stock to add nine offices around Baltimore and Annapolis. Provident will pay 1.256 shares, worth about $18, for each share of Baltimore-based Harbor Federal, the owner of Harbor Federal Savings Bank. The shares of Harbor Federal rose $2.375 each, to $16.625, in Nasdaq trading. Provident's shares were unchanged at $14.3125.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a town hall meeting held by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in Rochester referred incorrectly in some copies to his remarks about whether he would seek the endorsement of the Independence Party if Patrick J. Buchanan was its presidential nominee. The mayor said he would ''have to think long and hard,'' adding, ''I probably wouldn't want to be on that ticket.'' He did not explicitly say he would not appear on the ticket with Mr. Buchanan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PETER
description: THOMPSON-Peter, one of New York's leading acting teachers, died April 24th at New York Hospital of complications following heart surgery. Mr. Thompson taught at Circle in the Square, NYU, and the Michael Howard Studios. As an actor, he appeared opposite Jane Alexander, Eva LeGallienne, Sada Thompson and Moses Gunn. He directed plays in New York and numerous regional theaters. Mr. Thompson was born in Carnegie, OK on March 28th, 1935. He received his BFA and MFA from the University of Oklahoma. He is survived by his partner, Bob Cosenza, and his brother, William Thompson of Oklahoma City. A memorial service will be held at the Michael Howard Studios, 152 West 25th St. on Friday, May 19th, at 3 PM.

title: Sprechen Sie Technology?; Europeans Try to Relax Borders for Skilled Workers
description: Eric Perbos-Brinck gave up a promising management career last year at Promodes, the big French retailer, to start an Internet company called Bravonestor.com. He began in November with just 2 people, but already has 10 employees, with plans to hire 5 more in the next few weeks. To fill the jobs, Mr. Perbos-Brinck, 31, casts his net wide. One of his programmers is Moroccan. The designer of search engines is Senegalese. Both were studying in France as exchange students when Mr. Perbos-Brinck found them in a desperate search.

title: Board Member Leaps Into Race For Chancellor
description: The search for a permanent New York City schools chancellor has been thrown into tumult by a last-minute bid for the job by Irving S. Hamer Jr., the Manhattan member of the Board of Education.

title: Panel Suggests Latent TB Testing for Immigrants
description: Though the number of tuberculosis cases in the United States has fallen to an all-time low, a panel of experts called yesterday for renewed efforts to prevent the disease, including screening immigrants for the dormant form of TB and tripling the financing for tuberculosis research.

title: At Libyans' Trial, Lockerbie's View of Horror From Sky
description: A noise that kept growing louder. A dark mass just clearing the rooftops. A fireball like a mushroom cloud. The Flannigans' house not there anymore, replaced by a pile of rubble as high as a kitchen window. Great gouts of fire raining down, the reek of jet fuel, and things lying in the street that, in the light of the flames, slowly became recognizable as bodies.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee prices, down about one-third this year, climbed 2.8 percent in response to a plan by leading producers to restrict exports. In New York, coffee for July delivery was up 2.75 cents, to 99.95 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARNITT, ROY F.
description: BARNITT-Roy F., Jr. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM Sat, May 6 at the Terry Schreiber Studio, 151 W. 26 St, NYC, 7th Flr.

title: Bicoastal Ownership
description: The phrase ''strategic alliances'' has been echoed on the Internet for years, but only in recent weeks has it been heard in the museum world. Last month came the news that the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and the Tate Gallery in London were joining forces to initiate a dot-com business that would run as a separate entity whose profits would be channeled back into the two institutions.

title: CANADIAN CENTRAL BANKER RETIRING
description: The head of Canada's central bank, Gordon Thiessen, 62, said he would retire in January after completing his seven-year term. The Bank of Canada's directors will recommend a successor, but approval rests with the federal cabinet and especially the finance minister, Paul Martin, who said he regretted Mr. Thiessen's decision not to seek reappointment. During Mr. Thiessen's tenure, the central bank has kept Canada's inflation rate within a target range of 1 to 3 percent, but the value of the Canadian dollar has tumbled. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: CUMULUS AND CLEAR CHANNEL TO EXCHANGE RADIO STATIONS

Cumulus, based in Milwaukee, will obtain various stations in Florida, Louisiana, Iowa and Pennsylvania. title: Lessons Learned Not by the Boy but the Father
description: With all the times we've seen or read ''Pinocchio,'' the story of a lovable little wooden marionette who yearns to become a real boy, have we ever given a thought to poor Geppetto? There he is, a lonely old toy maker in a tiny Italian village, wishing on a star for the joys of fatherhood, and what does he get? A puppet who comes to life, keeps him up all night asking silly questions, gets into fights at school, gives people splinters when he shakes hands, lies chronically, runs away, falls prey to kidnappers, ends up at a strange amusement park where he turns into a donkey and gets himself (and his father) swallowed by a whale. Not to mention that he doesn't even want to follow in Dad's footsteps as a toy maker. The nerve!

title: GERMAN CROSS-SHAREHOLDINGS ARE CUT

The transactions are prompted by German government plans to let companies shed holdings without facing mammoth capital-gains taxes. Under the plan, Allianz and Munich Re will reduce their stakes in each other from 25 percent to 20 percent. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JOHN CARDINAL
description: O'CONNOR-John Cardinal, His Eminence. The Board of Trustees and members institutions of the Catholic Health Care system of the Archdiocese of New York mourn the loss of the beloved Shepherd of the Archdiocese who has gone to his eternal rest to be with Our Lord. A defender and champion of the poor, the sick, vulnerable and all those who are marginalized. His Eminence brought Christ's healing presence to those most in need. In the way he lived his life and the grace with which he faced his death, His Eminence was an inspiration to all of those dedicated to fulfilling the Church's healing ministry through the hospitals and nursing homes of the Archdiocese's Catholic Health Care System. His commitment to life-from his staunch advocacy for the unborn to his support of the tiniest of infants who began life at Our Lady of Mercy's neonatal unit; from the AIDS patients, whom he visited in nightly unannounced visits at St. Clare's Hospital to those who suffered with Huntington's Disease and were cared for at Terence Cooke Health Care Center; from those who were ravaged with the end stages of cancer and found compassion at Calvary Hospital and the sick who were treated at St. Agnes Hospital to the elderly cared for at Carmel Richmond, Ferncliff, Kateri, Mary Manning Walsh, St. Vincent dePaul, Terence Cardinal Cooke and St. Teresa's nursing homes, -whether through his actions or his prayers, touched us all. His faith in Our Lord was unwavering. His will to serve was inspiring. As Archbishop, his reach extended beyond Archdiocesean borders. Though truly a world leader, His Eminence was first and foremost a priest who followed his calling. As concerned with those who did not have adequate health care in Africa, the Caribbean, Central and South America and around the world as he was with those in New York, his legacy will perhaps best be measured by the care received by those whom he did not know and who in turn may not have even known his name. Despite his extraordinarily demanding schedule he always had time for a quiet moment of counsel, praise and gratitude to those who so willingly served under him. It was an honor and a privilege to do so, and for that we are eternally grateful. Our prayers go out to the Cardinal's immediate family and his extended family of New York. As beloved as he was in life so too will he be missed in death. As we pray for his soul, we also pray that his light may continue to shine upon us all. May the Lord grant him eternal peace. Donations to support the Archdiocese's health care ministry may be made in the Cardinal's name to: Providence Health Services Foundation, 155 E. 56 St, 2 Floor, New York, NY 10022 Mary Healey-Sedutto, Ph.D President & CEO Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman

title: WESTAFF AND INVESTOR GROUP CALL OFF TAKEOVER DEAL
description: The staffing company Westaff Inc. said yesterday that it had called off an agreement to be acquired for $160 million by an investor group that included members of Westaff's management. The deal valued Westaff at $10 a share, and news that it would not be completed sent the company's stock tumbling nearly 36 percent to $4.50, a drop of $2.50. Westaff said ending the agreement, which was announced in March, was by mutual consent. The company said it would explore other strategic alternatives. Westaff, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., provides temporary workers from 360 offices worldwide. It had $647.5 million in sales in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

It's hard to recall a time in the last 20 years when so many galleries on or just off the avenue offered such a diverse range of high-quality viewing opportunities. One resident art dealer cheerfully described the neighborhood as ''the Chelsea you can get to.''

title: Some Things Are Too Big for Even Imax to Capture
description: ''Michael Jordan to the Max'' is a big, loud, expensive statement of the proposition that the Chicago Bulls guard was the greatest basketball player of all time. That nobody is likely to dispute the assertion is both the film's reason for being and its principal flaw. Until his retirement two years ago, Mr. Jordan dominated his sport as no one else has, and he continues to be a ubiquitous media presence, lending his fame, his face and his soft, deep voice to worthy causes like batteries, long-distance calling plans and Gatorade. No other individual athlete -- perhaps no other individual -- could so comfortably occupy the superhuman Imax format, but the format and the purposeful blandness of the script make Mr. Jordan seem remote, more icon than human being.

description: Summit Technology, the No. 2 United States maker of surgical eye lasers, said yesterday that it would sell its Lens Express unit to the closely held Strategic Optical Holdings for $31 million in cash. Summit is selling the business to focus on its ophthalmic laser systems and related products used to correct common vision disorders like astigmatism and nearsightedness. The company, based in Waltham, Mass., had losses in each of the last four quarters, most recently losing 30 cents a share in the first quarter of 2000. Summit Technology's shares rose $1.8125, to $10.75, in Nasdaq trading.

description: MAHONEY-David. The President, Board of Trustees, staff, and extended family of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute mourn the passing on May 1 of our esteemed friend and colleague, David Mahoney. In his role as leader of the Charles A. Dana Foundation, David Mahoney helped Dana-Farber to make tremendous progress in cancer research. He was recently awarded the Sidney Farber Medical Research Award for his outstanding contribution to the fight against cancer. David Mahoney's support also transformed the field of brain research. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, EILEEN KERRILL
description: WHITE-Eileen Kerrill. On May 4, 2000, at age 60, in New York City. Beloved sister of Robert White and Philip White; aunt of Maureen Ann, Linda, Kerrill, Kristina, Stefanie, James and Christopher; sisterin-law of Anna Mae White and Sigrid Kornacker and aunt-in-law of Rosalie Divall, all of whom were so especially there for Eileen, plusaunts, cousins, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Eileen was endowed with a rare grace and Irish beauty that was cherished by her friends and family and admired by her colleagues and those who shared her sense of humor and keen intellect. She was a graduate of Hunter College. Until her illness, she was a major gifts officer for New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Earlier, she held a similar position at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. While a student, she took part in archaeological digs in Greece, where she developed a lifelong appreciation of the art and poetry of this ancient civilization. A joyous highlight in Eileen's life took place this past March 17 when she attended the St. Patrick's Day gala at the White House. Eileen's dynamism, her caring warmth, her uncompromising ethical standards and her dignified beliefs were appreciated by all who knew her, and she will be lovingly remembered. She remains a beacon for us all. We also wish to thank the Urgent Care Staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering for their wonderful care of our sister.

She was also a frequent model for the renowned illustrator, Rene Boucher. Mrs. Hiss went on to become the beauty editor of Glamour magazine and wrote many articles on health care issues. A memorial evening will be held at a later date. Donations in her memory may be made to The Nation Institute, 33 Irving Place, New York, NY 10003, and Doctors Without Borders USA, P.O. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEGA, ALFRED S.
description: ALLEGA-Alfred S. Died Wednesday, May 3, 2000. Mr. Allega was born in East Douglas, Massachusetts on December 19, 1917, the son of the late Josephine (Lavella) and Salvatore Allega. A World War II veteran, he served in the United States Army Air Force. Alfred Allega is survived by his wife Nadia (Mandalakis) Allega of New York City and by his two sisters, Josephine Anderson and Lillian Epstein. Two brothers and six sisters predeceased him. Well known in the wholesale produce business for many years, Mr. Allega was President of American Banana Company located in the Bronx. Previously he was President of Yel-O-Ripe Banana Company, Inc. which he founded in the Bronx with his two brothers in 1945. When the Yel-O-Ripe and American Banana Companies merged in 1952, Mr. Allega was appointed President of the American Banana Company, Inc. A philanthropist and an honorable man whose word was his contract, Alfred Allega was admired and very well respected by associates in the business community in the United States and by his adopted Greek community here and abroad. Farewell to a rare individual who gave so much of himself to his fellow man. Viewing hours are 2-4 and 6-8 p.m. on Sunday at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY, 914375-1400. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, CLAUDIA HAINES
description: MARSH-Claudia Haines, pastpresident of Public Welfare Foundation of Washington, D.C. died Wednesday, May 3 at her home. She was 100. Mrs. Marsh was the widow of Charles E. Marsh, who established the foundation in 1947 in Austin, TEX. The offices were eventually moved to Washington, where Mr. Marsh died in 1964. Mr. and Mrs. Marsh were married in 1953. In 1952 Mrs. Marsh became actively involved in the foundation's operation when Mr. Marsh donated three newspapers he owned to the foundation to provide a source of greater and more permanent funding. She served as president from 1952 until her retirement in 1974. The foundation grew from its modest beginning into an international organization providing assistance to people and organizations who could get help from no other source. Mr. and Mrs. Marsh established a system of agents throughout the world to extend the foundation's activities. Agents received modest monthly stipends to assist people in need. Mrs. Marsh kept in regular contact with agents, many of whom were selected during their travels. Others were family members and friends. The agent system was later abandoned as the foundation developed in size. Claudia Elizabeth Kellogg was born in Oak Park, IL. On Nov. 7, 1899. After her mother's untimely death she moved to Summit, NJ to live with her aunt and uncle Mr. and Mrs. George LeHuray. She graduated from Kent Place School in Summit and attended Smith College. Her marriage to Charles Ernst Haines ended in divorce. She is survived by her daughter, Mrs. Donald T. Warner of Salisbury, CT; her son, Davis Haines, Virginia Beach, VA; seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

Kalfus, M.D., President Eugene Friedman, M.D, V.P. Keith Cardell, M.D., Secretary Randall Feingold, M.D., Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCOPO, MARIA GRAZIA
description: LOCOPO-Maria Grazia (nee Giugno) age 59, on May 3, 2000 of Garden City, after a brief illness. Mrs. Locopo was born in Italy. Beloved wife of Anthony. Loving mother of James and mother-in-law of Laura. Cherished Nonna of Anthony and Christina. Adored sister of Cosima Lazzari and Rosetta GiugnoPirozzi. Beloved sister-in-law of the Locopo family in Italy. Maria was an extraordinary 1st grade teacher of Homestead School. She was a recipient of the Teacher of the Year awarded by the Garden City News. Her contributions to the education of her students went beyond the classroom. The impact Maria had will last a lifetime because she inspired each child to love learning and to become a compassionate, caring person. For the past four years, Maria was president of Delta Kappa Gamma Int'l Society-Ch. Alpha Upsilon, an honorary society for women educators. along with many other contributions to her community, she has served on the executive board on the Italian Cultural Society. She promoted cultural awareness of her native land with pride. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Friday. Mass of Christian burial St. Anne's Church, Garden City 9:15 A.M. Saturday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations to the American Cancer Society for the research of Glioblastoma, 839 Stewart Ave., Garden City, New York 11530, appreciated.

title: Finding Life After Murder, and Sharing It
description: LOUISE SPIERS, wearing polka dots and a tired frown, is sitting in a tiny borrowed office at Manhattan Family Court, ignoring the vase of spring flowers on the desk behind her. Once an avid gardener and flower lover, Ms. Spiers, who counsels the families of murder victims, does not have the heart for indulging in flora anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENENHOLZ, RICHARD SAMUEL
description: DENENHOLZ-Richard Samuel Agustus Binion on May 3, 2000. Eighty four years, a Mason and Shriner. Beloved husband of Sally Kraft. Dear brother of Alma Kaplan, Amelia Orringer, Grace and the late Marshall, Daniel, Jessica Levin, Reginald, Victor and Devora Schwebel, beloved friend of Trini A. Montes. Loving brother-inlaw, uncle, great uncle and friend to all. Services today at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Ave at 10th Street, NYC At 1:00 PM.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES HIRES ADVISER FOR LIGHTING UNIT
description: U.S. Industries, maker of Jacuzzi baths and other household products, hired a financial adviser yesterday to explore alternatives for its lighting division, including a possible sale. The adviser, Compass Partners International, will look at options for the division, the Lighting Corporation of America, whose brands include Columbia, Dual-Lite and Prescolite. Sales of lighting fixtures and related products at U.S. Industries were $805 million in the 1999 fiscal year. In January, U.S. Industries, based in Iselin, N.J., agreed to sell its diversified business unit, which includes the vacuum cleaner maker Rexair, EJ Footwear and Bilt Best Windows.

title: Brodeur and Joseph Create Fragile Balance in Series
description: Forty minutes into practice today, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur slumped forward in front of his net, his helmet touching the ice. Brodeur had blocked a shot by Petr Sykora with the puck hitting a portion of his ribs unprotected by his pads.

title: New Law Eases Sale of Needles in an Effort to Curb AIDS
description: The New York State Legislature passed a measure today that will permit the sale and possession of hypodermic needles without a prescription, a move intended to slow the spread of the virus that causes AIDS among addicts who inject drugs.

description: There are very few differences, ritually speaking, between a funeral for a cardinal and one for any other Catholic. One is that a cardinal, like other priests, lies in state in his church before burial. In this case, of course, the cardinal is John O'Connor, who died at 80 on Wednesday night, and the church is St. Patrick's Cathedral, the largest Roman Catholic cathedral in the United States.

title: High Rewards and High Costs As States Draw Autistic Pupils
description: One family came from India, others from Greece, Italy and Israel. An Australian family is thinking about coming. Compared with those migrants, Rob and Anne Mandel had it pretty easy, giving up his medical practice and a life they loved in Indiana to get their son, Sam, the help he needed in New Jersey.

title: Bill Musselman, 59, Intense Basketball Coach
description: Bill Musselman, who in the last 35 years held 13 head coaching jobs in college and professional basketball and left an imprint everywhere as a volatile, intense taskmaster, died yesterday at the Mayo Clinic's St. Marys Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 59.

title: Saluting a Visionary Nurturer
description: The air was filled with laughter and affection when dancers, choreographers and students gathered to pay homage to Joan Miller last Saturday at the Dicapo Theater in a celebration of her 30 years in dance. Ms. Miller is one of those quiet teachers and artists who have brought extra vitality and vision to New York dance. For more than three decades she has nourished careers as director of the dance program at Lehman College, where Joan Miller's Dance Players is a resident company.

title: Political Memo; Private Life A Whirlpool, But Giuliani Is Tranquil
description: It has been one of the most turbulent weeks in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's 55 years. He met with more doctors to determine his treatment for prostate cancer, acknowledged at a news briefing that he has a ''very good'' female friend, fended off questions about his wife's postponement of her starring role in ''The Vagina Monologues,'' and stepped outside the gates of Gracie Mansion shortly before midnight on Wednesday to talk of his sadness at the loss of a friend, Cardinal John O'Connor.

title: S.E.C. Ends One Limit on Stock Trading
description: In a long-awaited move, the Securities and Exchange Commission removed a ban today that prohibited certain stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange from being traded off the exchange floor, a rule that the S.E.C. and many in the industry players had viewed as anticompetitive.

description: The filly Winning Colors burst from the starting gate first, hustled to a four-length lead with half a mile to go, was ahead by three lengths around the final turn and hung on in the stretch to win the 1988 Kentucky Derby by a neck. Strike the Gold broke leisurely, was in 10th place with half a mile to go, swung hard into sixth place on the final turn and passed five horses in the final quarter of a mile to capture the 1991 Derby.

description: In the press, around water coolers and at dinner tables, people have been discussing the ''I Love You'' virus, which raced through the Internet this week, leaving a trail of binary destruction. The often breathless accounts have suggested that someone far away lobbed the Big One on us, the helpless citizens of the brave new online world.

title: PHONE MERGER TALKS END
description: Talks about a merger between two leading European telecommunication companies -- Royal KPN of the Netherlands and Telefonica of Spain -- broke down. It would have been the first merger of two state-owned phone monopolies. The companies said that a majority of the Telefonica board backed the deal but that opposition ''by an important minority group within the board'' undermined KPN's confidence in the chance for success of the new company. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

At his recital in the Great Performers series at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, his performances were beautifully composed and thereby gripping, even though, or because, there was nothing attention-grabbing in them.

description: The Pataki administration has called a timeout in the battle to build a major Indian casino in the Catskills, where the St. Regis Mohawk tribe has signed separate deals with two competing developers.

title: Couple Sues Town and Officials, Accusing Them of Anti-Gay Bias
description: A Long Island couple who bought a well-known gay bar and restaurant on Fire Island in a bankruptcy sale 16 months ago filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court here, charging the Town of Brookhaven and four of its officials with anti-gay bias and illegally preventing the reopening of the bar.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER PRICES JUMP. Copper rose as falling inventories signaled strengthening demand from manufacturers. Copper for July delivery rose 2.1 cents, or 2.6 percent, to 84.05 cents a pound.

title: U.S. Giving a Lift to Salmon, But Future of Aid Is in Doubt
description: For roughly half of the millions of salmon born on the Snake River that set out each spring for the Pacific Ocean, the journey past four federal dams is an arduous and often lethal one. They can be whacked to death by giant blades of the dam turbines, knocked out from collisions with concrete spillways, or succumb to a fatal condition not unlike the bends.
