title: Judge Allows Maryland To Proceed in Tripp Case
description: A Maryland judge ruled today that the state could go ahead with its prosecution of Linda R. Tripp on charges that she broke the law when she secretly tape-recorded conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky about Ms. Lewinsky's relationship with President Clinton.

title: Farewells Begin for Cardinal As Body Is Taken to Cathedral
description: Free of the illness that sapped his energy and ultimately his life, Cardinal John Joseph O'Connor's body was returned to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, beginning a final farewell to the eloquent, unswerving archbishop of New York from the millions of Roman Catholics he led.

title: Mississippi Forms Commission To Design a New State Flag
description: A day after Mississippi learned that its bitterly contested state flag had not been an official symbol for 94 years, Gov. Ronnie Musgrove today formed an advisory commission to design a new flag, guaranteeing a year of debate about whether the flag should bear a Confederate symbol.

title: Abroad at Home; Ghosts
description: The National Guardsmen were walking up a hill when they suddenly wheeled around and fired into a group of unarmed students. That was how four students died at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.

title: Four Drug Companies to Pay $33 Million in Fines
description: Four drug companies have agreed to plead guilty to taking part in an international conspiracy to fix vitamin prices, and two former executives agreed to prison terms, Justice Department officials said today.

title: THE INNER LIFE
description: Americans are polled on almost everything, except what they hold closest -- concerns of the heart and mind. For a special issue, The Times Magazine commissioned a poll that asked how people understand their identities. The results reveal religious beliefs and sexual mores; where people find happiness; what causes anxiety.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption last Saturday in a grouping of pictures of livery-cab drivers killed this year in New York City misidentified the borough where Manuel Lopez died. And an article on Monday about the deaths misstated the number of deaths in the Bronx. Mr. Lopez was one of four drivers killed in Brooklyn; four more, not five, were killed in the Bronx, and one in Queens.

title: BMW Casts Doubt on Plan by British Group to Rescue Rover
description: BMW A.G. of Germany raised new doubts today about the likelihood of a deal with a British consortium to rescue BMW's ailing Rover Cars operations at one of the biggest auto plants in Britain.

title: National News Briefs; Boston Herald Revises Suspension of Columnist
description: The Boston Herald revised its indefinite suspension of a consumer affairs and transportation columnist today to two weeks without pay.

title: Marathon on Ice: Tired Teams Skate Into the Wee Hours
description: In the two dressing rooms, during the many intermissions, hockey players consumed what was to have been their postgame pizza. They munched on nutritional energy bars, washing them down with water and other healthful beverages. They stretched to ward off muscle cramps. They talked among themselves about who would get the winning goal that would allow everyone to finally go home.

title: Rowland Vetoes Bill Setting Limits on Campaign Spending
description: With all the surprise of a spring rainstorm, Gov. John G. Rowland vetoed a bill today that would have established voluntary spending limits for state political campaigns and used millions in public money to pay for them.

title: A Run for Chancellor Gets Cut Short
description: Two days after saying he wanted to be New York City schools chancellor and throwing the selection process into turmoil, Irving S. Hamer Jr. was barred from seeking the post. He was told that he had applied too late.

title: Companies Refuse to Guarantee ABC on Cable
description: Executives of Time Warner and ABC told City Council members yesterday that they could not guarantee that ABC programming would not be disrupted again as they proceed with bitter contract negotiations in the coming months.

title: LOWEST SINCE 1970
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell below 4 percent in April for the first time in 30 years, the Labor Department announced yesterday, as employers hired, among others, tens of thousands of census takers, restaurant employees and temporary workers in a boom that showed no signs of letting up.

title: Ex-Hoya Jackson To Join YankeeNets
description: Michael Jackson, a point guard for Georgetown in the mid-1980's, will leave Turner Sports soon to join the YankeeNets. Jackson is expected to play a role with the Nets, but to work primarily in the company's television business, an executive knowledgeable with the hiring said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Case Goes To Court, But Howdy Sits It Out
description: As Howdy Doody cooled his heels in a secret Rhode Island bank vault, two lawyers tried today to persuade a United States District Court judge here to grant their clients custody of the famous puppet. Decades after entertaining millions of children in the early years of American television, Howdy has become a freckle-faced federal case.

title: APPLIED DIGITAL TO ACQUIRE ATEC GROUP FOR $55.4 MILLION
description: The Atec Group, a computer hardware and software developer, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Applied Digital Solutions Inc. for $55.4 million in stock, significantly revising a transaction announced last month. In the latest deal, Applied Digital will exchange 1.25 of its shares for each of Atec's 7.2 million outstanding shares. That supersedes an agreement under which Atec was to acquire Applied Digital's IntelleSale.com unit for $375 million in stock. Applied Digital also said this week that it had retained Prudential Securities to help find a buyer for IntelleSale.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Consortium Finds Oil in Big Caspian Field
description: A consortium of nine foreign energy companies has found oil in a huge Caspian Sea field and has resumed drilling to determine just how much exists, officials close to the companies say.

title: Pirro Case Is Delayed by Plans For Filing Another Indictment
description: The federal tax fraud case against Albert J. Pirro Jr., Westchester's most prominent real estate development lawyer, was delayed indefinitely today after prosecutors said that they planned to file a new indictment related to Mr. Pirro's business dealings with Robert E. Boyle, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATH, MOLLIE T.
description: MATH-Mollie T. On May 5, 2000. Of Woodmere, L.I. Beloved wife of the late Nathan W. Devoted mother of Tamah and Miles Portman, James and Lana Math, Ellen and Douglas Shute. Dear sister of Fannie Bailenson. Adored grandmother of Elliott, Natalie, Nicole, Amanda and Matthew. Cherished greatgrandmother of Daniel, Joshua, Kensie and Elias. Services Sunday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

description: Law enforcement officials and computer security investigators focused on the Philippines yesterday in their search for the author of a malicious software program that convulsed the world's computer networks.

title: State Can Seek Full Financial Takeover of Camden, Judge Says
description: A Superior Court judge today dismissed the City of Camden's efforts to keep control of its financial operations and ruled that the state can seek a full takeover.

title: Recalling a Choreographer As a Human, Not an Icon
description: One of the thorniest problems facing dance is how to keep the classics of the past alive yet authentic. Videotaping and dance notation now augment the age-old handing down of dances from one performer to another. But what about differences in individual interpretation or even a choreographer's different versions? Which should be the interpretation of record? Those questions are addressed in impressive depth in Michael Blackwood's ''Balanchine Lives!'' on WNET (Channel 13 in New York) tomorrow at 7 p.m. and Tuesday at 1 a.m.

title: Ties to Former Firm Are Corzine Hurdle
description: Jon S. Corzine, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company who is seeking the Democratic nomination for a seat in the United States Senate, says he cannot disclose his financial records because his old firm will not let him. But his opponent, Jim Florio, is making political hay out of the refusal, calling it a convenient dodge.

title: The Heat's Hardaway Is Ready for the Knicks
description: Tim Hardaway had a cocksure step to his gait. It was not quite a strut, but the way the Miami Heat point guard walked off the court today said it all.

title: Nassau Sheriff Says Reforms Are Under Way
description: The Nassau County sheriff, Edward Reilly, who assumed the post in February, says he has changed how his department operates its fleet of 127 vehicles, following recommendations by the county comptroller that could save the financially troubled county $300,000 a year.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about Santa Barbara County wines misspelled the name of a winery. It is Richard Longoria Wines, not Longaria.

title: New Life for Old Railroads; What Better Place to Lay Miles of Fiber Optic Cable
description: Henry Flagler came to Florida in 1883 to build grand hotels in what was sparsely populated coastal scrub. Using wealth amassed as one of the Standard Oil Company's founders, he began cobbling together a railroad down the length of the state. He opened up Florida as he went, erecting posh resorts like the Palm Beach Inn, later called the Breakers, that would serve as starting points for future cities. By 1896, he had built 350 miles of track from Jacksonville to Miami.

description: STARK-Helen. On May 4, 2000. Devoted daughter of the late Charlotte and Wolf Stark. Loving sister of Gladys Weltman and the late Albert, David, Michael, Joseph and Louis. description: Cisco Systems said today that it had agreed to buy ArrowPoint Communications in a stock swap valued at $5.7 billion.

title: MEDALLION FINANCIAL TO PURCHASE AMERITRANS CAPITAL
description: The Medallion Financial Corporation, which specializes in making taxicab-related loans, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, the Ameritrans Capital Corporation, for about $16.9 million to create the largest United States taxi-medallion lender. Medallion will pay 0.5842 share, or $9.64 a share, for each share of Ameritrans, based on Medallion's closing price on Thursday and a floating exchange ratio agreed to by the companies. Ameritrans has 1.75 million shares outstanding. It is Medallion's 12th acquisition since the company first sold shares to the public in 1996. Both companies are based in New York.

title: EARTHSHELL TO SELL SHARES TO ACQUA WELLINGTON
description: The EarthShell Corporation, the maker of a new biodegradable sandwich container for the McDonald's Corporation, said yesterday that Acqua Wellington North America Equities Fund Ltd. had agreed to purchase $60 million in EarthShell's shares. Acqua Wellington will buy at least $2.5 million in common stock at market prices each month for the next 12 months and has the option to buy an additional $2.5 million of stock each month over the same period. Based on Earthshell's closing price today of $3.28125, up 3.125 cents, the New York-based Acqua Wellington would hold about 18 percent of EarthShell's shares by the end of the agreement. EarthShell, based in Annapolis Junction, Md., makes food packaging from biodegradable and dissolvable materials including vegetable starch and limestone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EUGENE
description: KATZ-Eugene. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute mourns the recent passing of Mr. Eugene Katz. Mr Katz served the White Institute over many decades as an active and vital member of the Board of Trustees. His continued dedication to the mission of the Institute earned him the position of Honorary Trustee, a position which Mr Katz held until the time of his death. Our profound condolences to Mr Katz' devoted family, and to his many friends and colleagues. Charles Harrington, Ph D, President, Board of Trustees Marylou Lionells, Ph D, Director, White Institute

title: In a Crowded Field, Fusaichi Pegasus Stands Out
description: America's oldest racing traditions surrounded 19 of the world's best 3-year-old thoroughbreds today on the eve of the 126th Kentucky Derby with its deep cast primed to answer the question: Is Fusaichi Pegasus a wonder horse, or will he be thwarted by the dense traffic in the race and the 150,000 clamorous fans watching it?

title: Gore Dangles Teacher Raises, But Attaches Conditions, Too
description: Vice President Al Gore promised today to spend billions of dollars to recruit new teachers and increase teachers' salaries, but only if the states and teachers' unions agreed that all new teachers meet rigorous national standards and only if hiring decisions are based on expertise, not seniority alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, YVETTE
description: BROWNSTEIN-Yvette (jewelry designer). Beloved wife of Max. Loving grandmother of Rachel and Hannah. Cryptside services on Monday. For information call Weinstein-West End, 800-452-9597.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ELSIE
description: WIENER-Elsie. Oakland, CA. April 30, at 93. Born in Brooklyn, one year after her family immigrated from Mogilev, Russia, she lived in Brownsville with them behind her parents' candy store. Educated at City College, worked for the NYC Board of Education. Lived in Astoria and then Forest Hills. A member of the Brandeis Club, she and her husband, Philip L. Wiener, moved to CA. to be near their children and grandchildren. In the last years of her life, her wit revealed itself and kept us all in stitches. We are grateful that we had her with us and wish it had been longer. Survived by her sister, Lillian Gordon of Oakland, CA, children, Elizabeth Wiener of Oakland, Deborah Wiener, son-in-law W. Daniel Boone, grandchildren, Sarah and David of Berkeley, CA. Donations may be made in her name to VNA/Hospice Foundation, 1900 Powell St, Suite 300, Emeryville, CA. 94608.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Boston Herald's suspension of a consumer affairs columnist, Robin Washington, misstated his account of the cause. Mr. Washington has said publicly that he believes he was originally demoted after a bank, the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, complained about his columns on its fee structure. He said he was then suspended after asserting publicly that the bank influenced coverage. He did not say he believed he was suspended because of pressure from the bank.

title: WPP and Young & Rubicam to See if 3rd Time Might Be a Charm
description: The on-again, off-again merger talks between the WPP Group of Britain and Young & Rubicam Inc. are on again. A week after negotiations between the two advertising companies broke down, WPP said today that it had returned to the bargaining table in hopes of reviving a takeover of Y.& R., which is based in New York.

title: GAS FIND IN INDONESIA
description: Britain's big oil-exploration company, Lasmo P.L.C., said its joint venture with the Unocal Corporation had found natural gas in Indonesia. Unocal estimated the reservoir at two trillion to three trillion cubic feet. Gas from the Indonesian development could be sold to Japan, Korea and Taiwan through the world's largest liquefied natural gas plant at Bontang, Indonesia, where gas is converted to liquid for export, according to Lasmo, whose chief executive is Joseph Darby (above). At the company's meeting, shareholders also approved a plan to buy back as much as 10 percent of its shares.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS IN 2 FIBER OPTIC DEALS
description: ADC Telecommunications Inc., a provider of technology that speeds the transmission of voice, data and video signals, said yesterday that it would buy two European fiber optic component makers for a combined $952 million. ADC, based in Minnetonka, Minn., will pay $872 million in stock for the Swedish laser manufacturer Altitun and roughly $80 million in cash for Ibsen Micro Structures of Denmark. ADC said Altitun helps telecommunications providers deploy high-bandwidth networks at increasingly competitive costs. Altitun's high- power and wide-wavelength tunable lasers, can emit light signals at any required wavelength, unlike a fixed laser, which is more limited. ADC's stock jumped $5.875 a share, to $63.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: 2 Faces of Beauty: Timeless and Timely
description: There was once a time, says the cultural historian Sander Gilman, when Irishmen had their noses surgically altered to look more like Englishmen so they could seem more American. Later many Jews had their noses surgically altered to look more like Irishmen so they could seem more American. Such are the knotty ways in which different cultures pursue visions of beauty, proclaiming timeless ideals while succumbing to the tastes of their time and place.

title: This Week's Season
description: Somehow this spring, the weather seems more sharply creased than it has been in springs past. Instead of gentle transitions -- easing from overcoat to jacket to shirtsleeves -- the temperature swoops and dives like a phoebe feeding on the wing. An installment of April is followed by a parcel of March and then a dose of early December. Spring has managed to be both early and late this year, and still it is only half gone. In a week or two it could be February again in all but name. Or perhaps July.

title: Leiter Stays Focused, And Mets Halt a Skid
description: The Mets arrived here tired and concerned, reeling from a late-night flight from San Francisco and a four-game losing streak. Al Leiter came to Pro Player Stadium concerned but not so tired. The left-handed pitcher was allowed to travel here Thursday morning, nearly a full day ahead of his team.

title: Secret Status in a Runaway

title: TAIWAN PRICES RISE
description: Taiwan's consumer price index rose 1.25 percent in April from a year earlier. It was the highest increase in 14 months, influenced by rising domestic oil prices and a low base period, but was still within market expectations. It was also the sixth consecutive increase since the 0.9 percent contraction in November, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said. Consumer prices rose by only 0.18 percent in 1999, the lowest increase in 13 years.

title: 2 Swiss Banks Will Give Account Data to Holocaust Survivors
description: Representatives of Swiss commercial banks and Holocaust survivors are expected to present the final details of a $1.25 billion restitution settlement to a federal judge next week after two of the largest banks agreed to give the survivors' lawyers access to databases containing information on 2.1 million Nazi-era accounts, the lead lawyer for the survivors said yesterday.

description: KASPER-Lois M. On May 4, 2000. Beloved wife of Dr. Bruce Tuchman. Dear sister of Arlene Gottlieb. Loving cousin of Iris Levinson. title: Sports of The Times; Characters In the Annual Derby Drama
description: IF you love horses, the smells, the sights and the sounds never get old; if you love the Kentucky Derby, the pre-race excitement never loses its electricity. At 6 a.m. yesterday, the darkness at Churchill Downs was defined by shadows, with grooms, trainers and riders moving in a haphazard choreography of chores in the refreshing chill of spring air. Through the muddy maze of walkways and stables, Wayne Kotcamp led the way.

title: CANADIAN UNEMPLOYMENT STEADY
description: Canada's unemployment rate held at 6.8 percent in April for a fifth consecutive month, although the economy's steady creation of new full-time jobs came to an end, Statistics Canada reported. The number of full-time jobs fell by 29,000 last month, while part-time employment rose by 34,000. in the last year, full-time employment has increased by 3.1 percent and part-time employment by 1.9 percent. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

description: After weeks of speculation over whether she would take the witness stand, Sante Kimes abruptly declined to testify in her murder trial yesterday and accused the judge of making it impossible for her to defend herself.

title: WARBURG PINCUS TO INVEST IN COVENTRY HEALTH SHARES
description: Coventry Health Care Inc. said yesterday that the investment firm E. M. Warburg Pincus & Company would pay Principal Financial Group $100 million for 10 million shares of Coventry to become the largest shareholder in Coventry, a managed health care company. Coventry said Warburg, which is privately held, will own about 31 percent of the company's shares after the deal is completed. Principal Financial will own about 23 percent. Principal Financial, also a privately held investment firm, said it wanted to reduce its investments in health maintenance organizations. Coventry, based in Bethesda, Md., has 1.5 million members in its managed care plans.

title: Gino Bartali, 85, a Hero in Italy For His Cycling Championships

title: Paying for a Trip, Ethically
description: Gov. George Pataki got a mostly favorable ruling this week from the New York State Ethics Commission on the controversial financing of his two trips to Hungary in 1995 and 1996. The commission found no violation of the state's ethics law in allowing the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce, a nonprofit trade group largely financed by companies lobbying the governor's office, to pay for his trips, which were combined trade missions and family vacations. The panel said its ''extensive inquiry'' supported the governor's claim that neither he nor anyone else in his administration knew that the chamber was soliciting funds for the trips from companies with significant business pending in Albany. These included Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, Pepsico and two pharmaceutical giants, Pfizer and Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JOHN CARDINAL
description: O'CONNOR-John Cardinal. The Board of Trustees of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York wishes to express profound sorrow and a deep sense of personal loss at the death of His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York and President of this charitable Federation. Throughout a lifetime characterized by extraordinary accomplishments and service, Cardinal O'Connor was foremost and preeminently a dedicated priest, imbued with love of God and love for all God's people. His leadership and many initiatives on behalf of the poor and disadvantaged of the Archdiocese have been a source of untold strength to this Board and a special blessing from Almighty God. With loving concern, our Good Shepherd recognized the demands of our changing times and encouraged tirelessly the development of many new programs for the benefit of children and youth, recent immigrants and refugees, the aged, the homeless, handicapped and the sick. As the Shepherd of God's people, his concerns were universal as he devoted himself with apostolic charity and zeal to the welfare and the best interest of all, not only in New York but throughout the United States, the Americas and the Third World. We thank Almighty God for sharing with us the faith and wisdom, the strength and the talents of his devoted servant, John Cardinal O'Connor. His memory and example will remain with us as a lasting legacy and inspiration. The Board of Trustees of The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York Most Rev. Patrick J. Sheraton Vice President Rev. Msgr. James J. Murray Secretary

title: Hedge Fund Industry Creates a Dinosaur: The Macro Manager
description: George Soros and Julian H. Robertson Jr., money managers who once rattled world financial markets with mere hints of their actions, have lost much of their punch. But hedge funds, the investment vehicles for the wealthy that these prominent investors epitomized, are by no means on the ropes.

title: Lonely Bowlers, Unite: Mend the Social Fabric; A Political Scientist Renews His Alarm At the Erosion of Community Ties
description: Robert D. Putnam, a political scientist at Harvard University, is a big, red-faced, enthusiastic man with the Amish whiskers and explosive gestures of a 19th-century fundamentalist preacher -- useful characteristics for the ''hell will get us if we don't mend our ways'' thesis that has taken over his life in the last five years.

title: Law Barring Insurers' Tips On Car Shops Is Tossed Out
description: In a decision that could affect all drivers in New York State, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled this week that state regulators could not prevent two insurance companies from recommending specific auto repair shops to their policyholders.

title: GENERAL RE, REINSURER, DECIDES TO KEEP INVESTING UNIT
description: The General Re Corporation, the nation's largest reinsurance company, said yesterday that it would not sell its derivatives-investing concern. General Re is owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., which is controlled by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffet. Berkshire Hathaway acquired General Re in 1998. In February, General Re, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said it had hired Goldman, Sachs to help it explore strategic alternatives for General Re Financial Products, which invests in derivatives. A derivative is an investment whose value is derived from the value of another security or asset. Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, serves as a holding company for Mr. Buffet's investments.

title: A Composer to Help Divas Let Their Hair Down
description: Jake Heggie, the San Francisco-based composer best known for his art songs, has benefited immeasurably from the devotion he has attracted from important singers. That devotion was palpable on Monday night when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented five fine singers in an evening of Mr. Heggie's songs, most of them accompanied by the composer at the piano, a program essentially drawn from a 1999 RCA Red Seal recording: ''The Faces of Love: The Songs of Jake Heggie.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEGA, ALFRED S.
description: ALLEGA-Alfred S. Died Wednesday, May 3, 2000. Mr. Allega was born in East Douglas, Massachusetts on December 19, 1917, the son of the late Josephine (Lavella) and Salvatore Allega. A World War II veteran, he served in the United States Army Air Force. Alfred Allega is survived by his wife Nadia (Mandalakis) Allega of New York City and by his two sisters, Josephine Anderson and Lillian Epstein. Two brothers and six sisters predeceased him. Well known in the wholesale produce business for many years, Mr. Allega was President of American Banana Company located in the Bronx. Previously he was President of Yel-O-Ripe Banana Company, Inc. which he founded in the Bronx with his two brothers in 1945. When the Yel-O-Ripe and American Banana Companies merged in 1952, Mr. Allega was appointed President of the American Banana Company, Inc. A philanthropist and an honorable man whose word was his contract, Alfred Allega was admired and very well respected by associates in the business community in the United States and by his adopted Greek community here and abroad. Farewell to a rare individual who gave so much of himself to his fellow man. Viewing hours are 2-4 and 6-8 p.m. on Sunday at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY, 914375-1400. Funeral service 11 a.m. Monday at the funeral home with interment following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Israel Abruptly Halts Reprisals on Lebanon
description: The Israeli government, facing a coming troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon for which it needs international backing, today decided not to continue reprisal bombings in Lebanon even though another cross-border guerrilla offensive took place this morning.

title: CHIP MAKER IN DEAL WITH NORTEL
description: A Swiss chip maker, STMicroelectronics N.V., received a six-year contract worth at least $2 billion to supply semiconductors to Nortel Networks, Canada's giant phone and Internet equipment maker. The contract is part of a deal to buy Nortel's chip-making plant in Ottawa for $100 million. STMicroelectronics said it expected the contract to be worth $2 billion over the first three years. The company had $5.1 billion in sales last year. STMicroelectronics said it would hire the plant's 470 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, HOWARD J.
description: SERWER-Howard J. On May 3, 2000 in Washington, D.C. He was Professor Emeritus of Musicology of The University of Maryland, College Park, and resided in Chevy Chase, MD., and Georgetown, ME. He leaves his wife Nancy Rose, sons Nicholas and Andrew, daughter-in-law Frances Fifield and grandchildren Emily and Katherine. A memorial gathering of friends and family will be held at 12:00 noon on Wednesday, May 10, 2000 in the Memorial Chapel of The University of Maryland, College Park, MD. The family asks that remembrances be made in the form of donations in Howard's name to The Performing Arts Library of The University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, in lieu of flowers.

title: FIAT TO BUY COMPANIES
description: Italy's largest industrial company, Fiat S.p.A., said it would offer to buy the shares it does not already own in the insurer Toro Assicurazioni S.p.A. and in the auto components maker Magneti Marelli S.p.A. for $1.07 billion, to gain greater flexibility in pursuing alliances. Fiat will offer 16 euros ($14.30) for each Toro common share and 12 euros for each savings share. It will pay 5.5 euros for each Magneti common share and 3.8 euros for each savings share.

title: EATON PLANS SPIN OFF OF AXCELIS, ITS CHIP-MAKING UNIT
description: The Eaton Corporation, a manufacturer of car and truck parts, said yesterday that its semiconductor equipment subsidiary, Axcelis Technologies Inc., had filed for an initial public offering. After the offering, the Cleveland-based Eaton will own 80 percent of the chip-making unit, which makes ion implanters for semiconductor manufacturing. Six months after the offering, Eaton plans to award its Axcelis shares to its shareholders in a tax-free transaction. Eaton has sold several of its noncore operations in the last year and is focusing on expanding its businesses in emerging markets in Asia and Latin America. Axcelis had sales of $397 million in 1999.

description: Iranians voted today in runoff elections for a new Parliament, in an atmosphere of heightened suspense after the conservative crackdown on the politically ascendant reform movement.

title: GREENBRIER, FREIGHT-CAR MAKER, PLANS LAYOFFS
description: The Greenbrier Companies, the third-largest railroad freight-car maker, laid off 500 employees yesterday at a plant in Nova Scotia, or 11 percent of its work force, in response to a 50 percent drop in North American orders. The company plans to cut administrative costs by 10 percent annually. Greenbrier, which is based in Lake Oswego, Ore., said that 1999 North American orders for its freight cars fell to 41,000 from 86,000 in 1998 as industrywide demand declined. The company expects that orders will pick up and that it will be able to rehire the 500 workers at the plant in Trenton, Nova Scotia, which has 1,300 employees. Greenbrier has 4,500 total employees.

description: There may never be a full accounting of the terror plot that brought down Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, just before Christmas in 1988. title: The Experience Card
description: In a series of brisk exchanges last week, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush laid out their disagreements over gun control, foreign policy, tax cuts, Social Security and Mr. Bush's record in Texas. Perhaps because he is struggling to stay even with Mr. Bush in the polls, Mr. Gore was on the attack almost every day, using highly personal language to derogate his opponent's policies. The subtext, however, was not about policy. It was about experience and temperament. Mr. Gore, with his customary lack of subtlety, was suggesting that Mr. Bush is an untested leader with half-baked ideas. Stressing the value of experience is a time-honored strategy for the more seasoned candidate in presidential contests. But it comes with no guarantee of success. Otherwise we would never have had presidents named Carter, Reagan and Clinton.

title: What's Couched in a Couch?
description: The people who come in to the psychiatrist's office mustn't get the wrong idea of what it's all about. Even if you feel at home there, it's not a home, because it's all being paid for. So the tie or the earrings the analyst wears, the color of the carpet, the pictures on the wall -- these are all messages. And yet, as the psychiatrist should be the first to acknowledge, we never know exactly what messages we are sending, or indeed how they will be received. The books and journals that so often furnish a consulting room may be meant to suggest a studious commitment to the work; to the patient they may speak rather eloquently of a fear of sex, or a need to be taken seriously. However silent the psychiatrist prefers to be, her room speaks for her; and whatever the patient may or may not say about it, it is furnished with clues.

title: His and Hers
description: Johnny Cash once said that one of the secrets of his 32-year union with June Carter Cash, his wife and fellow country music legend, was separate bathrooms. ''The lady needs her space,'' he explained recently. ''Not everyone can afford it, but it can be a real marriage-saver.'' The Cashes' his-and-hers bathrooms say as much about the couple's personalities as they do about their nearly five decades as Nashville's reigning monarchs.

title: The Maharajah Wore Stripes
description: THE Indian jungle is unpredictable,'' said my guide, Navneet Singh, a dedicated conservationist with an intimate understanding of its secrets. ''Suddenly something will happen right in front of you. But two minutes later, nothing's there. You think it was a phantom. That's the mystery. And that's what kept the British fascinated for 200 years.''

title: Ground Water, Pesticide And Drinking Water
description: I am appalled that none of the governmental authorities mentioned in the cover article on the mosquito season (April 9) took into consideration that many of us in Connecticut get our drinking water from individual wells. Floating solid cakes of pesticide chemicals (or spraying these areas) will contaminate the ground water and, therefore, our drinking water. For example, the standing water in an improperly graded storm drain is less than 100 feet from my well, and upstream from the wells of my neighbors.

title: The World; Sometimes, National Security Says It All
description: TEN years after recapturing the Continent, Dwight D. Eisenhower calculated that the lessons of D-Day could be usefully applied in persuading Congress to lace the land with highways. His administration dreamed up the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways and argued that these roads were not only about economic development, they were about national security.

title: The Pursuit of Autonomy
description: At least since 1845, when Henry David Thoreau took off for Walden Pond to find out, before he died, whether he had ever lived, Americans have admired the individualist willing to leave society behind to discover his true self. But they have also admired him from a distance. For every lonesome cowboy, for every adventurer willing to fly solo across the Atlantic, for every monkish worshiper of solitude, most Americans, until well past the middle of the 20th century, were only too happy to find in faith, family or subdivision the security they needed to get through the insecurities of life.

title: The Uses of a Young Art at a Devastating Moment
description: THE Paris Commune of 1871 is one of those smoldering ash heaps in French history, like the 1968 riots, stirred habitually by left and right to inflame old class allegiances and fears. To the left, the Communards are secular martyrs who refused to accept the humiliating peace imposed by Bismarck after the Prussian army crushed the French in 1870. With Napoleon III readily conceding defeat, these die-hard nationalists had no choice but to replace the capitulators with leaders of their own. To the right, the Commune is a vital lesson in the perils of social disorder. Without respect for the central authority of the state, chaos ensues and Robespierre's reign of terror is reborn.

It is an airy, spacious place of majestic arches, massive beams, graceful chandeliers, a wall of French doors, tiny candles and glorious music. It serves healthy portions of both robust and refined dishes at very unHamptons prices. With a three-course $19.95 fixed price dinner, the Island's only Sunday gospel brunch (a drink, entree and dessert affair) for $24.95, soups and desserts for $5 and entrees as low as $16, Bridges is nearly every diner's dream: it looks expensive, but isn't. There are few local restaurants this sophisticated and attractive, especially in the Hamptons, that offer comparable value.

title: Revealing the Strength of Segal as Sculptor and Draftsman
description: GEORGE SEGAL, a master of 20th-century figurative sculpture, has been living and working on what was once a poultry farm in South Brunswick for more than 50 years. His tableaux of contemporary American life made in his studio, a former chicken coop, bring together elements of both sculpture and painting, high art and consumer culture. No history of the Pop Art movement could be complete without a discussion of his assemblages. In the early 1960's, the innovative white plaster casts of ordinary people doing ordinary things in a realistic environment had earned Mr. Segal an international reputation. At their best, these sculptures are more than representations of anecdotal situations; they evoke feelings of ennui and alienation, reflecting a deep concern for the human condition.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: When Warren Beatty won the best director Oscar for REDS (1981), none other than Orson Welles stood onstage and praised him. A lot of people had been comparing Mr. Beatty's film to Welles's ''Citizen Kane,'' and the older man just wanted to say that he'd be honored to have his work compared to ''Reds.'' Beatty's thrilling epic is about the Bolshevik Revolution as seen through the eyes of the idealistic, eventually disillusioned young writer John Reed (Beatty) and Louise Bryant (Diane Keaton), the woman he loves but frequently leaves. It's also a smart, funny portrait of optimistic young bohemians in New York not long after the turn of the last century. Jack Nicholson is unforgettable as Eugene O'Neill, particularly in his scenes with Ms. Keaton. And Maureen Stapleton received the best supporting actress Oscar as the antiwar activist Emma Goldman, holding on to her dream -- Thursday at 8 p.m., Thursday/Early Friday at 2.45 a.m. on AMC.

title: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Crimes
description: ''HOW are you supposed to act if you've killed people?'' wonders Joseph Paul Franklin on a segment of Court TV's criminal biography series ''MugShots'' (Mondays through Thursdays at 7 p.m.). ''You supposed to have blood dripping from your mouth? Fangs?'' Mr. Franklin is clean- cut, almost genial, even when videotaped through a plate glass partition on death row. He could be your friendly neighborhood mailman or trusted accountant. In fact he was responsbile for more than 20 murders in 12 states, targeting mostly mixed race couples. Two of his victims who survived were Vernon Jordan, then president of the Urban League, and Larry Flynt, the publisher of Huslter magazine. It is the very ordinariness of Mr. Franklin, the absence of fangs, that makes his ''MugShots'' segment so eerie.

title: The Long Shadow of 'The Sorrow and the Pity'
description: LONG before ''Schindler's List'' came along, ''The Sorrow and the Pity'' had already redefined how we think and feel about the Holocaust. Through profound revelation and catharsis, the landmark 1971 documentary by Marcel Ophuls personalized the harrowing Nazi occupation of France, delving into the psyches of a few fascinating participants. In analyzing the web of collaborators, resistance fighters and apathetic onlookers, and how they haunted -- and still haunt -- a nation, Mr. Ophuls elevated the documentary to a higher art form through the force of his subject and storytelling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRITZE, DAVID DURHAM
description: HENRITZE-David Durham, 76, a well-known insurance executive, passed away on Thursday, May 4, 2000. He was Vice Chairman of Huffines-Russell & Associates. He was the founder of Insurance Underwriters, Inc. of Georgia, which was later sold to the Crump Companies of Memphis, Tennessee of which he was a Director. After the Crump Companies were sold to the Sedgwick Insurance Group of London, England, he was a Vice Chairman of Sedgwick James of Georgia, Inc. Mr. Henritze spent his business career specializing in handling the insurance and surety requirements for construction companies in the Southeast. He was a member of the National Association of Surety Bond Producers and the Georgia Association of Insurance Agents. He graduated from the College of William and Mary in Virginia and was a former President of the College's Georgia Alumni Society. He was a founding and continuing member of the Atlanta Quarterback Club. He was also a member of the Buckhead Club and the Cherokee Town & Country Club. He was on the Advisory Board of Reinhardt College at Waleska, Georgia and on the Advisory Board of Our Lady of Lourdes School in Atlanta. He was a veteran of World War II having served in the Pacific Theater with the Seventh Air Force. He was an avid traveler and an active golfer. He was dedicated to his family and friends and never met a stranger. His willingness to help people in need was legendary. He is survived by his wife, Katrina Sharpe Baird Henritze, his sister, Mary Lou Carter, his children, David Henritze, Jr., Fred Henritze, Ann Blonder, Bob Henritze, and his grandchildren, Evan Henritze, Morgan Henritze, Tyler Henritze, Hunter Henritze, Porter Henritze, Parker Henritze, Reeves Henritze, Rebecca Blonder, Paige Blonder, Zachary Blonder, Robert Henritze, Jr. and Thomas Henritze. Visitation will be Monday, May 8, 2000 from 7:00 p.m - 9:00 p.m. at H.M. Patterson & Son Spring Hill Chapel. The funeral will be held on Tuesday, May 9, 2000 at 2:00 p.m. at The Cathedral of Christ the King with interment at Arlington Memorial Park Cemetery in Atlanta, Ga. In lieu of flowers, family requests contributions be made to Reinhardt College for ''The Dave Henritze Schlorship Fund'', Reinhardt College, 7300 Reinhardt College Circle, Waleska, GA 30183. For more information contact H.M. Patterson & Son Spring Hill Chapel (404) 876-1022

description: I am a female internist. A patient with a sexually transmitted disease asked that his wife -- not my patient -- be tested but not told about his extramarital affair. I worried that she might go untreated or be sent to a doctor unaware of her risk. I saw her, and she never asked about the source of her infection. As both patients are now entitled to confidentiality, I am apprehensive of conflicts of interest. Did I do right? /Anonymous

title: When Producers Strutted The Earth
description: ONE day, in the long-ago time when larger-than-life showmen reigned on Broadway, the producer Robert Whitehead had the idea of putting on staged readings in the Belasco Theater on Sunday nights, when the Odets play he was producing there was dark.

title: A Native Celt Brings His Crosses to Manhattan
description: When Mel Hamill moved to New York from Dublin, he spent time working at the Gap before recognizing that there was a niche to be filled in Celtic jewelry. He began importing jewelry and small gifts with Celtic designs for sale at flea markets in New York. After four years, he set up his silver rings ($12 to $22), jewelry boxes (about $18 to $50) and silk scarves (about $24 to $42), at a kiosk in the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne, N.J. Last month, two years later, Mr. Hamill opened a Manhattan store, Tulla Celtic Designs, at 201 East 34th Street (at Third Avenue).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 4 of the Television section today about Robert Halmi Sr. and Robert Halmi Jr., producers of ''Jason and the Argonauts,'' misidentifies the television movie that was considered their high point last year. It was ''A Christmas Carol,'' not ''Annie.''

title: New Trash Plan Gains Backing, but Problems Remain
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's latest plan to export nearly 10,000 tons of city trash a day is winning widespread praise, even from the New Jersey community that would handle most of the garbage after the city's last landfill shuts down.

title: Small-Town Cops, and Proud of It
description: A PURPLE knit outfit, valued at $238, is left overnight in the dryer at a coin laundry and is gone the next morning. A Chinese restaurant is plagued by ''false and misleading'' takeout orders, all made by the same young man.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; A Rental Apartment Tower Is Rising in Fort Lee
description: FOR years a derelict garage was all that stood on the 4.8 acre-site along the Palisades cliffs here, a symbol of a stalled condominium development from the late 1980's.

title: Susan Jackson, Eric Pomerance
description: Susan Elizabeth Jackson and Eric David Pomerance were married yesterday by the Rev. James Speer at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part in the ceremony.

title: OPINION; Stretching Limits of Free Speech
description: THE other day, I parallel parked my car next to a black van advertising the name of a contractor in Plainview on its side. On the driver's window, I couldn't help but notice an National Rifle Association decal, I guess because the N.R.A. is not one of my favorite organizations. Below that was a small black sign with white letters printed on it. It read: ''IF YOU DON'T SPEAK ENGLISH, GET THE [expletive] OUT.''

title: Made for Two Women, Remade for Two Men
description: IN the hands of the Dutch choreographer Beppie Blankert, everyday events, like waiting, watching, wondering, can become extraordinary. In 1986 she made ''Dubbelspoor'' in collaboration with the composer Louis Andriessen. ''It contains one of the supreme theatrical surprise effects of my experience,'' said Christopher Hunt, the producer of PepsiCo Summerfare in 1987 when ''Dubbelspoor'' was first performed in the United States. ''Beppie certainly isn't someone whose concern is to get the largest numbers in, but rather to do something in exactly the scale that its inner integrity requires.''

title: To DiFrancesco, Gun Control Is Simple Political Calculus
description: It is hardly unusual that a politician would want to enact tougher gun laws. It's not so unusual that he is willing to invite greater federal control over enforcement of firearm laws, and it is certainly not unusual that he should have ambitions for higher office.

title: Protest at a Lumberyard Draws Unusual Allies
description: As a union protest at a lumberyard stretched into its seventh month, community groups, religious organizations and high school students have joined workers in criticizing a business they say has locked out employees and refused to pay fair wages. The focus of the protest is Rode & Horn Lumber, a company at 90 Waterbury Street that supplies high-end wood to carpenters and furniture makers.

title: Jennifer Bush, Thomas Evans
description: Jennifer French Bush, the daughter of Virginia Jones Bush of Old Saybrook, Conn., and William Clyde Bush of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Mortimer Evans, the son of Wanda L. Plumer of Upper Marlboro, Md., and George H. Evans of Islesboro, Me. The Rev. Christopher H. Neely, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Pink Sands, a resort in Dunmore Town, Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

title: Political Briefing; A Prayer of Thanks, A Prayer of Humility
description: Speaking of religion and politics, here is the take of the Rev. Donald L. Roberts of Sarasota, Fla., as expressed in his prayer that opened the session of the Florida Senate on Thursday:

title: A Live Wire to the Brain: Hooking Up 'Hamlet'
description: IF I feel physically as if the top of my head were taken off,'' Emily Dickinson once said, ''I know that is poetry.''

description: To the Editor:

title: St. Maarten Gets Its Own Dialing Code
description: St. Maarten, the Dutch territory in the Caribbean, may not have its own island (it shares it with French St.-Martin), but it now has its own international dialing code for its telephone system. Anyone calling from another country must dial the international access code 011, plus the island's five-digit code, 599-54, and then the local number. For calls within St. Maarten, the number 54 must precede all local five-digit numbers. The tourist board suggests practicing by calling (599-54) 22337 for more information.

title: Before Plane or Saw Touch Wood, He Wants to Know Where It's From
description: ALAN HEDGES is a carpenter who hates the idea of cutting down trees.

title: Guare Rebuilds, Making His Connections Anew
description: JOHN GUARE'S play ''Gardenia'' begins in 1875 with Joshua Hickman sitting on the beach at Nantucket and reading from Walt Whitman's poem ''On the Beach at Night Alone'': ''A vast similitude interlocks all.''

title: Life Under the Billboard Blanket
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, GEORGE S.
description: MOORE-George S., 95, former Chairman and CEO of Citibank (now Citicorp), died April 21, 2000 at his home in Sotogrande, Spain. A Memorial Service will be held at 10:45AM, Monday, May 22nd at St. Vincent Ferrer's, 66th Street & Lexington Avenue, New York, NY.

title: Women and the Appeal Of Sport Utility Vehicles
description: To the Editor:

title: At 17, She Finds Herself Already on Top of the Acting Game
description: IN 1990, at age 7, Heather Matarazzo won the part of a Munchkin in a local production of ''The Wizard of Oz'' to benefit children with AIDS. Though it was hardly a starring role, she intended to give it her all. And when she noticed in rehearsal that her cast mates did not share her enthusiasm, she took matters into her own hands.

title: When a Legend Speaks, These Children Listen
description: SO I thought I'd tell you about my trip to Las Vegas,'' Lillian Vernon told the children gathered around her. Ms. Vernon, the grande dame of catalog sales, was the speaker for ''Take Your Child to Work Day,'' and about 20 children were gathered in her elegant office.

title: Rivals on Offensive as They Near Wire in Genome Race
description: The 10-year project to decode the human genome is entering its end game, but the high goal of unlocking the secrets of human heredity is ending in a fractious exchange of claims and countercharges.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: April 30-May 6; On Again, Off Again
description: Senate Republican leaders took one look at the famous photograph of an immigration agent holding a submachine gun near a cowering Elian Gonzalez and rushed to call hearings into the Little Havana raid. But after public opinion surveys showed vast support for the raid, they softened their language and uncharacteristically retreated from a public inquiry. Most senators now say the inquiry is best handled on paper, behind closed doors. LIZETTE ALVAREZ

title: His Days Are Numbered
description: MR. PHILLIPS

title: A 'Gone With the Wind' Theater, But Does Anyone Give a Damn?
description: Edna Mamula vividly remembers the first time she entered the Olympia Theater at Broadway and 107th Street. She was 19 and the movie was ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKLE, JEROME
description: GARFINKLE-Jerome. Died on May 4, 2000, in Great Neck, NY. Born in Riga, Latvia, on March 10, 1906. Beloved husband of Raye Gewirtz Garfinkle for 66 years, father of Helen Garfinkle of Tucson, AZ, and Ann Garfinkle-Brent of Washington, DC, grandfather of Duncan, David and William Brent, and great-grandfather of Malcolm and Eli Brent, of Silver Spring, MD. Jerome led a full and satisfying life, filled with love. He founded Youthful Fashions, worked as a manufacturer of women's dresses until he was 88 years old. Fishing and gardening were his passions with many neighbors and friends enjoying his fresh fish and tomatoes. He was a mensch. Services Monday, 9:45 AM, at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Rd. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing on Page 52 of Arts & Leisure today includes an outdated entry for the musical ''Thunder Knocking on the Door,'' which was to open on June 11 at the Minetta Lane Theater. It has been withdrawn from production.

title: Kavita Amin, Brian Stern
description: Kavita Pankaj Amin, the daughter of Neena Amin and Dr. Pankaj Amin of North Woodmere, N.Y., was married yesterday to Brian Alan Stern, the son of Deborah and Richard Stern of Allenwood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, performed a ceremony that combined Hindu and Protestant themes at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York.

title: Robin Alperstein, Seth Gross
description: Robin Lee Alperstein and Seth David Gross were married last evening by Cantor Oreen Zeitlin at the Manhattan Penthouse in New York.

title: Food; Big Bird
description: Early in the morning, the young and the hungry surf the Web for arcane food facts, entertaining tips and fanciful recipes. When dinner is still in the distance, people can afford to dream.

title: Brown Solidifies Eastern Ranking
description: Brown University's heavyweight squad, undefeated in varsity, junior varsity and freshman competition and ranked first among Eastern crews, solidified its ranking yesterday, convincingly defeating Princeton in all three categories under ideal racing conditions on the Tigers' home Lake Carnegie course.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Fish Caught in Time

title: UNION CHIEF REBUFFED
description: The county's new commissioner of emergency services, Patrick T. Kelly, has rejected a labor leader's call to consider replacing volunteer firefighters throughout the county with paid firefighters. ''The concept that a volunteer fire department provides adequate fire and emergency protection is the biggest illusion since Houdini,'' Anthony Pagano, president of the Yonkers Professional Firefighters Union, said in a statement last week, two days after Mr. Kelly's appointment. On Wednesday, Mr. Kelly -- a former division chief of the Baltimore County Fire Department in Maryland -- replied, saying: ''My job is not to determine whether paid fire service is better than volunteer service. My job is to work within the system that's here and make it operate the best it can.'' ELSA BRENNER

title: BENEFITS
description: Remembering Broadway

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, HOWARD J.
description: SERWER-Howard J. On May 3, 2000 in Washington, D.C. He was Professor Emeritus of Musicology of The University of Maryland, College Park, and resided in Chevy Chase, MD., and Georgetown, ME. He leaves his wife Nancy Rose, sons Nicholas and Andrew, daughter-in-law Frances Fifield and grandchildren Emily and Katherine. A memorial gathering of friends and family will be held at 12:00 noon on Wednesday, May 10, 2000 in the Memorial Chapel of The University of Maryland, College Park, MD. The family asks that remembrances be made in the form of donations in Howard's name to The Performing Arts Library of The University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN WORMER, BENJAMIN F.
description: VAN WORMER-Benjamin F., of West Norwalk, Connecticut on Thursday, May 4th, a retired Senior Vice President of American Standard, Inc. Husband of Marjorie. Father of Frances and Laura Van Wormer and Susan and Robert Ault. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, May 10th at 11:00 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1848 Boston Post Rd., Darien, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to The Benjamin F. Van Wormer Memorial Fund, St. Lawrence University, Canton, NY 13617.

title: Lives; Secrets of the Confessional
description: The first time I heard confession was a couple of weeks after my ordination in 1973, at St. Matthew's Cathedral in Washington, D.C., where John F. Kennedy's requiem Mass was celebrated. The penitent was a tourist who had wandered in almost by accident. ''I was on my way to a McDonald's,'' he said, ''but I saw the church and remembered Kennedy's funeral -- then I noticed the little green light in the confessional, so I came in. I'm not really sure of what I want.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYDECKER, SALLY MCCORMICK
description: LYDECKER-Sally McCormick, 85, of 88 Notch Hill Road, North Branford, CT died January 20, 2000 at Yale New Haven Hospital. She was the widow of Garrit A. Lydecker. She was born in Leonia, NJ, August 8, 1914, a daughter of the late Howard and Josephine Newell McCormick. She was a longstanding member of Darien Book Aid Plan and the Rowayton (CT) Garden Club. She is survived by two daughters Nancy L. Jones of Newton, MA, Laura Carr of Park Hall, MD, two sons Robert Lydecker of Windsor, John Lydecker of Winsted and six grandchildren. She was predeceased by a sister Nancy M. Scott and a brother Peter Newell McCormick. For information contact Oak Grove Cremation Service, West Haven, CT.

title: Tess Finnegan, Laurent Pavageau
description: Catherine Jennifer Finnegan, the daughter of Carolyn La Corte of Cranford, N.J., and the late William R. Finnegan III, was married yesterday to Laurent Charles Pavageau, a son of Philippe Pavageau of Versailles, France, and the late Roxanne Pavageau. The Rev. Lupton Abshire performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Clinton; Gritty Gives Way to Gentrification
description: THOUGH the western chunk of Midtown that its boosters call Clinton may be proud of its gritty Hell's Kitchen past, the streets where gangs once roamed are yielding to the tides of gentrification. Housing prices may be lower than in other areas of Manhattan, but now they are catching up, real estate brokers say.

title: IN BRIEF; Technology Concern Recruits At Schools and Colleges
description: To meet the demand for information technology workers, U.S. Information Systems of Nyack is recruiting at schools and colleges in Westchester, Rockland and Orange Counties. The voice and data technology company employs 300 workers and wants to hire 100 to 150 more, at pay of $12 to $15 an hour, with benefits.

title: On TV, a Loss of Independents
description: FOR more than two decades, Robert Greenwald, a prolific television producer, has owned the films he made, which gave him the leverage to do such Emmy Award-winning shows as ''The Burning Bed'' and ''A Woman of Independent Means.'' But now Mr. Greenwald, and every other producer of films and series, is under powerful pressure to yield to the networks and allow them to own more and more of their shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCAT, ESTHER
description: DUCAT-Esther, 85, died April 29th. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, superb teacher, will live on in hearts of those lives she touched.

title: Where Indian Dishes Lead to the Unexpected
description: GRIM'' was one guest's reaction to the decor of the new Tandoori Taste of India in New Canaan.

title: School Outing Ends in Tragedy and a Hail of 'If Onlys'
description: UNTIL three weeks ago, Karen and Robert Pace had been eagerly looking forward to the graduation of their son, Robert D. Pace, from Riverhead High School. Now they are setting up a memorial fund in their son's name dedicated to preventing what happened to him from happening to anyone else's child.

title: Eugenie Diserio and Bill Buttenwieser
description: AS the founder of Astronet.com, an astrology Web site, Eugenie Diserio will gladly, even proudly, tell you that until recently she experienced plenty of setbacks, broken hearts, horrific blind dates, cars that broke down and unemployment. To her, life is about cycles -- caused by moons and planets moving in and out of one's celestial house -- and at 45 she's been through plenty of them.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Air Vacations
description: This is the time of year when affluent families begin planning their summer getaways to the seashore or the mountains. But for millions of New York City kids, there is no escape from a city that seems to get hotter every summer. The best they can hope for is a splash or two in an overcrowded pool or under a fire-hydrant sprinkler.

title: All Things Considered
description: To the Editor:

title: PERFORMANCE-BASED GRANTS
description: In the first year of a program rewarding New Jersey's 31 public universities, colleges and community colleges for good performance, schools were awarded $8 million in grants for good performance, or 92 percent of the amount of money available. The grants are based on universities' and colleges' performance in such areas as graduation rates, numbers of transfers, the diversity of funding sources and efficiency (cooperation with other institutions and having optimum enrollment in classes). Rutgers University (awarded $2.8 million) and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey ($1.7 million) got the highest ratings. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: A Long Test for Offshore Beach Cats
description: Awash in the nautical lexicon are a sea of oxymorons -- small gale, light anchor, jumbo shrimp -- that at first take seem like contradictions, but which upon further review are marvels of concise description. But tomorrow, off Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a race begins that is centered on a waterborne concept -- offshore beach catamarans -- that many find impossible to grasp.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about obstacles faced by cultural groups in renting space misstated the ownership of the Joyce Theater in Manhattan. Although leased to the Joyce Theater Foundation, it is owned by the Ballet Tech Foundation.

title: Rain? In Spain
description: For all of its 18 years, only money has rained on the Frederick Law Olmsted Awards luncheon given by the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. In the Conservatory Garden at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, the event on Wednesday raised $3 million. Over the years it has raised $230 million to restore the park. In a setting that suggested the ''My Fair Lady'' Ascot scene in modern dress, 1,200 guests, including 100 men, entered through the Vanderbilt Gate. As Andrea Lans, a guest, said of the hundreds of women wearing hats, ''I just love being a girl.''

title: Rise in Cases of Mad Cow Disease Alarms Europe
description: At first the veterinarian said that it might just be milk fever. Then the possibility of a brain tumor was discussed. But as the laboratory took longer and longer to report test results, Guy Jambon accepted the inevitable. One of his herd had been infected with mad cow disease, although no cases had ever been detected in this southeast region of France.

title: A Nightmarish Drop Through the Safety Net
description: SHE remembers the last moments of her old life. It had turned into a bright May afternoon and she was on Broadway, feeding quarters into a pay telephone on which she called friend after friend asking to spend the night. She could not reach anyone.

title: Ideas & Trends: Nasdaq Roadshow; Feeding America's Craving for Value
description: IT has been a season of dizzying highs, record lows and amateurs rushing in.

title: From Here to Where?
description: BONNIE KRAMEN, who started a new job in Manhattan last September as business manager for the actress Olympia Dukakis, was driving home one night and saw a sign on the Jersey City side of the Holland Tunnel that read ''Newport Mall.''

title: A Tale of 2 Schools, but Only 1 Building
description: SCHOOL enrollments are burgeoning around the state, and cities and towns are scrambling to find space in which to put all these students. Some are reopening long-closed schools; others are building new ones.

title: Contest That Rewards Pupils' Mental Agility
description: UNLESS you are a trained actor, chances are the thought of performing an improvisational skit in front of strangers is terrifying.

title: Poaching as a Way to Cook Meat, Fish and Poultry
description: POACHING is often overlooked as a method of cooking meat, fish and poultry, but it offers several advantages: it's uncomplicated. Once you grasp the technique, it is extremely useful for preparing a dish that can be served hot or cold. And it is low in fat. All you need alongside is sauce or a condiment, assembed from scratch or bought in a store.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Caroline Summers Bruce misspelled the surname of the bridegroom and his parents. He is Sean David Hector Macaulay, not Macauley. His parents are Pauline Macaulay and Iain Macaulay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, ANN LOUISE
description: BECKERMAN-Ann Louise. Precious daughter. Loving sister to Dan and the late Larry. A young woman of beauty, grace and warmth. An accomplished poet and gifted teacher. Her kindness and intelligence touched all who knew and loved her. To Ann's many friends, who visited and encouraged her, we give our thanks.

title: Small Provider Sees Gain in Cable TV Fight
description: The dispute between the Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Cable that blacked out ABC television for about 1.8 million New Yorkers on Monday and Tuesday provided an unexpected business opportunity to a small telecommunications company based in New Jersey.

title: PULSE: MOTHERS DAY -- GIFTS A MOTHER COULD LOVE; Mother's Little Helpers
description: Mom's gone millennial on you, listening to trance music, practicing Bikram yoga and declaring her pearl choker ''too Mrs. Simpson.'' So give her a piece from Britain's hottest jewelry designer, Stephen Webster, as a token of support for her transformation. London-style queens (including expatriated Madonna with child) clamor for large and in-charge Webster designs. For his signature Crystal Haze collection, he layers faceted crystal over colored stone for a prism effect. Surrounded with diamonds, his rings, bracelets and earrings, from $3,500, are the jewelry equivalent of a meteor shower. For more glam moms, there are the Rose and Crown rings: stones like chalcedony set in diamonds, from $2,800. At Michael Eigen: 1200 Madison Avenue, at 88th Street. SARAH MILLER

title: Witness to the Terror Of a Caged Woman
description: HER married name is Hedda Tesman but it is not her rightful one, so don't dare to use it. If you do, she will be displeased, and Hedda is the classic case study of a woman who doesn't forget and doesn't forgive.

description: BURKE-Edward J. Sr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward J. Burke Sr., associated with The Times from 1949 until retiring in 1993.

title: INVESTING WITH: John Montgomery; Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company Portfolio
description: ON Sunday mornings, John Montgomery plays the flute with a folk-rock group at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church in Houston. On Tuesday evenings, he rehearses for three hours with the group's vocalists and other musicians. ''We could really use a drummer,'' he complains.

title: In 2000, a 1928 Opera Still Sings
description: FASTER than you can say switchblade, and with little more than a week to go before the opening curtain, ''Three Penny Opera'' got a new Ballad Singer. Mike Harvey has replaced the hip-hop artist Cee-Lo (who canceled at the last minute for personal reasons).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMKO, DOLORES C.
description: SIMKO-Dolores C. On May 1, 2000. Beloved daughter of Albina Taylor of Cleveland, OH. Memorial services at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave, NYC, at 6 PM, Wednesday, May 10. Donations in her memory may be made to the Gay Men's Health Crisis or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: A&P Store in White Plains To House Apartments
description: A shuttered A&P store on Main Street in White Plains is being sold to an apartment developer. The broker for the deal, Martin Deitch, said the buyer, whom he would not identify, is seeking zoning approval for stores on the street level and apartments above. The developer would raze the existing structure and rebuild, possibly also building on the parking area behind the store. The 1998 closing of the store, which served many elderly and disabled people who live in the neighborhood, angered the community and the city. ELSA BRENNER

title: Surfin' N.Y.C.; If These Rockaway Beach Boys Catch a Wave, They're Sitting on Top of the World
description: IF you live in Manhattan and don't have a car, a walk to the subway before dawn is the first step to surf the closest waves. Winds channel between Midtown buildings and try to pry the surfboard loose from a tight grip. Gusts kick trash along the street. Revelers in bulky black leather shoes stagger listlessly, untroubled by the early-morning chill. Though the sting of winter has long since left the air, the water temperature still hovers at 43 degrees in late April. In the meantime, there is the warmth of an empty corner on an A train.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, F. AUSTIN
description: WALTER-F. Austin. Age 89, May 1, 2000. Esteemed teacher, musician, friend. Memorial service May 21, 3 PM, Kirkpatrick Chapel, Rutgers University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIN, MURRAY
description: CURTIN-Murray. On May 3, 2000, at age 66, after a short illness. Graduate of Hamilton College, Heidelberg University and Oxford University. He would want to be remembered as former Editor-inChief and Publisher of the Random House College Department, literary agent and ''Village type.'' Survived by his twin sister Ann Curtin, loving daughters Arielle Curtin and Becky Curtin, grandchildren Chadeayne and Rees Curtin-De Tar. No service will be held. Donations in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Palliative Care Center would be appreciated. Rest in peace Dad, we love you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNETTA, DORIS MILENA
description: BRUNETTA-Doris Milena Fugazy. On May 5, 2000. Devoted wife of Frank Brunetta and late Louis V. Fugazy. Loving mother and mother-in-law to Louis and Madlyn Fugazy, Milena and Francis Del Torto, Christopher & Laurie Fugazy, Susan & Jeffrey Behrendt, Steven & Michelle Fugazy, and Doris Fugazy, Jr. Adoring Nanni (grandmother) to Amanda & Scott Brennan, Danielle, Louis, Brian, Nicole, E.J., Mathew, McKenzie, Francis, Michael, Stevie, Alex, and Julia Anne. Doris is also survived by her in-laws, Sister Irene Fugazy and William D. & Joan Fugazy. Visiting will be Sunday and Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY. Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at Holy Family Church in New Rochelle, NY. Committal service to follow at Ferncliff Chapel in Hartsdale, NY. title: QUICK BITE/Bayonne; Light Rail and a Light Meal
description: Suppose in 1923, you asked a fortune teller to envision Bayonne in the year 2000. ''I see hot dogs and a train'' would seem like a lazy and short-sighted response. Neverthless, it would be prescient. The train is the new Hudson-Bergen Light Rail, which runs from Bayonne to Jersey City, and will eventually link 32 northeast Jersey stations. And the hot dogs are provided by Petridis just as they were in 1923.

title: MUSIC; The Latest Nonconformist From Nashville West
description: NASHVILLE has long touted itself as the Country Music Capital of the World, and there's no denying it: the city emerged as the hub of the country recording industry during the 1950's. But dating almost that far back, Nashville has had a pesky, if unlikely, rival: Bakersfield, Calif., a town at the southern end of the San Joaquin Valley rich in cotton, oil, truck stops and dance halls.

title: Laura Chittick, Graham Goodkin
description: Laura Vickers Chittick, the daughter of Dr. Marilyn Vickers and Dr. William Chittick, both of Athens, Ga., was married yesterday to Graham Laird Goodkin, the son of Helen and Michael Goodkin of Manhattan. The Rev. Martha Fulmer Smith performed the ceremony at St. James United Methodist Church in Athens.

title: Bannister Favors More Drug Testing
description: Roger Bannister, the first person to run a sub-four-minute mile, said today he thought that increased use of blood testing could help curb the use of performance-enhancing drugs by track and field athletes.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions last Sunday with an article about the improved financial outlook of the utility industry after deregulation misstated the location of a Pennsylvania power plant that the Duquesne Light Company has agreed to sell to Orion Power Holdings. Though it is called the Cheswick plant, it is in Springdale, Pa.

title: Voice of Hope in Kosovo Tells the U.S. of Goals
description: For all the problems of Kosovo today, Veton Surroi, the publisher of the province's largest newspaper, reminds himself that things could be much worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOWE, ALEXANDER ROBERT
description: SHOWE-Alexander Robert. Born July 14, 1920, died May 5, 2000. Mr. Showe passed after a sudden illness in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Showe was born in Papa, Hungary. He graduated from a private preparatory school and came to the United States in 1939 to study at Columbia University. He served as a M.A.S.H. medic in the United States Army, stationed in the Pacific. After the war, Mr. Showe married Janet Lehrfeld of Philadelphia, PA. He is survived by his daughter, Mrs. Katherine Elizabeth Chavkin of Manhattan and his son Alan Robert Showe of Manhattan. His wife Janet Lehrfeld Showe predeceased him in 1994. In addition, he is survived by his two granddaughters Ms. Jessica Chavkin and Ms. Arielle Chavkin as well as his son-in-law Jeffrey Stuart Chavkin. Mr. Showe was President and founder of Showe Furniture and Showe Realty. He was associated with Scott Gordon Realty. He was founding member of the Bank of New Haven and served on various civic, business and charitable boards in both Connecticut and Florida. Among other positions, he most recently served as Chairman of Israel Cancer Association, USA. He will be remembered by many friends in Connecticut, New York, Florida and around the world. Services on Monday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 91 Street.

title: Street Scenes Revisited

The images range from small black-and-white prints of Mr. Racioppo's family to large color panoramas of sprawling urban landscapes. Mr. Racioppo was born and raised in South Brooklyn, lives in Belle Harbor, Queens, and has photographed his city since 1970. He said of the exhibition: ''It is really a look at the city and how the city has changed over the years I have been photographing it. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Timeless Passage
description: In 1853, when the federal government authorized five Army expeditions to survey the West for a transcontinental railroad route, there was a conspicuous absentee in the command structure: John C. Fremont, whose exploits in the Rockies and Sierra Nevada had captivated the nation's imagination. But Fremont's fourth western expedition, in the winter of 1848, had ended disastrously, with 10 of his men dead of cold or starvation, and he was passed over. Undeterred, Fremont mounted his own mission, with the foolhardy notion that he would make a wintertime passage across the mountains of Colorado, Utah, Nevada and California. Fremont also brought along a New York painter and photographer, Solomon Nunes Carvalho. The expedition failed in the snowy Wasatch Range of Utah, where the men froze and starved until they were saved by Mormon pioneers. Though the effort proved nothing in practical terms, it had passed through some of the most dramatic midwinter terrain in North America, and Carvalho captured an extraordinary visual record on the fragile copper plates of his daguerreotypes. Although the images were copied on steel engravings, the actual daguerreotypes were destroyed in 1881 along with Fremont's journals in a New York warehouse fire. In 1994 Robert Shlaer, a former biologist turned art photographer, who had mastered daguerreotypy, began a four-year odyssey to retrace the four-month-long Fremont expedition in a specially equipped darkroom van. He painstakingly reproduced Carvalho's images with the still difficult old process. SIGHTS ONCE SEEN: Daguerreotyping Fremont's Last Expedition Through the Rockies (Museum of New Mexico, $45), containing 126 haunting, finely-detailed modern daguerreotypes, depicts some of the West's wildest scenery, most of it virtually unchanged after 150 years. The illustrations are augmented by many period engravings, paintings by Carvalho, and a number of Shlaer's helpful but less artistic record shots. His text freely draws on historic sources as well as his equally fascinating attempts to identify unlabeled 1853 views and to duplicate exactly Carvalho's vantage points. David Haward Bain

Sure, there have been protections, protests, campaigns to save the country's true-love resources. But even those efforts were just placating diversions, as we learned last week, when an independent agency reported that the heralded True Love Protection Act of 1977 was too soft from the beginning, was a hole-plagued butterfly-net kind of legislation and that we haven't really protected anything at all. Since 1930, when scientists started accurately measuring true-love levels, we have been losing it at a rate of 4 percent a year. In the past 20 years, those years since the act, the rate of loss is at 11 percent per year. Appalling.

title: Where to Connect to the Inner Hum
description: On a gray afternoon I sit in a silent room and contemplate din. In the street a single car passes -- a rapid bass vowel -- and then it is quiet again. So what is this uproar, this hubbub, this heaving rumble of zigzag static I keep hearing? This echo chamber spooling out spirals of chaos? An unmistakable noise as clearly mine as fingerprint or twist of DNA: the thrum of regret, of memory, of defeat, of mutability, of bitter fear, made up of shame and ambition and anger and vanity and wishing. The soundtrack of a movie of the future, an anticipatory ribbon of scenes long dreaded, or daydreams without a prayer of materializing. Or else: the replay of unforgotten conversations, humiliating, awkward, indelible. Mainly it is the buzz of the inescapably mundane, the little daily voice that insists and insists: right now, not now, too late, too soon, why not, better not, turn it on, turn it off, notice this, notice that, be sure to take care of, remember not to. The nonstop chatter that gossips, worries, envies, invokes, yearns, condemns, self-condemns.
