title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JOHN CARDINAL
description: O'CONNOR-John Cardinal. The Board of Trustees and staff of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center and Saint Agnes Hospital and Children's Rehabilitation Center acknowledge with a deep sense of personal loss the passing of His Eminence, John Cardinal O'Connor. His Eminence made extraordinary personal contributions to health care and education and tireless efforts to reestablish and revitalize the essential Catholic mission, that of providing the highest quality health care for everyone. We at Our Lady Of Mercy Medical Center were very honored that His Eminence allowed us to name our Medical Center Campus at East 233rd Street in the Bronx in his honor. His Eminence had a particular fondness for our program at Rosalie Hall, our 28bed residence and shelter program for single mothers. He was very grateful that our medical center had a strong interest in the elderly, as well as our fragile newborns. He always emphasized the importance of taking care of the needs of those just entering the world and those at the end of life. The lives that he touched will never be the same. We will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, the auxiliary bishops and priests, religious and laity of the Archdiocese of New York. Edwin S. Mruk, Chairman Board of Trustees, The Catholic Health Care System and Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System William F. Harrington, Esq. Chairman, Board of Trustees Saint Agnes Hospital and Children's Rehabilitation Center Gary S. Horan, FACHE President and Chief Executive Officer, Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System Sister Diane Prusinski, s.m. Executive Director, Rosalie Hall

title: The Detective and the Disaster
description: ''The humanity!'' So goes the familiar radio lament from an announcer witnessing the explosion of the Hindenburg at Lakehurst, 63 years ago yesterday, which killed 66. Equally familiar is the conclusion that leaking hydrogen was ignited by lightning or static electricity. But on May 17 at 8 p.m., PBS will broadcast one in a series provocatively called ''Secrets of the Dead,'' which changes the story. It introduces a retired NASA scientist named Addison Bain, an advocate of hydrogen fuel, who notes that the ball of flame was red; hydrogen burns blue. He conducts research, finds a piece of the blimp's cloth cover, performs tests and concludes it was that cover, coated with powdered aluminum and iron oxide (the ingredients in rocket fuel), that caught fire. Besides being a gripping scientific detective tale, the episode is a reminder of the days when airships provided a combination of speed and luxury, something like a cross between the Titanic and the Concorde, and a landing at Lakehurst was something to behold, until May 17, 1937.

The department is asking residents to call the West Nile Virus Hotline (637-4926) to report dead birds, and it is dropping a larvicide, which prevents mosquito larvae from becoming adults, into 50,000 catch basins. The county is also urging residents to help reduce the mosquito population by removing unnecessary water containers, by covering trash containers to keep out rain and by turning over plastic wading pools and wheelbarrows when not in use. Also, homeowners should make sure that window screens fit tightly and are in good repair. ELSA BRENNER

title: Give Their Regards To Nasdaq Plaza
description: After putting its stamp on Times Square with an eight-story digital billboard, Nasdaq has now asked the city to put the stock market's name on the southeast corner of 43rd Street and Broadway.

title: Footlights; Music Teachers Pick Winners
description: Woodwinds and strings reigned at this year's scholarship competition sponsored by the Music Teachers Council of Westchester. Judging for the contest, geared to accomplished high school seniors aspiring to professional careers in music, took place last Sunday in the White Plains studio of Robert Canfield, a pianist and longtime council member.

description: AS a child singing in a professional choir, Harold Rosenbaum suffered such acute stage fright that it almost ended his career.

title: Bookend; Second Thoughts
description: Stephen Spender, the British poet, expressed astonishment when we told him we were rewriting our biography of Eugene O'Neill, which had been in print for 32 years. The occasion was a small dinner party in Sir Stephen's honor in 1994 at the New York Public Library.

title: Surprise! The Price May Grow
description: HOMEBUYERS know that they are often required to pay several thousand dollars in closing costs to complete the deal. But while the types and amounts of those costs are usually predictable, real estate experts say that buyers of apartments in New York City -- particularly when the apartment is in a recent conversion or a newly constructed building -- may be in for some unpleasant surprises.

description: How old are you?

description: To the Editor:

title: Morality; The Good Lie
description: After reading the results of this poll, you'd have to say that lying to protect someone's feelings is as American as enriching your life by having children, almost as American as not ever having done yoga, and more American than thinking you are too fat or feeling guilty about a thing or two you did when you were younger. On the other hand, lying to protect someone's feelings is not nearly as American as thinking that being American is a big part of who you are.

title: Lodges in Africa That Make a Case For Settling In
description: GLAMOROUS as they may be by reputation, game safaris in East Africa, whether tented or otherwise, have never been truly luxurious, nor did most people expect them to be.

title: Identity; American Dreaming
description: Of all our national traits, I find it the most singular, the most astonishing, the most appalling and heartbreaking, and the one that most sets us apart from the rest of the self-describing world. Is it possible in America to be pretty much who you want to be? More of us think so than believe in life after death.

title: Medical Help On the Web
description: THE International Society of Travel Medicine has spent hours of its biennial conventions since it was formed in 1989 debating how to tell people that travel in the developing world is not like being in Kansas: that malaria is a reality in particular areas, that motor-vehicle crashes are a more severe hazard than Japanese encephalitis, that diarrhea is a frequent problem in the tropics. Slips inserted into airline ticket jackets were discussed, as well as in-flight filmstrips, data sheets to be distributed by travel agents or even folders for brochure racks.

title: 12 Awarded Grants
description: A new college scholarship program, which recognizes academic achievement among low-income high school students, has named 12 students from Westchester public high schools as its first recipients. Each will receive $10,000 over four years to help pay for college.

title: Charlotte Cudlip, Perry Bartol
description: Charlotte Luxmore Cudlip, the daughter of Mrs. David S. Dickenson II of Gates Mills, Ohio, and Charles T. Cudlip of Washington, was married yesterday to Perry Lewis Bartol, the son of Melanie Smith of Southport, Conn., and Peter W. Bartol of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Dr. Luis Leon officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Gregory Jones, a cousin of the bridegroom and an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Affordable New Houses, Go East, Young Buyers
description: IN this still-rural enclave of Suffolk County where woods and fields have not yet given way to surburban sprawl, Uri Hason and his partner, Avi Sharabani, are carving a 76-house subdivision out of the scrub oak forest. Starting prices of $184,900 for a three-bedroom ranch and a top price of $237,900 for 2,000-square-foot, four-bedroom colonial are giving young couples buying their first homes a chance to get into the housing market.

title: Does the Smell of Coffee Brewing Remind You of Your Mother
description: What is your deepest thought about, say, coffee? Not Colombian versus Sumatran, latte or espresso; forget that. What I want to know is, when you are thinking about coffee, really thinking, what do you think about? It doesn't really matter. I already know what you think, and besides, you're wrong.

description: POLITICAL strategies come and go, but this one endures: never underestimate the political potency of motherhood.

description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a week at Phoenix Valley Elderhostel, I really commiserated with Julia Duffy Ward (''On the Road to Reform -- The Traveler Within,'' March 12).

title: In Czech Jail Without Bars, Women Tend To the Elderly
description: Martina Holmanova, a cheerful blonde in her early 20's, is a convicted criminal serving two years for assisting armed robbery. She is also, as part of an experiment that contrasts starkly with the overcrowded, underfinanced prisons common in the Czech Republic, a nurse who has learned to delight 90 elderly patients with her animated puppet shows.

title: New Questions On Drug Plans As Costs Soar
description: Americans took home some 2.8 billion prescriptions last year, obtaining some of the newest, most heavily advertised and most expensive drugs. They bought many of those medications as members of managed care drug plans run by pharmacy benefit managers, companies that arrange discounts from retail drugstores and often operate mail-order pharmacies on behalf of employer health plans.

title: A Good Address
description: ON a beautiful spring night in Montclair, it felt right choosing Twenty Eight for dinner. Ducking under the bowing, flowering pear trees, I entered the restaurant feeling confident and unencumbered, for it has a clear sense of style and ease. It allows you to relax and makes you pleased to be doing so. Twenty Eight is just that -- just right.

title: Buzz Off: Secret Bars That Spurn Hype
description: AT 1:30 a.m. on a recent Saturday, Milk & Honey, a tiny bar on the Lower East Side, was jammed for one of the few times since it opened in January. But instead of feeling elated, the 27-year-old owner, who had barely been able to make the rent until a few weeks ago, scooped up the discarded martini glasses and cast a disapproving eye on the cheery crowd.

title: Here Comes The Mother Of the Bride
description: FRETTING over what to wear to her daughter's wedding, Ilene Beckerman experienced an instant of panic. ''Everybody remembers Princess Diana's wedding dress, but who remembers what her mother wore?'' she told herself soothingly. ''Nobody pays attention to the mother of the bride.''

title: TAX CREDITS
description: More than 280,000 low-income New Jerseyans with jobs would be eligible for state income tax refunds under a bill passed unanimously by the Assembly appropriations committee last week. The bill would provide tax refunds to families that have at least one child and earn less than $20,000 a year. Eligible families would get a check equivalent to 10 percent of their federal income tax credit, and within four years that amount would rise to 20 percent. WENDY GINSBERG

description: To the Editor:

She was 65 and lived at the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood.

When someone like Bobby Grier leaves the game, a longtime football man who has survived four owners and eight head coaches, his career goes under the microscope, and everyone takes a turn with the scalpel, picking and dissecting.

Kenneth Bauer, 52, of Long Beach, the L.I.R.R.'s vice president and chief financial officer, was named acting president.

title: For Expatriate Families, A Home Away From Home; Foreign Enclaves Dot the Landscape as County Attracts Temporary Residents
description: IT is a glorious spring morning, the daffodils standing at attention outside Bernice Woodbury's white Colonial on one of Scarsdale's prettiest streets. Inside are nine women, babies and toddlers in tow, eating bagels and swapping shopping tips and vacation ideas. But in one important way this is not a typical Westchester play group: the happy chatter has the long, flat accent of Australia, with a sprinkle of New Zealand and Scotland.

title: Songs About Hard Knocks and Sweet Love

While those who have seen his intense performances or have heard his award-winning 1996 debut, ''Big Dead Waltz,'' rave about his artistry, there are still many who have never heard of him.

title: Married, With a Yard
description: OVER a half-century ago in England a woman named Margery worked for an autocratic newspaper editor named Walter Fish. Eventually the two married, retired to the country, and created a garden. Margery Fish described their triumphs, tribulations and disagreements in her 1956 book, ''We Made a Garden.''

title: Why Is It So Attractive? Who Knows. Ask a Goat.
description: Jim Parker never intended to be a goat herder, nor did he ask to become a stop on the underground livestock railway for animals fleeing the local slaughterhouse.

description: The first time Vladimir V. Putin deserted Moscow and staged a meeting with a visiting head of state here, Russians hardly noticed.

title: The Real Clemens May Have Arrived
description: Roger Clemens pumped his last fastball of a gorgeous yet draining day, a high heater that roared by Rich Amaral for the final out in the seventh inning and caused most of the 54,350 fans at Yankee Stadium to rise and cheer. Clemens exhaled and trudged ever so slowly to the dugout, pulling his glove off, wiping the sweat off his forehead and ending a quality day of work.

description: GAIL THORSON'S life changed forever when she got the call that her son Matthew Gross had been shot at the top of the Empire State Building. That is why Ms. Thorson will join women from across the country as they come together in Washington, D.C., next Sunday, Mother's Day, to march for stronger gun control legislation.

description: Fusaichi Pegasus, the $4 million colt named for the flying horse of mythology, came flying through the homestretch at Churchill Downs today to win the 126th Kentucky Derby by a length and a half over Aptitude and give further evidence that racing has a brilliant new star.

The Park Service put the pass on sale last month in cooperation with its nonprofit partner, the National Park Foundation. For those arriving on foot, the pass admits the purchaser, spouse, parents and children.

title: IN BREAKTHROUGH, I.R.A. WILL ALLOW ARMS INSPECTIONS
description: The Irish Republican Army offered today to open its secret arsenal of weapons to international inspection as a way of meeting peace negotiators' demands that it ''completely and verifiably'' put its arms beyond use.

title: THE ARTS; Arts Center Receives Two Big Grants
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center received grants of $5 million last week.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00; Coming Into The Country
description: In the Old World, there was one way of life, or 2, maybe 10. Here there are dozens, hundreds, all jammed in together, cheek by jowl, especially in the dizzying cities. Everywhere has a somewhere else just around the corner. We newish Americans leapfrog from world to world, reinventing ourselves en route. We perform our college selves, our waitress selves, our dot-com selves, our parent selves, our downtown selves, our Muslim, Greek, Hindi, South African selves. Even into the second or third generation, we speak different languages -- more languages, often, than we know we know. We sport different names. I am Gish, Geesh, Jen, Lillian, Lil, Bilien, Ms. Jen, Miss Ren, Mrs. O'Connor. Or maybe we insist on one name. The filmmaker Mira Nair, for example, will be called NIGH-ear, please; she is not a depilatory product.

title: Self-portrait; NAN GOLDIN
description: My work has been about making a record of my life that no one can revise. I photograph myself in times of trouble or change in order to find the ground to stand on in the change. I was coming out of a melancholic phase. This was taken when I was traveling extensively, on the road from hotel to hotel. You get displaced, and then taking self-portraits becomes a way of hanging on to yourself.

title: For Countless People, O'Connor Was a Source of Compassion and Strength
description: Cardinal John O'Connor reached out to countless people, as a priest, a counselor, and above all, a human being. Those whose lives were touched by the cardinal remembered a compassionate man who listened, avidly and carefully, a man whose active presence was as memorable as his eminence.

title: Foreigners Leaving Sierra Leone; More Troops Missing
description: Foreigners and officials with international relief groups left Sierra Leone today, as the United Nations reported no progress in obtaining the release of more than 300 of its peacekeepers and civilians kidnapped during clashes last week with the rebel Revolutionary United Front.

title: For Home Furnishings, A New Store in a 'Mecca'
description: After two years at 112 West 72nd Street (at Columbus Avenue), Hudson Dry Goods opened a second location at 873 Broadway (between 18th and 19th Streets) last month. Kimberlee Hanson, the buyer and a co-founder of the stores, said she and the proprietor, Richard Beyda, were ''working on finding the right location for over two years,'' and finally discovered a 14,000-square-foot space in an area of Manhattan she called the ''mecca of home furnishing.''

title: A Dissenting Voice On Hunting
description: The question and answer session with Commissioner Arthur J. Rocque of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection (March 26) leaves more questions for your readers than answers. Without shame, Mr. Rocque unabashedly supports his small minority of hunters at the mortal peril of the state's majority.

title: Reliving Yesterdays
description: 'Na Vota, in Piedmont dialect, means ''olden times.'' At Cantine Sant'Agata this label relives yesterdays when locals turned backyard grapes like the obscure, rustic ruche into homemade wine. In the late 1980's, the authorities endowed a few villages with an appellation, Ruche di Castagnole Monferrato, and the personal grape went commercial.

title: Emissary of a Higher Country
description: Cardinal O'Connor made a lot of people sore when he relayed his positions on abortion, homosexuality and birth control. His critics were immobilized, when all was said and done, by his defense. It was that his mission, as head of the church in New York, was to give the views of his church. This warrant grates a little in the popular hearing of it: he is, after all, an American. Isn't it reasonable that he should project American thoughts on public issues?

title: April 30-May 6; Round-the-Clock Trading
description: In a major realignment, the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges announced plans for a merger and a tie-in with New York's Nasdaq exchange. The deal reflected the rapidly changing face of European markets, where investors are demanding faster and cheaper trading and an end to national distinctions between the continent's fragmented exchanges. The announcement created the biggest European exchange by far. The smaller Milan and Madrid bourses also plan to join the alliance. ALAN COWELL

title: April 30-May 6; Charged as Spies
description: Three of the 13 Iranian Jews accused of spying for Israel confessed, but neither human rights activists, foreign diplomats nor their own lawyers were convinced. While international concern about the case brought extraordinary public assurances from Iranian officials that the closed-door trial will be fair, defense lawyers said the government has not provided any evidence that the men -- most of them shop clerks and part-time Hebrew teachers -- had access to or transmitted state secrets. SUSAN SACHS

description: In 1943, Walter Marx, a Jewish teenager, was fleeing the Nazis in a small town in northwest Italy. A young Italian woman saved his life by hiding him from German soldiers and helping him escape.

description: William Hague, leader of the Tory opposition in the House of Commons, rose to denounce the prime minister: ''Tony Blair is the control freak who has lost control.'' title: Romance Plus Finance Equals Extravagance
description: TRAFFIC jams are rare out here on the North Fork, except during the season of pumpkin madness. So it was a shock last Saturday when I turned out of the supermarket parking lot into an immobile line of traffic stretching as far as I could see. After about a mile of inching along, the road widened and cars started to swing around the obstruction at the head of the line. When it was my turn, I saw the cause of the problem: an open white carriage drawn by two elderly horses at a steady speed of about four miles an hour in the direction of the nearest catering hall.

description: An Iraqi doctor who worked with the Central Intelligence Agency against Saddam Hussein, only to be jailed for nearly four years on the basis of secret C.I.A. evidence, may soon be free, his lawyer said this week.

description: THE fox hunters were out, jodhpurs freshly cleaned, boots polished, riding their plump mounts across the winter-brown fields silvery with frost. I was on foot, rounding the last leg of the loop I run whenever I visit this southeastern Pennsylvania countryside I grew up in.

title: Much to His Relief
description: In that Disney opposes Time Warner's planned merger with America Online, Steve Case, AOL's chairman, had an interest in events leading to ABC stations' being blocked from 3.5 million homes. ''It's not really about retransmission rights'' but about Disney's and Time Warner's broader dealings, he said Monday night, shortly before a Columbia Business School fundraising dinner. ''Luckily, it's not my problem yet.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Close Reading; Are You Happy Yet?
description: A couple of weeks ago, I picked up a new magazine called Simplicity, whose premiere issue features ''a quiz to test your happiness quotient.'' To help improve your score, it offers a Web site, www.simplicityonline.com, dedicated to creating ''a virtual universe that's not just about making your life easier, but also more euphoric.'' When I got home and checked the mail, I found another interesting artifact: a brochure promising happiness from a few spurts of a new ''stud spray'' (derived from ''bushy herbs'' favored by Bulgarians and Brazilian tribesmen). Pump some under the tongue, and -- presto! -- you'll ''Go From Zero to Hero.''

title: New Support to Help Serbs Return to Homes in Kosovo
description: Ten months after they fled the province in the face of revenge attacks from Kosovo Albanians, the Serbs of Kosovo and other minorities are seeing international political will swing in their favor.

title: Crime
description: It's sleepy time down South in Robert B. Parker's HUGGER MUGGER (Putnam, $23.95), until his Boston private eye, Spenser, heads for rural Georgia to investigate the baffling attacks on thoroughbred racehorses at Three Fillies Stables. ''I felt like I had just wandered into a Johnny Mercer lyric,'' cracks Spenser, who also has witty words for the local climate, cuisine and intelligence quotient. But the Southerners give it right back. Spenser's ''Northern charm'' is dismissed as ''an oxymoron'' by his client's sassy daughter. The deputy sheriff drolly assures him that ''nothing makes us dumb Southern boys happier than having a smart Yankee show up to help us.'' And the gay clientele at the Bath House Bar and Grill turn out to be so tough they don't need our brawny hero to settle a brawl.

title: Curbed Hospitality
description: ON the signs greeting visitors to many New Jersey towns, just below the ''Welcome'' is posted ''Overnight Parking Prohibited'' or ''No Parking 2 A.M. -- 5 A.M.'' Such words might conjure images of peaceful, quiet suburbs, but they also represent evidence of discriminatory treatment against many members of these welcoming communities.

title: BICYCLE SUNDAYS
description: A display of vintage bicycles marks opening day today of Bike and Skate Sundays and Concerts in the Park on the Bronx River Parkway. During the event, part of the parkway closes to cars and opens to bicyclists and skaters from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The cycling course begins at the Westchester County Center in White Plains and runs south to Scarsdale Road in Yonkers. The in-line roller skating course runs north from the County Center to Fisher Lane in North White Plains, a two-mile round trip.

title: The Long Run of Sammy Glick
description: WHEN Budd Schulberg dreamed up Sam my Glick the ultimate Hollywood wheeler-dealer, ''a little ferret of a kid, sharp and quick'' -- back in the 1930's, he meant his novel, ''What Makes Sammy Run?,'' to be seen in part as a cautionary tale. Back then, Sammy Glick was the villain of the piece, the awful example of what might happen if you let individualism and free enterprise run away with you. Yes, Sammy was a product of his environment (''in the midst of a war that was selfish, ruthless and cruel, Sammy was proving himself the fittest, the fiercest and the fastest'') and perhaps readers did pity him, a bit. But they definitely did not want to be him.

title: The Walls Talk: Two Tours in Newport
description: This summer visitors will be able to hear about the Gilded Age as well as see its Newport, R.I., setting. The Preservation Society of Newport County is offering new guided and audio tours. The Victorian Cottages Walking Tour of Bellevue Avenue is a three-hour guided program providing an architectural as well as social history of the town's most illustrious street from Kingscote to Chateau-sur-Mer. Kingscote was the first ''summer cottage'' built along what was then a dirt road in 1839. Chateau-sur-Mer, designed by a local architect, Seth Bradford, was built in 1852 and renovated by Richard Morris Hunt in 1872. Tours of both of these landmarks will be included. Walking tours will run from Memorial Day weekend to Columbus Day starting daily at 10 a.m. at the Preservation Society's offices at 424 Bellevue Avenue; $25, $9 ages 6 to 17.

Also last month, a former child care worker at Leake & Watts was indicted in the rape and sodomy of two teenage residents of the center. Five children from Westchester are at the Yonkers center, but the two who were raped were not from the county, said Nancy Travers, deputy commissioner for the Department of Social Services. Not satisfied with the administration's response, Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democratic county legislator from Yonkers, is calling on the county to take broader action and reconsider a contract it has with Leake & Watts to run Woodfield Cottage, a detention center in Valhalla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDING, GERTRUDE A
description: FIELDING-Gertrude A. Died May 4, 2000 at the age of 87 in Miami after a short illness. A life-long New Yorker, Mrs. Fielding was born in Brooklyn, the daughter of the late Jeanette and Morris Aronson. She attended City College of New York, and then became a model for the John Robert Powers Agency in New York City. She married Robert C. Fielding in 1941. Subsequently, she became a psychotherapist and was a pioneer in community-based mental health services, working on the staff of the Throggs Neck Mental Health Center in the Bronx. She developed new techniques to improve patient self image and social function through improved grooming, choice of clothing and job interviewing skills. She also taught these techniques to physicians and mental health professionals at Albert Einstein University. She practice psychotherapy in New York City until 1995. Recently, she divided her time between New York City and Palm Beach Fl. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Robert Fielding, two sons, Brian Fielding of Danbury, CT. and Dr. Jonathan Fielding of Los Angeles, her daughter-in-law Karin, and three grandchildren, Keith Fielding, Andrew Fielding and Preston Fielding. A memorial service to be held in New York City is planned for June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFF, KNUT
description: HOFF-Knut. Born December 28th, 1912 in Tonsberg, Norway. Died April 30th, 2000 in NYC. Joined Norwegian Merchant Marine in 1928. Spent 1932-34 in Antarctic on Anglo-Norwegian whaling expeditions, wintering on the island of South Georgia. Received degree in engineering from Ilmanau in Thuringen, 1937. Joined in Resistance at Narvik, Norway in June 1940. After internment by Nazis, walked to Sweden in 1941, then traveled through Russia, the Middle East and India to join the Royal Norwegian Air Force headquartered in Toronto, Canada. Sent to Britain in 1942 and stationed in London. Transferred to U.S. in 1943 for further training at Harvard and MIT. Met and married Maud Sanderson in Boston in 1943. Retired from Air Force in 1952 and settled in Los Angeles where he joined Lockheed Aircraft Corp. in the same year. From 1959 to 1977 worked in the Lockheed ''SkunkWorks'' on projects including the YF12A, SR71 (''Blackbird''), U2 and Orion P3. Vestry member and longtime Sr. Warden of St. John's Episcopal Church, Los Angeles. Active member, with his wife Maud, of St. James Episcopal Church in NYC since 1986. Survived by his son, Knut, Jr., two grandchildren, and nieces and nephews in the U.S. and Norway. Memorial service Monday, 1 PM, at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison and 71st St.

title: April 30-May 6; Chinese Treasures Reclaimed

In the end, two Chinese companies bought the items, vowing to return them to the motherland. The world's art dealers had to wonder whether a more assertive Chinese government might upset the lucrative trade in relics -- many of which have shady pasts. ERIK ECKHOLM

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Possessed in Maine
description: Populated by star-crossed lovers -- both living and dead -- Beth Gutcheon's spooky and idiosyncratic sixth novel, MORE THAN YOU KNOW (Morrow, $24), opens quietly enough, with an old woman named Hannah reminiscing about her youthful fling in the isolated, picturesque Maine coastal village of Dundee. In a brilliantly circular, atmospheric narrative, Hannah's romance is interwoven with a deadly love story, set 100 years earlier, that will in turn mysteriously haunt her. In Hannah's Depression-era tale, the 17-year-old summers with her stepmother in an old Dundee schoolhouse, which proves to be possessed by a ghostly figure only Hannah sees -- a woman with ''burning colorless eyes that seemed to have no pupils.'' Hannah takes solace in the arms of blue-eyed Conary Crocker, Dundee's ''all-around wild seed,'' who charms her with lazy afternoon boat trips off deserted islands. These scary and sweet events alternate with the 1850's courtship of conventional young Claris Osgood by a taciturn fisherman named Danial Haskell; their later, horrifying marriage will scar their daughter and son and end in murder. The taut facility with which Gutcheon twines the two stories creates real suspense -- both in the exact fates of the couples and the identity of the ghost, who grows viciously vengeful. While Gutcheon cannily evokes the ephemerality of passion, she also evinces, with stark and elemental resonance, the way love and hatred shape lives. Megan Harlan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFF, KNUT
description: HOFF-Knut. Born December 28th, 1912 in Tonsberg, Norway. Died April 30th, 2000 in NYC. Joined Norwegian Merchant Marine in 1928. Spent 1932-34 in Antarctic on Anglo-Norwegian whaling expeditions, wintering on the island of South Georgia. Received degree in engineering from Ilmanau in Thuringen, 1937. Joined in Resistance at Narvik, Norway in June 1940. After internment by Nazis, walked to Sweden in 1941, then traveled through Russia, the Middle East and India to join the Royal Norwegian Air Force headquartered in Toronto, Canada. Sent to Britain in 1942 and stationed in London. Transferred to U.S. in 1943 for further training at Harvard and MIT. Met and married Maud Sanderson in Boston in 1943. Retired from Air Force in 1952 and settled in Los Angeles where he joined Lockheed Aircraft Corp. in the same year. From 1959 to 1977 worked in the Lockheed ''SkunkWorks'' on projects including the YF12A, SR71 (''Blackbird''), U2 and Orion P3. Vestry member and longtime Sr. Warden of St. John's Episcopal Church, Los Angeles. Active member, with his wife Maud, of St. James Episcopal Church in NYC since 1986. Survived by his son, Knut, Jr., two grandchildren, and nieces and nephews in the U.S. and Norway. Memorial service Monday, 1 PM, at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison and 71st St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JOHN CARDINAL
description: O'CONNOR-John Cardinal. The Board of Trustees of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York wishes to express profound sorrow and a deep sense of personal loss at the death of His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York and President of this charitable Federation. Throughout a lifetime characterized by extraordinary accomplishments and service, Cardinal O'Connor was foremost and preeminently a dedicated priest, imbued with love of God and love for all God's people. His leadership and many initiatives on behalf of the poor and disadvantaged of the Archdiocese have been a source of untold strength to this Board and a special blessing from Almighty God. With loving concern, our Good Shepherd recognized the demands of our changing times and encouraged tirelessly the development of many new programs for the benefit of children and youth, recent immigrants and refugees, the aged, the homeless, handicapped and the sick. As the Shepherd of God's people, his concerns were universal as he devoted himself with apostolic charity and zeal to the welfare and the best interest of all, not only in New York but throughout the United States, the Americas and the Third World. We thank Almighty God for sharing with us the faith and wisdom, the strength and the talents of his devoted servant, John Cardinal O'Connor. His memory and example will remain with us as a lasting legacy and inspiration. The Board of Trustees of The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York Most Rev. Patrick J. Sheraton Vice President Rev. Msgr. James J. Murray Secretary

title: Claims of a Safer Cigarette

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROD, CAROL
description: BROD-Carol. On May 6, 2000. Carol died peacefully, at age 57, after a difficult four month battle with complications resulting from treatment for a brain tumor. Carol was, for nearly 38 years, the cherished wife, friend and constant companion of Ernie. She was the proud and loving mother of Joanna, Mara and Jon; the devoted daughter of Hannah and Milton Rodney; and sister of Jodi Rosenberg and Eric Rodney. Carol's professional life as a certified psycoanalyst was inextricably connected to both her family and her community. Carol graduated in 1984 from the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies and was, for more than 20 years, deeply involved with the Center's activities. She was a member of the Center's board of directors, was founder of its extension program and Dean of Extension Studies, and served as Dean of the library. She also supervised other younger analysts in their training. Carol was a member of the Society of Modern Psychoanalysts and maintained a private practice in Manhattan and Brooklyn for families, couples and adults. Carol graduated from Hunter College and received an M.A. in Philosophy from The City University of New York. She earned a Ph.D. in Psychoanalysis from The Union Institute and she both published and lectured in the area of dreams and their relationship to psychoanalysis. She also earned an M.S.W. degree from the Wurzweiler School of Social Work at Yeshiva University. In 1989, Carol founded and served as Director of the Brooklyn Seminars in Modern Psychoanalysis-a neighborhood outreach program for the Brooklyn community. Among her family, her many friends, her havurah, her professional colleagues and all who knew and loved her, Carol will be especially missed for her thoughtfulness, empathy, enthusiasm and indefatigable energy. Service Tuesday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the Brod family will greatly appreciate contributions to either the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies at 212-260-7050 or the American Cancer Society programs for brain cancer at 800-ACS-2345.

President of the ATS Northern California Chapter, member of the National Board of Directors and of the 21st Century Leadership Group, Dalia's brilliant, passionate commitment was an inspiration to everyone who worked with her. Together with her husband, Dan, president of Applied Materials, Inc., and one of the Technion's outstanding graduates, she was a moving force behind a recent innovative art program that celebrates the 75th anniversary of the Technion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dan & the entire Maydan family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. title: AGL BUYS DOMINION'S VIRGINIA NATURAL GAS UNIT
description: AGL Resources Inc., owner of Atlanta's natural gas utility, agreed yesterday to buy the Virginia Natural Gas unit of Dominion Resources for more than $500 million in cash. The price could rise by as much as $50 million if Dominion Resources decides to treat the transaction as a sale of assets for tax purposes. Virginia Natural Gas, which is based in Norfolk, has 230,000 customers. It will become a subsidiary of AGL Resources, which is based in Atlanta. AGL Resources is the parent company of the Atlanta Gas Light Company, the largest natural gas utility in the Southeast, with more than 1.5 million customers in Georgia. Dominion Resources obtained Virginia Gas in January.

description: EISEN-Herbert. The family of Herbert L. Eisen regretfully announces his passing on Sunday, May 7, 2000 at the age of 79 years. Herb was the husband of Jacqueline for nearly 49 years. He was the father of Lauri Elliot and father-in-law to Jack Elliot. He was the proud grandfather of Lauri and Jack's children, Eric and Alyssa. Herb served his country during the Second World War and achieved the rank of First Sergeant in a Field Artillery Battalion. He saw action in Germany and fought in the infamous Battle of the Bulge. During his professional career he held the positions of Administrator at the Flushing Manor Care Center; Assistant Executive Director at the Dr. William O. Benenson Rehabilitation Pavilion and the Flushing Manor Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. He held these positions simultaneously for a major part of his 25 years associated with these facilities. Herb's passing will be mourned by his brother Milton and wife Evelyn, his nieces and nephews, all his cousins and his many, many friends and coworkers. description: SHEFTELL-Joseph age 87 of Lake Worth, Florida died May 6, 2000, after a protracted illness. Born in Russia to Benjamin and Hoda, he emigrated to America as a young boy. He had two sisters, Irene and Selma. After serving in the Battle of the Bulge in World War II he began his career as a business agent for local 325 in Brooklyn, New York and emerged as an important force in the labor movement. He was devoted to Israel and was visited by Golda Meir as a young man in recognition of his efforts. He was later honored for his achievements in fund raising for Israeli Bonds. He leaves behind his loving and devoted wife of 62 years Wilma, his loving sister Selma, two sons Fred and Steven, his daughters in law Karen and Vincetta and four grandchildren Jason, Lauren, Justin, and Melanie. Service Menorah Gardens Cemetery Monday, May 10, 2000.

Hanna, based in Cleveland, provides specialty chemicals to the plastics and rubber industries, while Geon, in Avon Lake, Ohio, makes polymers and vinyls. Under the deal, M. A. Hanna shareholders will get one share of the new company for each Hanna share, while Geon shareholders would get two shares. title: President Vladimir Putin
description: Presidential authority in Russia passed from Boris Yeltsin to Vladimir Putin last New Year's Eve when Mr. Yeltsin resigned, but the symbolism of Mr. Putin's inauguration on Sunday was still lustrous. It completed the first transfer of power from one freely elected leader to another in more than 1,000 years of Russian history. After the ceremony, the energetic new president and his aging predecessor stepped into the bright sunshine of Cathedral Square, the very place where generations of czars appeared after being crowned in the Cathedral of the Assumption. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, ELIZABETH
description: WILCOX-Elizabeth, 84, died on May 6th at Evergreen Woods in North Branford, CT. She had lived in Riverdale, New York before retiring in Redding, Connecticut. Her husband of 60 years Herbert B. Wilcox, Jr. M.D., died in 1997. Starting with children's photography, she developed a career that included medical photography as represented in the 100,000 pictures and negatives of the Elizabeth Wilcox Photographic Collection at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Born in Baltimore, she was the second daughter of Elizabeth Elliott Wilson and Gordon Wilson, M.D., and attended Bryn Mawr. Her photography included assignments for Time, Newsweek and the Ford Foundation, which supported her work in Africa with Columbia Presbyterian doctors. She later was a Director of Operations Crossroads, and taught photography to its participants. Her work started with pictures of the days of children of officers of the Second General Hospital formed with the staff of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in World War II. She was recognized in her profession and became an officer of the American Society of Magazine Photographers. Highlights of her career included participation in a select workshop in Santa Cruz, California with Ansel Adams after which she received a Polaroid Foundation grant for related work and a one woman show at the IBM Gallery. She is survived by her sons, Herbert B. Wilcox, III, and his wife Catherine of North Hero, Vermont, Gordon W. Wilcox and his wife Ginger of Seattle, and Thomas E. Wilcox, and his wife Whitney Ransome of Concord, MA and her grandchildren Alexander, Tanya, Virginia, Kate and Christopher. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Church Riverdale at 4:00 p.m. Tuesday, May 9, at the corner of 252nd Street and Riverdale Avenue in Riverdale. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the Libby Wilcox Pediatrics Special Needs Fund, c/o Dr. Kenneth A. Forde, 3959 Broadway, BHS102, NY, NY, Columbia University Department of Surgery.

Climax Molybdenum said it was also reducing its mine production this year.

title: NOVARTIS AND VERTEX ENTER PACT TO DEVELOP NEW DRUGS
description: Novartis A.G., Europe's third-biggest drugmaker, has agreed to work with Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., to discover and develop new drugs in an accord worth as much as $800 million. Novartis said it would pay Vertex, a biotechnology company that makes the AIDS treatment Agenerase, to search for natural substances known as kinases that are linked to cancer, heart disease and nervous disorders. The agreement could help the Swiss company develop and sell as many as eight drugs. Under the accord, Novartis will give Vertex an initial payment of $15 million and research funds of $200 million over six years. The Basel-based Novartis could pay up to $600 million in additional fees as the drugs progress.

title: FIRST UNION TO BUY BROKERAGE BUSINESS OF FIRST ALBANY
description: The First Union Corporation, a commercial bank snapping up regional brokers to expand its securities business, agreed yesterday to acquire the brokerage business of the First Albany Companies for $100 million in cash. First Union, the sixth-largest United States bank, will add 200 retail brokers and 20 Northeast branches serving about 90,000 accounts, with $11.4 billion in assets. The transaction will expand the reach of First Union, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., into Illinois, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont. description: WILCOX-Elizabeth, 84, died on May 6th at Evergreen Woods in North Branford, CT. She had lived in Riverdale, New York before retiring in Redding, Connecticut. Her husband of 60 years Herbert B. Wilcox, Jr. M.D., died in 1997. Starting with children's photography, she developed a career that included medical photography as represented in the 100,000 pictures and negatives of the Elizabeth Wilcox Photographic Collection at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Born in Baltimore, she was the second daughter of Elizabeth Elliott Wilson and Gordon Wilson, M.D., and attended Bryn Mawr School. Her photography included assignments for Time, Newsweek and the Ford Foundation, which supported her work in Africa with Columbia Presbyterian doctors. She later was a Director of Operations Crossroads, and taught photography to its participants. Her work started with pictures of the days of children of officers of the Second General Hospital formed with the staff of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in World War II. She was recognized in her profession and became an officer of the American Society of Magazine Photographers. Highlights of her career included participation in a select workshop in Santa Cruz, California with Ansel Adams after which she received a Polaroid Foundation grant for related work and a one woman show at the IBM Gallery. She is survived by her sons, Herbert B. Wilcox, III, and his wife Catherine of North Hero, Vermont, Gordon W. Wilcox and his wife Ginger of Seattle, and Thomas E. Wilcox, and his wife Whitney Ransome of Concord, MA and her grandchildren Alexander, Tanya, Virginia, Kate and Christopher. A Memorial Service was held at Christ Church Riverdale on Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the Libby Wilcox Pediatrics Special Needs Fund, C/O Dr. Kenneth A. Forde, 3959 Broadway, BHS102, NY, NY, Columbia University Department of Surgery.

title: SPRINT PLANS TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN EARTHLINK

EarthLink said Sprint's investment would increase its cash reserve 64 percent, to $1.1 billion. EarthLink shares rose $1.4375 each, to $18.4375, while Sprint fell 37.5 cents, to $59.875. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., has until August to regain its original 29 percent stake under its agreement with EarthLink.

title: UNITED NEWS SELLS A MAGAZINE UNIT TO TRADER PUBLISHING
description: The British media company United News and Media P.L.C. said yesterday it had sold UAP Inc., its United States consumer magazine business, to the Trader Publishing Company for $520 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, GUS
description: FLEMING-Gus. With great sadness, the Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Gus Fleming, Director of Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher and Alice Tully Concert Halls since 1988. Gus passed away on Saturday, May 6, 2000, at his home in Mount Vernon, NY. Gus' twelve-year tenure at Lincoln Center was one that was particularly innovative, creative, and effective. He was the force that pushed the halls very early on into the new age of technology and implemented new hall marketing, co-production, and box office systems. From actor, to musician, to producer, to facilities director, he knew and loved the business of the performing arts. Prior to his appointment as Director of Lincoln Center's Concert Halls, Gus was the line producer for Lincoln Center Out of Doors and the Community Holiday Festival, and Co-Artistic Coordinator of Roots of American Music, which continued throughout his tenure at Lincoln Center. He was also the line producer for New York's JVC Jazz Festival, the field manager for the Grande Parade de Jazz in Nice, France, and one of three producers of the Off-Broadway play, Split Second. Gus was also instrumental in working the Caribbean Cultural Center on the Caribbean Expressions Festival. Gus played bass and sang with the Wickers Creek Bluegrass Band for the last two years. His commitment and passion will be sorely missed, he will be fondly remembered by his many friends and colleagues at Lincoln Center. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kimberlee Kimes Fleming; their children, Joshua, Samuel, Helene Elizabeth (Holly), and John Nicholas; his mother, Clara Fleming; his sister, Dorothy Ohlendorf, and his large and loving extended family. Memorial contributions can be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 30, at 4:30 PM, in Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway at 64th Street. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FATES, J. GILBERT
description: FATES-J. Gilbert, on May 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Faye Appleberry. Proud, adoring father of Amy, Gib, Decia. Smitten fatherin-law of Yolanda. Friend of Bushrod and Mazie. Born Sept. 29, 1913, in Newark, NJ to Dora Racicot and Joseph Faatz, Gil graduated from the University of Virginia in 1937. After a brief stint in legitimate theater, his career as a pioneer in T.V. was launched with CBS in 1941 and, after service in the Coast Guard during WWII, continued for some 50 years, most with Goodson-Todman Productions, where he produced such classic game and panel shows as ''To Tell the Truth,'' ''I've Got a Secret,'' and ''What's My Line?'' An avid fisherman, seasoned world traveler, relentless photographer, jazz aficionado, skilled tinkerer, sublime dancer, passable but enthusiastic golfer, peerless raconteur, Gil's warmth, intelligence, humor and generosity will be missed and long remembered by legions of friends and acquaintances. Closely held BC Partners is expected to pay as much as $26 a share, or $1.2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday. The shares rose $2.125 yesterday, to $23.25. The Upper West Side is mourning the sudden untimely death of entrepreneur Gary Marano, 47, an owner of the Raccoon Lodge who was killed in a motorcycle accident in Montauk on Sunday, May 7, 2000. Awardwinning artist, photographer, sailing enthusiast, world traveler and theatrical producer, Mr. Marano was known for treating his patrons as family by keeping the bars open on Thanksgiving and Christmas as a haven for ''holiday orphans.'' Every December, there would be a day when 83rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue became a sea of Harley-Davidsons, as Mr. Marano's friends gathered for the annual Toys for Tots Run to St. Mary's Hospital for Children in Bayside, Queens. His family, friends, godchildren, employees and patrons will miss him profoundly. Mr. Marano is survived by his mother, Dorothy and two brothers, Thomas and Michael. title: A Berlin Transformer Plant Transformed Into a Museum

Led by Alexander von Vegesack, the museum has staged some extensive modern design shows (including ''Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of Invention'' and ''Frank Lloyd Wright: The Living City''). Frustrated by a lack of sufficient space for its shows, the museum is now opening satellite branches. The first is in Berlin, where Mateo Kries, the curator, will oversee installations in a 300-foot 1930's transformer plant. The building's tower (above) houses a cool control room with original switches and fittings. A Verner Panton exhibition, to include the Panton chair (top, in the control room), will open the museum on July 1.

In personal terms, it was a day of high emotion and personal anguish for Mr. Giuliani. In political terms, it was certainly the most complicated and perhaps the most critical moment of the New York mayor's career.

title: A Weak but Crafty Microsoft Response
description: Microsoft proposed a tactically shrewd but substantively shallow remedy yesterday for the antitrust violations that a federal court found it had committed. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled last month that Microsoft had violated the antitrust laws by using its monopoly over Windows, the operating system that runs personal computers, to block potential rivals. The government proposed two weeks ago that the judge break Microsoft in two -- creating a company that sells an operating system and a separate company to sell word processors, browsers and other application programs. In yesterday's filing, Microsoft rebutted the judge's findings that it had done anything wrong and, in any case, rejected the government's plan as disproportionate to the alleged violations.

In the end he decides simply to endure. If life is purgatory, at least the pain is real.

Keynote, based in San Mateo, Calif., is the largest provider of Internet performance-measurement services for electronic commerce Web sites. It will pay 850,000 shares for Velogic and will pay more cash or stock if certain performance goals are met. The acquisition price is based on Keynote's closing price on Tuesday. The shares of Keynote fell $5.75 each yesterday, to $43.25. Velogic provides a service that allows companies to determine how to reduce site shutdowns and improve performance during high-traffic periods.

Funeral services on Wednesday, 17 May at Church of the Advent, Westbury, L.I. at 11AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Last Hope, Inc., for Animal Rescue and Rehabilitation, Box 61, Syosset, NY 11791.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, MORRIS, M.D.
description: ALPERT-Morris, M.D. On May 7, 2000. Beloved uncle of Carol and Ellen Alpert. Also survived by brother Robert, sister-in-law, Sylvia, nephew, Steven and two great nieces, Sarah and Hannah. Memorial service on Monday, May 15, at 11AM, Temple Beth Emeth, Albany, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Morris Alpert Scholarship Fund, Albany Medical College, New Scotland Avenue, Albany, NY 12210 or Community Hospice, 315 South Manning Blvd, Albany, New York 12208.

title: 5 Music Companies Settle Federal Case On CD Price-Fixing
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced a settlement of an antitrust case against the nation's five largest music companies today that the commission said should result in significant price cuts for compact discs.

title: Everything Old Is New Again
description: What's the name of that new book? Isn't the story vaguely familar? Are we talking about plagiarism? Self-plagiarism? These questions are raised by a recent example of a traditional literary gambit: the repackaging and even the rewriting of past clunkers by best-selling authors into somewhat new books that will possibly sell in the hundreds of thousands on the second go-around.

title: The Heat Is Shrinking the Knicks' Big Guards
description: They were supposed to be the stars of this series, the tag-team scorers who would allow the Knicks to overcome Alonzo Mourning's superiority to Patrick Ewing and whatever offensive exploits Jamal Mashburn could muster. But in the first two games of the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Miami Heat, Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston have gained more notice for their struggles than for their skills.

title: Eros Online: Sex, Lies and Cyberspace
description: Easily the most unpleasant character in ''The Love Machine,'' Gordon Eriksen's malicious satire of cybersex, is the movie's pushy prime mover, Becca Campbell (Marlene Forte), a fictional documentary filmmaker who doesn't know the meaning of the word boundary. Nosy, bullying, self-righteous and duplicitous, Becca is so intimidating to the people she interviews in the name of truth that it's a wonder any of them put up with her for more than five minutes, let alone come back for more.

title: Invasion of the Design Lab Mutants
description: THERE was a time, in the distant 80's, when Corian was such an exotic material it had to be installed by licensed technicians. Now, it's just another tired surface at Home Depot, and everyone is lusting for raw concrete countertops that resemble picnic tables at a state penitentiary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, ANDY
description: RUDOLPH-Andy. Born July 9, 1939, died May 8, 2000 after a short but fierce battle with cancer. Andy spent his career in the financial services industry on Wall Street. He joined National Securities Corporation based in Seattle, WA in September of 1998 as Eastern Regional Compliance Officer. He was a dedicated employee and a good friend. He will be sorely missed by all. He is survived by his dear wife Irene and mother Josephine. There will be a gathering of friends at the beloved home of Andy and Irene on Saturday May 13th from 2-7pm. In lieu of flowers rememberances to Andy's passion for music can be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKSTEIN, ANITA MAY
description: ECKSTEIN-Anita May. Our hero, lost her battle with ovarian cancer in the evening of May 9, 2000. She is survived by her loving son John, Jr. and her other loves Oscar and Carla. She leaves behind her brother, Elliot Blum, sisters-in-law, Deborah Blum and Ann Reifman, her loving niece and nephews Belinda, Jonathan, and Joey Blum; and her stepdaughters Allison Colton and Leslie Eckstein; and her wonderful friends Judy and Jerry, Eileen, and so many others. Mom, you were so special to so many. Thank you for the wonderful times and joy you brought everyone you came in contact with. The love we have for you will always be kept in our hearts and thoughts. You have touched so many people. We pray that your kindness and warmth keep you safe, pain-free, and smiling forever more...143 forever! Services Friday, May 12, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be receiving at the funeral home Thursday 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZERBI, PLINIO E
description: ZERBI-Plinio E, 92, of W. 112th St., died April 24, 2000. Husband of Ana Escalona Zerbi, father of Pliny Zerbi, Jr., Josephine Eschmann and Frank Zerbi. Memorial Mass at Notre Dame Church, W. 114th St., Saturday at 11:00 am.

title: MICROSOFT OFFERS ALTERNATIVE PLAN IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: While continuing to reject the antitrust findings against it, the Microsoft Corporation today offered a series of narrow restrictions on its behavior that it said would be more appropriate remedies than breaking up the company.

title: The Furniture That Baby Boomers First Crawled Around
description: ''Franklin Street is going to become the design center of New York,'' said Evan Snyderman, 29, an owner of TriBeCa's newest upscale vintage furniture store, R 20th Century Design, an adjunct to the R in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The new R wants to publicize less-known modern masters and on May 22 will open a show of 53 pieces by the Dutch designer Cees Braakman (left, his Combex coffee table, $2,500, and chair, $2,800, from the 1940's). Mr. Braakman's work, made by the Pastoe company, celebrates joinery and 50's forms. ''It's kind of French and minimal,'' Mr. Snyderman said. R is at 82 Franklin Street; (212) 343-7979. Pastoe pieces are at Totem (71 Franklin Street).

title: Transforming Theater Row; An Unlikely Urban Drama Heads for a Happy Ending
description: Some of the prostitutes had Actors' Equity cards. That, at least, was a point of connection for the theater people and other dreamers who 25 years ago thought they could reclaim perhaps the seediest sex strip on wild West 42nd Street.

title: New Charges for Yonkers Official
description: A Yonkers official who is awaiting trial on charges of sexually molesting a minor whom he met through the Internet was indicted today on charges of possessing more than two dozen pornographic images of children.

title: ANTEX HIRES FIRST SECURITY FOR FINANCIAL ADVICE
description: Antex Biologics Inc., a developer of vaccines to fight such ailments as food poisoning and ear infections, said yesterday that it had hired First Security Van Kasper to advise it on financial strategies. Terms were not disclosed. First Security Van Kasper, a San Francisco-based investment banker, will assess product and technology acquisitions, possible mergers or alliances and financing options, the company said. Antex's shares fell 6.25 cents, to $1.3125. At that price the company's stock is worth a total of about $63 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Biographer Peers, Briefly, at Her Own Life
description: SLEEP-DEPRIVED -- that's the disclaimer Stacy Schiff, who's won the Pulitzer for biography, throws over her interview. She spent five years on her book about the marriage of Vera Nabokov, but what's concerning her now is her own domestic life.

title: Untangling the Legal Maze by Surfing the Web
description: YOU have had a bad week. Your landlord raised the rent without notice. You had an accident with your new car just after you drove it out of the dealership. And your spouse is threatening divorce. In a wave of desperation and self-pity, you make your way to the computer and find yourself cruising the Net. Suddenly, hope appears in the form of a site that may help you learn about all these troublesome legal issues in your life.

description: LISTEN up, Liebchen. This year is Kurt Weill's double anniversary -- he was born in 1900 and died in 1950 -- and only two years after the centennial of the birth of Lotte Lenya, his wife. The resulting cultural attention is a good excuse to get to know two of the leading lights of Germany's Weimar artistic explosion.

description: A children's advocacy group that has won court-ordered changes in foster care systems in New York and elsewhere filed a federal class-action lawsuit today to force an overhaul of Tennessee's foster care system.

title: Walk-Ons That Might Steal the Show
description: Kristin Ordahl (on left at right) is a painter and video artist. Kelly Bortoluzzi (right) designs furniture. Together they are Orbo, a Brooklyn-based company, which makes vibrant hand-painted rugs and runners of varnished cotton canvas. They have been influenced by the minimalist painter Agnes Martin, by early Marimekko fabrics and by mattress ticking. A Calavita 32 (above right, 32 inches square) is $328; a Bandana 71 (above, 26 by 68 inches) is $782 at www.orbodesign.com; delivery in six to eight weeks.

description: China's chief arms negotiator said today that the American proposal to build an anti missile defensive shield posed an unacceptable threat to China's security and could force Beijing to significantly expand its own nuclear forces in response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, RENATE
description: SHAPIRO-Renate. The New Museum of Contemporary Art family mourns the loss of Renate Shapiro. She was a supportive friend of the Museum from its earliest beginning. Her positive spirit, beauty, and regal demeanor lent credence to the program of the New Museum. The memory of Renate will continue to live in our hearts and minds, renewing itself with the ever-living contemporary art she so loved. The Staff and Board of The New Museum

title: Woman, 24, Shot to Death Near Her Home in Queens
description: A 24-year-old Japanese woman who worked as a music promoter was fatally shot early yesterday morning as she walked home on a quiet Queens street, the police said.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD SETS RATIO FOR SHARES OF AGILENT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the computer maker, yesterday set the ratio at which its shareholders will get stock in the measurement-equipment and medical-device maker Agilent Technologies Inc., which it is spinning off. Investors will receive 0.3814 share of Agilent for each Hewlett-Packard common share. They will get stock for whole shares of Agilent and cash for fractional ones. The distribution, expected to close June 2, will give Hewlett-Packard shareholders about 84 percent of Agilent's stock outstanding. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., first sold shares of Agilent in November.

description: Through the miracle of technology, electronic greeting cards can really save your hide when holidays (like, say, Mother's Day THIS weekend) sneak up on you. But now you can ''care enough to send the very best'' even if you don't have the time to go to the store and buy it.

title: Arthur William Dake, 90, Chess Grandmaster
description: Arthur William Dake, a chess grandmaster and one of the last of a talented crop of American players who won major competitions before World War II, died on April 28 in Reno. He was 90 and lived in Portland, Ore.

title: In Stages, the Boss's Secretary Becomes a Dot-Com Executive
description: The Internet revolution has allowed people with unconventional professional backgrounds to become far more successful far more quickly than they might have in the past.

title: CANADA REVAMPS GRAIN TRANSPORT
description: Hoping to eliminate late rail deliveries of western grain, the Canadian government is changing the way $4 billion worth of wheat and barley exports are transported each year. The role of the Canadian Wheat Board, which now oversees exports, will be reduced, and the Canadian National Railway and Canadian Pacific Railway will charge 18 percent less. Timothy Pritchard

title: Crystal Goes Whimsical in New Steuben Quarters
description: The glassmaker Steuben may not be known for cutting-edge style, but it has attracted some of the design world's leading lights for an inaugural exhibition in its new store, at 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street), formerly the Shanghai Tang emporium. The show, called ''Celebrating by Design'' and produced with the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, will take place in the 6,000-square-foot Corning Inc. Gallery downstairs, which, along with the store, will open to the public at noon on May 18. For the exhibition, fashion designers, architects and interior designers were asked to intepret celebratory moments. In ''Zen Bride'' (drawing, inset), Isabel and Ruben Toledo use an elegant Pucci-designed mannequin, posed in a quilted organdy wedding gown, trailing past a single Steuben bowl. Avi Adler, the artist and event designer, is working with Kate Spade, the accessories designer, on Valentine's Day (above), in which Steuben's whimsical crystal heart collection is showcased in a room upholstered with silk roses and washed in brilliant red light. Other contributors are Richard Meier, David Rockwell, Courtney Sloane, Ali Tayar, Adam Tihany and Eric W. Warner. The 2,500-square-foot space, Ralph Appelbaum's first store design, will include innovative display tables with embedded screens (in the rendering above) to show video compositions of, for instance, a flower vase, with flowers blooming beneath it.

title: The Tangled Web in the Murder of a Rabbi's Wife
description: For nearly four years, as the innuendo and accusations mounted about Rabbi Fred J. Neulander's role in the slaying of his wife, a burly, talkative man would buttonhole reporters, strenuously proclaim the rabbi's innocence and offer his own theories about who might have beaten Carol Neulander to death in the living room of her suburban Philadelphia home.

title: BRAZIL APPROVAL ON MOBILE PHONE DEAL

title: Foreign Affairs; The Parallel Universe
description: When the Industrial Revolution came along it shaped the contours of several U.S. elections. Although our current election comes at the dawn of the information and biotech revolutions, you'd never quite know it from the presidential campaign, which has been almost a parallel universe, operating on its own news and historical logic. It has been characterized either by the arcane -- the Confederate flag and Bob Jones -- or by the evergreens -- Social Security, campaign finance reform, abortion and gun control. There is a general sense that not much is at stake in this election, and that we have entered an era of good feelings and tiny differences.

title: White Supremacist Agrees to Make a Public Apology to Victim
description: In a settlement that entailed as much public humiliation as punitive fines, the Department of Housing and Urban Development today announced that a Pennsylvania white supremacist must make a public apology to a woman he acknowledged harassing and must help promote anti-discrimination efforts.

title: BARNES GROUP BUYS CURTIS INDUSTRIES FOR $62 MILLION
description: Barnes Group Inc., a maker of jet engine parts, said yesterday that it had purchased Curtis Industries for $62.1 million to become a distributor of equipment that makes keys for automobiles. Curtis, based in Mayfield Heights, Ohio, was combined with Barnes Group's Bowman Distribution unit to form Barnes Distribution. About 30 percent of Curtis's $80 million in annual sales has been from distributing key-making equipment and materials. Curtis also distributed maintenance and repair products like automobile fuses. Barnes Group, based in Bristol Conn., had revenue of $622 million last year. Curtis was formerly a unit of the closely held Paragon Corporate Holdings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUIRST, WILLIAM
description: FUIRST-William, age 99 on May 11. Beloved husband of the late Pauline Fuirst, loving father of Alan and Susan Fuirst; Phyllis and Richard Baker; adored grandfather of Ken and Sue Fuirst; Pam and Allen Weiss; Ellen and Michael Weiss and Caren Baker and proud great grandfather of six. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLCUTS, MILDRED G.
description: WILLCUTS-Mildred G. Of New York City. After attending the University of Wisconsin, she worked for the National Labor Relations Board in Washington, D.C. and Minneapolis. In 1947, she came to New York and became legal secretary and office manager for Lawrence R. Condon and, more recently, for Milton Maurer. For many years she was an active member & Treasurer of the Pilot Club of New York. She is survived by her sister Katherine Chase, Sea Cliff, L.I., nieces Kathleen Starr, Middlebury. VT., and Nancy Rouisse, North Hero, VT., and their families. Memorial service Saturday, May 13th, 2PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Pilot Club of New York , C/O Pamela Domestico, 110-11 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York 11375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBARRUBIA, SALTZMAN, JODI
description: COBARRUBIA - SALTZMAN - Jodi. May 8, 2000. Seattle, Washington. Died suddenly age 34. Beloved wife of Frank, loving daughter of Muriel and Ralph, sister of Lisa. Her love of life will live on in the hearts of those she touched. You will always be in our hearts. Contributions in her memory may be sent to The Churchill School, NY. Service on Monday, May 15, at 11 AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUMEROFF, DR. SEYMOUR
description: NUMEROFF-Dr. Seymour. Your valiant struggle is now over and at last your are at peace. Our thoughts are with you Harriet, and the magnificent wife you were; one in a million. Goodbye dear friend, we will always miss you. Carol and Don Schiffman

title: The War in Sierra Leone
description: Sierra Leone is a difficult place for peacekeepers, as the United Nations has found in recent days. U.N. forces sent to the West African nation to enforce a peace agreement have instead been ordered into battle against rebel forces that defied the accord and are now assaulting Freetown, the capital. To prevail in this fight, and to prevent a new round of indiscriminate killing by the rebels, the U.N. forces must quickly be reinforced with troops from the alliance of West African countries led by Nigeria. Washington and its allies should be generous in providing this regional force with the logistic and financial resources it needs to respond swiftly.

title: Rebels Destroy a Convoy Outside Chechnya
description: Islamic rebels mounted a major attack outside Chechnya's borders for the first time in nearly nine months today, all but wiping out a convoy of 22 Russian soldiers as it moved down a mountain road in a neighboring region of Russia, Ingushetia.

title: Florio Puts Corzine on the Defensive in Their First Debate
description: After enduring an eight-week barrage of costly television commercials by Jon S. Corzine, his opponent in the Democratic primary, former Gov. Jim Florio, seized control of their first debate today, forcing Mr. Corzine on the defensive for a full hour as the two men showed why theirs is perhaps the most captivating Senate race outside New York.

title: FRANCE TELECOM PLANS TO SELL ITS STAKE IN CROWN CASTLE
description: France Telecom said yesterday that it would sell its $1.3 billion interest in Crown Castle International to buy a stake in a cable company. France Telecom must sell its 20 percent stake in Crown Castle, a provider of wireless services, to get antitrust approval in Britain to buy a 25 percent stake in the cable company NTL Inc., a deal it agreed to last year. Crown Castle, based in Houston, and NTL, based in New York, both broadcast to cable customers in Britain. The Crown Castle stock sale will include a public offering of 22 million Crown Castle shares. The stock was down 43.75 cents yesterday, to $29.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUTEUR, ROGER
description: TUTEUR-Roger. On May 9, 2000 at age 94. Adored husband of Audrey. Father of the late Henry Tuteur. Loving father of Ann. Cherished grandfather of Ottavia. Dear brother-in-law of Barbara and Herbert St. Lifer. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street on Friday 11:30 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKS, HAROLD FREEMAN
description: PARKS-Harold Freeman, retired actor and theater director in New York City for many years, died Wednesday, May 10, in Beth Israel Hospital. Born October 18, 1918 in Medford, MA, he was the son of the late David and Annette Robillard Parks and was a Captain in the U.S. Army Air Corps in World War II. He was a member of the Lambs Club and the Actors Equity Guild in New York City for many years. Mr. Parks is survived by three nephews, Dr. Richard P. Tobin of New Jersey, Ronald B. Tobin of California, and David F. Tobin of Connecticut, two nieces, Tracy A. Kirkpatrick and Linda R. Klugman, both of California, and a brother-in-law, Richard A. Tobin, also of California. Graveside services will be held on Saturday, May 13, 2000 at 10AM in Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT. There will be no calling hours. For information contact F. Hoyt Funeral Home in New Canaan, CT,

title: Russian Security Agencies Raid Media Empire's Offices
description: Federal agents wielding guns and wearing black masks staged a raid on the downtown headquarters of Russia's largest private media empire today, raising alarms among politicians and journalists about the prospects for an independent press under President Vladimir V. Putin.
