title: Dell's Quarterly Earnings Are Better Than Expected
description: The Dell Computer Corporation posted better-than-expected first-quarter earnings yesterday, benefiting from a richer mix of products, with particular strength in sales of servers and storage devices for Internet use.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about the renaming of a German army base for a German sergeant who saved hundreds of Jews in Lithuania in World War II and was executed by the Nazis mislabeled the country on Lithuania's northern border. It is Latvia, not Estonia.

title: A First Release Meets a Big Boy
description: Tom Dey thought the preview screening of ''Shanghai Noon,'' his first effort as a feature film director, was going pretty well, but he was unprepared for the phone call from Disney distribution executives. ''They said they were so excited about it that they wanted to make it their big Memorial Day release,'' Mr. Dey said. ''Never did I imagine anything like that. We were just a relatively small production shooting in Calgary. We were never considered a summer heavyweight. It was a dream come true.''

title: Kosovo Towns Mourn a Slain Guerrilla Army Commander
description: Tens of thousands of people stopped work today to mourn a former commander of the Kosovo Liberation Army who was gunned down at his home on Tuesday. His family and fellow commanders denounced the killing as an attack on Kosovo's stability and its very future.

title: Denver's Newspapers, Long at War, Now Plan to Publish Jointly
description: After losing $123 million since 1990 in an unsuccessful effort to win the country's fiercest newspaper war, the owners of The Rocky Mountain News in Denver announced yesterday that they intended to combine their business operations with those of The Denver Post, effectively ceding victory to The Post's owner, William Dean Singleton.

title: Ex-Communications Director Denies Affair
description: Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas said yesterday that she had never had a sexual relationship with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and that they merely had ''a very close friendship'' during the six years they worked side by side in City Hall.

title: Man in the News; Secure at the Helm
description: As a seminary student in Chicago, he was the only member of his class chosen to go to Rome to finish his theology studies.

title: Maine Enacts a Law Aimed at Controlling Cost of Drugs
description: The Maine Legislature gave final passage yesterday to a bill that makes Maine the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls, which could come into force in 2003, and in the meantime effectively turns the state into a giant drug-price negotiator for about half its citizens.

title: Israeli Court Halts Early Parole For Jew Who Executed an Arab
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a decision to parole a Jewish settler who had initially been sentenced to life imprisonment for the execution-style killing of a Palestinian.

title: A Simpler Melancholy
description: ''It is curious; one never thinks of attaching 'Hamlet' to any special locale,'' the critic Kenneth Tynan once wrote of Shakespeare's tragedy, and the director Michael Almereyda has brilliantly seized upon that by rooting his voluptuous and rewarding new adaptation of the play in today's Manhattan. The city's contradictions of beauty and squalor give the movie a sense of place -- it makes the best use of the Guggenheim Museum you'll ever see in a film -- and New York becomes a complex character in this vital and sharply intelligent film.

title: Gotta Psych Yourself Up To Win at This Game
description: As much as some people would like to regard boxing as nothing more than a brute contest of physical endurance, the sport also has its spiritual side. The importance of attitude -- of psyching yourself up and psyching out your opponent, of maintaining a feeling of emotional and physical self-mastery under extreme stress -- is almost as crucial to winning as physical strength and agility. That point is brought home again and again in ''Shadow Boxers,'' Katya Bankowsky's upbeat documentary portrait of women's boxing, a sport that has only recently begun to be taken seriously by promoters.

title: A Palatial Patio's Fresh Air
description: A PALACE was not a palace without a patio in the days of Don Pedro Fajardo y Chacon, the Castilian nobleman who built the Castle of Velez Blanco near the southeastern coast of Spain between 1506 and 1515. The crowning glory of his Gothic abode was its patio, an ensemble that mated local Gothic and Spanish-Moorish structural elements with architectural and decorative components from the Italian Renaissance.

title: John Ruskin as a Marriage Critic, Too
description: ''The Countess,'' which originally played at the Greenwich Street Theater, opened last night at the Lamb's Theater, 130 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Following are excerpts from Anita Gates's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 30, 1999.

title: LOSS NARROWS AT THOMSON
description: A leading Canadian publishing company, the Thomson Corporation, said its first-quarter loss narrowed to $22 million, from $72 million a year earlier. The company announced in February that it was leaving the newspaper business to focus on electronic media. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: A Showcase for Emerging Talent Nurtured Within the Same Environment
description: ''Good business is the best art,'' said Andy Warhol, who might have been an accountant if he hadn't been an artist. His once-provocative words would probably sound common-sensical to an M.F.A. candidate today. At present they are serving as the title for an exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

title: Gomez Takes Coach's Timely Message to Heart
description: After pulling out of a brief slump, Scott Gomez was skating freely and effectively again for the fourth consecutive game, making plays for himself and his linemates from his center position. With the Devils ahead of the Maple Leafs by a goal and dominating the game, Gomez confidently skated into the left-wing corner of the Toronto zone near the end of the first period.

title: Where Unicorns and Tapestries Wait in Timeless Repose
description: The most beautiful European cloister I've ever experienced lies along the Hudson River, just south of the Bronx border. The Cloisters and I were introduced in early May of my 11th year, a season when the transplanted monastery gardens in Fort Tryon Park explode with color.

title: Candidates Clash Most Sharply Over Social Security Plans
description: Of all the scuffles in today's acerbic debate between New Jersey's two Democratic candidates for the Senate, no clash was more bitter than the contestants' exchanges over the volatile issue of Social Security.

title: Conservation Measure Wins Strong Approval in House
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a sweeping environmental measure today that sets aside $45 billion over 15 years to buy parks and open spaces, pay for wildlife protection and restore damaged coastal areas.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article yesterday about the settlement of an antitrust case involving the pricing of compact discs omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. The affected passage is reprinted today, on Page C2.

title: WESTFIELD UNIT IS ACQUIRING OLD GUARD FOR $45 MILLION
description: Old Guard Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Ohio Farmers Insurance Company for about $45 million. Ohio Farmers Insurance is part of the Westfield Companies, based in Westfield Center, Ohio. After the acquisition, Westfield will have about $2 billion of assets and $1 billion in written premiums. The combined companies will be a large insurer of agribusiness. Shares of Old Guard, based in Lancaster, Pa., rose $1.50 yesterday, to $11.375.

title: Fairfield Porter
description: 'A Life in Art'

title: Women in Military Say Silence On Harassment Protects Careers
description: Out of the blue, when they were cooling down after their regular morning jog, a colonel was groped by her male running partner, another colonel who forcefully tried to embrace her, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, CLAIRE
description: FELDMAN-Claire. May 12, 1922November 3, 1996. Remembering your fourth birthday since you passed with deep sorrow. Each day I miss you more than the day before. Your unique goodness and generosity, moral strength, buoyancy of spirit and wisdom were rare ''gifts'' one can never restore. Rest in Peace with Mom and Pop. Loved very much, Miria

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after a report by the International Energy Agency reinforced concern that demand will outpace production later this year. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose $1.01, to $29.11 a barrel.

title: Metro Business; Consumer Unit Fines 6 Apartment Finders
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs fined six apartment information vendors yesterday as part of its first investigation of companies that charge a fee for locating available apartments.

title: People
description: * Gretchen G. Teichgraeber was named president and chief executive at Scientific American Inc., New York, a unit of Holtzbrinck, succeeding Joachim P. Rosler, who left to join a new Internet publishing venture. Ms. Teichgraeber had most recently been vice president for marketing and information services and general manager for publishing at CMP Media, Manhasset, N.Y., part of Miller Freeman.

title: Napster May Have Weak Defense in Fight With Music Industry
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND SLUMPS. The British pound fell amid expectations the Bank of England may have finished driving borrowing costs higher for now. In New York, the pound settled at $1.5022, down from $1.5115 on Wednesday.

title: Earth Capitulates in 9 Minutes to Mean Entrepreneurs From Space
description: ''Man is an endangered species,'' announces one of the titles at the beginning of the sci-fi lump ''Battlefield Earth.'' And after about 20 minutes of this amateurish picture, extinction doesn't seem like such a bad idea. Sitting through it is like watching the most expensively mounted high school play of all time. The film is stocked with evil aliens who, in their padded body stockings, plastic armorlike fittings and matted hair extensions, resemble nothing so much as members of GWAR, the metal-rock parodists that Beavis and Butt-head loved. It may be a bit early to make such judgments, but ''Battlefield Earth'' may well turn out to be the worst movie of this century.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: On a very polite block near the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Revel strikes an antic pose. The name suggests wild doings. The flaming red banquettes seem designed for mad, mad evenings. It's all a tease. Beneath the flashy trappings, the town house, once the home of Parioli Romanissimo restaurant, maintains a dignified, even aristocratic bearing supported by exquisite plasterwork on the ceiling and Corinthian details on the woodwork.

title: Confronting J. C. Penney's Ennui; A Veteran of Wal-Mart Tries to Repeat Her Successes
description: Vanessa Castagna, J. C. Penney's new executive vice president and chief operating officer, is making demands again. At a summit conference for suppliers yesterday at Penney's headquarters in Plano, Tex., the imposing Ms. Castagna, who is nearly 6 feet tall in heels, strode back and forth as she hammered away on what it would take to turn around the ailing department store chain she now runs.

title: Family Life, Not a Cup of Tea
description: Alan Ball was talking about his idea for a movie the other day. ''Can you imagine pitching this?'' he asked. ''Two families, really screwed up. You think you know what's going on, but it's really something different because actually the movie is about the elusive nature of reality, and there's a whole metaphysical bit with this plastic bag.''

title: Miscellany
description: * American Business Press, New York, was renamed American Business Media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, JOANNE P.
description: KRAUS-Joanne P. Born May 27, 1930 in NYC to the late Charlotte and Ralph Kraus. Died May 3, 2000 in Beverly Hills, CA of cancer. She leaves sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Jackie Cooper of Beverly Hills; nephews Russell Cooper of Manhattan & John Cooper of Marin, CA and niece Cristina Cooper of Woodland Hills, CA. Interment at Westwood Memorial Park, Los Angeles.

title: BIG AIRBUS ORDER
description: The European aircraft consortium, Airbus Industrie, booked an order for up to 50 aircraft with a list price of more than $3 billion from the International Lease Finance Corporation of Los Angeles, a unit of American International Group. Last year, Airbus led its American rival, Boeing, in orders, by 476 to 391, but their order backlogs are about equal at 1,600 each. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Facing the Voices; Those Sonorous Messages Have People Behind Them
description: They speak to you about terribly private things. Your bank balance. Your e-mail. Who called. What they said. The movies you watch. As they get more sensitive, more attuned to your habits, they talk more and more, blabber a bit, actually, yakking for as long as you stay connected.

description: Lennon Weinberg

description: The first national accounting of toxic chemical emissions by electric power plants and the mining industry has tripled the estimated volume of those releases.

title: Planet Hollywood Says It Canceled Debt
description: Planet Hollywood International Inc., which has 66 entertainment-theme restaurants worldwide, said this week that it had emerged from bankruptcy protection after canceling about $282 million in debt.

title: A Father Of Pottery As a High Art
description: It was only about 80 years ago that the West started to see pottery as high art, and that view was shaped by Bernard Howell Leach, an English studio potter who learned his art in Japan. It was Leach who said, ''Pots, like all forms of art, are human expressions.''

title: Female Teacher Accused Of Affair With Boy, 15
description: A 29-year-old English teacher at Canarsie High School was arrested Wednesday night and accused of having a sexual relationship with a 15-year-old boy in the ninth grade, officials said yesterday.

description: PERTON-Fannie. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Fannie Perton, beloved mother of Irwin Perton, our Assistant Treasurer. We extend our deepest condolences to Irwin and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Residential Real Estate; Rental Tower Seeks to Ride Times Square Wave
description: When leasing begins tomorrow for the 921 rental apartments at the 40-story brick-and-glass tower at 42nd Street and the Hudson River, it will be a milestone in the 16-year journey Larry Silverstein has been on since he first envisioned the project in 1984.

title: Rabbi Is Deported 5 Years After Conviction, Lawyer Says
description: A Hasidic rabbi on parole in Rockland County after serving a prison term for kidnapping a teenager under his tutelage was deported to Israel yesterday, even as his conviction was being appealed, his lawyer said.

title: Public Interests; A Woman Scorns
description: If we accept Clinton-era conventional wisdom and assume that a male politician's ability to survive a sex scandal depends on the wife's willingness to impersonate a good sport, Rudy Giuliani has a problem.

title: E.P.A. Computer Model on Auto Pollution Is Flawed, Study Says
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's computer model for predicting how much air pollution comes from cars and trucks underestimates emissions and may overestimate the benefits of some pollution-control strategies, the National Academy of Sciences said in a report today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Stanley Boxer, 73, Prolific Artist Known for Abstract Paintings
description: Stanley Boxer, a versatile artist known for his thickly brushed abstract paintings, died on Monday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 73.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campaign Briefing column on Wednesday about the United States Senate race in Massachusetts misstated the year the incumbent, Edward M. Kennedy, was first elected. It was 1962, not 1964.

title: Ken Price
description: 'Lumps, Bumps,

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOUTHERN CO., Atlanta, a power producer, said it planned to build a natural-gas-fired power plant in southwestern Michigan. The cost was not disclosed.

title: Hospital's Move Gives Staff Room to Breathe
description: The moment was three years in the planning for Carol Fazio, the nurse manager at the Kings Highway Division of the Beth Israel Medical Center. To celebrate, she passed out tiny plastic Rollerblade keychains from a paper bag. ''It's nurse appreciation day,'' she joked. ''I bought you a new E.R.''

title: FORD IS CONCEDING S.U.V. DRAWBACKS
description: The Ford Motor Company, which depends on sport utility vehicles for much of its profit, acknowledged today that they cause serious safety and environmental problems.

title: Politicians of the Cloth
description: The appointment of Edward M. Egan as the ninth Roman Catholic archbishop of New York represents more than just the filling of an ecclesiastical position; for the future of the city, it could be the political event of the year. Over the past century and a half, Archbishop Egan's predecessors have wielded enormous influence in local and national politics, far more so than the holders of any other religious post. New York's archbishops have often had more clout than senators or cabinet members.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A 'Fame' for Today's Dancing, Striving Adolescents
description: Alan Parker's ''Fame'' is a movie that will live forever in the memories of anyone who was a stage-struck adolescent -- or the parent of one -- in the waning days of the Carter administration. But it has been 20 years, almost to the day, since that swirling, high-kicking soap opera about students at New York's High School for the Performing Arts was released, and today's aspiring troupers surely deserve a movie of their own about young artists coming of age and learning how to fly.

title: Pace of 'Sleeping Beauty' Is Anything But Sleepy
description: The New York City Ballet's ''Sleeping Beauty'' returned in all its streamlined splendor to the New York State Theater on Wednesday night. And the company is offering performances of this great 19th-century classic, with various changes of cast, through May 21.

title: ONLINE EUROPEAN TRAVEL AGENCY
description: A group of European airlines said it would create an online travel agency to cut the cost of ticket sales and distribution. The airlines, which include British Airways, Air France, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Lufthansa and six others, aim to reduce reliance on travel agents and their commissions.

title: Chrebet and Elias Fined After Guilty Pleas
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet and Keith Elias, a running back formerly with the Giants and the Indianapolis Colts, were each fined $230 yesterday after pleading guilty to a nuisance violation stemming from a disturbance outside a Seaside Heights, N.J., bar on Feb. 6.

title: Romance on the Eastern Shore
description: Once again I wanted a romantic weekend, and I wanted it in a hurry. The Eastern Shore of Maryland, a two-hour drive from Philadelphia, where I live, seemed a good bet for that and for an early taste of spring. I had never been there, but my friend Lou, who had made one visit with his son, said he remembered charming small towns and farmland spilling down to the Chesapeake Bay.

title: China Likely To Modernize Nuclear Arms, U.S. Believes
description: The Clinton administration, responding to a detailed public warning by China against national missile defenses proposed by Washington, said today that it believed Beijing would go ahead with modernizing its nuclear forces even if Washington were not planning the new system.

title: Riley Throws in Dash of Levity After Woeful Game at the Line
description: As the Heat's three-hour practice wound down today, Coach Pat Riley divided his players into two teams -- black shirts against red shirts -- and started a contest called Nets. The goal: to see how many free throws each player could make without hitting the rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JOHN T.
description: McCARTHY-John T., M.D. of Tenafly, N.J. on May 10, 2000. Beloved Husband of Carol (nee Wacewiz). Devoted father of Ann E. Gardiner, Dr. Denise McCarthy Abel and Caroline Krasnoff. Dear brother of Dr. Denise McCarthy. Loving grandfather of David, Thomas and Lauren. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Dr. Tenafly, NJ on Friday 24 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass 10AM Saturday Mt. Carmel Church Tenafly, New Jersey. Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery Tenafly, NJ. Donations to a charity of you choice would be appreciated.

Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: Clinton Asks Congress to Raise the Limit on Visas for Skilled Workers
description: Racing to keep up with a booming economy, President Clinton today proposed an increase of more than 85 percent in the number of skilled foreign workers who could be admitted to the United States to fill job openings in high-technology industries.

description: No Hot Time At Four Seasons

description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Austin, Tex.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about public reaction to corruption in Louisiana and the conviction of former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on federal charges of racketeering, conspiracy and extortion misidentified the subject of one indictment. It is Louisiana's former election commissioner, Jerry M. Fowler, not the current one, Suzanne Haik Terrell.

title: Giuliani's Marital Uproar Brings Winces and Sighs
description: Over sandwiches and keyboards yesterday, at soda machines and bus stops, it seemed as if New Yorkers were hardly surprised by the news: the marital problems of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover.

title: New York's Harmful Drug Laws
description: In 1973, under Gov. Nelson Rockefeller, New York enacted some of the toughest, most rigid drug laws in the nation. At the time it was thought that imposing long, mandatory sentences on drug pushers would stop the illegal drug trade. But 26 years of experience has shown that those expectations were completely baseless. Not only have the laws failed to increase public safety or stem the traffic in drugs, but they have filled state prisons with nonviolent drug offenders at huge public expense, clogged the court system and created new problems for communities and families already burdened by drug addiction.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an obituary of the furniture designer Ross Littell misidentified a chair he designed with William Katavalos and David Kelley. It is the T-chair (Laverne Company, 1952), not the Criss Cross chair (Knoll, 1959).

title: Oladele Bamgboye
description: Thomas Erben Gallery

title: Schwab Says Account Values Plunged
description: The clients of the Charles Schwab Corporation, the biggest discount brokerage firm, sustained $56.2 billion in market losses in April, as declining stocks shaved the value of holdings by 7 percent.

title: Rerouting and Closings On the E, B and F Lines
description: For the next four weekends, work on the signals and switches along the tracks of the E, B and F trains will cause extensive rerouting and the closing of some subway stations, transit officials said this week.

title: Judges Ask Tough Questions About Cuban Boy's Interests
description: In pointed questions to lawyers for both sides in the battle over the future of Elian Gonzalez, three federal judges wondered today how a 6-year-old who cannot even sign his full name could apply for political asylum but questioned whether sending him back to communist Cuba was in his best interests, regardless of his father's fitness as a parent.

title: Gore, Bush and Guns
description: As a million moms get set to march on behalf of gun control this weekend, it's not clear how this issue will play in voter decisions in the fall. The conventional wisdom has held for a long time that while proponents of more restrictions on firearms outnumber opponents, it's intensity that counts at the ballot box, and the Second Amendment crowd has had a big edge there.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; A Debate Over Daytime Headlamps
description: WHEN safety ideas come along, the government is usually the first to embrace them. Automakers are dragged along later, sometimes kicking and screaming. But with daytime running lamps, the pattern is reversed.

title: Devout, Wise and Loves To Dance at Weddings
description: ''Jesus'' begins with bad dreams. The son of Mary and Joseph, 30 years old and still holding back from setting out on his real mission in life, has nightmares about the future: wars, crusades and immolations that will be carried out in his name. So really -- as Satan suggests to him later in the wilderness -- what's the point of even preaching the word if that's what it's all going to come to?

title: Making Music Without the Chancellor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DART, ALLAN KENT
description: DART-Allan Kent. Colleagues and students of The American Language Institute, NYU mourn the passing May 4 of Allan Kent Dart, much-loved teacher, author, friend. Born August 20, 1937, he earned degrees from the California College of Arts and Crafts and Cornell University. He is survived by sister, Jill Garrett, niece, Nancy Johnson and other nieces and nephews.

title: Nike Will Sell High-Tech Gear to Athletes
description: Nike said this week that it was branching out from athletic shoes and clothing by forming a division for high-technology sports gear that will introduce five gadgets for athletes this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, DOROTHY FAHS
description: BECK-Dorothy Fahs, Dr., Sociologist and Humanitarian. Retired Research Director of the Family Service Association of America, died May 5 at 94. She was widely admired for her insightful research work on family issues and for her broad commitment to the advancement of social justice. Readers may wish to consult ''Who's Who in America'' for more detail. A native of New York City, Dr. Beck lived most of her life in Manhattan. In 1989 she moved to a Pennsylvania retirement community called Crosslands. Dorothy Beck was co-founder of the Fahs/ Beck Fund for Research and Experimentation at the New York Community Trust, 2 Park Avenue, New York City, NY 10016. Donations to the fund are welcome.

title: A Surprised 'Wild Party'
description: The unexpectedly strong showing of the Public Theater's production of ''The Wild Party'' in the Tony Award nominations -- the show landed seven -- has apparently lifted the fortunes of that struggling musical enough to persuade its producers to run at least through the Tonys.

title: Lottery Fever Leads to Record Tolls
description: Officially, there were two winners in the record-breaking Big Game lottery that was drawn on Tuesday. But yesterday a third emerged: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Some Quicksilver Riffing By a Hostage in the Desert
description: Jamie Foxx is a witty actor and an intuitive comedian who can sometimes manage to make the lamest material -- the WB sitcom that bears his name, for instance -- amusing. As if to test his powers, ''Held Up,'' which might have worked better as an episode of ''The Jamie Foxx Show,'' strands its star in the middle of the Arizona desert (actually the outskirts of Regina, Saskatchewan) with nothing to do but hold a gun to his own head and negotiate with the North Butte sheriff's department on behalf of the inept stickup man (Eduardo Yanez) who has taken him hostage.

title: Elizabeth Olbert
description: Caren Golden Gallery

title: Retailers Post Mixed Results As Gap Gains, but Kmart Slips
description: Two retailers, moving in opposite directions, reported earnings today. Gap Inc. said first-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, bolstered by sales at new stores, while Kmart said profit plummeted 61 percent, as cool and rainy weather last month dampened demand for spring clothes.

title: Yanks Lose Jeter First, And Then The Game
description: Derek Jeter had been struggling at the plate. So when the rains hit Wednesday night and postponed the game against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, Jeter retreated to the batting cages and took two extra practice sessions in hopes of finding the route out of his slump.

title: Jeanne Silverthorne
description: McKee Gallery

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Fire Department to Train Its Drivers on City Streets
description: The Fire Department has expanded its driver-training program in response to an incident last month in which an engine company did not answer an alarm because the firefighters assigned to the pumper truck said they did not know how to drive it.

title: Harassment in the Senior Ranks
description: The Army inspector general's office has substantiated the accusation by Lt. Gen. Claudia Kennedy, the Army's highest-ranking woman, that she was sexually harassed by another Army general, according to defense officials. The disturbing case shows that ending harassment of women is no easier in the top officer ranks than it is in the barracks.

title: Barkless Puppy In Tree's Place
description: Rockefeller Center is famous for the 100-foot Christmas tree it installs every year. Now, over the next few weeks, another large but definitely cuter silhouette will take its place: a 43-foot terrier puppy made of flowers will go up in front of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in the same spot where the tree stands.

title: National Pride Over a Virus In Philippines
description: An editorial in a local paper captured the national mood today as a computer student all but admitted creating a destructive program that crippled e-mail systems around the world.

title: FAILED BID COSTS AIR PRODUCTS $450 MILLION
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. said yesterday that it expected to take charges totaling $450 million for the cost of abandoning its acquisition of BOC Group of Britain. Air Products and Air Liquide of France said on Wednesday that they were scrapping their plan to buy BOC for $11.5 billion, because of opposition from the Federal Trade Commission. Air Products, based in Allentown, Pa., said most of the costs it incurred in the BOC deal were related to the currency forward contracts it used to hedge its share of the purchase. Air Liquide is the world's No. 1 producer of industrial gases, while BOC is No. 2 and Air Products is No. 4. Air Products' shares rose $3.5625 yesterday, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My first reaction was, Edward, get down on your knees and beg the Lord to give you a hand, and don't get up too quickly.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Acknowledges Risks Of Sport Utility Vehicles

title: Love Hopes to Finish as He Started
description: It has been more than two years since Davis Love III last won a golf tournament. That is a long time for a player of Love's caliber, long enough for confidence to slip, for frustration to become overwhelming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORFINKLE, LAWRENCE DAVID
description: GORFINKLE-Lawrence David. 56, on May 10, 2000, after a courageous battle with a sudden illness. Beloved husband of Alaine. Loving father of Joshua, Gwen, Lynn and Marc. Devoted brother of Irene Lowengart, Anne Schneider, Emily Watt and the late James. Son of the late Herbert and Evelyn. Caring uncle of Andrea and Jeffrey Schneider and Michael Watt. Service Friday 10AM Plaza Memorial, 91 St. & Amsterdam Av. Contributions in his memory to Chabad of Fairfield County, 57 Revonah Av, Stamford, CT. 06905 or Westchester Day School, 856 Orient Avenue, Mamaroneck, New York 10543.

title: By Push or Hustle, Ward and Childs Get It Done
description: Pound for pound, they are perhaps the toughest players in this roguish series that passes for playoff basketball. One talks the talk, verbally challenging referees and competitors and, if necessary, throwing right-left combinations at larger, more celebrated opponents on national television. The other studies his Bible daily, speaks in a slow monotone that suggests disinterest and carries himself humbly throughout the often egotistical atmosphere of the National Basketball Association.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ALTAVISTA CO., London, named Pierre Paperon, formerly a managing director at AltaVista France, to the post of president for Europe.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLIONE, JOHN J.
description: GALLIONE-John J. On May 11, 2000. Beloved husband of Dori. Devoted father of Joy Martinez and her husband Ernesto, Gale Cohen and her husband Michael and the late Jan Gallione. Cherished grandfather of Grace and Jesse Martinez and Jonathan and Allison Cohen. Devoted brother of Joyce Binder. Service Saturday, May 13, at 10 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: G.O.P. Will Scrutinize Clinton's National Security Policies
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, agreed today to create a national security advisory panel of senior Republican experts in an effort to give more credibility to Congressional scrutiny and criticism of President Clinton's foreign policy.

title: Gervase Cowell, 73, Manager of a Soviet Turncoat Spy, Dies
description: Gervase Cowell, the British secret agent who ran Col. Oleg Penkovsky, one of the most valuable Soviet turncoat spies, died on May 2.

title: Dr. Jay Shorr, 75, Teacher of Analysis
description: Dr. Jay Shorr, a psychoanalyst and leading teacher of other psychoanalysts, died on Saturday at his home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. He was 75.

title: Financier Maintains His Innocence in Jail Interview
description: The man accused of masterminding the largest insurance fraud in American history, Martin R. Frankel, now insists his complex financial dealings were a legitimate effort to feed the world's hungry.

title: Hofstra Set To Face Maryland
description: Hofstra has been to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's lacrosse tournament before, and each of those appearances was greeted with a celebration on campus. This year, with a berth in the tournament already secured thanks to the Flying Dutchmen's status as America East champions, the reaction was different. Hofstra is hoping the result will be different, too.

title: Computer-Generated Havoc
description: Most of us know what postal junk mail looks like, no matter how cleverly it comes disguised. Most of us also know what a computer-generated phone call sounds like -- the telltale click and pause before your name is mispronounced by a badly paid stranger. But even the worst junk mail will not open your other mail, read your address book and send out fake letters above your forged signature. Even the most obnoxious phone rep cannot go through your phone log and call all your friends and business associates while mimicking your voice.

title: Subtle Juxtapositions From a Diffident Force for Change
description: If fame is a reputation earned by achievement, and celebrity is just the fame of being famous, as Daniel Boorstin once suggested, what do you call achievement without much fame or any celebrity? The answer for today: Nathan Lyons. A photographer, Mr. Lyons has had a major impact on his field for close to four decades, yet very few people other than photographers and photography experts know his name, and not even many experts are familiar with much of his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNSTLER, PHYLLIS FRIEDMAN
description: KUNSTLER-Phyllis Friedman. Of Rye, NY, died suddenly on May 9, 2000. Wife of the late Michael J. Kunstler, beloved mother of Susan Y. Kunstler, and the late William H. Kunstler. Children's Librarian for over 20 years at Port Chester Public Library. Beloved sister, aunt, and cousin to so many who loved her dearly. Services Friday, May 12th at 2 P.M. at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARANO, GARY R.
description: MARANO-Gary R. The Upper West Side is mourning the sudden untimely death of entrepreneur Gary Marano, 47, an owner of the Raccoon Lodge who was killed in a motorcycle accident in Montauk on Sunday, May 7, 2000. Awardwinning artist, photographer, sailing enthusiast, world traveler and theatrical producer, Mr. Marano was known for treating his patrons as family by keeping the bars open on Thanksgiving and Christmas as a haven for ''holiday orphans.'' Every December, there would be a day when 83rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue became a sea of Harley-Davidsons, as Mr. Marano's friends gathered for the annual Toys for Tots Run to St. Mary's Hospital for Children in Bayside, Queens. His family, friends, godchildren, employees and patrons will miss him profoundly. Mr. Marano is survived by his mother, Dorothy and two brothers, Thomas and Michael. Viewing will be held on Thursday, 2-4PM and 7-9PM at Hungerford and Clark Funeral Home, 110 Pine Street, Freeport, LI. 516-379-3119. Memorial Service May 13, 2000 at 4PM at NY Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, NY, NY.

Much loved husband of Joan Ohlson, suportive son of Kathleen Barry, caring father of Kevin, Dianna (Speranza), Garrett and Darren, respected brother of Jim, Tim, and Steve, and proud grandfather of Aleah, Jimmy, Brian, Devin, Nikolas. We will miss his agile mind and challenging discussions, his honesty and warmth, his strength and dynamism, his ability to be himself. Memorial Service at Hudson Guild, 441 West 26th Street, on May 12th, at 1 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hudson Guild or American Cancer Society.

title: Buyback at BorgWarner
description: BorgWarner Inc., the second-largest engine-turbocharger maker, plans to buy back as many as 1.2 million shares, or 4.5 percent of the stock outstanding, after the shares lost a quarter of their value in the past year. The automotive parts company, which changed its name from Borg-Warner Automotive in February, may reissue the shares for general corporate purposes. Based on today's close, the new buyback would cost about $52.7 million. The company's shares rose $1.3125 each, to $43.9375.

title: Citron Haligman Gets Palm Account

title: Planned Blaze Close Cousin Of a Wildfire
description: The hard truth of fire management is that the conditions most auspicious for a ''prescribed burn,'' in which dangerously dense pine forests are purged of combustible debris, are not so very different from those that can lead to a devastating wildfire. The weather must be dry enough for brush, dead wood and thickets of stunted pine trees to ignite, and there must be enough wind to spread the flames.

title: AES IS PAYING $667 MILLION FOR 70% STAKE IN POWER PLANT
description: The AES Corporation, an international utility, said yesterday that it planned to pay $667 million for a 70 percent stake in a Nevada power plant. With the plant, the MW Mohave Generating Station in Laughlin, Nev., AES will add to its position in high-growth areas like Las Vegas, Phoenix and Southern California. The company, based in Arlington, Va., plans to buy a 56 percent stake from the Southern California Edison Company, a subsidiary of Edison International, for $533 million, and a 14 percent stake from the Nevada Power Company for about $134 million. The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power and the Salt River Project own the other 30 percent.

title: BANK OF IRELAND'S EARNINGS DISAPPOINT
description: The Bank of Ireland reported a 10 percent increase in the year that ended on March 31, to 920 million euros, or $830.76 million, but the results were short of expectations. title: Czech Gypsies Knock Harder on the Closed Doors
description: Monika Horakova, a sparky psychologist of 26, is a member of the Czech Republic's Parliament -- the only one who is a Roma, or Gypsy. But she is still seeking criminal prosecution of the club in her hometown, Brno, that barred her because of her race.

title: Dinner With Bourgeois Friends. Hold the Realism.
description: Luis Bunuel's career began with one of the most famous images in cinema -- the sliced eyeball of ''Un Chien Andalou,'' his 1928 collaboration with Salvador Dali -- and ended in the 1970's with a loose trilogy of high-style surrealist extravaganzas for the French producer Serge Silberman. The first of these -- ''The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie,'' which won the Academy Award for best foreign film in 1973 -- has now been rereleased by Rialto Pictures, to celebrate the centenary of the director's birth. More such releases are promised, but ''The Discreet Charm'' is an excellent place to renew acquaintance with Bunuel (who died in 1983), or to meet him for the first time.

title: State Senator Will Challenge Congressman
description: State Senator Larry B. Seabrook announced yesterday that he would challenge United States Representative Eliot L. Engel, who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County, for the Democratic nomination for that seat in Congress.

title: INVISIBLE INJURY: A Special Report.; A Perplexing Foe Takes an Awful Toll
description: Eric Lindros, the Philadelphia Flyers' star center, has missed the first two rounds of the Stanley Cup playoffs and will not be on the ice Sunday when his team faces the Devils in the first game of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Downtown Life, River to River
description: AN elfin, top-hatted statue perched high on a venerable red-brick building at Houston and Lafayette Streets leans over the sidewalk, holding a mirror above the passing crowds. The gold-leaf figure is Puck, the playful sprite of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' whose mischievous spirit animates the building that takes his name and the scene below on which he muses. For along Houston Street, Puck, who proclaims ''What fools these mortals be!,'' has a rich array of humanity to marvel at. There are finger-snapping jazz-hounds, 4 a.m. pool sharks, dancing fools, fools waiting behind a velvet rope to start dancing, pregnant folk singers, walkers, poseurs from SoHo (south of Houston), shoppers from NoHo (north of Houston), gardeners, noshers, moviegoers of every stripe -- and a handful of sinks for the bar and bathroom, if not the kitchen.

title: Heady Throw by Ventura Protects Leiter's Victory
description: Al Leiter bounced off the mound, a bundle of energy and nerves, as Bruce Aven's soft chopper floated toward third base. If the Pittsburgh Pirates were going to tie the game, you could almost hear Leiter saying, it was not going to be on a hit like this.

title: A logistics problem prompts the Four A's conference to reassess its format and agenda.
description: THE saying that necessity is the mother of invention was not, as far as can be determined, coined on Madison Avenue. But the trade organization representing the nation's advertising agencies is taking that adage to heart in planning its annual management conference.

description: If you think children grow up too fast, pity the poor insect. Only 2 days old, Maya the Bee is told to toil in the hive. Since a bee's work is never done, Maya decides not to begin it at all. Instead, she flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey.

title: QUANTA SERVICES SHARES JUMP ON NEWS OF SIX PURCHASES
description: Quanta Services, an installer of power and phone lines, said yesterday that it had bought six companies with expected sales of about $105 million in 2000. Terms were not disclosed. Quanta's shares rose $6.1875 each, or 12.5 percent, to $55.625. Quanta said it bought the Utilities Construction Company in South Carolina, TVS Systems in Utah, Southeast Pipeline Construction of Georgia and MC Underground of Colorado. The company also bought the Croce Electric Company and the Eastern Communications Corporation, both based in Massachusetts. Quanta, based in Houston, provides contracting services to telecommunications companies, electric utilities and cable television operators through offices in 37 states.

title: Vatican Makes Egan's Appointment as Archbishop Official
description: Making official an appointment eclipsed by the death of Cardinal John O'Connor last week, the Vatican named Bishop Edward Michael Egan of Bridgeport, known for his success in replenishing the priesthood and streamlining church operations, the next archbishop of New York yesterday.

title: E.P.A. Finds Malathion Poses Low Risk
description: A new federal review of the health effects of malathion, the insecticide sprayed around New York City last year to kill disease-carrying mosquitoes, has found ''suggestive evidence'' that high doses of the chemical may cause cancer in laboratory animals, but no evidence that it poses a threat to people when used properly.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair set out to modernize England by building bridges to both the Continent and the United States. So far he has been succeeding, and with a baby due any day, he retains the British public firmly on his side. A report by Warren Hoge in The Times Magazine.

title: Making 'Impossible' Game Consoles a Dream Teamer
description: Many of the world's best players are gathered in Las Vegas this weekend for two long-established events. The Cavendish Pairs began yesterday afternoon, and the top-ranked pairs, based on the Calcutta pool, were: first, Steve Weinstein and Bob Levin, the defending champions; second, Zia Mahmood and Bob Hamman; third, David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen; fourth, Gabriel Chagas and Geir Helgemo. The total in the Calcutta pool was $1,140,500.

title: In Hunters' Havens, Gun Control Is Risk for Gore
description: It has become conventional wisdom among Democratic strategists that the Million Mom March for gun control on Sunday will be good for Vice President Al Gore in his quest for the presidency. But the conventional wisdom does not apply here in Beaver County.

title: Gift at Dinner for Senator: Honor, or Seeking Favor?
description: Among the dignitaries who gathered earlier this month in the white marble grandeur of the Folger Shakespeare Library on Capitol Hill to pay tribute to Senator Connie Mack was the chief executive of Merck & Company.

title: Duck Soup to Go? Horse Feathers!
description: A knack for conjuring fun in a laughter-free vacuum may be the ultimate test of a comic performer. And in ''Screwed,'' a confusedly misconceived hybrid of interracial buddy comedy and imitation Marx Brothers farce, Danny DeVito is the only cast member who succeeds in making something out of the movie's nothing of a screenplay. As Grover Cleaver, a bushy-haired undertaker who gets drawn into a kidnapping scheme, Mr. DeVito huffs and mugs and waddles through his role like a happy mad scientist whose maniacally gleaming eyes suggest he could be imagining a chorus line of lab rats doing a striptease.

title: Spanish Company Is in Talks With Lycos
description: Setting its sights on affluent North America, Terra Networks S.A., the aggressive Internet company controlled by the Spanish phone giant, Telefonica S.A., told stock market regulators in Madrid today that it was in talks with the Web search company, Lycos Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASPER, LOIS
description: KASPER - Lois. Your grace, strength and humor were a inspiration. The depth of love between you and our son Bruce was beautiful to behold. It's been our honor to have you as a member of our family. Estelle and Eli Tuchman & family

title: The Big City; Parting Ways With His Hero And His Wife
description: IN September 1995, Donna Hanover sat down with me for an interview that must have struck her as awkwardly timed. New York magazine was on the newsstands with a cover story, ''The Woman Behind the Mayor,'' and the woman was not Ms. Hanover. The story was about Cristyne Lategano, the communications director and constant companion to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Am I a Cool Mother?
description: Seeing a mother yelling at her daughter in a supermarket recently, I felt two things: pretty sure that with Mother's Day approaching, that mother was asking for a lump of coal, and smug about my close relationship with my own 10-year-old daughter.

title: Ford to Close British Plant, Laying Off 1,900 Workers

title: U.N. CHIEF FAULTS RELUCTANCE OF U.S. TO HELP IN AFRICA
description: Faced with wars on several fronts in Africa, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that the United Nations' peacekeeping efforts needed the kind of military help that the United States was now unwilling to provide.

title: At University, Dreams Of Billions and Billions; As Rochester Pursues a Higher Profile, A Potentially Lucrative Patent May Help
description: The University of Rochester had ambitions to be a national powerhouse in medical research. And it had charted a meticulous 10-year plan to get there: get more research money from the National Institutes of Health, recruit 100 more biomedical scientists and construct two research buildings.

title: Gloves Come Off in New Jersey Republican Senate Race
description: The Republican candidates for the United States Senate barely uttered an unneighborly word about one another in their debate on Monday. But with 25 days left until the June 6 primary, the knives have come out.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMGEN INC., Thousand Oaks, Calif., named Kevin W. Sharer, president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive. He succeeds Gordon Binder, who is retiring.

title: Writing Their Own Ticket On an Original of the Past
description: The pianist and composer Lennie Tristano left a legacy that seems to go radically against the grain of jazz in the be-bop era: for the most part, his surviving music sacrifices dynamics and the ecstatic spilling-over of swinging rhythm sections; on his records, drummers tick like metronomes, avoiding the emphasis of the second and fourth beats.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARORDER.COM INC., Austin, Tex., a car seller on the Internet, has laid off 100 workers, or nearly one-third of its work force, as it struggles with competition in the online auto sales industry.

description: Jockey Richard Migliore has appealed the five-day suspension handed down Wednesday by Churchill Downs stewards for careless riding aboard Wheelaway in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Privacy Rights Win Over Bias Charges In Defamation Case
description: As a dispute with their neighbors intensified in 1994, Mitchell and Candace Aronson of Evergreen, Colo., tuned in a police scanner to intercept private phone conversations and heard the neighbors make what the Aronsons perceived as anti-Semitic remarks about them. The Aronsons sought help from the Anti-Defamation League, whose local director publicly called the neighbors anti-Semites.

description: The parents of an Israeli-American teenager killed in a 1996 terrorist attack in Jerusalem filed a $600-million lawsuit in Chicago yesterday against several Islamic charities, nonprofit groups and individuals, contending that they raised money in the United States for Hamas, the militant Palestinian group.

title: Religion Journal; Repenting Racist Acts And Recalling Genocide
description: When leaders of the United Methodist Church gathered for their General Conference in Cleveland for the last two weeks, much attention focused on whether the denomination, the nation's largest mainline Protestant body, would modify its stands against ordaining gays and blessing same-sex unions. That did not happen, as delegates voted this week to retain those prohibitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISNER, SELMA
description: REISNER-Selma, on May 11th, 2000, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Adolph Reisner. Loving mother of Nancy Schlick and Henry Reisner, mother-in-law of Lynn Reisner and the late Larry Schlick, grandmother of Carla Valentino, Erica Payne, Robert Schiffmann, Jr., Brad Reisner & Alison Reisner, great-grandmother of Robert and Douglas Payne. Services on Sunday, May 14th, at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn Heights, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or Cancer Care.

title: F.B.I. Computer Problem Halts Gun Sales
description: Legal gun sales around the nation came to a halt after a computer software malfunction at the Federal Bureau of Investigation prevented instant background checks of prospective buyers, officials said today.

title: Mayoral Marriage: Public or Private?
description: To the Editor:

title: SWISSAIR EYES BRAZIL
description: The four main airlines in Brazil are in discussions with Swissair, part of SAirGroup, about possible partnerships. Swissair said it wanted to add flights to Brazil after the cancellation of such flights by the most financially troubled of the four carriers, Vasp. Under Brazilian law, foreigners can own up to 20 percent of a domestic airline. Vasp, Varig, Transbrazil and TAM are all struggling with heavy debts and the effects of a currency devaluation last year. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Homer Thompson Dies at 93; Led Excavation of the Agora
description: Homer A. Thompson, an archaeologist who for decades led the sweeping and painstaking excavation of the Agora, the civic center of ancient Athens, died Sunday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 93.

title: Saul Bellow on Birth, Death and All That Stuff in Between
description: Sitting in the office that the art critic Harold Rosenberg once used (his poster of a beautiful Nautilus shell still hangs there), Saul Bellow is leaning back slightly, fingertips touching, pausing before beginning to speak. For a listener whose education was shaped in part by Augie March and Henderson and Mr. Sammler, Mr. Bellow's meditations can seem a creation of his characters' pungent imaginations. Now his surgically shaped phrases and dreamlike imagery make it sound as if he were reciting one of Herzog's letters to the famous dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHEL, MARJORIE S.
description: FISCHEL-Marjorie S., Weston, CT, on March 24. Much loved by grandson Noah Fischel, son Alwyn Fischel, Jr., daughters Catherine Schlossberg and Sally Fischel; fondly remembered by stepdaughters Phyllis Tannous, Constance Kappel, stepson Arnold Fischel. ''I have known sadness, I have known great joy, I have known love. With all these wonderful possessions, I am rich, and cannot be trapped in an ailing body or a distraught mind''. Memorial donations to Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind or to Mid Fairfield Hospice appreciated.

title: EXXON MOBIL TO SELL JET TURBINE UNIT TO BP AMOCO
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its jet turbine lubricator business to the Air BP Division of BP Amoco. Financial terms of the transaction, which still requires United States regulatory approval, were not disclosed. Exxon Mobil said the business includes its blending and packaging operations in Linden, N.J., as well as research equipment, raw material and the rights to several Exxon patents. Sale of the jet turbine lubricator business was part of the divestiture package agreed to by the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation to get merger approval from the Federal Trade Commission last November. Exxon Mobil will continue to make and sell Mobil jet turbine lubricating oils worldwide.

title: ECOLAB TO REPURCHASE $200 MILLION OF ITS STOCK
description: Ecolab Inc. said yesterday that it planned to repurchase up to $200 million of its shares, roughly 4 percent of its stock outstanding. Ecolab, a cleaning and pest-elimination company based in St. Paul, reported $2.1 billion of revenue for the last 12 months. The company has about 129.7 million shares outstanding valued at roughly $5.1 billion. The stock was down 50 cents yesterday at $40.1875 on the Big Board. The buyback will take place over an unspecified time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, RUTH
description: GROSS-Ruth. On May 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Stewart. Loving mother of Fred, Alan and Paula. Dear sister of Harriet and the late Doris. Adoring grandmother of Stephanie and Samuel. Loving companion of Leonard Sherman. She will be profoundly missed. Service Sunday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'',76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Near the Apex At Xerox and Loving the Hill
description: Anne M. Mulcahy, the new president and chief operating officer at the Xerox Corporation, is often mistaken for Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of the Xerox archrival, Hewlett-Packard. And Ms. Mulcahy gets a huge kick out of playing off the parallels.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: John P. Robin, 87; Led the Redevelopment of Downtown Pittsburgh
description: John P. Robin, who played an influential role in the transformation of Pittsburgh from a smoggy, grimy city into one of gleaming skyscrapers and grassy promenades, died on Sunday at his daughter's house in Pittsburgh. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UCHIMA, ANSEI. SARAH LAWRENCE
description: UCHIMA-Ansei. Sarah Lawrence College notes with sorrow the death of emeritus faculty member, Ansei Uchima, on May 9, 2000. Distinguished artist and revered teacher, he provided a guiding vision for our studio arts program for 20 years until his retirement in 1982. We extend our deepest sympathy to his devoted family. Michele Tolela Myers, President Barbara Kaplan, Dean of the College

title: New York's New Archbishop
description: In Bishop Edward M. Egan, Pope John Paul II appears to have found a dependable successor to Cardinal John O'Connor as leader of the country's most visible Roman Catholic archdiocese. Bishop Egan is well known to the pope after years of work at the Vatican, and is a theological conservative who can be expected to reinforce the pope's -- and Cardinal O'Connor's -- stern views on abortion, contraception and homosexuality. But given the financial and managerial challenges facing the diocese, Bishop Egan's demonstrated administrative skills may have appealed to the pope every bit as much as his doctrinal reliability.

title: A Town's Grieving Mothers Find Reason to Pray and to Cry, but Not to March
description: Teresa Brown carries a letter and a photograph in her pocketbook. The photograph is of her son, Patrick. The letter is from one of the five young men who killed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTA, IDA (NEE GANZ)
description: SIROTA-Ida (nee Ganz). On May 11, 2000, age 92 years. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Linda Brown (Stephen) and Dr. David King Sirota (Theodora). Cherished grandmother of Miriam Sirota, Eliot Cail-Sirota (Jessica), Allison Brown Kotin (Alan), and Jennifer Brown Simon (Neal). Adored great-grandmother of Zachary, Ryan and Jake. Caring teacher at P.S. 117 in Queens for many years. Service Sunday, 9:30AM, ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS WITHDRAWS PLANS FOR OFFERING
description: The American Greetings Corporation, the greeting card company, said yesterday that it was withdrawing its plan to offer a minority stake in its online unit because of ''changing financial market conditions.'' The company did not say whether the initial public offering in AmericanGreetings.com was a postponement or a cancellation. Cleveland-based American Greetings filed in August with the Securities and Exchange Commission, hoping to raise $60 million. People who visit the AmericanGreetings.com Web site can create their own online greeting, send it electronically or print it out. The company has been discussing ways to merge its online businesses with San Francisco-based Egreetings Network Inc.

title: A Celestial Being Illuminates Assisi but Also Brooklyn
description: In a sane musical world, the magnificence of Olivier Messiaen's opera ''St. Francis of Assisi'' would long since have overwhelmed the difficulties of putting it on. But nearly two decades after the work's first performance, it has still not been staged in the United States, nor has there even been a full concert performance. So tonight's presentation at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, when the Brooklyn Philharmonic will play three crucial scenes from the opera, is an especially welcome opportunity to hear, and feel, some of the most glorious music of the last quarter century.

title: Mothers of Reinvention Chat About Offspring
description: One of Margaret Pataki's proudest memories is of her son George, when he was first able to lift a strawberry basket.

title: 'Tiger Lady' Vows to Fight an Order to Close Compound
description: Even as New Jersey officials work to find a new home for 26 tigers housed at a compound in Jackson Township, Joan Byron-Marasek, the ''Tiger Lady'' who has been raising the animals on her property for 24 years, is determined to continue her legal fight against a judge's order last month to shut down the preserve.

title: On Road Again in Midwest, Clinton Promotes China Trade
description: President Clinton took his campaign to improve trade relations with China to the Midwest today, arguing that if Congress rejected the measure it would deny troubled farmers a chance to tap a giant new market.

title: Jarvis Discusses Wizards' Job
description: Mike Jarvis, the St. John's basketball coach, has met with Michael Jordan to discuss the Washington Wizards' head-coaching job, a person familiar with the meeting said.

title: Foster Care Agencies Fault Statewide Computer System
description: In 1995, in an effort to better monitor the state's most vulnerable children, state officials approved the creation of an ambitious statewide computer system. It was supposed to enable private and public social service agencies throughout the state to track child abuse reports, to find appropriate foster homes for abused and neglected children and to comply with layers of government reporting requirements swiftly and accurately.

title: Ewing Shows Knicks Both Sides of Coin
description: Patrick Ewing held up his shooting hand high, arching his wrist as if he were doing a King Tut impression or auditioning for the ''Walk Like an Egyptian'' video. When the shot fell through with 2.6 seconds remaining in regulation and Madison Square Garden became delirious and finally too loud to hear, the hand was still raised. He backpedaled downcourt that way, the longest follow through anyone could remember, maybe since Christian Laettner sank Kentucky in 1992.

title: NO MORE LUNCH AT SEOUL EXCHANGE
description: The lunch-hour break at the Korea Stock Exchange will be abolished, probably starting Monday, the Financial Supervisory Service said. The exchange has reconfigured its computers to run through the lunch hour, said Lee Kap Soo, director of the capital market supervision department. The abolition of lunch hour has been planned for some time but had been delayed because of protests from unionized workers. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: LeMond Raising Funds for Hall
description: Greg LeMond, widely considered America's greatest cyclist, will pay his first visit to the United States Cycling Hall of Fame next month to help raise money for the institution, which was founded in 1987 in Somerville, N.J.

title: Clemens and Yankees Undone by the Atmosphere
description: Tiger Stadium would have never held the ball the Yankees' Jorge Posada smashed in the ninth inning tonight. No, Posada's drive would have crashed into the second deck and rattled amid empty seats, tying the game, and the Yankees would have probably gone on to beat the Tigers.

title: Challenger Warns Jones To Get Ready to Battle
description: There is always a fighter who thinks he knows the secret to beating Roy Jones Jr., the undisputed light-heavyweight champion. Before they step into the ring, opponents pick him apart, looking for weaknesses that are not really there. Younger opponents think they can take advantage of his age (31), taller boxers his height (5 feet 11 inches) and stronger combatants his relatively slight frame.

title: Never Too Late To Make Debut In the Majors
description: The 37-year-old rookie was leaning against a wall outside the visiting clubhouse at Shea Stadium, smiling.

title: Telefonica's Brave New World; A Strategy With a Latin American Centerpiece
description: In Spain's corporate world, with its cozy relationships and closely knit elite, it might have seemed that Juan Villalonga's greatest asset as head of the national phone company was his boyhood friendship with the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar. But Mr. Villalonga, the 47-year-old chairman of the company, Telefonica, has also made his way on his own.

title: Quality Time Is Authority Time
description: Last week's White House conference on teenagers kept coming back to one conclusion above all: that parental involvement is the best tonic for what ails troubled teenagers. President Clinton, calling attention to a report from the Council of Economic Advisers, announced that ''teenagers that had dinner with their parents five times a week are far more likely to avoid smoking, drinking, violence, suicide and drugs.'' He and the first lady trumpeted a campaign to encourage family togetherness, and he promised to make it easier for federal workers to spend time with their teenagers.

title: Sports of The Times; Riley Finding His Time Is Passing By
description: PAT RILEY is back in town, the venerable crunch-time coach who brought you Showtime in Los Angeles, Short Time in New York and now Zo Time in Miami. Last night Riley pulled another rabbit out of his hat with Alonzo Mourning saddled with fouls and Tim Hardaway barely able to walk. The Heat forced the Knicks to play one of those nasty, head-butting, arm-wrestling games that used to be New York's signature but now is just something they do whenever they play Miami.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These two countries, they each try to throw the ball -- or should I say the people -- into the other's court.''

title: Youngest Racer of Petty Family Killed in Crash
description: Adam Petty, the only fourth-generation athlete in American sports and part of the famous Nascar auto racing family, died yesterday after crashing during practice at New Hampshire International Speedway. He was 19.

title: Judge Rejects Suits to Block Filtering Plant
description: A federal judge dismissed three lawsuits against a planned water filtration plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday, allowing the city to go forward with construction of a project that has been assailed by community groups and environmentalists as a misuse of public parkland.

title: Woman Is Robbed And Hit With Brick
description: A woman was robbed and struck with a brick yesterday morning as she walked along a Queens street, a police official said.

title: Stolen Trailer Found in Queens, But Cargo of Cyanide Is Missing
description: Police officers found a stolen truck trailer on a deserted street in Queens last night, but it was missing 20 drums of potassium cyanide, a highly poisonous chemical.

title: Opposition Grows to Deadline for Pulling G.I.'s From Kosovo
description: The Pentagon and a bipartisan group of senators today criticized legislation that sets a deadline for withdrawing American ground troops from Kosovo, warning that the measure would undermine the NATO operation and embolden President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Weekend yesterday misidentified the hall where the Bronx Opera Company is presenting Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale'' this weekend. The performance at 8 tonight is at the John Jay College Theater, 899 10th Avenue, at 59th Street, in Manhattan, not at Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about renewed rivalry between Moscow and St. Petersburg misstated the history of St. Petersburg's name and referred incompletely to the shift of the Russian capital from St. Petersburg to Moscow. St. Petersburg was renamed Petrograd as a patriotic gesture after war broke out with Germany in 1914; it was not renamed by Lenin. In 1918, Moscow was made the capital in part because it was easier to defend than St. Petersburg, not solely as a symbolic stamp of the triumph of Communism over the czar.

title: Bush Offers Texas Handgun Owners Free Trigger Locks
description: George W. Bush announced today that he would spend $1 million a year as governor of Texas to provide free trigger locks for handgun owners in the state and would push for a similar national initiative, at a cost of $65 million a year, if he was elected president.

title: When the 3 Tenors Have a Party, It's Relax and Enjoy
description: The Metropolitan Opera's Millennium Celebration served so many purposes on Thursday night that one scarcely has room to list them.

title: Head Scarf Required at Official Functions : For Malaysian Women, Pressure to Be Islamic
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Rafidah Aziz, the trade and industry minister of Malaysia, wears bright, floral outfits and is famous for her stinging tongue and fierce negotiating tactics.

title: From Near-Ruin to King of the Ad World
description: It was not so long ago that Sir Martin Sorrell was on the brink of ruin, having nearly bankrupted the British advertising conglomerate, the WPP Group, that he was trying to build.

title: As Johnson Sits, Camby Gets Chance in Stretch
description: He is arguably the Knicks' best clutch player, the powerful forward who becomes a 3-point marksman at the game's most critical moments. He put his signature on last year's fanciful playoff run with his unforgettable 4-point play that pushed the Knicks to victory over Indiana in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals, then made back-to-back 3-pointers in the fourth quarter of a victory in Game 5 on the Pacers' home floor.

title: A Little Give And Take Over Refs
description: Jeff Van Gundy and Pat Riley have been tugging at the officials like Silly Putty over the last couple of days in an attempt to find more favorable calls for their star players.

title: Stranded Pakistanis Dreaming of Deliverance
description: The world ceaselessly churns out human tragedy. The newly conquered. Newly dispossessed. Newly hungry. Newly diseased. Newly destitute.

title: Woman, 78, Fatally Shot; Granddaughter Is Hurt
description: A 78-year-old woman was fatally shot in the head as she slept in her bed and her 22-year-old granddaughter was shot in the face yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Robert C. Bassett, 89, Lawyer and Publisher
description: Robert C. Bassett, a former lawyer, labor negotiator and publisher who represented small-business interests on the councils of two presidential administrations, died on May 2 in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 89.

title: Insuring a Fair Vote in Peru
description: In the first round of Peru's presidential elections last month, President Alberto Fujimori manipulated the agencies that oversaw the election and counted the votes. He kept coverage of his major opponent -- and even the candidate's advertising -- off television. Opposition rallies were sabotaged and candidates and election monitors intimidated. If there had not been intense international criticism of the abuses, Mr. Fujimori would probably have pushed his vote total over the 50 percent required to claim victory.

title: A Real New Jersey Debate
description: With a crucial Senate primary less than a month away, New Jersey voters have finally seen their first unscripted debates this week, the highlight being a brutal but revealing match between the two Democratic candidates. The encounter forced Jon Corzine, a former Wall Street financier with no political experience, to come out from behind his $1 million-a-week advertising shield to face off against an opponent known for his acerbic debating style, former Gov. Jim Florio.

title: Abducted and Then Shot, Student at Seton Hall Dies
description: A 23-year-old Seton Hall University student died this afternoon, two days after she was abducted from a street near the campus and shot in the head by a former boyfriend, who then took his own life.

description: In percent

title: Carter Plays the Unlikely Hero With a Most Unlikely Basket
description: The ball had hung above the rim for what seemed an eternity before dropping through the net. And as it descended, thousands of voices in the Madison Square Garden crowd cried in agony. On the floor, amid the stunned and shocked players, the official Dan Crawford started to wave the basket off.

title: BLUE SHADOWS -- A special report.; Suspicions Swirl Around New Jersey Police Clique
description: Lt. Edward Szpond, once one of the most influential officers in the Elizabeth Police Department, sits these days at a desk in the department's basement, in charge of the property room. He was reassigned to the glamorless job several years ago after the mayor of Elizabeth said he had determined that he was one of the leaders of a secretive and disruptive group of officers known as the Family.

title: Giuliani Decision on Senate Expected in Days
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spent yesterday afternoon behind closed doors as he began what his advisers said would be a weekend-long effort to consider treatment options for his prostate cancer and to try to decide whether to stay in -- or drop out of -- his supercharged race for the United States Senate.

title: Annalee Newman, 91, Muse And Support for the Artist
description: Annalee Newman, who spent 34 years as the wife and another 30 as the widow of Barnett Newman, the Abstract Expressionist painter, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: In Michigan, a Lunch Break Leads to $181 Million
description: A man walks into a convenience store, buys a hot dog with a $100 bill, spends the change on 98 lottery tickets and a few hours later, wins half of the nation's richest jackpot ever.

title: Political Turmoil Adds to Colombian President's Woes
description: Since taking office in August 1998, President Andres Pastrana of Colombia has had his hands full trying to fend off both guerrillas and drug traffickers. Now a deepening political crisis is threatening to weaken his authority even further.

title: Ford's Admission Perplexes the Neighbors in Henry's Hometown
description: The doors and floor mats at City Hall here proudly bear the logo, ''Home Town of Henry Ford.'' The Ford Motor Company's headquarters, an immense rectangle of glass and steel in a community of two-story homes, is a mile down the street, and the company's endless office parks, factories and test tracks cover most of the landscape.

title: A Gleam That Corrupts
description: In the 1970's, when I first began working as an anthropologist in the Kono diamond mining district that is now the center of the rebel-held territory in Sierra Leone, I attended the trial of an old Kono chief. Men in red berets and red T-shirts intimidated the chief's supporters and witnesses and surrounded the open-air court. Although the official charges covered an assortment of crimes including murder and cannibalism -- not one of which this local court actually had the jurisdiction to hear -- the real issue was diamonds.

description: To the Editor:

title: GREENLIGHT CAPITAL WITHDRAWS BNC MORTGAGE BID
description: Greenlight Capital Inc., a New York hedge fund, has withdrawn its $56.1 million offer to buy BNC Mortgage Inc., a residential mortgage lender. After reviewing BNC's financial records, Greenlight ''decided not to proceed with the proposed transaction,'' according to a letter dated Thursday from Jeffrey A. Keswin, Greenlight's co-president, to the chairman of BNC Mortgage, Evan Buckley. The letter was included in a regulatory filing. BNC, based in Irvine, Calif., agreed in February to be bought by a management-led group for $10 a share. Then, it received the offer of $11 a share from Greenlight. BNC now expects the sale to the management group for $10 a share to occur by the end of July.

title: ENTERCOM TO SELL 3 RADIO STATIONS AND BUY 3 OTHERS
description: The Entercom Communications Corporation, an owner and operator of more that 90 radio stations in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three radio stations in Kansas City, Kan., to the Susquehanna Radio Corporation for $113 million. The company was required to sell the stations to comply with federal broadcast regulations, because it owns seven stations in the Kansas City market. The company, which is based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., also announced yesterday the acquisition of three radio stations in Madison, Wis., from Woodward Communications Inc. for $14.6 million. Entercom's stock fell $1.375 yesterday, to $46, on the Big Board.

title: BRAZIL CHALLENGES W.T.O. RULING
description: The Brazilian government will appeal a World Trade Organization ruling against export subsidies for the aircraft maker Embraer, a leading maker of small passenger jets. If the ruling is upheld, Canada, home to Embraer's rival Bombardier, could retaliate with up to $3.3 billion in trade sanctions in the next seven years. Canadian and Brazilian trade negotiators will meet on May 23 in hopes of resolving the dispute. Canada was also cited by the W.T.O. for its subsidies to Bombardier, but the Canadian government has said it will respect the ruling. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: The Opposites Of Sex: The Normal' And the Not
description: When it comes to sex, who decides what constitutes normal? Who decides what's too little and who says what's too much? For years, sociologists, psychologists and other experts have charted the continual shifts in sexual attitudes and practices. Now, two feminist historians are trying to upend conventional assumptions about sex, one of them studying celibacy, the other nymphomania.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 6 about the move of Florida East Coast Industries into the telecommunications business misstated the company's ownership. description: Jacquelyn Buglisi has a wondrously extravagant streak in her choreography, which is sharp and clear in its penetrating images. Donlin Foreman opts for passionate lyricism in his dances: he is not afraid of lushness, in movement quality and poetic ideas.

description: President Vladimir V. Putin today offered a backhanded defense of a police raid at the corporate headquarters of Russia's largest private media empire, noting in a statement that ''all are equal before the law, no matter what business they are in.''
