description: SBC Communications Inc., the nation's No. 1 local telephone carrier, took a small step toward entering the long-distance market yesterday when the Justice Department said the company had alleviated one of the department's concerns about opening its networks to competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEARY, GENEVIEVE L.
description: LEARY-Genevieve L. On May 10, 2000, of Rockville, MD. Wife of the late William P. Leary. Beloved mother of Brian M. Leary and his wife, Barbara A. Leary, Kevin D. Leary and his wife, Elizabeth M. Leary, grandmother of Brittany E. Leary, Genevieve N. Leary and Alexis E. Leary, sister of Mrs. Maurice McKenna. A memorial gathering will be held at the Grosvenor Park Condominium, Rooftop Terrace, 10500 Rockville Pike, Rockville, Maryland, on Sunday, May 14th, 6-8 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Society of St. Edmund, 270 Winooski Park, Colchester, Vermont 05439-0270.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RALLIES. A late afternoon rally sent the euro up more than a cent, but it was unable to find enough support to break above the 92-cent mark. In New York, the euro closed yesterday at 91.89 cents, up from 90.06.

title: Controlled Burning, Out of Control
description: As almost everyone in the country knows by now, there is nothing exact about the science of ''controlled'' or ''prescribed'' burning of forests. It is a time-honored technique for clearing forests of debris and thus preventing even more devastating fires that can incinerate entire landscapes. But there is a thin line between success and failure, and what began as a controlled burn in New Mexico's Bandelier National Monument wound up on the wrong side of that line. Fed by winds gusting higher than 60 miles an hour, the fire jumped its intended boundaries, destroying about 270 homes and forcing the evacuation of 18,000 people in nearby Los Alamos. It also immobilized the Los Alamos National Laboratory, where the nation's nuclear weapons are designed.

title: REPORT DISCLOSING MASSACRE BY G.I.'S IS UNDER QUESTION
description: New evidence has been published that appears to undermine the testimony of two witnesses who said that American soldiers were ordered to kill civilians during the Korean War.

title: Two Mozarts, One Sunny and One Stormy
description: Fourteen years and a world of experience separate Mozart's Symphony No. 28, composed in 1773 when he was a 17-year-old prodigy, and his Symphony No. 38, composed in 1787 when he was 31 and at the height of his powers, with only four years left to live. The earlier work breathes with the innocent playfulness of Classical courtliness. The later one rides a wave of high drama, picked up both in the opera house and perhaps also reflecting personal turmoil.

title: Craig Stevens, the Suave Star Of 'Peter Gunn,' Dies at 81
description: Craig Stevens, who created the title role of the suave but tough private eye in ''Peter Gunn,'' a popular television series in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: Pakistan Court Upholds Coup but Orders Reforms
description: Pakistan's Supreme Court ruled today that last October's military coup was legal but set a three-year deadline on a return to civilian rule.

title: Fire-Ravaged Los Alamos Bracing for High Winds
description: Improved weather conditions today stabilized the fire that has destroyed huge swathes of forest and residences here and threatened a major nuclear weapons laboratory. But as officials scrambled to prepare for higher winds expected over the weekend, they said it would be at least a week before thousands of residents forced to evacuate could return to the area.

title: Arguments End in Murder Trial of Mother and Son
description: Four days of closing arguments ended yesterday in the trial of a mother and son charged in the murder of a wealthy Manhattan widow, with prosecutors arguing that while the defendants had successfully hidden the body, they left a map to the crime inside 14 spiral-bound notebooks.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS MAKES DEAL FOR QEYTON OF SWEDEN
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the maker of Internet networking equipment, said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held Swedish company Qeyton Systems, which makes technology to optimize the performance of Internet service providers' networks in metropolitan areas, for $800 million in stock. Based in Stockholm, Qeyton develops metropolitan dense wave division multiplexing technology, which uses multiple colors of light to increase the capacity of fiber networks carrying a combination of phone, Internet and video traffic. Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it expected a one-time charge against after-tax earnings of up to 5 cents related to the deal.

title: The Prosecutor Who Conquered Edwin Edwards
description: IN 1985 and 1986, when Edwin W. Edwards was tried the first two times, Eddie J. Jordan Jr. was a low-level assistant United States attorney prosecuting drug dealers and mail thieves. He played no role in the fraud and conspiracy cases against Mr. Edwards, then Louisiana's governor. But Mr. Jordan never forgot the effect that the cases had on his boss, John Volz.

title: Abroad at Home; Cruelty Without Mercy
description: Michelle Swensen was a zoology student at Kent State University when in 1994 she won a scholarship to go to Japan for a year and learn the language. At Shimane University there she met a student from Yemen, Ashraf al-Jailani. They were married in 1996.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the One Show awards for creative excellence in advertising misstated the number won by two runner-up agencies. Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won 11 awards, not 7; Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York won 9, not 5.

title: Mets' Return Home Is a Lot Like Being on the Road
description: The scoreboard operator welcomed the Mets back to Shea Stadium by playing the memorable scene in which Dorothy finally gets to go home in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' There was Judy Garland, her eyes closed, sweetly and hopefully saying, ''There's no place like home.'' But the Mets did not prove that last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, EVELYN HYMAN

She was a teacher and District Health Ed Supervisor and, from 1958 through 1970, principal of PS66 in Queens. She co-authored the Health Education Curriculum for New York City. She leaves a son and daughter-in-law, Daniel and Deborah Feingold, of Bloomfield, Connecticut, and nephews Milton David Hyman of Hohokus & John Hyman of Chicago, Illinois. Funeral Service will be held Monday, May 15, 2000 at 11:00 AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Corrections

He was Sir Alexander Mackenzie, a fur trader and explorer, not the journalist and political leader William Lyon Mackenzie.

title: General Urges Women to Tell Of Harassment
description: In her first public remarks on a sexual harassment case that has roiled the Army, Lt. Gen. Claudia J. Kennedy said tonight that women in uniform who face harassment needed to report it immediately to friends and superiors or ''misconduct will continue to harm us.''

description: The Republican Party leadership moved today to prevent an early conclusion to the presidential nominating process, recommending a system in which the smallest states would hold their primaries in February while the biggest states would have to wait until May.

description: In the wake of new allegations about the volatile behavior of Bob Knight, Indiana's basketball coach, a meeting of university trustees scheduled for tomorrow has taken on new urgency.

title: ALLTRISTA GETS A BUYOUT OFFER FROM MARLIN PARTNERS
description: The Alltrista Corporation, a maker of metal and plastic products, said it had received a $30-a-share offer from a minority shareholder, Marlin Partners II L.P. The $172 million offer depends on certain financing and management conditions. Alltrista's chief executive, Thomas B. Clark, said the proposal would be sent to the company's board. Financial terms were not disclosed. Marlin Partners, a firm in Rye, N.Y., controlled by Martin Franklin, owns about 9 percent of the 6.3 million outstanding shares of Alltrista, based in Indianapolis. Alltrista's shares rose $3.0625, to $24.75, on the Big Board.

title: Riders of 'Orphan Train' Meet to Tell Life Stories
description: In January 1918, a month-old boy was discovered in a basket in the Gimbels department store in Manhattan, and as he changed hands from a sales clerk to store officials to the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital, someone along the way named him Arthur Field.

title: HONDA PROFIT FALLS
description: Japan's second-biggest automaker, the Honda Motor Company, said its fourth-quarter earnings fell 12 percent from a year earlier, less than expected, as the yen's strength offset record vehicle sales, producing the company's first full-year profit drop in six years. Honda, which relies more on United States sales than any other Japanese automaker, said net income fell to 62.7 billion yen ($580 million) in the three months that ended on March 31, while sales gained 1 percent, to 1.6 trillion yen. Honda said its net income was likely to fall 27.6 percent to 190 billion yen in the year ending March 31, 2001.

title: U.S. Publisher to Pay In Ulster Pair's Libel Suit
description: A small Colorado publisher yesterday agreed to a $1 million settlement in a libel suit brought by two car dealers from Northern Ireland who were accused in a book of belonging to a secret ruling committee of Protestant terrorists.

title: Joseph McCarthy, 86, Forestry Researcher
description: Dr. Joseph LePage McCarthy, emeritus professor of chemical engineering and forest resources at the University of Washington and a former dean of its graduate school, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 86 and lived in Seattle.

title: Two Auction Houses Disclose Confidential Records
description: Exploring a possible settlement of a potentially vast class action lawsuit, Sotheby's and Christie's have turned over confidential company information to lawyers representing customers who have accused them of price-fixing in the wake of a federal antitrust investigation.

title: Battles Erupt Along Border Of Ethiopia And Eritrea
description: Heavy fighting erupted today along the disputed border of Ethiopia and Eritrea. Many diplomats said they believed that the outbreak was a push by Ethiopia to end a war that has worsened severe food shortages in the region and claimed tens of thousands of lives in two years of sporadic fighting.

title: BAILOUT FOR KOREAN TRUSTS
description: Two of South Korea's largest investment trusts -- the Korea Investment Trust Company and the Daehan Investment Trust Company -- will each receive one trillion won (about $900 million) in June, as the first part of a 4.9 trillion won bailout, the Ministry of Finance and Economy said. The move is part of the South Korean government's latest round of changes in the financial sector aimed at the investment trusts, which are the nation's biggest buyers of corporate bonds. Their heavy exposure to bonds sold by the Daewoo Group and other deeply indebted conglomerates threatened the financial health of the investment trusts last year. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: CASCADE HIRES ADVISER TO CONSIDER ALTERNATIVES
description: The Cascade Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Gleacher & Company to advise it on alternatives, including a possible sale of the company, which makes lift attachments for trucks. The company said it would move ahead with its evaluation ''as expeditiously as possible.'' The announcement comes more than a month after Cascade's management said it was considering taking the company private in a leveraged buyout. Cascade's shares have fallen 19 percent in the last year. The company's management has not yet submitted a buyout proposal. The stock of the company, which is based in Fairview, Ore., rose 62.5 cents, to $10.5625, on the Big Board. At the current price, the company's stock is worth $120 million.

title: Threat Eases As U.N. Adds To Peace Force In Sierra Leone
description: Three hundred Jordanian peacekeepers arrived in Sierra Leone today, and 100 United Nations civilian employees who had been evacuated returned to Freetown, as the threat to the capital receded and pro-government forces prepared to push rebels farther east.

description: Rebecca J. Scott, a history professor at the University of Michigan, had just finished presenting a paper at a conference in Cienfuegos, a provincial capital in central Cuba, when one of the translators suggested that she might like to meet his grandfather. A few hours later, Ms. Scott was introduced to 96-year-old Tomas Perez y Perez, who had been a laborer at a nearby sugar plantation where his mother had been a slave.

title: Gore Speaks Out on Dams, and Maybe Suicide
description: Vice President Al Gore stepped into two contentious local issues in Oregon today, saying that he would ''work for a quick resolution'' on whether to breach the Snake River dams to protect endangered salmon, and, according to a key Democrat, saying he was opposed to the state's law allowing assisted suicide.

title: Police Say Mother Left Girl, 8, At the Metropolitan Museum
description: An 8-year-old Queens girl was abandoned by her mother at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday and was found wandering disoriented among the antiquities in the Egyptian wing, the police said yesterday. The girl's mother was arrested when she returned to pick her up six hours later.

title: NEW SUITOR FOR THOMSON TRAVEL
description: Europe's largest travel company, Preussag A.G. of Germany, is said to be buying shares in Thomson Travel P.L.C. and to be considering an outright buyout. Preussag's German rival C&N Touristic valued Thomson about $2.4 billion during buyout talks and has been pursuing a deal since April. Thomson issued a statement saying it had been contacted by another party, which may be interested in making a bid. Thomson did not name the suitor, but market rumors focused on Preussag, which owns the British travel operator Thomas Cook.

title: Accident Snarls Traffic On Bridge in Rush Hour
description: A New Jersey-bound car overturned on the upper level of the George Washington Bridge about 5:20 a.m. yesterday, closing three of four New Jersey-bound lanes until 10:50 a.m., the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

description: PIORE-Emanuel R., PhD. The Boards of Overseers & Managers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center are deeply saddened by the death of their colleague and advisor, Dr. Emanuel R. Piore. Dr. Piore began his association with Memorial Sloan-Kettering in 1963 as a member of The Board of Trustees of Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. At the time of his death Dr. Piore was a member of The Board of Overseers Emeriti of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. We will miss his wise counsel and friendship. We extend our healtfelt condelences to the Piore family. Laurance S. Rockefeller Honorary Co-Chairman James D. Robinson III Honorary Co-Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, MD, President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Starwood Hotels Decides To Stay in County
description: After considering sites in Connecticut, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, the world's largest hotel chain, has decided to locate its corporate headquarters -- and eventually 600 employees -- in White Plains. It had been leasing temporary space at two spots in the county. Starwood will sublease about 203,000 square feet at 1129 Westchester Avenue from Nine West, a shoe and handbag manufacturer whose headquarters will remain at the complex. The county's Industrial Development Agency approved incentives worth $775,000 for Starwood over the 11 years of the sublease. Starwood, with more than 700 hotels, owns the St. Regis and the Westin, Sheraton and FourPoints chains.

description: If everything goes exactly according to plan -- if there are no fatal foot faults or dropped batons, if her tender back and thrice-broken left foot survive the dozen or so preliminary rounds and if she isn't ultimately humbled by higher powers for her hubris -- one evening next September in Sydney, Australia, Marion Jones will prove to the world what she already thinks: that she is the greatest female athlete on the planet.

title: Enemies, A Love Story
description: Sullivan was disarmed that he didn't have to endure any ''anti-gay, anti-Clinton Democrat-bating'' at the gala for Pat Robertson. What did he expect? It was a birthday party. But just wait, Andrew. Keep your disguise, and maybe you will be invited to the Republican convention.

title: On Longer Stays, All-Suite Hotels
description: MANY hotels claim to be a home away from home. But however warm the welcome, hotel life can pall pretty quickly. It's great to be pampered and waited on, with that fine concierge and a host of bustling bellboys. But sometimes more privacy and independence is preferable, as is being able to stock your own refrigerator. When you're tired of room service and restaurants, wouldn't it be nice to fix a chicken salad just the way you like it?

title: Actress From Connecticut Heads Back Home to Help
description: AMY BRENNEMAN'S life has a funny way of repeating itself.

title: Fortissimo Country
description: IN ancient Rome, all wheel traffic was banned within city limits for a 10-hour period beginning at dawn. Consequently, throughout the night a steady traffic of wagons and carts thundered through narrow, twisted alleyways, drovers caught in nocturnal traffic jams hurled Latin oaths, and tenement dwellers in urban apartments suffered chronic insomnia. ''Unbroken nights,'' wrote the poet Juvenal in the first century A.D., ''are a rich man's privilege.''

title: A Master Sculptor, No Longer A Secret
description: WILLIAM EDMONDSON of Nashville had his first one-man show in New York in 1937, when a dozen of his elegantly spare limestone sculptures went on view at the Museum of Modern Art. Despite the venue, the New York art world seems to have regarded Edmondson less as a modern artist than a folkloric primitive -- according to the blithely condescending press reports of the time, an ''innocent Negro'' (Newsweek) whose ''guileless use of plastic symbol language'' (New York Times) revealed the ''imaginativeness of true naivete'' (New Yorker).

title: Christina Ohly, Alexander Evans
description: Christina Hallowell Ohly, the daughter of Kathleen Hammer of New York and Frederick Ohly of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Alexander Donnell Evans, the son of Elizabeth Fitzsimmons of Indianapolis and David Evans of Imperial Beach, Calif. The Rev. Beverly Morrison Boke performed the ceremony at the North Chapel Universalist Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Lending Crackdown Said to Fall Short
description: When government regulators announced recently that they were protecting homeowners by cracking down on an abusive nationwide lending company, Margaret C. Roundtree hoped that they would intervene to save her home in Jamaica, Queens, from foreclosure.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Case of Letting the Gene Out of the Bottle
description: IN the annals of bureaucratic slip-ups, this one was a beaut. Last December, an obscure government agency known as the European Patent Office mistakenly issued the first patent to allow the cloning of a human being. More alarmingly, critics say, it may have granted scientists the right to change the genetic makeup of the entire human species.

description: KELLY-Francis J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Francis J. Kelly, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring in 1999.

title: New York's Bargain Hotels, With Help From the Web
description: I SPENT six weeks this spring bottom-fishing for affordable hotel rooms in Manhattan, a project I approached with trepidation. As any New Yorker knows, living space is at an all-time premium in the city. To make matters worse, New York has far fewer hotel rooms, for its size, than Los Angeles, San Francisco or Miami, so the laws of supply and demand operate with a bloodless precision that would warm the heart of Adam Smith. Setting myself an upper limit of $125, without taxes, for a night's stay ($25 more than I would budget for hotels in any other U.S. city), I envisioned bleak nights in sour, minuscule rooms with peeling wallpaper, ventilated only by air shafts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSKY, HERMAN
description: PERSKY-Herman. Beloved husband of Belle. Loving father of Mark, Susan and Joan, and dear grandfather. Services were held Wednesday, May 10. Contributions may be made to the Volunteers of Israel, 330 West 42 Street, Suite 1618, New York City 10036.

title: Enjoy the Show. Test Will Follow.

The trouble is knowing what's happened to you! Because to understand how people see you we have to treat you not just as a particle, but as a wave. I have to use not only your particle mechanics, I have to use the Schrodinger wave function.

title: Markers Honor Parades Honoring Heroes
description: Snaking between the skyscrapers of Lower Manhattan, Broadway is known as the Canyon of Heroes, the route of the city's signature ticker tape parades honoring athletes, astronauts, world leaders and the like. Now, the parades -- 199 in all, starting in 1886 -- are being honored themselves, with stone markers along the very path they traveled.

title: How to Give Away $21.8 Billion
description: Critics of Gates's aid to the United Negro College Fund are more than a little off base in assuming that any type of educational aid to minority groups is about some form of affirmative action. Many minority students, myself included, who are accepted into Ivy League schools (which typically serve as springboards to a brighter future) simply cannot afford to go. There are few scholarships that cover four-year tuitions in excess of $25,000.

title: Colosseum Couture
description: Watching Ridley Scott's audience-immersing Roman epic, ''Gladiator,'' the first blockbuster of the summer movie season, at times feels like you have gone camping with the Versaces. The story of Maximus (Russell Crowe), a soldier-turned-slave-turned-gladiator, is a study in maximalist style. The lavish costumes designed by Janty Yates -- body armor for men, body jewelry for women, body fur for everyone -- take their cues from the work of the English painter Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema. The result is ''a Roman look with pre-Raphaelite overtones,'' Ms. Yates said last week via cell phone from the streets of Florence, where she is doing the costumes for ''Hannibal,'' Mr. Scott's sequel to ''Silence of the Lambs.'' But while ''Gladiator'' is set in A.D. 180, many of the clothes and accessories mirror current runway trends: Lucilla (Connie Nielsen), the emperor's daughter, is done up in pearl-beaded wraps and exquisite headbands that could easily be worn this summer. Her dresses, laced over the bodice, are reminiscent of the bikinis at Gucci; and armbands are just like those seen on stars like Cate Blanchett at the Academy Awards. Of course, fashion-conscious moviegoers know that period movies always say as much about the period in which they're made as they do about the period in which they're set. As for the men, the designer eschewed the embarrassingly short lengths that resulted in so many bare legs in ''Spartacus'' and ''Ben Hur'' during the last great round of toga movies. ''We made sure the men's tunics were more like Scottish kilts -- more funky and macho,'' Ms. Yates said. Where was she when Charlton Heston needed her? FRANK DeCARO

Currently, the park's eight clay tennis courts are open to the public from May to October. The rest of the year the courts are leased to the Harbor View Racquet Club. Mayor Deborah Chapin said the village was losing money on the courts. Under the proposed contract, Sportime would replace the courts and build and operate a multisport complex, spending an estimated $1.9 million and paying the village $4.5 million over the 17-year life of the contract. By law, the board can award such a contract without public hearings. But most residents at the meeting agreed with Richard L. title: The Way We Live Now: 5-14-00: Salient Facts: Quasars; Brightness Visible
description: FIRST LIGHTOn April 6, astronomers from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey -- a five-year project to map half of the northern sky -- located what may be the most distant object ever observed: a quasar billions of light-years away. The universe itself is about 14 billion years old and the light from this quasar was emitted less than a billion years after the Big Bang. The discovery may help solve a profound question in cosmology: when did the first light-giving objects form? For about 300,000 years after the Big Bang, the universe was a dense, hot haze of subatomic particles that hadn't coalesced into atoms. Sometime later, stars and galaxies were born; astronomers refer to the period in between as the Dark Ages. This quasar provides a new boundary to that epoch. We now know there were light-giving objects one billion years after the Big Bang.

description: As a recent Cuban immigrant, I read Mirta Ojito's article (April 23) with a painful feeling of understanding. However, the last two paragraphs of the article prompted me to write this letter.

title: Profits and Diversity Jostle At a Gentrification Forum
description: Some trembled with emotion as they recounted horror stories about apartment-snatching real estate brokers. Others voiced support for small-property owners who could now afford to send their children to college, thanks to soaring local rents.

title: Why G.M. Is Getting A Cold Shoulder
description: THE car business is booming these days -- in Europe, Mexico and Brazil as well as in the United States -- and the shares of General Motors have climbed nearly 17 percent so far this year. Of course, G.M. has major technology exposure in the form of its Hughes Electronics business. (While G.M. owns all of Hughes's assets, G.M.'s class H shares are designed to track the unit's earnings independently.)

title: It's Not All Dazzle: MTV Has a Conscience, Too
description: SINCE its founding in 1981, MTV has gotten plenty of mileage out of young people's fantasies about sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. But if the staple of the channel's programming, the music video, often conveys an unbridled hedonism, the channel's documentary programs can be regarded as the proverbial dropping of the other shoe.

title: Off to See the Lizards
description: DINOSAUR!

title: Footlights; Winning Combinations
description: It was business as usual when Bridge Records of New Rochelle, a specialist in contemporary classical music, arranged to record Melinda Wagner's ''Concerto for Flute, Strings and Percussion,'' a piece commissioned by the Westchester Philharmonic in honor of its 15th anniversary. Little did Bridge know that the work would win the 1999 Pulitzer Prize for music. ''We were, in a word, vindicated,'' said Becky Starobin, the company's managing director. ''It's easy to say, 'Yes, we'd like to record your Pulitzer Prize-winning piece.' But our decision was made strictly on artistic merit.''

title: Catherine Ip, Simon Smith
description: Catherine Ip, a daughter of Wai Chuen Ip and Wai Sham Ip of New York, was married yesterday to Simon Garnet Smith, a son of Judith Ann Smith and Dr. Garnet Oliver Smith of Melbourne, Australia. The Rev. Krystin S. Granberg performed the ceremony at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Amy DePoto, Robert Speranza
description: Amy Dorothy DePoto and Robert Vincent Speranza were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Willie Raymond, a Roman Catholic priest, in the Memorial Chapel at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn.

title: Jesus According to John, for the Most Part
description: Even if one puts aside its religious significance for a moment, the story of Jesus, as told in the Gospels, is packed with drama moments and a driving narrative power. Think of it: The carpenter from a village in the Galilee embarks on a mission preaching the coming of God's Kingdom. He heals the sick and casts out demons, draws vast crowds and then collides with the earthly power of the Roman Empire, which sentences him to death. But after three days, he is resurrected and appears again to the his followers!

title: Sierra Leone Rebel Leader Reportedly Smuggled Gems
description: In the wake of fighting among rebel groups and government troops in the capital of Sierra Leone, officials loyal to President Ahman Tejan Kabbah are beginning to amass documents which they say show the extent to which the rebel leader Foday Sankoh was systematically exploiting the country's diamonds to pay for his rebellion and enrich himself.

title: The K.G.B. Candidate
description: FIRST PERSON

title: A Weak Euro Means Bargains for U.S. Visitors
description: BANKERS are wringing their hands; tour operators are applauding.

title: An Abundance Of Markets; LONDON
description: Do you need prime Jaffa oranges? Avocados? Sharon fruit, an ogen melon? An outfit for the baby, running shoes for yourself? A set of keys, a doormat, a bunch of lilies? Do you want to riffle through a tray of secondhand books, try on glitzy earrings, pick up a cheap CD?

title: Putin Decrees New Controls And Envoys For Provinces
description: President Vladimir V. Putin moved today to assert sweeping control over Russia's far-flung and often headstrong provinces, decreeing that they be organized into seven vast administrative districts, each overseen by a powerful Kremlin representative.

title: Nashville Is Going Up-Tempo
description: ON arriving in downtown Nashville, look up. You will see the city's future looming overhead as cranes duck and pivot in the sky above the gleaming scaffolds of a dozen works in progress. There is no better time to be a construction worker: there's a new arena and stadium for the professional teams that have been imported, a sports hall of fame, a giant consumer complex on a par with the Mall of America; and, still under construction, a speedway, a new zoo, a downtown pedestrian bridge across the Cumberland River, a massive office complex with an eye-catching traffic circle with a $2 million sculpture, luxury hotels like the Marriott, Hilton Suites, Embassy Suites and possibly a Ritz-Carlton, an art gallery, and a Country Music Hall of Fame that resembles a piano (not the first instrument one associates with the genre). With the metropolitan area population having just surpassed one million, Nashville is booming.

title: Jones Easily Wins Bout Against a Hapless Foe
description: Even before Roy Jones Jr. began to actually fight, the head games had started. Jones entered the ring with a rap artist and an entourage that seemed the size of the Chinese Army. Several seconds later, Jones walked up to his opponent, Richard Hall, got in his face, and gave him a stare that could melt lead. It looked as if a scuffle might break out right there.

title: They Come to the Dance Floor Bearing a Gift: Jazz
description: ON a sunny Tuesday in April, shortly after arriving in his seaside room at the West Coast Hotel here, the dapper trumpeter Marcus Printup removed his horn from its case, strode out on his balcony, leaned back on his heels and played Louis Armstrong's sultry ''West End Blues.'' On the beach below, a young man in jeans rose from the sand, threw his hands to the sky and began swaying his hips as if possessed. As Mr. Printup's lustrous notes filled the air, a couple of other members of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra appeared on nearby balconies with their instruments and for the next 20 minutes a jubilant sound billowed out to meet the waves.

title: Taking Away Rights: Where Do You Stop?
description: The opinion essay by Jim Panos [''Stretching Limits of Free Speech,'' May 7] made my blood run cold. Apparently Mr. Panos would dearly like to rewrite the Constitution, in particular those annoying First and Second Amendments. While you are at it, Jim, why not get rid of that pesky Fourth Amendment, which prevents your home from being searched without a warrant. And since we have the sword drawn, why not get rid of the Fifth Amendment? Why should you not incriminate yourself?

title: Seattle
description: Seattle certainly made a name for itself last December as host to the World Trade Organization meeting. The boosters' idea of using the summit to show off their city as a world-class friend to free trade didn't exactly pan out, amid all the demonstrations and the tear gas, but many residents think that the raucous protests against globalization amounted to a badge of honor for Seattle.

title: Sierra Leone's Slide Back to Warlord Rule Draws In U.N.
description: For years, warlordism has ruled over Sierra Leone, a state in name alone. With the authority of the government barely extending beyond Freetown, warlords have been ensconced in different corners of the country, each with access to enough diamond mines to buy arms. The balance of power shifted occasionally, depending on the energies of a Nigerian-led intervention force or mercenaries hired by the government.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-14-00: The Ethicist; If It Looks Like Rape . . .
description: In New Orleans for Mardi Gras and drinking heavily, my friends and I got separated. When I returned to our hotel, I found my college roommate in bed with a girl from our school. Days later, I learned he'd had sex with her while she was in a drug-and-alcohol-induced stupor. In my view, he is a rapist, but I don't know how to react, given my friendship with him and my sympathies for her. -- Anonymous, Virginia

title: Kasparov Lures Hapless Foe Into the Treacherous Woods
description: It is extremely difficult to write books on the openings these days, or even to give off-the-cuff advice to average players about current variations.

title: Reporters and Editors Defend A.P. Story on Korea Massacre
description: ''It was a story no one wanted to hear.'' Those were the opening words of The Associated Press's Pulitzer-Prize winning report documenting the massacre in 1950 of hundreds of South Korean civilians by American troops at No Gun Ri. When they were crafted by an editor during one of the numerous rewrites, the report's authors found them an apt description of A.P. executives' initial response to their findings.

title: U.S. Extends Deadline On Peconic Cleanup
description: The Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency have informally agreed to extend for at least six months a May 15 deadline for public comment on a project to remove mercury, silver, copper, PCB's and low levels of radionuclides, including plutonium, from the headwaters of the Peconic River.

title: All On a Summer's Day
description: Young people didn't waste a minute flinging themselves into summer looks to accommodate the August-like weather a week ago. Midriffs and tattoos were exposed, jeans' outer seams were slashed open to cool legs, and inner seams were cut to turn jeans into skirts, with a gusset of flower-print fabric. Other skirts showed eclectic lengths, and young men's droopy pants continued to sag. A metallic jersey tube dress had the sides opened up almost to the armpits, with dipping pointed panels front and back. Could this be the new T-shirt? And could the scooter be fashion's new accessory?

title: PORT CHESTER PROMENADE
description: As part of a multimillion dollar redevelopment plan for Port Chester's downtown, the county will assist in the creation of a public promenade along the village's waterfront. Under the plan, G & S Investors of Bethpage on Long Island, the developer of the redevelopment project, would build the public promenade along a half-mile stretch of waterfront. The county would lease the land to help with the financing. The village would be responsible for the promenade's upkeep. ''This plan is in keeping with my commitment to revitalize our cities and urban areas by promoting economic development that will expand our tax base and create jobs,'' County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. ELSA BRENNER

title: Family Feud: Manganaro's Against Manganaro's
description: At least the Capulets and Montagues didn't have to share a name. Not so the descendants of a 19th-century Neapolitan who opened an Italian deli on Ninth Avenue 107 years ago. In high fairy-tale tradition, the business eventually passed to descendants: four brothers named Dell'Orto who, citing differences in management style, divided it up between the oldest and youngest pairs.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: BIG STONE GAP

title: Sharon Lesser, Matthew Maguire
description: Sharon Lesser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Lesser of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Keown Maguire, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Maguire III of Edina, Minn. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Tin Kickers
description: DEADLY DEPARTURE Why the Experts Failed to Prevent the TWA Flight 800 Disaster and How It Could Happen Again. By Christine Negroni. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Cliff Street Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $25.

title: Stress of Infertility, And the Power of Hope
description: WHEN Albert and Laura DiBella of Greenwich go to church this Tuesday, they will have one goal in mind.

title: Streetscapes/Hotel des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street; Cornerstone Building on a Block of Artists' Studios
description: ALTHOUGH the Hotel des Artistes with its Gothic-style facade is often considered the cornerstone building on a block of artists' studios, it was actually the fifth on the street to be built. Now the co-op, completed in 1917, is weighing the advantages and disadvantages of cleaning the exterior to return it to its original appearance.

title: A Sudden, Violent Moment That Still Haunts a Life
description: Pro basketball is a different game these days, and it isn't simply what happens on the court. When I see the way Latrell Sprewell has turned around his image after the much-publicized confrontation with his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, it reinforces my belief that you can overcome something negative provided someone wants to help you.

title: American Gothic
description: Hunts in Dreams By Tom Drury. 200 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.

title: OPINION; Who Will Serve on Budget Board?
description: THE Governor, George E. Pataki, has pointed the cavalry toward Mineola with the command to take charge and fix Nassau County's busted budget.

title: Habitats/Madison Avenue Near 32nd Street; Buying a Studio Cheap, Then Improvising
description: FOR months and months, Jacob Bump looked at apartments, riding his bicycle to open houses all over Manhattan. He knew he wanted to spend no more than $150,000 -- but other than that he was flexible.

title: Team New Zealand's Allegiance Is Tested
description: Dave Dobbyn is New Zealand's answer to Bruce Springsteen, a populist singer and songwriter whose homeland and countrymen are the source of his creative wellspring. Last March, when the Team New Zealand America's Cup squad paraded into an Auckland amphitheater to accept its awards for defeating Italy's Prada Challenge and defending the cup, a Dobbyn tune called ''Loyal'' provided the soundtrack for an open-air video montage of the crew's nautical heroics.

title: Reflections of a Post-Little League Dad
description: EVERYONE knows the old riddle about the life stages of man -- first a creature who travels on four legs as a baby, then on two, then on three as an old person with a cane.

title: Barclays and Vanguard, Index Fund Giants, Square Off
description: TWO titans of index investing are getting ready to rumble.

title: Stay Tuned on the Road
description: NO matter how grueling the baggage claim wait or the customs process, the first real jolt of culture shock for many travelers comes when, behind the wheel of their rental cars, they reach for their favorite radio station. Some people scan the dial for good music before setting off, and program the preset buttons to ensure optimal driving bliss. For the rest, venturing onto the radio dial in a foreign city is an exercise in high-fidelity futility.

title: Shoes and Causes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about a 19th-century New Yorker named Preserved Fish misstated his burial place. It is the New York City Marble Cemetery; the New York Marble Cemetery is one block away.

title: Susan Fallon, Christopher Mattingly
description: Susan Kathleen Fallon, a daughter of Vice Adm. William J. Fallon and Mrs. Fallon of Norfolk, Va., was married yesterday to Christopher Lindsay Mattingly, a son of Patricia Aiken-O'Neill of Washington and Francis H. Mattingly of Staunton, Va. Msgr. Thomas M. Duffy performed the ceremony at the Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart in Washington.

title: Amy Perez, Samuel Friedlander
description: Amy Jo Perez and Samuel David Friedlander were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Max Hausen at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Donna Avedisian, Craig Chanti
description: Donna Adeline Avedisian, the daughter of Dorothy Avedisian of Chicago and Armen G. Avedisian of Munster, Ind., was married yesterday to Craig Louis Chanti, a son of Gerri M. Chanti and Louis Chanti, both of Roebling, N.J. Archbishop Khajag Barsamian, the primate of the diocese of the Armenian Church of America, performed the ceremony at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Here's What Mothers Are All About
description: MOTHERS aren't what they used to be. When I was a child, all mothers were huge and terrifying and agelessly old. They had voices like the Greek hero Stentor and the disciplinary habits of the Hindu goddess Kali. I had no trouble believing that they were all direct descendants of the original mother-goddess of antiquity and shared her terrible powers.

title: With Patience Long Gone, Mets Release Henderson
description: Rickey Henderson jogged himself right out of a Mets uniform Friday night when he unabashedly slipped into his home run trot without the ball leaving the ballpark.

title: Among the Himba
description: To the Editor: I am in the seventh grade. Last summer, with my parents, I went in search of the Himba in northern Namibia. We met a small group of these unique people. The Himba children, much like me, want to wear baseball caps and play games. If they knew of computers and Game Boys, I am sure they would want those, too, rather than herding cattle.

title: Putting 'That Great Street' Back Into State Street
description: AFTER 20 years of on-again off-again urban-renewal efforts, State Street, which was for generations Chicago's premier retail area, appears ready to reclaim its heritage.

title: Letting Sellers Do The Selling
description: UNTIL recently, people who wanted to sell their homes had two basic options: they could list their home with a broker -- and in most cases pay a six percent commission -- or they could avoid a commission by putting a ''For Sale by Owner'' sign on the front lawn.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Ben Watts's brief stint as a wedding photographer took place in Australia, where he was studying photography a decade ago. To butter up a teacher, he volunteered to shoot his wedding. And the results were so fantastic (and cheap!) -- even if Watts says so himself -- that hordes of lovebirds started to call, and suddenly every Saturday was devoted to other people's connubial bliss. Watts exchanged his own vows at 1 Centre Street last June, on his lunch hour. And being the romantic he is, he restaged the experience for our shoot, right down to the subway ride over. But, alas, there was no Sammy's Roumanian restaurant at the end of the day. ''We had what is called a blessing in Wales, about a month later,'' he says. ''So now I've got two anniversaries, which is kind of annoying.''

title: Of Gender and an Index
description: There are indexes for countries. There are indexes for industries. So why not indexes for the sexes?

title: Owners' Insurance In a Co-op
description: Q I am involved in the ownership of a co-op building in New York. Recently, we had a pipe freeze in the building and three apartments were damaged. The owners of two of the apartments did not have homeowners insurance. Can we require all shareholders to carry homeowners insurance? . . . Howard Rosenthal, Flushing, Queens.

title: It's a Dog's Life
description: HOW TO TALK TO YOUR DOG

title: A Singer Convinced That Song Can Heal
description: THOUGH the singer-songwriter Margo Hennebach of Bloomfield earned her undergraduate degree from the Oberlin Conservatory, she said it was her experience as a music therapist that taught her how best to relate to an audience.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Renewing a Friendship for a Fifth Summer
description: THE Cherney house here looks like the embodiment of the American dream: a neat white Colonial with dark green shutters, a pink front door, even an exuberant springer spaniel that bounds up to greet visitors. Inside, Lee Cherney, who works for a real estate investment company, and his wife, Cheryl, are friendly people who clearly adore their daughters, Meredith, 8, and Emily, 2.

title: Germaine Febles, Charles Andruss
description: Germaine Marie Febles and Charles Arthur Andruss were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Stephen DeLuca at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: How to Give Away $21.8 Billion
description: I can't think of anything more demoralizing than to have one's portrait in your magazine: wrinkles, age spots, scraggly chin whiskers, pleated chins all scarily exposed and larger than life. The rich and famous, powerful, gifted, sinful or righteous -- no one is safe.

title: Bernhard Heiden, 89, Composer And Indiana University Professor
description: Bernhard Heiden, a composer who was for many years chairman of the composition department at Indiana University, died April 30 at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 89.

title: An Abundance Of Markets; JERUSALEM
description: Tour buses will drop you at the Jaffa Gate, so that you must ascend to Jerusalem's Old City, accruing reverence with each steep step. I prefer the Damascus Gate, an entry by descent, a plunge into the pulsating souks of the walled city's largest district, the Muslim quarter. You glide down worn stone steps, past the posters of Arab pop stars laid out like prayer rugs.

title: Revising the Rules on Protests
description: Political demonstrations were not exactly common in Chappaqua before a certain politically prominent family moved to 15 Old House Lane. But on Tuesday the town board of New Castle, which includes Chappauqua, gave the police chief added power to regulate such activity, requiring applicants for protest permits to spell out the nature of any demonstration. It also eliminated the requirement for seven-days notice before a demonstration.

title: RUNNING AGAIN
description: Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, 78, has announced his bid for a 15th term and will be running -- as he did two years ago -- against Paul J. Feiner, 44, supervisor of Greenburgh and a Democrat. Mr. Gilman's 20th congressional district includes parts of Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan Counties. ELSA BRENNER

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-14-00: On Language; Oh-Oh
description: A satirical form of intellectual sabotage took place at The Boston Globe 20 years ago. An editorial about President Carter's economic plan was scheduled to be headlined ''All Must Share the Burden.'' This is one of the dullest, most hackneyed cliches in journalism, always followed by a mournful paean to responsibility.

title: Vaccine Delivered by Fork, Not Needle
description: Raw potatoes might not be most people's idea of a delicious meal, especially if the potatoes have been genetically modified to contain a protein from the Norwalk virus, which causes vomiting and diarrhea. But when 20 volunteers in Baltimore ate such potatoes, the viral protein not only did no harm; it stimulated an immune response in 19 of them that might prevent them from becoming sick if they ever encounter the real virus.

title: Taking Schiller Straight
description: TO literate Europeans of the 19th century, the poet, playwright and historian Friedrich Schiller (1759-1805) ranked right up with Shakespeare, an idol he honored not only by conscious imitation but also in a translation of ''Macbeth.''

title: Bright Lights, Big City . . . Action!
description: SOMETHING seemed familiar about the grouping of the love seat and chairs -- and the big window beside it. For some reason, I kept imagining George Clooney on the other side, making funny faces. With a little boy?

title: Life After Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Dues Paid, Rock Band Is Climbing Charts
description: THE process of a Long Island cover band moving on to become cover boys is more revolutionary than evolutionary. But that is just the transition the rock band Nine Days has made.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MORTON
description: SANDERS-Morton, 79, formerly of Manhattan, died May 5 in Toms River, NJ. He worked as an architectural designer creating Morton Sanders/Space Planning and Design, retiring in 1983. He played drums and shekere on Sundays in Central Park for about 25 years; moved to NJ in 1997. Survived by his wife of 31 years, Eleanore and son Mark of Manhattan.

title: May 7-13; Unwanted Advances
description: Lt. Gen. Claudia J. Kennedy, the Army's top female officer, won an early round in her sexual harassment case when the Army's inspector general concluded that she had been the victim of sexual harassment four years ago. At least two reviews are needed before a final decision by the Vice Chief of the Army. General Kennedy charged that Brig. Gen. Larry G. Smith accosted her in her Pentagon office after a routine briefing. It is the first time one general has accused another of sexual harassment. ELIZABETH BECKER

title: Disorderly Conduct
description: Almost one year ago to the day, in a Brooklyn neighborhood that sounds very similar to the one where Stephen S. Hall lives, I was attacked by five youths as I walked home from work (Lives, April 16). It was a typical scenario: they said they had a gun and demanded that I hand over my money. I refused. Having spent the previous eight hours hauling food for a party of well-fed writers or some other group of beautiful, rude people, I felt that I had worked very hard for the hundred or so bucks in my pocket and deserved it more than my teenage muggers did. I resisted, we struggled and I lost my jacket, catering tuxedo, wallet and keys. The kids ran into the projects. I followed them onto the basketball court-playground and collected my knapsack, which was torn to pieces, then walked a block home to my apartment.

title: IBM Global Services And Texaco in an Alliance
description: White Plains-based Texaco has awarded a five-year, $100 million contract to IBM Global Services to be the company's primary global information technology service provider. IBM, which is based in Armonk, will manage Texaco's 9,000 North American desktop computers and the company's Local Area Networks. Additionally, IBM will provide remote support for 550 servers at more than 30 locations around the world.

title: Commencement; Poet Gives Concrete Advice at Manhattanville College
description: Before the speeches and granting of degrees, the poet Nikki Giovanni stopped to chat with a visitor at the 159th commencement at Manhattanville College here.

title: Outside Interests
description: I LIVE in a neighborhood built in friendlier times, before central air-conditioning and television rendered front porches obsolete. By local standards, my porch is barely adequate. It's not particularly gracious, it doesn't wrap around, it isn't screened and it's just big enough to support a couple of window boxes, a few chairs and a table. But that's enough, when the weather gets nice, to give me a purchase on the outside world at the same time I'm engaged in that despicable activity known as work.

title: Ideas & Trends; Everything Is Under Control
description: Officials have begun to express anger at the National Park Service, which set what it had hoped would be a controlled fire.

title: Special-Interest Groups Widening Political Attack Ads
description: It was one of the more astonishing political images of the year: a newspaper advertisement that linked Osama bin Laden, the suspected international terrorist, with Senator Spencer Abraham, the Michigan Republican.

title: Books in Brief: Children's Books
description: ADALINE FALLING STAR

title: Mom's Personal Shopper
description: Everyone knows it is a mother's right to make remarks on a son's appearance, from facial hair to slide sandals. But for years I've been on my mom's case, too. Like many daughters of the Depression, she is conflicted about spending money or time on fashion and hates shopping. When she was younger, she got away with this nonapproach because she was an obvious beauty. Now that she's living with a chronic illness, dressing herself to distract from her fragility seems especially crucial to me, and it is harder than ever to control my bossy inner stylist on my visits home.

title: In Kentucky, a Show Of Chinese Equine Art
description: An exhibition focusing on the role of the horse in 3,000 years of Chinese history and culture is on display through Aug. 31 at the Kentucky Horse Park, in the Bluegrass region. The exhibition, ''Imperial China: The Art of the Horse in Chinese History,'' features more than 300 artifacts from museums in Shaanxi Province, including Xi'an, the ancient Chinese capital.

title: Dispute Flares in Florida Over Licensing of Cuban Doctors
description: A decade-long dispute over the licensing of a group of Cubans who want to practice medicine here is testing the power of the Cuban-American lobby in Florida against that of the state's medical establishment and is about to involve the American Medical Association.

title: Valerie Rockefeller, James Carnegie
description: Valerie Blanchette Rockefeller, the daughter of Senator John D. Rockefeller IV and Mrs. Rockefeller of Charleston, W.Va., and Washington, was married yesterday to James Douglas Carnegie, a son of Sir Roderick and Lady Carnegie of Melbourne, Australia. The Rev. Daniel R. Heischman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Among a Show of Drawings, Looking for Ones With Bite
description: THE odds of getting into the competition, ''Vital Signs: Drawing as Inquiry,'' at Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven were long. There were 750 drawings entered from all over North America, and only 65 were chosen by the judge, Robert Reed, a painting professor at the Yale School of Art. It is evident from the exhibition's title that Mr. Reed wanted to produce a coherent show.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Dr. Harriet Lange Rheingold, 92; Swayed View on Infant Behavior
description: Dr. Harriet Lange Rheingold, a child psychologist and research professor emeritus at the University of North Carolina, died on April 29 at a retirement center in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 92.

title: Harrison High Football Star Is Headed for the Buckeyes
description: SAMMY MALDONADO of Harrison High School may move from the Westchester County high school football spotlight to the national college spotlight as quickly as he changes direction when a hole is blocked.

title: A House Divided
description: Anil's Ghost

title: Martha Posner and Larry Fink
description: ALMOST everyone who knows Larry Fink, the photographer, describes him as a wild man, part Hunter S. Thompson, part Roberto Benigni, who embraces life with a bearhug and plenty of howling.

title: Getting Back to the Land in Summer Gallery Shows
description: THE idea of a big backyard is well understood in the New Jersey art world. An artist can be local all over the state.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-14-00: Word & Image; A Sinister Rorschach
description: It was on this date in 1965 that the F.B.I. delivered to the White House information about me from ''an extremely sensitive source'' suggesting that it might ''be of interest'' to President Lyndon Johnson. Even 35 years later, however, my government refuses to tell me, or historians, what this nugget might have been or whence it came. The Rorschach blobs of censorial black on the documents reproduced here are your taxes at work, obliterating our rights.

title: Who Set Up the Dominoes?
description: American Tragedy

title: Q & A
description: Affordable San Francisco

title: Homeless Children And Educational Needs
description: Someone should welcome Mr. Sanacore to the real world. School districts would have to cope with the cost of providing his list of services. And people are indifferent to the plight of the homeless. If they weren't, there wouldn't be a million homeless children in the country.

title: Another Round of Questions Aimed at Pequots
description: SINCE 1984 the residents of Ledyard, North Stonington and Preston have watched gambling on the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal reservation grow from a bingo hall to a billion-dollar casino that attracts 40,000 people a day. Taxpayers in the three towns that border the casino have spent almost $1.3 million fighting the expansion of the reservation and the recognition of two other tribes in the region.

title: Wind's an Attraction; Yankees Are Not
description: Hot dog wrappers drifted by like tumbleweeds inside Comerica Park today, bouncing and hopping from right field to left. When fly balls went into the air, the players turned helplessly, as if caught in the whirl of dust devils.

title: Landmarkers and Owners At Odds Over Town Houses
description: A plan to preserve a dozen historic town houses on East 54th and 55th Streets has hit some stumbling blocks.

title: Britney Grows Up, Very Carefully
description: BRITNEY SPEARS is a tease. That's the gist of the title song from her second album, ''Oops . . . I Did It Again,'' due to be released on Tuesday. After some introductory moans, the song tells some poor sap that she didn't mean to make him think ''we're more than just friends''; she temporarily lost her senses, but she wasn't serious. The song is by no means an apology. It's a near-boast punched home by the last line of the chorus: ''I'm not that innocent.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. She was a mother of devotion, beauty, charm, and artistic talents. I could not have hoped for such a plethora of maternal assets that would so enrich my life.

title: Food Fight
description: Two side-by-side food shops in Chelsea share a name -- Manganaro's -- but the relatives who run them have been sparring in court for years. With other reports from Times Square, the Lower East Side, Lower Manhattan, the Upper East Side, SoHo, West Farms, Ozone Park, Forest Hills and Park Slope.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Victoria Rae Scully and Mar-Jan Ostrowski misstated the name of the bride's mother. She is Nancy Rae Scully, not Rae M. Scully.

description: CRAZY

title: A Missing Ingredient Of the Pyrameter
description: To the Editor:

title: Once More Upon a Time
description: Froggie Went

title: Homeowners Rise Up To Oppose A Building
description: Matt Farrell recalls driving through a residential section of Forest Hills last August with his boss, Councilwoman Karen Koslowitz, when they came upon an agitated crowd at a construction site on Kew Forest Lane near 77th Road. Curious, he and Ms. Koslowitz got out to see what was happening.

title: For Under a Peppermint-Striped Tent
description: Take the idea of white zinfandel, at best a bimbo of a wine, give it a Ph.D. during winemaking in Languedoc, and you've got Fortant de France's sophisticated '98 white merlot.

title: Coping With Supersalmon
description: Just as we were getting used to genetically engineered corn and potatoes, along comes a strain of salmon that grows to market size in only 18 months, twice as fast as normal salmon. These hormonally hyperactive creatures -- called Frankenfish by their detractors -- may in fact turn out to be the first genetically modified animal to make it onto American dinner plates. But before they do, regulators here and in Canada have two obligations -- to see whether these fish pose a threat to the environment and, if they do, to ensure that they are properly regulated.

title: Footlights; Parkway-Inspired Reveries
description: Take a roadway, weave it through 15 miles of greenery and what do you have? Landscape art, if it's the Bronx River Parkway. To celebrate the 75th anniversary of America's first parkway, the county has culled photographs from its archives and mounted them in a show at the Bridge Gallery in White Plains. This is a much loved highway, as passionately defended against the Philistines (anyone wanting to straighten or widen it) as any place in the county. Westchester also claims the parkway as the first ''linear park'' in the country.

title: In France? Non
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Just Like They Do in Portugal
description: IT'S possible to whiz along Mineola Boulevard and not notice that the large stucco building with the wrought-iron gates, brick-trimmed entrance and circular windows that was Little Portugal is now Heart of Portugal. The Mineola spot has experienced an admirable resurgence under its new owners. Although it's not unpleasant cliched Portuguese decor (stone and rough-hewn walls, fireplace, lanterns, antique guns, boat models, Old Lisbon mural) remains largely in place, the nine-month-old Heart of Portugal, at 241 Mineola Boulevard (516-742-9797), has a revitalized menu, warmth and spirit that makes it one of the most outstanding restaurants in this ethnic enclave.

title: M Is For . . .
description: WHEN girls from around New York City, juniors in public schools, sat down to write about ''A Woman I Admire'' they chose subjects as celebrated as Princess Di, as memorable as Hester Prynne and as ancient as Eve. But many of the girls, in an annual essay contest sponsored by Barnard College and the CBS Foundation, wrote about mothers: mothers who struggled in a new country or changing circumstances, birth mothers who live in the imagination or heroic stepmothers who saved the day. Here are excerpts from some of the winning essays, offering a snapshot of motherhood on Mother's Day 2000.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Housing for the Aged: Is Supply Outpacing Demand?
description: THE three-story Victorian-style building under construction along the Hudson River in Edgewater breaks the pattern of mid- and high-rise apartment projects that have sprouted up and down the New Jersey shoreline in the last few years.

title: Vieques Island
description: To the Editor: As one who covets the relatively undeveloped aspect of my island retreat, I winced when I saw your recent article on Vieques. While locals and visitors alike agree that Cafe Blu is snob city, Ms. Dreifus is the first person I know of who's been even slightly disappointed by a meal at La Campesina. And the setting, amid jungle flora where each evening a chorus of coquis serenades diners, can't be beat.

title: SOAPBOX; Curbing Municipal Hostilities
description: LIKE nations, towns often battle with their neighbors. In March, Mamaroneck proposed to require developers to gain its approval for projects just outside its borders. This escalated hostilities between municipalities throughout Westchester.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: OZONE PARK; Reclaiming a Cemetery Plagued by Weeds and Vandals
description: Bayside Cemetery in Ozone Park, Queens, long plagued by vandalism and disrepair, is getting help.

title: Love and City Hall
description: A fairy tale of urban amour.

title: On a Tour of Tableaus, You Move, They Don't
description: THE choreographer and performance artist Ann Carlson has a knack for astonishing audiences with simplicity. Downtown dance mavens still oh and ah when recalling ''Visit Woman Move Story Cat Cat Cat'' (1987), in which the voluptuous 5-foot-tall performer danced naked while clutching a tiny kitten, vividly recreating the image of Koko, the 300-pound female gorilla who learned to communicate through sign language, and her pet kitten, All Ball.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; A 'Health House' Can Help Its Owner Breathe Easier
description: THE new three-bedroom, 2,700-square-foot house being completed along a dirt road deep in the woods of Roxbury is one that anybody with a respiratory ailment might covet. The air inside is so pure that it exceeds the requirements set by Health House, an affiliate of the American Lung Association that sets stringent clean-air specifications for home builders.

title: The Nation; The Way We Live Now
description: IT may take a village to raise a child, but a family still ought to be able to afford one. It now costs about $160,140 to raise a middle-class child through age 17, according to the Department of Agriculture's annual report, ''Expenditures on Children by Families.'' That's up from $25,229 in 1960 and $69,333 in 1980, seemingly a huge increase. But that 1960 figure, adjusted for inflation, would equal $141, 998 today, so in fact, the cost of brining up baby has risen only about 13 percent since 1960.

title: AT A CONCERT WITH/Gretchen Pulvermann; The Force Behind a Series of Free Programs That Set Toes to Tapping
description: TWICE a year, Rye High School opens its doors to the free -- and increasingly popular -- Pulvermann Foundation concerts. Since 1992, the programs have featured such major artists as the bass-baritone Jerome Hines, the pianists Oxana Yablonskaya and Michael Boriskin, the violinist Chee-Yun, the folk singer Tom Chapin and the United States Military Academy Band from West Point, whose May visits have been a hallmark of the series.

title: Save Mosaic From Death by Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Now in Print, Untold Stories of Giants in Their Fields
description: A 200-year-old tree grows in Brooklyn. Another inspired the borough's unofficial poet laureate, Marianne Moore, to write about ''the filigree of an elm overhead'' that she named ''our crowning curio.''

title: Beyond Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the new owners of the New York Islanders misspelled the surname of a professor of sports management at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst who commented on the obstacles the new owners face. He is Glenn M. Wong, not Wang.

title: Marchers And Their Imprints
description: On this Mother's Day, thousands of mothers will march on Washington to demand tough new gun control legislation, but it is unlikely that the Million Mom March will prove effective in getting Congress to act. Americans have been marching on Washington to demand change ever since the populist Jacob Coxey led his ragtag army of the unemployed from Ohio to Washington during the depression of the 1890's. Some of these marches have had lasting and visible effect, but others have been quickly forgotten.

title: Finding a Surprise Hit In 18th-Century Germany
description: WHEN Rupert Penry-Jones first started reading ''Don Carlos,'' the Friedrich Schiller play that brings him to New York this week, he was only three pages into it before he thought: ''This is too long, too wordy.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Page 7 of the Westchester section today about Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to investigate allegations of misconduct by the Putnam County Sheriff's Department refers to a civil suit in which a jury awarded $645,000 to a man who said he was a victim of selective prosecution. Of that amount, $435,000 was to be paid by the sheriff himself, Robert Thoubboron. On Thursday, after the article had gone to press, Judge Charles L. Brieant of Federal District Court in White Plains cut the sheriff's liability to $3,000, saying the original award ''shocks the conscience of the court.''

title: Spinning Mozart Into Space
description: HE set ''The Barber of Seville'' in a health club, and now he is sending Mozart into space. Dan Montez, director of Taconic Opera's current production, ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' says he rarely presents operas the old-fashioned way, set in their own time periods. Without changing a word or a note, he updates them -- mostly for fun, he says, but also to give a new spin to the story.

title: Claudia Saunders, James Bourke
description: Claudia Nastuk Saunders and James Joseph Bourke were married yesterday afternoon at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Robert B. O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Fosca Piomelli, William White
description: Fosca Francesca Piomelli, the daughter of Maria Rosaria Piomelli-Ambrosi of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., and Dr. Sergio Piomelli of New York, was married yesterday to William Shackleton White, the son of Doris Shackleton Sommer of Damascus, Md., and William R. White of Reston, Va. The Rev. Gregory Maturi performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Sleepy Hollow.

title: Priscilla Stern, 65, Nexus in House of Rabbis
description: Priscilla Rudin Stern, who took pride in being the daughter, wife and mother of rabbis, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 65 and lived in Great Barrington, Mass. The cause of death was cancer, said her husband, Rabbi Jack Stern, the former leader of the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale.

title: TEACHERS OFFERED A TAX EXEMPTION
description: In a striking gesture of support for public education, Gov. Gray Davis today proposed to exempt California public school teachers from the state's personal income tax, in what state officials said they believed was the first such peacetime exemption for any occupation in American history.

title: How to Give Away $21.8 Billion
description: Last week, I (and some 200 others) spent four days reviewing applications for the Gates Millennium scholarships. This year's funds will go to minority students at all levels of college and graduate studies, not just entering freshmen. The applications are evaluated according to what we know about what makes minority students persist in college and beyond rather than by simply looking at grades and test scores.

title: Suzanne Yalof, Marc Schwartz
description: Suzanne Katherine Yalof and Marc Alan Schwartz were married last evening by Rabbi Barry Friedman at Bridgewaters in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHINAI, RUKMA, M.D. (NEE DR. MIRCHANDANI)
description: CHINAI-Rukma, M.D. (nee Dr. Mirchandani) on May 12, 2000 at age 71. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Suresh Chinai. Loving mother of Anil and Aroon and grandmother of Mihir Chinai. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Monday, 11:30am. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital for Cancer Research, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021.

title: The World: AIDS in South Africa; A President Misapprehends a Killer
description: THE tone and substance of the letter was so peculiar that some officials in Washington thought it was a hoax. In a five-page letter to President Clinton last month, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, argued that his country had to chart its own course in dealing with AIDS, including consulting those who challenged prevailing views on the causes and treatments of the disease.

description: Scott Stevens is an 18-year veteran and Brian Rafalski is a rookie, and they work well as a pair on the Devils' defense. Their experience differential is not the only contrast that makes them an odd couple of roommates during the Stanley Cup playoffs.

description: IS architecture an art? What restrictions can government place on architects without violating constitutional principles?

description: RESORT

description: The harder Davis Love III tries to win, the more difficult it seems to become.

description: AS ten pins tumbled and bowlers celebrated strikes, spares and balls that avoided the purple gutters, Patricia DiGioia and her elderly mother planted themselves near Lane 28 at AMF Post Lanes in White Plains and lamented the center's imminent closing.

title: Kelly Finn, Grant Felgenhauer
description: Katherine Blackburne Finn, a daughter of Catherine and Harold Finn III of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Grant Patrick Felgenhauer, a son of Patricia and Neil Felgenhauer of Spokane, Wash. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: MAYOR DEMANDS RESIGNATION
description: Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers is calling on Andre J. Hornsby, superintendent of schools, to quit, less than a year after he was hired. The mayor's comments followed a news conference by Dr. Hornsby on Tuesday, when he blamed the city for the schools' budget problems, which he said would mean cuts in programs and up to 1,000 layoffs. Dr. Hornsby, who has proposed a $353 million budget for the coming school year, said revenues fall $43 million short of expenses. ''I'm outraged that Dr. Hornsby made statements suggesting the city of Yonkers is not doing its part,'' Mr. Spencer said. ELSA BRENNER

title: Facing the Music, But on a Grand Scale
description: William C. Ford Jr., chairman of Ford Motor and great-grandson of Henry Ford, acknowledged last week that sport utility vehicles, the automaker's most profitable products, might be as unsafe and environmentally damaging as critics say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, GERTRUDE
description: DORFMAN-Gertrude. Cherished wife of Sam for fifty-seven years. Beloved mother of Michael and Fern. Dear mother-in-law of Urszula and Ed. Adoring grandmother of Russell and fond sisterin-law of Sophie & Ted Leifschutz and Mayme and Julius Gerstel. Your sudden passing on May 11, 2000 has left us devastated. Go in peace with our love.

title: Indiana's Knight Admits To a Temper Problem
description: On the eve of a meeting of the Indiana University trustees to decide whether his successful but volatile career will continue here, the embattled basketball coach Bob Knight acknowledged today that his temper had led him into past confrontations, and he promised to work harder at developing a more diplomatic approach.

title: Who Wants to Be in the Audience?
description: WE live in a quaint, antebellum city in South Carolina where every six months or so, a TV crew from a travel or food show comes to town, sending the locals -- intensely private folk -- running for cover. And we often travel to New York, where there are street-side TV studios and, on every other block, it seems, a camera crew offering sightseers bit parts in a small-screen drama. All of New York City is a stage these days, and -- unlike our Carolina friends -- we think it's a whole lot of fun.

title: CALENDAR
description: May 20 through June 25

title: May 7-13; Let the Bidder Beware
description: The perils of Internet auctions -- and the potential for fraud -- were highlighted when the price of a ''great, big, wild'' painting soared on eBay from 25 cents to $135,805 on speculation that it was by the artist Richard Diebenkorn. The seller, Kenneth A. Walton of Sacramento, later acknowledged that he had fabricated part of the story that described the work and had bid on the painting ''for a friend.'' EBay suspended him and voided the auction. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCE, KATHLEEN (NEE KATHLEEN FORBES MOREHOUSE)
description: SPENCE-Kathleen (nee Kathleen Forbes Morehouse) 1904-2000. Died peacefully January 7 in Northern Ireland. She was the daughter of Mary Edith and Theodore Chichester Morehouse; educated at Wells College and received a Master's degree from UC Berkeley. In 1933 she married Thomas Everard Spence of Northern Ireland and lived there except during the war years. Kathleen Spence maintained a lifelong interest in, and support for, Irish American relations and for the Quaker Peace Movement in Northern Ireland. She was widowed in 1992 and is survived by her two sons, Ralph and Stuart, daughter Lucy, and grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Long Island section today about votes scheduled for Tuesday on school budgets and bonds misstated the plans of the Port Washington district for the $86.7 million it is seeking. The bond issue would be used to renovate all seven schools in the district, not just a middle school, and to expand some of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLIONE, JOHN
description: GALLIONE-John. Age 81, on May 11, 2000. Retired NYC Trial Attorney representing various trade unions and active in NYC politics. Served in WWII as Assistant Judge Advocate. Beloved husband to Dori. Father of Gale Cohen and her husband Michael, Joy Martinez and her husband Ernesto and the late Jan Gallione. Devoted brother of Joyce Binder and cherished grandfather of Grace, Jesse, Jonathan and Allison.

description: Weeks

title: Fort Lauderdale
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's delightful article ''Fort Lauderdale for Grown-Ups'' (April 9) reminded mer of my ultimate college experience, my spring visit to Fort Lauderdale back in 1962. As a survivor of what was probably one of the first spring break ''happenings'' (a 60's word), I was extremely pleased to return in ensuing years to find the city itself not only surviving, but slowly evolving into an independent ''happening'' of its own.

title: Not on Our Waterfront, Foes of Ferry Landings Say
description: Site designs for six ferry landings along the East River are being drawn up this month, but residents near sites that have been selected are worried that passengers would bring noise, crowds, traffic and congestion to their quiet neighborhoods.

description: Marguerite Kerr Screnk, a daughter of Katherine and William Schrenk of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Scott Carr, a son of Patricia and Paul Carr of Broomfield, Colo.

description: The serious patrons of Beijing's Panjia-yuan Antiques and Curios Market, better known as the ''Dirt Market,'' all go at the same time: Just after dawn on Saturday.

description: ''You can't have people over. You don't want them to step in the wrong spot and go through the floor.''
