description: As the nation's capital and other cities prepared for Mother's Day demonstrations favoring stricter gun control laws, President Clinton said the events on Sunday would show that the gun lobby ''is no match for America's moms.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-14-00: Questions For Sajeda Hayat And Sehar Saba; Tearing at the Veil
description: Q: Sajeda and Sehar -- and we should say that we aren't using your real names here, they're the names you use to travel, because of the danger in which your work places you -- you're both members of the Revolutionary Association of the Women of Afghanistan. Many Americans hear the word ''revolutionary'' and they think ''Communist'' and ''violent.'' Can you tell me about RAWA?

title: Peacocks, Doves and Tile-roofed Quintas
description: As a destination, the town of Sintra and its surrounding countryside come thunderously endorsed. Poets have waxed lyrical about this privileged enclave of Portugal, northwest of Lisbon.

title: Schussing Throughout a Summer's Day
description: Canada Day, July 1, and my 11-year-old daughter, Margaret, and I wake in our rented condominium in Whistler Village. It's raining. Out the big living-room window, a green mountain rises past the gables and shiny metal roof on the far side of the condo's courtyard, and I can see the line of a chairlift disappearing into a low gray cloud. Blackcomb Mountain rises another 5,000 feet past that gray ceiling, and somewhere up there is snow. Although I've skied since I was a boy, neither Margi nor I have ever skied in July, and the logistics of how to dress, and how to get from here to the slopes without becoming wet and miserable, remain a mystery.

title: CONTENDERS FOR HOCHBERG SEAT
description: Amy Paulin, a former Scarsdale village trustee, is the County Democratic Party's choice to replace Audrey G. Hochberg, the State Assemblywoman from the 88th District, who is retiring. Mrs. Hochberg, 66, has represented Pelham, Eastchester, Scarsdale and parts of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and White Plains since 1992. Ms. Paulin, 44, was interim executive director of My Sisters' Place, a shelter for battered women, until she stepped down recently to run for office. James E. Cavanaugh, Westchester Republican Party chairman, said three people were interested in the G.O.P. nomination, to be decided May 24 at the party's convention at the County Center: Max DiFabio, an Eastchester businessman; Maria Munoz-Kantha, a White Plains resident who unsuccessfully ran for the Board of Legislators in 1997; and former Mayor Marcia Lee of Bronxville. ELSA BRENNER

description: The Consolations

title: Thespians Raid 7 Seas to Aid A Children's Theater Project
description: THE SETTING -- Yar, matey. More than 500 actors, set designers, volunteers and friends, many in pirate garb, crowded a costume ball at the Puck Building on Monday night to benefit the 52nd Street Project, a group that teaches children as young as 8 in Hell's Kitchen to write, direct and perform plays with professional theater people. After-school classes are held in the project's clubhouse on West 52nd Street, and the plays are performed at theaters in Manhattan. Monday night's entertainment included jerk chicken and a play performed by professional actors and students, followed by limbo dancing.

description: To the Editor:

title: May 7-13; Scandal Fallout for Clinton
description: When Bill Clinton leaves the presidency in less than a year, few assume that he will hang out a shingle and practice law. Nonetheless, he is battling to keep his law license in Arkansas in a proceeding that could result in his being disbarred or suspended from the practice of law. In a recent filing, Mr. Clinton disputed the main charge against him -- that he lied under oath when he denied having had a sexual relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky -- by continuing to insist that his answers were technically accurate if misleading. A decision may come later this month. NEIL A. LEWIS

title: Ideas & Trends; Nothing Succeeds Like Controlling Succession
description: LAST week, Roman Catholics in New York began to take the measure of their next archbishop, Edward M. Egan, who has been bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., for more than a decade. At a press conference Thursday, hours after the Vatican announced the appointment, the archbishop-elect showed himself to be multilingual, answering questions in English, Italian and Spanish.

title: Cut, Pinch And Set Out

George W. Bush, his wife, Laura, and two prominent Republican officeholders, both women, all in a semicircle and awaiting their first guest.

description: SCHIFFMAN-Sidney, age 85, of Longwood, FL., died Wednesday, May 10th. Survived by daughters Ellen (Martin) Prague of Winter Park, FL., and Marjorie (John) Henley of Altamonte Springs, FL, sister Doris Sanet of Hollywood, FL, four grandchildren: Donna, Roberta, Wendy, and Ronald and five great grandchildren: Brooke, Lindsey, Haley, Jessica and Jason.

title: On the Continent, on the Cusp
description: THE newly won star status of the European entrepreneur, and the crushing burden of Big Government. The lure of the nimble American economic model, and the strengths of European multiculturalism. The unifying force of the euro, and lingering obstacles to a truly single European market.

title: Enemies, A Love Story
description: That people on the religious right are ''really quite nice,'' as Andrew Sullivan thinks he has discovered, is no secret at all. As right-wingers themselves are fond of saying, they like individuals. It's the larger masses of humanity that they believe must be held at bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, MILDRED
description: BERGMAN-Mildred. on May 11, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Blossom and Melvin Schecker, and Marvin and Eileen Bergman. Devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside services are Monday at 10:30 A.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Driving W.
description: George W. Bush had just nailed down the Republican Party's presidential nomination with his Super Tuesday primary victories, and in Texas it was a night to celebrate. (The campaign contributions were not down the drain after all, thank you, Jesus.) Yet the winner's top strategist, Karl Rove, moved uncomfortably through the victory bash at the Four Seasons in Austin that evening. ''The king has arrived!'' someone shouted at Rove, and the king winced. ''This is because of you,'' said a woman who dribbled her drink on his jacket as she hugged him. When Michael Levy, the publisher of Texas Monthly, knelt before him with a flourish and pretended to kiss his ring, Rove turned around, bent over at the waist and hiked up his jacket. As in, ''Kiss this.''

title: Books in Brief: Children's Books; Relaxed Fit
description: Ever wonder why loose cotton pants are called bloomers? Apparently, they're named after Amelia Bloomer, a 19th-century women's rights advocate and newspaper editor who flouted the corsets and hoop skirts of her day by wearing loose pantaloons under a short skirt. Her story is told in YOU FORGOT YOUR SKIRT, AMELIA BLOOMER! (Scholastic, $16.95; ages 4 to 8), an appealing picture book by Shana Corey, illustrated with style and wit by Chesley McLaren.

description: Natalie Lucie Fiebrich, a daughter of Christiane Fiebrich and Dr. Rolf-Dieter Fiebrich of Newport Beach, Calif., was married last evening to Daniel Hunt Clare IV, the son of Gwen Cavanagh Clare, the United States ambassador to Ecuador, and Daniel Hunt Clare III of Quito, Ecuador, and Hilton Head, S.C. title: Life as a Jailer

As Conover stopped by his cell one day and engaged in a brief conversation about a book of antiquated anthropology that Powerful was reading, the inmate looked at the correction officer inquisitively. ''What's your story, Conover?'' he asked. ''You're not like the other C.O.'s here.''

title: A Trek Into Bhutan's Magic Mountains
description: We stood fidgeting at the edge of the trail, acting more like schoolchildren than seasoned travelers. The advance man for the royal party came bouncing down the path carrying a walkie-talkie. A redstart -- a crimson and black bird with white cap -- landed on a farmhouse roof, gave three flicks of its tail and, as if on cue, the king, Jigme Singye Wangchuck, rounded the bend, nattily turned out in a silver gray gho -- a traditional belted knee-length robe -- long socks and white sneakers. He stopped to shake each of our hands and, in perfect English, inquired where we were from and where we were going. He had been camped at the base of Mount Jumolhari on a fishing vacation with three of his four wives, one of whom also stopped to say hello. The other two, on tiny horses with red saddles, smiled their greetings.

It's hard to make a villain out of any fish now that Great Whites have somehow or other become Man's Best Friend, but that little striper may well have become so plump and tasty by eating -- and now nearly destroying -- the shad population of the Hudson River.

The team is still struggling, but the Indian seems to have turned everyone else here into warriors.

title: Updating (and Retouching) an Old Passion Play
description: FROM the opening performance next Sunday until Oct. 8, half a million playgoers will make their way to Oberammergau, Germany, to witness a dramatic re-enactment of the crucifixion and resurrection of Jesus. The villagers of Oberammergau, in the foothills of the Bavarian Alps, have been staging their six-hour Passion play roughly once a decade since 1634. It is a Roman Catholic play about Jews, performed in German before a largely Protestant audience, most of whom will be American or British. The newly refurbished Passion playhouse holds 4,700 people, and 112 performances have been scheduled. The play (with the exception of some returns from travel agents) is sold out.

That is why we blush if a friend breaks with custom and trusts us with a financial confidence.

title: Mannequins That Are Model Citizens
description: Mannequins, like the seasonal clothes they wear, have short lives. In 1998, the artist Kenny Scharf designed pointy-headed, one-eyed aliens for Pucci International, a mannequin manufacturer. But in this season of handbags, knee-length skirts and other ladylike looks, Pucci has commissioned Robert Clyde Anderson, a Manhattan illustrator, to design a coterie of mannequins representing the more mature aesthetic of the moment -- highly manicured, blithely self-confident, chin-erect people of the Establishment. The mannequins are precise and tidy. No blowsy look for them. No pierced orifices. ''I wanted an uptown series,'' said Ralph Pucci, president of Pucci International, ''people you associate with Fifth Avenue and a house in Greenwich, Conn.'' Each has a personality, job and name: Hamilton, shown in a dark suit, is a silver-haired banker in his 60's; Caroline, second from left, is a gallery owner also in her 60's. Among the younger well-bred friends are Leander, third from left, a Wall Street broker; Helen, far left, an aspiring model; and Sam, an English pointer. A pit bull wouldn't do. The mannequins, which are called the ''Brownstone'' collection, sell for $1,100 each. Sony Style Stores, at Madison Avenue and 55th Street, ordered 15 of them. ELAINE LOUIE

title: New Roc City Unit Files for Bankruptcy

Apicella, a New Roc City senior vice president, said the bankruptcy would allow Family Golf to regroup and would have no impact on New Roc City. ''They're one of our highest-yielding locations,'' he said. ''We have every confidence that they're here for the long haul.'' title: Limits of Love
description: Susan Merrell's first novel, A MEMBER OF THE FAMILY (HarperCollins, $25), is a heartbreaking story about an adoption gone very wrong; more generally, it's about the limits of familial love. Chris and Deborah Latham, a clean-cut, all-American couple living in Sag Harbor, N.Y. -- he's a dentist, she's a part-time photographer -- decide to adopt a young Romanian orphan rather than have a second child on their own. Their new son, whom they call Michael, is bright and attractive and affectionate. He's also severely emotionally disturbed. The Lathams try everything from traditional psychology to homeopathy, from indulgence to tough love, in an attempt to give Michael a normal future. Michael has several terrifyingly violent episodes, alienates his friends and is thrown out of school for disruptive behavior. A child psychiatrist (who ''had been picking through human wreckage for years, and . . . knew the difference between detritus and the seeds of possibility'') reads a scan of Michael's brain and informs his parents that ''betting on Michael's chances for becoming a functioning citizen . . . was akin to buying fool's gold.'' But not until someone outside the family draws their attention to the damage Michael is doing to his sister, Caroline, and by extension to them, do the Lathams begin to think about the tough decisions that lie before them. Interwoven into the family drama is a subplot involving Chris, himself orphaned as a child, who has a big secret in his past. Though the attempt to link Chris's past with his current travails is less than successful, ''A Member of the Family'' is a nuanced exploration of what it means to be just that. Betsy Groban

The prison system is well-managed, he said, and provides its residents with food, medical attention and a place to sleep. Mr. Edwards may well have a chance to test his assessment first-hand at some point. He, his son, and three other co-defendants were convicted on Tuesday by a Federal District Court jury in Baton Rouge on racketeering charges related to the extortion of businessmen seeking riverboat casino licenses. title: Reckonings; Nihon Keizai Shambles
description: Last week Japan's Nikkei -- the stock index that takes its name from the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the country's leading financial newspaper -- fell almost 9 percent. Now normally it's a mistake to read too much meaning into the fluctuations of this or any other market index (especially because the index was revised to include more tech stocks just in time for the big tech slump). If the 30 percent rise in the Nikkei between June and April didn't foretell a real turnaround in Japan -- which it didn't -- then the 15 percent decline since April doesn't necessarily predict a new recession. But in this case the stock plunge is telling us something: namely, that the economic strategy of Japan's government is falling apart.

They pack a minty wallop so strong they leave lips stinging. The Thursday Plantation, their Australian manufacturer, claims they freshen breath, help with oral hygiene and ''relieve the stress associated with giving up smoking.'' But Dr. David Ores, a Lower East Side general practitioner, says they are not the newest answer to the nicotine patch. ''They're ineffective, but they're harmless,'' he said. A former smoker, Happy Massee, who is a commercial and film production designer, chews through a couple of boxes a week. He said they were helpful, but he had his reservations. ''Believe me,'' he said, ''I'd rather smoke.'' Still, they're better for the teeth than lollipops, and look tougher, too. PETER PAVIA

Heavy winds sent flames racing through tinder-dry canyons and then residential areas, and even across portions of the highly sensitive nuclear weapons laboratory at Los Alamos. The local head of the National Park Service, which set the fire, was suspended, more than 25,000 people had to be evacuated and at least 260 homes were destroyed. The nuclear lab suffered no major damage and officials said there was no release of radioactivity. Still, officials said, it could take weeks to get the facility running fully again. title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; Art in a Box
description: Joseph Cornell made accumulation a fine art, incorporating a vast range of materials into his poetic box-constructions, collages and dossiers. Of the manifold sources in his work, Jodi Hauptman argues in JOSEPH CORNELL: Stargazing in the Cinema (Yale University, $40), ''the cinema pervades the artist's aesthetic imagination and his artistic vision,'' and to understand Cornell's art ''requires a view through the lens of a motion picture camera.'' There is no doubt that Cornell was immersed in the cinema, both as a historian and as a fan -- he owned an extensive collection of film stills and movies and created some 20 short films. Cornell's ardent engagement with film is further borne out in his ''portrait-homages'' to screen actresses like Lauren Bacall, Greta Garbo, Hedy Lamarr and Marilyn Monroe, and to child stars including Deanna Durbin and Margaret O'Brien. Hauptman, who teaches art history at the University of Delaware, deftly analyzes the cinematic motifs and formal devices in these portraits and goes on to probe the ambivalence underlying all of Cornell's work. His art embodies a ''confluence of longing and futility, vision and desire, distance and alienation, disturbance and bliss,'' traits that also define the voyeuristic appeal of the motion picture image. Cornell's homages to film stars are ultimately futile attempts to capture and control the ephemeral screen presences that aroused his desire. And although they are presented as tributes, these portraits are shown to be more telling as projections of Cornell's own longing than as memorials to their cinematic subjects. In addition to illuminating some of Cornell's lesser-known work, Hauptman's study hints at the artist's sublimated passions and helps us detect the faint scent of eroticism and morbidity surrounding his hermetically sealed boxes. Suzanne Ramljak

title: Enemies, A Love Story

Of his own admission, he kept his homosexuality a secret that evening so he could ''watch the enemy at ease.'' Had Sullivan decided to make evident that he was gay, it is likely his dinner companions would have remained ''charming.'' Most people, after all, want to appear gracious. title: The Spicy Pleasures of Phuket
description: Phuket, even more than most places, becomes what you make of it. I like this idea, mostly because I can't decide if it's a very mature notion or a completely childish one. The island is dangerous that way, like any real paradise (or hell, for that matter). It's not the sort of place that takes you by the collar and says, ''This is how it is, and you're going to like it.'' You do and see what you want -- whether this means spending long hours on the wide, white-hot beaches, or bungee-jumping off some rugged cliff, or pub-crawling with the young and blond of the world or being massaged and oiled and herbally steamed -- and you do so without a single guilty thought of what else you should be doing. For my wife, Michelle, and me, it meant that our pleasure drive, for four days in January, went mostly toward the ingestion of many curries green and red, until finally, and gorgeously, we were thoroughly curried ourselves -- details of this to follow.

title: Stolen Art and the Law
description: On Jan. 7, 1998, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, obtained a grand jury subpoena to prevent the return to an Austrian museum of two paintings by Egon Schiele that had been lent to the Museum of Modern Art for exhibition. Both paintings had been confiscated by the Nazis from their prewar Jewish owners, and heirs to those owners were seeking their return as stolen art. Late last year, however, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled 6 to 1 that Mr. Morgenthau's subpoena of the Schiele paintings violated an Arts and Cultural Affairs Law passed in 1968 specifically to prevent the seizure of works of art on loan by non-residents to exhibitions in New York State. The goal of this law was to encourage the worldwide lending of art for museum shows without the threat of confiscation. As Louis Lefkowitz, the attorney general at the time, expressed it, without such a statute ''incalculable harm may be done to the cultural institutions of this state.''

description: A 2-year-old Queens boy who was found unconscious in a swimming pool yesterday was resuscitated in the back of a police van by an officer as his partners drove to the hospital, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, HERMAN
description: TENENBAUM-Herman. Passed away May 13, at the age of 94 in Weston, Florida. Formerly of West End Avenue, he was a survivor of the Holocaust, a real estate broker, investor and philanthropist in New York, Philadelphia and Israel as well as a passionate Mets fan and tennis player. Husband of the late Eda Tenenbaum. Loving father of David of Hingham, MA and proud grandfather of Erica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT
description: FELDMAN-Robert. We are deeply grieved to have lost the Chairman of our Board, Robert Feldman. Robert Feldman, a man of understanding, compassion, humor and generosity, served this Board and the children of New York City for over forty years. He devoted his talent, energy and time to helping the students of the High School of Fashion Industries succeed in school and prepare for their future careers. A true gentle man, he made all whose lives he touched better people. The Members of the Fashion Crafts Educational Commission

title: NBC Plans To Expand 'Today' and Add 7 Shows
description: NBC plans to shake up its fall schedule on both mornings and evenings. The network announced its new prime-time schedule yesterday and disclosed plans to expand its 48-year-old ''Today'' program from two hours to three.

title: More Is Less (Or Is That Vice Versa?) At Film Fest
description: It seems that taxi drivers are the same all over the world, taking hairpin turns as if they were driving in the Indianapolis 500 -- or, here, the Grand Prix in Monaco -- and subjecting passengers to unsolicited opinions. When one driver overheard muttering about the ride's resemblance to the Joel and Ethan Coen film ''The Big Lebowski,'' in which a surly cabby literally tosses a passenger out of the car for objecting to his taste, he smiled and joined in the conversation.

title: Nike's Power Game
description: When Phil Knight, the chief executive of Nike, withdrew a promised $30 million donation to the University of Oregon last month, his announcement had the tone of an angry parent. He chastised the university for joining the Worker Rights Consortium, a group that monitors conditions in factories that make clothing with college logos. He accused the university of ''inserting itself into the new global economy where I make my living'' and doing so ''on the wrong side, fumbling a teachable moment.''

title: Seas and Soils Emerge as Keys to Climate
description: Over the last 150 years, the burning of coal, oil and natural gas has released some 270 billion tons of carbon into the air in the form of heat-trapping carbon dioxide. If all that had stayed in the atmosphere, much of the substantial global warming predicted for a century from now might have already taken place.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about an easily applied hearing aid misstated the fitting method. While many other kinds of hearing aids require taking an impression of the ear and having the patient return weeks later, the new device does not.

title: Adding White Noise to a Korean Lunar Ritual
description: Ancient lunar rituals got a technological upgrade in ''Dong Dong Touching the Moons,'' a multimedia piece by Jin Hi Kim presented last week at the Kitchen. Ms. Kim plays the Korean komungo, a zither akin to the Japanese koto, and has devoted much of her career to composing mixed-culture hybrids. ''Dong Dong,'' named after a 15th-century Korean homage to the moon, brought together Korean and Indian musicians and dancers with video images and computer processing, including sensors that allowed a dancer's gesture to send a sound spinning around the room.

title: GRANADA IN TALKS WITH COMPASS
description: Britain's biggest hotel owner, Granada Group, said it was discussing a merger with Compass Group P.L.C., the country's largest contract caterer, that would permit Granada to separate its hospitality and media activities. Granada owns one-third of the Independent Television Network of Britain, and a split would enable it to concentrate on strengthening its television production interests. Compass and Granada shares both rose about 4 percent. Granada said a merger would reflect the company's recent market values: $9.3 billion for Compass and $17.8 billion for Granada. Alan Cowell

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR CLIMBS. The dollar gained on expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 91.20 cents, down from 91.89 cents on Friday; the dollar traded at 109.53 yen, up from 108.89.

title: New Leaps of Abandon in Ballet Theater's 'Don Quixote'
description: A new set of dancers in some of the principal roles helped add to the merriment of American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote'' on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: TMP Worldwide Purchase
description: TMP Worldwide Inc., which operates the job search Web site Monster.com, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held VirtualRelocation.com for about $56.5 million in stock and cash to expand its online moving services. TMP will issue 947,916 shares in addition to paying $726,000 in cash to acquire VirtualRelocation. By acquiring VirtualRelocation, the New York-based TMP gains the company's 87,000 Web pages of moving-related resources.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Building Lyme Immunity in Children
description: The vaccine against Lyme disease, so far given only to adults, has been found to be safe and effective in children as young as 4, according to research presented on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHEL, JOSEPHINE. ARIEL
description: REICHEL-Josephine. Ariel. American Friends of Midrasha deeply mourns the passing of Rebbetzin Josephine Hannah Reichel, of blessed memory; wife of Rabbi O. Asher Reichel, a member of our Board of Governors; sister of Dr. Naomi G. Cohen, wife of our Chancellor, Rabbi Shear Yashuv Cohen; mother of Rabbi Aaron Reichel, Miriam Bronner and Rabbi Hillel Reichel. She served for many years as President of both the Women's Branch of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregation of America and Agudah Women of America. Her piety, devotion and leadership will always serve as a source of inspiration to all who knew her. Natalio S. Fridman, President Lawrence A. Kobrin, Chairman Michael D. Jaspan, Treasurer Ephraim Savitt, Secretary

title: Cheaters' Final Response: So What?
description: Five years after shaming their school by cheating to win a statewide academic contest, some of the former Steinmetz High School students on the quiz team now say they have a single regret: being caught.

description: WALLACH-Lillian Weinberg Opatoshu, on Saturday, May 13, 2000. Wife of Ira, wife of David, will be greatly missed by son Dan, daughter-in-law Anne, stepdaughter Leah, niece Ronit, their families, and her many lifelong friends.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; The Price of Ending 'Drive-By Deliveries'
description: A Pennsylvania law against ''drive-by deliveries'' -- limits set by insurance companies on how long mothers and their newborn infants can remain in the hospital -- has succeeded in extending the average length of stay, but at a cost that may outweigh the law's benefits, according to a study released Sunday.

title: EDS Pulls Out of Merger Talks With Policy Management Systems
Echoes of an Artists' Retreat
description: On Thursday evening at the Society for Ethical Culture, members of the Orpheus chamber orchestra gave the second of three concerts in celebration of Yaddo, the artists' retreat outside Saratoga Springs, N.Y. George Tsontakis, a member of the Yaddo board and an organizing force behind these concerts, spoke of the suitability of the setting -- of the warmth and the wood and the rounded shapes, all recalling features that have made Yaddo a welcoming and inspiring place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLUGER, JOSEPH
description: SCHLUGER-Joseph. Husband of Charlotte. Father of Neil, Olga and James. Father-in-law of Leona, Phil and Rosemary. Grandfather of Jenny, Aaron, Martha, Benjamin, Adam, Julia, Hannah and Jack. Brother of Bernard, Nancy, Ray, Abie, Millie, Betty and Jack. On May 14, 2000. His long and distinguished career as a physician was spent mainly at Long Island College Hospital, where he established the cardiac catheterization laboratory and served as Professor of Clinical Medicine (SUNY Downstate) and Chairman of the Department of Medicine. In his practice, he provided extraordinary care to patients for more than 35 years. At the New York Heart Association, he lead the Emergency Cardiac Care Committee and developed standards for care which are now used in hospitals throughout New York. He served as President of the NYHA with distinction. In his later years, he became a valued consultant to Medical Liability Mutual and he was a talented artisan of the Isabel O'Neil Studios. Funeral services Tuesday, May 16th, 9:15AM, at Frank Campbell, 81st St. & Madison. Contributions in his memory should be made to The American Heart Association, NYC Affiliate, 122 E. 42 St., NYC 10168 or the Berkshire Natural Resources Council, 20 Bank Row, Pittsfield, MA. 01201. No Flowers Please.

title: Verna Aardema, 88, Chronicler Of African Folklore for Children
description: Verna Aardema Vugteveen, a late-blooming, prolific writer who regaled generations of American children with the folklore of faraway Africa, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 88.

title: As Mt. St. Helens Recovers, Old Wisdom Crumbles
description: Here at the foot of a still snow-covered Mount St. Helens, a gentle, new spring is hatching as alder trees leaf out, the first warblers sing, salamanders squirm out of gooey eggs and the Toutle River rushes toward its destination.

title: No Inquiry on Gulf Attack
description: The Army said today that it had no plans to reopen an investigation into an attack made at the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991 by soldiers under the command of Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired Army general who is now President Clinton's drug-policy adviser.

title: Levy Meets With Mayor, Asking Support for Chancellor's Job
description: Harold O. Levy, the interim schools chancellor, quietly visited City Hall yesterday to ask Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to support his bid for the permanent chancellor post.

title: First Step Is Recognizing the Signs of Internet Abuse
description: Addictive and compulsive disorders are notoriously difficult to treat, particularly when they involve a substance or behavior that, when used or practiced normally, is an essential or important part of life, like eating or sex. When people lose control of such behaviors, the goal of treatment is not to cut them out completely, as might be done with alcohol or nicotine, but to re-establish a healthier pattern of use.

title: Good Propaganda, Bad Economics
description: College students continue to propagate the myth that Nike and other apparel companies contract out to foreign ''sweatshops'' where overworked and underpaid workers toil in unhealthful conditions. They are especially outraged by the recent decision by Phil Knight of Nike to withdraw a promised $30 million donation to the University of Oregon in protest of the school's decision to join the Worker Rights Consortium, a labor rights group.

title: E*Trade and Wit Capital Join to Face Off-Line Rivals
description: Acknowledging how hard it has been to break the stranglehold Wall Street has on the underwriting of new stocks, two online financial services companies, the E*Trade Group and the Wit Capital Group, said yesterday that they would team up to compete against their off-line rivals.

description: CORN PRICES FALL. Corn plunged after new forecasts predicted showers in parts of the Midwest where a long drought has threatened crop production. In Chicago, corn for July delivery fell 7 cents, to $2.3875 a bushel.

title: U.N.'s Unlikely Ally for Sierra Leone
description: Even as United Nations officials today confirmed the release of 139 peacekeepers held hostage by rebels, thereby delivering the best piece of news since the beginning of a humiliating month in this corner of Africa, there was hardly ringing praise for the man who had made it all possible.

title: WOMEN LOSE RIGHT TO SUE ATTACKERS IN FEDERAL COURT
description: Declaring that ''the Constitution requires a distinction between what is truly national and what is truly local,'' the Supreme Court today invalidated a six-year-old provision of federal law that permitted victims of rape, domestic violence and other crimes ''motivated by gender'' to sue their attackers in federal court.

description: * Fathom, New York, which plans to operate an education Web site at www.fathom.com, named six agencies to handle assignments with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million. They were Weiss Stagliano Partners, New York, with O'Malley & Hogan, Dublin, Ireland, for branding and advertising; Organic, San Francisco, for Web site development; Clark, Martire & Bartolomeo, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., for market research; Emerging Technology Solutions, Fairfax, Va., part of Veridian Inc., for project management and e-commerce; and Outrider, New York, part of the Tempus Group, for customer marketing.

title: U.S. Officials Said a Wildfire Was Likely
description: Whether sparked by lightning, a carelessly tossed cigarette or a prescribed burn like the one now flaring out of control, a catastrophic wildfire threatening Los Alamos National Laboratory was bound to happen.

title: Los Alamos Becomes a Laptop Lab
description: Throughout the 11-day-old fire that has swept through the pine forests around Los Alamos National Laboratory in northern New Mexico, the lab's computer system has remained up and running -- providing an eerie but comforting virtual presence for scientists exiled from their research. Everyday they have been able to sign on to the system to exchange e-mail messages, download unclassified files for work and reassure themselves that the lab is still there.

title: As the Space Station Falls, NASA Moves to Prop It Up
description: The space station is falling. As it orbits Earth, even at a height of 210 miles, the nascent International Space Station brushes against wisps of atmosphere, causing it gradually to lose speed and altitude.

Panel Fears Security at Labs Hurts Foreign Hiring
description: A panel of scientists and engineers who advise the president and Congress issued a statement yesterday expressing concern that heightened security measures at federal laboratories appeared to be damaging their ability to hire and retain foreign-born and minority scientists.

title: Hardaway Will Start Despite Foot Sprain
description: Slowed by a sprain in his left foot, point guard Tim Hardaway fielded suggestions after the Miami Heat's loss to the Knicks on Sunday that he might be hindering his team. Today, after meeting with Coach Pat Riley, Hardaway announced that he would start Wednesday night in Game 5 of the four-of-seven-game series at American Airlines Arena.

She taught us about life, its humor and balance. May she be at peace in the quiet of the heights. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

title: Even a Mother Can't Love Rent Official's Job
description: YOU never got to play second base for the Yankees, were rejected by Harvard Law, lost $15,000 (and the race) in your 1990 New Jersey Congressional campaign, didn't fulfill that teenage prediction about being a second-term senator by 45. Now you're the Giuliani-appointed chairman of the much-vilified New York City Rent Guidelines Board, and to top things off, you're even having trouble hanging on to your hair.

title: Grand Jury Inquiry On Diet Drug Filings
description: A federal grand jury is looking into whether American Home Products hid reports from the United States Food and Drug Administration that its withdrawn diet drugs caused potentially fatal side effects in users.

title: RENAULT, NISSAN TO CUT JOBS
description: France's second-biggest carmaker, Renault S.A., and the Nissan Motor Company, said they expected to save 1 billion euros ($915 million) by 2005 as they combine sales forces in Europe, where they will cut 504 jobs. The companies aim to increase market share in Europe to 17 percent from 14.2 percent now. They plan to redesign and rebrand some models for Europe, allowing Renault to sell sport-utility vehicles and Nissan to expand light truck sales.

title: Violence Against the Constitution
description: With its 5-to-4 ruling yesterday overturning part of the Violence Against Women Act, the Supreme Court left women more vulnerable to gender-motivated violence. It also provided confirmation that a narrow majority on the court is determined to reconfigure the balance between state and federal authority, even at the expense of weakening civil rights. The effect of this decision is to undermine Congress's traditional power to identify problems that states cannot or will not adequately deal with and to fashion national remedies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICCARI, PETER
description: VICCARI-Peter. Born in London, February 17, 1915. Beloved husband of the late Eunice, father of Rodney of Greenwich, CT, and Carolyn Klemm of Washington, CT, and grandfather of Peter and Graham Klemm of Washington, CT. Private services. Contribtutions: Washington Art Association.

title: Excerpts From Prepared Remarks by Bush and Gore
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Gov. George W. Bush's speech yesterday about Social Security and Medicare, as provided by the Bush campaign. Mr. Bush spoke at a center for the elderly in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif. Also included are excerpts from the prepared text of Vice President Al Gore's speech on those issues yesterday at Beaver College in Glenside, Pa.

title: Rumors That Suitors Are Ogling Nabisco Send Shares Higher
description: Investor interest perked up noticeably yesterday for Nabisco Holdings, the maker of Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies, and its parent, the Nabisco Group.

title: Key Democrat Seems to Lean In Support Of Trade Bill
description: An influential senior House Democrat from New York signaled today that he is leaning in favor of a decisive China trade bill, as the measure's supporters and opponents geared up for a furious week of lobbying before next week's scheduled vote.

title: Without a Body, Murder Case of Widow Relies on Circumstantial Evidence
description: On Valentine's Day, four of the Manhattan district attorney's senior prosecutors stood before 12 jurors and began an exhaustive, carefully choreographed presentation aimed at achieving the seemingly impossible. They vowed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that a pair of con artists had murdered a wealthy elderly widow, even though investigators had failed to turn up a corpse or any other physical evidence linking the defendants to the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANLER, RANDALL W.
description: CHANLER - Randall W. died peacefully at her home in Golden's Bridge, New York on May 13th. She was 89 years old and the daughter of the late Captain Roger Williams & Frances Mcllvaine Williams. She attended Smith college. Her first marriage to John S. Rogers ended in divorce. She was subsequently married for 46 years to the late William C. Chanler. Mrs. Chanler is survived by a sister, Eveline Holt of Virginia Beach, Virginia, & by five daughters: Evelyn Chanler of Rhineback, New York; Shiela Swett of Norwich, Vermont; Elizabeth Janeway of Webster, New Hampshire; Randall Hunt of Washington, DC; & Sarah Walker of Peck, Idaho. Her family included 15 grandchildren & 14 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, New York on Friday, June 2 at 11:00 AM. Contributions in her name may be sent to Hospice Care, 100 South Bedford Road, Mt. Kisco, New York 10549.

Survived by loving daughters, Gisele Melnick & Faith Kanner, son-inlaw, Michael Melnick, grandchildren, Amy, Alyssa, Gary & Adam, great grandchild, Quentin, & companion Shifra Blinova, all will miss him dearly. description: SAYRES - Joan Gilpatric, 66, daughter of Roswell Gilpatric and Margaret (Kurtz) Gilpatric and wife of William Sayres, died May 13, 2000 at her home in Readfield, Maine. Contributions are invited to HealthReach Hospice Comfort Fund, 212 Main Street, Waterville, Maine, 04901.

title: Coach Is Gone, and Capriati Loses
description: In need of a mentor, Jennifer Capriati found an effective one last year in Harold Solomon, the former member of the men's top 10 who had already helped Mary Joe Fernandez win on a regular basis. With his guidance, Capriati, the former teenage phenom, managed to rebuild her confidence and her resume and reach the semifinals at this year's Australian Open.

title: AUSTRALIAN CHIEF EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: Shares in Australia's biggest supplier of accounting software, Solution 6 Ltd., surged after Chris Tyler resigned as chief executive to return to the United States. Mr. Tyler owns 11.8 million options in the company, worth 31.2 million Australian dollars. The resignation follows revelations of Mr. Tyler's past conviction for marijuana possession and involvement in a failed Canadian company. It also comes after a planned merger with Sausage Software Ltd. was scuttled after Solution 6's shares plummeted 60 percent.

title: CHOICE ONE TO BUY US XCHANGE, RIVAL PHONE CARRIER
description: Choice One Communications Inc., a provider of telecommunications services to small and midsize businesses, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy US Xchange, a competing local exchange carrier, for $518 million in cash and stock. Choice One said it would pay $311 million in cash and seven million shares for US Xchange. The shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $30.125, in Nasdaq trading. US Xchange, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich., serves about 17,000 business and residential clients in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin with an installed base of nearly 60,000 access lines. Choice One, which operates primarily in the Northeast, said the combined company would have more than 93,000 lines in service.

title: Toys 'R' Us Earnings Increase For First Time in Two Years
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the nation's largest toy chain, said today that its earnings rose for the first time in more than two years under its new chief executive's plan to increase sales.

title: Closing the Achievement Gap
description: Over the last five years, the New York State Board of Regents has enacted a series of public school reforms that have placed the state in the lead of the national movement for standards and accountability. At the same time, however, local educators and politicians who claim to want reform have sometimes reacted with skepticism and resistance when confronted with the discomfort that comes with change. Defenders of the status quo whipped up a fuss, for example, when the Regents raised graduation standards across the state, demanded a tougher curriculum and began to issue ''report cards'' that exposed as mediocre schools that many citizens thought were excellent.

title: U.S. Planned Nuclear Blast On the Moon, Physicist Says
description: The United States weighed a plan to detonate a nuclear bomb on the moon as a show of military and technical strength during the feverish post-Sputnik days of the cold war, a physicist involved in the plan said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, GLENN R.
description: DAVIS-Glenn R. Age 57, of Ann Arbor, MI. On May 13, 2000, he lost a brave battle against cancer. Beloved husband of Katie Pelz-Davis, adoring father of Peter, Becky and Michael, loving son-in-law of Mary Jane and Robert Pelz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLFMAN, DR. ARNOLD W.
description: GOLFMAN-Dr. Arnold W., of Bay Shore passed away at home on May 13, 2000 after a long illness. He was 81. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father and stepfather of Sheila Ackerman, Robert Golfman and Michael and Steven Glass. Loving grandfather of Evan & Colin Ackerman, Peter, Catherine Casey and Jessica Ann Glass. Dear brother of Lillian Starr and Sidney Golfman, M.D. Born in Canada, Dr. Golfman graduated from St. Georges Hospital Medical School, London, England in 1946. After 2 years as the only physician providing care to several Canadian Indian tribes by flying himself to their reservations, Dr. Golfman went on to specialized training in pathology. Upon completion of his studies, he began his career as a pathologist in the United States. In 1959, Dr. Golfman was asked to oversee all aspects of the building and development of the laboratory at the new Diocesan hospital being built in West Islip. When Good Samaritan Hospital opened later that year, the Pathology Department was indeed ready to serve both pysicians and patients with Dr. Golfman as the Director, a position in which he happily served for the next 25 years. An accomplished aviator, sailor, skier & woodworker; Dr. Golfman will best be remembered by friends & colleagues for his intellectual curiosity, professional integrity & the respect with which he treated all who crossed his path. The family will receive visitors at Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hway, (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy), Thursday, May 18, 2000 between 3-7 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center, 1000 Montauk Highway, West Islip, New York 11795

title: Microsoft Revises Program To Protect E-Mail Users
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had developed a software update for its Outlook e-mail program that would reduce the vulnerability to rogue computer programs like ''I Love You'' and ''Melissa.''

title: A Coach Beyond Punishment
description: Myles Brand, the president of Indiana University, showed lack of judgment and nerve yesterday when it came time to discipline his volatile, abusive basketball coach, Bob Knight. Instead of firing Mr. Knight for behavior that would not have been tolerated in any faculty member -- or for that matter, in any coach less successful at winning games and generating revenues -- he gave him only a very mild penalty. The punishment includes suspension for three games, a $30,000 fine and a demand that Coach Knight abide by a stringent code of conduct under which he can be dismissed for any inappropriate physical contact or other infractions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, LOUISE FRITH STICKNEY
description: TANNER-Louise Frith Stickney. On May 15, 2000 following a brief struggle with cancer. Born February 16th, 1922 in New York. Adored mother of Michael and Betsy. Grandmother of Henry. Wife of the late Patrick Tanner. Funeral service on Friday May 19th at 10 AM at St. George's Church on Stuyvesant Square (209 E. 16th Street). Interment at St. James Episcopal Church in St. James, Long Island. ''...For God loveth a cheerful giver''.

title: Yanks' Skid Catches Steinbrenner's Attention
description: There was a time when George Steinbrenner would have reacted decisively to a four-game losing streak. He might have ordered a trade, a demotion or a firing. He might have waded into a band of reporters and blistered a slumping player.

title: Bush Presents Social Security As Crucial Test
description: Casting the overhaul of the Social Security system as a ''test of presidential candidates,'' Gov. George W. Bush today proposed a fundamental change in the retirement system that would allow workers to choose how to invest some of their payroll taxes.

title: EMC TO REVISE PLAN TO BUY I.B.M. HARD DRIVES
description: The EMC Corporation, the maker of computer data-storage systems, dropped a plan to buy $3 billion of hard drives from the International Business Machines Corporation, citing I.B.M. production delays. EMC said it had worked out a new agreement to buy drives from I.B.M., the No. 1 computer maker, that does not include a specific amount. The accord is part of an agreement the companies disclosed on Friday to settle all patent suits against each other. At his annual meeting with analysts in New York last week, I.B.M.'s chief executive, Louis V. Gerstner, repeated warnings that a delay in introducing new drives would cut into second-quarter revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JACK
description: KATZ-Jack. The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center records with deep sorrow the passing of Jack Katz, Vice Chairman Emeritus of the Associate Board of Directors. In 1980, he received the Brookdale Medal, the institution's highest honor. Mr. Katz was Chairman of the Cadillac Raffle Campaign and an active member for four decades. Our sincere condolences to his sons Ronald, Steven and Alan, and the entire family. Edwin L. Schulman Chairman, Board of Trustees David I. Schachne Chairman, Executive Committee Hon. Samuel Plotkin Chairman, Associate Board of Directors Alvin I. Kahn, MD, President & CEO Cosmo J. LaCosta Executive Vice President & COO

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He trusts the government to manage our retirement. I trust individual Americans. I trust Americans to make their own decisions and manage their own money.''

title: Dong Kingman, 89, Whimsical Watercolorist
description: Dong Kingman, an American-born watercolorist known for humorously illustrational cityscapes, magazine covers and contributions to Hollywood films, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Palestinian Forces Exchange Gunfire With Israeli Troops
description: For the first time in almost four years, Israelis and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank today as a wave of violent protest swept through the Palestinian territories. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won his Parliament's approval to cede three villages near Jerusalem to the Palestinian Authority in an effort to advance the peace talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINITZ, JEROME L.
description: REINITZ-Jerome L., died Saturday, May 13, 2000, at age 85. He is survived by his children, Michael, Nancy Bernstein and Peter, their spouses, nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Jerry was loved by his family and many friends. He was a Brooklyn boy who became a major force in the printing industry. He was formerly Chairman of the Royal Zenith Corporation, a major manufacturer of lithographic presses, and represented manufacturers of auxiliary printing equipment all over the world. Jerry loved two women in his lifetime, Clarice Lasar, his boyhood sweetheart, mother of his children and wife of 36 years; in his later years, his companion, Kay Sirota, was very dear to him. Funeral on Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, 11520 State Road #

title: VITAL SIGNS: NUTRITION; A Dose of Fiber for Diabetes Regimen
description: Fiber's reputation as a defense against cancer has taken a beating lately, but a new study reported last week in The New England Journal of Medicine reaffirms its value as a treatment for adult onset diabetes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PI, SUNYER, JAMES, M.D.
description: PI-SUNYER-James, M.D., of NYC, formerly of Montclair, on May 12, 2000, husband of the late Mercedes, father of James A. Pi-Sunyer, F. Xavier Pi-Sunyer, M.D., Lina Grogan, Luis C. Pi-Sunyer, and the late Berta Williams, brother of Pere Pi-Sunyer. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and six great - grandchildren. Memorial Mass on Wednesday at 1 PM, at St. Cassian's Church, Upper Montclair. For information call Caggiano Memorial, Montclair, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVY, REBECCA
description: ALVY-Rebecca, 86. Passed away on Mother's Day, May 14, 2000. Beloved wife of Daniel. Devoted mother of Norman and Susan, Harvey and Bonnie and Vida and Lawrence. Loving grandmother of Rachel, Deborah, Rebecca, Daniel, Elliot and Julia. Dedicated aunt and sister. Loved working at Middle School 45, Bronx, N.Y. for over 30 years. ''You're the best''. Services Tuesday, May 16, 10AM. Louis Hirsch and Sons, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Banks Shift Priorities to Meet Needs of a New Generation of Wealthy Entrepreneurs : In Asia, Clients Are Demanding Global Investments
description: The landscape of private banking in Asia has changed since the Asian crisis roiled world markets in 1997. To get a perspective on the shifts in private banking priorities and practices in Asia, as well as the changing needs of clients, Sharon Reier spoke with Alex Widmer, chief executive officer for Asia Pacific at Credit Suisse Private Banking. Mr. Widmer spent 12 years in Asia  seven in Japan and five in Singapore  and is now back at Credit Suisse headquarters in Zurich, where all the bank's Asian operations report to him. He is also on the board of Credit Suisse Private Banking.

title: NEW BID FOR TRAVEL CONCERN
description: In a scramble for scale in Europe's tourism industry, Preussag A.G. of Germany, the Continent's biggest tour operator, said it had outbid a rival, C & N Touristic A.G., to buy Thomson Travel Group P.L.C. for $2.7 billion. Thomson is Britain's leading travel company. Preussag offered 180 pence a share, compared with C & N's last bid of 160 pence a share. Analysts said the battle reflected a drive among the leaders to dominate Europe's $230 billion tour industry. C & N is jointly owned by Karstadt Quelle and Lufthansa. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESSLER, ANITA LOUISE
description: SESSLER-Anita Louise. May 13, 2000. Daughter of the late Jonas and Sydelle. She is survived by her husband Robert, sons, Scott and Lee, and daughters-in-law, Andrea and Madeline, and grandchildren, Ryan and Jordan. Sister of Stevie and sister-in-law of Rosalie. Funeral services May 16th at 11:15 A.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. She will be greatly missed but her memory will forever be in our hearts.

title: Crop Genetics On the Line In Brazil; A Rule on Seeds May Have Global Impact
description: He was dazzled by the vast fields of soybeans in Brazil, and the efficiency of the farms in Argentina frankly frightened him. But nothing that Harold H. Dyer, an Iowa farmer, saw on his working vacation in South America last year surprised him more than finding out that his competitors freely used genetically modified soybeans in ways that would have landed him in a heap of trouble.

title: Unilever Chief Presses Bestfoods on Takeover Offer
description: Stepping up the pressure on a reluctant takeover target, the co-chairman of Unilever said yesterday that he thought the $66-a-share offer made earlier this month for Bestfoods was ''serious money'' and that the company wants the management of Bestfoods to meet with Unilever to discuss it.

title: In Tough Reply, Police Call Civil Rights Report Recklessly Unfair
description: In a bitterly worded rebuttal, the New York Police Department has denounced a draft report by the United States Civil Rights Commission that accused the police of racial profiling. The department asserted that the panel's research was slipshod and its conclusions recklessly unfair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVET, PAUL H., PH.D
description: SAVET-Paul H., Ph.D. May 14, 2000 and Savet, Gabrielle, Ph.D. February 13, 1999. They were the beloved parents, grandparents and great-grandparents of the family of Leslie A. Kory, M.D. and Odile A. Kory, Ph.D.. Paul and Gabrielle were both born and raised in Cluj, Transylvania. They left to study in France before the war where Paul obtained a doctorate of mathematics at the Sorbonne and also served as a pilot instructor for the French Air Force in Saint Cyr, France. In 1940 he managed to escape the Nazi Occupation and made it to the United States. Gabrielle, who had returned to Transylvania and been deported, became one of the few survivors of Auschwitz. She and her son, Leslie, joined Paul in New York in 1947. Before he retired, Paul was a staff scientist at Grumman's where he contributed to the creation of the first manned lunar module. Gabrielle obtained a Ph.D. in French from Columbia University and was Chair of the French Department at Hofstra University. They were married for 52 years and lived in Westbury, NY. Funeral will be private. Contributions may be made in their names to your favorite charity.

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court's Decision on the Violence Against Women Act
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today declaring unconstitutional the civil remedy provision of the Violence Against Women Act, referred to by the court as Section 13981. The vote, in United States v. Morrison, was 5 to 4. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion, and Justice David H. Souter wrote the dissent.

title: Guare's Utopia Seems Like Less Than One
description: America has always been in love with utopias. The trouble with earthly paradises, however, is that they end up being run by mortals. In John Guare's haunting and humorous two-play series, ''Lydie Breeze,'' which opened last night at the New York Theater Workshop, the utopians are a Civil War nurse, Lydie, and three soldiers whose lives she helped save. She has lured them to Nantucket with a siren song of ''I know an island,'' and the four have set up a commune devoted to the transcendental life.

title: Wagner After the 'Ring'? Why Not?
description: Here was a stacked deck if ever there was one. James Levine and the Met Orchestra have wowed listeners in recent years with concerts at Carnegie Hall, typically showing the players' versatility with symphonic repertory. But as the season winds down, Mr. Levine has turned even those concerts largely to operatic fare, in which this orchestra is unsurpassed in proficiency.

title: Beer and Sausage, but No Accordions, Thank You
description: The sound system just wasn't happening at the Polish National Home, but the strained, suffering speakers added a new dimension to the electronic music that was drilling through them: homeliness. The Beer and Sausage Festival, a three-day experimental event in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, which finished up with a night of electronics on Friday, took place in a building that is normally host to polka dances; Polish food was served up in a side room.

description: NEWS

title: KODAK BUYS OUT REST OF PICTUREVISION FOR $90 MILLION
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photography company, bought the remainder of the closely held PictureVision Inc. for $90 million to strengthen its Internet-based photography business. The company owned 51 percent of PictureVision, based in Dulles, Va., which is the host of the Kodak PhotoNet and the America Online ''You've Got Pictures'' Web sites. The company bought a majority stake in PictureVision in March 1998. Shares of Kodak, based in Rochester, rose $1.125, to $57.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, RABBI THEODORE N.
description: LEWIS-Rabbi Theodore N. Died on May 15, 2000. Beloved father and teacher, grandfather and great grandfather, mourned by his family. Remembered with love by the thousands and thousands of men and women of four generations to whom he taught Torah and Yiddishkeit and the love of Ha - Shem, Zeicher Tsaddik L'Brocha: The memory of the righteous man is a blessing.

description: To golf fans angered by CBS Sports' abrupt departure from the Byron Nelson Classic on Sunday before Jesper Parnevik won on the third sudden-death hole, add one more dissenting voice: the PGA Tour.

title: For Knicks and Heat, It's Poof! A Star Is Born
description: First, Anthony Carter emerged from anonymity with tales of $1,000 playground games to become the unlikely hero of Game 3 for the Miami Heat. Then, in Game 4, Charlie Ward wiped off the criticism that has fallen on him like rain throughout his Knicks career and played savior on Sunday.

title: Emotional Malady Is Linked To Smell
description: The sense of smell, as Marcel Proust and his madeleine made clear, is intimately tied to feeling and memory.

title: AUTONATION TO BE EXCLUSIVE CAR DEALER ON AOL
description: The car seller AutoNation Inc. said yesterday that it would become the exclusive auto retailer on the AutosDirect Web pages of America Online. AOL, based in Dulles, Va., said AutoNation had the country's largest inventory of new and used cars available for online sales. AutoNation, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., owns a chain of 400 car dealerships across the United States and operates a retail Web site. The company said it would maintain the separate Web site after the introduction of the AOL service this fall. Financial terms of the deal between AutoNation and AOL were not disclosed.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; When Excess Water Can Kill a Runner
description: Runners who get dehydrated face obvious dangers, but drinking too much water during a race can also be deadly, according to a study in this month's issue of the Annals of Internal Medicine.

Funeral services at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Tuesday, 11:45 AM. For information, contact 718-853-4000.

description: The union representing striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art has been put on the defensive because 40 percent of the 250 workers in the bargaining unit, according to management's count, have crossed the picket line during the 18-day strike.

description: BEARY-John. Memorial service for John Beary, theatre director, Monday, May 22, 6PM, St. Malachy's Church, 239 W. 49 St.

description: When Millicent Gillespie pulled the 38-page Census 2000 form out of her mailbox, on 171st Street in Jamaica, Queens, she tossed it in the trash.

title: AstraZeneca to Sell a Genetically Engineered Strain of Rice
description: AstraZeneca P.L.C., a giant pharmaceutical company, said today that it would sell a genetically altered strain of ''golden rice'' in the developed world and also help make the technology freely available to the world's poorest countries.

title: Playfully, Tilting at Those Windmills Again
description: It doesn't pay to take American Ballet Theater's ''Don Quixote'' too seriously. That was borne out by performances of the sunny, enjoyably silly production on Friday night and Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Staged by Kevin McKenzie, the company's artistic director, and Susan Jones, a company ballet master, this ''Don Quixote'' embraces the comedy of the 19th-century original by Marius Petipa rather than the darker naturalism of a later version by Alexander Gorsky, though it draws from both. The character of Don Quixote in all his tattered dignity has survived relatively intact along with plot elements from the Cervantes novel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, KENNETH
description: WEISSMAN-Kenneth. My love, my best friend and wonderfully kind step-father to Dan. I miss you utterly and desperately. It's our first wedding anniversary & has been the most interminable year of my life, every day 1000 years. I feel you deep in my bones, in every glance, each unendurable moment. The wind touches your bare skin one more time and you are gone. All my love is with you and I'm sending the pieces of my heart where you are. Audrey Shachnow-Weissma

title: Visionary of the Opera Inspires a Turnaround
description: When Paul Kellogg became the artistic and general director of the New York City Opera in 1996, the company was carrying a $5 million debt, had lost its sense of artistic direction and was coping emotionally with the death from AIDS of its previous director, the conductor Christopher Keene. Revitalizing the City Opera was going to be a formidable challenge. And the greatest impediment to doing so, in fundamental ways, was the New York State Theater itself, the City Opera's home since 1965, which is shared with the New York City Ballet. Rehearsal space and administrative offices had always been woefully inadequate there.

title: Player Pleads Not Guilty In Assault
description: Having finished the 1999 season with a strong performance in Penn State's 24-0 rout of Texas A&M in the Alamo Bowl in December, Rashard Casey was poised for his first full season as the starting quarterback this fall.

title: Mayor Inclined Toward Run, But His Backers Are Nervous
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised more money last night for his Senate campaign, telling a small crowd of supporters at a Manhattan restaurant, ''I'm very much inclined to do this.''

title: Academia and Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: On Left-Handedness, Its Causes and Costs
description: In medieval times, right-handed warriors had a distinct advantage in swordfights. They held their shield with their left hand -- over their heart -- and thus lived to fight another day, and to reproduce, even after they had been stabbed.

title: Battle Over Iroquois Land Claims Escalates
description: The Oneidas want 250,000 acres of rural New York between Syracuse and Utica. The Cayugas are staking claim to a 64,000-acre wishbone at the northern tip of Cayuga Lake. The Senecas are eyeing the Buffalo bedroom community of Grand Island. And the Mohawks, though distracted by a possible Catskills casino, are asking for various islands and parcels straddling the Canadian border.

title: Foreign Affairs; Complete And Utter Nonsense
description: During a visit to Shanghai last year my Times colleague Seth Faison and I interviewed the top managers of one of China's largest food companies, which had been partially privatized. While Seth interviewed the Chinese executives in Chinese, I leafed through the company's annual report. On the first page there were four pictures: the chairman, the vice chairman, the general manager and ''the Communist Party representative'' to the company. At one point I interrupted Seth's interview, pointed to the picture of the Communist Party rep and asked our Chinese hosts: ''Say, what does this guy do?'' They waved at the picture with disdain, as if to say: ''He doesn't do anything. Just ignore him.''

title: Woman Crossing Street Is Killed by a Bus
description: A 60-year-old woman died after being run over by a private bus in Downtown Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: Feeling Crash-Resistant in an S.U.V.
description: Each year for the past decade, the automaker that has offered the biggest lineup of heavyweight sport utility vehicles has won a huge sales and profit windfall. S.U.V.'s now account for some 20 percent of all vehicles sold by Ford (up from 5 percent in 1990), and brisk sales of the company's massive new Excursion have been generating profits of roughly $18,000 per vehicle, several times the margin for passenger cars. By one recent estimate, the Excursion and other jumbo vehicles accounted for most of Ford's record profit of $7.2 billion last year.

description: E*Trade and Wit Capital Team Up for Underwriting

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about the popularity of Commune, a new restaurant on East 22nd Street in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of an MTV news anchor who dined there recently. She is Serena Altschul, not Altshul.

title: Kosovars Changing Canadian Prairie
description: Here in Canada's big sky country, midway between Medicine Hat and the Continental Divide, Blerina Hoxha sat in her apartment and recalled the day one year ago, back in the Balkans, when she stood in the rain at a tent camp, running her finger down a list. Next to her family's name was written ''Canada.''

title: Gil Fates, 86, a TV Producer Of Shows Like 'What's My Line?'
description: Gil Fates, an executive producer of some of the leading television game and panel shows of the 1950's and 60's, died on May 1 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Coalition Urges Easing of Immigration Laws
description: Jack Kemp, the former Republican candidate for vice president, and Henry G. Cisneros, the former secretary of Housing and Urban Development, are leading an unusual coalition of conservatives and liberals that is beginning a major campaign to persuade Congress to ease the nation's immigration laws.

title: Margin Credit Fell in April
description: A slide in technology shares prompted investors to cut the amount they borrowed last month for share purchases by $27 billion, or 9.6 percent.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Payback for those who sold the bull market short: missing out on high-technology's rapid descent.
description: PITY the short-sellers. Practically driven to extinction by a bull market run, they should be reveling now that many of the stocks they long considered overvalued have fallen sharply. But many of them have been left out of this market move, too.

title: COINMACH LAUNDRY TO BE BOUGHT BY INVESTMENT FIRM
description: The Coinmach Laundry Corporation, the nation's largest provider of coin-operated laundry machines to apartment buildings and dormitories, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by the privately held investment firm GTCR Golden Rauner L.L.C. for $14.25 a share, a total of $188 million. Coinmach's stock rose $5.6875, or 71 percent, to $13.6875, on Nasdaq. Coinmach, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., had revenue of $505.3 million last year. It expects the buyout deal to close in July. The transaction follows GTCR's failed bid to buy Coinmach for $13 a share, or $171.6 million. GTCR, which is based in New York, said in February that it had withdrawn its original offer when it could not reach an agreement with Coinmach.

title: Have a Child, and Experience the Wage Gap
description: Progress for working parents, it seems, can only come drip by drop. The latest in incremental improvements came earlier this month, when President Clinton signed an executive order banning discrimination against parents in the federal workplace; it is now illegal to deny jobs or promotions to people because they have obligations to children at home. Bruce Reed, the president's chief domestic policy adviser, said the White House wanted to ''send a clear signal to employers that there is nothing wrong with being a parent.''

title: ANOTHER BID FROM HUNT
description: The privately owned Hunt Oil Company of Dallas has made a friendly $328 million cash bid for the Newport Petroleum Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, and will assume $190 million of Newport's debt. At 5.50 Canadian dollars a share, or about $3.85, the offer is 10 percent above Newport's closing price on the Toronto Stock Exchange last Friday. Hunt has been trying to expand its Canadian subsidiary, which is based in Calgary, and last month lost a hostile bid for Ulster Petroleums Ltd. of Calgary to Anderson Exploration Ltd. Timothy Pritchard

title: Life Imitating Art Imitating Life in a Jamaican Movie
description: The sound of helicopters flying over the Kingston ghettos was not the kind of buzz the producers of ''Third World Cop'' had in mind before this movie's hometown opening here last summer. But with life intimidating art, the premiere of this violent tale about a hardened police officer named Capone who is fighting ghetto gunrunners, was postponed for two months while the police and soldiers engaged in deadly battles against heavily armed gangs.

title: U.S. Study Offers Grim Prognosis for Lasting Peace in Balkans
description: On the eve of a Senate vote to set a deadline for withdrawing American troops from Kosovo, a General Accounting Office report released today said that prospects for lasting peace in Kosovo, Bosnia and other parts of the Balkans remained bleak and warned of the prospect of instability and even renewed violence.

title: Miller's Toughest Routine Might Be Her Comeback
description: She began nosing around the gym in Oklahoma City last fall, a day here, a day there, nothing that would put any real strain on her muscles or her new lifestyle. Shannon Miller had retired after the 1996 Summer Games, her career secure as the most successful American gymnast, with seven Olympic medals, two of them gold. She was married now, attending college. She was 23 in a sport that had come to treat maturity as an impediment, where the arrival of breasts and hips was an occurrence as unfortunate as a broken ankle.

title: Federal Tax Fraud Trial of 2 Brothers Opens
description: On the first day of the federal government's tax fraud trial of two well-known Westchester brothers, most of the opening events hinged today on a matter outside the scope of the case: Albert J. Pirro Jr.'s fathering of an Indiana teenager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, MARGARET V.
description: CONNOLLY-Margaret V. On May 14, 2000 at age 55. Loving mother of Craig, Alexa, Christian and Samantha Averill. Dear sister of Maureen Stenzel, Virginia Whelan, Helen Donohue, Claudia Johnson, Frances Kaschel and Christina Connolly. Beloved friend and companion to Edward Averill. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, PAUL N.
description: BANKS-Paul N. On May 10, 2000, at his home in New York, after a short illness. Pioneer in the field of book and library preservation, a founding member of the American Institute of Conservation and president 1978-80. Born in California, graduate of Carnegie-Mellon University. Book designer, The Viking Press, New York, before being invited to the Newberry Library, Chicago, as conservator (1964-81). One of an international team of experts called to Florence to salvage books and manuscripts after the 1966 flood. Founder and director of the conservation/preservation program at the School of Library Service, Columbia University, he transferred the program to the University of Texas, Austin, in 1991. After retirement in 1996, he was consultant to the Library of Congress and the national Archives. Devoted partner of the late Dan Warshaw. He will be greatly missed by colleagues, students and many loving friends in Austin and New York. Memorial service to be announced.

Both companies are real estate investment trusts. Bradley's shares rose $2.75 each, to $21.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
