On Sept. 24, Formula One drivers from 11 countries will compete in the United States Grand Prix, on a new 13-turn road-racing course cut into the infield at the venerable speedway.

title: Mining Company Says Chief Will Leave His Post in July
description: Anglo American P.L.C., the world's largest mining company, announced today that Julian Ogilvie Thompson, the last of a generation of managers who dominated the South African-led company during and beyond the apartheid era, would step down as chief executive in July.

title: Big Jury Award Against Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies must pay the Canadian investor Henryk de Kwiatkowski $111.5 million for failing to warn him of the risks of foreign currency speculation, a federal jury found yesterday.

title: Hewlett Posts 6.5% Increase In Earnings for 2nd Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported fiscal second-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street estimates. The company cited strong sales of personal computers and Unix servers used on corporate networks and the Internet.

title: Herbert Cahoon, 82, Curator at Morgan Library
description: Herbert T. F. Cahoon, a curator who presided over the collection of literary and historical manuscripts at the Morgan Library for 35 years, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICCONE, DANTE N.
description: PICCONE-Dante N., on May 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee: Bocker). Loving father of Stephen, Catherine, Nancy, Elizabeth, Mary, Theodore, James and John. Devoted grandfather of 23 grandchildren. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Mass on Friday 10AM at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye, New York.

title: Investigators in Los Alamos To Weigh Decision to Burn
description: A team of investigators has arrived in this fire-stricken region to help determine whether the National Park Service acted responsibly when it ignited a blaze that is still burning out of control in the tinder-dry hillsides and canyons here.

title: E.P.A. to Issue Tougher Rules On Diesel Fuel
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans on Wednesday to announce new pollution-control rules that would cut truck and bus emissions drastically, in part through a 97 percent reduction in the sulfur content of diesel fuel over the next 10 years.

title: BUS OPERATOR DEFERS DEBT PAYMENTS
description: The operator of North America's largest fleet of school and intercity buses, Laidlaw Inc. of Burlington, Ontario, has deferred semiannual payments of $23 million on three series of debentures as it continues to negotiate new agreements with creditors. Laidlaw said its operating companies, including Greyhound Lines, were not affected. Timothy Pritchard

title: Lack of I.O.C. Ethics Is Business as Usual
description: Having declared him innocent beforehand, the International Olympic Committee set about investigating excessive travel privileges for one of its delegates, Kevan Gosper of Australia, in the Salt Lake City bribery scandal. To no one's surprise, Gosper was cleared of wrongdoing on Monday. You usually have to be the president of Indiana University to conduct an investigation as feeble as an I.O.C. inquiry.

title: The Pre-Freudian Freud: Physician, Analyze Thyself
description: ''Young Dr. Freud'' begins in 1938, with Old Dr. Freud boarding a train from Vienna to London. ''Of all the wise men of his day,'' an unseen narrator intones, ''he was perhaps the least loved, even by himself.'' Axel Corti's film, made for Austrian television in 1976 and opening today at the Film Forum, arrives on these shores at a moment when Freud may be less loved than at any time since his arrival, in 1909, to give a series of lectures. (''They don't know it,'' he is supposed to have remarked to Jung, surveying the crowd waiting to greet him at the dock, ''but I'm bringing them the plague.'')

title: Coach Bob Knight Should Be Ex-Coach
description: To the Editor:

title: Tread Dread: Solving The Mystery of Tires
description: IT is common to feel foolish at the tire store. What should you ask for? Should you stay with the kind of tire that came with the car, or try something different, maybe sportier? Is it O.K. to go for low-cost tires, or do you sacrifice safety and handling? Can buying top-of-the-line tires turn your station wagon into a roadster?

title: Agencies Revamp, Absorb and Acquire
description: Several agencies are being reorganized through mergers and acquisitions.

title: Knicks and Heat Face the Twilight Zone
description: It is hard to condense all the pugnacious behavior, league-mandated suspensions, venomous talk and late-game drama that are the Knicks versus the Miami Heat into one neat package. But if it were necessary to capsulize this annual scrum, it would be done this way: Game 5.

title: Discovering the Finer Side of Rum
description: A FELLOW on the Internet says that he has collected 3,688 different rum labels from 81 countries. If he's correct (and he offers to show his collection to anyone interested), then there are probably more rums than there are brands of beer.

title: All of the Flavor, None of the Fuss
description: IT will disappoint some cooks on sight, for it looks like mayonnaise. It will trouble gardeners, who will not understand how a noble artichoke could be reduced to something with so little visible remains. It will be pooh-poohed by purists who never buy anything in a jar.

title: Shorter Presidential Term Gains in France
description: Since the French Revolution, France has remodeled its Constitution four times. Now it looks as if the Fifth Republic, 42 years old, may soon be refashioned too.

title: After 2 Days, Jury Selection Ends In Pirro Brothers Tax Fraud Case
description: After two days of legal maneuvering, jury selection in the tax fraud trial of Albert J. Pirro Jr., the prominent Westchester lawyer, ended today, clearing the way for opening arguments to begin on Wednesday.

title: No Tacos? No Burritos? And This Is a Mexican Place?
description: WHAT is a Mexican restaurant? Thankfully, in New York expectations have evolved to the point where this question is no longer easy to answer. From humble taquerias with just a few inexpensive dishes to fancy restaurants with ambitious, creative menus, Mexican restaurants are no longer beholden simply to cliches of burritos and margaritas. And now comes Casa Mexicana, maybe the first Mexican restaurant in New York that owes as much to hip downtown Manhattan as to Mexico City.

title: Panel Discussion Canceled
description: A panel discussion on the New York City Buildings Department scheduled for tomorrow evening, described in an article in the Real Estate section on Sunday, has been canceled. All five of the department's borough superintendents were to have taken part in the discussion, sponsored by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. The organizer, Steven Zirinsky, and a spokeswoman for the agency, Ilyse Fink, said scheduling conflicts had caused the cancellation.

title: Loves Fights. And Cliches.
description: I have a T-shirt framed outside my office, saying, ''You let up, you lose.'' I bought it in a barroom in my early days at Lycos. I was meeting at a hotel with some investment bankers and there was a guy playing pool and wearing this shirt. After a bit of haggling, I was able to talk the shirt off his back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, NINA HOWELL
description: STARR-Nina Howell, photographer, 97, May 14, at home in Hamden, CT. Widow of Nathan Comfort Starr, survived by daughters Margot Starr Kernan, Penelope Comfort Starr, 9 grandchildren, 4 great-grandchildren. Two children, Lt. Col. William John Starr and Lisa Starr Rudd predeceased her. Funeral services at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, (71st Street), Friday, May 19, 11:00a.m.

title: In Jail for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Game of Nerves, With No Real Winners
description: THIS is the city, Los Angeles, California. A sprawling urban oasis in a coastal desert, 465 square miles of stop-and-go freeways and clogged surface streets, of lane-changers and speed demons, secret shortcuts and rampant sport utility vehicles. It's easy to feel overwhelmed. I should know. I drive a car.

title: Love Bug May Have Over 40 Authors
description: 'Love Bug' May Have Over 40 Authors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMEL, PEARL
description: SEMEL-Pearl, 85. Beloved wife of the late David, devoted mother of Martin Semel, Sharon Kalvert and Cindy Linder, and mother-in-law of Paula Semel, Michael Kalvert and Steve Linder, cherished grandmother of Michael, Alissa and David and great-grandmother of Zachary, Kate and Rachel. Service Thursday, May 18, 10 AM, at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Heat Loses Grip on the Fans
description: Before the Miami Heat began its series with the Knicks, Heat management, apparently weary of having its home-court advantage diluted by supporters of other teams, offered free Heat clothing in exchange for any opponent's merchandise.

title: Forget Microchips: Simple Things Make Driving Safer
description: SOMEDAY, cars might come equipped with automatic pilots that let them safely follow one another bumper to bumper at 60 miles an hour. They might have transmitters that send a signal to the police whenever there is an accident, giving location and severity of impact. Highways might have sensors that instantaneously measure traffic speed and spot areas of congestion simply by tracing patterns of cellular-phone use.

title: Delta joins the war of the carry-on bag by enlarging its overhead bins.
description: THE balance has shifted significantly again in the airline industry's carry-on bag wars. Delta Air Lines, the world's largest carrier, is retrofitting overhead bins in most of its airplanes to allow more storage for passengers' carry-on bags.

title: Young Audience Spends New Money at Auction
description: Soaring prices and persistent bidding at Christie's sale of contemporary art last night proved how few good works are on the market these days and how much money people have to spend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARACHAN, EVELYN
description: SARACHAN-Evelyn. Of Rochester, New York. Beautiful, stylish, spirited wife of the late, great, Judge Goodman A. Sarachan; mother of Donna and Martin Lawrence and Richard H. Sarachan of Rochester, and Niki Singer and Michael Sheets of New York City; grandmother of Julie Lawrence and Wlodzimierz Tomczyk and Romaine and Nicholas Sheets. Happy memories of her optimism and cheerfulness will be with us always.

title: Lovable Sore Thumb In Bedford Hills' Eye
description: THE commuter parking lots at the Bedford Hills train station are lease-to-lease with cars right out of the promised land -- you know, the ones that can climb mountains, ford streams, ferry soccer leagues, shake traffic, repel mud and after all that drop off a couple of beautiful people at the Plaza.

title: Riley Makes Remark, Then Offers Apology
description: During his post-practice news conference today, Coach Pat Riley was asked how the Heat might make Miami fans out of some of the transplanted New Yorkers in South Florida who root loudly for the Knicks.

title: Social Security Debate Framed in Generalities
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has reignited the debate over the future of Social Security and whether it is a good idea to allow individuals to invest some of their payroll taxes in the stock market.

title: Gore Retreats From Earlier Signal of Support for Medical Use of Marijuana
description: As anyone who has watched Al Gore over the years knows, some of his positions on various topics have a way of evolving. As the vice president himself has acknowledged, this has been true on abortion and gun control.

title: An Un-Brooklyn Crime; Army Officer Charged in Killings in Land Fraud
description: Capt. John Lau of the United States Army, an officer with the South European Task Force stationed in Italy, left behind his wife, three young children and the busy affairs of his foreign posting to make a brisk two-day trip home to New York four years ago.

title: Barak Focus Is Long View
description: The morning after Palestinian rioting disintegrated into fierce gunfire, many Israeli and even some Palestinian political analysts were surprised to find themselves crediting Prime Minister Ehud Barak with defusing a potential political, diplomatic and military crisis.

title: NEOFORMA.COM MAY CANCEL $2.72 BILLION BUYOUT
description: Neoforma.com Inc., which operates an online marketplace for medical equipment, said yesterday that it was in talks about ending its $2.72 billion buyout offer for the Eclipsys Corporation and Healthvision Inc. Since Neoforma announced the deal at the end of March, the stock of the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has plunged to under $10 from $30. The shares rose slightly yesterday, gaining 72 cents, to $9.875 each, in Nasdaq trading. Eclipsys, based in Delray Beach, Fla., has been named in two shareholder lawsuits that contend Neoforma's offer was too low. Eclipsys makes software for managing medical payments and patient information. Healthvision, based in Irving, Tex., helps local health care organizations set up Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLUGER, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: SCHLUGER-Joseph, M.D. The Board of Directors, volunteers and staff of the New York Heart Association mourn the passing of Joseph Schluger, M.D., former Board President. Through his dedication and commitment, he helped establish the New York Heart Association as a major force in addressing the health needs of all New Yorkers, particularly in the area of emergency cardiovascular care. We extend our sincere condolences to Charlotte and his entire family. Steven W. Duff Jonathan L. Halperin, M.D. Morgan B. Stark Michael L. Weamer

title: A Confessor Who Hears It All
description: Before I took this job I was a Nasdaq trader, and before that I was in law enforcement. I came here because I wanted to be more involved in helping people. I listen to their hardships and help them work out a plan so that they don't end up losing everything. I show them that there's hope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, ELBERT
description: DUNCAN-Elbert. St. John's in the Village mourns the death of its beloved friend and Sexton, Elbert Duncan, who faithfully and lovingly served this church and its people for more than 20 years. Solemn funeral Eucharist on Thursday, May 18, at 7:30 PM, St John's in the Village Episcopal Church, entrance at 222 W. 11th St, Manhattan.

title: Gore Has Not Bought Stocks for Decades
description: When E. F. Hutton talks, Al Gore doesn't listen.

title: Judging Bush on the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE RISES HINTED
description: The Federal Reserve adopted a more aggressive stance today in its fight against inflation, voting to push short-term interest rates up by half a percentage point to try to slow the headlong pace of economic growth.

title: U.S. Seeks Sweeping Overhaul To Fix Peacekeeping by U.N.
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, just back from an extended peace mission in Africa, called today for a sweeping overhaul of the United Nations peacekeeping operations and for more money from member nations to make the operations effective.

title: Gore's National Security Advisers Assemble as Part of a Government-in-Waiting
description: Vice President Al Gore has assembled a large team of foreign policy advisers whose members could form the national security nucleus of a Gore administration.

title: Tough Veteran Wing Turns Flyers Around
description: The Philadelphia Flyers' No. 1 center, Eric Lindros, is out indefinitely with a series of career-threatening concussions. Their No. 2 center, Keith Primeau, started a first-period fistfight tonight with Randy McKay exactly a week after suffering a concussion himself against the Penguins. Philadelphia's No. 3 center, Daymond Langkow, is going to be tested for a concussion Wednesday morning after absorbing a vicious open-ice hit by Scott Stevens in the third period. Undaunted, it was the Flyers' 36-year-old right wing who dazed the Devils tonight, 4-3, in one of the fiercest playoff games in recent memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, THEODORE N., RABBI
description: LEWIS-Theodore N., Rabbi. The New York Board of Rabbis mourns the death of its distinguished Past President, Rabbi Theodore Lewis, and extends its sincere condolences to his family, loved ones, and many students and former congregants. Rabbi Marc Gellman, Pres. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal Exec VP Armand Lindenbaum, Pres., Advisory Council

title: A Mix for WB
description: In some respects it seems as if the WB network would like to have its cake and eat it, too.

title: Cruiserheads, and the Big, Bare Bruisers They Love
description: SOME vehicles beget cultlike followings: the Toyota Land Cruiser, for example. To a generation of explorers, adventurers, mercenaries and photojournalists -- real and would-be -- this is the object of their desire. Not the curvy, comfortable and expensive models of the last decade, but the heavy, ungraceful, boxy bruisers imported to the United States between 1958 and 1990.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New Brasserie District

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZAN, MICHEL
description: KAZAN-Michel. May 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Maria, devoted father of Michelle, Jacqueline, Michel, Roman and Zofia, cherished grandfather and great grandfather, loving brother of Simone. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Wednesday and Thursday 6-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, May 19, at 10 A.M., St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DAVID
description: WILLIAMS-David. The Board of Directors, staff, & volunteers of God's Love We Deliver are saddened by the loss of David Williams, dearly loved father of Vaughn C. Williams, our valued Board member. As a lawyer and then as both a state and federal judge, he was a champion for justice his entire life & enriched the lives of those who knew him. Through his dedication to the principle of equal justice for all, he made a difference in the lives of thousands of Americans throughout his career. We extend our deepest condolences to Vaughn & the entire Williams family, as well as his many friends & colleagues.

title: MORE SURGERY FOR BURRELL
description: Nets forward Scott Burrell underwent surgery for the third time in three weeks yesterday when Dr. Michael Kelly, the team's orthopedist, performed arthroscopic surgery on his right knee. Burrell had a torn lateral meniscus repaired and loose particles removed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEMAN, H. EDWARD, JR.
description: ALLEMAN-H. Edward, Jr. A memorial service will be held today, 2:30 PM, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th St,

title: New Beauty Displays A Shrewd Awakening
description: Peter Martins's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' for the New York City Ballet has a fairy-tale splendor. Happily, this staging, which continues throughout the week at the New York State Theater, does not depend only on the ballerina in the title role.

title: The Flyers Get Angry, And Then Get Even
description: Capitalizing on defensive mistakes by the Devils, the Flyers extinguished a two-goal deficit in a three-minute span tonight and scored a 4-3 triumph over the Devils to even the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference finals at one game apiece.

title: School Custodian Charged in Boy's Abuse
description: A 9-year-old boy was sexually abused by a custodian at Public School 127 in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: More Speed? Power? Now Drivers Can Have It Their Way
description: ONE winter several years ago, Jim Conforti of Bonneville, Utah, had trouble getting his BMW 325i to start. At an altitude of 4,000 feet, the pre-programmed fuel mixture flooded the car's spark plugs when temperatures hovered near 32 degrees.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial in Saturday's Times misidentified Bishop Edward M. Egan as having been archbishop of the archdiocese of Bridgeport. He was bishop of the diocese of Bridgeport.

title: U.S. Will Oppose World Bank Loans to Iran
description: The Clinton administration will oppose the first World Bank loans offered to Iran in seven years, even though Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright declared some easing of sanctions recently, officials said today.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Near-Carbuncle, Not 'Just a Lump'

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Child Care In Military Is Praised As a Model
description: The military has so improved its child care system in the past decade that it has become a model for state and national programs, according to a study released today.

title: SCIENTIFIC GAMES AND AUTOTOTE CONFIRM MERGER TALKS
description: The Scientific Games Holdings Corporation, the biggest maker of scratch-off lottery tickets in the United States, said it was discussing a merger with the Autotote Corporation. Scientific Games, based in Alpharetta, Ga., said an agreement had not been reached. Autotote, which makes computerized wagering systems for greyhound and horse tracks, off-track betting centers and lotteries, confirmed the talks in a separate statement. Shares of New York-based Autotote rose 62.5 cents, to $3.75 each, in American Stock Exchange trading. Scientific Games rose 18.75 cents, to $18, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Putting the Clamps on Consumers Accustomed to Borrowing Freely
description: Consumers will quickly begin to feel the pinch of the Federal Reserve's half-point rate increase as borrowing -- from home equity loans to car and truck financing to credit cards -- becomes more expensive. Rates on fixed-rate mortgages, however, have already climbed and may even retreat some from their current level of about 8.5 percent, specialists said.

title: Even in the Barn, Fusaichi Pegasus Stands Apart
description: Stall 40 in Barn E at Pimlico Race Course is reserved every year for the winner of the Kentucky Derby, making it the royal stall for horses arriving for the Preakness, the second race of the Triple Crown. But five days before the 125th Preakness, Stall 40 was empty, with advance notice that it will not be the home of this year's Derby winner, Fusaichi Pegasus.

title: Remember When $29 Shocked . . .
description: IN bringing his chain of meateries from Dallas to Midtown Manhattan, Terry White, the executive chef at Del Frisco's, introduced a special menu item just for New Yorkers.

title: The Ballad of 'Guitar Man' in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: On Land, Sea or Bun, These Babies Move
description: IF you are hauling a lawn mower to the repair shop, a pickup truck or minivan will do. But if you are moving the space shuttle, you need something much more specialized.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Moment
description: In her first outing as a candidate for elective office, Hillary Rodham Clinton has demonstrated a firm grasp of a basic rule of politics. That is the one about never interfering when your opponent is being engulfed with bad news. Indeed, Mrs. Clinton has campaigned with such quiet decorum during Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's travails that the public may be tempted to overlook the accomplishment represented by her formal nomination yesterday.

title: House Backs Bill To Ban Net Fees
description: The House tried to put to rest today longstanding Internet rumors of pending e-mail taxes, unanimously endorsing a bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access.

title: What's the Speed Limit? What Would You Like It to Be?
description: MARIO ANDRETTI won't give an exact number. When pressed, the race-car-driving legend will reluctantly admit that on some deserted roads, he has driven his bright yellow Lamborghini Diablo nearly three times as fast as the posted speed limit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, HELEN
description: EPSTEIN-Helen. On May 15, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Eva and Irving Epstein. Loving sister of Daniel and the late Shirlee. Services Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours thursday 6-9PM.

title: Homage to 'Great Leader'?Summit Protocol Makes Seoul Uneasy
description: SEOUL  South Korean officials face a contentious problem when it comes to planning President Kim Dae Jung's visit to North Korea next month for the first such summit talks ever.

title: He's Turning Seattle Into His Kind of Town
description: No, notwithstanding a joke making the rounds here, Seattle has not changed its name to Allentown. Not yet, anyway.

title: F.A.A. Tape Shows Controllers Searching for EgyptAir Flight
description: The last conversation between the crew of EgyptAir Flight 990 and air traffic controllers was numbingly routine, a transcript released today by the Federal Aviation Administration shows. But after the Boeing 767 disappeared from radar, controllers in New York took the unusual step of asking an Air France jet to detour, to see if its crew could hear an emergency signal or spot a plane in the water.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Everett, Wash.

title: Making Sure Brand-New Teachers Know Technology
An Evening of Tributes to Daniel Patrick Moynihan
description: Since the day 18 months ago when he announced he would not seek a fifth term in the United States Senate, Daniel Patrick Moynihan seemed to yield the spotlight, turning it over to newer names like Schumer and Clinton.

title: ONLINE AUCTION MERGER
description: Under challenge from eBay Inc. in Europe's Internet auction business, Britain's biggest online auctioneer QXL P.L.C. agreed to buy Ricardo.de A.G., a German rival, for $1 billion in stock, a premium of 27 percent. The London-based combination will be known as QXLricardo P.L.C. and will have 1.3 million members. EBay already sells more goods in Europe than the British and German companies combined. Alan Cowell

title: Scientist Dies At South Pole Research Site
description: An Australian astrophysicist died suddenly of undetermined causes Friday at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station, a research center operated by the National Science Foundation, and his body must remain there until the Southern winter ends in October. It was only the third death at the pole in nearly 35 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINNEGAN, LAWRENCE J., JR.
description: FINNEGAN-Lawrence J., Jr. One year ago, you were taken from family and friends who miss you very much and think of you often. I especially miss you more than words can describe. My heart aches without you and I cherish my memories of us. I miss you every day and will love you forever. You are always in my heart. Forever yours. Your loving wife, Jackie

title: Judging Bush on the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: With Senate Rival Uncertain, Party Nominates Mrs. Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton tonight accepted the nomination of the New York State Democratic Party for United States senator, plunging into a race shrouded in confusion with a speech that reflected her uncertain political reality: she still did not know if her opponent this fall would be Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: In the Pursuit of Cybercriminals, Real Detectives Rely on Amateurs
description: Within hours after a destructive computer program began circulating this month, borne by an e-mail message marked ''I Love You,'' a handful of high-tech detectives around the globe leaped into action.

title: Stockholders Angrily Assail BMW's Stewardship of Rover
description: A week after BMW A.G. agreed to pay a British group more than $750 million to take over its money-losing Rover subsidiary, angry investors accused the German automaker's top management today of amateurism, arrogance, bad judgment and deceptive statements.

title: THE CHEF; Wylie Dufresne
description: AT any given time, there are dozens of sauces, oils, purees and stocks in my storage bins and walk-in refrigerator. Like most chefs, I'm always trying to find new uses for these flavoring agents. Most of these experiments never make it into the dining room. But sometimes, I get lucky and create something memorable. My chive-flavored mashed potatoes are one example.

title: Fish With Flourishes, and a Rink-Side Seat
description: DINNER at the freshly renovated Sea Grill starts with a bang. No sooner have you taken your seat than a team of waiters approaches, bearing clear, cylindrical glasses filled with a white substance. On my first visit to the restaurant, I assumed they were votive candles, until the waiters placed little spoons on the table and, looking more closely, I saw a small dollop of caviar in the glass.

title: After a Century of Talking, Tax Plan Has a Familiar Ring
description: In 1898, Congress approved an excise tax on a luxury item of the day, the telephone, to help pay for the Spanish-American War. And except for three tax-free hiatuses, it has been on the books since then.

title: Eritrean Town Is Empty After Ethiopians Take Control
description: This town apparently picked up and fled in a hurry. Someone even left behind an artificial leg that lay on the main street today along with school books and the empty ration tins of a new occupying army.

title: MANAGEMENT: Return of the Native Executive; Many Repatriations Fail, at Huge Cost to Companies
description: At the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998, Scott Fedje, an art director for a Fortune 500 apparel manufacturer, returned to his company's headquarters in the northwestern United States from a five-year stint in Hong Kong. Even though he got a promotion and a pay increase as a reward for his overseas performance, Mr. Fedje resigned a few months later to take a job with a design-consulting firm in San Francisco.

title: DEAL TO BUY ARCO PIPE LINE UNIT IS AMENDED BY $36 MILLION
description: The Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Company said yesterday that it amended its agreement to buy the Arco Pipe Line Company from BP Amoco L.P., lowering the purchase price by $36.5 million, to $318.5 million. Under the new pact, BP Amoco would retain its interest in the refined petroleum products pipeline of the Seaway Pipeline Company. BP Amoco was forced to sell Seaway assets as part of the Federal Trade Commission's approval on April 13 of the $27.1 billion acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company. Under the amended agreement, Texas Eastern would acquire Arco's interest in the Seaway crude pipeline from Freeport, Tex., to Cushing, Okla. The Seaway system was a partnership between Arco Pipe Line and a subsidiary of the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: New Jersey Democratic Candidates for Senate Clash on Gun Control and Taxes
description: New Jersey's two Democratic candidates for the United States Senate clashed over gun control, national security and taxes tonight during their third debate, as each candidate tried to portray himself as the stronger champion of working families and the elderly.

title: 3M Says It Will Stop Making Scotchgard
description: The 3M Company, the giant consumer products company, said today that it would stop making many of its well-known Scotchgard products after tests showed that the chemical compounds used to make the products linger in the environment and in humans for years.

title: Dominicans Stay Tuned To Voting At Home
description: In cafes, on street corners and in front of newsstands, many people in Washington Heights have been heatedly talking for weeks about the tactics of the presidential campaign and the merits of the candidates. But in their rapid-fire Spanish, they aren't speaking of Al Gore or George W. Bush. Instead, they intone the names Balaguer, Mejia and Medina, the three men seeking the presidency of the Dominican Republic.

title: Mommy-Mobiles Get A Macho Makeover
description: SUBURBAN cowboys, look out. The revved-up interloper in the next parking space may be a minivan.

title: MANAGEMENT SHAKE-UP AT VARIG
description: Brazil's largest airline, Varig, replaced its president in a shake-up intended to return the carrier to profitability. It has lost money in three of the past four years. The new president, Osires Silva, a member of Varig's board, replaced Fernando Pinto, who cut costs and jobs. The carrier still lost $54 million last year. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCHMAN, EVELYN SUGARMAN
description: TUCHMAN-Evelyn Sugarman. 82, May 15,2000. Loving wife of the late Jack Tuchman, mother extraordinaire of Gaye and Phyllis. Adoring grandmother of Ethan. Services 11:00 AM, Thursday, May 18, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY at Sugarman Family Circle section.

title: Sante Kimes Chastised by Judge Over Contacts With News Media
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday threatened to handcuff Sante Kimes if she again tried to get in touch with the news media. The jury in Mrs. Kimes's murder trial, meanwhile, did not reach a verdict after a second day of deliberations.

title: Imitations of 'West Wing'
description: In this season's final episode of ''West Wing,'' President Josiah Bartlet (played by Martin Sheen) will deal tonight with a downed pilot in Iraq, a balky space shuttle and a battle with Congress over campaign finance reform. As it happens, the last of these issues is unfolding in the real Washington this week, in almost the same way. But while President Bartlet is bravely trying to reshape the Federal Election Commission and ban soft money, President Clinton (played by himself) and the real Democrats are battling only half-heartedly for reform.

title: Review of Subsidies For Exports Sought
description: The Treasury Secretary, Lawrence Summers, called today for major industrialized countries to decide whether some export subsidies go against a 22-year-old agreement aimed at preventing unfair international competition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, ROWENNA L. WIGHT
description: WHITE-Rowenna L. Wight. 20th birthday, 5/17/80-9/2/98. Born in New York; died in Nova Scotia. Remembered in China as the most beautiful Rows. By her mothe

title: Al Hirschfeld Sues Gallery, Asserting It Cheated Him
description: Al Hirschfeld, the artist whose witty caricatures of stage and screen stars long ago made the leap from newspaper illustration to art displayed by museums, has dismissed his longtime dealer, Margo Feiden, and yesterday took her and Margo Feiden Galleries to court. His suit, filed in state supreme court in Manhattan, accuses Ms. Feiden of cheating him in the buying and selling of his work; of refusing to return drawings that belong to him; of breach of contract; and of otherwise breaching her fiduciary duty.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Printer Is Moving, to Aid Both Itself and Landlord
description: Astoria Graphics is a financial and commercial printing company that has been operating in buildings owned by Trinity Church Real Estate for the last 50 or so years. And it will continue to do so as a result of an unusual deal under which it gave up space at an extraordinarily favorable rental rate in one building in return for space in another Trinity location at a higher, but still favorable, rate.

title: A Highway Phobic Meets Her Demon: Merging Traffic
description: LIKE the gold rush past and present -- the open road is part of the mythology of California. Thus it was with mortal terror that I, a 45-year-old highway phobic, received the news that we would be moving to the San Francisco Bay Area, a place where highways are hoisted in midair and quake-ridden bridges collapse on national television.

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: Caught Between Payday and Principle
description: When she was a securities broker in Florida for the NationsBank Corporation in the early 1990's, Catherine Hovis knew that the elderly clients she was selling mutual funds to did not have the financial or emotional means to take on risky investments. One couple, both in their 70's, were living on Social Security and wanted something as safe as a certificate of deposit but with a better return -- maybe 7 to 8 percent.

title: In Automobilia, a Yearning for the Days of Youth
description: LEILA DUNBAR remembers the family outing to search for old tin automotive signs at the antiques fair in Brimfield, Mass. It was 1973, and she was 12. ''We slept in a borrowed van, right on the side of Route 20, the tractor-trailers rolling by and causing the van to sway all night,'' she said.

title: Sancerre for a Summer's Day

title: In Boom Times, the Have-Nots Influence the Dominican Vote
description: Dominicans turned out in large numbers on Tuesday to elect a president -- either one who would build on the current government's policy of economic liberalization or one who wants to reconsider some of the changes to help the poor and rural residents who say the boom years have overlooked them.

Ann McDonald, dear sister of Malcolm Patrick Austin, and adored wife of the late Robert J. McDonald. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., on Friday, May 19, 2-5 PM, Saturday, May 20, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and Monday, May 22, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St. and Lexington Ave., on Tuesday, May 23, 10 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Legal Aid Society, Columbia Law School, or New Yorkers for Children.

Bush's proposal to let workers invest some of their Social Security taxes, Vice President Al Gore asserted yesterday that the plan would hurt the very baby boomers it is intended to help by placing their retirement savings at the mercy of ruthless and whimsical markets.

title: Cars

Lucent said it received a $175 million contract from Hughes Tele.com of India to build a high-speed phone network in India.

The new Cadillac Seville that had cruised so majestically down the Champs-Elysees the night before now crept tentatively through the narrow, deserted streets while the driver rehearsed his supplicative refrain: ''Excusez-moi de vous deranger, Monsieur; ou est la rue. . . . ?''

title: COUNTRYWIDE SOFTENS STANCE ON POSSIBLE TAKEOVER BIDS
description: Shares of Countrywide Credit Industries rose sharply yesterday after its chief executive said in a trade publication that the company would listen to takeover offers. The stock of the company -- the largest publicly traded mortgage lender in the United States -- rose $6.0625 a share, to $33.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The chairman and chief executive, Angelo Mozilo, was quoted yesterday in The American Banker as saying remaining independent was no longer a sacred tenet. Mr. Mozilo did not specifically say, however, that Countrywide was on the block and he would not talk about possible suitors or prices. Countrywide is based in Calabasas, Calif.

title: Nucor to Buy Back Stock

The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 6 percent of Nucor's outstanding shares. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Shares of Nucor, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., were up 75 cents today at $42.6875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pistachios are arrayed in small containers on the bakery counter, where ice cream ($6 to $8 a portion), fruit tarts ($6), filled beignets ($6 for six) and layered coupes of cream, cake, jelly and mousse ($7 to $8) are assembled a la minute -- in two to four minutes -- while you wait.

title: SCHLUMBERGER BUYS THE ASSETS OF CELLNET DATA SYSTEMS
description: Schlumberger Ltd., an oil-service company that is expanding into meter-reading and electronic-commerce technologies, said yesterday that it had bought the assets of the wireless-network provider CellNet Data Systems Inc. for about $117 million in cash. The company will also assume $118 million in debt. Schlumberger, whose meters measure heat, water and electricity use, will use CellNet's network to read information from those meters. It already uses CellNet, which filed for federal bankruptcy protection in February, as a contractor for that purpose. Schlumberger, which is based in New York, also makes ''smart'' cards that improve the security of banking and e-commerce transactions.

title: Sniffing Around New Cars for the Sweet Smell That Sells
description: FOR many car buyers, the aroma of a new car can be a deal breaker. New car smell -- an amalgam of odors from the rubber, leather, cloth, plastic and chemicals used in making the car -- can draw buyers to a car the way an animal is drawn to its kin. Or it can turn them off. If the smell reminds them of a wicked aunt's old Buick or gives them the sense that they are losing brain cells from the chemicals, they may change their buying decision.

title: National News Briefs; Fresh Leadership at 110 Livingston
description: The New York City Board of Education made the only sensible call yesterday when it promoted Harold Levy from interim chancellor to permanent chancellor. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani had little choice but to go along with the decision. With a majority of the board supporting the interim chancellor, City Hall's appointees could not have blocked the appointment. The mayor would have risked voter disapproval and political embarrassment had they tried. Even so, yesterday's unanimous vote brings a welcome end to the uncertainty and political infighting that have dominated the school system since the former chancellor, Rudy Crew, was forced out by the mayor in January.

title: Run It Up, See Who Salutes
description: ''No one wants to read a book about old men weeping into the telephone.'' This was perhaps the harshest of 27 rejections that a particular book proposal received when it was offered around in New York in 1997 and 1998. But there were 26 others, representing nearly all of the most esteemed publishers in the country. They were just as unyieldingly dense, if not quite as nasty, when it came to evaluating the project's possibilities. It was, as it turned out, one of those fantastical enormities in judgment, as unprophetic as it was ridiculous, that engulfs the industry periodically, like the coming of the locust. For the book dismissed with such general brio by publishing's best and brightest has become the surprise runaway nonfiction best seller of the season.

title: TIME WARNER UNIT BUYS GST TELECOMMUNICATIONS ASSETS
description: GST Telecommunications Inc. said yesterday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and had agreed to sell its assets to Time Warner Telecom Inc. for $450 million. GST Telecommunications, based in Vancouver, Wash., provides phone and Internet transmission services in the western United States. In a filing with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, the company said it had cash flow problems, heavy debt and insufficient financing. Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection will allow the company to operate while it negotiates a settlement with its lenders. Time Warner Telecom, based in Littleton, Colo., said the purchase would accelerate the expansion of its communications network. The company is owned by Time Warner Inc.

title: M & T BANK AGREES TO BUY RIVAL IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The M & T Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Keystone Financial Inc. of Harrisburg, Pa., for about $1 billion in cash and stock. The deal between the Buffalo-based M & T and Keystone will create a bank with $29.8 billion in assets and 450 branches in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia. M & T will take a $52 million charge for consolidating back-office functions. M & T will pay Keystone shareholders $21.50 a share in cash or 0.05 of an M & T share. In all, M & T will pay about $370 million in cash and the remainder in stock. Keystone's stock was up $4.25, to $20 a share, while M & T's stock fell $14.0625 a share, to $400.9375.

title: It's Alive: 100 Years of Design
description: ''It's like seeing my library come alive,'' one architect gasped at the opening of ''At the End of the Century: 100 Years of Architecture,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art at the Geffen Contemporary here. Ambitiously conceived by Richard Koshalek, the former director of the museum, the show is on its last stop after a two-year international tour. The breathtaking collection of models, photographs and drawings charts the course of 20th-century architecture and urbanism. It is arranged in themes, like the Politics of Monumentality in 1930's Architecture (''Let's Transform Moscow Into a Model Socialist City of the Proletarian State,'' 1931, above); Structural Expressionism (Le Corbusier's 1951 chapel at Ronchamp, France, middle) and housing in the 1920's and 1930's (right, Karl-Marx-Hof, Vienna, 1927). The exhibition's design lacks the pizazz of its contents (it is about as alive as a library), so it may lack the wide appeal it deserves. Geffen Contemporary is at 152 North Central Avenue, Los Angeles, (213) 626-6222.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, WALKER E., SR.
description: SHIELDS-Walker E., Sr. Died peacefully at age 93 on May 8, 2000 in Palm Beach, Fl. Dorothy Henderson Shields, his wife since 1988, also a resident of Palm Beach for many years, died on March 22, 2000. Miriam Stevenson Shields, his wife of 50 years and mother of his son, Walker E. Shields, Jr. had died in Massachusetts in 1988. Mr. Shields Sr. is survived by his son and his daughter-in-law, Joyce Dagnal Shields of Belmont, MA. Two of his grandchildren, Mimi Harris Shields and Robert Walker Shields live in Cambridge, MA. His other grandson, Michael Walker Shields lives in Sandwich, MA with his wife Jennifer Everett. Mr. Shields, Sr. was born in 1906, grew up in Rock Island, IL., went to Saint John's Military Academy, Deerfield Academy, and then graduated from Bowdoin College during the years of the Great Depression. He began work for the City Bank of New York in 1931 and was involved in commercial banking in Manhattan for forty years, during most of which time he lived in Greenwich CT. At the time of his retirement from Citibank in 1971, while working in the branch at Lexington and 42nd Street, he served as Senior Vice President. Subsequently he continued in banking and financial consultation in Palm Beach, FL. for many years. As a result of his college experiences at Bowdoin, Mr. Shields communicated great fondness for Maine. The family frequently enjoyed trips together to the Belgrade Lakes Region, to the Maine Coast near Brunswick and also to the homes Mr. Shields Sr shared with his wife Miriam in Connecticut and Florida. A family burial service will be held in Lincolnville, ME. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions to Bowdoin College, Brunswick, ME.

Though questions about the battle were raised as the war ended in 1991, and subsequent Army investigations found no fault, there is good reason for the Pentagon and Congress to revisit the matter. Some officers familiar with the American assault offer detailed testimony that one of the country's most decorated commanders, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, ordered a punishing and unwarranted attack.

description: SARACHAN-Evelyn. Of Rochester, New York. Beautiful, stylish, spirited wife of the late, great, Judge Goodman A. Sarachan; mother of Donna and Martin Lawrence and Richard H. Sarachan of Rochester, and Niki Singer and Michael Sheets of New York City; grandmother of Julie Lawrence and Wlodzimierz Tomczyk and Romaine and Nicholas Sheets. Happy memories of her optimism and cheerfulness will be with us always.

description: SO after three hours of an interview over a theater district lunch, the playwright offers a romantic tale that is remarkable, magical even, if possibly embroidered. It cries out for retelling somewhere in this article, but there's a structure problem: it doesn't readily fit.

title: U.S. Prisoner Restraints Amount To Torture, Geneva Panel Says
description: Use of electric stun belts and restraint chairs, which human rights groups say is widespread in the United States, almost inevitably violates the international treaty against torture, according to a United Nations monitoring group.

description: There was confusion creeping into the Knicks' scrambled minds as the Heat players began shuffling the ball from hand to hand, from man to man, like street hustlers in a game of three-card monte.

title: I.M.F. DEAL WITH INDONESIA
description: The International Monetary Fund signed a new letter of intent with Indonesia that should free up $400 million in loans that the fund froze in early April after Jakarta missed economic-reform targets. Jakarta is counting on I.M.F. financing to fill budget shortfalls. The fund has agreed to extend several deadlines for politically sensitive tax increases, subsidy cuts and government audits in return for promises of tougher moves to collect $81 billion owed the government by powerful companies. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
Response by U.S. Faults Microsoft Alternative to Breakup Plan
description: Defending its plan to break up the Microsoft Corporation, the government filed documents with a federal judge tonight that disparaged Microsoft's alternative proposal as ''a cosmetic remedy that would have virtually no competitive significance.''

title: Indian Schools, Long Failing, Press for Money and Quality
description: There was no Christmas vacation this year at the Omaha Nation Public School, and no spring break either. Instead, the superintendent, Todd Chessmore, decided to front load the school calendar so classes would end a few weeks early, the first week of May.

title: Neighbors Grab Fugitive Rebel In Sierra Leone
description: Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader who vanished nine days ago after dealing humiliating blows to the United Nations peacekeeping force in this West African country, was captured here today in a bizarre incident outside his abandoned house.

title: Brazil Encounters Resistance to Privatization of Bank
description: Over the last six years Brazil has reduced state ownership of telecommunications, power and mining companies in what is widely regarded as a highly successful privatization. But the government is facing unexpectedly tough domestic resistance to selling one of the biggest state assets, a bank known as Banespa.

title: Trading an Angelic Face for Any Face That Comes Along
description: THERE'S a new kid in town, and he's not like the macho, muscle-bound heros brandishing brazen attitudes and big guns in games like Quake III and Unreal Tournament. His name is Bob, and he's the cute little cherub starring in Messiah, a new 3-D action game from Interplay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEUER, RICHARD
description: SCHEUER-Richard. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Shelly Schiff on the loss of her beloved father. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Top Editor of Real Simple Resigns After Just 2 Issues
description: In a management shake-up that shows that even the most promising publishing team does not always guarantee a smooth start-up, the managing editor of Real Simple -- a new magazine from Time Inc. for women who want to simplify their lives -- resigned yesterday.

title: Gamepad Uses Radio Waves And Awaits PlayStation 2
description: At first glance, the $40 Airplay video game controller looks much like any one of many handheld game devices. But a closer look reveals a significant advance: hey, no wires.

title: Eagles' Nest In Manhattan Irks Brooklyn; Officials and Veterans Want Statues Returned
description: Even for dedicated archaeologists of Brooklyn's ancient civic grudges, it is hard to pinpoint which aspect of the Missing Eagle Affair has inflicted the most insult. The list of perceived snubs is long, and growing longer by the day.

title: Strike Is Authorized Against 4 Utilities
description: A union representing 9,300 workers at Consolidated Edison and three other New York power companies announced yesterday that its members have authorized a strike if a new contract is not reached before the current agreement expires at 12:01 a.m. on June 25.

title: CENTENNIAL IN DEAL TO EXPAND CARIBBEAN CABLE SERVICES
description: The Centennial Communications Corporation, which sells wireless-telephone service in the Caribbean, agreed yesterday to buy Puerto Rican cable television systems from the Pegasus Communications Corporation for $170 million. Centennial will get 55,000 cable TV subscribers from Pegasus, based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Further terms were not disclosed. The company also provides phone service in 11 states. Centennial, based in Neptune, N.J., has been acquiring telecommunications assets to offer one source for TV, long-distance and wireless services in Caribbean nations. Shares of Centennial fell 6.25 cents, to $18.0625. The company is controlled by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe and by the Blackstone Group, New York-based investment firms. Pegasus's shares fell $2.1875, to $82.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, DOROTHEA BEAL
description: BERNSTEIN-Dorothea Beal. On May 16, 2000. Survived by her beloved husband, Abraham, whom she met in Paris; her loving son, Bruce; his wife, Catherine; her cherished grandsons, Eric and Christopher, and her dear sister, Edythe Rhodes. She worked for the British Ministry of Supply Mission in New York during World War II and served for many years as administrative assistant to the president of Rhodes School in NYC. Although retaining Canadian citizenship, she lived in Greenwich Village since 1943. She will be dearly missed by her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ARTHUR
description: GORDON-Arthur. Of Forest Hills, Queens. Loving husband of Alice Gordon (Buchwald). Caring father of Eric and Nancy. Devoted grandfather of Jacob and Keri. With wit and compassion, he enriched the lives of fellow New Yorkers for 81 years. Died peacefully May 14, 2000. He will live forever in our hearts. The funeral service will take place Thursday, May 18, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY, 718-263-7600.

title: Take the Freeway To the Metaphor
description: For snapshots of life on the freeway, the photographer Dennis Keeley shot some from a stop in the fast lane (not on the shoulder: ''That's against the law,'' he said). The result is ''Inertia,'' two 20-foot-long light boxes displaying a montage of fleeting cars and concrete. ''Our city center is our freeway,'' he said. ''My work is about this wonderful and terrible view of how we move past each other.'' ''Inertia'' is on view at Deep River, 712 Traction Avenue, Los Angeles; (213) 625-2958, through June 4.

title: Lawmakers Say U.S. Intelligence Agencies Are Not Up to the Job
description: Poor organization, inadequate financing and a lack of aggressive leadership have eroded the ability of United States intelligence agencies to face new threats, said a Congressional report released today.

title: TheStreet.com Threatens to Cancel Program in a Dispute With Fox
description: When James J. Cramer, the co-founder of TheStreet.com, went on TheStreet.com's cable television program and plugged TheStreet.com's own stock, he set off a battle over the ethics of stock promotion that may result in cancellation of the program.

title: Candidates, Rise to the Global Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Venus Williams Is Back, And She Intends to Stay
description: Sporting less muscle and hardly any beads, Venus Williams returned to the scene of one of her most important victories today and made it clear that, despite her father Richard's suggestions to the contrary, she always intended to return to the game.

title: Dueling D.S.L.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Education page yesterday about the distribution of eyeglasses to low-income schoolchildren misidentified the organization running the program on behalf of Childsight, a nonprofit group. It is Helen Keller International; the Columbia School of Public Health operates the program in Washington Heights only.

title: Cannes Journal; Enchantment At Cannes, Outside The Awards
description: Though one could lose several nights' sleep trying to catch all the films in competition at this year's Cannes International Film Festival -- and some of them, at over three hours, seem to last at least one night -- there are great movie finds outside the main event. Among them is ''Girlfight,'' from the writer and director Karyn Kusama, which is being shown in the highly regarded Directors' Fortnight series for new talent. Ms. Kusama's debut work is the story of a young girl (Michelle Rodriguez, in her acting premiere) who discovers a way to channel her anger and aggressions through training as a boxer, and the film is enchanting audiences at Directors' Fortnight the way it did at the Sundance Film Festival, where it was awarded the Jury Prize.

title: Antimissile System's Flaw Was Covered Up, Critic Says
description: A prominent antimissile critic has found what he says is a major flaw in the Pentagon's antimissile plan and is calling on the White House to appoint a high-level scientific panel to investigate what he says were fraudulent efforts to cover it up.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Paul Bartel, Director and Star Of 'Eating Raoul,' Dies at 61
description: Paul BartelPaul Bartel, a director, screenwriter and actor whose taste for farce, black humor and social satire was reflected in films like ''Eating Raoul,'' ''Death Race 2000'' and ''Scenes From the Class Struggle in Beverly Hills,'' died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 and also had a home in Los Angeles.

title: An Affordable Makeover Through a Prism Of Glass
description: All that glisters is . . . recycled glass at the private prayer garden (left) created by the landscape architect Andy Cao and his business partner, Stephen Jerrom. Mr. Jerrom says the two specialize in ''quick-fix, high-style inexpensive garden makeovers,'' relying largely on balls and chips of recycled glass.

title: Sather Set To Leave The Oilers
description: After 24 years, Glen Sather's tenure in Edmonton is apparently nearing its end. Now, the question is whether Sather will wind up in New York as the Rangers' new president and general manager.

title: NBC Will Begin Olympics Promotion
description: It may be months before the Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, but the network that will broadcast the games, NBC, is starting a promotional campaign.

title: An Updated Interior As Sleek as a Seal
description: Sleek postwar Airstreams notwithstanding, travel trailers usually suggest a lack of means and class. Jim Huff of Inside Design of New York, a product development company, says 20-somethings want more style than typical models offer. Inside Design joined with Wilsonart International, a Texas-based laminates manufacturer, and Christopher Deam, a San Francisco-based architect, to revamp a vintage Airstream. Above is the relaminated kitchen and bedroom of a 1948 Wanderer. The Wanderer will be at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Javits Convention Center. Retailers may go Saturday through Tuesday; the public, Tuesday only, $25; (800) 272-7469.

description: Moving Wild Canada Columbine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBER, LEOPOLD, M.D.
description: LEBER-Leopold, M.D. On May 16, 2000. Husband of Edith Rosen Leber. Father of Dr. George B. and Yvonne Leber, Bernice K. Leber and David Rosenberg. Grandfather of Andrew and Melissa Leber and Aaron Rosenberg. Brother of Dr. Arthur and Lusia Leber. Uncle of Dr. Mark Leber. He and Edith survived the Holocaust. He practiced medicine for 35 years in Schenectady, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Englewood Hospital or the Jewish National Fund. Services Thursday 1PM, ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66 Ave, Forest Hills

title: Devils' Special Teams Will Miss Madden
description: One of the Devils' hallmarks this season has been special teams. Today, they learned that one of their best penalty killers would miss Game 3 and possibly the rest of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: St.-Tropez Journal; The Bikini's Habitat, a Fabled Beach, Is Endangered
description: Even on a cold, rainy spring day, the tourists find their way to the beach that made this resort so famous. Some of the restaurants perched on the dunes are full, their tables set below canvas roofs that flap in the blustery winds. Bleached-blond hunks hustle to park the Jaguar, Mercedes and Porsche convertibles that roll in.

title: Campbell Soup Posts Drop Of 14% in Quarterly Profit
description: With sales of its signature soups on the wane, the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell 14 percent, and warned that the rest of its fiscal year, which ends in July, was unlikely to be much better.

title: Puck-ish Ramblings in Midsummer
description: HUNTS IN DREAMS

title: Jury Sequestered, Kimes Judge Discloses Other Accusations
description: A Manhattan jury failed to reach a verdict yesterday after a third day of deliberations in the trial of a mother and son accused of killing a missing Upper East Side socialite.

title: Key Minister Denies Bribery Charges in Tokyo
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa denied charges today that when he was prime minister he bribed a politician for his silence.

title: Essay; The Biggest Vote
description: The most far-reaching vote any representative will cast this year will take place next week. It will be on the bill to permanently guarantee that Congress will have no economic leverage to restrain China's internal repression of dissidents or external aggression against Taiwan.

title: Runoff or Not, Dominican Opposition Declares Victory
description: Tantalizingly close to an outright majority, Hipolito Mejia of the left-leaning Dominican Revolutionary Party today declared himself the winner of Tuesday's presidential election, vowing that the country's poorest residents would no longer be bystanders to the economic boom of the last four years.

title: At Central Park Summerstage, a World of Performers
description: The 15th season of Central Park Summerstage will present performers from all over the map in its series of free concerts from June 15 through Aug. 15. The series, presented by the City Parks Foundation at the Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 72nd Street, is announcing its schedule today.

title: Revealing a Japanese Garden As Serene Melting Pot
description: TRYING to see through the gates, shuddering at the sound of jackhammers and buzz saws, worrying about 85-year-old cherry trees dangling their roots in the drained pond. It was like pacing the halls during a beloved's interminable operation. But now the vigil is over and worrywarts can relax: the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is about to reopen its Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden, and the patient never looked better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALHAME, GEORGE C.
description: MALHAME-George C. On May 17 May 17, of Garden City, formerly of Douglaston, New York. Beloved husband of Gloria. Dear father of Therese, Edmond, James, Elizabeth, Jean, Mary, Thomas and the late Charles. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Brother of the late Edmond. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Friday at St. Anastasia RC Church, Douglaston, with interment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Liver Foundation or Cancer Care.

title: Study Reveals Web As Loosely Woven
description: WEB idealists and online merchants like to think that the World Wide Web is, like its name suggests, an interconnected global bazaar of ideas and products, a place where the answers to any question or want is only a few clicks away.

title: Prices of Treasuries Decline As Investors Assess Fed Move
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as the full scope of the Federal Reserve's half-point interest rate increase and hawkish statement on inflation risks began to sink in for many investors.

title: GRANADA AND COMPASS TO MERGE
description: In an all-stock deal worth $8 billion, Granada Group and Compass Group have agreed to merge, allowing Granada to start spinning off its media unit this summer. Granada, Britain's biggest hotel owner, owns a third of the Independent Television Network and wants to separate its media arm so that it can pursue acquisitions. Compass is Britain's leading caterer. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Effort to Oust Assembly Speaker Upsets Democrats' Show of Unity
description: The State Assembly suddenly dissolved into open warfare today, as the second-ranking member, Michael J. Bragman, announced he would try to overthrow Speaker Sheldon Silver in a showdown vote Monday. The speaker retaliated by stripping Mr. Bragman of his title of majority leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZANCER, IRENA (ZILZ)
description: SZANCER-Irena (Zilz). On May 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Henryk Szancer. Loving mother of Elizabeth Szancer Kujawski and husband Nathan. Proud and adoring grandmother of Melissa and Stephanie. Cherished sister of Melita Huppert and husband Victor. Dear aunt of Frances Huppert (Jeffrey Fishman) and Arthur Huppert (Miriam Field). Born in Krakow, Poland, and a graduate of the law school of the Jagellonian University in Krakow. Came to the United States in 1947 after surviving World War II. Devoted member and chapter officer of The Woman's League for Israel. Her legacy of warmth, courage, and the love of life will live on in the many lives that she touched. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Jewish National Fund of Greater New York for the Irena and Henryk Szancer Memorial Water Project, 42 E. 69 St., New York, NY 10021, att: Mrs. Dadiani.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; CHEVRON RAISES STAKE IN CASPIAN FIELD
description: Increasing its investment in the largest proven oil field on the Caspian Sea, the Chevron Corporation signed an agreement to pay $450 million for 5 percent of the Tengiz field in Kazakhstan in addition to other cash payments to help the country, a former Soviet republic, construct its new capital, Astana. Chevron's stake will increase to 50 percent. Steve LeVine (NYT)

title: 2 Charged in 1963 Church Blast That Killed 4 Birmingham Girls
description: Nearly 37 years after a bombing that horrified the nation, the authorities here charged two longtime suspects with murder today in the deaths of four black girls in the explosion at Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAILEY, LOUIS B.
description: DAILEY-Louis B. Died peacefully at home, age 96. of New York City and Brookfield, NH on May 17. A prominent New York lawyer in private practice, lifetime activist for world peace, nationally ranked tennis player, blueberry farmer. Graduate of Princeton University '23, Columbia Law School '27. Devoted husband of 67 years to Evelyn Hammond. Loving father to Robert H., MD of Orinda, CA; Thomas H., MD of New York City; Sarah (Mrs. Ivan Diamond) of San Francisco, CA; and Susan (Mrs. Carl Lohse) of Columbus, OH. Survived by nine loving grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Family service private.

title: Pull Up a Lawn Chair and Watch the Robot Mow the Grass
description: ALTHOUGH many futurists have envisioned robots that could relieve humans of ordinary tasks like cooking and cleaning, people must still do most of the domestic drudge work, at least inside the house. But outdoors, the future is here, in the form of mow-bots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, PAULINE
description: NADLER-Pauline. On May 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Nadler. Loving mother of Leia Boutros Ghali, Enrico, Fred and Emanuel Nadler. Beloved grandmother of Ava Nadler and Debra Broek. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street Friday 11:30 A.M. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Gives Police Union New Deadline
description: A game of chicken between Nassau County and the union representing its police officers continued today as county officials gave the union yet another deadline by which to decide whether to accept a so-called lag payroll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALSITZ, FELICIA ''FELA'' (NEE KLUGER)
description: SALSITZ-Felicia ''Fela'' (nee Kluger). Beloved wife of the late Leo (Leibush) Salsitz. Mother of Edwin. Aunt of Eva Wald (with whom she was especially close) and Marla, Stella, Halina, and the late Aryeh. Sister of the late Rosia, Mania, Leon, and Samuel. Born in Cracow, Poland. A Holocaust survivor, whose parents Asher and Regina, brother Leon, and first husband Leon Finder perished in the Shoah. She was hidden and saved by Jan Nakonieczny, a righteous one among the nations. She was grateful to start a new life in America. Despite the horrors of the past, she was optimistic about the future, and had a warm, giving, energetic and cheerful presence. She will be missed as the matriach of our family in the U.S.A. and Israel. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Isreal Medical Center, New York.

title: Disabled Girl Is Found Dead, Amid Signs of Malnutrition
description: A 5-year-old girl who had cerebral palsy was found dead in her Bronx apartment Wednesday, and a preliminary report by the chief medical examiner's office yesterday indicated that her tiny 17-pound body showed signs of acute malnutrition.

title: The Irish Provide A Surprise
description: As the men's Division I tournament heads into the quarterfinals this weekend, first-seeded Syracuse and second-seeded Virginia remain solid favorites. Unseeded Notre Dame, which might not have broken into this lacrosse summit except for an automatic bid, remains the solid surprise.

title: Cable TV Dispute Ends
description: Time Warner's chairman said his company and Disney had resolved the dispute over the cable transmission of television channels owned by Disney. Neither company would disclose details of the agreement.

title: A Cavalier Erupts in Elation As a 'Sleeping Beauty' Suitor
description: Yvonne Borree and Peter Boal are the latest Princess Aurora and Prince Desire to step into ''The Sleeping Beauty'' that the New York City Ballet is presenting through Sunday afternoon.

title: Despite Overcrowding, Proposal for School Divides Queens Community
description: In many neighborhoods, it would be an easy question to decide: Should a long-vacant property, centrally located in one of the city's most overcrowded school districts, be used for a new 900-seat elementary school or for a Staples office supply store?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASILE, THERESA C.
description: CASILE-Theresa C. (Kay) on May 17, 2000. Sister of Orlando Casile. Friends may call at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 726 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY Saturday 7-9 and Sun 25 & 7-9. Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Solace Church, Bronx, NY, Monday, 9:45AM.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: A Mormon Family Tree, Or Is It Really Spaghetti?
description: Branches sprawl in a convoluted tangle across the heavens of the set at the Women's Project Theater. It's quite an image for a show that exposes the confusing mess of a Mormon family tree in which a father marries his daughter's best friend years before the daughter's husband marries her half sister, who is the daughter of her father and the best friend.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: 'Blair Witch'-Type Dread Infuses an Outback Puzzle
description: The first half of ''The Well,'' the Australian director Samantha Lang's beautifully creepy debut feature, is an efficient study in the contrasting temperaments of two lonely women. Hester (Pamela Rabe), who lives with her father on a desolate sheep station, is the repressed one. We know this because of her long skirts and buttoned-up blouses, her orthopedic shoes and her flat, colorless hair, which she wears either severely plaited or gathered into a bun like the one Anthony Perkins sported in ''Psycho.'' Her taste in music runs to German lieder sung at dirge pace to the accompaniment of an out-of-tune upright piano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUPIANO, ROSELLE S.
description: LUPIANO-Roselle S. On May 15, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Hon. Vincent A. Lupiano. Loving mother of Vincent and Paula. Fond mother-in-law of Joseph F. Conway. Dear grandmother of Elizabeth A., Christopher, Paul and Alexandra. Cherished great grandmother of William. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St today, 2-6 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM Saint Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89 Street, NYC. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Saint Vincent's Hospital, Chelsea Village Program, 41 East 11 Street, 9th Flr, NY, NY 10003, would be greatly appreciated. Her elegance and spirit were an inspiration to her family and friends.

title: PAINEWEBBER TO CLOSE INVESTMENT BANK UNIT
description: PaineWebber Group Inc. said it was closing the investment-banking unit J. C. Bradford & Company, the brokerage firm it agreed to buy for $620 million last month. The plan will eliminate about 90 investment banker and analyst positions in Nashville, according to Susanne Loftis, a spokeswoman for J. C. Bradford. J. C. Bradford, based in Nashville, was purchased by PaineWebber mainly for its network of 900 brokers. Those brokers are valuable as the company's PaineWebber broker-dealer unit tries to gain access to wealthy investors in the Southeast. PaineWebber -- which has 7,608 brokers of its own, making it the nation's fourth-largest brokerage firm -- is paying cash for the closely held company, which operates in 14 states. Shares in PaineWebber gained $1.125 each, to $46.3125.

title: Camby Shows No Fire and His Game Is Up in Smoke
description: Marcus Camby slipped out of the gym at SUNY-Purchase, hurriedly making his way to the stairs with his head down, trying to ignore the news media, perhaps making the most aggressive move he has displayed during the Eastern Conference semifinals.

title: Gillian Wearing
description: 'Drunk'

title: Frederick Coggan, an Archbishop of Canterbury, Dies at 90
description: Frederick Donald Coggan, a former archbishop of Canterbury and the first spiritual head of the Church of England to support the ordination of women, died on Wednesday night in a nursing home in southern England. He died after a long illness, according to a statement from Lambeth Palace, official home of the archbishops of Canterbury. He was 90.

title: Marbury Keeps Views to Himself
description: As one of the league's brightest young stars and the Nets' best player, Stephon Marbury could play a significant role in the team's search for a coach and a director of basketball.

title: Opener Set For Queens Ball Team
description: The Queens Kings, a Class A affiliate of the Toronto Blue Jays that will change its name when it becomes a Mets farm team in Brooklyn next year, will begin play on June 21, with tickets going on sale June 3.

title: Recife Journal; A Brazilian City Resurrects Its Buried Jewish Past
description: The Street of the Benevolent Jesus traverses an area of restaurants and nightclubs just off the docks of this port city of 1.5 million people. And right in the middle of the busiest block, one of the most unusual archaeological projects ever undertaken in Brazil is under way: the excavation and reconstruction of the first synagogue built in the New World.

title: Benefits and Drawbacks to Bush and Gore Proposals for Overhauling Social Security
description: Social Security is slowly going broke, says Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and the best way to avoid painful benefit cuts or tax increases is to establish private investment accounts through which workers could seek higher returns on their contributions to the retirement system.

title: Social Security, as Seen at 19 and 65
