description: Government Hesitated in Reacting to Virus

title: Rules Oblige Corzine and Florio to Pull In Their Claws for Final Debate
description: In their fourth, final and tamest debate, New Jersey's two Democratic candidates for the United States Senate found themselves defending their positions tonight on campaign spending and taxes, but the biggest issues in the race -- gun control and Social Security -- were explored only briefly.

title: Restaurant Protocol And Other Helpful Tips
description: ''Road Trip'' has a serious lesson to impart. Never, ever send a plate of French toast back to a restaurant kitchen because it happens to be sprinkled with powdered sugar. If that plate should be returned denuded of the dreaded topping by a waiter who seems a tad too obsequious when he plops it down in front of you, it's probably because he knows where that French toast has just been, and you don't. And trust me, you don't want to. If you have any notions of eating what is smilingly put before you, think again, no matter how appetizing it may appear.

title: Oil Industry Balks at Priceline Gasoline Offer
description: Oil Industry Balks at Priceline Gasoline Offer

title: WCBS-TV and Daily News to Start Joint Morning News Segment as First Collaborative Effort
description: WCBS-TV and The Daily News announced yesterday that they would begin producing a joint morning news segment as a first step toward collaborating on a range of reporting projects.

title: Months Later, Boy's Death Is Ruled Homicide by Starvation
description: The death of a 10-year-old Brooklyn boy in February has been ruled a homicide, according to a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office, who said the child died of starvation and dehydration.

title: ABC goes in search of a younger audience for its soap operas.
description: IT is increasingly common for marketers to focus advertising on teenagers and 20-something consumers in the hope of developing shopping patterns that become lifelong buying habits. Now the ABC television network is joining the ranks of advertisers like Kraft Foods and Procter & Gamble with an ambitious campaign intended to stimulate demand among consumers 16 to 24 for four of its own ''products'': daytime soap operas.

title: Murray Koenig, 85, Judge and Politician
description: Murray Koenig, a retired judge of Bronx Criminal Court and later acting justice of New York State Supreme Court, died on Saturday in Miami Beach. A former resident of the Bronx, he was 85 and had lived in Aventura, Fla., since retiring from the bench in 1986.

title: Southern Baptist Consider Check on Women as Pastors
description: Leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, yesterday proposed revising the denomination's basic statement of faith to say that the Bible allows only men to be church pastors.

title: Richard F. Arens, 81, Mathematician and Teacher
description: Dr. Richard Friederich Arens, a mathematician steeped in abstruse theories and abstractions, died on May 3 at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 81 and a resident of Los Angeles.

title: Lack of Body Was No Barrier to Conviction, Jurors Say
description: There was no body, no eyewitness to an attack or even any evidence of a struggle, yet jurors said it was not difficult for them to convict a mother-and-son pair of grifters of murdering a wealthy Manhattan woman.

title: Opportunity Is at Hand, But Ledee Can't Seize It
description: Ricky Ledee went to sleep in a Cleveland hotel last night, hoping that his dreams about baseball would not recur. The dreams are not really nightmares since Ledee usually smacks hits in them, but they still unnerve him because they prevent him from relaxing for a few hours.

title: BRAZIL SHOWS BIG SURPLUS
description: Brazil's budget surplus rose to a record in March, reflecting the government's efforts to control spending. The surplus, which excludes interest payments, rose to $3.1 billion last month, compared with $2.1 billion in February. For the first quarter, Brazil posted a $7.4 billion primary surplus, almost doubling the target of $3.95 billion agreed upon with the International Monetary Fund. Jennifer L. Rich

title: No Job Offered, Jarvis Says
description: Mike Jarvis, the St. John's basketball coach, acknowledged yesterday that his agent had spoken with the Washington Wizards yesterday. But Jarvis said there was no offer on the table.

description: BASEBALL

title: VOLVO STOCK BUYBACK
description: The Swedish heavy-vehicle maker Volvo said it planned to buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock by offering shareholders the opportunity to sell every tenth share to Volvo for cash. Roughly $1.3 billion will be transferred if the offer is fully accepted. The buyback comes in the wake of an agreement under which Volvo will acquire the truck unit of Renault of France for a 15 percent stake in Volvo. Volvo plans to transfer 10 percent of its A and B Series shares as partial payment to France's Renault, in exchange for 100 percent of the shares in Renault VI/Mack. If the buyback offer is not fully accepted, Volvo plans to acquire the remaining shares on the open market.

May God give comfort to his brothers Bobby, and Steven and to the entire family. We are with them in the hour of their grief. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Laurence A. Feldman, President

description: Maybe it was a couple of 20-something Filipinos who created the rogue e-mail program that disabled computer systems on May 4. Maybe it wasn't. But there is no doubt that a couple of other young Filipinos played a big part in rubbing the bug out.

description: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. warned in 1996 that Attorney General Janet Reno and one of her top deputies should remove themselves from an investigation into Democratic fund-raising after the aide was quoted as saying that Ms. Reno could lose her job if the inquiry proceeded, government officials said today.

title: Lucent to Add Over 2,000 Jobs
description: Lucent Technologies said today that it would spend $40 million to increase manufacturing of components for optical networks in Southern California, creating 450 jobs in the next 18 months.

title: Richard's Results Due Next Week
description: Results of tests on the former Montreal Canadiens great Maurice Richard for a suspected recurrence of abdominal cancer are expected next week, his agent said yesterday.

description: Elton Brand of the Chicago Bulls and Steve Francis of the Houston Rockets, the co-rookies of the year, were voted unanimously to the National Basketball Association's all-rookie first team.

title: A State Votes to End Its Death Penalty
description: Reflecting a mounting national unease over the death penalty, New Hampshire's generally conservative Legislature today became the first in the country to approve a bill banning capital punishment since the Supreme Court allowed executions to resume nearly 24 years ago.

title: A Model Child Care System
description: In a remarkable turnaround over the past 10 years, the Department of Defense has transformed an abysmal military child care system into a model for the nation, judging from a report by the National Women's Law Center, a research and advocacy group. A decade ago, military child care services were plagued with poorly trained staff, extremely high turnover in caregivers, long waiting lists and costs too high for many military families to afford. But child care became a key personnel issue, and in 1989 the Military Child Care Act mandated that improvements be made.

title: Kitsch in Sync With Treasures
description: THE Guggenheim's ''1900: Art at the Crossroads'' is a wacky exercise in historical simulation, the excuse being a new century. It is hard to remember the last time so many bad pictures were in one place at one time, unless you consider eBay a place. But the show no doubt will be as popular in New York as it was in London. There is no underestimating the public's taste for kitsch.

title: Expecting Fraud, Peru Challenger Drops Out of Presidential Runoff
description: The outspoken challenger in Peru's presidential race said today that he was pulling out of the runoff election scheduled for later this month because he believed the vote would be a fraud.

It was a new character on stage: vulnerable, affectionate, introspective, indecisive, apologetic to his enemies, more concerned with being ''better as a person'' than winning a political fight.

description: The designer Tibor Kalman was a jack of several trades who deliberately avoided mastering any of them. This, at least, is the impression conveyed by the vivid, if motley, exhibition at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo.

title: Finale? Look Out for That Cliff!
description: LAST month Al Gore sat on a couch in the study of the Vice President's official residence and said with great urgency: ''Get in the tube, dummy! We only have a few seconds before the universe is destroyed.'' He had already made his position on the destruction of the universe clear: ''As an environmentalist, I'm against that.''

description: If Europe is virtually allergic to the genetically modified seeds that are so popular with North American farmers, it got a reason this week to sneeze with fury.

description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order this evening, telling all airlines that use the Boeing 767 to check the steel bolts holding the plane's engines in place, after an airline found damage on both bolts under one wing and one of the two on the other side.

description: The much-admired sculptor Robert Gober will represent the United States at the 2001 Venice Biennale. Known for his surreal and perfect re-creations of body parts and everyday objects like sinks, urinals and drainpipes, he relates his work to the explicit and social-political art of the late 80's and early 90's in oblique and illusive ways.

After the winsome reptilians and their primate pals, paleontologically doubtful but ever so cute, have wandered off into the Cretaceous sunset, the screen fills with rapidly scrolling double columns of names, identifying the few hundred people who labored to bring those extinct, eternally fascinating beasts back to life.

She thinks President Clinton ought to invite the leaders of Taiwan and China to hash out their differences at the White House. description: The Pentagon announced today that a decisive test of a national missile-defense system had again been delayed, increasing pressure on the project's managers to meet the Clinton administration's timetable for deciding whether to deploy the system.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCKEFELLER, RODMAN C.
description: ROCKEFELLER-Rodman C. The Phelps Memorial Hospital community mourns the passing of Rodman C. Rockefeller, who was a dedicated friend and counselor to the Hospital for many years. Mr. Rockefeller was a member of the Hospital's Board of Directors throughout the 1990's, serving on the Planning and Nominating Committees. His broad experience in the fields of finance and real estate brought invaluable expertise to the Board at a time when the Hospital faced important decisions regarding its expansion and growth. Mr. Rockefeller will long be remembered at Phelps for his brilliant insight and his selfless devotion to the community and, especially, to Phelps Memorial Hospital Center. James C. McGroddy, Chairman, Board of Directors Keith F. Safian, President and C.E.O. Kenneth C. Kaplan, President, Medical Staf

title: PANTRY TO BUY CONVENIENCE STORES IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Pantry Inc., the largest convenience-store operator in the Southeastern United States, agreed yesterday to buy 19 Big K convenience stores in Mississippi for an undisclosed price to add its first stores in that state. The chain, based in Hattiesburg, Miss., is being acquired from the closely held Tip Top Convenience Stores Inc. Pantry, based in Sanford, N.C., said the transaction is its first step in building its business in Mississippi and Alabama, while adding in other states where it already has stores. Excluding Big K, Pantry has purchased 85 stores in its 2000 fiscal year. Pantry operates 1,269 stores in Florida, Georgia, Indiana, Kentucky, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.

description: With a scathing indictment of the federal response to fires that have now burned nearly 80 square miles of northern New Mexico and more than 400 housing units, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said today that the government was wholly to blame and would do whatever possible to compensate victims.

title: CYTEC TO SELL STAKE IN CRITERION FOR $60 MILLION
description: A specialty chemicals company, Cytec Industries, agreed yesterday to sell its 50 percent stake in Criterion Catalyst, a petrochemical refining company, for $60 million to its joint venture partner CRI International Inc. Cytec will also assume $40 million of Criterion's debt, half of the venture's debt. CRI, which is based in Houston, is owned by the Dutch oil giant Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Cytec said the sale would allow it to focus on its core businesses of producing chemicals and making adhesives.

description: Equity Office Properties Trust said yesterday that it had sold 11 parking operations in five cities to Urban Growth Property Trust, an affiliate of Security Capital Group Inc., for $180 million. Chicago-based Equity Office owns and manages office properties, with a portfolio of 294 buildings in 23 states and the District of Columbia. Security Capital, based in Luxembourg, invests in publicly traded real estate investment trusts. The parking operations are in Boston, Indianapolis, Milwaukee, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia.

title: South Carolina Votes to Remove Confederate Flag From Dome
description: After 38 years of conducting their state's business under the Confederate battle flag, the two houses of the South Carolina General Assembly voted today to remove it from the Capitol dome and their chambers. At noon on July 1, South Carolina will become the last state to remove the old symbol of secession from its seat of government.

title: Seeking More Greenbacks in the Greenery
description: HERE we are, confronting the same old same old at Kutsher's Country Club: an elderly man is sound asleep in the lobby, while two women with no intention of spilling their age paddle across the indoor pool like a pair of spandex tugboats. Outside, the golfers ponder their divots. Helen Kutsher, who can spot a tarnished fork from 50 paces, is on hostess patrol, as she's been for the past half century, and her 52-year-old son, Mark, who runs the place, is solving the mystery of the missing tile in the men's health center.

title: The Ascent of Mankind: An Allegory in 38 Minutes
description: The French-Canadian troupe Cirque du Soleil is renowned for conjuring visual magic that fuses dance and the circus arts in scenarios that often carry a mythical and spiritual charge. And in the tableaus they have created for the new Imax-3D film ''Journey of Man'' they have compiled an all-engulfing sensuous wonder book of aesthetic adventures with a light moral gloss.

description: Hundreds of thousands of people fled their homes today in western Eritrea as Ethiopian troops captured a strategic town and continued their rapid advance beyond border trenches and into Eritrea's towns and farmlands.

description: STRAUS-Alexander H. Of Southbury, CT. Formerly of Manhasset, N.Y. On May 15th. Husband of Mary Ellen (Simon). Father of James, Patti and John (Diane). title: Barton Harvey, 79, Investment Executive
description: F. Barton Harvey Jr., who was managing partner, chairman and chief executive of the Baltimore investment firm that became Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., died on Monday at his home in Baltimore County, Md. He was 79.

description: Ireland's Supreme Court overturned a ruling that had prevented an Irish-American mobile phone company, Meteor Mobile Communications, from using a license originally granted almost two years ago, after a competitor, Orange Communications, challenged the selection process as biased. title: Congress Impatient With Progress on Embassy Security
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department has substantially increased surveillance around its overseas facilities in the aftermath of the 1998 bombings of two U.S. diplomatic posts in Africa, and has detected hundreds of incidents of suspicious activity, officials said here.

title: GIULIANI QUITS RACE FOR SENATE, AND G.O.P. RALLIES AROUND LAZIO
description: New York State Republicans rushed to ensure that the party could still mount a serious challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton following Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's protracted exit from the Senate contest yesterday. They rallied around the candidacy of a little-known Long Island representative as they contemplated a race whose every dynamic was altered in the space of a single afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, DOROTHY
description: KAUFMAN-Dorothy, 86. Longtime resident of Larchmont, N.Y. died at her home on Thursday May 18th. Born and raised in Monessen, PA, she was the youngest of five children of Ida and Abraham Friedland. After her marriage to Jerome Kaufman on November 28, 1935, the couple moved to Washington, D.C. where they resided until 1944 when they moved to New York. The Kaufmans were among the founding families of the Larchmont Temple and she served as President of its Sisterhood. She will be remembered for her quiet strength, warmth, and generosity to both family and friends. She is survived by Jerome, her beloved husband of 64 years, her loving daughter Ronne and granddaughter Lauren of Chappaqua, N.Y. She was predeceased by her children Lynn in 1956 and Richard in 1968. Funeral services will take place Sunday, 12:30pm at Larchmont Temple with interment to follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Ardsley, N.Y. Memorial contributions can be made to Lynn & Richard Kaufman Scholarship Fund c/o Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.10538 or Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, New York 10707.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MRS. THOMAS A.
description: KELLY-Mrs. Thomas A. (nee June Hess), age 92, died on Thursday, May 18 from complications from a stroke in Croton, NY. Daughter of Mr. & Mrs. Harry Bellas Hess of New York City and Huntington, LI, she attended the Spence School and studied history and literature at Columbia University. She was married to Thomas A. Kelly and is survived by their five children, Barbara Johnson and Maureen Congdon of East Hampton, NY, Carolyn Kelly of Newfoundland, PA, Linda Hodgden of Enid, OK and Thomas Kelly, Jr. of Croton, NY. She is also survived by ten grandchildren, 12 great grandchildren and one great great grandchild. Funeral services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the Music and Art Programs of Guild Hall in East Hampton, NY.

title: Report Faults F.B.I. Over Its Handling of Nuclear Secrets Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation gravely mishandled its inquiry into Wen Ho Lee, the nuclear scientist suspected of passing secrets to the Chinese government, by failing to dedicate sufficient resources to the task and focusing too narrowly on a single suspect, a secret Justice Department review has concluded.

description: Four college students from the East Side of Manhattan assaulted a 24-year-old man in the East Village yesterday after shouting anti-gay slurs at him, the police said.

title: Democratic Stirrings in Albany
description: The attempted coup in the New York State Assembly this week had a healthy feel to it at first, like a blast of oxygen that aroused hope of energy and independence among the Assembly's Democratic majority. Then, within a few hours, the attempt to overthrow Speaker Sheldon Silver began to look less like an effort to change the State Legislature's claustrophobic system than a plot to replace one autocrat with another.

title: Michel Kazan, 92, Hairstylist Known for Bouffant Hairdos
description: Michel Kazan, who gave society and entertainment figures the bouffant hairdo and created the coiffures for the models of several fashion designers, died Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Where Country Twang Meets Romantic Melody
description: ''When you sing Jimmy Webb songs, you must speak them in tune because the stories are so profound,'' Glen Campbell declared on Tuesday night at the opening of his five-night reunion engagement with Mr. Webb at Feinstein's at the Regency.

title: Troubled Mom and Son, Sadly Adrift in an Impala
description: ''We'll have to wait till yesterday's here,'' goes the Tom Waits song that accompanies the end credits for ''Luminous Motion,'' and Bette Gordon's funny, unnerving new film casts a similar spell of low-key dislocation. It begins with the voice of 10-year-old Phillip (Eric Lloyd) reflecting on his earlier life as if it were the distant past. ''Childhood feels like a ghost town,'' he muses. ''It's hard to distinguish what's real from what's something else.''

title: CFW COMMUNICATIONS TO PURCHASE WIRELESS ASSETS
description: The CFW Communications Company announced a group of deals yesterday aimed at increasing services in Virginia and nearby states. CFW, based in Waynesboro, Va., will buy the wireless licenses and operations of the Bell Atlantic Corporation's PrimeCo PCS in Richmond, Va., and Norfolk, Va., for $407 million. CFW will also assume $20 million in debt and give PrimeCo a stake in two CFW cellular properties. CFW also agreed to buy the privately held telecommunications company R & B Communications Inc. of Daleville, Va., for $131 million in stock. CFW will also receive a $200 million investment from the buyout company Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe and a $25 million investment from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company.

description: It's not often that Chelsea sophisticates, Midtown commuters and 10-year-old Upper East Siders are after the same hot item. But there it is. And there. And there.

description: With his recent statements on China trade and the deployment of American troops in Kosovo, Gov. George W. Bush has placed himself squarely in a Republican tradition of favoring internationalism and presidential supremacy in foreign policy.

title: Store Employee Killed In Brooklyn Robbery
description: One employee was killed and another was critically injured last night in a robbery in a bodega in East New York, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Rangers And Oilers May Clash On Sather
description: The board of directors of the group that owns the Edmonton Oilers met in an emergency session for more than three hours yesterday to map out a plan to try to control the fate of Glen Sather, the Oilers' president and general manager.

title: Taking Another Trip to 'Town'
description: With glowing reviews and some help from a Hollywood legend, the Encores! concert series's production of ''Wonderful Town,'' which had a brief run at City Center two weeks ago, may be headed for Broadway.

title: Foreign Affairs
description: At stake in next week's vote by Congress over whether to grant China permanent normalized trade relations -- which in plain English means a long-term, open trade relationship between America and China -- is not just the future of U.S.-China relations but also the future of the Democratic Party.

title: Dresdner Bank Expected to Cut 5,000 Jobs
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., which abandoned a huge merger with Deutsche Bank last month, is expected to announce plans on Friday for reducing its work force by 5,000 people -- about 10 percent of the total.

description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits yesterday about an Internet dictation service, iDictate .com, misstated the telephone number. It is (877) 342-8283.

title: 2 Old Foes, Buckley And Yale, Signal Truce
description: William F. Buckley Jr., a founder of modern American conservatism who 49 years ago accused Yale of rejecting God, is returning to campus on Monday, this time to accept an honorary degree from the university he has so devoutly castigated.

title: Chief Executive of Efdex Resigns Abruptly
description: Ellen R. Marram, the former head of Tropicana, abruptly resigned yesterday as chief executive of efdex, an Internet start-up she joined nine months ago.

title: USA Networks Buys 2 Digital Cable TV Channels
description: USA Networks Inc. has acquired two digital cable television channels for approximately $100 million, company executives said last night.

title: Average Cost Of Apartments Hits $700,000
description: Continuing a seemingly inexorable climb, the average price for apartments in much of Manhattan jumped by nearly a third over the last year, breaking the $700,000 mark for the first time, according to one of the real estate industry's most comprehensive surveys.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: ANDREW HILL: ''Dusk'' (Palmetto). The pianist Andrew Hill has long been embraced by the jazz underground, whose language of appreciation too often rests on notions of musicians' being underserved, underrated or not having the appropriate context for their genius to shine. ''Dusk,'' Mr. Hill's first album in 10 years, should end his marginal status: it connects him with some of the better young jazz musicians working today and takes the full measure of Mr. Hill as a composer better than one would have thought possible. It makes him important again.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about a plan to build a high-technology industrial park in Hong Kong misstated the projected cost. It is $2 billion, not $2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRISTOL, SYLVIA
description: BRISTOL-Sylvia. On May 16, 2000 at the age of 82, Sylvia passed away at her home in Hollywood, FL, surrounded by her awestruck family. Sylvia was a circumambient blur of love and wit who injected her soul into all those fortunate enough to have met her. She is survived by her slightly older and identical twin sister Helen, her younger sister Norma, her three children, Diane, William (and wife, Linda) and Mark, her grandson Adam (and wife, Andrea), nieces and nephews, Maris and Shlomee, Rick and Debbie, and Roberta, grand-nephew Leron, grand-niece Shira, guardian angel Sylvette, and countless friends and relatives, all of whom she loved as her own. Sylvia now joins two of her former husbands in a heaven replete with ocean views, cocktail parties, brisket and endless laughs.

title: A Weekend's Lark For Studebaker Club
description: STUDEBAKER owners are a stubborn, iconoclastic group. John Cohoe, a founder of the Manhattan Studebaker Club, said: ''One of the early mottoes was, 'We'd rather fix than switch.' And some cigarette smokers in the club would only smoke Lark. I guess they've grown up to Avanti cigars now.''

title: Court Upholds Rejection of Guilty Plea in Killings
description: The state's highest court ruled yesterday that a man accused of strangling eight women in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., cannot avoid the possibility of a death sentence by pleading guilty.

title: Flamboyant Owner Finds a Horse to Match
description: In July 1998, Fusao Sekiguchi traveled from Japan to Lexington, Ky., with a horse on his mind: an extraordinary one listed as Hip No. 228 at Keeneland race track's annual yearling sales. This was a regally bred colt, the equine equivalent of a Rembrandt, and he was no secret; he was coveted by a group of bidders from the United States and Europe.

title: 76ers Can Get Even or Head Home
description: Allen Iverson was late for today's practice, but once the game begins, he is often a step ahead of everyone else.

title: Assembly Speaker Wins Support in Bid to Keep His Job
description: The speaker of the State Assembly moved swiftly to put down a revolt within his chamber today, retaliating against renegade lawmakers and enlisting the support of influential union officials and party leaders to shore up his power base.

title: Israeli Printer-Maker Deal
description: An Israeli maker of inkjet printers, NUR Macroprinters Ltd., said today that it had agreed to buy the digital printing company Salsa Digital Ltd. of San Antonio for $30 million in cash and stock. NUR said the move was part of a strategy to build market share in Asia and Latin America. NUR said it would pay $20 million in cash and issue 666,667 of its shares. The privately held Salsa Digital had $25 million in revenue last year and NUR had $60.7 million in revenue last year. NUR's stock closed today at $16.5625, up 56.25 cents, on the Nasdaq.

title: Despite U.S., World Bank Approves Iran Loans
description: Over the objections of the United States, the World Bank today approved its first loans to Iran in seven years: $232 million for a sewage-treatment project in Tehran and for improvements in health care.

title: Europe Suitors Said to Hold Nabisco Talks
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the big British confectioner and beverage company, and the French global foods giant Groupe Danone have held talks about possibly making a combined bid for Nabisco Holdings, executives close to the negotiations said tonight.

title: Tipper Gore Seeks Privacy Under a Public Microscope
description: Here is one difference between Tipper Gore and Hillary Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, LOUISE FRITH STICKNEY
description: TANNER-Louise Frith Stickney. On May 15, 2000 following a brief struggle with cancer. Born February 16th, 1922 in New York. Adored mother of Michael and Betsy. Grandmother of Henry. Wife of the late Patrick Tanner. Funeral service on Friday May 19th at 10 AM at St. George's Church on Stuyvesant Square (209 E. 16th Street). Interment at St. James Episcopal Church in St. James, Long Island. ''...For God loveth a cheerful giver''.

title: PROFIT JUMPS AT FRENCH BANK
description: France's third-largest bank, Societe Generale S.A., said its first-quarter profit rose 53 percent. Net income rose to 883 million euros ($790 million) from 576 million euros a year earlier. That exceeded the gain forecast by analysts. Investment banking earnings rose 66 percent and accounted for half the profit. Retail banking earnings, for which Societe Generale is better known, rose 49 percent.

title: THE ELECTRONIC FISHBOWL
description: Coming to TV this summer: real people who live under round-the-clock surveillance. A confessional culture meets up with the Internet, and exhibitionism becomes an extreme sport.

title: Boo.com, Online Fashion Retailer, Goes Out of Business
description: It was supposed to follow the dot-com fairy tale script. Two young entrepreneurs devise an idea for the next big e-commerce Web site, raise enormous sums of cash, spend lavishly on advertising, lose money on every sale, take the company public and make every employee a billionaire.

title: Chopping Down the Forest Won't Save It
description: Yesterday's release of the National Park Service plan for a ''prescribed burn'' in New Mexico -- the fire that went awry and destroyed homes and businesses in Los Alamos -- has added to calls for a re-evaluation of the service's fire policies. But some of these exhortations, coming from the timber industry's supporters in Congress, look more like opportunism than considered criticism of what went wrong in this fire.

title: Chief of Fiber Optic Leader Retires, Citing Exhaustion
description: JDS Uniphase, the largest component manufacturer for fiber optic equipment, said today that Kevin Kalkhoven had retired as co-chairman and chief executive.

title: E.P.A. Says It Pressed 3M for Action on Scotchgard Chemical
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had pressed Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing to come up with a solution after the company's own tests had shown that a chemical compound used in Scotchgard and an array of household products could pose a risk to human health and the environment.

title: ECUADOR WINS BANANA RULING
description: The World Trade Organization authorized Ecuador to impose punitive measures on European Union goods and to withhold copyright protection for sound recordings like compact discs to retaliate for the European Union's failure to revise its import policy on bananas. Ecuador, the world's largest banana exporter, sought the sanctions after it successfully contested the European policy, which favors former colonies primarily in the Caribbean, as violating international trading rules. The W.T.O. ruling was significant because it represents the first time the trade body has approved a sanction that invalidates intellectual property protections.

title: Protests Flare As Belgrade Takes Control Of TV Station
description: About 20,000 people gathered again tonight to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station here, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, policemen in riot gear charged them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSH, BERTHA
description: GERSH-Bertha. On May 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William J. Gersh. Devoted mother of Phyllis Becker, Judy Hoffman and the late Victor. Dear mother-inlaw of Philip Becker and Daniel Hoffman. Loving sister of Blanche Lossef and Dr. Bernard Brooks. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Sarah, Marc and Andrew. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, RODMAN C.
description: ROCKEFELLER-Rodman C. The Boards of Directors and the staffs of the Americas Society and the Council of the Americas mourn the passing of a good friend and fellow Board member, Rodman C. Rockefeller, who was a vital personality, deeply committed to the betterment of inter-American relations and the advancement of the goals of the Society and the Council. He also served for 15 years as the Chairman of the U.S. Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee and effectively guided the work of the U.S. Council through a period of rapid change in Mexico-U.S. relations. He played a central role in the deliberations on the Fast Track Authority and the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the mid-1990s. A member of the Board of Directors of the Council of the Americas since 1970, and of the Americas Society Board since 1991, Rodman recognized the role the two organizations could play to help foster free trade and investment in the hemisphere. He will be sorely missed. We extend our most sincere condolences to all of his family, most especially to his wife, Sascha, and his children, Meile, Peter, Stuart, and Michael, and to his grandchildren. William R. Rhodes, Chairman of the Boards Martha T. Muse, Vice Chairman Thomas E. McNamara, President

title: National News Briefs; Energy Dept. Tightens Policy on Its Contractors
description: Frustrated by the performance of the contractors that it hires to run its nuclear weapons plants, the Department of Energy will demand the right to fire the contractors' top managers and control the managers' bonuses in future contracts, Secretary Bill Richardson said today.

title: UAL DECLARES FIRST CASH DIVIDEND IN 13 YEARS
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, yesterday declared its first quarterly cash dividend in 13 years. The dividend of 31.25 cents a share will be paid on June 15 to shareholders of record May 30. It was approved at the Chicago-based company's annual meeting. The dividend comes as UAL lets a 1994 employee stock-ownership program that gave workers a controlling stake in the company expire. The company is 55 percent owned by employees, which means that most will also receive the dividend. UAL's shares fell 25 cents, to $62.375.

title: When Americans Awoke to Modern Styles
description: The United States had to take a pass when offered a choice exhibition space at the great Paris show of modern design in 1925, the ''Exposition des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes.'' Why? Herbert Hoover, at the time secretary of commerce, had consulted V.I.P.'s in the art, educational and business worlds, who advised that there was no modern design in America.

title: Sports of The Times; Defenders Get Too Close For Comfort
description: ALLAN HOUSTON was played so closely by Dan Majerle Wednesday in Game 5 of the Heat-Knicks playoff series that it appeared he'd know if Majerle had eaten onions on his steak for his pregame meal, or had radishes in his salad.

title: Jeter Is Sent for Treatment
description: Derek Jeter worked out lightly at Yankee Stadium yesterday and the Yankees then decided to send him to Tampa, Fla., for additional treatment on his strained left abdominal muscle, a strong indication that he will be placed on the 15-day disabled list as early as today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISSAUER, DIANA FRAID
description: LISSAUER-Diana Fraid. Born in Montreal; heart in New York. Lived courageously; died peacefully on May 18. Wife of the late Franz Lissauer; mother of Emil; sister of Elaine Rush and the late Stephen Fraid; sister-in-law of Bob Rush, aunt of Hillary Rush; loving friend to Mark Trujillo and the many others whose lives were graced and enriched by her intelligence and taste; the celebratory way she decorated and dressed and her kindness and generosity. It is, however, her infectious exuberance and joyous humor that will be most sorely missed. She was curious about many things; passionate about even more: dancing, jazz, opera, gardens, antiques; baseball and the Mets; art; Japanese basket weaving and the Bible - recently; literature, people and ideas - always. Diana, we will forever embrace and cherish your memory. Funeral services Sunday, May 21, 2000, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to New School University, Diana Lissauer Scholarship, 66 W 12 St, NYC 10011.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND SLIDES. The pound fell after a weak retail sales report reinforced expectations that United States interest rates will rise faster than those in Britain. In New York, the pound settled at $1.4819, down from $1.4930.

title: VIBRANT JOB GROWTH IN FRANCE
description: With computers and telecommunications leading the way, French companies lifted the number of jobs in the economy by 1 percent, or 142,300 jobs, in the first quarter, the biggest number since France began keeping job creation statistics in 1970. The growth was attributed to the rapidly expanding economy, likely to show growth above 4 percent this year. In March, unemployment fell to 10 percent, its lowest in eight years. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, JOSEPH F.
description: MANES-Joseph F. at his residence, Croton-on-Hudson, New York. Beloved by his wife Helen, his son David J., his daughter Victoria E. and his four grandchildren and three sisters. A private Catholic Mass was held on May 5, 2000. Mr. Manes practiced Law for fifty years and served as Town Justice in the Town of Cortlandt for sixteen years. In lieu of memorial contributions, the family has requested donations to Phelps Hospice in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., or to his Church, Holy Name of Mary in Croton-on-Hudson, New York.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to keep the International Space Station in its orbit misstated the effects of the atmosphere on its descent. As the space station loses altitude it speeds up, it does not slow down.

title: T-ONLINE POSTS LOSS
description: Europe's largest Internet service, T-Online International, posted a first-quarter loss after booking costs for its initial public offering and said good-will charges for the purchase of Club Internet of France would hurt profit this year. T-Online said it had a first-quarter loss of 21.7 million euros ($19 million). Excluding one-time items, the loss would have been 200,000 euros. Sales rose 42 percent, to 173.8 million euros.

title: PepsiCo Ordered To Pay Overtime
description: In a ruling released yesterday, a New Jersey administrative panel told PepsiCo that it must pay overtime to hundreds of drivers who worked for the company between 1993 and 1995.

title: Blunders in Los Alamos
description: Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt left no doubt yesterday about the National Park Service's responsibility for the disastrous Los Alamos fire. A preliminary internal report, he said, found that officials at the Bandelier National Monument had made several critical mistakes. Among other things, they failed to fully evaluate the risks before giving the go-ahead for a ''controlled burn'' that quickly roared out of control, destroying more than 200 houses and apartment buildings and driving 25,000 people from the city. They should also have had more firefighters on hand in case the fire jumped its prescribed boundaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEERBOHM, BERTRAM
description: BEERBOHM-Bertram, Dr./PhD. Age 76. Survived by his wife Sylvia and sister and brother-in-law Mallie and Marvin Sandberg. Bert counseled patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He will be sorely missed by all.

title: SENATORS REFUSE TO SET A DEADLINE ON KOSOVO TROOPS
description: In a victory for the Clinton administration, the Senate today narrowly rejected a measure to set a deadline for withdrawing American ground troops from Kosovo. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas had also criticized the measure, but even so 40 Republicans voted for it.

title: Home Ice Faint Comfort as Flyers Jump Ahead of Devils
description: Turnovers by the Devils and inadequate goaltending by the usually outstanding Martin Brodeur allowed the Flyers to take away New Jersey's home-ice advantage tonight with a 4-2 victory in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals.

A graduate of S.U.N.Y., Albany. MBA from Penn State University. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to gather at the Delaney Funeral Home, 48 Common St., Walpole, MA on Friday, May 19 at 1 PM for an interment service. A memorial service will be held in the Delaney Funeral Home on Saturday, June 3 at 2 PM. Donations in her memory may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Central New England Chapter, 101 First Ave., Suite 6, Waltham, MA 02451. For additional information please call 508668-0858 between 7 PM and 9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits yesterday about the discovery of what may be a rare photograph of the poet Emily Dickinson included two sentences erroneously merged in editing. The error produced an incorrect reference to Dr. Philip Gura, professor of American literature and culture at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Dr. Gura, who bought the photograph on the eBay auction site, is not a forensic anthropologist and is not the person who will try to determine the photograph's authenticity.

description: Deitch Projects

title: After '63 Bombing, Hard Lives for Suspects
description: Thomas E. Blanton Jr. should not get claustrophobic in his cell in the Jefferson County jail. At 8 feet by 10 feet, it is roomier than the ramshackle 5-foot-by-10-foot trailer in nearby Fultondale where he lived before surrendering on Wednesday to murder charges related to the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham.

title: School Star on Target to Join Sub-4-Minute Milers
description: When Marty Liquori became the third high school miler to break four minutes in the 1960's, he remembered calling his coach and saying, ''This is great and all that, but I wonder who will do it next year?''

title: Scientists Offer a Vision of New Tools to Explore Space
description: Ten years from now, astronomers will have seen the first glimmerings of light as stars and galaxies coalesced in the gloom of the early universe, observed how the powerful gravity of a black hole warped the very fabric of space, and, perhaps, searched for signs of life in the glow of blue planets like Earth as they circled nearby stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERTCHIK, SAMUEL H.

title: Hospital Company Agrees to Pay $745 Million in U.S. Fraud Case
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest health care company, has agreed in principle to pay $745 million in civil penalties to settle part of a broad government inquiry into whether its success was achieved in part by cheating federal health programs.

title: In the Year 3000, Travolta Is the Only One Who Laughs
description: Battlefield Earth

title: Grown-Up Sentiment, Every Word Purposeful
description: Imagine the younger Kathleen Turner crossed with Sandra Dee, and you'll have some idea of the complicated flavors projected by Barbara Brussell, the gifted Los Angeles-born cabaret performer who is making her debut engagement through June 3 at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street,Manhattan). Ms. Brussell, who has diligently worked her way up the New York cabaret ladder, has an utterly distinctive voice: medium-size, with a cottony texture and a quickening vibrato.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In a city that has seen seafood in every possible form, it takes a little ingenuity to make the idea of fish seem fresh. Esca, the latest production from Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich, the team behind Babbo, Becco, Lupa and Po, pulls off the trick by giving the food a regional Italian focus. Esca, which is Italian for ''bait,'' draws on the rich maritime cuisine of Naples and the Amalfi coast. It also borrows a little from Istria on the northern Adriatic, where Mr. Bastianich's family comes from, in a menu-within-a-menu of raw fish served with fragrant olive oil, herbs and vegetables. Firm slices of gope, a sardine-like fish, are paired with tiny bitter greens and slivers of preserved lemon from Sorrento; weakfish with pea shoots and mint; and fluke with radishes and sea beans. David Pasternack, formerly at Picholine, runs the kitchen.

title: As Some Tenants Give Up, Others Continue Fight for Building Repairs
description: Facing water leaks, faulty heating and holes in their walls, the residents of 1420 Grand Concourse, a Bronx building with 138 apartments, did for years what most tenants in the city do when something needs to be fixed. They called for maintenance.

title: Social Security, as Seen at 19 and 65
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed's Notes Give Reasons for Show of Restraint in March
description: Federal Reserve policy makers unanimously approved raising interest rates by a quarter percentage point at their March 21 meeting, preferring to stick with what they called a gradual approach to monetary policy absent evidence of surging prices, according to minutes released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, THEODORE N.
description: LEWIS-Theodore N., Rabbi. The Rabbi, Cantor, Presidents and Trustees, the Congregation of Temple Beth Emeth Progressive Shaari Zedek mourn the passing of their illustrious and beloved Rabbi Emeritus, Theodore N. Lewis, whose leadership and influence spanned a good part of the twentieth century, leaving the legacy of a good and beloved name.

title: 'Insertion'
description: 'Self and Other'

title: From Team to Car, Woe Is Van Gundy
description: He stepped off the team's charter plane about 3 a.m., the loss in Game 5 still gnawing at him. A tired and beleaguered Jeff Van Gundy would soon have to worry about more than why his Knicks team could not grab an important rebound or make a defensive stop. As he walked down the plane's stairwell at Westchester County Airport, he soon learned he had another problem.

title: Trade Deal Will Hurt China's Hard-Liners
description: As Congress takes up the bill that would establish permanent normal trade relations with China, the question before it is not whether China's human rights record is good or whether the deal by itself will cure it. The question is, in addition to the overwhelming economic benefits, will its passage increase the chance of positive change in China?

title: Drkoop.com Lays Off 35 Percent of Staff
CRUISE COMPANY STAKE SOLD
description: The world's second-biggest cruise company, Royal Caribbean Cruises, said it would acquire a 20 percent stake in First Choice Holidays of Britain for $300 million to tap Europe's growing cruise market. The deal showed the rapid pace of change in Europe's tourism business after Preussag's purchase of Thomson Travel this week. Royal Caribbean and First Choice said they would also invest around $48 million each in a 1,500-berth cruise ship for the European market.

title: An Insular Family Confronts an Incipient Revolt
description: The Potter family of Tremont, N.H., is awfully behind the times. Asa, the father, is the county road agent, vigilant in his neighborly functions of snow removal and the occasional emergency rescue but inept as a politician and unable to use a computer. His 19-year-old son, Warren, is a crack mechanic but he cannot face the fact that his girlfriend, Jeannie, a promising student, is going off to college in the fall. And Rita, mother and wife, is the kind of homemaker who keeps the coffee pot on and instinctively salves every setback with fresh-baked cookies.

title: Exploring the Morning Of a Long Day's Journey
description: O'NEILL

title: Digital Signature Bill Moves Toward Compromise
description: Digital Signature Bill Moves Toward Compromise

title: European Space Agency Boldly Goes to Sci-Fi Fans for New Ideas
description: PARIS  Leonardo da Vinci created plans for a helicopter. Arthur C. Clarke wrote about communications satellites when the V-2 rocket was state of the art. Isaac Asimov devised his three laws of robotics long before whole factories were turned over to making robots. And William Gibson dreamed of a virtual reality in which hackers entered the realm of "cyberspace" by plugging their minds into computers.

title: Bush's Words to Conservative Group Remain a Mystery
description: The Council for National Policy is a little-known group whose members are often very well known and very conservative. There are radio personalities like Oliver L. North and James C. Dobson; religious broadcasters like Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell; and lawmakers like Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dick Armey of Texas.

title: Metro Business; City's Jobless Rate Is Lowest Since '88
description: The unemployment rate in New York City fell sharply in April to the lowest level in almost a dozen years, according to data released yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

title: Conan Doyle, On Holmes
description: ''It was really terribly important after the war when all the young men needed contacting,'' Sir Arthur Conan Doyle says rather breezily on camera during a 10-minute address he delivers on a DVD recently released by Focusfilm, a distributor in Ossining, N.Y. It was 1926, and by his remarks and manner the writer clearly wants to be done with his celebrated creation, the detective Sherlock Holmes, and move on to matters that he considers more serious: psychic experiences and communication with the beyond.

title: BANK ONE SELLS CREDIT CARD DIVISION IN CANADA
description: The Bank One Corporation sold its year-old credit card business in Canada to Royal Bank of Canada for an undisclosed amount as the company, the fourth-largest United States bank, retrenches under new management to regain investor confidence. Royal Bank, Canada's No. 1 bank and second-largest Visa issuer, gains 250,000 card holders with outstanding balances of $286 million. Bank One, based in Chicago, hired the former president of Citigroup Inc., James Dimon, in March as chairman and chief executive to revive earnings growth and turn around the credit card unit, the world's second largest.

title: Timberland Stock Split
description: The Timberland Company, the boot and clothing maker, said today that it would split its stock two shares for one. The new shares will be issued July 17 to shareholders of record as of June 30. Shares of Timblerland, which is based here, closed at $72.125 each, up $2.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sierra Leone's Wobbling Government Talks of Peace
description: Sierra Leone's minister of justice sat in his office today and spoke of the need for reconciliation -- even with the warlord Foday Sankoh.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: MIXED RESULTS FOR TRADING HOUSES
description: Five large Japanese trading houses have reported mixed earning results for the year that ended on March 31. Mitsui and Sumitomo posted big profits, but the results of the three other companies were weighed down by bad assets and unprofitable businesses. Itochu, Marubeni and Nissho Iwai each will skip a dividend payment for the year because they are undergoing revampings. The trading houses have been withdrawing from less profitable trading and refocusing on strong business sectors. This dragged down sales for the year that just ended.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Latest 'Gotcha' In the Senate Race

title: Sunni Muslims Settle Suit Against Police
description: The State Department of Corrections yesterday settled a federal discrimination suit by 33 Sunni Muslim officers who claimed they were in danger of being fired because the department banned beards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HARRIET KNECHT
description: FRIEDMAN-Harriet Knecht. Beloved wife for 53 years of Raymond; treasured mother of Claire, Terry, Eliot and Sari; adoring grandmother of Morgan, Gareth, Benjamin, Leo, Efrem, Giselle and Sophia. A cum laude graduate of Brooklyn College, she later earned her master's degree and taught at the Chatterton School in Merrick, NY for 24 years. In the words of her devoted mother, Giselle Knecht, ''she is our shining star.'' Services Friday, May 19, 2000, 1 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Blvd., Fresh Meadows NY

title: Prosecuting Foday Sankoh
description: For the last decade Foday Sankoh has led one of the world's most brutal guerrilla movements. His Revolutionary United Front has terrorized Sierra Leone by murdering thousands of civilians, gang-raping women and girls, and chopping off the limbs of suspected opponents. Mr. Sankoh's arrest this week is therefore welcome news. It is imperative that he now be charged and tried for war crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, MAJ. BEN
description: ARKIN-Maj. Ben, USAR. NYCTA trainmaster. Devoted husband, loving father, grandfather, 88, May 8, peacefully at Hebrew Home, SF, CA. Memorial June 5, NYC.

title: Culling Trophies Of a Boom
description: Enough years have passed since the roaring 1980's that it's probably time for a television mini-series on the decade. And what would furnish the sets better than the antiques in the collection of the swashbuckling tycoon Saul Steinberg and his wife, Gayfryd, who are selling most of their decorative arts collection at Sotheby's next Friday?

title: When Every Child Is an Only Child
description: Last Saturday, my husband and I had the rare pleasure of seeing our three children play together for several hours. By some freak of nature, no dance lessons or softball games, no play dates or house guests, no errands or work deadlines intruded.

title: Advertiser Shuns Talk Show As Gay Protest Gains Power
description: For years, the Paramount Television studio has been left out of the riches of daytime talk television as shows starring Oprah Winfrey and Rosie O'Donnell became wildly popular.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the artist Al Hirschfeld against his dealer, Margo Feiden Galleries, referred imprecisely to its payments to him. The contract stipulated that the gallery owner, Ms. Feiden, must pay Mr. Hirschfeld an annual minimum of $12,000 if the contract was to be renewed. Her payments this year have been more than that sum, not equal to it.

title: Phillips Tries Again and Now Succeeds
description: Bernard Arnault is not a man who makes the same mistake twice. Ever since LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton bought Phillips Auctioneers in October, Mr. Arnault, its chairman, has been determined to make the house -- a distant third to Sotheby's and Christie's -- a major player in the art world. Last week, Phillips's first evening sale of important Impressionist and modern art was something of a disaster: about 40 percent of the works went unsold.

title: Reining In Patronage
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Selects National Squad
description: The coach of the United States men's national team, Bruce Arena, selected a 22-man squad yesterday for next month's Nike U.S. Cup. The team is evenly split between European-based players and those playing in Major League Soccer.

title: To Sweep Those S.U.V.'s Off the Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Take the Money and Run? Nah, She Wants Class and Culcha
description: Artistic ingenuousness is something that's difficult, if not impossible, to fake. That's one reason why Woody Allen's silly new comedy, ''Small Time Crooks,'' is such a pleasantly surprising little treat. In this sweet, funny wisp of a movie, Mr. Allen shucks off his fabled angst and returns in spirit to those wide-eyed days of yesteryear, before Chekhov, Kafka and Ingmar Bergman invaded his creative imagination. As willfully goofy and freshly scrubbed as Mr. Allen's 1969 directorial debut, ''Take the Money and Run,'' it suggests that that once a naif always a naif, that at the core of Mr. Allen's sensibility persists an inviolable strain of innocence.

title: Social Security, as Seen at 19 and 65
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is not the right time for me to run for office. If it were six months ago or it were a year from now or the timing were a little different, maybe it would be different. But it isn't different and that's the way life is.''

title: Web Sites Offer Cheaper Gas
description: THE Internet has changed the ways that people order new cars and bid on old ones. Now Web entrepreneurs are out to change the way you fill your gas tank.

title: In Pirro Trial, Employees Say Some Errands Were Personal
description: In meticulous and often personal detail, federal prosecutors fleshed out their tax fraud case today against Albert J. Pirro Jr., summoning a parade of contractors and employees who said they had performed chores for Mr. Pirro and his family but had been paid by his companies.

title: A Faux Pas? Get Over It!
description: Five years ago, at a stationery store on the Left Bank, I picked up a copy of Paris Match, fished in my pants pocket for some francs and walked toward the counter, a smile of fear frozen on my face. As my brain locked, I croaked out this sentence to the old woman at the counter:

title: CANADA'S INFLATION FALLS
description: Canada's inflation rate dipped in April to an eight-month low of 2.1 percent, down from 3 percent in March. The inflation number was lower than expectations and could make it difficult for the Bank of Canada to match any further interest rate increases applied by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States. Timothy Pritchard

title: 'I Saw Stars'
description: Momenta Art

title: STRONG PROFITS AT CANADIAN BANKS
description: Canada's two largest banks -- Royal Bank of Canada and the TD Bank Financial Group, both based in Toronto -- reported record second-quarter profits. Royal Bank posted a 30 percent increase in profit to 562 million Canadian dollars, or $393 million. TD Bank, which fattened its asset base by 30 percent with the purchase of Canada Trust last year, earned 537 million Canadian dollars, or $376 million, reported profits were up 50 percent. TD's chief executive, Charles Baillie, called the results ''a defining quarter,'' because of the strong earnings and inclusion of Canada Trust.

title: A Place to View the Gems of Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ELECTRONIC FISHBOWL
description: Coming to TV this summer: real people who live under round-the-clock surveillance. A confessional culture meets up with the Internet, and exhibitionism becomes an extreme sport.

title: In Crisis, a Changed Man
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has often been called operatic, but little in his past prepared the audience for yesterday's performance. It was a new character on stage: vulnerable, affectionate, introspective, indecisive, apologetic to his enemies, more concerned with being ''better as a person'' than winning a political fight.

title: NYT Article
description: Motorola Sees Asian Mobile Internet Growth

title: Switching Composers Midstream
description: Vladimir Feltsman has an extraordinary talent for recreating himself -- or at least, for toppling the expectations of listeners who think they have him figured out. When he came to the United States in 1987, in a blaze of publicity centering on his long fight to be allowed to leave the Soviet Union, he was encouraged to focus on the Russian repertory, apparently on the theory that this is what Russian pianists are meant to do.

title: Mr. Giuliani Stays at City Hall
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's announcement yesterday that he is bowing out of the Senate race against Hillary Rodham Clinton marked a decision that, once revealed, feels both correct and inevitable. But no one could have predicted as recently as a few weeks ago the degree to which the mayor who asks and gives no quarter would turn his withdrawal press conference into an existential meditation on life, love, mortality and priorities. It was, in its way, as extraordinary a political moment as the Bryant Park press conference of May 10, when Mr. Giuliani acknowledged the emotional impact of his cancer diagnosis and surprised the city, and his wife, by announcing the end of his 16-year marriage.

title: Tasting Early Williams With the Bar Stools Full
description: A revival of ''Small Craft Warnings'' opened last summer for a brief run at the TriBeCa Playhouse. It reopened there on May 9. Following are excerpts from Peter Marks's review, which appeared in The New York Times on July 1, 1999.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Sports of The Times; In the End, Ewing Is the One
description: IN the wee hours of a new day, a large throng milled around the stands at Madison Square Garden, trying to get a peek at the hero of Game 6, maybe even give a cheer. Patrick Ewing does not get many ovations these days. But now, in the joy of the moment, after the Knicks' 37-year-old center had so clearly been the one to keep the Knicks' season from expiring, there were all these Knicks fans who felt they had to linger and watch Ewing being interviewed on the court.

title: Trade Deficit For March Hit $30.2 Billion
description: The United States trade deficit widened to a record in March as surging demand for oil, automobiles and other imports overpowered a second consecutive monthly increase in exports, government figures showed today.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; PRAISE FOR MEXICAN POLICY
description: The International Monetary Fund's new managing director, Horst Kohler, praised ''the clear direction of the economic, financial and monetary policy'' of Mexico and said he did not foresee economic turmoil as a result of presidential elections on July 2. Mr. Kohler said the economy was much stronger than it was during presidential changeovers in the last two decades, which were followed by financial instability. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: The Met Cancels Exhibit On Chanel
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Thursday that it was canceling for now a proposed retrospective of the work of Coco Chanel, the French fashion designer, after weeks of increasing internal debate about the exhibition. It was to be the highlight of the Costume Institute's fall schedule, as well as the backdrop to its glittering annual gala.

title: IMPROVED OUTLOOK FOR SOFTBANK
description: Japan's largest Internet investor, the Softbank Corporation, more than doubled its forecast for its annual earnings, partly because of a rise in the value of its stake in a computer network design company and an improved profit outlook for its Softbank Finance Corporation unit. The company, led by the billionaire Masayoshi Son, said it expected net income of 8.5 billion yen ($78.2 million) for the year that ended on March 31, up from its previous forecast of 3.5 billion yen.

title: Cannes Journal; Cannes and Asia: It's Love at First Sight
description: The evidence after a week and a half of the Cannes Film Festival is that the usual excess, the hype, the anxiety, the strenuous star-studdedness of this annual event can coexist rather comfortably with what the French would call a serious cinematic sensibility. Serious is a serious word in this country, a word that suggests a willingness to do the hard job, to take pains, to be not just flashy but also good. So far it's been a serious festival, a festival where, contrary to custom, no big-budget Hollywood film was included in the official competition, even though the festival directors are said to have tried unsuccessfully to open this year's event with the ''Mission Impossible'' sequel starring Tom Cruise.

title: Robert Stone, 81, Actor and Teacher
description: Robert W. Stone, an actor and teacher, died on May 11 in New York. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: What's Love Got To Do With It?
description: How many moralists can dance on the head of a pin? The more the merrier.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RALLIES. The yen hit a three-week high against the dollar on speculation that the Bank of Japan might abandon its zero interest rate policy. In New York, the dollar traded at 106.73 yen, down from 108.70 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, DR. HERMAN
description: WECHSLER-Dr. Herman, on May 18, 2000, at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Rosalind. Devoted father of Michael and Joyce, and Robert and Sally. Proud grandfather of Rabbi Deborah, Steven, Stuart and Stacey, Daniel, Lisa, Jay, Jordan, and Matthew. Past President of the Genesis Hebrew Center, Founding member of the Albert Einstein College Hospital, dedicated physician, and decorated Captain in the United States Army, 1941-1945. Service Sunday, May 21, 1:30pm, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Rabbinical College of the Jewish Theological Seminary.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the war between Ethiopia and Eritrea misstated the title of Ethiopia's leader, Meles Zenawi. He is prime minister, not president.

title: Jones Wins In Return, With a Lift By Piazza
description: It had been 13 months since Bobby J. Jones's last victory, and holding runners was not a priority. The Mets right-hander sat out most of last season with a shoulder injury, and he went down with a calf strain after three forgettable starts this year. The game plan last night was simple: hold runners on as well as possible, but concentrate on making quality pitches.

title: Lawsuit Says 35,000 Drank Water Tainted By Carcinogens
description: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against a chemical manufacturer on behalf of up to 35,000 people who drank water contaminated with cancer-causing chemicals from public wells in Toms River, N.J., during the 1960's and 1970's.

title: N.R.A. Planning Restaurant And Arcade in Times Square
description: The National Rifle Association plans to open a theme restaurant and a game arcade in Times Square, a move that has outraged gun-control advocates and astonished redevelopment officials.

title: A Year After Victory, Barak Fights on Many Fronts
description: A week that began in violence ended violently here, with bloody clashes in the West Bank and Gaza and intensified fighting in southern Lebanon.

title: Rethink Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Understudy Lazio Is Thrust Into the Starring Role
description: When Rick A. Lazio, the Long Island congressman, first began mulling a bid for the United States Senate last year, his biggest drawback was perceived as his lack of name recognition in a race that was fast becoming defined by celebrity and star quality.

title: Melancholy Reflections On the Lot of the Exile
description: The young German baritone Matthias Goerne assembled a moving if unusually melancholy program for his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, the first of two concerts that are part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series. (The second is tomorrow.) His theme was exile, and at the heart of the program were selections from Hanns Eisler's ''Hollywood Liederbuch,'' with a selection of dark-hued Schubert songs woven around them.

title: Army Training School to Rise Again, Recast but Unmoved
description: Dogged by years of controversy over its mission and its graduates, the Army's School of the Americas is on the verge of getting a new charter, a new curriculum and a new name. It appears likely, however, to face the same old protests.

title: As Usual, Yankees Feel At Home in Indians' Park
description: Laughter echoed from the other half of the Yankees' clubhouse before tonight's game. ''Look at Knoblauch,'' David Cone said, pausing in his conversation.

title: Lazio Was the Main Choice For Pataki From Beginning
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to drop out of the Senate race today may or may not turn out to be good for New York Republicans. But for one top Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, there was no such ambiguity.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DRKOOP.COM INC., Austin, Tex., the Internet health company, said it had laid off about 35 percent of its staff since the beginning of April.

title: How to Be a Cool Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Brooke Ellison, a quadriplegic who is to graduate from Harvard next month, included an erroneous surmise from the university about the achievement. Harvard now says Ms. Ellison is not the first such graduate; it has identified two other quadriplegics who earned bachelor's degrees.

title: Guatemalan Squatters Torching Park Forests
description: The distant roar of howler monkeys echoed like a ghastly dirge on a recent day in the smoldering remains of a thick forest of palms, cedar and mahogany. Illegal loggers had cut down the best trees and hauled them off at night, while land-starved peasants torched what remained to clear the land for cornfields.

title: Partisan Battling on Census Resurfaces
description: Partisan vitriol dominated a House hearing on the census today, with Republicans suggesting that the Clinton administration was trying to manipulate the count to benefit Democrats, and Democrats insinuating that Republicans did not want to count members of minorities.

title: Solitary Republican Senator Blocks Peacekeeping Funds
description: A Republican senator has singlehandedly blocked the United States from paying $368 million that it owes the United Nations for four difficult peacekeeping missions, infuriating the Clinton administration and some of its allies.

title: THOMSON CHAIRMAN TO RETIRE
description: Kenneth Thomson, ranked No. 15 on the Forbes magazine list of wealthy people, said he would retire within two years as chairman of the Thomson Corporation of Toronto. The Thomson family owns 73 percent of the company, an electronic publishing concern that accounts for most of the family's estimated wealth of $20 billion. Mr. Thomson, 76, has asked directors to name his son David, 42, as his successor. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Serb Opposition Leaders Going to Moscow to Ask Putin's Help
description: The leaders of Serbia's political opposition finally emerged from their private meetings and spoke to their supporters tonight, telling a rally of fewer than 5,000 people that they would fly to Moscow next week and ask Russia to help moderate the policies of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Gritty Knicks Roll a Seven
description: The instant the serene Allan Houston calmly put down two free throws with 17.6 seconds left on the clock, there was an explosion of noise from the amazed witnesses to an improbable comeback.

title: GIULIANI QUITS RACE FOR SENATE, AND G.O.P. RALLIES AROUND LAZIO
description: New York State Republicans rushed to ensure that the party could still mount a serious challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton following Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's protracted exit from the Senate contest yesterday. They rallied around the candidacy of a little-known Long Island representative as they contemplated a race whose every dynamic was altered in the space of a single afternoon.

title: Traveling On the Wings Of the Dollar
description: Just before his wedding in 1985, Mark Lesser priced a honeymoon in Paris. Even though the dollar was stronger then than at any time since the early 1970's, the trip was out of the question.

title: U.S. Court Upholds Limits On Size of Cable Operators
description: A Federal appeals court upheld today the constitutionality of a law that sets limits on the size of a cable company. The ruling strengthens the hand of the government as it completes its review of the largest merger in the cable television industry.

title: As Convention Opens, N.R.A. Sounds Defiant Note
description: A week after hundreds of thousands of mothers demonstrated for gun control in the nation's capital, thousands of gun owners gathered here today for the National Rifle Association's 129th annual convention, vowing to fight new firearms restrictions and threatening to carry their pro-gun sentiments into voting booths this fall.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about Marcus Camby of the Knicks in Wednesday night's game against the Miami Heat misidentified the Heat player scoring against him. It was Clarence Weatherspoon, not Tim Hardaway.

title: NYT Article
description: Surprising Criticism at World Bank Site

title: European Cities Of Two Minds On One Bourse
description: The pioneering merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges is running into heavy resistance in both cities.

title: Mrs. Clinton Wishes an Ex-Rival Well and Forges Ahead
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton faced a delicate political balancing act yesterday in reacting to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's withdrawal from the Senate race: she sought to offer compassion to the mayor, while at the same time seeking to portray a business-as-usual agenda of campaigning.

title: Despite a decline of Protestant denominations, a new report finds there's room for optimism.
description: The death of distinct Protestant denominations has been, it appears, greatly exaggerated. For some while, the very notion of denomination -- Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians, Episcopalians, Lutherans and so on -- has been viewed as theologically fuzzy and sociologically doomed.

title: Harlin Quist, 69, Publisher of Children's Books
description: Harlin Quist, a publisher of sophisticated childrenHarlin Quist's books, died last Saturday at the home of a niece in Minneapolis. He was 69.

title: After '63 Bombing, Hard Lives for Suspects
description: Thomas E. Blanton Jr. should not get claustrophobic in his cell in the Jefferson County jail. At 8 feet by 10 feet, it is roomier than the ramshackle 5-foot-by-10-foot trailer in nearby Fultondale where he lived before surrendering on Wednesday to murder charges related to the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham.

title: John Sawhill, Ex-N.Y.U. Chief Who Led Conservation Group, Dies at 63
description: John C. Sawhill, a former president of New York University who advised three presidents on energy policy and for the last decade of his life was president and chief executive of the Nature Conservancy, died on Thursday at a hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 63 and lived in Washington and Virginia.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee for July delivery rose 3.85 cents, or 4.1 percent, to 97.95 cents a pound, after the world's largest growers approved an export-reduction plan aimed at bolstering prices.

title: INSIDE
description: Gun Owners Promise a Fight

title: Taiwan's New Leader Ends Decades of Nationalist Rule
description: Chen Shui-bian was sworn in as president of Taiwan this morning, a landmark for Taiwan's democracy but the start of a risky period in relations between this prospering island of 23 million people and a strengthening Chinese mainland that claims Taiwan as its own.

title: Mother's Account Conflicts With Grim Details of Severely Disabled Girl's Death
description: New details emerged yesterday about the last months and hours of a tiny, severely disabled 5-year-old girl who was discovered dead in her family's Bronx apartment Wednesday morning, but investigators were still scrambling to answer the central questions surrounding the death: just how well the child's mother had cared for her, and whether the city's child welfare agency had taken adequate action to protect her.

title: China Watchers Fighting A Turf War of Their Own
description: If business and political leaders have focused on China in recent months, so too have the intellectuals and others who make up the American ''strategic class'' -- that collection of academics, commentators and policymakers whose ideas help define the national interest. Yet unlike traditional Sinologists, who have made a broad study of China's complex history, intricate culture and social relations, this new crop of experts are preoccupied with a much narrower question: Will China be the next enemy?

title: Stock Prices Fall as Fears of More Interest Rate Increases Grow
description: United States stock markets suffered another down trading session yesterday as investors became increasingly afraid that the Federal Reserve plans to raise short-term interest rates through the summer.

title: Missiles and Snowballs
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Poets to Work Making Startling Images
description: Ariane Anthony took on Wallace Stevens and Samuel Beckett in ''Why Imagine Golden Birds?,'' a program of new and recent dances Ms. Anthony presented on Monday night at the Construction Company studio. Stevens is one of the least corporeal and most metaphorical of poets, with Beckett not far behind. But Ms. Anthony is a young choreographer of rare imagination and sureness. The dark iconic birds and coolly charged landscapes of Stevens's ''Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird'' came alive in purely physical terms, as did Beckett's ''man who saw himself rise and go'' in the prose poem ''Stirrings Still.''
