title: At Sarah Lawrence, a Hero for 6th Grade
description: Rain pattered on the wide tent as 33 Brooklyn sixth graders from Public School 93 in Bedford-Stuyvesant sat quietly in rows, waiting for their big moment. After a seemingly endless list of names, it finally came. They jumped out of their seats and cheered, clapped and waved toward the podium.

title: Steelers Penalized For Pay Violations
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers lost their third-round pick in the 2001 draft and were fined $150,000 by the National Football League yesterday for violating salary cap rules with the retired offensive tackle Will Wolford.

title: Schoolteacher Accused In Sex Abuse of Student
description: A teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested Thursday night and accused of sexually abusing one of her students.

title: Sports of The Times; Trainers Seek a Hope To Emerge, in Theory
description: IF there is one thing that unites all racing people, it is the fervent prayer that their stagnant industry will develop a great four-legged hope, a Michael Jordan or Wayne Gretzky of the equine set.

description: Egreetings Stock Jumps on Microsoft Pact

title: Virus is Less Widespread but More Dangerous : A Deadly 'Love Bug' Cousin Is Infesting Computers
description: NEW YORK  An uglier cousin of the so-called computer "love bug" circulated around the world on Thursday and Friday, and though the number of computers affected by the new program seemed far less than the estimated 45 million hit by its predecessor, the results were much more dire.

title: Miller's Return to the Pacers Forces Out the 76ers
description: The return of Reggie Miller marked the end of the Philadelphia 76ers' season. Led by Miller, who returned from a one-game suspension to score 25 points, the Indiana Pacers advanced to the Eastern Conference finals by eliminating the Sixers, 106-90, tonight in Game 6 of their playoff series. By winning the four-of-seven-game series, 4-2, Indiana will make its third consecutive trip to the conference finals, against the winner of the Knicks-Miami Heat series.

description: The Pentagon has classified as secret an antimissile critic's letter to the White House, and the censored expert is crying foul.

title: Wire, Together Again, Returns to Its 70's Roots
description: Hindsight has struck Wire, the English band that formed in 1976, broke up in 1980, regrouped in 1985 and dissolved in 1990. Bypassing two decades of dabbling with synthesizers, Wire is touring in its original configuration of two guitars, bass and drums.

title: Court and Congress
description: Today's conservative critics often condemn as undemocratic the Supreme Court's power to hold legislative actions unconstitutional. Former Judge Robert Bork has gone so far as to propose, in the name of democracy, that all Supreme Court decisions be subject to reversal by majority votes in Congress.

description: A day after withdrawing from the Peruvian presidential contest, Alejandro Toledo called for peaceful demonstrations against the government to discredit the vote scheduled for May 28.

title: Trials for the Khmer Rouge
description: Two decades after the Khmer Rouge killed more than a million Cambodians, surviving leaders of the terror may finally be prosecuted for their crimes. The United Nations recently reached an agreement with the government of Cambodia that could establish a credible judicial process for handling the cases. The court would be in Cambodia and require the cooperation of the Cambodian leader, Hun Sen, who had been seeking to cripple any prospect of independent justice. He has now agreed -- orally at least -- to substantial safeguards against his ability to manipulate the trials.

title: Brodeur Recalls a Game He'd Just as Soon Forget
description: Good goalies can have bad games, as Martin Brodeur of the Devils demonstrated in his most recent outing. The question -- and perhaps the key to the Eastern Conference finals -- is how well he responds to the next challenge.

title: CANCER IS CONCERN
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani withdrew from the most celebrated Senate race in the nation yesterday, saying that his health and his still-undecided treatment for prostate cancer were more important to him than his campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Excerpts From Giuliani's Remarks on Decision to Withdraw
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's announcement yesterday at City Hall of his withdrawal from the United States Senate race, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: On Settling Old Scores With Friends
description: Nine former friends reunite for an evening of reminiscences in which old scores are settled and new romances nearly bloom. Sound familiar? ''Seduction,'' a ''dance-opera'' presented on Wednesday night at Marymount Manhattan Theater, is the child of ''Contact'' and ''Follies.'' But the performing is so good and the staging so sleek that it all seems fresh again.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT MAY SELL OVERSEAS COMPANIES
description: Waste Management Inc. is in talks to sell its waste operations in Britain and Sweden to Severn Trent P.L.C. and an unidentified investment firm, its chief executive, Maurice Myers, said yesterday. Severn Trent is Britain's second-biggest water utility. Waste Management's British unit may sell for as much as $725 million, said Stewart Scharf, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Equity Group. He did not estimate the value of the Swedish business. Waste Management is selling all of its operations outside North America, as well as some on the Continent. The Houston-based company has agreed to $1.3 billion in asset sales this year and expects to use most of the proceeds to reduce debt.

title: Financier Uses Scholarships To Spur Action
description: In a drive to fill all of the 7,500 empty seats in parochial and private schools in New York City, a philanthropic organization co-founded by Theodore J. Forstmann, the billionaire financier, has offered $50 million in new, partial scholarships to underprivileged children for this fall.

description: Cherie Blair, 45, the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair, 47, gave birth to a baby boy at a London hospital early today.

title: The Lovely Linda, Camera in Hand
description: First we hated her for marrying Paul. She wasn't beautiful enough; she wasn't famous; she was American, for heaven's sake. Later we hated her for breaking up the Beatles (with Yoko's help), then joining her husband's new band when it was clear she couldn't sing, and wasn't she just a little too self-righteous about those vegetarian cookbooks and her work in animal rights? Then, two years ago last month, she died of breast cancer at the age of 56 and we made her a saint.

title: Korean Traders Want Their Lunch and Time to Eat It, Too
description: Workers in South Korea are known for their not-infrequent strikes over issues like pay and job security. But a coming showdown with the Korea Stock Exchange will be the first time they have threatened to strike over the right to have a lunch break.

description: RAMOS-Paul. The Ryan Community Health Network is deeply saddened by the sudden loss of Paul Ramos. For the past two decades, we worked together in the struggle to provide affordable, quality health services to our patients. He was a tireless advocate for the underserved in our communities. Our hearts go out to Roni and his daughters, and everyone at Betances. He will be missed. Julio Bellber Barbra Minch Kathy Gruber

title: Maryland and Princeton Gain Final With Routs
description: Alison Comito snaked along the ridge of the crease in short jagged bursts, as though she were using the Loyola defenders for footholds, scaling the arc of their craggy defense. Then she found her balance.

title: WESLEY JESSEN VISIONCARE OPPOSES TENDER OFFER
description: The board of Wesley Jessen VisionCare Inc. recommended yesterday that shareholders refuse the $35.55-a-share hostile offer from Bausch & Lomb Inc. Bausch & Lomb initially offered $34 a share for Wesley Jessen in March and raised the offer to its current level on May 8. Wesley Jessen said its board was still in discussions with other parties to consider alternative deals. In addition, Bausch & Lomb sued to block Wesley Jessen's agreement to buy Ocular Sciences Inc., saying Wesley Jessen breached its fiduciary duties. Wesley Jessen has agreed to buy Ocular for $18 a share in a deal valued at about $900 million. All three companies make and sell vision lenses. Shares of Wesley Jessen rose $2.75, to $33.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: In Desperate Times, Anything Is Possible
description: The Knicks were desperate, playing for their season, doing anything to put the ball in the hole. Marcus Camby dunked in a rebound, Patrick Ewing drained a long jump shot from the right wing. The fans at Madison Square Garden, fed up and booing moments earlier, were now agog with noise and disbelief.

title: 'Frasier' Finale Upsets 'Millionaire'
description: Scoring one of the first noteworthy dents in the ratings armor of the ABC game show hit ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' NBC's ''Frasier'' won a smashing victory on Thursday night with its hourlong season finale. ''Frasier'' racked up a 22 rating, while ''Millionaire'' trailed far behind with a 12.2. (Each rating point represents just over 1 million homes.)

description: Detectives have arrested a Bronx man and charged him with killing a taxi driver during an argument over a parking space last Saturday, the police said.

title: American Tissue Purchase
description: American Tissue Inc., a closely held paper maker, said today that it had acquired CST/Star Inc. for undisclosed terms to add business forms and label paper to its line of office products. The closely held CST/Star had sales of $160 million last year and is one of the largest producers of business forms in the United States, according to American Tissue. CST/Star, which distributes branded and private-label paper, operates eight plants.

title: The Flying Horse Faces a New Challenge: A Trial by Water
description: The horse of the moment, Fusaichi Pegasus, was snugged down in his barn at Pimlico Race Course today on the eve of the Preakness, but one unexpected complication fell on him and his seven rivals: rain.

title: After a Victory, Ethiopia Looks Toward Other Fronts
description: It took three days for Ethiopian troops to battle their way into this town, and now that they have it, they are pressing deeper into Eritrea, denying with every step that they plan any long-term invasion of their neighbor and once-tight ally.

title: Nissan Loses $6.3 Billion in Fiscal Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's third-largest carmaker, reported today one of the biggest losses ever recorded by a nonfinancial company.

title: Four Mayoral Hopefuls Now on an Even Footing
description: They wished Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani well after he withdrew from the Senate race yesterday, but for a quartet of Democrats aspiring to replace him, the real news was the altered electoral landscape for next year, not this one. Or rather, the changed fortunes of Mark Green, the mayor-in-waiting who will now remain in waiting.

title: School Bands Play Up The Value of Surprise
description: Jazz, especially in New York, is a music of cool tact: the code of conduct among musicians and audiences is to remain impassive even when faced with ecstatic surprises. But it takes the annual Essentially Ellington High School Band Competition and Festival, put on by Jazz at Lincoln Center, to remind you of what live jazz can bring out of people before they acquire that outer layer: stomping, screaming, standing up and waving arms in the air.

title: NETERGY NETWORKS TO PURCHASE CLOSELY HELD UFORCE
description: Netergy Networks Inc., a provider of equipment for telephone and Internet-service companies, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held UForce for about $51 million in stock. Netergy will pay 3.6 million shares for UForce, which is based in Montreal. Netergy, based in Santa Clara, Calif., will also issue one million options. UForce, with about 85 employees uses the Java programming language to manage services for telephone, cable and wireless companies. UForce's technology lets telecommunications providers offer custom products that give access to voice mail, faxes and e-mail from one source, like a phone, computer or wireless device.

title: New Yorkers Lament the Political Matchup That Will Not Be
description: When asked about their mayor yesterday, New Yorkers were as rambunctious as the political landscape itself.

title: The Candidate Who Might Have Been: Jeanine Pirro
description: With Rudolph W. Giuliani bowing out of the race for the United States Senate, this could have been a day for Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, to savor, a day when she might have stepped into the limelight as the Republican Party's next best hope.

title: Dearborn Journal; Challenging Islamic Myth on Organ Transplants as Ailments Rise
description: Even now, six months after her decision, Najah Bazzy's family is still upset with her. Her 14-year-old daughter pleads with her to reconsider. Older relatives fear that she has offended God.

title: Bid to Remove Speaker Falters As Insurgent Loses Support
description: The daring attempt to depose the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly sputtered today as the man who orchestrated it acknowledged that his base of support had seriously eroded.

title: Court Rules Nude Photo Can Be Taken On the Street
description: In the most recent in a series of free-speech lawsuits involving the city government, a federal appeals court cleared the way yesterday for an artist to photograph a large group of nude people on a street in Lower Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about New York City children who were learning to ride horses misstated the surname of a student from Public School 118 in Queens. He was David Quintana, not Quinones.

title: Can This Guy Take the Heat? It Sure Looks That Way
description: THERE was a time say, two weeks ago -- when John C. Browne regarded the expression ''trial by fire'' as an apt metaphor for what he had endured as the director of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the government's leading nuclear weapons research center. From the day he stepped into the job a turbulent two and a half years ago, he had faced an extraordinary series of crises, from steep budget cuts, layoffs and an epidemic of safety problems to plummeting morale because of accusations that China had stolen weapons secrets from the laboratory.

title: Sather One Step Closer to the Rangers
description: After 24 years with the Edmonton Oilers, Glen Sather, the team's president and general manager, announced his resignation yesterday. The only question now is whether he will end up in New York or Phoenix, running either the Rangers or the Coyotes.

title: Experts Warn Of New Virus Hitting PC's
description: Antivirus software companies warned yesterday of potential damage from a new computer program circulating on the Internet, similar to but more malicious than the one that disrupted computer systems around the world earlier this month.

title: Tribute to Teri Thornton
description: A musical tribute to the jazz vocalist Teri Thornton will be held tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. at St. Peter's Church at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Ms. Thornton died on May 2 at the age of 65.

title: Cesare Valletti, 77, Tenor Of a Vanished Lyrical Style
description: Cesare Valletti, a lyric tenor whose performances Cesare Vallettiwere praised for their refinement and expressivity but who left opera in 1968 to run a family business that made him wealthy, died on Saturday in Genoa, Italy. He was 77 and lived in Milan.

title: China Suspends Web Site for Spreading Rumors
description: China Suspends Web Site for 'Spreading Rumors'

title: When a Cellist Is an Event, Others Play Accordingly
description: At the invitation of the violinist and conductor Jaime Laredo, who runs the popular chamber music series at the 92nd Street Y on Lexington Avenue, guest artists frequently join the core players for concerts. But there are guests and there are guests. And on Tuesday night one of the most respected elders of chamber music, the cellist Janos Starker, 75, participated in a program. Every time this important Budapest-born musician plays there is a sense of event in the hall. No doubt the choice of Schubert's late Quintet in C, one of the great works of the repertory, was made in deference to Mr. Starker, whose performances of the core Viennese masters have long been admired.

title: No More Beer in the Bleachers
description: There are 5,502 bleacher seats at Yankee Stadium, and beginning next Friday night, they will be a relatively inexpensive place to watch baseball but not a place to drink beer.

title: U.N. Expands Troop Limit For Mission In Sierra Leone
description: The Security Council today increased the number of troops allowed in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone by 2,000 and is likely to expand the force by several thousand more in the next week or two.

title: Big Board Reports 4.4% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange rose 4.4 percent in the most recent monthly period, the stock exchange reported yesterday.

title: Fire Renews Safety Concern Over Los Alamos Lab Waste
description: The fires that consumed nearly 50,000 acres of northern New Mexico, including parts of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, have raised new concerns over the buildup of nuclear and hazardous waste stored at the laboratory.

title: Directors Apologize for an Ad Actors Call Racist and Sexist
description: Ridley Scott, the director of ''Gladiator,'' the No. 1 movie at the box office, has apologized for a trade publication advertisement that has heightened tensions in a three-week-old actors' strike. The advertisement depicted the bare breasts of a black woman.

title: Trail Blazers Have Had Some Success Containing O'Neal
description: Shaquille O'Neal slowly lowered himself into a folding chair today and quickly enlightened everybody about what not to expect in the Western Conference finals. For the record, the center with the extra-large Superman tattoo on his left arm will not fly solo against the Portland Trail Blazers.

description: Dr. Alexander Sandor Nadas, who trained generations of pediatrDr. Alexander Sandor Nadasic cardiologists at Children's Hospital in Boston and at Harvard Medical School, died on Tuesday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 86.

title: For the Heat, It's a Familiar Feeling
description: The crowd at Madison Square Garden was surging forward last night, the sound reverberating in the ears of the Miami Heat players as the Knicks gasped their way to an improbable comeback in the final minutes. And it all looked familiar.

title: Firefighter Ignored Warning On Air Tank, Report Says
description: A fire captain who died of smoke inhalation last spring after searching a burning Queens home for a probationary firefighter disregarded a warning that his air tank was nearly empty and then collapsed from lack of oxygen, according to a Fire Department inquiry released yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Wednesday about new support for Vicente Fox Quesada, the leading opposition candidate in Mexico's presidential election, referred incorrectly to Federico Reyes Heroles, a political commentator whose views were cited. He is an independent political analyst who wrote that Mr. Fox would probably be elected president. He is not a politician, is not a member of PRI, the governing party, and has not endorsed Mr. Fox.

title: NATURAL MICROSYSTEMS TO ADD CANADIAN CONCERN
description: The Natural MicroSystems Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held InnoMediaLogic Inc. of Canada for $155 million in cash and stock. The deal would combine two companies that develop technology for phone calls over computer networks. InnoMediaLogic specializes in developing technology for digital subscriber lines, a way to use existing phone lines to send data at high speeds. Natural Microsystems said that it believed that use of that medium would grow exponentially over the next few years. Natural MicroSystems, based in Framingham, Mass., had $79.5 million in revenue last year. Its stock traded down $3.875 a share, to $61.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Looking in a Giant Mirror
description: Beppie Blankert's ''Double Track'' makes disorientation a pleasure. The Dutch choreographer has devised an amazing theatrical conjuring trick. As danced by two women, it astonished American audiences in 1988 at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N.Y. It proved equally surprising performed by two men.

title: Second Half of $363 Million Lottery Is Claimed
description: A brewer and his family collected their half of the $363 million Big Game lottery jackpot here today, after waiting nearly two weeks to identify themselves as one of two winners of the largest lottery prize ever awarded in America.

title: Stores Complain of Pressure To Shut for Malcolm X Rally
description: A march along Harlem's main shopping street in honor of Malcolm X yesterday drew criticism from some business owners who said they were pressured into closing for much of the afternoon by organizers of the event.

title: Siblings of Starved Boy Taken From Mother
description: Social workers took custody of a Brooklyn woman's two surviving children this week after the New York City medical examiner ruled that her 10-year-old son had died of starvation and dehydration.

title: Effort for Peace in Ulster Stumbling Over Symbols
description: Just as a breakthrough in the long deadlock over guerrilla disarmament is at hand, the Northern Ireland peace effort is falling back into the grip of politically charged symbols, which have often been as divisive as firearms.

She was 92 and lived in Bayside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, NELLY H.
description: WILSON-Nelly H. Suddenly on May 16, 2000 at age 63. Graduate of Hood College, MD, longtime resident of Forest Hills Gardens. Member of West Side Tennis Club. Survived by her husband, George, her son Alfred and daughter Christine. Funeral services private.

description: Imagine a Martian anthropologist coming to Earth, reading the tabloids, watching a couple of talk shows and taking in a few movies. He might well return to his planet persuaded that humans beings are a freak race beset by murder, rape, incest, kinky sex and the like.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC SELLING CONEMAUGH GENERATING STAKE
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company, known as Pepco, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 9.7 percent stake in the Conemaugh Generating Station power plant in New Florence, Pa., for $152.5 million. Pepco, which is based in Washington, agreed to sell the stake to the PPL Corporation, an electricity and natural gas company based in Allentown, Pa., and Allegheny Energy Inc., an energy company based in Pittsburgh. Pepco, which provides electricity to 700,000 customers in Washington and the Maryland suburbs, had $2.1 billion in revenue last year. The sale is part of Pepco's plan to divest itself of its generation assets. Final bids for the rest of its generation assets, which include four power plants in Maryland and Virginia, are due at the end of May.

title: Abner Levin, 88; Ran Store at Dawn of LP Era
description: Abner Levin, a music connoisseur and a former geAbner Levinneral manager of Sam Goody's record store in Manhattan, died on May 12 at a convalescent home in Hilo, Hawaii. He was 88.

title: A Clean Bill of Fare
description: The New York City Health Department's new Web site listing restaurants' sanitary violations gives the public information it has a right to know. Making it available to everyone should help force restaurants to become more vigilant in maintaining high standards of cleanliness. But the Web site also highlights problems with the city's inspection and reporting system.

title: PROXYMED TO CUT WORK FORCE 20% IN REVAMPING
description: ProxyMed Inc., a maker of software used by health care professionals, said yesterday that its top management had resigned and that it planned to cut the company's overall work force 20 percent in a major reorganization. The company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., had nearly 400 employees at the end of 1999. ProxyMed's chief executive, chief financial officer, chief operating officer, chief marketing officer and a senior sales executive all resigned. The company said its cost-reduction plan necessitated the resignations. Harold Blue will be interim chief executive. ProxyMed's desktop software and Web site allow physicians to exchange clinical and financial messages with payers, labs, pharmacies, suppliers and patients.

title: Hitting Where They Ain't With the Directed Nonlead
description: Inexperienced players who become nervous in tense competitive situations would be wrong to suppose that experts are immune from this problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAWHILL, JOHN C.
description: SAWHILL-John C. New York University mourns the passing of its 12th President, John Sawhill. He was a man of vision, wisdom and wide-ranging talents. He took office during difficult times, but through his genius for finance and administration, he was able to put the University on a sound footing and permitted to embark on the course that has brought it to the stature it today enjoys. He brought diversity to the University's leadership, and he created the culture that emphasizes the centrality of the Arts and Science. For what NYU is today, this community owes a great debt of gratitude to John Sawhill. We offer our deepest sympathy to his loved ones and many friends. He will be remembered in these halls with respect and admiration. L. Jay Oliva, President Martin Lipton, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: After Affirmative Action
description: California's decision in 1996 to outlaw the use of race in public college admissions was widely viewed as the beginning of the end for affirmative action at public universities all over the United States. But in the four years since Californians passed Proposition 209, most states have agreed that killing affirmative action outright would deepen social inequality by denying minority citizens access to higher education. The half-dozen states that are actually thinking about abandoning race-sensitive admissions policies are themselves finding that the only way to enlarge the minority presence in college without such policies is to improve dramatically the public schools that most black and Latino students attend.

title: Harcourt to Buy All of Medical Internet Site

The buyback, worth about $421 million at the current price, would provide shares for employee compensation programs and other corporate purposes, the company said in a statement. title: Portraying Africa By Its Own Rules
description: IN Jean-Pierre Bekolo's short film ''La Grammaire de Ma Grand-mere,'' the Senegalese director Djibril Diop Mambety deploys a bit of French wordplay to explain the productive tension at the heart of his work. ''My grandmother always tells me to contradict my grammar,'' he declares. ''Grandmother'' (grand-mere) stands for African ancestral wisdom, while grammar (the homonymous ''grammaire'') refers to the rules and techniques of moviemaking, a historically Western, paradigmatically modern art form. Like other great iconoclasts of film, Mambety revolted against the conventions of the medium in order to express his faith in it. And like many African artists and intellectuals who came of age in the decades after colonial rule, he was preoccupied with the politics of autonomy and cultural self-determination. His career -- interrupted by 17 years of silence and truncated by his premature death, from lung cancer, in 1998 -- consists of a series of attempts to recast ''grammaire'' in the voice of ''grand-mere.''

title: May 14-20; Kosovo Deadline Averted
description: The Senate defeated a measure to set a deadline for withdrawing American ground troops from Kosovo, averting a foreign policy setback for the Clinton administration. The Senate stripped a provision from a military spending bill that would have cut off funds for the 5,600 United States forces in Kosovo by July 1, 2001, unless Congress approved an extension. The White House said the measure would undermine the NATO operation in Kosovo. ERIC SCHMITT

title: Bad Traffic Is a No-Brainer For Bronx Science Officials
description: Parents and school officials at the Bronx High School of Science are concerned that the dangers from speeding traffic and construction on 205th Street between Goulden and Paul Avenues -- a stretch where several accidents have occurred recently -- will only become worse if nothing is done.

title: Bishop Egan Ordains 5 Priests in Solemn Mass
description: In his first liturgical act as New York's archbishop-elect, Bishop Edward M. Egan ordained five graduates of St. Joseph's Seminary yesterday in a solemn Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that began their lives as priests in a church ailing for new faces.

title: Rafting in the Dark
description: Anyone who watched the greenish videotape of bombs exploding during the Persian Gulf war and in Kosovo should be familiar with night-vision viewers, which allow soldiers to see in very low light. Now, ITT Night Vision, the primary producer of night optics for the armed forces, is offering models from $1,895 to $3,845 in outdoor-equipment stores for adventurers ready to battle the elements, instead of an enemy. The devices create the illusion of daylight by capturing and intensifying available light on an interior phosphor screen (like a video screen). Lakota River Guides rafting trips use the viewers for moonlight runs down the rapids of the Colorado River, and Texas River and Jeep Expeditions offers after-dark desert Jeep tours in Big Bend National Park, the better to spot cactuses and the occasional desert pig.

title: Jordan's Long Road To the Free-Trade Club
description: MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization.

description: Americans love to get fashion on the cheap. Even with the economy booming, they are snapping up more $4.99 cotton T-shirts and Indian print sundresses than ever.

description: Express bus service to Manhattan is speeding up. Ridership increased 60 percent citywide in the last two years, mostly on trips to and from Staten Island.

description: Four months after he rekindled the death penalty debate by imposing a moratorium on executions in Illinois, Gov. George Ryan now says he strongly doubts any inmates will be put to death while he remains in office.

title: MetroStars Overcome a Slow Start and Stun the Mutiny
description: The MetroStars blocked out a dreadful first half tonight and then shocked Tampa Bay in overtime when Petter Villegas rocketed a 25-yard shot past a stunned Mutiny defense and goalkeeper Scott Garlick for a 3-2 victory.

description: This is the season when many parents begin the perilous journey of getting their toddlers into the right preschool and face the possibility of their social and intellectual rejection. As applications for the fall of 2001 loom, two of New York City's veteran preschool directors, Marlene Barron, head of the West Side Montessori School, and Jean Rosenberg, founder and director of the Chelsea Day School, offer an inside view of the dreaded admissions interview.

description: Three different varieties of specialty foods can be found in shops that opened this spring on the western side of Second Avenue between 22nd and 23rd Streets. They are part of a strip of remodeled stores in the base of the co-op building at 235 East 22nd Street.

title: An Antique Galley For Lake Geneva
description: Maritime history buffs and the just plain curious have been trickling into the Lake Geneva town of Morges, Switzerland, for the past four years to witness an odd bit of living history -- the construction of a 17th-century-style galley powered in part by sails and up to more than 200 oarsmen.

description: AFTER being a forgotten word for two decades, ''antitrust'' is again a part of the government's vocabulary.

title: Not Yet 16, a Rutgers Grad
description: When 7,000 students at Rutgers receive their degrees on Tuesday, 15-year-old Shant Sarkuni will be there too -- the university's second-youngest graduate ever. He would have been the youngest graduate but his cousin, Hannes Sarkuni, who graduated in 1996, was 14 at the time. The third-youngest graduate was Hannes's brother Sehrope, who graduated from Rutgers last year at the age of 15 (at his graduation he was two months older than Shant is now).

title: The Electronic Fishbowl
description: On a sunny afternoon in the quiet den of her house in the Netherlands, Karin van Elswijk, a 40-year-old housewife and mother of three, enthusiastically re-enacts her captivity. She has pulled back her dark hair to highlight her striking green eyes, and if her glamour looks a bit studied -- the leather pants, leopard-print top and black suede boots -- it's because she has just returned from one of the many charitable events over which she now presides. ''After my last day inside the house, I couldn't eat for a week except for little bites,'' she says, fondly recalling the experience that made her a national celebrity in Holland. ''I was shaking terribly the whole time. The psychologist said it was a reaction to being locked up.''

title: TOYS 'R' US
description: Earnings of Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the nation's largest toy chain, rose for the first time in more than two years under its new chief executive's plan to increase sales. Profit from operations in the quarter, which ended April 29, rose 41 percent, to $24 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with net income of $17 million, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 7.1 percent, to $2.32 billion from $2.17 billion. The increase in profit was the first for the company, based in Paramus, since its third quarter in 1997. John Eyler, who joined Toys ''R'' Us as chief executive in January, is adding clothing to the toy stores, pushing exclusive products and stocking more top-selling items to lure back shoppers lost to Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other discount chains. Mr. Eyler was chairman of the rival F. A. O. Schwarz before joining Toys ''R'' Us, where he replaced Robert Nakasone, who quit in August.

title: Streetscapes/70th and 71st Street Between Madison and Park Aves.; How 7 Rear Yards Became a Secret Garden
description: BUILT as a group in 1929, seven contiguous houses facing 70th or 71st Street between Madison and Park Avenues were put up by the developer Alfred Rheinstein with restrictions to preserve their rear gardens as a unit. For him, the whole was greater than the sum of its parts. As the first owners left, fences went up, but the great, green interior of the block still remains an enclave of peace and beauty.

title: Our Towns; For Judges, Drug Laws Can Mean Having to Say You're Sorry

The dissident declared: ''I'm not condoning narcotic trafficking. I'm in total support of the enforcement of those laws. My mere position is sometimes we have to have some compassion in life.'' He ended by saying, ''It's a very unfair situation.''

title: Politics and Czech Art: The Party Isn't Over
description: THE black and white newsprint pictures looked like oversize ''wanted'' posters hanging on the wall of the Vaclav Spala Gallery on Narodni Trida, a main shopping street here. In fact, that's exactly what they were intended to be. The show, called the ''Gallery of Established Nomenklatura'' (''G.E.N.'') and subtitled ''Malik Urvi'' (a play on the Czech words for ''Little Whores''), was a set of three-foot-tall mug shots and potted biographies of Czechs -- some prominent, some less so -- whose careers first bloomed when they were members of the Communist Party during the country's 42 years of totalitarian rule.

title: Buy Predators To Eat the Aphids
description: Aphids are beginning to make their appearance on rose buds and the tender new growth of many plants. They are most efficiently controlled by predators like lady beetles, lacewings and syrphid flies, which can be purchased for release in the garden. They will stay as long as there are aphids to eat. If the beneficial insects can't keep up, a direct spray of horticultural oil will kill aphids and has little residual impact on predators. PATRICIA JONAS

description: Hundreds of millions of dollars set aside by the federal government to help provide health insurance to poor people leaving welfare remains unused because states have not claimed the money, a new accounting by the Department of Health and Human Services shows.

description: What does ''home life'' mean to New Yorkers? What objects, people and places evoke comfort and nostalgia? ''New York Inside Out,'' a photographic exhibit at the New-York Historical Society, explores these questions.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Williston Park, N.Y.; 'Happiness Homes,' Long Before Levitt

Chatlos had erected 1,000 one-family Dutch colonials on 40-by-100-foot lots in what became the village of Williston Park in 1926.

title: On Broadway, an Awning Gap

title: The Dass Effect
description: A full moon was rising on a windy winter night three years ago when Ram Dass was lying in bed in San Anselmo, Calif., trying to fix a book he was writing on aging and dying. He was 65, his hair had turned white and he had spent hundreds of hours working with people who were severely ill. He had completed a draft of the book, ''Still Here'' (to be published by Riverhead this month), but on that same day in 1997, his editor, Amy Hertz, had sent the draft back to him. She said it was ''too glib -- funny and interesting but not really getting to the heart of the matter.''

title: Ideas & Trends; Sonny Liston: He Never Knew What Hit Him

And so it is that Muhammad Ali, who easily dispatched Sonny Liston in the ring, may never beat him in the arena of popular mythology and public opinion. There, Liston may forever be bobbing and weaving, held up by the famous ''phantom punch'' that floored him in their heavyweight championship fight in 1965.

title: Feasts That Tantalize and Picnics to Go

Yet most of us automatically head back indoors when hunger strikes. But if you pack a picnic along with your book, you can savor more than just your trusty apple. And with so many portable possibilities in Westchester, the journey to the park could be as liberating as the picnic itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNDON, FRANK (MILO)
description: DUNDON-Frank (Milo). Born Hells Kitchen, New York City, 1942. Died May 15, at age 57, in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Loving life partner of Joyce Kravets, father of Donna, Bryan and Sandie Dundon, Marc, Robin and Susie Kravets, grandfather of Jahmila, Atiba, Michi, Taki, Ari, Melissa and Elijah. Milo/Frank will be sorely missed by a circle of friends, his colleagues at Prudential Securities and especially his family. A private memorial service was held in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Contributions in his honor may be made to an environmental or ecological organization in your community.

description: SOUND loves to revel in a summer night,'' said Edgar Allan Poe, though he was probably not thinking about the New York Philharmonic, which will give a free concert in Westchester this summer.

title: High Notes and a Whirlwind Pace
description: IN the same time that elapsed between the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, the countertenor David Daniels managed to race from New York to London, record Handel's opera ''Rinaldo,'' and make it back for his recital in Princeton tomorrow. The Decca recording was slotted in to follow his last performance (on Derby day) of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: In Place of Salsa and Merengue, Prayers for a Slain Livery Driver
description: As candles burned on the makeshift altar in the Torres living room, two dozen guests each found a way to help the prayer leader, Emilia Gomez, remember Jose Torres. A niece led an Ave Maria. A sister wiped away tears as she whispered inaudibly. An older neighbor concentrated deeply, the fingertips of his weathered hands held lightly together. A baby girl in a frilly pink dress made gargling sounds when she wasn't chewing quietly on her shiny black shoe.

title: Another Reunion of Mr. B's Diverse Progeny
description: DANCE Theater of Harlem celebrates its 30th anniversary this year. The classical ballet company was founded by Arthur Mitchell, a leading dancer with the New York City Ballet at the time, in response to the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, the founders of City Ballet, encouraged Mr. Mitchell to start the troupe.

description: BY now you know what happened at Daphne's wedding (or if, in fact, it took place) on the season's last episode of ''Frasier.'' And just where Ross, Rachel, Chandler and Monica stand in their relationships on ''Friends,'' at least until fall. But there are an abundance of season finales this week too - with the promise of a couple of weddings, at least one divorce, a political scandal at Gracie Mansion and one very scary baby sitter. Here are a few of the episodes ahead.

title: Adriatic Abundance
description: A FRESH breeze off the Adriatic sailed into my room, filling the curtains like spinnakers, and I was instantly awake. If I rose before dawn, I could explore the cobbled streets of Rovinj at first light and watch by the harbor while sunrise caught the old town in high relief: the ancient stone houses, all mass and texture, and the steep Venetian ones, all line and color, under the equal protection of a copper St. Euphemia, poised on her bell tower 200 feet in the sky.

title: The Ugliest American
description: Steven Erlanger's article (April 2) on Frank J. Ronghi hit our family hard. The Frank we know is loving and good.

description: BRICK and mortar is making a comeback. Elaborate brick and stone barbecue fireplaces are starting to appear in backyards around the region.

title: Parties Oil the Wheels of Art Sales
description: ON half a dozen nights in the last two weeks, tuxedoed men have whispered discreetly into telephones, and gavels have rapped down in brightly lighted rooms where the earnest business of the big spring art auctions was taking place.

title: Lisa Jacobson, Chris Jones
description: Lisa Anne Jacobson and Robert Christian Jones were married last evening by the Rev. Bruce Epperly, a Disciples of Christ minister, at Dumbarton House, a Federal-period house museum in Washington. Rabbi Lewis Solomon took part in the ceremony.

title: What's It All About? The Kids Know. Do You?
description: GOING to the movies used to be no big deal for kids. Many of us would see films the way we read books: because it never occurred to us not to. I remember walking, every Saturday, to the RKO or the Loew's on East 86th Street. There'd be a double bill, and no one was too particular about what was playing or what time it started. ''This is where I came in'' still had meaning then, and often it wasn't until the movie ended and began again that you learned what the title was. My friends and I saw every single movie that was made for us, and many that weren't. And later, we also occasionally sat upstairs in the balcony and necked and sneaked cigarettes, but that's another story. Or perhaps not.

title: Crime
description: ''Hot, fast and dangerous.'' Robert Crais's neat description of Modex Hybrid, an explosive compound used in missile launchings, applies just as well to DEMOLITION ANGEL (Doubleday, $24.95), a flammable techno-thriller with the kind of force that knocks out windows. In contrast to the casually plotted escapades of Elvis Cole, his preternaturally cool private eye, this out-of-series adventure pitches a volatile protagonist into a complex story in which a master bomber known as Mr. Red is targeting bomb technicians in a ''dominance game'' of destruction.

title: Telling the Truth, or at Least Most of It
description: WHEN the results of an annual honesty and ethics poll were released last fall by the Gallup Organization, I had just begun a stint as a college professor and was feeling quite smug. There among the 10 professions ranked most honest by the American public was my new calling, with 52 percent of respondents judging its honesty as high or very high.

title: The Alley Where It's Chic to Be Mundane
description: SO there you are lounging around your East Hampton mansion on a Saturday night. (Never mind how you got a Hamptons mansion; work with me here.) You're recovering from an overpriced meal at a restaurant filled with sleek waiters and outrageously dressed models. And you're looking for some action.

title: Corrections

title: Pigeons as Pawns in an Airborne War Game
description: ERIC ALICEA was admiring photographs of his award-winning Damascene pigeons when a flutter of feathers sliced the air, accelerated past the sales counter and smacked loudly into the plate glass window. A huge white King Homer pigeon had leaped from its perch inside the Maspeth Bird Store in a vain attempt to launch itself over the flat garage roofs of Flushing Avenue. Pounding the air with its heavy wings, it righted itself and flapped back to its nest in the rafters. ''I'm trying to train him to fly around inside the store,'' said Mr. Alicea, an employee. ''A few more of those and he'll learn.''

title: Muriel Maignan, Arden Wilkins
description: Muriel Maignan, a daughter of Camie and Ferauld Maignan of Brentwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arden Wilkins, a son of Jessie Wilkins of Washington and the late Wadell Wilkins. Msgr. Russell Dillard performed the ceremony at St. Brigid Church in Westbury, N.Y.

title: Brodeur's Struggles With Puck Come to Pass
description: Fortunately for the Devils, goalie Martin Brodeur played better last night than he did in the previous game. He made some good saves and some good clearing passes and said afterward that he ''kept my team in the game.''

title: May 14-20; Women and Stress
description: When humans encounter stress, they will, by instinct, choose ''fight or flight'' -- or so goes the accepted wisdom. The trouble is, that wisdom is based largely on the study of men. But guess what? According to a study in the journal Psychological Review, women are different. Instead of slugging or running when demons appear, they ''tend and befriend'' -- they stick together and nurture children. A good thing, too, the study suggests: it would have been an evolutionary disaster if no one had protected the young. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Corrections
description: The caption on May 7 with the Photographer's Journal picture, showing a cat sitting in an opening in an apartment door, misstated the name of the street. It was Blake Avenue in Brooklyn; there is no Blake Street.

description: The cat is out of the bag: Your boss knows you use the Internet on the job to shop and to plan your next Club Med vacation. But how is all that surfing affecting your work?

description: An oasis of calm -- in the form of a 105-acre wildlife reserve -- has been developed just seven miles from the bustle of the center of London. Opening Friday, the Wetlands Center has been created by the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, a conservation charity, around four unused reservoirs in Barnes, a West London suburb.

Loving mother of Bryan and his wife Margie, Jonathan, Jamie and her husband Adam, Ian and his wife Jodi, and her grandchildren Catherine, Sarah, Grant and Rick. Beloved daughter of Regina Kaufman and the late Herman Kaufman & sister of Lois Geller. Services 12:30 today from ''Boulevard Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Detroit Journal; Mexican Immigrants Lead a Revival
description: When he was a boy growing up in west-central Mexico, Jesus Lopez and his brothers would load agave leaves onto the backs of donkeys and haul them to factories to be converted into tequila. Along the way, he would dream of living in a place with electricity and abundant water.

title: SHUTTLE BUSES
description: New Jersey Transit announced last week that it will supply shuttle buses to Clifton, Secaucus, Rutherford, Glen Ridge, Maplewood, Orange, South Orange, Marlboro, Red Bank, Rahway, Edison, Metuchen, New Brunswick, Hackensack, North Plainfield and Old Bridge, plus Atlantic and Camden Counties. The 20-passenger vans, which will arrive next spring, will be used to transport commuters to and from train and bus stations. New Jersey Transit was awarded $3 million in federal transportation funds to buy the vans and is anticipating $3 million more next winter to expand the program. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Some Really Cool Stuff for a Day at the Beach
description: FOR most of us, beachfront property translates into that patch of sand where, for a fee paid at the guard's gate or in local taxes, we feather a waterside nest with appropriate creature comforts and settle in for a few precious hours. Everybody has developed their own set of beach rituals. Some go early, and stay all day. Others arrive late afternoon and watch the sun set and the moon rise. Some go to the same beach, same spot, year after year. You can hear cards being shuffled and dealt to a foursome sitting cross-legged on a beach blanket, or you can hear salsa music throbbing from a tape player off in the distance that gets your hips moving in your beach chair. Cooler lids pop on and off throughout the day. Grills sizzle. The water's music is moderate, no crashing surf along the gentle Sound, just a pedal-point of water lapping, a little more loudly when a boat passes or the tide comes in.

title: DATABANK: May 15-19; How Much Higher Can Interest Rates Go?
description: Wall Street just couldn't shake its interest-rate jitters last week, even though the Federal Reserve did what many had expected when it raised interest rates for the sixth time since last June.

description: FOUR years ago my family and I spent part of the summer in Italy, hopping from one breathtaking Tuscan village to another. Two years ago we ogled Versailles and stood before the ''Mona Lisa'' at the Louvre. This year it will be the Tower of London and Hamlet at Shakespeare's Globe Theater along the Thames.

description: DEATH puts a pretty effective end to most human endeavors. But it will no longer stop us from e-mailing our friends and relatives, thanks to a new Web site, www.FinalThoughts.com. The site archives e-mail messages to be dispatched when subscribers shuffle off their mortal coils. A ''guardian angel'' notifies FinalThoughts.com of the subscriber's demise; the intended recipients receive e-mail notes to visit the Web site for a message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, PROFESSOR CHARLES A.
description: MYERS-Professor Charles A., an expert in labor economics, management, and education and development, died April 2, 2000, age 86, in Naples, Florida. Mr. Myers was a professor of economics and management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 42 years and author of more than 85 books and articles. He was born in 1913 in State College, Pennsylvania and graduated from Penn State University. He earned a Ph.D in economics from the University of Chicago. From 1942 to 1945 he served on the War Production Board and the War Labor Board; from 1957 to 1959 on the Federal Advisory Council on Employment Security; from 1960 to 1962 on the Presidential Railroad Commission; and from 1969 to 1971 on the National Manpower Policy Task Force. He was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, President of the Industrial Relations Research Association, and Charter Member of the National Academy of Arbitrators. His academic work included pioneering studies of U.S. labor markets; of comparitive labor relations in OECD and developing countries; and of the relationship between investment in education and the rate and nature of economic and social development. He leaves his wife of 63 years, Nancy (Nash); a son, Charles N. of Duxbury, MA; 2 daughters, Anne M. Forsyth of Midlothian, VA and Temson M. Ely of Amherst, MA; a sister Christine Ellenburger of Fairfield, CT; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Entertainment; Hollywood Wants A Bigger Box Office
description: The entertainment industry -- especially Hollywood -- has been enthusiastic about easing trade barriers with China and has been pushing hard for the trade bill. There are two reasons: China is a huge potential market, even if few American movies are now released there. And studios worry that rejection of the bill would prompt Beijing to spitefully cancel the fledgling trade agreements already in place.

title: In Some Things, Appearances Really Count
description: SOME say appearance is everything. How painstakingly the job of grooming is done determines the look and feel of the public places and hallowed spaces of summer, but also, more subtly, the quality of memories they make.

title: Political Briefing; Internet Addresses As a Political Tool
description: In the world of the Internet, it is known as cybersquatting -- the practice of putting down $75 to lay claim to an especially appealing or recognizable Internet address before another person or organization can, then offering to sell that address to the latecomer for a nice profit.

title: May 14-20; Peru Challenger Drops Out
description: Even though he is running neck-in-neck with President Alberto K. Fujimori in the polls, Alejandro Toledo dropped out of the runoff in Peru's presidential race, saying he could not win on a playing field fraudulently tilted against him. Mr. Fujimori apparently has a clear shot at winning a third five-year term unless Mr. Toledo and the international community put enough pressure on the government to postpone the May 28 runoff election until mid-June. CLIFFORD KRAUSS

The money, approved last week, will preserve at least 12,000 acres of farmland around the state either through outright purchases or by buying the development rights to farms. KAREN DeMASTERS

But like many actors, her bread and butter comes from television spots. She has played what she calls a ''very tacky Italian bride'' to sell Alka-Seltzer, for example, and a receptionist with a squeaky voice to promote the History Channel.

title: Walls That Talk, Vividly, of Healing Mercies

They do not perform examinations, and they do not dispense medicine. Instead, they offer comfort, mostly to children. Here a medical man in vest, starched collar and umber tie guides a blind boy in knickers. There a nurse props a sickly infant on her hip.

The cops told Piazza how too many kids from the area wind up joining gangs, selling drugs and forgetting that school exists. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAINWRIGHT, JANET PARSONS
description: WAINWRIGHT - Janet Parsons. Passed away on Sunday, May 14, 2000, just 10 days after her 80th birthday. She was survived by her four children, nine grandchildren, and three great grandchildren. She was very proud to have been a member of the LVIS, the Garden Club of East Hampton and the Colonial Dames of America. Contributions may be made to the LVIS or the East Hampton Library. There will be a celebration of her life on June 25, 2000 at her residence at 12 noon.

title: French Impressionists At the National Gallery
description: Many first-time visitors to Argenteuil have a sense of deja vu: they recognize parts of the small town on the banks of the Seine northwest of Paris from the many paintings Monet, Manet, Caillebotte, Renoir, Sisley and Boudin made there. More than 50 of those paintings can be seen in ''The Impressionists at Argenteuil,'' the first exhibition to focus on the second most important site, after Paris, in the development of Impressionism. It opens at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on May 28 and travels to Hartford this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGAN, EDWARD F.
description: DUGAN-Edward F. 65. Investment banker. Owner of Dugan Associates, Inc., an investment banking firm serving entertainment and media companies, died on May 19, 2000. The cause was complications from cancer, which he had been fighting for the past five years. At the time of his death, Mr. Dugan was a Director of S.F.X. Entertainment, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange company. Born in Jersey City, NJ, Mr. Dugan was a member of the 1952 St. Peter's Prep Basketball Team, which was nationally ranked and won the championships of Jersey City, Hudson County, the State of New Jersey and the Eastern United States. After graduation, Mr. Dugan spent two years as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army, stationed for a period of time at Governor's Island. While at Governor's Island, Mr. Dugan obtained his M.B.A. at night from the Graduate School of Business of New York University. In early 1961, he joined the investment banking department at Smith Barney & Co. He founded the firm's merger and acquisition department, headed up the new business department and was President of the firm's venture capital partnership. After 14 years at Smith Barney, Mr. Dugan left as a Managing Director to become President of Warburg Paribas Becker, an international investment banking firm partially owned by S.G. Warburg and Banque Paribas. In 1978, Mr. Dugan became a Senior Vice President and Director of Paine Webber. In 1980, he founded the firm's media and entertainment investment banking groups as a Managing Director. He is left by his wife Susan and their daughter Kelley, as well as three children from his first marriage, Jamie Casale of Basking Ridge, NJ, Edward of Westfield, NJ, and Kirsten Freeman of Bernardsville, NJ, as well as a brother, Robert, of Jacksonville, FL, and three grandchildren, Daniel, Erin and Edward IV. Visiting will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home on Sunday, May 21, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. There will be a funeral mass at St. Thomas More on Monday, May 22, 10 AM.

Beloved grandmother of Merissa, Lauren, Brian, William Jr. and Jonathan. Graveside services Sunday, May 21, 2000 at 3PM, Star of David, 7701 Bailey Rd, North Lauderdale, FL. description: 1. Case in point: ''Tiny Green Thumbs,'' a children's gardening primer (b) written by the gardening columnist C.Z. Guest -- the ''green-fingered queen,'' as Bruce Weber once described her -- for her grandsons. When young Gregory, Winston and Ivor visit at Templeton, Guest's house in Old Westbury, playtime is back to the earth. ''Oh, my God, they're such marvelous gardeners,'' Guest exclaims. This year, Ms. O'Donnell will be at her post -- at Radio City Music Hall -- on June 4. But concerns remain about the awards in general.

title: Strategies Bloom From Last Year's Drought

The absence of rain last summer acted as a two-edged sword, weakening plants but doing little to deter hungry deer, which are not choosy about whether their vegetation is served up moist or extra crispy. The parched days, dry winds, voracious varmints and watering restrictions created havoc in gardens all over the New York metropolitan region.

One minute the circular foyer is empty. The next, it contains a slight, straight-haired young woman, bare-legged below a slim black skirt, wearing red flip-flops and no apparent makeup. It's a dancer's entrance more than an actress's, both in its reliance on the eloquence of line and carriage and in its air of waiting for the music to begin. And though at 11 a.m. on a foggy May morning the cafe is nearly deserted, and the young woman unassumingly pretty and visibly pregnant, those heads that are present turn. It is suddenly no longer possible to be unaware of the difference between ''at rest'' and ''in motion.''

title: Fateful Attractions
description: Trouble is so much in the air in KICK IN THE HEAD (Doubleday, $22), Steven Rinehart's debut collection of short stories, that when, in the title story, one character reassures another, ''Everything's going to be fine,'' it registers as a particularly pathetic self-delusion. The speaker of the line is a college student fallen hard for a veterinarian. The trouble is that the doctor is a diabetic with a habit of neglecting her insulin shots. She's also a chronic drunken driver with a knack for plowing into people and property. She's also married to the student's film studies professor. Clearly, nothing about this arrangement will be fine. Some of the sharpest of Rinehart's stories are about men caught up in similarly inexplicable, often dangerous attractions: a Boy Scout's fascination with his unhinged tentmate; a high school teacher's obsession with a troubled student; a college dropout's love for his best friend's girlfriend. Rinehart has a talent for entering his stories in midstream, then revealing in small, unsettling ways just how badly things have already unraveled for his characters. A hitchhiker left stranded in the desert in ''Burning Luv'' seems worthy of sympathy until he reveals his previous experience with abandoning and being abandoned. Shortly thereafter, he casually produces a weapon, to chilling effect. A suburban insurance man in ''LeSabre'' seems merely inept until a calamitous Friday night exposes his own vulnerability. ''I'm not in control,'' he admits. ''I am miles behind.'' Rinehart's stories are full of such moments, offering a view into the ways a life can go wrong. Andrew Santella

A sense that things are done differently on island turf; an attention to old customs and legacies; a respect for nature and a husbanding of natural resources. You feel it in Sardinia and in Sicily and on Patmos. Imagine, though, feeling it on a river island, one connected to a major highway by a bridge not much longer than a freeway overpass.

It is a work so loved by so many that a lazy production is all that's needed -- hey, everyone knows the story anyway, and why even try to top Laurette Taylor, Maureen Stapleton, George Grizzard, Piper Laurie, Treat Williams and all the other great actors who have inhabited the play over the years?

title: A Hand-Rubbed Coffin At Double the Price
description: To the Editor: The article about funerals and caskets (''Big Box Stores, Redefined,'' April 30) was informative. Four years ago, a friend in her 80's called on the services of a funeral director somewhere in Ocean County when her husband died. The cost was about $4,000 without the plot. One year later, after a long illness, her son also died. She had the same funeral director. She lamented the fact that for exactly the same funeral, one year later, the cost had almost doubled. When she complained, the funeral director said this was not exactly the same funeral -- this time the casket was hand-rubbed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ABNER
description: LEVIN-Abner, 88, Music Retailer and Critic. Abner Levin, General Manager of Sam Goody's from its less than auspicious origins in a Ninth Avenue loft building in the early 1950's through its expansion to a half-dozen major metropolitan area outlets by the mid 1960's, died in Hilo, Hawaii on May 12 after a prolonged illness. Mr. Levin joined Sam Goody's at approximately the time the long playing record was introduced and it was under his direction that Goody's became the first retailer to stock long playing records in substantial volume and to market them at discounted prices. Described in a 1954 Collier's magazine profile as the man with the ''sharpest ears in America'', Mr. Levin was also a respected classical music critic who, in addition to co-authoring ''The Disc Book'', wrote an influential column for ''The Long Player'' record catalog (which he founded and edited). He is survived by his wife Flora, two sons, Robert and Andrew, a daughter, Jo, and a grandson.

title: Star Spelled Backward
description: APPROACHING Rat's for the first time, you might think you'd wandered into one of those senseless, antic dreams from which you wake up giggling. The road from Interstate 295, which seems headed for nothing more enticing than a wasteland of industrial parks on the bedraggled outskirts of Trenton, turns out to be lined with larger-than-life contemporary sculptures, including a superrealistic molar as big as a bungalow. Just when you think you've gotten hopelessly lost amid the corporate clutter, you find yourself on an island of greenery dotted with still more sculpture, much of it lifted from French Impressionist paintings. And a sign that says, ''Welcome to Rat's.'' Where on earth are you?

title: Rock Star Vs. Rock Fan: Who Matters?

It recalled a scene in VH-1's ''Behind the Music'' episode devoted to Oasis. That band's exceptionally grumpy singer, Liam Gallagher, fled a tour a while ago to help his wife buy a London flat. Accosted by a reporter who asked, ''Does this mean you matter more than the fans?'' Mr. Gallagher exploded. ''That's right!'' he screamed, peppering his tirade with expletives. ''I matter more!''

title: Seeking the Naked Truth, and Finding It Nearby

Worried that their father had a secret, the girls showed the picture to their mother, who said she knew all about it; their father had taken it before he was married. It was no big deal, their mother assured them. But then she warned her daughters never to pose like the woman in the picture.

title: Ideas & Trends: Chaos Theory; Harness Fire? Mother Nature Begs to Differ
description: AS the site of the secret workshops of the Manhattan Project, Los Alamos, N.M., is known to history as ''the atomic city'' -- the place where scientists harnessed nuclear power, building the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. The Cerro Grande fire, which burned on last week, was a reminder of how absurd it is to believe that mankind can ever harness a force of nature. Los Alamos learned to tap the power of nuclear energy. But it was brought to a standstill by a different kind of chain reaction: ordinary fire.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-21-00: Counter Culture; The Double-Life Crusade
description: You've got to believe that the old man, wherever he is now, enjoyed his own funeral Mass. The climax was Cardinal Bernard Law's eulogy to the career and mission of Cardinal John O'Connor. ''What a great legacy he has left us in his constant reminder that the church must always be unambiguously pro-life,'' Law said, his strong Brahmin voice resonating throughout the nave. And then, after a stunned pause, the applause grew, first from the back of the cathedral, then spreading to the front, as the assorted politicians found themselves rising uncomfortably to the occasion. I doubt if Cardinal O'Connor had ever made more people less comfortable in his lifetime. And it wasn't for lack of trying.

description: PEOPLE who remember the movies of the 1930's and 40's the first time around are always saying that today's explicit sex scenes aren't half as erotic as the subtle gestures of yesteryear. Feeling the electricity when Daniel Day-Lewis finally touches Michelle Pfeiffer's hand in THE AGE OF INNOCENCE (1993) makes the argument pretty convincing. It's Edith Wharton's story of 1870's New York society - a countess with a past, a true gentleman wildly attracted to her and his seemingly delicate baby fiancee (Winona Ryder in steel-magnolia mode), who simply isn't going to let that happen. If Martin Scorsese could make a film like this, why doesn't he direct more movies with pretty people and elegant fashions and gorgeous interiors? - Monday at 3:45 p.m. and Saturday at 2 p.m. on Showtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUITER, JAMES EVANS BUTLER
description: SUITER-James Evans Butler. Born September 8, 1914, at Williamsport, PA, to Albert Ezra and Hannah Rickard Suiter. Died May 7, 2000, at Monroe County, Georgia Hospital after a brief illness. He received his Bachelor of Laws Degree from John Marshall College of the Rutgers University in 1938. He received his Master of Arts degree from Rutgers in 1939. He received his Ph.D. from New York University in 1959. He was appointed a Counselor at Law by the State of New Jersey in February of '43 and served in several positions as a State appointed judge and magistrate. He entered the teaching field in 1960 and taught at Western Illinois University at Macomb, Illinois, and retired as a professor of English literature from Kean University in Union, NJ. He was a member of the Modern Language Association, English Speaking Union, Beaux Arts Alliance, Navy League, World Ship Society. He is survived by his daughter, Margarita Defore of Smarr, GA, and sons, A. Nicholas Suiter of Avis, PA, and Galen Suiter, Sr., of Coosada, AL, four grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Burial will be Monday in Lock Haven, PA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Rutgers Alumni Association, 732932-8808.

Dr. Schultheis, a graduate of the Lawrenceville School, Cornell University, and the Long Island College of Medicine. He was on the staff of Flushing Hospital and St. Francis Hospital. He served his country as Captain and Flight Surgeon from 1948-1950. Dr. Schultheis was an avid sailor, member and Fleet Surgeon of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, member of Shelter Island Yacht Club and Royal Bermuda Yacht Club. He will be greatly missed by his loving family, friends, patients, and colleagues. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Labor and the China Vote

Of all the groups lobbying on this issue, none has made a greater historic blunder than organized labor. By bludgeoning Richard Gephardt and the Democrats into sticking with labor on the issue, which the House is set to vote on this week, Mr. Sweeney is squandering much of the good will he has built up in recent years and damaging the interests of American workers. House Democrats should back the bill, which deserves bipartisan support.

description: If all continues to go well, the nation's capital will be allowed out of the intensive care ward fashioned by Congress sometime next year. The District of Columbia will not only regain home-rule prerogatives lost in its profligate past; it will also confirm the stewardship of Mayor Anthony A. Williams, an unlikely politician as bland in his style as the paint on the municipal walls.

description: A METAPHOR helps to explain what the ''marking down to market'' program is all about, said the housing official. Then he launched into an elaborate one.

title: The World; A Chance to Give Evil Its Rewards
description: FODAY SANKOH, the Sierra Leone warlord whose thugs made a tactic of hacking off the hands and limbs of children and others, ended the week a prisoner under the guard of British soldiers, but that is just the beginning of the story for the rest of the world.

title: The Award Theater People Hate and Love
description: FOR die-hard theatergoers -- the kind of devoted fans who gnawed their cuticles over the battle between ''Dreamgirls'' and ''Nine'' in 1982, or agonized over which actor from ''Two Trains Running,'' Laurence Fishburne or Roscoe Lee Browne, to root for in 1992, or pulled for ''Pacific Overtures'' to upset the popular favorite, ''A Chorus Line,'' in 1976 -- the Tony Awards have been as exciting as the Oscars.

title: Congratulations! Remember Me?
description: I HAVE never understood celebrities who wipe their eyes and lament the terrible cost of fame -- no privacy, no job security, never knowing if someone likes them for who they are.

title: Molly Rouse, Fabio Terlevich
description: Mary Paulding Rouse, a daughter of Emy M. Halpert of Philadelphia and Willard G. Rouse III of Phoenixville, Pa., was married on Friday to Fabio Terlevich, the son of Bianca and Luciano Terlevich of Buenos Aires. The Rev. Douglas Scott performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Martin's Church in Radnor, Pa.

title: Making Airports More Tolerable
description: IS there a nice place to eat here?'' I asked the Delta counter agent at the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport one afternoon last month. ''Next door,'' responded the agent, Linda Cartisano. ''Behind the Continental counter.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: COIN TOSS, LITERALLY
description: Patricia Dilks lost her opportunity to serve on the Pine Hill School Board by the slimmest of margins -- the width of a new Sacajawea gold dollar. On Tuesday, Ms. Dilks lost a coin toss to Mary Jane Oerhl, an incumbent, for the final seat on the nine-member board in the small Camden County town. Last month, Ms. Dilks and Ms. Oerhl tied with 177 votes for third place; three three-year seats were up in the election. According to the Pine Hill schools superintendent, Don Falato, neither woman wanted a recount, since it might cost them personally several hundred dollars, nor did they want a runoff election, which might have cost taxpayers as much as $3,000. So they settled on the coin flip. Ms. Dilks chose heads. County Superintendent Daniel Mastrobuono flipped. The coin landed on tails, and Ms. Oerhl was back on the board. ROBERT STRAUSS

title: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Pharmaceuticals; Approving Factories, But Not the Drugs
description: Pfizer will sell billions of dollars worth of Lipitor, its popular cholesterol-fighting drug, this year, but none of those sales will be in China.

title: Landmarking of a Wall Sculpture Hits Bricks-and-Mortar Opposition
description: A Landmarks Preservation Commission vote on the future of a wall sculpture was postponed Tuesday after the owner of the building involved submitted an engineers' report that the artwork could not be fully restored once some repairs were made.

title: Jasmine Ferrer, Jason Matthews
description: Jasmine Ventura Ferrer, the daughter of Lourdes Ventura Ferrer and Dr. Juan C. Ferrer of Princeton Junction, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Jason Daniel Matthews, the son of the late Anna Peacock Matthews and Dr. H. Allen Matthews Jr. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Navigating the Amazon Circle
description: Introduce a computer to a heap of raw data and the temptation to slice the information every which way can prove irresistible. One example is Amazon.com's purchase-circle program, which enables customers to see what books are popular among different groups. Apparently, the idea is that readers can learn the buying preferences of people with whom they might have something in common, or about whom they might be curious, and that one can glean insights into a place or company by seeing, for instance, that a top seller in Kenya is ''The Carbohydrate Addict's Lifespan Program'' or that in Hoboken, N.J., a number of people want to know how to put on a Jewish wedding.

title: Caveat Surfer
description: To the Editor: Regarding Bob Tedeschi's article, ''Web Air Deals: Caveat Surfer'' (April 16), I too was disappointed with a booking Web site, skyauction.com, which I used because it offered big savings. After ''winning'' an auction to a choice of 11 European cities, I was informed that none of the cities were available when I wanted to travel, because of space limitations in the class of service for which the site had contracted.

title: Beautiful People, Beautiful Feet?
description: What's your favorite place to go barefoot? Your best barefoot memory? Several well-known Long Islanders were asked where they let their feet hang out.

title: Marity Brody, Michael Smith
description: Marity Brody and Michael P. Smith were married yesterday by Msgr. Daniel A. Peake in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Simply 'Writer' Will Do
description: LAN SAMANTHA CHANG cringes when she's told she's the next Amy Tan or Maxine Hong Kingston -- that she is the next great female Asian-American writer.

title: Hampton Helps Himself as Mets Barely Hold On
description: The Mets' locker room emptied quickly last night. Nobody lingered for card games or a meal or to watch television. Nobody remembered to turn on the postgame victory music. It looked as if 25 players had escaped, and it's hard to blame them for wanting to flee the scene.

title: Commencements; Voice of the Dodgers Speaks, Humorously, to Fordham's Graduates
description: ''I'm not a military general, a business guru, not a philosopher or author; it's only me and I'm one of you,'' said Vin Scully, the sportscaster for the Dodgers since before they deserted Brooklyn, who avoided a weighty commencement speech yesterday and entertained Fordham University's class of 2000 with a series of humble anecdotes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 7 about Burt Lancaster referred incorrectly to the location of DeWitt Clinton High School, from which he graduated. It moved from Hell's Kitchen to the Bronx in 1929, before his senior year.

title: A Haider In Their Future
description: Haider's coalition came to power by popular vote in a democratic institution. Likewise, the coalition can be removed from power if so desired by the electorate. This is a key element of democracy. By placing sanctions against the Austrian government for fascist remarks made by Haider, rather than for undemocratic policies implemented by the government, the European Union has infringed on Austria's national sovereignty.

title: Vendors' Tricks, Water Woes and Upward Growth
description: NEW YORK has long been a subject of study by scholars and fare for academic as well as popular publishers. Here are excerpts from three recent books from university presses that explore various aspects of the city: a collection of essays from that quintessential New York observer, William H. Whyte; a history of how the city created its amazing water system; and a sociologist's view of how New York, along with Chicago and Los Angeles, take their place in the global economy.

title: Flirtatious Albarino and Shy Godello
description: Two whites from northwestern Spain, one extroverted and the other inward, fuel the at-home pleasures of summer: socializing and light fish and seafood meals.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on April 23 about a spring cleanup in Larchmont and Mamaroneck misstated the full name and the age of the sponsoring organization, LIFE. The initials stand for Local Involvement for Environment, not Local Fund for Environment; the group is 29 years old, not 27.
