description: Have Steamers Will Travel

title: Man Is Charged With Raping Woman in Restaurant Bathroom
description: A 19-year-old Swedish au pair was raped early yesterday in the bathroom of an East Village restaurant by a man who had approached her and several friends in a nearby bar and then followed them when they left for the restaurant, the police said.

title: Potato Salad Always Welcome, Indoors and Out
description: POTATO salad may not strictly be seasonal, but like local strawberries, backyard grilling and gin and tonic, it signals summer. And its adaptable nature makes it appropriate for everything from a picnic to an elaborate dinner.

title: INSIDE
description: Baby Boy for the Blairs

title: Russia and Poland Seek to Heal Rift
description: In Poland, long a trophy of East-West competition and now one of NATO's newest members, the installation of Vladimir Putin as Russia's president has raised new questions about Moscow's intentions.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-21-00: The Ethicist; Worse for Not Wearing
description: I often ride my motorcycle without a helmet. Our state helmet law basically applies to motorcycle riders under 18. I figure I'm not putting anyone but myself at risk. My friends say that this is tantamount to suicide. But isn't it just one of many risks all of us take everyday? -- Kelly Krebs, Minneapolis

title: Everywhere but the Dinner Table
description: It was almost like a support group for people who had become obsessively dependent on their hand-held BlackBerry wireless Internet devices. New York businessmen were standing up, declaring ''I'm a BlackBerry-a-holic.'' One even acknowledged that he couldn't stop checking his e-mail throughout the recent event that prompted such confessions -- a speech by James Balsillie, the BlackBerry creator and chairman of Research In Motion Ltd.

title: Home Schooling Graduates; Students, Jittery About College at First, Are Doing Well Academically and Fitting In Socially
description: ANNIE BYAR could be any Princeton junior. She lives in campus housing with three other young women, has her meals at one of the university's eating clubs, and during finals makes midnight runs to the local Wawa convenience store to load up on snacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ROBERT W.
description: STONE-Robert W. (Robinson Stone). Actor/professor, age 81, resident of NYC, native of Oak Park, IL., passed away May 11, 2000. Son of Mr. and Mrs. S.O. Stone and brother of Virginia Stone Holland. Loved uncle of Nancy and Charles Arends, Gay and Charles Mead and Sandra and Stephen Nelson. Graduate of Northwestern and Yale. Broadway and other stage credits: Othello with Paul Robeson and Uta Hagen, Cyrano de Bergerac with Jose Ferrer, Macbeth with Michael Redgrave, 20th Century with Gloria Swanson and Mamba's Daughters with Ethel Waters. Best known as Joey, the mute, in the film Stalag 17 starring William Holden. Served as casting agent for Dave Garroway's Today Show, Jose Ferrer and David Merrick. Later years spent as tenured professor at Fordham. Taught English with a focus on playwrights. Mr. Stone's courses had long waiting lists and he was an inspiration to many students. He came out of theatrical retirement to play opposite student Denzel Washington in Fordham's production of Othello. Mr. Stone became a mentor to Mr. Washington and helped him obtain his first agent. Mr. Washington often credits Mr. Stone for launching his career. In lieu of flowers, send donations to West Suburban Hospice; 1000 Lake Street; Oak Park, IL. 60302.

title: May 14-20; Using a Mouse to Check for Mice
description: Vermin. There it was in blue and white, highlighted for all cyber-world to see. Vermin at Le Bernardin. Vermin, ruthless and undiscriminating, the great equalizer of the restaurant world.

title: Genetic Mapping
description: To the Editor: In our young days my twin brother and I were geography buffs, just as Ralph Schoenstein and his grandson Max are in ''Genetic Mapping'' (April 9). In addition to the states puzzle that Mr. Schoenstein describes, we had a game called States and Cities, with United States geography questions. I still remember the sonority with which ''Butte, Bozeman, Billings and Missoula'' rolled off our 9-year-old tongues in answer to a question about Montana. From that game I learned of the existence of Pawtucket and Woonsocket, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, DOROTHY K.
description: WEBER-Dorothy K. Passed away on May 18, 2000, in the arms of her loving and devoted husband of 47 years. Dorie was born on August 16, 1925, in NYC. She was a graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College where she earned her BS degree. She went on to earn advanced degrees in English and Library Science at the University of Connecticut and CUNY, respectively. Her distinguished career included classroom teaching, and numerous supervisory and administrative positions in the New York City School System. Dorie chose to make her contribution to the underprivileged youth of New York. William P. Weber survives his beloved ''Shane,'' the love of his life. He acknowledges she was a woman of elegance, grace and style. Her brother, Donald F. Kauer of Honolulu, loving nieces and nephews also survive Dorie. In lieu of flowers memorial donation to a charity of choice.

title: A Beltway Insider Who Casts His Lines for Fish
description: Flyfishers love clean, fresh water, and they prefer to see it going by them horizontally, sucking at their waders, rather than vertically, in the form of rain. But the customary chagrin any angler feels as rivers begin to swell and turn the color of caramel during a deluge was doubly troubling to me on a recent expedition to the Little Delaware River. I was accompanied by guests, Jim and Lizzie Range, who split their time between a home in Washington, D.C., and a lovely ranch in Craig, Mont. They did not come to the Catskills because they were dying to poke around in musty antique shops, haggling over the price of some old weathervane.

description: WAY back when, warm weather months meant a period of battery-recharging for most musicians, some breathing space before the pressures of the regular season.

description: The Investment Company Institute, the main trade group for the mutual fund industry, reacted coolly last week to a call for it to back more frequent mandatory disclosure of fund portfolios.

description: When Yuni Rodman and her husband, Akiva Yaglom, come to New York, one of their first stops is Black Sea, a Russian bookstore on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Ready to Roll
description: It's a far cry from the Depression-era 2 by 4 with roller-skate wheels and an orange crate in the front. The new scooter is another obstacle for pedestrians, who have been dodging in-line skates, skateboards and bicycles on the sidewalks. A few scooters are battery-powered (top, far right), but the cheapest and most popular is the six-pound, collapsible (left), metal model. Sneakers are the key fashion note, to grip the board. Could this be the first big fad of the 2000's?

title: Diaper Diplomacy
description: Jeffrey Goldberg's discussion of Jamie Rubin's marriage to Christiane Amanpour (The Way We Live Now, April 30) failed to mention a crucial issue. Amanpour is a foreign-affairs correspondent for CNN, while Rubin was the spokesman for the State Department. Given that the ostensible role of the news media is to report on (and, ideally, to hold accountable) public officials, shouldn't this striking conflict of interest have prompted a career change for Rubin or Amanpour long before the birth of their child?

title: No One Will See It, But a Pad Will Add Life to Your Carpets
description: A GOOD carpet should never rest directly on the floor but on a pad. The pad can add extra cushioning to the carpet and provide a softer walking surface. In addition, the pad insulates the carpet from the hard floor and thus prevents the carpet fibers from being crushed whenever someone walks on it. This can add to the life of the carpet.

title: A Jazz-Blues Singer Finds Her Inspiration on Her Corner
description: For the last 10 years, in all sorts of weather, Elaine Briggs has stood on the corner of Seventh Avenue South and West Fourth Street, singing the dozens of jazz and blues songs that she has written about the neighborhood. During her time on that corner, she has witnessed countless scenes that she has written into songs.

title: Corrections
description: The Word for Word column on April 30, about newly declassified documents on the Vietnam War, referred incorrectly to a sequence of events in Henry A. Kissinger's negotiations with North and South Vietnam in 1972. Mr. Kissinger met with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam on Oct. 22; it was four days later -- not ahead of the meeting -- that he publicly declared at a news conference in Washington that ''peace is at hand.''

title: Settlement on Kemper Ads
description: Kemper Distributors was censured and assessed a penalty of $100,000 by the National Association of Securities Dealers last week because of what the N.A.S.D. described as inaccuracies in mutual fund advertisements that continued to appear even after the company had been asked to stop them. In settling the case, Kemper Distributors, the sales arm of Kemper Funds, neither admitted nor denied the findings.

title: Genetic Mapping
description: To the Editor: Ralph Schoenstein recalls being ''enchanted'' as a boy with the map of the United States and how even today, over half a century later, ''I still like the way that Iowa manages to touch six other states.'' Enchanting indeed. One can only wonder what fascination he'd have experienced if he'd gazed further and noticed that Missouri and Tennessee each touch eight states.

title: Troy Journal; In Gritty City, Flow of Art Adds Life
description: William Kennedy, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, has offered his writings in homage. Jenny Holzer, the multimedia artist whose work is displayed at the Museum of Modern Art, has graced the walls with her scrolls of text.

title: Rock's Original Poets, Still Howling
description: WHEN Allen Ginsberg, the last surviving member of the Beat trinity that included Jack Kerouac and William Burroughs, died three years ago, it was entirely appropriate that Lou Reed and Patti Smith be prominent among those participating in the ceremonies honoring Walt Whitman's greatest poetic descendant. Four decades earlier, Ginsberg had emerged on the literary scene like a bardic John the Baptist. This raving, shaggy-haired voice from the urban wilderness arrived strewing incantatory broadsides whose blunt evocations of homosexuality, drug delirium and political paranoia wafted a pungent body odor into the genteel tea party of American letters.

description: AN important line of defense for what may be a hot and dry summer is to practice the art of mulching.

description: An article yesterday about the Serbian opposition misstated the name of the opposition party led by Vuk Draskovic. It is the Serbian Renewal Movement, not the Socialist Renewal Movement.

description: FINKEL-Lawrence, Ph.D. ASID NY Metro Chapter mourns the loss of a distinguished and loyal friend and sends its condolences to his wife and former chapter president, Terry Finkel, ASID, and her immediate family.

title: Mr. Pataki's Nassau Travails
description: Nassau County on Long Island is one of the nation's wealthiest counties -- and also one of its most poorly governed. Years of irresponsible budget policies have brought it to the edge of bankruptcy. Earlier this month, Gov. George Pataki realized that allowing the county to sink into bankruptcy could damage the whole state's credit rating and undermine his own political standing. His proposal for an infusion of state money and a state financing agency to oversee the county is reminiscent of what Gov. Hugh Carey did for New York City in the 1970's. It was a welcome first step, but Mr. Pataki will have to step in more forcefully to help the county make extremely tough budget decisions in the future.

description: This season, art and fashion converge in the garden.

title: A Haider In Their Future
description: In the German election of September 1930, the Nazis obtained 30 percent of the vote. In the following couple of years, articles in your files should show the same kind of reporting on Hitler as Cohen's on Haider. After all, Neville Chamberlain and quite a few others wanted to be convinced that Hitler was not such a bad fellow.

title: Blairs' New Son Goes Home to 10 Downing Street
description: Cherie Blair, the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair, gave birth to a boy early today, and hours later mother, father and son left the London hospital for a quiet weekend in the privacy of 10 Downing Street.

title: A Sultry New Reporter For the Nightly News
description: WHEN Andrea Thompson, who plays the empathetic blond detective on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' leaves network television to become a reporter for CBS's Albuquerque affiliate beginning Memorial Day, she will fulfill a childhood dream -- even as she ignites a debate on the professional values of TV journalism.

description: Karen Lynn Hirschfield, the daughter of Gerard A. Hirschfield of Tarzana, Calif., and the late Ruth Hirschfield, is to be married today to Mark Lindsey Safire, the son of Helene Safire and the columnist William Safire of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Jonathan Maltzman will officiate at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Harpers Ferry, W.Va.

title: Airborne Spas and Beds for the Upper Class
description: Attention, coach class passengers: that bag of honey roasted peanuts is about to look even more measly now that fresh-baked chocolate chip cookies are the least of the treats offered on the other side of the curtains. As airlines begin to recognize that they make most of their money in business and first-class travel, they are spending millions to upgrade long-distance planes and offer more luxuries to upper-class passengers.

title: May 14-20; Hospital Giant Settles
description: The sprawling fraud investigation of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has lasted seven years, but prosecutors have finally won a tentative settlement. The hospital giant agreed in principal to pay $745 million in civil penalties to resolve allegations that it cheated federal health programs. But the deal will not be finalized unless the outstanding criminal investigations are resolved before year's end. KURT EICHENWALD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMAN, HELEN
description: HABERMAN-Helen, loving mother of Arnold, Clyde and Beverly, devoted mother to Kathy, Nancy, Clyde and Evelyn, cherished grandmother of Theo, Maggie, Zach and Emma, left us on May 18th, in Lauderdale Lakes, FL. Our loss is incalculable.

title: The He Hormone
description: After reading the outraged responses (Letters, April 23) to Andrew Sullivan's article on testosterone (April 2), I finally got around to reading his article myself. Did I miss something? It was, in my opinion, a thoughtful, modulated treatise. It would seem that most of Sullivan's hypotheses were backed by clinical research or personal experience (or both), rather than racist or sexist supposition.

title: The Eroded Self
description: Jeffrey Rosen's chilling article on Internet privacy (April 30) might have gone a step further. There is a real prospect of defensive retaliation, in which we spy on others and assemble dossiers to use in the event that others attempt to discredit us with the dossiers they've assembled. Perhaps this could be an antidote to cybersmearing. Since no one will know who has the goods on us, we'll all have to keep our mouths shut.

title: EMISSIONS TESTS
description: The new, stricter emissions tests, which had caused waits of up to five hours partly because the machines did not work in cold weather, may also have a problem operating when it is hot. The Department of Environmental Protection gave the system a routine check on May 8 and 9, two unusually warm days. Eight of the 14 gasoline analyzer machines tested failed to give accurate readings, said Jeff Maclin, a spokesman for the department, who said it was not known whether the heat affected the machines. Tests under hot conditions have since been conducted and the machinery operated properly, he said.

title: Growing Up More Popular Than You Are
description: The question just begged to be asked. So, that thing with Marcia, uh, Maureen McCormick? It really happened?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the average cost of raising children born in 1999 referred incorrectly to the amount, $230,680, that would be spent per child by the year 2016. The figure was indeed adjusted for inflation -- at 4.3 percent a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISSAUER, DIANA FRAID
description: LISSAUER-Diana Fraid. Born in Montreal; heart in New York. Lived courageously; died peacefully on May 18. Wife of the late Franz Lissauer; mother of Emil; sister of Elaine Rush and the late Stephen Fraid; sister-in-law of Bob Rush, aunt of Hillary Rush; loving friend to Mark Trujillo and the many others whose lives were graced and enriched by her intelligence and taste; the celebratory way she decorated and dressed and her kindness and generosity. It is, however, her infectious exuberance and joyous humor that will be most sorely missed. She was curious about many things; passionate about even more: dancing, jazz, opera, gardens, antiques; baseball and the Mets; art; Japanese basket weaving and the Bible - recently; literature, people and ideas - always. Diana, we will forever embrace and cherish your memory. Funeral services Sunday, May 21, 2000, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to New School University, Diana Lissauer Scholarship, 66 W 12 St, NYC 10011.

title: Carol Eggers, Brian Haynsworth
description: Carol Marie Eggers, a television producer with MSNBC, the cable network, in Secaucus, N.J., and Brian Clement Haynsworth, a lighting designer in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Glenview, Ill. The Rev. John E. Flavin performed the ceremony.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Starwood Leases a White Plains Building for Its HQ
description: THIS city's rebounding office market has received another major boost with the announcement this month that Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide plans to lease more than 200,000 square feet, occupying an entire office building along the Interstate 287 corridor, where it expects to establish its world headquarters.

title: Don't Surf? You Can Still Look the Part
description: EVEN if, as the Beach Boys sang, everybody did have an ocean across the U.S.A., they still might not be surfin' like Californ-eye-ay. (As any novice can attest, it's at least as hard as it looks.)

title: Diaper Diplomacy
description: Caregiving fathers who ''fulfill their responsibilities'' do diapers. The diplomatic distance that served Jamie Rubin so well at Foggy Bottom is no asset at the changing table, where unpleasant realities are not so readily evaded.

title: Faster Amtrak Trains, Fancier Safeguards
description: THE top speed of Amtrak trains running between here and Boston will soon rise to 150 miles an hour, up from 125 m.p.h. now between Washington and New York, and 110 m.p.h. from New York to Boston. The change will create a phenomenon that makes some people uneasy: trains whizzing over grade-level crossings at up to 85 miles an hour, a speed at which it takes about a mile to stop.

title: Roger A. Morse, Expert on Bees' Sweet Science, Dies at 72
description: Roger A. Morse, who turned a childhood interest in beekeeping into an encyclopedic knowledge that made him one of the best-known apiculturists in the world, died May 12 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHENKMAN, SOLOMON
description: SHENKMAN-Solomon. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Sweet and dear father of Lee and William, Beverly and Jerry. Loving Papa of Halle, Evan and Tess. Devoted son of the late Ethel and Louis. Loving brother of Freda and the late Shirley and Molly. Wonderful and wise uncle and dear friend to all. Services Sunday 1PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

title: At the Table, Relaxation
description: Ellen Wright is far from an old-timer. She didn't spend her first summer in the Hamptons until 1971.

title: The Florist
description: Long before Palm Beach colors became the shades of the season, Olivier Guigni, a floral artist, as he calls himself, whose clients include the restaurants Daniel and Cafe Boulud, loved lime green. His arrangements, which start at $350, are known for their leaves as much as for their flowers. His Upper East Side shop is paneled in lime-color enamel, and his wardrobe also has verdant touches. title: Appearances; Micromanaged
description: One day a few years ago, Anne Carullo -- 35, pregnant and in a state of permanent sleep-deprivation -- was commuting to her job in Manhattan from her home in Westchester. She took a seat on the train across the aisle from a woman who was maybe 20 and found herself staring at the woman's face, how the skin gave back light, how it glowed with translucent radiance. ''How come my skin doesn't do that?'' Carullo asked herself. If she had been a bond trader, she might have vowed to get more sleep or check into a day spa for a facial. But Carullo, who now holds the title of senior vice president for marketing and product development worldwide for Prescriptives, is obsessed with marrying technology to cosmetic needs. Her brain began churning over the question ''What can I put on my face to get it to look like that?'' It would be not a treatment, not a makeup, but a substance that would gather light and throw it back into the universe, just like the perfect, unblemished skin of the very young woman across the aisle.

title: Body, as Mannequin, Reinterpreted

In her best-known works, the artist's nude body was seen from her own viewpoint, with her feet back near the vanishing point of the pictures' perspective. The idea was to show that the female nude need not be portrayed only from the viewpoint of the desiring or appraising male but also according to a woman's own subjectivity -- and then to put the viewer in the position of the self-witnessing artist.

title: Bloomsberries
description: All scandals need a setting: tumultuous love affairs require bedrooms and shaded gardens, sociocultural revolutions their parlors and studios. With this in mind, Pamela Todd, a chronicler of domesticity, organized BLOOMSBURY AT HOME (Abrams, $27.50) ''by biography and geography.'' Todd, hoping ''to step behind the posed facade,'' has had the enviable task of poring over the letters and photographs of the celebrated aggregation of painters, writers and intellectuals and peering into what is left of their domains. She does a good job of extracting the gems -- the book glitters with wonderful quotations, images and anecdotes, like Vanessa Bell and Duncan Grant's newborn daughter, Angelica, being observed by her future husband, David Garnett, while she was being weighed in a shoebox on Christmas Day, 1918. But the chapters, defined by addresses, jump around in space and time and hunger for a sense of narrative. Thus we are told, on several occasions, that Grant was Bell's longtime extramarital lover. Lacking direction, you almost lose sense of what place meant to the Bloomsberries; however, paintings, drawings and home furnishings by the group allow an understanding to emerge. Which is a good thing, since, as Garnett himself once said, ''Places explain people.'' Jillian Dunham

title: Ethnic Fencing
description: The soldiers who run burundi resent it when outsiders describe the temporary settlements atop the steep green hills that surround the capital of Bujumbura as ''concentration camps.'' Yes, the soldiers concede, the camps are crowded. About 85 percent of the local population, more than 300,000 people, has been moved into them, by force, since September. Yes, conditions are awful: too many wobbly straw huts, too few latrines, too little food. Yes, these camps are only for Hutus and are guarded by Tutsis, the twinned elements in the unstable ethnic atmosphere of central Africa. But the leaders of Burundi's military government prefer to call the strikingly bleak places pictured in these pages ''regroupment'' camps, a phrase that makes them sound almost sensible. And perhaps they are -- if you leave human rights out of the equation.

title: Alabama Presses the Klan to Answer for Its Most Heinous Bombing

But his appearance, at 61, is indisputably that of a puffy old man. It was a big change from 18 years ago when I interviewed Mr. Blanton about his alleged role in the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church, where four children died on Sept. 15, 1963.

title: Birding at the End of Nature
description: Early this spring, long before the trees had leafed, I found myself standing in the rain in a dark field in southern New Jersey waiting for woodcocks -- shy, chunky, long-billed birds -- to rise out of the shadows and begin their mating dance. Sometimes called timberdoodles, woodcocks are not the most graceful birds on the planet. Their eyes are spaced so far apart that you might wonder how they can see the trees in front of them. As the late winter days begin to lengthen, they throw caution to the wind, and at dawn and dusk the males rise straight up into the air some 200 or 300 feet and then spiral down, uttering a plaintive, musical series of notes. Although deterred by cold, they don't seem to be bothered by rain -- and that's a good thing, too, because this ''sky dancing'' is how they maintain themselves as a species. The mystery is what was I, a devoted urbanite, doing there?

I have taken to carrying verb conjugation charts in my purse, along with the tiny notebook I've always kept for jotting down book ideas, overheard conversations, language detritus, phrases that pop into my head. Now that little notebook includes an increasing volume of Ojibwe words. My English is jealous, my Ojibwe elusive. Like a besieged unfaithful lover, I'm trying to appease them both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ABNER
description: LEVIN-Abner, 88, Music Retailer and Critic. Abner Levin, General Manager of Sam Goody's from its less than auspicious origins in a Ninth Avenue loft building in the early 1950's through its expansion to a half-dozen major metropolitan area outlets by the mid 1960's, died in Hilo, Hawaii on May 12 after a prolonged illness. Mr. Levin joined Sam Goody's at approximately the time the long playing record was introduced and it was under his direction that Goody's became the first retailer to stock long playing records in substantial volume and to market them at discounted prices. Described in a 1954 Collier's magazine profile as the man with the ''sharpest ears in America'', Mr. Levin was also a respected classical music critic who, in addition to co-authoring ''The Disc Book'', wrote an influential column for ''The Long Player'' record catalog (which he founded and edited). He is survived by his wife Flora, two sons, Robert and Andrew, a daughter, Jo, and a grandson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKIN, MORRIE
description: SLIFKIN-Morrie. Of Ardsley on Hudson, formerly of Tarrytown, died of cancer on Saturday, May 20, 2000, at home. He was 89. Judge Slifkin worked as a Supreme Court Judge for the State of New York in the 9th Judicial District. He was with the 9th Judicial District for 17 years before retiring in 1986. Judge Slifkin was born June 11, 1910, in Morristown, NJ, USA, to Samuel and Rebecca Velitzkin Slifkin. He was educated in Tarrytown, NY, and graduated from Washington Irving High School in 1927. He earned a B.S. degree in psychology from NYU, NYC, in 1931. Additional degree: Columbia Law School, 1934. On November 27, 1935, he married Rosalind Projansky. Mr. Slifkin lived in Ardsley on Hudson for the past 20 years. Before that, he lived in Tarrytown, NY, from 1910 to 1980. Activities: Tappan Zee Mental Health Center; Tarrytown Hospital-Director; Phelps Memorial Hospital-Director and Secretary; Easter Seal Society; Planned Parenthood; Hudson River Speech Center; United Nations Committee-Chairman; UJA-Local Chairman; Tarrytown Lions Club-President; Masonic Member; Temple Beth Abraham-Trustee Emeritus; Television Actor-CBS-1959-1963''Verdict is Yours''; monograph: ''Effect of Music on Performance of a Monotonous Task.'' He is survived by wife Rosalind, daughters and sons-in-law Barbara and James Lister, Susan and Douglas Levin, granddaughters Rachel and Rebecca Levin. Calling hours are one hour prior to memorial service at Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown. The funeral is at 2 PM, Monday, May 22, 2000. Friends may send memorial donations to Phelps Memorial Hospice, Temple Beth Abraham.

title: Muse Charmed by the Nature of Zero

It is Mr. Wellman's conceit, in the 60 minutes of ruminative jabberwocky that make up ''Hypatia,'' that her spirit has revisited the world from time to time, inspiring select women in places from 8th-century Damascus to early-20th-century Alexandria, Va. Sexual, brilliant and questioning (she is inclined, like a spoiled 4-year-old, to repeating ''Why?''), Hypatia serves the play as a puzzling legend and elusive muse.

Fiber has also been knocked around a bit lately, after three disappointing studies failed to find that a high-fiber diet helped to prevent colon cancer.

Born and raised in the Polish American Community South Brooklyn, Sister Cyrene entered the congregation of the Holy Family in Philadelphia in 1939. She was a graduate of the Social Services School of Catholic University in Washington. She returned to Little Flower Campus and served as an educator, a social worker, counselor and advocate for the children of New York separted from their families. For years she greeted ''children of the night'' who were in emergency placement, and calmed their fears. Interment will be on May 24, 2000 at 10:00 A.M. at Marion Heights, Monroe, Connecticut. Carlton had $59.6 million in revenue last year. It also produces television shows in Britain and owns several TV stations there.

Thus, ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' as witnessed by Sunday's concert performance by the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, is by virtue of its size and extravagance a closer cousin to Schoenberg's mammoth ''Gurrelieder'' than to the tersely beautiful string quartets that were to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDROP, GIDEON W.
description: WALDROP-Gideon W. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of Gideon Waldrop, Dean of the School from 1961 to 1986 and Acting President from 1983 to 1984. An accomplished composer and distinguished educator, he helped shape the programs in drama, dance and music that exist to this day at Juilliard. His legacy and caring ways are remembered by generations of Juilliard alumni. Sincere condolences are extended to his family and friends. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

description: Dr. Thomas A. Mattioni treats patients for heart disease, so he takes no position on whether the alternative-medical practice of sleeping on magnets has any effect on arthritis or other joint diseases.

title: Broken Hearts and Mended Dreams
description: There is a special happiness hiding in hard lives that springs out of a dark corner at the end of Nancy Nevarez's ''Blind Alley'' (''Callejon Sin Salida'') and sends you away with a slightly guilty feeling of uplift. The secret of this magic springs partly from Ms. Nevarez's determination to offer no explanations or apologies and to seek no pity as she presents the lives of nine women in three acts -- actually three short plays that share a few themes expressed in vivid conflicts and powerful language.

title: Accounts
description: * Enson Inc., San Bruno, Calif., which plans to sell children's apparel on the Internet under the Enson brand name, to Amazon Advertising, San Francisco, to handle a national introduction. KSL Media, San Francisco, owned by True North Communications, will handle media planning and buying. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Doctors in Antitrust Fight Boycott Merck Products
description: Hundreds of doctors across the country have been boycotting drug products made by Merck & Company, one of the world's largest drug manufacturers, in a bitter fight over the collective bargaining rights of doctors, pharmacists and other health care professionals.

title: Diageo Reported in Talks To Buy Part of Bestfoods
description: Diageo P.L.C., which owns Pillsbury bakery goods and Haagen-Daz ice cream, is negotiating to buy all or part of Bestfoods, the maker of Skippy peanut butter and Hellmann's mayonnaise, executives close to the talks said today.

title: G.M. in Deal On Fuel Cells
description: General Motors said today that it had formed an alliance with Giner Inc. to refine fuel-cell technology to power cars and trucks. The financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, EPHRAIM F.
description: BLOCH-Ephraim F. Age 85. Died in Palm Beach, FL. May 21, 2000. Extraordinarly beloved father of Michelle B. Bloch. Beloved father of Lawrence C. Bloch. Beloved of Joyce Cutty Bloch. Also survived by his son-in-law John Cuseo, his grandchildren Harry Franklin, Maggie Rose and Aaron Michael Bloch, sister Edna Bolno and brother-in-law Charles Bolno. Brother of the late Harry, Albert and Deborah. Benefactor and godfather of his many nieces and nephews. Ephraim was the Founder and CEO of Perfect Fit Industries. He was the greatest and most prolific inventor and marketer in the history of the domestics industry. His most notable accomplishment was the Bed Sack which achieved national fame. He was an accomplished pioneer. He was a substantial contributor to many charities, always in a self-effacing, quiet way. He helped many, many people in a like manner. He had an abundance of hidden warmth, plus a plethora of brains, knowledge and sense of humor. Ephraim, you paid for the last drink. This one is on me. There aren't any doctors in the land beyond the sky, only bartenders, so ask for a double. Rest in peace, you more than deserve it. Alvin L. Levine

description: In the satellite launching business, as in real estate, location is everything. Because of that simple fact, the spaceport the Brazilian government has built here on the eastern edge of the Amazon basin, and is now making available to foreign companies and governments, may soon become a very valuable piece of property.

title: Harvard President Announces Plans to Quit Next Year
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, a scholar of Renaissance poetry who recently led the largest fund-raising campaign in the history of higher education, announced yesterday that he would step down next spring after a decade as president of Harvard University.

title: New Rhetoric at City Hall
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was back at City Hall yesterday, repeating his pledges to reach out to critics, fondling puppies and offering new testimony to the power of love. He also said he would formulate plans about how to pursue his outreach initiative over the next couple of weeks. Some of Mr. Giuliani's critics are reacting with understandable cynicism. But other officials are promising to reciprocate the mayor's gestures. In our view, they are smart to seize the opening presented by Mr. Giuliani's new rhetoric of inclusion. If the mayor and his longtime adversaries work together to render his words into action, a genuine transformation can occur throughout New York City.

title: Punitive Stage Opens in Suit By Ill Smokers
description: A lawyer for the plaintiffs in the punitive damages stage of a landmark case against cigarette makers stood before jurors today and slapped himself on the wrist, the punishment he said that tobacco executives felt they deserved for decades of misconduct.

title: Questioning Long-Term Lyme Cases

title: Rusch Finds Good Pitching Is Not Enough
description: Glendon Rusch's game is control. He has impeccable control, staying around the plate, giving hitters no option but to go after his pitch. The Mets left-hander has the look of a pitcher who is finally understanding himself after three years in the majors, and when the Mets slot him in as their fifth starter, they now know he will given them a chance to win.

The Web privacy technology, ProxyMate, filters out user information that would normally be passed to Web sites. CMGI, also based in Andover, is a holding company for Internet companies. Lucent is based in Murray Hill.

description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: A Soprano Who Wrests Pragmatism From Pain
description: When Dawn Upshaw sings popular songs, she instinctively cleans them up. Without actually editing lyrics, she has a way of taking messy emotions, straightening them out and tucking them in like freshly ironed sheets with hospital corners. Ms. Upshaw can read the subtext of a lyric as clearly as anyone. What she doesn't do is turn songs into turbulent personal dramas brimming with sex and heartbreak. Everything is filtered through a wholesome, practical sensibility that grasps both sides of a situation. Even when singing a sad song sadly, Ms. Upshaw conveys her delighted appreciation of its craft.

title: Ethiopia Willing to Negotiate, But Refuses to Stop Fighting

description: To the Editor:

description: Now, six years after young people in Britain started dying from a human strain of mad cow disease, scientists are still struggling to understand how the disease spreads to humans, how many more will die from it and if a similar epidemic could start in the United States spread by infected deer and elk.

title: Business Group Giving Bonuses to Teachers
description: After a long delay, the New York City Partnership is finally preparing to award bonuses to teachers and principals in six Brooklyn schools where test scores improved during the 1998-99 school year. The Partnership, a business group, began the bonus program in District 19, in East New York, and expanded it to District 23, in Brownsville, this year.

title: New York Times Holders Back Web Unit Tracking Stock
description: New York Times Holders Back Web Unit Tracking Stock

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCKEFELLER, RODMAN
description: ROCKEFELLER-Rodman Clark. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 1st, 2:30 PM, The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. at 55th St. Contact: I.M. Antaki, 212-698-1213, 610 5th Ave., Suite 316, NY NY 10020.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Overrules Law Restricting Cable Sex Shows
description: Declaring for the first time that programming on cable television is entitled to the highest level of First Amendment protection, the Supreme Court today struck down a federal law that required many cable systems to limit sexually explicit channels to late-night hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, EVELYN
description: WIENER-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Cherished mother of Barbara Lloyd and Rollie Miller. Caring and supportive HiMa of four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

title: World Bank to Delay Vote on Oil Pipeline
description: The World Bank will delay a vote on financing a $3.5 billion oil pipeline project in Africa led by the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Chevron Corporation to give its board more time to consider the contested plan, a bank spokesman said.

title: State Remains Liable for Half Of Yonkers' Integration Costs
description: Rejecting an appeal by New York State, the United States Supreme Court agreed today with Yonkers officials that the state should continue paying half the cost of racially integrating the city's schools.

title: Steinbrenner Prods and Pushes Yanks
description: A shroud of weariness seemed to envelop Orlando Hernandez as he pitched Sunday against the Cleveland Indians. He loitered between pitches, stepping off the mound, wiping his right hand across his forehead. The man who loves to play baseball never smiled.

title: The Time May Have Come to Change Teams, Not Just the Players
description: Nearly 30 years ago two National Football League owners swapped teams. Carroll Rosenbloom traded the Baltimore Colts to Robert Irsay for the Los Angeles Rams. That the Colts now play in Indianapolis and the Rams in St. Louis (where they are the reigning Super Bowl champions, no less) is not a direct result of the unique exchange, but of the league's laissez-faire attitude on franchise shifts.

title: 4 Giants Set to Embrace Electronic Publishing
description: In signs of an intensifying digital rush in the American book industry, three trade publishing giants and Microsoft are poised to plunge deeper into the emerging electronic literary market.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the E-Commerce Report column of Business Day yesterday, about the rigors faced by Internet companies trying to expand globally, misstated the ownership of Boo.com, the British online retailer. The company, which announced last week that it was going out of business, is owned by its founders and private investors. It has not made a public stock offering.

title: Andrew Choa, 76, Former Bank Executive
description: Andrew Choa, an international banker and professional adviser, died on May 17 in a hospital in Mount Vernon, Va. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, LOUIS
description: BERKOWITZ-Louis. On May 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Sally; loving father of Joseph and Robert; grandfather of Brahm; brother of Michael Berkowitz and the late Joseph Brooks. Services at Gramercy Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, 12:00 PM, Tuesday, May 23. Graveside services, Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island. Visiting, Tuesday, 5:00 PM to Thursday evening, 442 East 20th Street, Apt. 11C.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the coming election for the House seat that is being vacated on Long Island by Representative Rick A. Lazio referred incorrectly in some copies to the job held by a possible candidate, Pierce Cohalan. He is an assistant district attorney. It is his father, Peter F. Cohalan, who is a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Quality Time (and Diapers) at 10 Downing
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, nudged in public by his wife, Cherie, to take some of the paternity leave his government has just authorized for British parents, is canceling his public appearances this week to spend time with her and Leo, their baby son.

title: American Amasses The Miles
description: Christie Welsh is about to embark on her second excursion to Australia in less than six months. But what she really wants is a hat trick of trips to the antipodes, specifically a spot on the United States roster for the Summer Olympics in Sydney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSH, JULIAN S.
description: BUSH-Julian S. 84. A retired Senior Estate Partner with the former Shea and Gould Law Firm in New York, died Tuesday, May 16 in Charleston, South Carolina. Mr. Bush was born in New York City, the son of Joachim F. Bush and Isabel Rosenthall Bush. He was an army veteran of W.W.II. He was a graduate of Columbia Law School and an Adjunct Professor of Law in Estate Planning at Columbia, 1958-1981 and formerly Adjunct Professor of Law in Taxation at NYU, 1981-1987. He was the author of numerous articles and texts. In his later years, he was a member of the Charleston Tax Council and Estate Planning Council. He was a Founder and Director of The Annual Estate Planning Institute at the Medical University of South Carolina. He was a member of the Charleston Symphony Orchestra's Board of Directors and a member of MUSC's President's Advisory Council on Planned Giving. He was a member of the Society of American Magicians. Surviving are his wife, Bette Bain Roe Bush; two daughters, Dorothy B. Seuter of New York and Kathryn D. Rucker of Connecticutt; 4 grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

title: French Can Pursue Polish Phone Company
description: France Telecom and a Polish partner, Kulczyk Holding, received exclusive rights today to negotiate the acquisition of a 35 percent stake in the former Polish phone monopoly, Telekomunikacja Polska, for roughly $4 billion.

title: Israeli High Court Rules for Women's Services at Western Wall
description: The Israeli Supreme Court changed the rules of worship at Judaism's most revered shrine today when it ruled that women can hold group services at the Western Wall, wear prayer shawls and read aloud from Torah scrolls.

title: Taiwan Aides Voice Hope on China Ties
description: Two of Taiwan's top security officials expressed cautious hope today that relations with the mainland could improve after President Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech and a nonbelligerent reply from Beijing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the coming vote in Congress on the bill to grant permanent normal trading rights to China misstated the stance of Representative Peter Deutsch, a Florida Democrat. He has not been won over; he is undecided.

title: Naming Sex Offenders On the Internet Gains
description: Legislative committees yesterday moved closer to amending the State Constitution to permit officials to post convicted sex offenders' names, addresses and physical descriptions on the Internet.

title: Alexander Cohen Tribute
description: A memorial tribute to the theater producer Alexander H. Cohen will be held tomorrow at 11 a.m. at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. Among those who are to speak at the tribute, which is open to the public, are Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist and former chief theater critic for The New York Times, the director Harold Prince and the producer Gordon Davidson. Mr. Cohen died on April 22 at the age of 79.

title: NAVIGANT RETAINS LEHMAN BROS. TO ADVISE IT ON OPTIONS
description: Navigant Consulting Inc., a utility consultant whose shares have fallen about 90 percent in eight months, said it hired the investment bank Lehman Brothers Inc. to advise it on alternatives. Navigant, which has a market value of $224 million, declined to say whether the options included a sale or merger. The company named a former BankAmerica Corporation executive, William Goodyear, as chairman and chief executive, replacing three co-chiefs who succeeded Robert Maher in November. Shareholders have sued, accusing Mr. Maher and Navigant of lying about the financial condition of the company. Navigant, based in Chicago, reduced last year's earnings by $17.2 million in January after a review of its accounting for acquisitions.

title: After Race, Mayor Finds Renewed Joy In His Work
description: He was boasting, once again, about New York City's war on graffiti and street litter. He proclaimed -- somewhat belatedly -- May as Pet Adoption Month. And by yesterday evening, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was out on Gracie Mansion's front lawn, holding a party for the city's theater community, complete with a performance by a star of ''The Lion King.''

title: Scientists Cast Bets on Human Genes; A Winner Will Be Picked in 2003
description: How many human genes are there? Recent estimates have ranged from 60,000 to 140,000 and might be expected to narrow sharply as the human genome nears completion. In fact, the range has widened, suggesting that gene-counting remains at least as much art as science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JEANETTE
description: GOLDMAN-Jeanette. Devoted wife of the late Isadore Goldman. Loving mother of Danny Goldman, Naomi Bernstein and the late Elaine Lazarowitz. Adored grandmother of Susan Pike Blinken, Lisa and Dan Bernstein. Great-grandmother of Alexandra Pike. Rest in peace, Nanny Jean. You have earned it. Graveside services Tuesday, May 23, at Old Montefiore Cemetery St. Albans, Queens, (718-528-1700).

title: Exxon Mobil Holds An Account Review
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation is conducting a review for the combined account of what the company calls its fuels marketing portfolio, which includes service stations and convenience stores. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: LSI Logic to Buy Chip Maker
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, a leading maker of custom semiconductors, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy DataPath Systems Inc. for about $420 million in stock to bolster its line of products for the communications industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, PEGGY
description: BARTH-Peggy. On May 21, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Grace and Joseph Barth; loving niece of the late Mae Houlihan; fond grandaughter of the late Mary and James Houlihan; dear sister of Eileen Barth. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 St, NYC, Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, St. Bernard's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Five Keys That May Open The Door to the Finals
description: 1. CAMBY'S CONSISTANCY

title: Art on Loan Must Be Protected
description: On Gov. George Pataki's desk awaits a bill that most certainly has been passed by the New York Legislature with the best of intentions: it would enhance the authority of state law enforcement officials to seize loaned artwork that officials suspect of having been stolen at some point.

title: Royal Philips Makes Offer
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest consumer electronics maker, agreed to make a tender offer for about 60 percent of MedQuist Inc. at $51 a share. The offer is a 30 percent premium to MedQuist's closing price of $39.125. MedQuist, based in Marlton, is the largest United States provider of medical transcription services, with 1999 sales of about $330 million. The acquisition will add to Philips's health care services and improve its speech technology capabilities, the company said. Philips' New York shares, each representing one ordinary share, fell $1.8125 to $39.1875.

title: Sports of the Times; This Repeat Is Replete With Drama
description: THE Miami Heat sounded like the hiss from a radiator when it's oversteamed. Jamal Mashburn, Tim Hardaway, Alonzo Mourning, et. al. were complaining, after an 83-82 loss in the deciding Game 7 of their playoff series against the Knicks on Sunday. They were charging that there was ''a conspiracy'' by the referees and the league to make sure that the Knicks won. They imagined that a Los Angeles-New York final series would be a TV-ratings bonanza, a commercial aspect surely not lost on David Stern and his minions.

title: For Writers, Father and Son, Out of Conflict Grew Love
description: EXPERIENCE

title: TELIA GAINS MARKET SHARE
description: Telia A.B., the subject of Sweden's largest public stock offering ever, increased its share of the cellular market in April and will raise spending about 40 percent this year to 17 billion kronor ($1.8 billion), said Reinhold Geijer, Telia's chief financial officer.

title: Nassau Chief Vows to Go Ahead With Pay Delay for Police
description: Retreating from his threat to lay off police officers, the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said this evening that he would go ahead with his plan to delay two weeks' pay to county police officers even though their union refused to ratify it.

title: TOTALFINA ELF TO SELL SOME U.S. OIL ASSETS TO ALON ISRAEL
description: TotalFina Elf S.A., Europe's No. 3 oil company, agreed to sell an oil refinery; 1,700 gasoline stations; and other assets in the United States to the closely held Alon Israel Oil Company in a package analysts valued at as much as $400 million. Alon, which was founded by Israel's socialist kibbutz movement, will get Total's Big Spring refinery in western Texas and stations in Texas, New Mexico, Louisiana, Arizona and Arkansas. Alon will also get 1,125 miles of pipeline, fuel storage operations, and oil and natural gas drilling licenses. The companies did not disclose financial terms. TotalFina Elf, which is based in Paris, wants to focus on its United States chemicals and global oil exploration businesses, analysts said.

title: Regaining Mobility Is Crucial for Houston
description: Allan Houston has been tethered to electric stimulators for three days in an effort to relieve a sore left ankle that may leave him moving as if he were tied down against Indiana's slithering Reggie Miller.

title: With an Ear For Baroque Passions
description: As part of the Baroqueworks series at Merkin Concert Hall, the harpsichordist Bradley Brookshire and his period instrument ensemble, I Musici di San Cassiano, offered works by Handel and the two Scarlattis last Tuesday evening.

title: TENNIS; Baseball Dream Fades, but Spirit Thrives
description: In his 30-year coaching career at Pompton Lakes High School, Dennis Arnold has listened to his fair share of excuses.

title: Israel's Volatile Border
description: Israel's hopes for an orderly withdrawal from its security zone in Southern Lebanon this summer were jolted yesterday by the sudden disintegration of large sections of the Southern Lebanon Army, a pro-Israeli militia. With Syria's blessing, Lebanese Hezbollah guerrillas quickly moved into the vacuum left by the militia's collapse, seizing fortified positions laden with Israeli munitions and occupying a slice of the zone reaching to the Israeli border.

title: Two Business-to-Business Deals Announced
Proud Russia Keeps Mir Aloft
description: By some plans, it should have been long dead. With most of its structure disintegrated by a fiery re-entry through Earth's atmosphere, the remains of the giant spacecraft should be resting on the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Giuliani Doubts N.R.A. Arcade In Times Square Would Survive
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he did not think a theme restaurant and shoot'em-up arcade run by the National Rifle Association could realistically survive in Times Square.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Diageo Said to Be in Talks For All or Part of Bestfoods

title: 2 Washington Officers Hurt in Drive-by Shooting
description: Two off-duty District of Columbia police officers were slightly injured in a drive-by shooting in Manhattan early yesterday, the police said.

title: National News Briefs; Clinton and Speaker Reach Antipoverty Deal
description: President Clinton struck a deal today with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert that merges their antipoverty initiatives by expanding the number of empowerment zones and enacting a Republican redevelopment program, officials said.

title: For Children, a Safer Race to the Hospital
description: For children who need medical attention at hospitals, the danger may not end when they are placed in ambulances.

title: ARTS ABROAD; Chechens Hope Their Muses Are Louder Than Bombs
description: Topa Elimbayev spent the last Chechen war in a basement bomb shelter in Grozny. In 1995 Russian air raids and artillery destroyed the dance theater he directed for 30 years, scattering his troupe across the former Soviet Union. This time, with Grozny flattened, he is in Moscow, teaching children to dance.

title: Sir John Gielgud, 96, Dies; Beacon of Classical Stage
description: Sir John Gielgud, one of the great actors of the English stage who enthralled audiences for more than 70 years with his eloquent voice and consummate artistry, died on Sunday at his home near Aylesbury, northwest of London. He was 96.

title: Bush Says Clinton Misstepped in Israel
description: Gov. George W. Bush today accused the Clinton administration of taking sides in last year's Israeli election and of trying to make Israel conform to American ''plans and timetables'' for peace. The governor said his own support for Israel was ''not conditional on the outcome of the peace process.''

title: A Chanel Exhibition That Lost Its Way
description: Last Friday, Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, asked me during an interview about the Met's decision to cancel its Chanel exhibition, ''Does Jenny Holzer sound like a Chanel show to you?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, DAVID
description: SCHLANGER-David, age 68, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Husband of Carol, father of Randy, Ronni (David) Weiner, and beloved grandfather of Billye Weiner. Services are 11 AM, Thursday, Gutterman-Warheit, Boca Raton, FL.

title: From Curtain Calls to Ivy Halls; Top Colleges Take Notice of Special School's Young Stars
description: If you are Anthony Roth Costanzo, your year looks something like this:

title: ADVANCED MICRO TO SELL MOST OF COMMUNICATIONS UNIT
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. agreed to sell 90 percent of its communications products division to the private equity firm Francisco Partners for $375 million in cash. Advanced Micro, the Intel Corporation's biggest rival in the microprocessor market, will keep a 10 percent stake in the unit and has an option to buy another 10 percent. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter. The division had $59.5 million in revenue in the first quarter, about 5 percent of Advanced Micro's total sales of $1.09 billion.

title: Israel's Buffer Strip in South Lebanon Collapsing
description: The center of Israel's buffer zone in southern Lebanon has abruptly collapsed, after the Israeli-backed Lebanese militia abandoned villages, command posts and arms to advancing Hezbollah guerrillas, and the Israeli Army early today hurriedly evacuated a major Lebanese base.

title: Left-Handed Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Joining the Club: Like Others, China Will Try to Protect Its Own Industries
description: Sun Guomin, a poor farmer in a village west of here, represents an example of why American business executives and government officials may be disappointed once China enters the World Trade Organization.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Even upon the assumption that the government has an interest in substituting itself for informed and empowered parents, its interest is not sufficiently compelling to justify this widespread restriction on speech.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, HARRY
description: CHEN-Harry. The Board of Directors, staff and clients of Hamilton Madison House are saddened by the loss of Harry Chen, our valued Board member. As a Board member since 1979, Harry was committed to the thousands of clients served by the Hamilton-Madison House. We extend our deepest condolences to Pauline, his wife, and the entire Chen family. Donations in loving memory of Harry Chen, can be sent to Hamilton-Madison House, 50 Madison Street, New York, New York 10038.

title: The Special Bond That Siblings Share; Quality and Quantity
description: To the Editor:

title: Antidepressants Ease Hot Flashes, Cancer Study Shows
description: Hot flashes were quickly eased in frequency and severity by relatively small amounts of antidepressant drugs among women with breast cancer, a researcher said today at the meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology here.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Tokyo Street Fashion in New York Bows to No Horizon
description: The ganguro (dark face) girls were out in force -- faces tanned the color of football pigskin, eyes ringed with stark white panda makeup, and hair, as a bystander put it, ''dried, fried and blown to the side.'' The yamanba were also well represented, women fashioned after a Japanese folk figure whose name translates roughly as ''monster mountain woman.'' Followers of the trend toward ladylike dressing, take note.

title: Bittersweet Marriage Caught in a Musical
description: Inside ''Enter the Guardsman,'' a first-rate musical is struggling to get out. But until someone fills its music and lyrics with more zest, elevates the level and consistency of its wit and finds the magic to make its wise, bittersweet romance more palpable, ''Enter the Guardsman'' will remain a modest, intermittently charming entertainment. If it never catches fire, it generally exudes warmth.

title: Metro Business; Label Maker Buys a Rival
description: Paxar Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of woven labels for apparel, has completed its $61 million purchase of a German clothing-tag maker, Bornemann and Bick.

title: Words of Warning to Help Stop SIDS
description: Putting infants on their backs when they go to sleep is a widely accepted technique for reducing the risk of sudden infant death syndrome, but doctors need to do a lot more to get the word out, a new study finds.

title: CASTLE & COOK ACCEPTS SWEETENED BID FROM CHIEF
description: Castle & Cook Inc. accepted a sweetened takeover bid from its chief executive in a transaction that values the company, a leading developer of real estate in Hawaii, at about $600 million. Castle & Cook's chief executive, David Murdock, the company's biggest shareholder and chief executive of the Dole Food Company, will pay $230.4 million, or $18.50 a share, in cash, for the 73 percent of the shares he does not own or control and will assume the remainder in debt. The offer is 9 percent higher than the $17 a share that Mr. Murdock bid on March 30. Castle & Cooke was spun off from Dole Food to shareholders in December 1995. The Los Angeles-based company builds homes and owns resorts in Hawaii, and is one of that state's largest landowners.

title: Lack of 'Black Box' Hampers Crash Inquiry
description: The cockpit voice recorder was not working in the twin-engine turboprop that crashed near Scranton, Pa., on Sunday morning and apparently had never worked, because it was the wrong model for that airplane, the National Transportation Safety Board said today. And the plane did not carry a flight data recorder, the other kind of ''black box.''

title: Fusaichi Pegasus Arrives at Belmont
description: The Kentucky Derby winner, Fusaichi Pegasus, arrived at Belmont Park yesterday morning after a five-hour van trip from Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, where he finished second to Red Bullet in the Preakness on Saturday .

title: Two Mergers Highlight E-Commerce Trends
description: The consolidation of the business-to-business software market accelerated today with two big deals. The Vignette Corporation said it was acquiring OnDisplay Inc. in a $1.7 billion stock swap, while WebMethods Inc. is buying Active Software Inc. in a stock deal valued at $1.3 billion.

title: Carver Bancorp Allows 2 Dissidents to Take Board Seats
description: Carver Bancorp, the Harlem institution that is the largest black-run bank in the country, announced yesterday that it had given up its struggle to keep two dissident shareholders off its board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANSNER, KERMIT I.
description: LANSNER-Kermit I. On May 20, 2000. Loving husband of Fay and father of Gabrielle and Erica. Father-in-law of Eugene Villalobos and grandfather of Maya and Flora. The family will be receiving friends at Riverside Memorial Chapel (Amsterdam Ave at 76 St.), 10 am to 12 noon today. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about Senator Judd Gregg's blocking of money owed by the United States to the United Nations for peacekeeping referred incorrectly at one point to a staff member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who commented. The staff member, Pat M. Holt, is a man.

title: CORNING ACQUIRES REST OF INTELLISENSE FOR $500 MILLION
description: Corning Inc., a leading maker of glass used in fiber optic networks, agreed to buy the 67 percent of the IntelliSense Corporation it did not already own for $500 million in stock to speed development of optical switches. Part of the payment is contingent upon IntelliSense achieving certain performance objectives. IntelliSense makes switching technology that helps improve the performance of telecommunications systems to carry more voice, data and Internet services. Shares of Corning, which is based in Corning, N.Y., fell $7.44, or 4.1 percent, to $175.

title: Regarding Sexism On the Job: Plus Ca Change...
description: Suddenly, the engineering workshops at Snecma S.A., the engine maker based in Paris, seem as pristine as a chapel. The nude photographs and girlie calendars that used to be plastered on some of the walls have disappeared into desk drawers or been tossed into the trash bin.

title: Fueled by Contempt, Miller Is Ready to Roll
description: The player whose postseason career is tethered to New York was asked today to clarify a comment he made. Yes, Reggie Miller said on the eve of the Eastern Conference finals, he ''hates but respects'' the Knicks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERMAN, MICHAEL
description: SERMAN-Michael. Passed away peacefully on May 20th, 2000 at the age of 84. Dear husband of Laura. Father of Michael & Linda S. Fuld. Loving grandfather of Jonathan Fuld and Laura and Michael. Dad was a dynamic player in life. He was honorable, generous and proud. Dad was a man of his word. His spirit will be with us always. Private family service. We welcome friends to the home of Linda S. Fuld, 211 East 70th Street, New York City, on Wednesday, May 24th, 4:30PM-6:30PM.

title: SINGAPORE TELECOM PROFITS WEAKEN
description: Rising competition in Singapore's deregulated telecommunications industry contributed to a 5.3 percent decline in the fiscal-year profits of Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., the former monopoly still controlled by the government. The decline, to 1.85 billion Singapore dollars or about $1.1 billion, had been expected. Despite two failed attempts to expand overseas by taking stakes in Cable and Wireless HKT Ltd. and Time Engineering of Malaysia, SingTel said contributions from foreign investments grew 26 percent, accounting for 15 percent of pretax profit. Wayne Arnold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBURG, LAWRENCE
description: WEISBURG-Lawrence, 78, died on May 20, of melanoma. Beloved husband of Elaine Greene, father of Henry Weisburg and Lisa Donneson, William Weisburg and Pamela Wells, and grandfather of Jessica, Emily, Madeline, and Marina. Funeral Tuesday, May 23, 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Burial in Sag Harbor. Contributions in his memory may be made to Planned Parenthood or Handgun Control.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Benefits column of Sunday Styles this week about a dinner and show tomorrow at Bridgewaters, at the South Street Seaport, to raise money for children's mobile clinics in Eastern European countries misstated the information telephone number. It is (212) 467-6630, extension 212.

title: Trone Advertising Promotes Managers
description: Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C., and New York, appointed a next generation of top management yesterday.

title: AT&T PURCHASES STAKE IN VOICE RECOGNITION WEB SERVICE
description: AT& T said it bought a $60 million minority stake in Tellme Networks Inc. to become the primary provider of telecommunication services to the closely held company, which sends Web content by voice over telephones. As part of the agreement, AT& T will provide networking services for Tellme, which will help the company offer local content to users. Revenue comes from sponsors and audio advertisements. To use Tellme, consumers dial a toll-free number to get Web site information like sports and traffic news, restaurant listings, movie times and weather reports. The service uses voice recognition programs so a consumer can gain access to Web content without having to use a computer. Tellme is based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, LAWRENCE S., ED.D.
description: FINKEL-Lawrence S., Ed.D. The College of New Rochelle Community records with sorrow the death of Dr. Larry Finkel, Associate Professor, Graduate School, and Chair of the College Senate. An indefatigable teacher, instructor, and administrator, he devoted his considerable talents to the development of future educational leaders nationally and internationally. With an irrepressible passion for his work and for the College, he has been a unique member of this community, and we have been immeasureably strengthened by his nineteen years with us. We mourn his loss and celebrate his life. Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D. President Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Is It a Plane? No, It's a Bird And a Very Rare Bird Indeed
description: The weather was hot and sunny with a stiff southwest wind blowing at about 30 knots on Tuesday, May 9, when a large seabird, an albatross, came flying in off Buzzard's Bay at 11:45 a.m. and buzzed researchers hunkered down in a blind here.

title: Tension And Tragedy As Traveling Companions
description: If you passed Florence and Arthur Gateman on the road, you probably wouldn't give them a second look. Dressed nicely in the fashions of their time, 1958 -- she in a fashionable brown suit, he in jacket, tie and fedora -- they might be any middle-aged American couple on a motoring vacation. But some people might run if they knew that the Gatemans' passenger, an attractive but distressed young woman, had Hansen's disease (more commonly known as leprosy). In Mark R. Giesser's drama ''Hansen's Cab,'' the Gatemans (Melissa Hart and Avrom Berel) make their living transporting patients from their homes to leprosariums, in this case United States Military Hospital No. 66 in Carville, La.

title: A Lot of Harry Potter
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Nets Must Hurry Changing of the Guard
description: The Nets' principal owner, Lewis Katz, and the entire organization were aglow on Sunday after receiving the first pick in this summer's National Basketball Association draft. But their elation can quickly turn to confusion and embarrassment if the franchise does not soon fill its vacant front-office positions.

title: The New Look of the Senate Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Mideast Reality Check
description: After all these years of Israelis and Palestinians talking about the core issues -- Jerusalem, refugees, prisoners, territory -- you'd think there would be no surprises left now that we have reached the endgame. But in fact the final peace talks are turning out to be more explosive and shocking then either anticipated. Why?

title: Fear, Not Anger, Led to Shelter Island Slaying, Defense Says
description: When a carpenter was charged two years ago in the first murder case on remote Shelter Island, the police said he had killed a longtime friend in anger, believing that the friend had molested an 8-year-old girl and had bragged that he would get away with it.

title: White House and Agency Split on Internet Privacy
description: Clinton administration officials today threw cold water on a proposal by the Federal Trade Commission for legislation to protect consumer privacy on the Internet. But the commission chairman said failure to put new federal privacy-protection standards in place would undermine consumer confidence and significantly retard the development of commerce in cyberspace.

title: Devils Raise Level After Coach Raises Voice
description: How do you respond when your boss yells at you? How do you feel when you are harshly criticized, even when it's accurate? Do you go out to do well or to prove the boss wrong? Or do you sulk and pout and perform even less effectively than you did before?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ALAN L., M.D.
description: GOLDBERG-Alan L., M.D. 79 years old. Born in the Bronx, NY, April 22, 1921. Died May 20, 2000 in Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Muriel. Loving father of Judy, Louise and Eve. Much loved grandfather of Phoebe, Megan, Sean, Zach and Simon. Grew up in the Bronx. Graduated Evander Childs High School, Columbia College and New York University School of Medicine. He was a devoted family practitioner in the Bronx for 39 years. Served as President of the New York Academy of Family Practitioners in 1978. Accomplished jazz pianist, gifted storyteller and brilliant humorist, he entertained friends, family and patients. He will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, RICHARD E.
description: NOLAN-Richard E., on May 22nd, 2000 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Agnes. Devoted father of Anthony, Christopher, Timothy, Mariana and Katherine. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St., NYC, on Friday, 10:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Tour Bus Kills Actor As He Walks On 45th St.
description: A 71-year-old actor known for dozens of Off Broadway roles was struck and killed yesterday by a double-decker bus operated by New York Apple Tours, which for years has been criticized for flouting regulations and disrupting residential neighborhoods, the police said.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Pacing the Floor, Instead of Taking It

description: To the Editor:

title: Forced Smiles in Southeast Asia, as Relations Turn Sour
description: SINGAPORE  Diverging levels of political stability and allegations of political interference in internal affairs are straining relations among Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore  four of the five countries that formed the original core of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

title: The Lesson for the Speaker
description: Despite a rare public thrashing by some of his fellow Democrats, New York State's Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, managed to hold onto his job yesterday as one of the top three leaders in Albany. Mr. Silver triumphed after a feverish bargaining for loyalties in the last few days that surprised even some legislative veterans in its passion and divisiveness. In the end, however, Mr. Silver should understand that this revolt was not merely about exchanging speakers. It was about changing the closed and undemocratic methods that strangle the legislative process in Albany.

title: Testaverde to Take Part in Jets' Minicamp
description: Coach Al Groh expects quarterback Vinny Testaverde, on his way back from the Achilles' tendon injury that ended his 1999 season during the first game, to participate fully when the Jets begin a veterans' minicamp today. Testaverde has been participating in passing drills for the past few weeks.

title: Dumped Ballots Raise Worries in Haiti Vote
description: The results of an undetermined number of legislative races from the election on Sunday may have to be voided because ballots were either damaged, lost or left susceptible to fraud when tired and poorly trained poll workers dumped hundreds of ballot boxes in a jumble outside of electoral offices, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMPAL, JEAN, PIERRE
description: RAMPAL-Jean-Pierre. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall note with deep sadness the passing of Jean-Pierre Rampal. One of the greatest flutists of the 20th Century and one of the greatest musical spirits of our time, he was a constant and beloved presence at Carnegie Hall, with 45 performances over twenty-nine years. We will treasure forever his great legacy to music and will greatly miss him as a friend. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, ZOLTAN
description: STEINER-Zoltan. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board, and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the passing of Zoltan Steiner. Sincere condolences are extended to his son, Henry Steiner, M.D., distinguished Director of Surgery and Secretary of the Medical Board, and to his family. Joel A. Miele Sr., P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors Robert V. Levine, President & Chief Executive Officer Peter A. Galvin, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Chief Is Appointed at Magazine Publisher
description: Gruner & Jahr, the publisher of seven consumer magazines in the United States including McCall's, Fitness and Parents, has named a chief executive, three months after the departure of its previous chief.
