description: Mystery Reproduction

title: Chancellor's Political Ability Balances His Outsider Status
description: Last week, as Harold O. Levy pulled off the improbable feat of becoming chancellor of the New York City schools, he announced at a cabinet meeting that 30 volumes of chancellor's regulations -- accumulating since 1958 -- had been slashed to 9 volumes. Gone were vestiges like how to help students deal with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

title: Layoffs at J. D. Edwards
description: J. D. Edwards & Company disclosed plans today to lay off 800 employees, or 13 percent of its work force. The company, a maker of business-management software, warned earlier this month that second-quarter results had lagged expectations. The cuts also follow the resignation in April of the chief executive, Doug Massingill. He was replaced by Edward McVaney, a company co-founder and chairman. J. D. Edwards, based in Denver, said cutting the jobs would help save money on office space and other related expenses.

title: That Day on Iwo Jima
description: To the Editor:

title: New Microscopes May Soon Shine A Beacon Into Molecular World
description: A glowing point at the tip of an optical fiber could someday be the torch that lights the world of DNA, proteins and other molecules.

title: Colle & McVoy Wins Best of Show Award
description: Colle & McVoy Marketing Communications in Minneapolis, which is majority owned by the MDC Communications Corporation, has won the Best of Show award at the 30th annual Ace Awards ceremony.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE CONTINUES TO RISE. Coffee prices surged after growers agreed to limit exports in an effort to bolster prices. In New York, coffee for July delivery rose 5.35 cents, or 5.5 percent, to $1.033 a pound.

title: Schumann, Stravinsky and the Fine Art of Hitting Things
description: Somewhere behind the heaps of percussion instruments on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening lurked an orchestra. Not that it could be much heard over the din of Askell Masson's Concert Piece for Snare Drum and Orchestra, or seen in Stravinsky's ''Symphonies of Wind Instruments.''

title: Jazz Suite With a Park View; Lincoln Center Unveils Its Columbus Circle Plan
description: A dance floor with a 50-foot window on Central Park will be the new face of Jazz at Lincoln Center. At a news conference today the organization is to unveil plans for its new home, including what are billed as the world's first concert halls built especially for jazz: a 100,000-square-foot complex at Columbus Circle with two auditoriums, a club-size jazz cafe, two rehearsal studios and a classroom, all wired for recording, broadcast and Webcast.

title: Panel Advises That Clinton Be Disbarred
description: A disciplinary committee of the Arkansas Supreme Court recommended today that President Clinton be disbarred because of his ''serious misconduct'' in the Paula Jones sexual harassment case.

title: Critics Question Legitimacy of Venezuelan Election Process
description: With less than a week left before Venezuelans cast ballots in a ''mega-election'' to fill every office from president on down, the government's opponents are questioning the integrity of the vote and warning of protests if it is not fair.

title: Vulnerable No More: Gloomy Becomes a Tad Bouncy
description: Elliott Smith was remarkably comfortable on Wednesday night at Irving Plaza, leading his high-kicking rock band through the first of three sold-out performances.

title: No Easy Decisions for a Man of Decision
description: In quitting the Senate race last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani discovered that choosing a therapy for prostate cancer was a far more daunting effort than he had expected. Mr. Giuliani said he had to focus entirely on the decision, letting his immediate political future fall by the wayside.

description: To the Editor:

title: Former G.M. Executive Indicted On Charges of Taking Secrets
description: A former senior executive at General Motors has been indicted on charges of defrauding the company by taking boxes of its confidential documents with him when he jumped to a top job at Volkswagen in 1993, reviving one of the most celebrated cases in recent years involving accusations of industrial espionage.

title: A Family's Goal Is Met And a Gene Is Found
description: In a culmination of concerted efforts initiated by one determined family, three groups of researchers are reporting that they have found the gene mutation that causes a rare disorder known as pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, SALLY
description: WEINGARTEN-Sally. Of Riverdale, NY, on May 21, 2000, at age 90 after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. Survived by husband Carl, daughters Margit, Evelyn and Harriet; grandchildren Geryl, Lisa, Lynne, Darren and Jodi; great grandchildren Michael and Julia; brother Benno. Burial Tuesday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

description: STEELE-Geoffrey. 93, of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ on May 18, 2000. Husband of Peggie H. Steele. Stepfather of Anthony and Rex Jackson and Karlene Kent Dickey. A farewell party will be held in the Day Room at Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ from 4-7 PM on Friday, May 26. In lieu of flowers contributions to the friends at Princeton University Library, Princeton, NJ 08544.

title: LUNCH BREAK PROTEST DELAYED
description: Workers at South Korean brokerage firms plan to go on a general strike May 31 to protest the government's decision to scrap the lunch hour recess at the Korea Stock Exchange, the Korea Securities Trade Union said. The union had planned to begin the strike yesterday but decided to delay it. The union contends that the end of the midday break means workers will effectively not be able to leave their posts for lunch. Samuel Len

title: DISNEY'S TOYSMART.COM IS CLOSED AND OFFERED FOR SALE
description: Toysmart.com, an Internet toy retailer majority owned by the Walt Disney Company, shut down and was put up for sale after talks to provide more financing failed. Toysmart.com said it stopped taking orders on Friday, and that its 170 employees were let go. The company, which is based in Waltham, Mass., is the latest of a few Internet toy sellers to experience financial problems.

title: Knicks and Pacers in the Conspiracy Series
description: The conspiracy theories were spilling out of the Miami Heat locker room Sunday evening and seeping into the public consciousness in places as far away as Indiana. But it does not matter to Jeff Van Gundy if a fan in the farmland nodded in agreement when Tim Hardaway accused the officials of cheating the Heat in Game 7.

title: A Typical Day: Stocks Plunge, Then Rebound
description: The stock market plunged early yesterday as jittery investors dumped the technology stocks that many already agreed were overpriced and also sold some of the so-called old-economy stocks that had actually been doing reasonably well recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, KEVIN CHUNG CHI
description: KING-Kevin Chung Chi. On May 20, 2000. Beloved son of Chuen Fong and the late Albert. Loving brother of Michael. title: Where to Sip Spain's Best in New York
description: THE first place to look for Spanish wines is obvious: Spanish restaurants. Solera, Marichu and Meigas have well-chosen selections. Both Solera and Meigas have a solid lineup of reds from Rioja and Ribera del Duero. Marichu is more eclectic, with roses from Navarre and Rioja, albarinos from Rias Baixas, and reds from Carinena, Cigales and Emporda-Costa Brava. All three restaurants carry whites from the up-and-coming Basque winery Txomin Etxaniz.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM RISES. Platinum rose 2 percent as traders continued to expect tight inventories and no new supply from Russia. In New York, platinum for July delivery rose $10.80, to $541.50 an ounce.

title: SUNTERRA, STRUGGLING FOR SURVIVAL, TO DISMISS 930
description: The Sunterra Corporation, an owner of time-share vacation resorts, said late on Monday that it would dismiss about 930 workers at company headquarters in Orlando and might not be able to continue operations. Sunterra also said it had stopped all sales at resorts in Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Hilton Head, S.C.; Lake Conroy, Tex.; Steamboat Springs, Colo.; Santa Fe, N.M.; and other locations. While the reduction in sales and marketing jobs expected to reduce expenses, Sunterra still may not be able to continue operations. The company said it is pursuing alternatives to remain in business.

title: Buzzy Drootin, 80, Leading Jazz Drummer
description: Benjamin (Buzzy) Drootin, a Russian-born jazz drummer whose career spanned a half-century and who played with many leading jazz musicians, died on Sunday at the Actors Fund Retirement and Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. Four years went by without you, but your smile & your courage will always stay with those you loved. You 'll be in our hearts forever. Love, Steven and Adolfo

description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies in New York is significantly stepping up its commitment to the fast-growing realm of specialized marketing services outside the scope of traditional advertising.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Republican primary in New Jersey for the Fifth District seat held by Representative Marge Roukema omitted clarification for an imprecise reference by her opponent, E. Scott Garrett. His comment read, ''When Hillary Clinton failed to get her giant health bill through, she said, 'Maybe we can do it incrementally.' '' By ''she,'' Mr. Garrett meant Mrs. Clinton -- not Mrs. Roukema, who opposed the Clinton plan.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Wins Kelly Awards
description: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., took top honors with two awards, including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 19th annual Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Thursday, about the election of Harold O. Levy as New York schools chancellor -- the first non-Hispanic white person to hold the post permanently since 1983 -- misstated the percentage of white students in the city's public school system. It is 16 percent, not 6.

title: Stairs and Surhoff Top a Short List
description: Trade rumors are like office gossip for players, and many Yankees whispered to one another and reporters today, asking about all the names that are circulating. Like most gossip, however, substance is outweighed by reality. The Yankees are evaluating a handful of hitters for possible trades, with Oakland's Matt Stairs and Baltimore's B. J. Surhoff heading their list. Officials with other teams do not have the impression the Yankees are rushing to make a deal -- although everybody involved understands that with a few more losses, the principal owner George Steinbrenner may force his executives to make a deal.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; DAIMLERCHRYSLER IN MEXICO
description: DaimlerChrysler said it would invest about $2 billion in Mexico the next five years. Miles Bryant, president of the company's Mexico operations, said it was attracted by the country's free-trade agreements with Europe and other Latin American countries, which will help protect the company against any slowdown in the United States market. Dan Fineren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTERAMO, ANGELA
description: SANTERAMO-Angela (nee Castellaneta). Died on May 23, just short of her 93rd birthday in Tamarac, FL. Beloved wife for 46 years of Michael who died on May 17, 1975, & sister of Leonardo Castellaneta. Cherished mother of Nicholas, Cesare, Rose Grove and Mary Devins. She is survived by her six grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Her ashes will be buried beside her husband's in Fairmount Cemetery, Newark, NJ.

title: Japan Assailed For Omitting Data in Growth Calculations
description: Japan's official economic statistics have always been mistrusted. They became even more suspect recently when the government omitted an important piece of information on quarterly growth, apparently for the first time.

title: REALIGNMENT MEETING POSTPONED
description: Major League Baseball owners continue to struggle with realignment. As a result, Commissioner Bud Selig has indefinitely postponed an owners meeting scheduled for June13 and 14 in Detroit.

title: MORE BRAZILIANS BORROWING
description: Brazilian bank lending rose in April for the 10th consecutive month as the economic recovery increased consumers' appetite for credit, the central bank said. Banks lent $33 billion in April, a 4.1 percent increase from the month before. Lending rates, while extremely high by United States standards, fell to the lowest rate since 1994, at 58.1 percent. In another sign of recovery in Latin America's largest economy, the government said April unemployment fell to 7.8 percent, down from 8.1 percent in March. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Swell of Minority Students Is Predicted at Colleges
description: College enrollment will swell by some two million students -- to 19 million -- over the next 15 years, with black, Hispanic and Asian-American students accounting for 80 percent of the growth, according to a study scheduled for release today by the Educational Testing Service.

title: Lee Brewster, 57, Style Guru For World's Cross-Dressers
description: Lee G. Brewster, whose Greenwich Village boutique became a bazaar for transvestites from Avenue A to Abu Dhabi, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 57 and lived in Manhattan.

title: College Feeder Schools Feel Pinch of Competition
description: They attend top high schools in the New York region and the Northeast, and, within that rarefied group, they are better-than-average students. Banking on the reputations of their schools alone, they would most likely have been snapped up by many of the top colleges they dreamed of attending -- if only they had applied three years ago.

title: Reckonings; The Good News Bears
description: When I was around 8 years old, I had an occasional playmate who was incapable of having a simple good time. If he was having fun, he would overdo it, getting more and more wound up -- until, inevitably, he would burst into tears and throw a tantrum.

title: Gore Defends Policies on Israel With Attack on Rival's Father
description: Responding to Gov. George W. Bush's criticism of the Clinton administration's policies on Israel, Vice President Al Gore today accused Mr. Bush's father of trying to pressure Israel to adopt positions it strongly opposed during his presidency.

title: Health Care Leader to Retire as Consortium Chief
description: Dr. Robert G. Newman, an influential leader in New York health care, said yesterday that he would retire at the end of the year as president and chief executive of Continuum Health Partners, a consortium that includes Beth Israel Medical Center, St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center and the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, all in Manhattan, and Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Merger of London and Frankfurt Exchanges Clears a Hurdle
description: The plan to merge the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges moved a step forward today when the supervisory board of the German exchange voted to approve the deal.

title: Temporary Coalition Against Trade Bill Crosses Party and Ideological Lines
description: Representatives Barney Frank, a liberal Democrat from the Boston suburbs, and Dana Rohrabacher, a conservative Republican from southern California, don't agree on much.

description: Shareholders of The New York Times Company authorized a new class of stock yesterday intended to track the value of New York Times Digital, the company's Internet business division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, RICHARD M.
description: MILLS-Richard M. Of East Orleans, MA. Formerly of White Plains, NY on May 21. Beloved husband of Judith M. (Oloskey). Devoted father of Rebecca Jeanne Mills of VA. Brother of Albert and Edwina Mills, both of Norwood, MA. Professor Emeritus Fordham University, Bronx, NY. Visiting hours Wednesday morning from 8:30-9:30 AM at the KrawKornack Funeral Home, 1248 Washington St., Norwood, MA, followed by a funeral mass at 10 AM in St. George Catholic Church, Norwood, MA. Interment private.

title: 'Future of Hockey' Takes It Day at a Time
description: When an 18-year-old prepares to move from high school to college, his mother tells him to clean up his room and throw out some of the old junk. One artifact excavated is an Ontario Hockey League yearbook from 1990-91, taken home from one of dad's newspaper reporting assignments. On the cover is 18-year-old Eric Lindros of the Oshawa Generals, the big No. 88 in white numerals on the right sleeve of his red uniform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMOS, PAUL
description: RAMOS-Paul. It is with profound sorrow that the Board and staff of the AIDS Service Center of Lower Manhattan mourn the loss of our beloved Board Chair, Paul Ramos. He was a staunch advocate, a powerful, compassionate, wise and giving man. As a founding Board member of ASC and fearless leader of the Betances Health Unit, Paul led with authority and respect, and was an inspiration to all. He will forever remain a guiding force in our lives. Heartfelt condolences to Roni and all of Paul's family and the staff and Board of Betances.

title: A New Greenwich Village Bistro Happy to Be a Bistro
description: IN 1993, when most people wouldn't have known a dot-com from kingdom come, David and Carol Cesaro opened their little French bistro, L'Ardoise. The world, or at least a small part of it, has changed since then. Scads of restaurants have opened and flamed out, fortunes have been made and squandered, and still L'Ardoise has plugged away on its rather unfashionable block of First Avenue on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERMAN, MICHAEL
description: SERMAN-Michael. The Board of Governors and members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Michael Serman, beloved husband of Laura. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Ira J. Gelb, M.D., President

title: After 20 Years, Iranian Caviar Returns to America
description: CAVIAR from Iran will be sold here for the first time in 20 years. Trade barriers were lifted two months ago, and the first shipment of 440 pounds is expected to arrive in Boston today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COES, KENT DAY
description: COES-Kent Day, 90, on May, 22, 2000 of Montclair, NJ. Beloved husband of Helen (Stoll), and brother of H. Vinton Coes. title: BMC SOFTWARE PURCHASING OPTISYSTEMS FOR $70 MILLION
description: BMC Software Inc., a systems management software manufacturer, agreed yesterday to pay about $70 million in cash for OptiSystems Solutions Ltd., an Israeli maker of enterprise application management software for mainframe computer systems. BMC, which is based in Houston, makes software to speed up corporate databases and back up network data. Under terms of the deal, BMC agreed to pay $10 cash for each OptiSystems share. Shares of OptiSystems rose $1 each, to $9.375. BMC's shares rose 31.25 cents, to $43.25.

title: Joni Mitchell Transcends the Musical Packages
description: It was a little startling to hear Joni Mitchell -- one of pop music's most iconic and stubborn free spirits -- announce from the stage of the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Monday night that she was about to take the audience on ''an old-fashioned journey through romantic love.'' Not that she hasn't written about all kinds of romantic love before in her own onrushing imagistic way or that she doesn't have a right to be old-fashioned;, it was the presentation. You have to picture her saying it while standing in a very un-bohemian purple dress in front of an enormous string orchestra.

title: THE HOUSE OPENS A SPIRITED DEBATE OVER CHINA TRADE
description: The House opened a spirited debate today on the China trade bill, as a furious final round of horse-trading with undecided members demanding everything from gas pipelines to a weather station left supporters confident that they would eke out a victory on Wednesday.

Service Wednesday 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times; This Team Could Score With Nielsen
description: IT took one early play Mark Jackson passing in the lane between his legs to Jalen Rose and Rose throwing outside to Austin Croshere for 3 -- to remind us how expressive and joyful this sport can be. It took one game to remember that basketball with offense can still be fierce, and how much the National Basketball Association owes the Knicks for saving it from more Miami Heat.

title: Oscar Shaftel, Fired After Refusing McCarthy, Dies at 88
description: Oscar H. Shaftel, who was one of the original faculty members at Queens College when it opened in 1937 and was fired by the city in 1953 after he refused to answer a Senate subcommittee's questions about Communist affiliation in academia, died at his Queens home on May 10. He was 88.

Buchanan.

title: Grudge Match

When Everett is reminded of an article in a New York newspaper two months ago, the new villain for Yankees fans insists that he must have been quoted from a group interview.

Friends Say Clinton Is Fighting for His Law License Out of Pride
description: Even though he has not practiced law since 1982, President Clinton has kept his license current by sending a $100 annual renewal check to the Arkansas Supreme Court, the registry of lawyers in his home state.

title: Bush Says U.S. Should Reduce Nuclear Arms
description: Declaring that the nation's security no longer required ''a nuclear balance of terror,'' Gov. George W. Bush called today for new -- and possibly unilateral -- reductions in American nuclear weapons coupled with a robust antimissile defense system.

title: Lazio Campaigns on Subway and Hits a Few Bumps
description: On his first Manhattan campaign stop as a Senate candidate, Representative Rick A. Lazio boarded the subway yesterday morning and criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton for tooling around in ''chauffeured limousines.''

title: Rowland's Order to Cut Emissions Sets Off Political Squabble Over Usefulness
description: When Gov. John G. Rowland signed an executive order last week directing Connecticut power plants to cut smokestack emissions, the political spin cycle began almost immediately.

title: Germans Plan To Trim Army And Rely Less On the Draft
description: Germany's defense minister accepted a recommendation today to drastically reform and shrink a draft-based army that is still set up to fight the cold war. But he stopped short of endorsing an all-professional army similar to those of other European countries.

title: Commencements; President of Rutgers Sees 'A New Era' With Internet
description: The Rutgers University president, Francis L. Lawrence, told graduates at the university's commencement today that the Internet would usher in ''a new era of fundamental and far-reaching change'' in education and that young people should be prepared to use it to its full potential.

title: Talking The Talk? Ask Miller
description: The Knicks treated Reggie Miller's comments concerning his distaste for their team like background noise today. Mostly, they ignored the Pacers' loquacious guard.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE HOUSE

title: Help China And Help Chinatown
description: In their fight against granting China permanent normal trade relations, labor unions say they are trying to protect Americans from having to compete with foreign workers who are paid barely a living wage to work in inhumane conditions. But keeping China out of the global economy will actually hurt American factory workers more than it helps them.

title: Gathering a Home-Grown Feast in the Hamptons
description: I NO longer eat out in the Hamptons between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the collapse of the Israeli buffer zone in southern Lebanon misstated the timing of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon led by Ariel Sharon, who now heads the opposition Likud Party and who criticized Israel's current withdrawal. The invasion occurred in 1982, not a quarter-century ago.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on National Security and Arms Policy
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Gov. George W. Bush's remarks yesterday in Washington on national security, and the question-and-answer session that followed and included a brief remark by Gen. Colin L. Powell, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIEGERICH, JOSEPH F.
description: GIEGERICH-Joseph F. Of Eastchester, NY, formerly of the Bronx, retired Battalion Chief, 18th Battalion, New York City Fire Department. Husband of Mary Aileen and the late Claire Giegerich. Father of Stephen, Thomas and Joseph. Grandfather of Marianne, Elizabeth, James, Matthew, Christine, Emily and Daniel. Father by marriage to Linda Jean, Anne Marie, Joseph J. and Mary. Grandfather by marriage to Kristopher, Karen, Jeanne Marie, Keith, Amanda, Andrew, Molly, Megan and Kathleen. A veteran of the U.S. Navy, he held a Bachelor of Arts degree from John Jay School of Criminal Justice and a Master's in English from Fordham University, both obtained in retirement. He was a lover of language, literature and history, and an avid baseball fan. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 79 PM Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, on Friday, May 26th at 9:45 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Inner City Scholarship Fund (Archdiocese of NY).

title: Mission? Improbable, but the Pigeons Are Nifty
description: After a splendidly confusing setup involving a Russian scientist, some kind of diabolical science experiment and one of those peel-off latex faces that have become a hallmark of the franchise, ''M:I-2,'' or ''Mission: Impossible 2'' tracks down its hero, Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise), in mid-vacation, hanging by his fingertips on the edge of a spectacular rock formation somewhere in the American Southwest. The camera circles like a curious buzzard, swooping and soaring in a brilliant aerial minuet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, LILLIAN
description: HOCHBERG-Lillian. On May 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Rema Goldberg, Kera Greene and Victoria Hochberg. Adoring grandmother of Justin Goldberg and Julie Goldberg, Scott Herzog, Jena JakeFriedman and Seth Herzog. A strong advocate for civil liberties, she will be profoundly missed. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Alzheimer's Association.

title: Board Member Denies Conflict In Dual Roles
description: The Board of Education member who is leading its effort to integrate the Internet into the classroom is also the co-chairman and a significant stockholder of a new company trying out an Internet test-coaching program in more than two dozen New York City public schools.

title: Autopsy Is Inconclusive In Boy's Death on Bus
description: The medical examiner's office said yesterday that an autopsy had not determined the cause of death of an 11-year-old Queens boy who was found dead Monday morning on his school bus, and that further tests were necessary.

title: High Level of Insulin Linked To Breast Cancer's Advance
description: In what appears to be a strong new risk factor for progression of breast cancer, high levels of insulin in the blood augur badly for women with the disease, a Canadian study reported here today has found.

title: Peace in Oslo, No Peace in Jerusalem
description: The recent rioting in the West Bank and Gaza, the worst in a decade, is a reminder of the stultifying imbalance in bargaining power between Israel and the Palestinian Authority -- created with American help in the 1993 Oslo accords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANGSER, LAWRENCE S.
description: BANGSER-Lawrence S. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are saddened by the passing of Lawrence S. Bangser, the husband of Phyllis B. Bangser, a devoted member of the agency's, Rita J. and Stanley H. Kaplan House Divisional Committee. We express our deepest sympathies to Phyllis; his children, Hank, Mike and Maggie; his five grandchildren; and other members of his family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President, JBFCS Irene Shiffman, Chairwoman, Kaplan House Divisional Cmte. Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President, JBFCS George Daniels, Director, Kaplan House

title: Suit to Be Filed In Laborer's Death
description: Six months after a 22-year-old Mexican laborer, Eduardo Daniel, was killed in a collapse at a Brooklyn construction site, lawyers for his estate said yesterday that they would file suit today against his employer, Eugene Ostreicher, a builder who is under criminal investigation by state and local authorities.

title: Hunting for Pigs, And Florida's Past
description: BILL WALLACE counts himself one lucky guy.

title: United States and Indonesia Quietly Resume Military Cooperation
description: The Clinton administration has quietly resumed military cooperation with Indonesia, senior defense officials said today, eight months after cutting off those ties following massacres in East Timor.

description: Another Austin Internet Firm Announces Layoffs

title: Out of 'Spin City' and Onto a New Stage; Michael J. Fox's Fight With Parkinson's Is Both Personal and Public
description: In an odd way, Michael J. Fox said the other day, he feels liberated by his decision to reveal his nearly decade-long battle with Parkinson's disease.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose on speculation that higher interest rates will slow economic growth in the United States, reducing demand for its financial assets. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.58 yen, down from 107.10.

title: Learning at Home, Students Take the Lead
description: It is 10 a.m., and the school buses in this Washington suburb have long ago finished their rounds. But the O'Malleys' old house is rocking.

title: Metro Business; Oneida to Buy Sakura
description: Oneida Ltd., the world's largest maker of stainless steel and silver-plated flatware, agreed yesterday to buy Sakura Inc. for about $40 million.

title: A Family Dynasty Turns Against Itself
description: The urbane, soft-spoken Seymour Milstein and his blustery, cigar-waving brother, Paul, used their good cop, bad cop approach to deal-making over the last five decades to turn their father's Bronx flooring company into a vast empire worth an estimated $5 billion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: MERRILL LYNCH, New York, named Kevan Watts, executive chairman at the Asia Pacific business, to the post of co-chief of investment banking, based in London. Also, Richard Saltzman, who oversees real estate and leveraged finance, was named chief operating officer for global investment banking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSON, DR. E. LAWRENCE
description: HANSON-Dr. E. Lawrence. Of Newport, Rhode Island, at age 64, after a prolonged illness. Born in Palmer, Nebraska. Husband of Jacqueline; father of Leslie Jill of New York and Lauren Polly of Boston; son of Robert and Eleanor of San Diego, California. Instructor and Fellow at New York University/Bellevue Hospitals Medical Center, Harvard Medical School/ Peter Bent Brigham Hospital and the State University of New York at Syracuse. He practiced thoracic and vascular surgery in Erie, Pennsylvania and most recently in Providence, Rhode Island. Served as a Captain & Paratrooper in the U.S. Army, 82nd Airborne Division during the Berlin crisis. He was an avid skier, sailor, horseman and accomplished jazz musician. In his memory please send contributions to the Memory Clinic at Butler Hospital, 345 Blackstone Blvd., Providence, Rhode Island 02906.

title: W.U.S.A. and M.L.S. Agree to Cooperate on Women's League
description: Bargaining from a position of strength, the Women's United Soccer Association emerged victorious yesterday in its attempt to become the sole operator of a women's professional outdoor league that is to begin play next spring.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APPLIED DIGITAL SOLUTIONS INC., Palm Beach, Fla. an electronic commerce systems provider, terminated its plan to acquire ATEC Group Inc., Hauppauge, N.Y., a systems integrator, because of difficult market conditions.

title: Dueling Attack Ads Etch Senate Campaign in Vitriol
description: Jon S. Corzine intensified his television campaign for the United States Senate today, letting loose a $2 million-a-week barrage of commercials that accuse former Gov. Jim Florio, his opponent in the Democratic primary, of lying about Social Security.

title: Lindros Returning to Face Devils in Game 6
description: For the first time in more than two months, Eric Lindros has been given medical clearance to play hockey.

title: Florio's Style, Like Tax Rise, Remains Issue in Senate Race
description: For all the countless, impassioned speeches Jim Florio has delivered in his quest for the Democratic nomination for New Jersey's United States Senate seat, the most telling two words in his campaign are the ones Mr. Florio has refused to utter: ''I'm sorry.''

title: Chase, the Eager Acquirer, To Buy Investment Boutique
description: Chase Manhattan has agreed to acquire the Beacon Group, a private Manhattan investment and advisory firm founded in the early 1990's by a group of former Goldman, Sachs deal makers.

title: Luring Celebrity Hounds Into the Halls of History
description: In the paternalistic spirit of Victorian England, Lord Palmerston believed that the general public could be inspired to ''noble actions'' and ''good conduct'' if allowed to study the features of ''those who have done things worthy of our admiration.'' So, with this uplifting thought, he used his authority as prime minister to approve a small grant for the creation of a National Portrait Gallery in London.

title: COMMERCECONNECT PLANS TO BUY CYGNUS BUSINESS
description: CommerceConnect Media, a seven-month-old company planning to publish trade magazines and operate Web sites, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Cygnus Business Media, owner of trade magazines and Web sites, for $275 million. Cygnus, based in Atlanta, owns 48 trade magazines and 17 custom publications, organizes 16 trade shows and conferences and runs 60 Web sites for industries that include agriculture, construction equipment, transportation and food. CommerceConnect is a partnership between its chief executive, Paul Mackler, and ABRY Partners L.L.C., a Boston-based company that buys equity stakes in media and communications companies.

title: Still a Star Of the Southwest
description: WHEN a party has been going full-tilt for nearly a decade, it tends to lose a little steam. If any restaurant has a right to slow down and show signs of fatigue, it's Mesa Grill, an instant hit on opening its doors in 1991 and still a downtown favorite, crowded and clamorous at lunch, and even more crowded and clamorous at night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LOUISE
description: SMITH-Louise (nee Luyster). On May 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harold A. Dear mother of Hope Bergenfeld and Lee Harold Smith. Grandmother of six and great grandmother of one. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (20th St.), NYC, Tuesday, May 30, 8:30-9:30 AM. Mass of Christian burial Epiphany RC Church Tuesday, 10:00 AM. Interment private.

title: Hostile Bid for Dexter Is Cut, to First Offer
description: International Specialty Products Inc. said today that it had lowered its hostile bid for the Dexter Corporation to the original offer of $45 a share, or about $933 million, accusing Dexter of ''delaying tactics'' and citing recent fluctuations in financial markets.

title: Must Be the Shoes as Testaverde Slips
description: When Vinny Testaverde disappeared from sight today, briefly slipping behind the horizon created by his linemen during the first practice of a four-day minicamp for veterans, the Jets' hierarchy may have suffered a few nervous moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEELSEN, JOAN FELDMAN
description: NEELSEN-Joan Feldman, 68, of Fillmore, CA, formerly of Forest Hills, NY on May 22nd. Beloved daughter of the late Betty and Sidney Feldman, cherished mother of Jane Ehrenreich and Andy Eisenberg, the best Nana in the world to her grandson, Cole Eisenberg, loving sister of Robert. We will miss her generous spirit, warm heart (and the beautiful knitted blankets). Contributions may be sent to the American Cancer Society. Private funeral.

title: Washington Loosens Restrictions on Sales of Weapons to Allies
description: Sobered by shortcomings in the NATO alliance in the battle last year for Kosovo, the Clinton administration is overhauling its controls on arms exports to friendly nations for the first time since the end of the cold war, American officials said today.

title: A Rural Intruder's Slaying Unsettles England
description: Tony Martin was a 55-year-old farmer with an obsessive fear of intruders who lived alone in a debris-strewn farmhouse called Bleak House. Fred Barras was a teenager with a long criminal record who lived with his family in a housing development 70 miles away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIORE, EMANUEL R.
description: PIORE-Emanuel R. The Board of Trustees and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School community sadly note the death of Emanuel R. Piore, Class of 1926, a former Trustee. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Nora Kahn Piore, his son Michael J. Piore, his daughters Jane Piore Gilman, Class of 1962, and Margot Piore Onek, Class of 1960, his granddaughter Ana Piore, Class of 1992 and his entire family. A renowned physicist and educator, a gifted researcher and visionary leader, many of Dr. Piore's endeavors helped to shape modern communications and computing. Dr. Piore's life exemplifies the vision of the founder of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, Felix Adler, who said, ''Education, as we conceive of it, is designed to train students for the growing life of the world, the destiny of the human race and for their part in achieving it.'' James A. Gara and S. Donald Sussman, Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Joseph P. Healey, Ph.D. Head of School

title: An online agency is offering reimbursement for some common frustrations like tardy flights.
description: THIS is not how my mother brought me up to address strangers, but circumstances argued for bluntness yesterday when I spoke with Hal Rosenbluth, the chief executive of Rosenbluth International, the big travel-management company.

title: MARKS & SPENCER CUTS PAYOUT
description: For the first time in its 106-year history, the British retailer Marks & Spencer cut its dividend, as part of a struggle to revive profit and fight competition. The cut triggered a jump of 40 pence in its stock, to 260.75 pence. The 18 percent rise was the biggest one-day gain in 12 years, after the stock hit a nine-year low on Monday. The reduction in the dividend, from 14.4 pence, to 9 pence, was depicted by analysts as a bold move by the chairman, Luc Vandevelde, who took over last February after more than two years of declines in profits and share prices. Alan Cowell

She is survived by her husband of 50 years, Bernard; her beloved son, David O. of Beverly Hills, CA; daughter Barbara Peloquin of Boca Raton, FL, and two grandsons, Nicholas and Matthew. Loving sister of Joseph N. Muzio of Leonia, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. Memorial services will be held in FL and NJ.

title: No Big Surge in Sex Programs Is Expected From Cable Ruling
description: The Supreme Court's decision on Monday striking down a law that required many cable systems to limit sexually explicit channels to late-night hours will most likely reap a modest increase in profits for programmers but is not expected to hasten a vast explosion of sexually oriented material on cable.

title: City to Ask Immediate Suspension of Bus Line After Fatality
description: City officials said yesterday that they would ask a judge to suspend the license of New York Apple Tours immediately, a day after one of its double-decker tour buses fatally struck a 71-year-old pedestrian in Midtown, an accident that once again set off concerns about a company with a long record of environmental, safety and traffic violations.

description: Scott Rink's ''Of Melodrama and Murder'' got off to a smashing start on Saturday night.

description: French Bill Has Web Ramifications

title: Citrus Shrimp, Thai Style
description: ALTHOUGH lime is by far the most commonly used citrus in the cooking of Thailand and Southeast Asia, grapefruit and its close relative pomelo are often found in savory dishes, especially cool salads. Either adds distinctive flavor, unusual texture and an impressive amount of juice to a simple dish. And at the end of the grapefruit season, it's easier to see grapefruit as a cool refreshing centerpiece rather than a winter stopgap.

title: PIVOTAL TECHNOLOGIES TO BE BOUGHT FOR $242.5 MILLION
description: The Broadcom Corporation, the top maker of semiconductors for digital set-top boxes, agreed last night to buy the Pivotal Technologies Corporation for $242.5 million in stock to add chips that speed information to flat-panel displays. The company will exchange about 1.94 million shares for all of Pivotal's preferred and common stock. The closely held Pivotal, based in Pasadena, Calif., makes semiconductors that regulate the flow of information from computers and set-top boxes to the flat screens, which take up less space than computer monitors. Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., expects to take a charge this quarter related to the acquisition. Broadcom's shares fell $11.0625 each yesterday, to $125.

title: Height Limits In Zoning Plan Draw Concern Of Hospitals
description: Say ''height limits'' and most New Yorkers probably imagine lopping a few dozen floors off a skyscraper in the middle of Manhattan.

title: Israel's Allies Flee, Fearing for Their Lives and Leaving Everything Behind
description: In the crush at the gray steel gates leading into Israel here today, Abdullah Abu Samra, a 24-year veteran of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia, fumbled with a suitcase, stuffing it with clothes he pulled from a large plastic bag.

title: Our Towns; Long Reach Of Words Said Long Ago
description: AT the end of a debate last week between New Jersey's Democratic contenders for the United States Senate, Jim Florio declared: ''I regard Social Security as the defining issue of this election.''

title: Bush's Missile Defenses Could Limit Warhead Cuts, Experts Warn
description: It lacked details and raised, but failed to answer, tantalizing questions. But Gov. George W. Bush's call today for ''a new approach'' to the nation's nuclear arsenal represented what could be, in the view of experts, a significant shift in arms control and post-cold-war relations with Russia.

title: Labor Issues Could Thwart Airlines' Plans
description: For years, labor unions have been a thorn in the side of the UAL Corporation and the US Airways Group, and now that the two airlines are planning to combine, experts wonder if the unions have enough power to squash the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEELE, GEOFFREY
description: STEELE-Geoffrey. 93, of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ on May 18, 2000. Husband of Peggie H. Steele. Stepfather of Anthony and Rex Jackson and Karlene Kent Dickey. A farewell party will be held in the Day Room at Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ from 4-7 PM on Friday, May 26. In lieu of flowers contributions to the friends at Princeton University Library, Princeton, NJ 08544.

description: Gov. George W. Bush set aside his customary reserve toward House Republicans in a trip to Capitol Hill today and was rewarded with an outpouring of admiration.

description: ZIMMERMAN-Estelle. Surviving spouse of the late Dr. Morris Zimmerman. Funeral services Wednesday, May 24th, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak today declared an end to the ''tragedy'' of Israel's two-decade occupation of southern Lebanon, as the last remaining Israeli troops and pro-Israeli militias pulled out of the border strip once known as Israel's security zone.

description: United Airlines to Acquire US Airways for $4.3 Billion

title: Corrections
description: The chart of Votes in Congress on Sunday misstated the action of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, on a provision to cut off financing for United States troops in Kosovo by July 1, 2001. He voted to strike the provision.

description: Gates Optimistic at Executive Gathering

title: New Bankruptcy Filing by Smith Corona
description: Smith Corona, the long-renowned but technologically eclipsed typewriter company, filed today for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to speed its $6 million sale to the privately held Carolina Wholesale Office Machine Company.

title: Metro Business; All Park Laurel Units Sold
description: The $99.5 million Park Laurel apartment tower development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has sold all the 53 units available, a year away from completion.

title: Is Salmon Organic? Not Yet
description: SENATOR TED STEVENS of Alaska says the wild salmon that swim around the waters of his state are so pure and clean they are entitled to wear the organic label.

title: Topics of The Times; The N.R.A. in Times Square
description: Give the National Rifle Association credit for audacity. At its annual convention last weekend it announced plans to build a theme restaurant in Times Square, along the lines of the World Wrestling Federation's new Times Square restaurant and, farther uptown, Planet Hollywood. The N.R.A. also plans an electronic-game arcade and gift store called NRA Sports Blast, which it described as an ''exciting total shooting sports and sporting goods experience.'' The gift store, a spokesman said, would not sell guns or live ammunition.

title: National News Briefs; South Carolina Governor Signs Flag Compromise
description: In an unusual live statewide television broadcast tonight, Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina signed into law a hard-won compromise that removes the Confederate battle flag from the dome of the state Capitol, where it has flown since 1962.

title: NEXTLINK BUYING FIBER OPTIC NETWORKS IN EUROPE
description: Nextlink Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy multiple European fiber optic networks from Level 3 Communications Inc. for $306 million. Separately, Nextlink said it would receive a $400 million investment from Forstmann Little & Company, the investment vehicle of the buyout specialist Nicholas C. Forstmann. The investment will increase Forstmann Little's stake in Nextlink to 10 percent. In January, the New York-based firm said it had invested $850 million in Nextlink. The fiber optic networks being bought from Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., will connect 21 major European cities. Nextlink, which is based in McLean, Va., builds fiber optic networks and sells capacity on them to phone and Internet companies.

title: Chief Is Named At Ameritrade
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, the fifth-biggest online brokerage firm, said today that Thomas K. Lewis Jr. had been appointed chief executive, succeeding the founder J. Joe Ricketts, who remains chairman.

title: VODAFONE NAMES CHAIRMAN
description: Vodafone AirTouch, appointed Lord MacLaurin chairman of the company. The move follows the resignation of Sam Ginn, who had been chairman and chief executive of AirTouch Communications before it merged with Vodafone. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Arriving Now, From Every Coast
description: WITH clams, it's cold beer, not Champagne. Oysters call for black tie, but with clams, jeans or shorts are fine. Nobody puts caviar and creme fraiche on clams.

description: IN THE HEART OF THE SEA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONGE, JOSEPH P.
description: MONGE-Joseph P. On Saturday, May 20, 2000 at Rancho Santa Fe, California from pneumonia at age 88. North American business executive and humanitarian. Rancho Santa Fe community leader since retirement in 1977 as Vice Chairman of International Paper Company and Chairman of Canadian International Paper Company after 40 years of service in New York and Montreal. Acted as Director of Royal Bank of Canada, Scandinavian Airlines System, Tahsis Company of British Columbia, Bradford National Corporation, California Life Corporation and Scarsdale National Bank. Named by U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1967 to the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped and served as Employer Committee Chairman and Executive Committee member. Also served the New York Speech Rehabilitation Institute (President and Chairman), ICD Rehabilitation Institute and Research Center (Director), National Multiple Sclerosis Society (Director) and International Federation of Multiple Sclerosis Societies (Executive Committee). Honored in 1969 by National Rehabilitation Institute (President's Award for ''outstanding contribution to rehabilitation movement'') and in 1977 by National Conference of Christians and Jews (Brotherood Award for ''distinguished service in field of human relations''). Born New York, New York 1912. Graduated Wagner College (summa cum laude 1934) and Harvard Law School (1937) and received an honorary Phd. in Humanities from Wagner College (1981). Married in 1940 to Dorothy Oschmann Monge (1912-1985). Survived by brother William F. Monge of Augusta, Georgia, by son Jay Parry Monge and his wife Elizabeth Tracy of Rye, New York and Charlotte, North Carolina, and by grandsons Justin Parry Monge of Rye, New York and Lindsay Newton Monge of Rancho Santa Fe, California. Memorial services were private. Contributions in Memory of Joseph and Dorothy Monge may be made to the Rancho Santa Fe Foundation, P.O. Box 811, Rancho Santa Fe, California 92067.

title: Testimony in Pirro Fraud Case Says Pay for Paternity Investigators Came From His Companies
description: In the most dramatic and adversarial day in the federal tax-fraud case against Albert J. Pirro Jr., six private investigators from Florida, Indiana and the New York region testified today that they had been hired to help Mr. Pirro fight a paternity suit that he then apparently tried to deduct as a business expense.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You know when birds fly out of a cage? That's how we feel.''

title: No Midwest Drought: Pacers Bury Knicks
description: Bodies were careening and banging in the mosh pit around the paint as Indiana's unassuming Austin Croshere slipped outside of the Knicks' attention like a lost thought. He wasn't important, was he?

title: Flamingo Fundamentals
description: My family moved to the country outside Atlanta when I was around 5. I used to tell people I helped my dad build the old family place. We had a mule, Kate, and a sled, and we'd pick up fieldstones, load the sled and haul it to the house. My mom still lives there.

title: Top Field Expected
description: The Japan Airlines Big Apple Classic, to be held July 13-16 at Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., has commitments from the top 10 players on this year's Ladies Professional Golf Association money list.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Sir John Gielgud yesterday misidentified the actress who played Ophelia to his Hamlet on Broadway in 1936. As shown in a picture with the obituary, she was Lillian Gish; Jessica Tandy played the role with Mr. Gielgud earlier that year in the London production.

title: A Common Heart and Uncommon Brain
description: Have you noticed how many well-educated characters are holding forth on New York stages?

title: Israelis Out of Lebanon After 22 Years
description: Draped with bandoleers, Shiite Muslim guerrillas reclaimed the Israeli-occupied zone in southern Lebanon today, and as they giddily rode abandoned Israeli tanks through village after village, they laid waste to Israel's plan for an orderly, scheduled withdrawal.

title: Lindros No Factor In Devils' Game Plan
description: The first step was taken in Philadelphia Monday night, when the Devils convincingly brushed aside the uninspired Flyers. But despite a 4-1 victory to stave off elimination, the team still has a treacherous climb before advancing in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Furor Over Bill Obscures Crucial Emigration Issue
description: The House vote on upgrading economic relations with China on Wednesday involves nearly every aspect of international relations: trade, human rights, national security and sweatshop labor. But the House will decide on an issue so arcane that it is almost never mentioned by supporters or opponents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILZER, HARRIET LAMB
description: SILZER-Harriet Lamb at home in Bedford, NY on May 21st, 2000 after an extended illness.She was born in Brookline, Mass. the daughter of the late Pauline Ayers Lamb and Ernest Lamb. She is survived by her husband Parker W. Silzer and a brother David S. Lamb, two brothers, Ernest and Walter are deceased. Five of her six children with whom she shared great understanding and devotion were with her at her death. They are Chesley Welch, Betsy Anderson, Jennifer Clark, Christopher and Nicholas McLaren and Richard McLaren who predeceased her. She leaves 8 grandchildren Monica and Brittany McLaren, Hayden and Harriet Anderson, Rebecca and Samuel McLaren and Paxton and Chase Clark. title: Drug Laws That Destroy Lives

Nelson Rockefeller in 1973, have helped propel the state prison population to a fivefold increase between then and 1999. Some 22,300 drug offenders are currently confined in state prisons. Many of these inmates are nonviolent users or small-time sellers who were dispensing drugs to support their own addictions. The annual budget cost of this incarceration is a staggering $700 million. But the human costs are even more horrendous. Excessive prison sentences destroy families for no good reason and prevent nonviolent offenders from leading productive lives.

title: Topics of The Times; The Elusive Ivorybil

The bird originally ranged from Ohio and Indiana in the north to the islands of the Caribbean in the south. The ivorybill largely relied on dense, tall stands of pine trees. When these began to disappear, so did the bird.

description: Flashing fake police badges that were movie props and other bogus law enforcement identifications, undercover investigators effortlessly entered 19 sensitive federal buildings including the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Pentagon and the Justice Department where the investigators sauntered into the attorney general's fifth-floor suite of offices.

title: Directors, Out of Character, Try Charting New Courses
description: When the film festival here features as many major directors taking their work in new directions as this year's did, that's notable.

title: 19 on Dodgers Penalized For Fighting at Wrigley
description: In the latest sign that Major League Baseball is cracking down on unruly behavior by players, the commissioner's office yesterday fined and suspended 19 members of the Los Angeles Dodgers for leaping into the stands and brawling with fans at Chicago's Wrigley Field last week.

title: FPL TO LEASE FIBER OPTIC LINES TO SBC COMMUNICATIONS
description: FPL Group Inc. agreed to lease fiber optic lines covering major cities in Florida to SBC Communications Inc. for as much as $110 million. SBC, the largest United States local-telephone company, will use the lines to provide voice and data services to customers in Miami, Orlando, Boca Raton, Fort Lauderdale, St. Petersburg, Tampa and West Palm Beach. FPL FiberNet, a unit of the FPL Group, based in Juno Beach, Fla., operates a 1,600-mile fiber optic network in Florida and is installing lines in more than 150 cities statewide.

description: Tripp Charges Are Dropped

description: To the Editor:

title: Ellis Kohs, 84, Composer of Works In a Modern and Classical Mode
description: Ellis Kohs, a composer known for works in which contemporary harmonic ideas were combined with the structural elegance of Classical forms, died at a nursing home in Los Angeles on May 17. He was 84.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on May 12 with an article about the United Methodist Church meeting in Cleveland, where leaders affirmed opposition to the ordination of active gays and to the blessing of same-sex unions, referred imprecisely to a group singing ''We Shall Overcome.'' The singers were bishops who supported demonstrators against the votes; they were not themselves demonstrators.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Sports of The Times; Defrocked Captain Comes Back
description: COLD. The entire Eric Lindros saga is cold. He probably should not even be playing, given his history of concussions. The Philadelphia Flyers give the impression that he is superfluous. And he may be playing for all the wrong reasons, like retaining his value for next year.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about merger talks between the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange mislabeled the scales showing trading volume in the number of contracts for futures and options. The figures are in the hundreds of millions, not the millions.

title: In the Art of the Sarod, Echoes of the Human Voice
description: Ustad Amjad Ali Khan's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening was a marvelous demonstration of the art of the sarod, an instrument that three centuries of tradition in India have contrived to make sound rather like an electric guitar, at least when amplification is used, as here it inevitably was.

title: A Lego Webcam Turns a Toy Into a Robot That Stands Guard
description: Lego's popular Mindstorm line of programmable toy robots proved that it was fun to watch robots do your bidding. The latest addition to the Mindstorm line may prove that it's just as much fun to have a robot watch you.

title: Russia Warns Afghanistan Not to Aid Rebel Groups
description: Russia warned today that it might bomb targets in Afghanistan if the Islamic-led government there shelters and supports rebels fighting in Chechnya and former Soviet republics in Central Asia.

title: From the Trade Debate: Democracy and Economics, Idealism and Politics
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate today on the trade bill that would grant permanent normal trading relations with Beijing, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Zipping Along at the Indy 500 From the Comfort of Home
description: News Watch: Zipping Along at the Indy 500 From the Comfort of Home

title: Parks Dept. Is Declaring War on Vines Killing Trees
description: Trees in New York City must deal with a host of nuisances: car exhaust, dog waste and, recently, the dreaded Asian long-horned beetle. Now, they are increasingly facing another threat: exotic vines brought by immigrants generations ago that are smothering and strangling acres of oaks, maples and other native hardwood trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULMER, JANET LEES
description: ULMER-Janet Lees, 74, died Easter Sunday following a fourmonth battle with brain cancer. Mrs. Ulmer of Vero Beach, Florida & Ocean Grove, New Jersey was predeceased by her husband of 50 years, Kenneth Marvin Ulmer in September 1998. Mrs. Ulmer graduated from East Orange High School and attended the University of Southern California. A long time resident of New Providence, New Jersey, Mrs. Ulmer taught at the Summit Speech School and was a volunteer at the Overlook Hospital. In her retirement, she was a volunteer in the nursery at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach. Mrs Ulmer had been both a summer and year-round resident of Ocean Grove for 50 years, and had been an active volunteer with the Women's Auxiliary. Janet is survived by her three children, Kevin Ulmer of Cohasset, Massachusetts; Scott Ulmer of Atlanta, Georgia; and Kathy Stilin of Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, and five grandchildren: Justin, Ashley, Kimberly, Ethan and Wesley. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M. on Saturday, May 27th at the New Providence United Methodist Church, 1441 Springfield Avenue, New Providence, N.J. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

title: Chinese Express Joy and Relief at Passage of Trade Bill
description: News that the House voted to grant China permanent normal trade status with the United States was generally greeted with joy here today, tempered by worries about the wrenching economic changes that are expected as China frees up its markets to outsiders.

title: A Galaxy Far, Far Away Is Becoming Fully Digital
description: WHEN the director George Lucas and the producer Rick McCallum recently shot screen tests for ''Star Wars: Episode II,'' there was a problem. At the end of the successful shot, Mr. McCallum said, Mr. Lucas couldn't use the traditional director's cry of ''Cut! Print!'' because he was shooting on digital videotape, not film. After a moment's hesitation, Mr. McCallum said, a new finale was proposed: ''Cut! Can we take a quick look at it?''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Grumpy When Moved

description: SANDOW-Helen (nee Coslow). Of Englewood, New Jersey, formerly of Manhattan. On May 20, 2000 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of the late Alexander Sandow. Much loved and loving mother of Lisa Lyons of Leonia, N.J. and Gregory Sandow of Manhattan. Sister of Judith Lieb. Grandmother of Nick & Sara. Mother-in-law of Richard. Memorial on Monday, May 29th, 11AM, Ethical Culture Society of Bergen Co., 687 Larch Avenue, Teaneck, New Jersey.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Approves Trade Bill Granting China Privileges

title: BP AMOCO TO BUY REST OF VASTAR FOR $1.47 BILLION
description: An offer by BP Amoco P.L.C. to buy the 18 percent of Vastar Resources Inc. that it does not own was approved yesterday by the company's board after BP sweetened the bid to $83 a share or $1.47 billion. The offer values all of Vastar, a natural gas explorer, at $8.1 billion. BP, the third-biggest publicly traded oil company, bid $71 a share on March 16. The sale is subject to the support of holders of two-thirds of the 17.7 million Vastar shares. BP acquired 82 percent of Vastar in last month's $33.1 billion buyout of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: FIRST PLACE TO ACQUIRE FFY FOR ABOUT $72 MILLION
description: The First Place Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the FFY Financial Corporation for $10.48 a share, a total of about $72 million, establishing the fourth-largest savings institution in Ohio, with $1.7 billion in assets and 35 branches. First Place, based in Warren, Ohio, the holding company for First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Warren, said it would exchange 1.075 shares of its stock for each share of FFY, which is based in Youngstown, Ohio. Shares of First Place were unchanged at $9.75 and FFY's stock was up 12.5 cents, at $10.125. in Nasdaq trading.

title: Boy, 12, Shot While Playing With a Gun
description: A 12-year-old boy was shot in the chest and critically injured in Brooklyn yesterday as he and two friends played with a gun that they told the police they found in a vacant lot, the authorities said.

title: Gideon Waldrop, 80, Composer Who Served as Dean of Juilliard
description: Gideon W. Waldrop, a composer and administrator, who served for 24 years as dean of the Juilliard School of Music and for nearly three years as president of the Manhattan School of Music, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACCHI, ELEANOR V. (NEE KENNEDY)
description: SACCHI-Eleanor V. (nee Kennedy), 87, on May 23, at Monroe Village in Jamesburg, NJ, formerly of Garden City, NY. Wife of the late Orlando A. Sacchi. Survived by her children, Carol Stoup, Eleanor McLaughlan, Richard Sacchi and Raymond Sacchi, and her four grandchildren, 5 step-grandchildren & six step-great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, May 26, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 31 Street, New York, New York 10001.

title: Helping the Favored Team End Up in Second Place
description: Last weekend was a time for favorites to finish second. That is not a reference to the Preakness but to the New York final of the Grand National Teams, which was played on Sunday at Honors Club, at 115 East 57th Street in Manhattan.

title: Senate Deal Ends Logjam On Nominee And Judges
description: The Senate voted today to confirm the nomination of Bradley A. Smith to the Federal Election Commission, although Mr. Smith, the Republican nominee for the agency, has angered Democrats by advocating a repeal of campaign finance laws.

title: Florio Campaign Turns to Print to Counter Corzine's Ads
description: After weathering the costliest barrage of attack ads in the history of a United States Senate primary, Jim Florio returned fire today by releasing his first three television ads -- all of them harshly critical of his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: New ThinkPads: Laptop as S.U.V.
description: IN a world where nearly everything seems to be getting miniaturized, the new I.B.M. Thinkpad T20 portable computer is traveling in the other direction. If it were any larger, I.B.M. could have equipped this impressively redesigned laptop with folding legs and offered it as a card table.

title: GPU DECLINES ALL BIDS FOR AUSTRALIAN ASSETS
description: GPU Inc. said yesterday that it had declined all bids made for its two Australian units: GPU PowerNet and GPU GasNet. The electric-utility holding company said yesterday that it had received various bids but considered all of them too low -- a phenomenon it attributes, in part, to rising interest rates in Australia. GPU added that an unfavorable exchange rate would have resulted in a pretax foreign exchange loss of about $132 million, if it had sold the units.

title: Zeile Has New Position And More on His Mind
description: People are just trying to be nice when they offer Hannah Zeile a lollipop or some ice cream. Hannah is 2 years old, and she would love to accept the treats the way most kids her age would. But she recognizes the risk, and that is a relief to her parents.

title: Seeing Garbage, Smelling Money; But Plans for a Transfer Station Annoy New Jersey Neighbors
description: It has been a tough sell, finding a town willing to take in New York City's garbage. But after four years of rejections, New York has finally found a place that is not just willing, but eager: Linden, N.J., a blue-collar town across the waterway from the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, BETTY K.
description: KANE-Betty K. On May 23, 2000. Beloved wife of Paul Kane. Dear mother of Caroline Kane Levy and Stephen Levy. Adored grandmother of Maya and Adam. Dear sister of Florence Steck and Dr. Sherwin J. Klein. Services Friday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to American Diabetes Association.

title: Fox Appoints Entertainment President At Network
description: The Fox network, confirming weeks of speculation, announced yesterday the appointment of Gail Berman as president of entertainment for the network.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: May 25, 2000 Fred R. Conrad / The New York Times

title: Off Those Sofas and Into the Great Outdoors
description: SO what if Bernadette Castro, into her sixth year as New York's vivacious and, when it comes to scaring up millions for pet projects, vociferous commissioner of parks, recreation and historic sites, wasn't always such a Campfire Girl? So what if the original Castro Convertible poster child still hooks more bushes than bass when she puts on her waders and, as parks poster woman, attempts the fly-fishing thing at Connetquot River State Park Preserve?

title: Spitzer Drops Opposition to Empire Blue Cross's Becoming a For-Profit Company
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer withdrew his opposition yesterday to plans by the big nonprofit health insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, to change into a for-profit company. As part of the shift, Empire would set up a multimillion-dollar foundation dedicated to making health care broadly accessible.

title: Ruling on Immunity Puts Chile Closer to Trial of Pinochet
description: A Chilean appeals court has stripped the immunity of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, removing an important obstacle in the way of his possible trial. He faces charges that he was involved in the kidnapping, murder and torture of thousands during his 17 years as Chile's dictator.

title: Finding Out How Much Free Shipping Is Worth
description: I HAVE been told that in some families a hammock can last for years. I am more familiar with the sort of situation in which eight small and medium-size children who are pretending to be pirates routinely pile onto a hammock, rock it vigorously to simulate high seas and dangle 16 legs through the mesh to taunt imaginary sharks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on May 11 about Web-based bill-paying services misstated the affiliation of Kellie Scott, who commented on security issues. She is a senior vice president of the First Union Corporation and director of eChannels, its e-commerce division -- not of Union Trust, which was bought by First Union in 1996.

title: Merchants Describe Pirro House Purchases
description: From a $13,250 Chinese rug to a $16,000 set of dining room chairs to a collection of expensive oil paintings, a parade of witnesses today described a list of lavish purchases that Albert J. Pirro Jr. and his wife, Jeanine, the Westchester district attorney, made to decorate their home in the county.

title: Priceline Wants Your Bid, This Time for Phone Calls
description: Priceline.com, which earned its reputation with the name-your-own-price model for airline tickets, will soon try to interest you in bidding for a new commodity: cheap phone calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIGSBERG, LOUIS
description: KONIGSBERG-Louis, 96, formerly of New York City, on May 23, 2000. Survived by sons, Stephen of E. Brunswick, NJ and Peter of Potomac, MD. Contributions may be made to Juilliard School of Music, Office of Development, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Joanna the Spy: More Bond Than Bond
description: THIS is Special Agent Perfect Dark,'' a female voice with a British accent said in a telephone message left at my home last week. ''I must be brief -- you never know who's listening. I need your assistance.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas surged after an industry report showed inventories rose less than expected last week. In New York, natural gas for June delivery rose 25.9 cents, to $4.073 for one million B.T.U.'s.

title: Abortion Rights Group Is Set to Endorse Mrs. Clinton
description: With Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani out of the race for the United States Senate, leaders of the national abortion rights movement said yesterday that they had abandoned plans to remain neutral in the New York contest and would endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton over her new opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio. Mrs. Clinton said she now intended to make abortion rights a central issue of her candidacy.

title: CADBURY SEEKS KRAFT CANDY UNIT
description: The candy and beverage company Cadbury Schweppes said it was in talks to acquire the French candy and chewing gum business of Kraft, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies. Cadbury Schweppes, based in Britain, refused to disclose how much it might pay. Analysts expect the unit, which makes the Hollywood gum and Krema candy brands, could fetch as much as $450 million.

title: Jury Sees Taped Statement About Shelter Island Killing
description: The videotaped confession of a defendant calmly and politely telling investigators how he shot and killed his neighbor on remote Shelter Island two years ago, was played to a wide-eyed jury today in a darkened courtroom.

title: IRISH MERGER TALKS END
description: Resisting a ''low-price takeover,'' the Irish mortgage lender First Active ended merger talks with the Anglo Irish Bank Corporation. It said Anglo Irish, which caters to small and medium-size businesses, wanted excessive management control. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: WEB SITE EXONERATED ON NAZI CONTENT
description: Two days after a French court ruled that Yahoo had violated French law by allowing Nazi memorabilia to be sold on a Web site accessible through its American portal, another French court said a French Internet access provider, Multimania, was not responsible for a Web site containing Nazi content. A Paris court fined Yahoo on Monday and ordered its French subsidiary to make sites originating in the United States that auction Nazi memorabilia inaccessible in France. But a court in Nanterre, near Paris, said Multimania was not responsible for the content of a site, NSDAP, which it had shut down earlier this year after learning that the letters stood for Hitler's Nazi party. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Senate Committee Staff Proposes Limits on Corporate Tax Shelters
description: Corporate tax shelters, whose resurgence is costing the government billions of dollars a year, would be much less lucrative under revisions proposed yesterday by the bipartisan staff of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Opening China to Goods and Ideas
description: By approving legislation that permanently normalizes trade relations with China, the House opened the way yesterday for a more stable and productive relationship with that country. President Clinton and the Republican leadership also won an important victory for the principle of bipartisan leadership in foreign policy. The Senate is expected to endorse the China trade bill soon. Congressional approval, however, must be seen as a first step toward broadening relations with the Chinese and pressing them to open their country to democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.

title: Westbeth, a Canvas Still Taking Shape
description: TWO original residents of Westbeth -- the grand experiment in subsidized artists' housing that opened in 1970 -- sat side by side on a planter in front of the entrance. One had a long graying beard and a brown fedora; the other was missing some teeth and wore a fisherman's hat.

title: Blood, Sweat and Never a Tear for Lemieux
description: When he arrived at the postgame news conference last night, Coach Larry Robinson of the Devils sat in a chair and then quickly jumped up. ''Ugh!'' he said with a look of bemused disgust. ''All wet!''

title: Beyond Interactive Buys a London Firm
description: Beyond Interactive in Ann Arbor, Mich., part of Grey Advertising, is acquiring its first agency in Europe, Media 21 in London, which specializes in online media planning and buying. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

description: RICK-Manuel. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. mourns the passing of our beloved member, Manuel Rick. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gladys and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Martin Kay, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, IRA S.
description: GLICK-Ira S. Passed away on May 22, 2000. He was born in Chicago in 1922, attended The University of Chicago and served in The US Air Force 1942-45. After moving to New York, he founded and was President of Glick & Lorwin, a management and educational consultant firm, from 1955 to 1992, when he retired. He then founded Sound Remedy, to assist organizations and provide aids and services for people with impaired hearing. For many years he was on the Boards for The Washington Square Association, The Washington Square Music Festival, and The 59 West 12th Street Condominium, as well as Bayberry Close, East Hampton. Mr. Glick was a lover of art works and a collector. He is survived by his wife Paula and a brother Larry, in Chicago. He will be greatly missed.

title: A Foreign Policy Worthy of The G.O.P.
description: In July 1948, the Republican presidential nominee, Thomas Dewey, met in Washington with two top advisers, John Foster Dulles and Senator Arthur Vandenberg, to decide what stance their party should take on one of the first showdowns of the cold war: the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

title: Rounding Out a Clear Clinton Legacy
description: With his victory today on trade with China, Bill Clinton has finally defined his imprint on American foreign policy: the president who cemented in place the post-cold-war experiment of using economic engagement to foster political change among America's neighbors and its potential adversaries.

description: BMG ENTERTAINMENT, New York, named Kevin Conroy, senior vice president for worldwide marketing and new technology, to the posts of president for new technology and chief marketing officer.

description: The best national missile defense requires a bold rhetorical offense.

title: Wire-Distribution Deal
description: The Kent Electronics Corporation, a distributor of specialty electronic products, said on Tuesday that it sold most of its redistribution business to the privately held Houston Wire and Cable Company. The price was not disclosed. The redistribution business resells specialty wire and cable products mostly used for industrial purposes. The redistribution business had $93 million in sales last year. Houston Wire and Cable also resells specialty wire and cable products.
