title: MICROCHIP TO BUY CHIP PLANT FROM MATSUSHITA
description: Microchip Technology Inc., which makes semiconductors used in everything from cars to computers, agreed yesterday to buy a plant in Puyallup, Wash., from the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and will hire more than 1,000 workers. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Adding the plant, which is on a 92-acre campus, will more than double Microchip's overall production. The company will begin installing equipment in October and start production in August 2001. Matsushita Electric, the Japanese electronics maker, bought the plant in 1993 and ceased production there in December 1998. Microchip plans to hire about 100 employees at the plant this year and expand the work force as production increases.

title: Metro Matters; The Obvious Falls Victim To Politics
description: HEREWITH a new installment of the occasional ''Let's Get Real'' column, to examine two political puzzles: 1) Why, despite broad support for softening the state's harsh drug laws, have they remained on the books? And, 2) why do both of New York's Senate candidates say they want to tighten campaign finance laws, even as they raise and spend the old-fashioned way?

title: Richard Meier Builds in Manhattan. At Last.
description: RICHARD MEIER, the world-renowned Pritzker Prize-winning architect, is promoting a glassy new condominium in Greenwich Village -- his first building in Manhattan in 30 years.

title: Firefighter Charged In Potential Cocaine Sale
description: A veteran Brooklyn firefighter, George Bechman, 49, was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of cocaine with intent to sell it, the authorities said.

title: Institute Restricted After Gene Therapy Death
description: The scientist who ran a gene therapy study that killed an 18-year-old patient at the University of Pennsylvania will no longer conduct experiments on people, and the prestigious gene therapy institute he founded is being scaled back, university officials announced today.

title: Chile Lifts a Barrier To Trial of Pinochet
description: A Chilean appeals court has stripped the immunity of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, removing an important obstacle in the way of his possible trial on charges that he was involved in the kidnapping, murder and torture of thousands during his 17 years as Chile's dictator.

title: Detective a Suicide, Officials Say
description: A police detective found dead yesterday at a Staten Island cargo terminal killed himself, the police said.

title: Gerald M. Kramer; Periodontology Professor, 77
description: Gerald M. Kramer, a retired professor and former chairman of periodontology in the Boston University School of Dental Medicine, died on May 18 at a hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 77 and lived in Swampscott, Mass.

title: Dismantling of Art Commission Is Urged
description: An unexpected coalition of City Council members introduced legislation yesterday to abolish the Art Commission, a mayoral panel that has sat in judgment over artwork and architecture on city-owned property for more than a century.

description: The parents of JonBenet Ramsey released the results of polygraph tests today that they said should remove any suspicion that they were involved in the killing of their 6-year-old daughter.

description: The rape and killing of a student at Beijing University, China's most prestigious college, has set off student demonstrations, in defiance of a general ban on public protests.

title: SELIG IS CONFIDENT
description: Yes, he does have the votes for his realignment plan, Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday.

title: 18th-Century Rococo a Rave in Techno-Today
description: THE young man, whose dapper mustache and cream-colored Prada raincoat proclaimed him to be a seeker of the most up-to-the-minute design truths, was transfixed. ''It's so exciting,'' said David Kimelman, 22, a student at Pratt Institute. ''This is design based almost purely on body language. title: Op-Art
Teeny-Boppers Shatter a Record
description: Metallica and others in the record industry may complain that unauthorized exchange of music files on the Internet is killing their business, but the numbers have yet to bear that out. In 1998, only one artist had ever sold more than a million copies of a record in its first week on sale: Garth Brooks. But in the last year teeny-bopper pop acts have been shattering his record. First, the Backstreet Boys sold 1.1 million copies of their second album, ''Millenium''; then 'N Sync sold a staggering 2.4 million copies of its second album, ''No Strings Attached.'' And this week, Britney Spears, one of the most widely traded artists on Internet sites, has broken a million with her second album, ''Oops! . . . I Did It Again'' (Jive).

title: YUAN RISES AGAINST DOLLAR

For years, China's foreign exchange controls have kept the yuan trading between $8.2770 and $8.2800. And despite perceived pressure on the currency during Asia's recent financial crisis, Beijing kept its promise not to devalue the yuan. But the country is expected to ease control over the exchange rate gradually after it joins the World Trade Organization, with a goal of making the currency convertible. Craig Smith (NYT)

But there is no doubt that Mr. Clinton must be called to account for his legal misconduct and that this disbarment proceeding is the appropriate forum in which to hold him accountable.

title: Bush's Strategy: Offer Big Ideas First, Work Out Details Later
description: With his recent speeches on Social Security and nuclear weapons defenses, Gov. George W. Bush this month has established a pattern: He put forward broad ideas with great appeal to the Republican base and then left the details to be filled in later should he be elected.

title: Memo on Risks to Reno's Job Touches Off Dispute at Senate Hearing
description: Top officials of the Justice Department and the F.B.I. engaged in an unusual public debate today at a Senate hearing over a 1996 memorandum about whether Attorney General Janet Reno's job was at risk as a result of the government's high-profile investigation into finances of the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign.

title: Israel Warns Its Neighbors To Rein In Hezbollah
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned Lebanon and Syria tonight that any cross-border attack on Israeli territory would be considered ''an act of war'' now that Israel has withdrawn from Lebanon, in a rush completed before dawn today.

description: Vice President Al Gore said today that the stock market was an attractive place for Americans to invest over the long run but that it was the wrong place to seek a solution to Social Security's problems.

title: After Lebanon Convulsion, An Uncertain Landscape
description: This hillside Christian village, with its church spires and sweets shops, was the picturesque military center of the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon for two decades. Before noon today, the morning after the occupation zone precipitately collapsed, its stores were shuttered and its cobblestone streets nearly empty but for two young men with a clipboard.

title: CABLETRON TO SELL DIGITAL UNIT TO GORES TECHNOLOGY
description: Cabletron Systems Inc., a networking-equipment maker that is reorganizing into a holding company, agreed yesterday to sell a business acquired in 1998 from the Digital Equipment Corporation to the Gores Technology Group. Terms were not disclosed. Cabletron bought the Digital Network Products Group in February 1998 for $439.5 million. Closely held Gores, based in Los Angeles, has a portfolio of 21 technology-oriented companies. The company is also trying to sell the switch maker NetVantage, which it bought in September 1998 for $77.8 million.

title: Beethoven's 16 Quartets, Free, for Whooping Guests
description: Advocates of classical music who argue that the high cost of concerts keeps potential audiences away received a boost for their point of view during the last two weeks at Alice Tully Hall. The Orion String Quartet, the quartet-in-residence with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, presented six free concerts devoted to the complete 16 string quartets by Beethoven. And before every concert, from the first on May 12 to the last on Tuesday night, a line of people hoping to get in snaked around the block on Broadway. They were of all ages, races and dress codes, exactly the target audience classical music organizations everywhere are trying to attract.

title: Duval Seeks EndTo Victory Drought
description: David Duval spent the past week fighting a severe cold, but he has been fighting his putting stroke all year.

title: AMAZON HEAD FILES FOR FIRST SALE OF SHARES SINCE '98
description: Jeffrey Bezos, chief executive of the online retailer Amazon.com Inc., has filed to sell 380,000 shares of the company, in his first sale since 1998. The sales will provide fianancing for investments and other commitments, according to Patty Smith, a spokeswoman for Amazon.com. Ms. Smith noted that the stock reported in the sale represents less than 1 percent of the 117.5 million shares that Mr. Bezos held as of Feb. 29. Mr. Bezos listed the date of sale as May 12 in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Ewing Aiming to Make the Most of His Minutes
description: Any irritation the Knicks' Patrick Ewing had concerning his 34 minutes of playing time Tuesday night -- which included a late entrance into the fourth quarter of Game 1 against the Indiana Pacers -- seemed to subside today.

title: THYSSENKRUPP DISAPPOINTS
description: Germany's largest steel maker, ThyssenKrupp, reported first-half earnings that fell short of expectations. Net income rose to 171 million euros ($155 million) in the six months through March, from 62.2 million euros in the period a year earlier. Pretax profit rose to 367 million euros, some 100 million euros below estimates, hurt by units the company plans to sell. ThyssenKrupp is still looking for a buyer for the shipbuilding, plastics machinery and engineering units. The co-chief executives -- Gerhard Cromme, above, and Ekkehard Schulz -- have pledged to shed units with about $5 billion in annual sales.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health Column on May 9, about the 40th anniversary of the birth control pill, referred incorrectly to the number of women who have taken the pill since its introduction in 1960. The exact number is unknown. Johns Hopkins University has estimated that 80 percent of American women born since 1945 have used oral contraceptives at some time. The erroneous figure, 468 million, applied to the number of women who started taking the pill in any given year plus the number of women who continued to use it from the previous year, for a total of 40 years.

title: Brooklyn Courts Strained By Arrests in Drug Sweeps
description: The caseload in Brooklyn's criminal courts nearly doubled in April compared with the same month last year largely because of the huge number of arrests in a sweeping Police Department antinarcotics plan, and court officials are expressing fears that the case backlog may get out of hand.

title: BMW COMPLETES ROVER SALE
description: The German automobile company BMW wound up its withdrawal from Britain's money-losing Rover Group by completing the sale of Rover's sport utility vehicle division to the Ford Motor Company for three billion euros ($2.73 billion) -- two-thirds to be paid immediately and the rest in 2005. Since the price was agreed on March 16, the euro has fallen 6.1 percent against the dollar, meaning that Ford's initial payment will be worth $1.82 billion, compared with $1.94 billion on March 16.

title: So Few Fellinis; Snub at Cannes Has Italy Fretting Over Its Filmmaking
description: When Roberto Benigni's ''Life Is Beautiful'' won an Oscar for best foreign film in 1999, many hoped that his success signaled a renaissance of Italian cinema after years of slump and slumber.

title: A Condensed International Melange
description: At P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, ''Greater New York'' is gradually being disassembled. (Sections of the show are on view through the summer.) But its youthful spirit lives on in Lower Manhattan in a small exhibition at the Clocktower, the imposing office building whose two top floors are home to P.S. 1's satellite gallery and its national and international studio programs.

title: VIACOM PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO $1 BILLION OF STOCK
description: Viacom Inc., the world's second-biggest media conglomerate, announced yesterday that it would buy back up to $1 billion in its stock. The buyback program follows the completion of Viacom's most recent share repurchase program at the end of April. The company had 1.5 billion shares outstanding after its acquisition of the CBS Corporation was completed on May 4. The merger made Viacom the second-largest media conglomerate in the world after Time Warner Inc., with such holdings as Paramount Pictures, MTV networks and Simon & Schuster. Shares of the New York-based Viacom rose 56.25 cents, to $55.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Honda Plans OnStar For Acura Sedans
description: The Honda Motor Company, Japan's second-biggest automaker, is planningd to equip United States versions of its Acura sedans with the General Motors Corporation's OnStar satellite navigation and information devices starting in 2002. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Credit Cards Duel Before Senate Panel
description: Judging by the nearly four billion solicitations that flooded American mailboxes last year, the credit card business would seem to be one of the most viciously competitive. description: CBS Sports, which has been in and out of boxing for the past decade, will return temporarily in July when it rebroadcasts four Showtime cable fights featuring Mike Tyson, Evander Holyfield, David Tua and Andrew Golota.

title: A Woman of Two Minds. Or Two Loves. Or Two Cities. Or . . .
description: Demi Moore stars in the dreamscape ''Passion of Mind,'' one of those other-side-of-the-looking glass pictures. During the daylight hours she's Marie and lives in a sun-dappled chateau in Provence with her two daughters, writing book reviews for this very newspaper. And when she closes her eyes at night, she's living in gray-blue Manhattan as Marty, a literary agent with her hair pulled back to heighten the severity of her loveless life in the big city. Fortunately she doesn't get around to reviewing any of the books by authors she signed, or there could be a very nasty battle between the two at Elaine's.

title: Nuclear Stockpile Guardians Squabble Over Cost of Project
description: In an unusually public display of acrimony among the caretakers of the nation's nuclear stockpile, Sandia National Laboratories has charged that cost overruns on a giant laser at another federal laboratory may disrupt the program to ensure that the stockpile remains safe and reliable.

title: Nights Of Jazz, Sweet And Hot
description: IVEY-DIVEY, as Lester Young would have said. June is almost upon us, and as usual, jazz clubs, independent concert producers and the big jazz festivals -- there are now three -- are wrangling for the attention of New Yorkers. This means an astonishing bounty for anyone interested in jazz (with Latin music, gospel and soul as connected satellite genres, in the tradition of the big festivals). There's no choice but to see it as one big unofficial citywide festival, the best and most complete in the world.

title: Yevgeny Khrunov, 67, Russian Astronaut
description: Yevgeny Vasilevich Khrunov, an early Russian astronaut who took part in the first linkup of two manned spacecraft high above the earth, has died at the age of 67. In reporting his death from Moscow on Tuesday, the news agency Itar-Tass said that several of his fellow astronauts had gathered on the day of his death to mourn him.

description: Even when a movie aspires to the intricate structure and weight of a knotty modernist poem, how good can it be when watching it gives you the queasy feeling that you are taking a math exam? That question could be applied to almost every work by the British filmmaker Peter Greenaway, whose movies, to a greater or lesser extent, feel like hybrids of art school essays and brain-tickling puzzles.

Earnest and interesting, this production revives the 1932 play adapted by Thornton Wilder from ''Le Viol de Lucrece'' by the French playwright Andre Obey, who in turn was inspired by Shakespeare's poem ''The Rape of Lucretia.''

title: New Homes Are Now Wired For a Lot More Than Lights
description: Michael Levine wanted what many people would in a new house: a safe neighborhood and low upkeep. But what really sold him on Centennial, a 900-home development north of Indianapolis, was the wiring -- a ready-to-use, high-speed Internet connection as well as cable and phone service, all provided by the builder.

title: INLAND RESOURCES TO BUY OIL AND GAS PROPERTIES IN UTAH
description: The oil and gas producer Inland Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to buy some oil and gas assets from Flying J Inc., a rest stop chain and diesel gas seller, for $77.3 million in cash and stock. Inland Resources, based in Denver, will also assume $5.8 million of debt from the privately held Flying J. The price consists of $50 million cash and 7.8 million Inland Resources shares. The assets include nine Flying J gas stations in the Salt Lake City area and Idaho; a refinery in North Salt Lake City, Utah; and oil and gas reserves in the Uinta Basin in northeastern Utah. Flying J is based in Bingham City, Utah.

description: McNAMARA-Ursula D. Mass of the Resurrection for Ursula D. McNamara, 81, of Bay Shore, N.Y. and New Smyrna Beach, Fla., who died Monday, May 15, 2000, will be held Tuesday, May 30 at 10 a.m. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore. Interment will be at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram, N.Y. She was born in New York City, the child of William Jerome Daly and Ursula Miller. She was predeceased by a brother, William J. Daly, Jr. Mrs. McNamara was married initially to Daniel G. Amend, a New York attorney who predeceased her in 1959. Of that marriage there were three children, Daniel G. Amend of Clearwater, Fla., Ursula A. Morris of Guilford, Conn., and John Miller Amend who predeceased her in 1987. In 1961 she married Emmett F. McNamara, attorney of Bay Shore, N.Y., a widower whose spouse Mary Holland had predeceased him in 1960. Due to the second marriage, she became the second loving mother to J. Paul McNamara of Bethesda, Md., Maryann Christie of Islip, N.Y., Patricia Moser of Titusville, N.J., and Cathleen Callahan of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.; 16 grandchildren and 10 great grandchildren. In lieu of other remembrances, donations can be made to Our Lady of Consolation, West Islip, N.Y.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES. Sugar climbed almost 3 percent on expectations for continued low exports from Brazil, the world's top grower. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.2 cent, or 2.7 percent, to 7.76 cents a pound.

title: As Protests Grow Violent, Peru Says Runoff Will Go On
description: The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot count.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIERIOT, CHARLES H.
description: THIERIOT-Charles H. of Locust Valley, LI, on May 24, 2000, age 85. Beloved husband of the late Edna T. Thieriot, devoted father of Charles H. Thieriot, Jr. of Los Angeles, CA, Julia D. Thieriot of Round Hill, VA and Frances T. Thieriot of Santa Monica, CA. Step-father of Jeff Carpenter and Katherine Carpenter Schulte both of New York City, C. Nicholas Potter of Mill Neck, NY and Mary Carpenter Zagorin of Washington, DC, grandfather of Cary Potter, Christopher Potter, Jennifer Potter, Revell Schulte, Dashiell Schulte, Edmund Zagorin and Oliver Zagorin. Great-grandfather of Macy Potter, Nina Potter and Nicholas Potter. After graduating from Harvard College in 1937 he joined R.H. Macy and Co. From 1941 to 1943 he was in the Civilian Pilot Training Program in Amarillo, Texas where he served as a flight instructor. From 1943 to 1945 he was First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps. His service included flying ''The Hump'' in the China-Burma-India Theatre. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, The Air Medal and The Chinese War Memorial Medal. In 1945, he joined the securities firm of Carlisle & Jacquelin. He served as senior partner of its successor firm, Carlisle, DeCoppet & Co., until its sale in 1976. In his retirement he was, with his late wife, an enthusiastic owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses. He was a Trustee of The New York Racing Association and The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga, NY. He also served for many years as a Fire Commissioner in Locust Valley, NY and as a Trustee of the Incorporated Village of Matinecock, Locust Valley, NY. Of his many chairtable and community interests, he was particularly devoted to St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA and the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City, both of which he served as a trustee for many years. Funeral Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Wednesday, May 31st at 11:00 A.M. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Church of the St. Sacrament, Box 1185, Bolton's Landing, New York 12184.

title: Invisible All Night, Smits at Last Saves Pacers
description: When Rik Smits, a giant frozen in ice for three quarters, dropped in a layup and converted a free throw for a 3-point play with eight minutes remaining in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals tonight, the Pacers trailed by 3 points. As he emerged, he suddenly brought his team back to life as well.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the new United Nations commission for inspecting Iraqi weapons referred incorrectly to the unit being formed by the commission's chairman, Hans Blix. It is the inspection commission; his advisory panel already exists.

title: The Synergy! The Ecstasy! The Biology!
description: Those of us who lived through the headiest days of the 60's counterculture, when pie-in-the-sky hippie gurus were popping up like daisies in July, should feel more than a twinge of deja vu watching Jon Reiss's impassioned documentary film ''Better Living Through Circuitry.'' An enthusiastic exploration of today's rave culture and the beat-driven electronic music that fuels it, the movie is packed with upbeat pronouncements by flush-faced techno-wizards and partygoers extolling the transformational power of these all-night dance parties.

title: Court Orders Venezuela to Postpone Election on Sunday
description: The Supreme Court today ordered the postponement of the election scheduled for Sunday, saying that the ''reliability and transparency'' of the electoral process could not be guaranteed.

title: FOREIGN BIDDERS FOR BRAZIL OIL
description: Brazil's national petroleum agency said it had authorized 44 companies from around the world, including the Exxon Mobil Corporation and Texaco Inc., to bid on 23 new oil and gas exploration blocks as part of the government's effort to diversify the country's petroleum industry. The blocks, which include 10 onshore and 13 offshore leases, will be sold at an auction on June 7. Brazil's oil and gas exploration was dominated by the state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. until its monopoly ended in 1998. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

description: When leaders of Japan's governing party met secretly seven weeks ago to choose a successor to Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who was felled by a stroke, the idea was not only to ensure a quick transition but also to perpetuate the party's long hold on power.

title: New York Outlet For Patrick's Show
description: ESPN Radio, which has had no New York outlet for its daytime sports-talk programs, yesterday placed the show that features Dan Patrick, the top SportsCenter anchor, on WEVD-AM/1050, weekdays from 1-4 p.m. WEVD will start carrying the program July 31.

title: UNEXPECTEDLY STRONG EARNINGS AT UBS
description: Europe's third-largest bank, UBS A.G. of Switzerland, reported a 41 percent gain in quarterly earnings, to 2.22 billion Swiss francs, or $1.29 billion, stronger than expected. The bank attributed the performance to a surge in the private banking business of its UBS Switzerland and UBS Warburg units. Earlier this month, UBS became the first Swiss bank to gain a listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Negotiators Stall on Patients' Rights Bill
description: The outlook for passage of legislation defining patients' rights turned bleak today as House and Senate negotiators issued an unusually negative report on their efforts to strike a compromise.

title: Metro Business; Best Buy Hiring 800
description: The Best Buy Company, the consumer electronics chain, said it would hire about 800 people for four new stores planned for the Hudson Valley in the third quarter.

title: Breaking Cold War Mold
description: Gov. George W. Bush's proposal this week to consider unilateral reductions in the American nuclear arsenal was a break with decades of strategic doctrine, a break that may foretell the end of traditional theories of arms control.

title: GATEWAY TO INVEST $150 MILLION IN WEB SITE DEVELOPER
description: The computer giant Gateway Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $150 million in Consumer Financial Network Inc., a developer of job benefit Web sites for corporations. Consumer Finance Network runs Web sites for about 350 companies, including Delta Air Lines, Merrill Lynch and Avon Products. Gateway's investment gives it a 10 percent stake in Consumer Finance Network, which is owned by iXL Enterprises Inc., a holding company based in Atlanta. IXL's stock was up 75 cents a share, at $14.6875, in Nasdaq trading and Gateway was up 93.75 cents a share, at $47.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Gateway, based in San Diego, and Consumer Finance Network also agreed to market computers and Internet services to companies that want to give employees home computers.

title: From Ur, the First and Most Famous
description: Mesopotamia, whose name comes from the Greek for ''between the rivers,'' is one of the places where it all began, a cradle of Western civilization, like ancient Egypt. The rivers are the Tigris and the Euphrates, and the land between is a flood plain that today is in Iraq. It was inhospitable terrain: flat, arid and lacking in indigenous plant life or useful materials like stone, metals and wood.

title: Nuclear Swords and Shields
description: It seems fitting that the first presidential campaign of the new century should confront the most dangerous military legacy of the last century, nuclear arms. Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore initiated an important and healthy debate in recent days about how best to reduce nuclear arsenals and diminish the threat of an accidental or intentional nuclear conflict. America's security will be best protected if the next president moves boldly to cut nuclear arms without suddenly overturning the carefully calibrated balance between offensive and defensive weapons that has long been central to preserving the peace.

title: California Medical Association Files a Suit Against 3 Insurers
description: Adding to the barrage of lawsuits attacking managed care, the California Medical Association yesterday accused three big insurance companies of violating federal antiracketeering laws by coercing doctors and interfering with physician-patient relationships for financial reasons. The California suit was the first broad-based legal assault on managed care by a state medical association, medical officials in several states said.

title: Eritrea Gives Up Vital Town to Ethiopia; Peace Hopes Rise
description: Eritrean troops abruptly pulled back today from a strategic town still in dispute with Ethiopia, in what may be a decisive step toward the end of a war that has claimed thousands of lives and crippled two of Africa's most promising nations.

title: VODAFONE PACIFIC WITHDRAWS OFFERING
description: Australia's third-largest cell phone company, Vodafone Pacific, withdrew its planned initial public offering in Australia because of unstable market conditions. The company had been expected to sell $972 million of stock, which would have been the biggest stock offering in Australia this year. Vodafone Pacific is 91 percent owned by the British wireless giant Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. (Dow Jones)

title: Mrs. Clinton, in Rochester, Takes On Queries on Motive
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton used a town hall forum in Rochester yesterday in part to answer what she acknowledged were continuing concerns about her ambitions and motives in running for a Senate seat representing a state where she had never lived until five months ago.

title: HYUNDAI PATRIARCH FOCUSES ON CARS
description: Chung Ju Yung, honorary chairman of the Hyundai conglomerate in South Korea, moved to acquire a controlling stake in its car manufacturing subsidiary, the Hyundai Motor Company. Mr. Chung, 85, acquired 6.8 percent of Hyundai Motor's shares and said he intended to buy enough additional shares to attain 9 percent. Mr. Chung's move came against a backdrop of increased concern among South Korean workers over the possibility that the nation's carmaking industry could be taken over by bigger overseas competitors. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Performances Are Suspended In Dance Group Graham Started
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company, a pioneering institution of American modern dance, yesterday pulled out of two major festivals and suspended operations for the foreseeable future because of financial problems.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's position on Social Security misstated one element of his personal finances. Mr. Gore receives no income from investments in the stock market. Although his financial disclosure form lists dividend income, the stock is held in trust for his mother, and the income goes only to her.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Creative Departures
description: The two creative directors at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy are planning to leave during the summer in departures that mean all the top-office leaders will be new.

title: Port Authority Budget Signals Easing of a Rift
description: In a signal that there may be some easing in the 18-month-long impasse between New York and New Jersey that has blocked approval of major Port Authority projects, the agency's commissioners unanimously adopted an annual budget yesterday.

title: Seymour Perry, 78, a Specialist In Assessing Medical Technology
description: Dr. Seymour Perry, a cancer specialist who became an expert in evaluating medical technology, died on May 19 at his home in Washington. He was 78.

title: A Threat to Meat Inspection
description: A federal judge in Texas undermined the safety of the nation's food supply yesterday by denying the government's authority to enforce critical regulations setting limits on the amount of harmful bacteria in ground beef sold to the public.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Dinner at the Rainbow Grill is not so much a meal as a real estate transaction. You want to occupy 16 square feet in Midtown with an unsurpassed view? Prepare to pay. Patrons of the old Promenade Bar atop 30 Rockefeller Center should prepare to weep when they leave the elevator on the 65th floor. It is gone, gone, gone. And so is the elegance and romance. The Cipriani family, which now runs the former Promenade Bar and the Rainbow Room, have whittled down the bar operation and expanded the dining area, installing double rows of tables to make the Rainbow Grill. It's a little like an airplane. Diners with window seats get the view. The rest get to watch their fellow diners.

title: School Sex and Drug Survey Angers 6th Graders' Parents
description: School officials here apologized today to parents who were outraged by a health survey, given to some students as young as 11, that posed specific questions about sexual orientation and behavior, drug and alcohol use and other intimate details.

title: Rerunning Reruns, Deja Vu All Over
description: It took Hollywood 23 years to turn ''Mission: Impossible'' into a movie. (The original CBS series went off the air in 1973; we're not counting the misconceived imitator that ran on ABC from 1988 to 1990). But it has taken only four years for the sequal. ''M: I-2'' opened this week with Tom Cruise returning as the dashing government agent Ethan Hunt whose latest assignment, should be choose to accept it, is to find and eliminate a German virus.

title: Applying RICO To Civil Cases
description: The lawsuit filed by the California Medical Association is an effort to apply the civil provisions of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO. The statute is best known for its use in criminal cases in which the government charges that groups like organized crime or gangs have engaged in a pattern of conspiratorial activity to further their crimes.

title: Editor of Texas Monthly Magazine Resigns
description: The editor of Texas Monthly resigned yesterday after 19 years. Gregory B. Curtis, who founded the magazine in 1973 with two colleagues and wrote some of the magazine's first articles, said that he would return to writing.

description: In her first public appearance since her recent libel case victory against a British writer who has denied the Holocaust, Deborah E. Lipstadt told the graduating class of Yeshiva University yesterday that her decision to fight her legal battle was similar to the decisions made by gentiles who rescued Jews during World War II.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have made New York the first state to require that cigarettes meet fire-safety standards. He said that such a requirement might encourage bootlegging, and urged the Legislature to send him an amended version of the bill that dealt with his concerns.

title: Justice Department Approves AT&T's Bid for a Cable Giant
description: The Justice Department approved AT&T's proposed acquisition of the MediaOne Group today, giving the telephone giant control over more than a third of the nation's cable network for television, high-speed Internet access and online telephone service.

title: Water Babies: The Alluring Chris-Craft
description: I was still in grade school when I had my first ride in a Chris-Craft Racing Runabout. It was mid-August 1959, and Barnegat Bay in New Jersey was pure glass. Taking my cues from my father -- a sailor and ice-boater -- I had disdained ''stinkpots,'' the sailor's term for motorboats. But when a friend invited me for a spin on his father's gleaming wooden motorboat, I hopped in.

description: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had reprimanded six current or former officials for their roles in the agency's initial investigation into evidence that John M. Deutch, the agency's former director, had mishandled classified information.

title: Time Warner and Disney Reach Cable Deal for ABC
description: Ending one of the most rancorous negotiations in the history of cable television, Time Warner Inc. and the Walt Disney Company completed a deal that allows the cable company to continue carrying Disney's ABC television stations for the next six years.

title: Disney and Goto.com Settle Logo Suit
description: The Walt Disney Company will pay $21.5 million to settle a trademark-infringement lawsuit by Goto.com Inc. over the logo for Disney's Go.com network of Web sites, Goto.com officials said today.

title: When Ideas Took Shape And Soared
description: SPEAKING at a symposium held at U.C.L.A. in January, the historian Anthony Vidler announced, ''All architecture is the result of panic.'' Panic has broken out with particularly vivid style in ''The Triumph of the Baroque,'' now on view at the National Gallery of Art. A survey of European architecture from 1600 to 1750, the show reveals that buildings, like people, can be overtaken by mass hysteria. For a century and a half, European walls, doors, roofs, windows and entire cities were contorted into quivering, writhing shapes.

Walk into Blockbuster stores around the country and you will see only a fraction of the ''American Beauty'' boxes you might have. In some Blockbuster stores, you will find ''American Beauty,'' the Academy Award winner, only under the front counter.

Handler is leaving to run Burly Bear Network, a cable TV network and Web site for college students, which is owned by Lorne Michaels, the executive producer of NBC's Saturday Night Live.

title: HOPE FOR BAAN
description: The shares of the ailing business-software maker Baan N.V. jumped on optimism the company would find new financing and benefit from new Internet-based products. Baan needs a savior, either a financial investor or company to purchase it, after seven quarters of losses have drained the company of cash. The company declined to comment on whether it was in talks with a potential buyer or financing partner.

title: 'Epidemic of Oral Disease' Is Found in Poor
description: Oral diseases, from tooth decay to mouth cancer, threaten the health of poor people, members of minorities, children and the elderly, despite vast improvements in dental care over the past 50 years, according to a study made public today by the surgeon general.

description: Offering an olive branch to Lebanon a day after withdrawing Israeli troops from its soil, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel traveled to this northern border town today and appealed to the Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, to begin peace talks.

title: Judge Rejects Federal Salmonella Tests in Texas Meat Plants
description: A federal judge in Texas struck down the Agriculture Department's inspection standards for meat-processing plants yesterday, saying they did not fairly measure sanitary conditions.

description: The Carver Bancorp, the largest black-run bank in the country, announced late yesterday that it had lost more than $1 million in the last year, and that it had reshuffled its board.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: SONIC YOUTH: ''NYC Ghosts and Flowers'' (Geffen). Self-exile can be a fruitful state, and New York's quintessential rock band tastes its gifts on this new release. ''NYC Ghosts and Flowers'' views the time and place that inspires Sonic Youth's breakthrough art rock -- Gotham, as shaped by the shared lineage of the Beats, the hippies and the punks.

title: The Proud Met Unveils a Prize
description: After four months of conservation and restoration, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has hung a recent acquisition: ''The Lamentation'' by the Italian Baroque painter Ludovico Carracci.

title: Two Painters, Far Apart, Intersect in Brooklyn
description: William Merritt Chase (1849-1916) and Maxfield Parrish (1870-1966), a generation apart, were in their day very popular artists. Each wielded a brush with true virtuosity; Chase in a filtered Impressionist style seen as ''high'' art, Parrish in a tight, finicky illustrational mode that left out no detail. They had little else in common until now, with the conjunction of their shows at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Reform Party Is Embroiled Over Buchanan Domination and Its Impact on Platform
description: The last time Reform Party leaders met, three months ago in Nashville, tensions rose to such an extreme that two women wrestled over control of a microphone, and the police were summoned to prevent the rowdiness from growing worse.

title: State Must Pay Building Costs In Poor Schools
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court declared today that the state was responsible for all of the costs of construction for poor school districts under the court's 1998 school finance ruling, not just a portion of them.

title: Foreign Affairs; All Fall Down
description: The last time I was in Israel's former southern Lebanon security zone I was being driven around by a nervous Israeli Army press officer called Alex in his beat-up old Mercedes. We were barreling down some road near Merj 'Uyun when an armored personnel carrier belonging to the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army came barreling along the other way. The Lebanese militiamen in the A.P.C. weren't very good drivers and their vehicle swerved and scraped our Mercedes. We were both going so fast, and the A.P.C. was so heavy, that it knocked the driver's door right off our car. It just went flying off the hinges. And that was my last image of the security zone -- being driven around by an Israeli officer in a beat-up Mercedes with no door.

title: Brownlie of Rutgers To Face Army
description: Bob Brownlie grew up just a few miles from the campus of Rutgers University, dreaming about pitching for the Scarlet Knights. That dream came true when he passed up a chance to play in the professional ranks or for some of the nation's highly regarded college teams farther from home.

title: Hong Kong Faces Loss Of Luster to Mainland
description: For a city that has prospered as an intermediary between the Chinese economy and the outside world, Hong Kong has lobbied hard to help China win full membership in the world's club of trading nations.

title: MEDICAL COMPANY TO ACQUIRE DIAGNOSTIC SYSTEMS MAKER
description: Welch Allyn Inc., a privately held maker of medical and dental equipment, agreed yesterday to acquire the diagnostic systems maker Protocol Systems Inc. for $16 a share, or a total of $145 million. Protocol's stock was up $2.5625 a share at $15.6875, in Nasdaq trading. Welch Allyn, based in Skaneateles Falls, N.Y., will begin buying Protocol shares within the next 10 business days. Protocol, based in Beaverton, Ore., makes equipment used by doctors and hospitals to monitor patients' vital signs remotely. In April, the company said it had hired a financial adviser to help it explore strategic options. The company's stock price and sales have not increased in several years. Protocol had $66.3 million in sales last year.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; STEEL MAKER BUYS PLANTS
description: The leading Mexican steel maker Grupo Imsa has bought two steel processing plants and seven steel finishing and service centers in the United States from the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, an Australian company, for $234 million in cash. The two steel plants are in Kalama, Wash., and Rancho Cucamonga, Calif. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY PLANS TO CLOSE 2 DISK DRIVE PLANTS
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the No. 1 maker of disk drives, said yesterday that it planned to close two plants that make disks that hold computer data and lay off about 1,200 workers because of falling demand and prices. The company, which plans to go private, said about 621 workers at its plant in Anaheim, Calif., and about 591 workers in Mexicali, Mexico, would be laid off. Seagate will consolidate disk production at its plant in Limavady, Ireland, moving virtually all of its disk drive production outside the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCKMAN, SIGURD
description: BOCKMAN-Sigurd, 89, passed away Thursday morning, May 25, at his home in Annapolis, MD. He was a noted classical clarinetist and teacher whose career spanned 52 years. He played with the Minneapolis Symphony, the Pittsburgh Symphony and the NBC Symphony. He was also an original member of Leopold Stokowski's American Symphony at Carnegie Hall as well as the New York City Opera Orchestra. Other playing engagements included performances with the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo Orchestra and the Cleveland Orchestra. Mr. Bockman performed with studio orchestras for ''Cavalcade of America,'' ''Theater Guild'' and the ''Bell Telephone Hour.'' He also played with the Firestone Hour Orchestra and for the Cities Service Hour in their coast-to-coast broadcasts. In addition, he participated in many musical recordings including the original score for ''Victory at Sea.'' Mr. Bockman was born in Seattle, Washington and grew up in Minneapolis, Minnesota. He graduated in Music Education from the University of Minnesota and held teaching positions at the University of Minnesota, Carleton College, the MacPhail School of Music, Minneapolis, and he often tutored during summer sessions at the Chautauqua Institution. Mr. Bockman is survived by his wife of 32 years, the former Marilyn Modern. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 30, at the United Methodist Church, Davidsonville, Md. He was a man whose musical talent was undeniable, whose wit and gentle charm were unparalleled and whose place in our memory will be unwavering. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Annapolis Symphony Orchestra.

title: A Man of Big Achievement but Very Little Fanfare
description: NEIL L. RUDENSTINE doesn't even look tired.

title: A Struggling Reliance Group Is Sold and a Corporate Raider Retires
description: Saul P. Steinberg, a corporate raider famous for trying but failing to acquire such big-name companies as Walt Disney and Chemical Bank, announced yesterday what amounts to a final withdrawal from a flamboyant career.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a takeover battle between Societe du Louvre, the main asset of the Taittinger Champagne interests in France, and Asher B. Edelman, an American takeover investor, misstated the title of Anne-Claire Taittinger. She is chief executive of Societe du Louvre, not of Taittinger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLINSKY, ROSE, NEE WISHMAN
description: DOLINSKY-Rose, nee Wishman, wife of late Harry, mother of Edith Tunick and Herbert Dolinksy, grandmother of Debra and Marc Melnick, and Harriet and Peter Nathan and Alissa Dolinsky. Great-grandmother of Alexis, Samantha, Adam, and Jordan. Service Sunday, at noon, Louis Hirsch and Son, Bronx, NY.

title: CUNY and Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Lazio to Keep House Seat During His Senate Campaign
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio said yesterday that he would not resign his Congressional seat for the United States Senate campaign, but would balance the demands of the campaign trail with the final five months of his term.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Jim Florio's record as governor of New Jersey referred incorrectly to the rarity of a defeat like the one he suffered in 1993. Mr. Florio was the second governor in the state's modern history, not the first, to lose a bid for a second term. Gov. William T. Cahill lost the 1973 Republican primary to Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.

title: The Big City; Forget Hoffa. What Happened to Squabby the Pigeon?
description: THERE may not be many people this Memorial Day weekend who still remember Squabby. But those of us who do can at last experience closure.

title: The Fuzzy Abortion Debate
description: The abortion debate has gotten murkier in recent years as pro-life forces have shifted their strategy. Whereas once they were focused on wholesale repudiation of Roe v. Wade, they are now finding it more productive to chip away at a woman's right to choose by imposing limitations. One result has been to blur the meaning of ''pro-choice.''

title: 60% OF AIR INDIA TO BE SOLD
description: India's cabinet committee on disinvestment decided to privatize India's money-losing international flag carrier Air India by selling a 60 percent stake. The government will retain a 40 percent stake and sell the remainder to strategic partners, private investors and employees. The government will allow a foreign airline to hold up to a maximum 26 percent stake in the airline. To reduce its losses, Air India has drawn up early-retirement plans for 60 percent of its employees. Air India currently has 26 airplanes in its fleet, including 11 Airbus jets and 15 Boeing aircraft. It flies to 11 cities within India and 23 cities abroad. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ROSE Y.
description: COHN-Rose Y. Of Paterson, NJ, on Friday, May 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David Cohn. Devoted mother of Betty Ann Weintraub and Albert L. Cohn. Sister of Ida Abramowitz and Frances Sanders. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey Weintraub, Andrew Weintraub and Lisa Bridges, Melissa Paprin, Joshua Cohn, Priscilla Karnovsky, Liza-Faith Wallach and Thaddeus Cohn. Great-grandmother of Rachel, Alex, Caleb, Noah, Eliza, Julian, Bernadette, and Sarah, Samantha, Sydney, Nicholas, Benjamin, Augustus and Rebecca. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 1301 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Nun Defies Vatican Request For Silence on Gay Ministry
description: A Roman Catholic nun from Maryland, ordered by the Vatican last year to end a ministry to gay and lesbian Catholics, said yesterday that she would not comply with a new request by Vatican authorities that she cease speaking and writing about the case.

title: Gore and Bradley May Be Ready For a Public Sign of Party Unity
description: In the 11 weeks since Vice President Al Gore beat former Senator Bill Bradley in the Democratic presidential race, the two men have not spoken. But there are signs that a reconciliation may lie ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCLAY, ELENANOR (PAUL)
description: BARCLAY-Elenanor (Paul), age 92, of 30 Bokum Rd. Essex CT, formerly of Lyme, CT, died Wednesda in CT. She is the wife of John W. Barclay and the late John K. Strubing. Besides her husband she is survived by her step-children Louise B. Rice of Cambridge, MA; John Whitney Barclay of Winston Salem, NC; Nina B. VerSteeg of Norwich, CT; and seven stepgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held on June 2, 2:00 P.M. at Saint Anne's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme CT. Memorial gifts may be made to St. Anne's Episcopal Church, 82 Shore Road, Old Lyme, CT 06371. For information contact The Swan Funeral Home, 1224 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook, CT.

title: Holiday on Monday: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Morgan Stanley Venture in Internet Real Estate
description: A Morgan Stanley Venture in Internet Real Estate

title: Tony Arefin, 38, an Influential Ad Designer
description: Tony Arefin, a self-taught graphic designer and art director of periodicals, art catalogs and advertisements who was responsible for influential ad designs like the handwritten look of the current I.B.M. ''magic box'' campaign, died on May 19 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 38.

title: Serbia's Muzzled Media
description: When masked police staged a 2 a.m. raid on Serbia's most important opposition television and radio stations last week, it signaled an escalation of Slobodan Milosevic's attacks on the media. Independent journalists throughout Serbia have been beaten and arrested, and their transmitters are mysteriously failing. Mr. Milosevic is apparently desperate to control the news as elections approach, which makes it particularly important for friends of democracy in Serbia to help these broadcasters.

title: Shopping, Back Then
description: To the Editor:

title: S1 CORPORATION SHARES RISE ON INVESTMENT REPORTS
description: Shares of the S1 Corporation, whose technology enables financial companies to do business on the Internet, jumped yesterday after it announced late on Thursday that a group of financial institutions would invest $244 million in the company. Shares of Atlanta-based S1 soared $6.875 each, to $35.1875, in Nasdaq trading. The five S1 investors are Zurich Financial Services Group, Allianz AG, the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, J. P. Morgan and the State Farm Mutual Auto Insurance Company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, BERT J.
description: LIPPMAN-Bert J. 19 years ago today. We think of you and miss you every day. You are always in our hearts. Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Jessica and Bradley

title: Man Charged in Defacing Of Five Church Statues
description: The Brooklyn district attorney announced the indictment yesterday of a man accused of vandalizing five statues at Roman Catholic churches in Brooklyn. The man, Primus St. Croix, 33, was charged with criminal mischief and other crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYMER, NATALIE M.
description: PAYMER-Natalie M. Beloved wife of Edwin. Devoted mother of Joel and Douglas. Dear mother-inlaw of Sheryl and Amy. Cherished grandmother of Heather, Jason and Sarah. Loving sister and sister-in-law of Martin, Libby and Marcella. Devoted daughter of Beatrice and the late Joseph Gamso. Also remembered as a dear aunt, relative and friend. She was the Executive Secretary of the NY Guild of Photographic Dealers from 1971 to 1998. Donations in her memory can be made to the American Cancer Society or the Alzheimer's Association. Services Sunday, May 28, at 11:30 AM, at Gutterman's Chapel, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: NYT Article
description: Big 3 Warn Dealers About Net Brokers

title: E-Mail Virus Posing as Resume Spreads Slowly Before Weekend
description: E-Mail Virus Posing as Resume Spreads Slowly Before Weekend

title: School Bus Collision Injures 19 Students
description: Nineteen students were hurt yesterday when a school bus and a pickup truck collided, the police said. The bus was taking students home from St. John Vianney High School in Holmdel just before 3 p.m. when it collided with the truck, Capt. Stuart Brown said.

title: OFFICE DEPOT STOCK TUMBLES ON EARNINGS WARNING
description: Shares of Office Depot Inc. plunged about 30 percent yesterday after the company, the seller of office supplies, said its second-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates because of low sales in its technology products in May and weakness in foreign currencies. The shares fell $2.9375 yesterday, to $7.50, after hitting a record low during the day. The company's stock has fallen about 70 percent from a 52-week high of $23.8125. Office Depot, which is based in Delray, Fla., said low sales in its technology department held revenue below expectations in May at stores owned for at least one year. Office Depot sells office supplies ranging from printers to paper clips.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture in Weekend yesterday showing a model for Bernini's sculpture of St. Teresa, with an architecture review of ''The Triumph of the Baroque'' at the National Gallery of Art, was reproduced in mirror image. St. Teresa should have appeared at the right, with the winged figure at the left.

title: Ruling Imperils Development By Reservoirs
description: In a decision that builders fear could greatly curtail development in some of the fastest-growing areas of New York State, a judge ruled this week that New York City cannot let developers install septic systems on steeply sloping hills around the city's upstate reservoirs.

title: Careers Teeter in the Graham Troupe
description: Katherine Crockett's body began to shake when she hung up the telephone on Thursday night after learning that the Martha Graham Dance Company was suspending activity indefinitely because of financial problems.

title: Almost an Energy Alternative; Fuel Cells Hold Promise, but Problems Remain
description: Jeff Colborn plunged into fusion energy research in the late 1980's, first at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and then at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, filled with idealism about fusion's potential for revolutionizing nuclear power generation.

title: Corzine's Spending Nurtures Supporters In the Grass Roots
description: The checks began cascading in a month before the elections in New Jersey last November -- $20,000 to the campaign arm of the Democrats in the State Senate, $15,000 to the Democratic machine in Hudson County, $15,000 to the one in Union County. Out of nowhere, it seemed, affluent guardian angels were coming to the party's aid.

title: Hampton Keeps Mets In a Mood For a Walk
description: Despite a few standout individual performances, the Mets have been a mediocre offensive team. Coming into tonight's game against the St. Louis Cardinals, they ranked 12th among the 16 National League clubs in runs scored and batting average, 11th in homers and 10th in hits.

title: Ulster Unionists in Crucial Vote Today on Accord
description: Members of the 870-member ruling council of the Ulster Unionist party convene here on Saturday for a crucial vote that will either give new life to the Northern Ireland peace accord or likely finish it off.

title: Double-Decker Menace
description: Randolph Walker, a 71-year-old actor, had the right of way on Monday afternoon when a large red New York Apple Tours bus ran him over at a corner crosswalk. The bus driver did not have a proper license. The bus was not supposed to be turning onto a side street. The tour company that owns the bus has been issued 1,800 summonses for traffic violations, many for reckless driving. The buses, imported from Britain, have had trouble meeting national safety and environmental standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, CECELIA NEE BACHRACH
description: GORDON-Cecelia nee Bachrach. On May 19th, 2000. Loving aunt, good friend, dedicated employee of the UJA for 40 years. Contributions may be made in her memory to that organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTABET, GRACE
description: ALTABET-Grace. Beloved mother of Leonard & Linda. Adored sister of Sam Cohen. Loving aunt & great aunt. We shall all miss her warmth. Funeral May 28, 11 AM, Midwood Chapel, Coney Island Avenue & Avenue M, Brooklyn.

title: Memo Details Payments Made to Influence Bids
description: Salt Lake City officials released a document yesterday that appeared to outline the plan for cash payments and other illicit favors that blossomed into an embarrassing scandal in the securing of the 2002 Winter Games. Two delegates of the International Olympic Committee not previously connected to the Salt Lake City scandal were implicated in the document. They face possible sanctioning by the I.O.C.'s ethics commission, which said it would investigate the 28-page document.

title: Test Version of AOL 6.0 Found Online
description: Test Version of AOL 6.0 Found Online

title: White House Loses and Gains in Ruling on a Privacy Act Case
description: A federal appellate court refused today to interfere in a lawsuit brought by a group that accuses President Clinton of violating the Privacy Act of 1974. But the ruling was still a partial victory for the White House.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARGUIMBAU, VINCENT CHARLES
description: ARGUIMBAU-Vincent Charles, Jr., 84, of Darien, CT. & Seville, Spain died Friday, May 19th in Bangor, Maine. Head of Arguimbau & Co, a professional artist, Trustee of Hispanic Society of America in NYC. Survived by wife of 51 yrs, Carmen Perez de Guzman; children, Vincent, Peter, Mariette & Suzanne; sisters Suzanne Davis & Mariette Badger, 7 grandchildren. Memorial Service 3:30 Wednesday, May 31, St. John's, Darien. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Eastern ME Medical Center, 489 State St, Bangor, ME 04401: or Post 53, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: European Inquiry on Deal by Boeing
description: The Boeing Company's proposed purchase of the Hughes Electronics Corporation's satellite unit faces an extended investigation by European antitrust officials, which may delay the acquisition's completion until at least late September.

title: Sports of The Times; In Death, Malik Sealy Continues as a Teacher
description: IN the pulpit of Riverside Church yesterday morning, speaker after speaker gave witness to the short, productive life of Malik Sealy.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 4 about the decline in the value of the euro omitted the source of remarks made by Ernst Welteke, president of Germany's central bank, and reported by Bloomberg News. Mr. Welteke, who doubted that intervention to prop up the currency would be successful, was interviewed by Market News International.

title: Nuclear Energy Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: House Vote on China Trade: The Politics Was Local
description: The most important foreign policy vote so far this year, the 237-to-197 House approval of the China trade deal, was no new affirmation of internationalism by an often provincial Congress, but a reaffirmation of one of its oldest truths: Members vote their districts.

title: Should Clinton Be Disbarred?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUDMAR, MILTON W.
description: LUDMAR-Milton W. May 27, 1993. Dear Dad: It is now seven years since your passing, to return home to God. You touched the lives of so many with your many acts of kindness and love. You are forever in my heart and soul. Your loving son, Scott

title: Collide and Conquer
description: The Devils accomplished what seemed impossible six days ago. Tonight, they made history.

title: Jail Guards Get 11 Years; Inmate Died After Beating
description: Two Nassau County jail guards who fatally beat an unarmed inmate were sentenced today to 11 years in federal prison, and a jail supervisor who tried to cover up for them received nearly 6 years.

title: Taps Have Been Turned Off In Kinder, Gentler Bleachers
description: The renowned ''bleacher creatures'' and other denizens of the cheap seats at Yankee Stadium had less fuel for their fanatical cheering last night, as a ban on beer sales in the bleachers went into effect.

title: Chance Discovery on a Train Led to a Ring of Counterfeiters
description: When the Amtrak train to New York rolled into Niagara Falls last October, customs officers boarded it for a routine inspection. What they found, stacked and wrapped in a newspaper in a bathroom stall, was anything but routine: $200,000 in $100 bills.

title: Apologies to the Iroquois Are Not Enough
description: Across upstate New York, Indians from the six nations of the Haudenosaunee, or Iroquois, are becoming impatient with the slow resolution of claims for return of land taken from us illegally after 1790. A claim by the Oneidas for 900 acres near Oneida Lake is finally heading to trial, but Seneca and Mohawk cases are crawling through the legal system, and an Onondaga claim is expected this year.

title: Remembering Sealy
description: Mark Jackson, Reggie Miller, Al Harrington, Dale Davis and Chris Mullin flew to New York on a private jet after Thursday's game to attend the funeral for Malik Sealy this morning in Manhattan. The rest of the team flew in this morning for a late afternoon practice.

title: ASIAN REGION RIDES A WAVE OF GROWTH LINKED TO EXPORTS
description: Less than three years after a plunge in the value of Thailand's currency set off a devastating economic crisis across much of Asia, the region is riding a wave of growth reminiscent of the Asian miracle of the 1980's.

title: Should Clinton Be Disbarred?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Assails Microsoft and Resubmits Proposal for a Breakup
description: The Justice Department denounced the Microsoft Corporation today, accusing the company of cynical, irresponsible behavior on the last day of its antitrust trial. The department also filed a modified version of its proposal to break up the company that includes a handful of small, technical changes that the judge had requested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MAX. YOUNG ISRAEL
description: HOROWITZ-Max. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member Max Horowitz. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about corporate tax shelter abuses referred imprecisely to the source of an estimate cited by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers for the shelters' cost to the government. The figure, $10 billion, came from a study by a Stanford University professor; Treasury Department tax analysts have not issued an estimate.

title: An Odd Veto
description: Gov. George Pataki is out of step with both the public and state lawmakers in vetoing an important bill that would require all cigarettes sold in New York to meet new fire safety standards by 2002. Lighted cigarettes dropped on beds and couches are the leading cause of fire-related deaths in the state, killing nearly 50 people a year. This deadly hazard can be significantly reduced if cigarettes are designed to be self-extinguishing after a smoker stops puffing on the cigarette.

title: Washington Journal; Media Frenzy Reaches the Chieftains
description: Proving once again that God has a sense of humor, Elian Gonzalez has landed in the most media-centric neighborhood on earth.

title: Yankees Give Away Runs and Then the Game
description: Carl Everett speaks disdainfully of the Yankees, implies that they are unremarkable, a common team with lots of championship rings.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This would never have occurred in France or Germany or Denmark. They would not let this happen. The arts flourish in this country because of the people who pay for it. But it's not enough.''

title: At Sea, Dreams of a Common Language
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SURGES. The euro hit a one-month high, ending its best week since its debut 17 months ago, on speculation the European central bank would buy euros. In New York, the euro rose to 93.17 cents, from 91.23 cents.

title: 'We Can't Walk Away'
description: The violence and chaos of Zimbabwe cast a shadow on its neighbor these days. South Africa is an utterly different country, far more developed and sophisticated. But some in the West fear it will go down the same road.

title: Maytag to Lay Off 120
description: The Maytag Corporation, the No. 3 maker of large appliances in the United States, said this week that it would lay off 120 workers in its laundry appliances division. The layoffs, which represent 4.8 percent of the 2,500 workers at the company's plant in Newton, Iowa, were attributed to slower sales of Maytag's Dependable Care washers. The last layoff at the Newton laundry products operation was in December 1997.

description: To the Editor:

description: ASIA

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New Wave of Growth in Asia Is Reminiscent of 1980's

title: Senator Frees Up Funds for U.N. Forces in Kosovo
description: Senator Judd Gregg, a New Hampshire Republican, has released his hold on $40 million in State Department funds appropriated for a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Kosovo, his spokesman said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Rally in Belgrade Protests Early Closing of Serbian Universities
description: Several thousand students, teachers and parents rallied today to protest the closing of universities a week early by the government of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mexican Candidates' Debate Proves as Harsh as Its Buildup
description: The three leading presidential candidates clashed in a harsh nationally-televised debate that all three acknowledged was crucial to their chances in the July 2 balloting.

title: Francis Lederer Dies at 100; Actor Known for Suave Roles
description: Francis Lederer, a Czech-born actor whose dark good looks made him a suave, continental character in films from the silent era through the 1950's and who continued to teach weekly acting classes in Los Angeles until just a few weeks ago, died on Thursday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 100.

title: Judge Gives State 2 Years To Meet Air Pollution Law
description: In a harsh rebuke to the Pataki administration, a state judge ruled today that the state has ''failed to come anywhere close'' to complying with laws requiring that it catalog clean air requirements and violations for hundreds of major polluters like factories and power plants.

title: Giuliani Seeks An Apology For Heckling
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that Hillary Rodham Clinton and the state's Democratic leadership should apologize for the reported harassment of a police honor guard at the May 16 State Democratic Convention in Albany.

title: Robinson Finds Right Touch for Young Team
description: In so many ways, Coach Larry Robinson seems to have his motivational thumb on the psychic pulse of the Devils. When they trailed the Philadelphia Flyers by three games to one in the Eastern Conference finals, he screamed at the players and spurred their historic comeback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, MAX, MD.
description: RICHTER-Max, MD. On May 25, 2000 of NYC, New York. Beloved husband of late Gloria. Loving father of late Dr. Paul (Barbara) and Dr. David (Miriam). Adoring grandfather of Adam, Dan, Amy and Dr. Michael. Dear brother of late Harry, late Irving, late Lee (Fabish), Shirley (Kolan) and Ethel. Loved by nieces, nephews, sister-in-law and many friends and patients. Proud Purple Heart veteran of WWII. Rest in peace, dear Max. We will always remember you. Service Tuesday, May 30 at 11:30 AM, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bipartisan Effort on Drug Coverage Is Begun
description: An influential Republican member of the House and a Democratic senator announced today that they would collaborate on a bipartisan effort to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year.

title: NYT Article
description: Sega and Nintendo See Profit Decline

title: Israelis and Arabs Face to Face at Border
description: Ram Eisenberg, an architect from Tel Aviv, stood at a barbed-wire border fence here today and gazed at the crowd chanting slogans and waving red and yellow banners of Hezbollah, or Party of God, at the Lebanese village of Kafr Kila on the other side.

title: Should Clinton Be Disbarred?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, CARL E.
description: HAAS-Carl E., 87, of Sarasota, FL, on May 5. Formerly of Jamaica, Great Neck and Manhattan, NY. Beloved husband for 60 years of Roslyn (nee Schachne). Much loved and loving father of Edward J. of Rhinebeck, NY and David S. of Riverdale, NY, grandfather of Gregory J. of Boston, MA, and Elizabeth J. of Kitty Hawk, NC, greatgrandfather of Nicole Fegan, brother of Charlotte Reiss of Portland, OR, Bernard of Somers, NY and Phillip of Oceanside, NY. He obtained his Chartered Life Underwriter designation in 1938 and had a long and distinguished career in the life insurance industry as a general agent for the Continental Assurance Company. He was a former president of the Brooklyn Life Managers Association, the Great Neck Square Club, and the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club; former Master of the Rufus King Masonic Lodge 1091, Jamaica, NY, founder and charter member of Steppingstone Masonic Lodge 1141, a member of Temple Beth Sholom in Sarasota, and since 1981 was a member of Sahib Shrine Temple in Sarasota. Memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: U.N. Envoy Sees Lebanon Backing a Pullout Report
description: The United Nations' special envoy to the Middle East said today that Lebanon had indicated that it would accept a United Nations' certification of Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon.

title: Zia Finds a Fork in the Road to a Slam
description: The Big Top is about to get far bigger, and it has nothing to do with circuses. It refers to bridge events scored across the field, and is possible only with computers. Next Friday and Saturday, the World Bridge Federation's Worldwide Pairs will be played in some 60 countries.

title: A Happy Reunion of the Balanchine Family
description: It was a heartwarming, festive evening, a joint venture by the New York City Ballet and Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: Fan Falls From Upper Deck
description: A 24-year-old man from Yonkers tumbled out of the upper deck at Yankee Stadium in the third inning, landed on the protective screen behind the field level seats and lay there unconscious for several minutes. The fan finally woke up and, after waving to the spectators below him, crawled back up the screen where security officials from Major League Baseball and the Yankees were waiting for him.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Revises Microsoft Plan

title: Bush Sides With Vatican On Its Status At the U.N.
description: Speaking to a Roman Catholic group, Gov. George W. Bush today took the side of the Vatican in a battle over its status at the United Nations, a clash that stems in large part from its stands in international disputes over family planning and abortion.

title: AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN
description: Before they could turn the murdered soldier Barry Winchell into a martyr, gay rights campaigners first had to turn his girlfriend back into a man. A report by David France in The Times Magazine.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, said its Saturn division would lay off 490 workers -- about 20 percent of the unionized work force -- from its assembly plant in Wilmington, Del., because of poor sales of its new L Series midsize sedan and wagon.

title: Cardinal Urges Moratorium On Executions In California
description: Echoing church teachings in the face of heightened national attention to the death penalty, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles has urged Gov. Gray Davis of California to impose a moratorium on executions in the state and to appoint a bipartisan commission to conduct a ''comprehensive and objective study'' of a capital punishment system that he called ''fatally flawed.''

title: ALLTRISTA HIRES BEAR, STEARNS TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: The Alltrista Corporation, which makes Mason canning jars under the Ball and Kerr brands, said yesterday that it had hired Bear, Stearns & Company to advise it on strategic options. Alltrista, based in Indianapolis, received a $30-a-share offer earlier this month from a minority shareholder, Marlin Partners II. Marlin Partners, controlled by Martin Franklin, owns about 9 percent of Alltrista's 6.3 million outstanding shares. The shares of Alltrista, which also makes coin blanks for the United States and foreign mints, rose $1.9375 each, to $25, on the New York Stock Exchange. At the current price the company's stock is worth more than $157 million.

title: Microsoft Postpones Strategy Forum
description: Microsoft Postpones Strategy Forum

title: In a New Age of Risk, Old Tests of Loyalty
description: There was surprisingly little shock when the General Accounting Office revealed this week that investigators with forged badges were able to gain entry into what are supposedly some of the most secure of federal agencies. It was, after all, only the latest in a series of similarly alarming stories about security lapses in the federal government.

title: Internet Cafe Chain to Try A Times Sq. Connection
description: It is an unlikely export from here, but come this fall, a Britain-based entrepreneur will be taking his phenomenally successful chain of Internet cafes across the Atlantic to Times Square. The company, called EasyEverything, has created the equivalent of cybercafes on steroids: the one being planned for Times Square will have 650 to 1,000 Internet terminals with high-resolution flat-panel screens.

title: Angry Election Monitor Leaves Peru 2 Days Before Runoff Vote
description: The head of the Organization of American States observation team, saying he had been deceived by Peruvian officials, angrily left Peru today, two days before the presidential runoff election that he was supposed to monitor to guarantee against vote fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, ELIZABETH ANN
description: CAREY-Elizabeth Ann. On May 26, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward Michael Carey. Loving mother of Edward C. Carey, Diane M. Cunningham and Jane E. Haswell. Mother-in-law to Moreen Carey, Myles Cunningham and Thomas Haswell. Adoring grandmother of Christine, Michelle, Elizabeth, Edward, Carolyn, Timothy and Genevieve Carey, Myles, Charles, John and William Cunningham & Laura Haswell. Great grandmother of Caroline, Lucy, Caitlin and Owen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. John the Evangelist Church, First Ave. at 55 St., Tuesday 10 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Pediatric Division, Bone Marrow Transplant Team, 1275 York Ave., New York, New York 10021, Attn: Susanne Hershowitz.

title: Serena Williams Pulls Out of French Open
description: Citing an injury to her left knee, Serena Williams withdrew from the French Open today shortly before the draw was conducted.

title: Who's In the Office on Fridays?
description: Memorial Day heralds the coming of the dog days of summer, a harbinger of longer, warmer days. Vacation. The beach. Fourth of July picnics. And, as a friend of mine on the East Coast said, ''Things finally begin to slow down enough to actually leave the office early on a Friday.''

title: Religion Journal; Perceived Shift in Ecclesiastical Center of Gravity
description: The Rev. Gerald H. Anderson has a resume that one would expect had allowed him an unusually broad view of trends within Christianity worldwide.

title: Stop Military Ties With Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: 81-Year-Old Killed Defending Relative
description: An 81-year-old woman in a wheelchair was killed last night while trying to protect her grown grandson from another man in her Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the Deutsche Borse supervisory board's approval of a plan to merge with the London Stock Exchange reversed the identities of the two Deutsche Borse executives shown. Rolf Breuer was at the left and Werner Seifert at the right.
