title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; American Portraits
description: In the early 20th century, a Seattle society photographer named Edward S. Curtis came up with a plan: to produce an illustrated encyclopedia that would document the lives of the Hopi, the Apache, the Cree and as many other North American Indian tribes as Curtis could persuade to cooperate with him. At the time, the American Indian population had become a source of curiosity rather than of fear; their numbers had dwindled to some 250,000 and were, Theodore Roosevelt wrote in 1906, ''on the point of passing away.'' In his introductory essay to EDWARD SHERIFF CURTIS, 1868-1952 (Taschen, $39.99), a handsomely produced collection of Curtis's American Indian photographs, Hans Christian Adam notes that there were many ethnographers who were not impressed with the photographer's grand ambitions. But Curtis, who possessed little formal education, had enough swaggering self-confidence and talent as a photographer to convince a few influential people that he was capable of taking on the project. Among those people were Roosevelt, who praised Curtis for doing ''what no other man could do,'' and J. Pierpont Morgan, who helped finance Curtis's research expeditions. During those travels, Curtis met members of some 80 tribes and made avid notes on everything from religious dances to eyewitness accounts of the Battle of the Little Bighorn. The photographs in ''Edward Sheriff Curtis'' have been largely culled from ''The North American Indian,'' the title given to Curtis's 20 leather-bound, gilt-edged volumes, each of which was accompanied by a portfolio of photographs. Many of these sepia-toned photographs of, for instance, a Teton Sioux in a feathered headdress or a Piegan medicine man were widely reproduced in magazines and as individually sold works of art. Over the years the pictures have contributed to the popular perception of the first inhabitants of North America, depicting, Adam writes, ''Indians as they might once have been -- or, rather, as we might wish them to have been.'' Suzanne MacNeille

title: The Solo Retreats From the Spotlight in Jazz
description: I REMEMBER a time, learning about jazz, when I was thrilled by a musician stepping up to take a solo. It struck me then that the solo was a vector of musical truth and insight, and all the other stuff around it was just set-up, material that could be learned quickly.

title: OPINION; Forgive, and Forget, the L.I.R.R.
description: SPRING is the season for renewal, and for me that should mean one thing: apologize to the Long Island Rail Road. Yes, after all these years of criticism and complaining I have realized that perhaps I should be more lenient and forgiving. I am much too grouchy. After all, no one is perfect, and let's face it, this age of prosperity has made us spoiled. We should be grateful for what we have and stop griping about what we could have had or merely want to have.

title: May 21-27; Harvard is Hiring
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, the 26th president of Harvard University -- and only the sixth appointed since the Civil War -- plans to step down next spring after a decade leading the nation's oldest and most prestigious university.

title: A Commencement For a Classmate Beloved by Many
description: Instead of caps and gowns, the graduates wore basketball and soccer jerseys. Instead of ''Pomp and Circumstance,'' the crowd swayed to ''Stand by Me.'' And instead of conferring 1,000 degrees, Brown University presented only one today, to Casey Shearer, a beloved member of the senior class who died less than a week before he was to graduate.

title: Lisanne Skyler, Kevin Black
description: Lisanne Skyler, a daughter of Rita D. Skyler and Martin L. Skyler of New York, is to be married this evening in Bryant Park to Kevin Andrew Justice Black, the son of Dr. Julia Schnebly-Black and Alastair MacDonald Black of Seattle. Rabbi Joel S. Goor will officiate.

title: Trading More Now For Less Later
description: BECAUSE it is so contentious, the debate over reforming Social Security draws plenty of attention. So it is easy to overlook that Congress has just reformed Social Security -- enacting a change that should have been contentious but somehow wasn't.

title: Specialists Devoted to a Single Kind of Plant
description: YOU could say that Melanie Vassallo likes day lilies, but that would be an understatement. Ms. Vassallo loves day lilies so much that she has 425 named varieties of them in her Huntington Station garden on Long Island. And that does not count the hundreds of seedlings that have resulted from her hybridizing efforts. Clearly raising day lilies is more than a casual hobby.

title: And Wait Till You Taste the Stuffed Shells
description: IN a city aswarm with new restaurants clamoring for recognition, the National Rifle Association managed to clear one hurdle with ease. Back in May 2000, it caught the public's attention by announcing plans to open a theme restaurant, the N.R.A. Sports Grille, in Times Square. Now, a year later, for the second hurdle: can it win the hearts, minds and, most important, the stomachs of a gun-shy city eaters?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-28-00: Questions for Susan Hendrickson; Close to the Bone
description: Q: What does it feel like to uncover the greatest Tyrannosaurus rex ever?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRETT, ANTHONY PISCITELLO
description: GARRETT-Anthony Piscitello. On May 5, 2000. Cherished father of Toni and Beatrice Garrett. Dear brother of Placido Piscitello. Loving grandfather of Linda Garrett, Frank and John DeMartino. Also survived by four great grandchildren. Services were held.

title: Footlights; Making a Canoe the Old Way
description: Jeff Kalin is a primitive technologist, eking out a living in the woods of Connecticut selling handmade prehistoric replicas. Mr. Kalin is also in demand at powwows and museum shows, carting his flint tools and gourds from one demonstration to the next.

title: A Short Leash For Camden
description: Never has the state taken so firm a hand with an errant city. Last week, the Whitman administration dispatched yet more expertise to Camden, introducing a local-government expert from Cleveland as the newest member of the team settling in here to take control of the city's troubled finances.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-28-00: Phenomenon; The Indie Scale
description: Mainstream movie lovers and moviemakers will be paying close attention to the potential summer blockbusters that are opening for Memorial Day weekend. But not aspiring independent filmmakers. They may in fact remain completely oblivious to the box-office grosses of ''Mission: Impossible 2'' and ''Shanghai Noon,'' choosing instead to bury their noses in their laptops or experiment with their new Canon PowerShot Pro 70.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUBALIN, HERBERT F.
description: LUBALIN-Herbert F. 1918-1981. Not gone. Not forgotten. Loved and missed. Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

title: Women Seek Louder Voice as World Peacemakers
description: ''African women are everywhere, in the media, in politics, in business,'' said Ergibe Boyd, an Eritrean-born American diplomat who has given herself an unusual assignment in the Rwandan capital, Kigali. ''But women are never at the peace table.''

title: Whispers of Recession Are Growing Louder
description: ''IT comes up in every meeting,'' said Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. '' 'Jeff, what is the risk of a hard landing?' ''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Human Resumes
description: ''Yesterday's thought was how did I get here, 31, 32, just this huge knot of unknowing and losing my hair,'' a telemarketer in one of Sam Lipsyte's stories laments before dialing to determine a stranger's satisfaction with a local salad bar. Lipsyte's first book, a collection of stories titled VENUS DRIVE (Open City, paper, $13), is made of such bleak portraits -- we meet the aching and nearly defeated, people who seek cold comfort in drug dens, peep shows and corporate cubicles. Lipsyte writes in a clipped manner that establishes distance from his fringe-dwelling characters, and he employs shots of dark humor to alleviate the loneliness that fills these pages. In ''Cremains,'' the protagonist moves into his dead mother's apartment and shoots up her leftover morphine while tending to the building's old women, offering to change their light bulbs. He even toys with the idea of mercy killings. ''The newspaper Hilda gets delivered would call me evil,'' he says. ''The one I buy on the corner would say it's more complicated than that.'' In the best story here, ''My Life, for Promotional Use Only,'' Lipsyte -- who writes about movies for the online magazine Feed -- creates a pitch-perfect parody of the new media world. It's a place where the narrator -- a former underground rock hero who thinks a skill-set is ''some kind of mail-order frying pan'' -- is a woeful anachronism among the ''human resumes'' who ''study esoteric forms of South American combat and go on all-deer diets.'' Not for the faint of heart (or soul), ''Venus Drive'' explores the complexity of despair with poignancy and sly wit. Christine Muhlke

title: Patricia Lucey, John Blackmar
description: Patricia Elizabeth Lucey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Lucey of Corona del Mar, Calif., was married yesterday to John Sutherland Blackmar, a son of Margaret E. Blackmar and Richard H. Blackmar of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Hart, the vicar general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: POSTINGS: Apartments to Rise Atop Theater in East Village; Drama Below, Condos Above
description: After escalating rents forced the Theater for the New City to move four times in 15 years, it bought a rundown city warehouse at 155 First Avenue in 1986 for $717,000 and spent more than $1 million fixing it up. As recently as a year ago the theater, in the East Village between Ninth and 10th Streets, was burdened with a mortgage that is still almost $600,000, plus a $350,000 construction lien on the property that with interest had grown to $550,000.

title: From Children to Medicine, a Particular Look at the World; H.M.O.'s: Enemy In Medical Thriller
description: DR. DAVID SHOBIN could not have produced his latest medical thriller, ''The Provider'' (St. Martin s Paperbacks, $6.99), at a more opportune time. Everybody, it seems, has a bone to pick with health maintenance organizations, and it's payback time, says the physician-author, who has published six novels.

title: The Draft in Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Cash in Hand, Suffolk Still Can't Get Land
description: SINCE the 1960's, Suffolk County had periodically pursued the purchase of the former Broad Cove Duck Farm, nearly 100 acres of waterfront woods and fields on a creek leading into Flanders Bay in Riverhead.

title: Carolyn Koegler, Robert Miller
description: Carolyn Ann Koegler, a daughter of Mary Ellen Scarborough of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Kurt G. Koegler, is to be married today to Robert Harrex Miller, the son of Monique Miller and Dr. Robert M. Miller of Manchester, N.H. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the Federal District Court for the Southern District, is to officiate at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Earthy, Flavor-Drenched
description: Before the onslaught of summer, when the atmosphere and the wine-tasting psychology make heavy-duty reds beside the point, it seemed wise to try Pellegrini's '97 cabernet franc. A second reason is that there is not a lot left at the winery: some 60 cases. The winery is limiting each customer to four.

title: The Left Wing of the Possible
description: THE OTHER AMERICAN

title: SOAPBOX; Intrigued by a Teacher's Past
description: MY first reaction to being invited to my 20th high school reunion was literally from the gut: how many pounds had I gained since 1980, and how many could I lose before the reunion?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-28-00: On Language; Dash It All
description: The stately colon, the confiding parenthesis and the gently pausing comma demand to know: what's behind today's big dash to the dash? Why has this lingua interruptus -- expressing uncertainty, jerking the reader around, setting up startling conclusions, imitating patterns of speech -- come to dominate our prose?

title: E-Books and Sunlight
description: To the Editor:

title: A View of the Hudson at West Point
description: REPORTEDLY $26 million has gone into the renovation of the guest rooms and facade of the Hotel Thayer, which claims to have ''changed everything but the river.''

title: A Building Transformed, Inside and Out
description: WHEN people in New London say ''Hygienic,'' they're usually not speaking of scrubbing their hands. They're referring to the Hygienic Building, a downtown landmark that dates to 1844.

title: Teacher, Cheerleader and C.E.O.
description: BETSY D. HOLDEN, the new chief executive at Kraft Foods, never disguised her ambitions for such a post, and never saw her sex as an obstacle.

title: The Blockbuster Can No Longer Live By Muscle Alone
description: LIKE death, taxes and those sprayed helmets of hair sported by many women on the Upper East Side, some things never seem to change. Like summer movies. Always the same: fiery explosions, knockout special effects, thin plots, well-muscled stars. Add to that nonstop television commercials, toys on the shelves, action figures in the Happy Meal. It seems so formulaic.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HEADLOCK

title: Another Person's Treasures
description: Good Will is good enough for Tara Subkoff and Matt Damhave, two 20-something art school dropouts who recently started Imitation of Christ, a Los Angeles-based line of thrift store couture. ''The idea is to take refuse -- or ''undesirables'' -- and make them desirable again,'' Mr. Damhave said. To that end, a polka-dot polyester dress (''Old Man's Fantasy'') has had its hem hiked and sleeves puffed ($888), and red-and-white-striped bathing trunks ($333) had the liner torn out and ''Sincerity is the new vulgarity'' scrawled on a pocket.

title: Reports From Faraway Places That Brought War Home
description: JOURNALISM, it is said, provides a first draft of history. It is a cliche, yet sometimes an unlikely combination of war and a witness illustrates the hallowed truth that lurks behind a hollow phrase. I write this sitting in Berlin, dreaming of Bosnia, and thinking of Kurt Schork, the Reuters correspondent whose dispatches from Sarajevo helped shape the world's view of a war that was as morally indelible to my generation of correspondents as Vietnam was to another.

title: The White Sox
description: To the Editor: In your article ''What's Doing in Chicago'' (April 30), you mentioned the Chicago Cubs but ignored the Chicago White Sox.

title: Rime of a Modern Mariner
description: THE WATER IN BETWEEN

title: China Trade Vote Splits Labor Movement
description: The American labor movement is badly divided on political strategy after last week's vote in favor of the China trade bill, which labor opposed. And some union leaders and Democratic consultants say this split could set back Vice President Al Gore's electoral chances as well as Democratic hopes of regaining control of the House of Representatives.

title: Kipling's Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Karush, Mark Erwin
description: Dr. Deborah Karush, a daughter of Dr. Ruth K. Karush and Dr. Nathaniel P. Karush of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Mark Edward Erwin, the son of Barbara and Edward Erwin of Corsicana, Tex. Judge Eduardo Padro of the Criminal Court in the Bronx is to officiate at Bridgewaters in Manhattan.

title: Fast-Paced Fun for Kids Is Hell on Wheels for the Elderly
description: Elderly residents say the hilly tree-lined streets from 181st Street to the Cloisters are a great place to live. Local teenage boys think these same streets, which include some of the steepest in Manhattan, are a great place to race through on their bicycles.

title: Signature Scoops
description: Ice cream enthusiasts know Ciao Bella as the brand behind unusual ice creams like Malted Milk Ball and Pumpkin Spice gelato. But what the foodies don't know is that the New Jersey-based retailer does the majority of its business supplying chefs and caterers with specially made flavors and will create custom ice creams for individual patrons as well. ''We haven't promoted it that much,'' said Charlie Apt, co-owner of Ciao Bella. One socialite on the Upper East Side sends a chauffeur to Ciao Bella to pick up her custom grapefruit/Campari sorbet; a downtown restaurateur has a gelato made with Maker's Mark Bourbon. We requested Cosmopolitan sorbet, which tasted just like the cocktail and seemed perfect for summer entertaining (adults only, please!). Minimum purchase is five gallons ($35 a gallon). Signature ice creams can be stored until needed at Ciao Bella, at 231 40th Street in Irvington, N.J. Ciao Bella can be reached at (800) 435-2863. ANNA HOLMES

title: Streetscapes/The Former Beach Street, Now Ericsson Place, in TriBeCa; A Shadow From the Civil War Fades Into the Past
description: IN 1864, when the inventor John Ericsson moved to Beach Street between Varick and Hudson Streets, his elegant house faced the private St. John's Park, which was built as one of the city's most ambitious residential squares. When Ericsson, the designer of the ironclad warship Monitor in the Civil War, died in 1889, his house was surrounded by factories and a freight railroad.

title: Graduates With Grit
description: One is a single mother who was thrown out of high school in the 1980's and nearly killed herself, only to be reborn in college as a short-story writer.

title: OZONE DANGER
description: Of 13 counties in New Jersey monitored for ozone levels in the air from 1996 through 1998 by the federal Environmental Protection Agency all except Bergen received a failing grade, and Bergen barely passed with a D, according to a survey of ozone levels made public last week by the American Lung Association. Camden County and Ocean County were rated worst among the counties where ozone monitoring devices are located in New Jersey; Camden ranked 21st out of the 25 worst counties in the country. Ground-level ozone is created when nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons such as unburned gasoline and diesel fuel react with the heat from sunlight.

title: Women at the Wheel As Ambulance Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Recombinations
description: Full Circles, Overlapping Lives

title: Reed, Rice and Irvin Nearing Retirement
description: Dallas Cowboys wide receiver Michael Irvin was never an angel. Away from the field, Irvin and trouble were often good pals. But as a player, he was one of the toughest, at times most spectacular, pass catchers of the past decade. Now he faces retirement because of a spinal injury.

title: A Time for Dialogue at CUNY
description: The 20-campus City University of New York was in chaos when the board of trustees hired Matthew Goldstein as the new chancellor last summer. Political infighting among the trustees had paralyzed the administration, driven out some of the institution's most talented minds and further demoralized a faculty that was already embittered by hiring freezes and disrespect from a few trustees who put politics ahead of academics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COMPANY F, 32ND INFANTRY REGT
description: Company F, 32nd Infantry Regt. Seventh Division U.S. Army Men and Officers Attu, Kwajalein, Leyte, Okinawa 1942-1945

title: Lights, Videos and Photos in a Biennial
description: ''THE Westchester Biennial 2000,'' now at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle here, simply doesn't live up to its billing; in fact, it falls painfully short.

title: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly
description: In ''The Silent Generation Seeks Its Due (May 7)'' Fred Brock looked at Americans who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers. Members of that age group, in their mid-50's to early 70's, often feel overlooked by employers, marketers and the popular culture.

title: Roman Luxury In a Renovated Hotel
description: In addition to its opulent furnishings and enviable location just off the majestic Piazza del Popolo, Rome's recently reopened Hotel de Russie vaunts a special attraction for a hotel in the center of the city: a garden, three-quarters of an acre with towering palms, magnolias, orange trees, rosebushes, a small grotto and fountain.

title: Carla Narrett, Richard Ott
description: Dr. Carla Marie Narrett, a college dean, and Dr. Walter Richard Ott, a college provost, were married yesterday. Judge Harold Kuskin of the New Jersey Tax Court in Morristown officiated at Arthur's Landing, a restaurant in Weehawken, N.J.

title: Knicks Beat Pacers Despite a New Injury
description: The Knicks, who began yesterday's game without the injured Patrick Ewing and then lost Marcus Camby to a knee injury, defeated the Indiana Pacers, 98-95, for their first victory in the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals. The Pacers still lead the series, two games to one.

title: A Liliputian Art Of Giant Beauty
description: A golden owl, streaked with copper and brown, his wings stretched wide, has landed on a curly baby goat. The kid, half his size, struggles to get free. But from under brows as thick and dark as a melodrama villain's, the owl's eyes make it clear: butchery will follow. Amazingly, this powerful image is only three inches across; its medium thousands of bits of glass called tesserae. The owl attacking a kid is a micromosaic; a term that did not exist 50 years ago, although the technique is more than two centuries old.

title: Making a Daily Task Of Chasing Dust Balls
description: IF clutter fills your counters, scum lines your sink and dust balls dance beneath your sofa, you are not alone. But Robin Kotz, president of Maid Brigade, says there is no need for the house-cleaning impaired to despair. She offered advice based on what she has learned running a housecleaning service that cleans more than 50 houses a day.

title: E-Brokers Take Brunt of Market's Fall
description: If Thomas K. Lewis Jr. always wanted to be the sole chief executive of a prominent, fast-growing company, Tuesday was his lucky day. If, however, he did not want that company's stock price to be at a 52-week low and falling as analysts retooled their earnings forecasts into projected losses, then it was not so lucky.

title: Crime in California: Taking the Stern Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now Poll
description: Thank you for the entire scope of your special issue. The discussion on psychotherapy moderated by Ariel Kaminer inspired me to write and reminded me of an undervalued piece of equipment in its practice: the office door (''What Do We Talk About When We Are Paying Someone to Listen?''). I often use the hinged door as a metaphor to describe the complementary value of opening and closing -- disclosure and boundedness. I find the moment that the door opens to be a point when my curiosity and energy are engaged. And while your pictorial essay on psychiatrists' offices was illuminating, I would feel remiss not to draw your attention to the door.

title: Rose Strong in Fourth
description: After a poor start in which he missed eight of his first nine shots, Jalen Rose put on a fourth-quarter show that came close to becoming a horror flick for the Knicks. In a scoring spree that overshadowed Rik Smits's 21-point first-half, Rose scored 22 points in the final period.

title: Tangy but Also Hip
description: AN Israeli hedonist's vision of heaven is Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend, lightly cool, alternating with forkfuls of grilled sweet-fleshed St. Peter's fish at a restaurant on the Sea of Galilee.

title: Other Paths to Success: Horses, the Web, a Buffet
description: IN Westchester, many real estate agents have found success with sometimes quirky methods.

title: Sports of The Times; Sprewell, a Lifelong Learner, Learns How to Bounce Back
description: A matter of concern was arising, like smoke in the distance, in relation to Latrell Sprewell. It came in the guise of last quarters in the playoffs this season. The Knick forward, after generally fine first three quarters, had become mysteriously ineffective in the final 12 minutes, as though someone had swiped his can of spinach, or slipped chewing gum under his sneakers.

title: Disarmament Timetable
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico's Opposition Candidate Rebounds
description: Vicente Fox Quesada, the leading opposition presidential candidate, gave a vigorous but level-headed performance on Friday night in a televised debate with two rivals that helped him recover from embarrassing mistakes in his campaign this week.

title: Seasoned and Seasonless
description: WHEN asked about what I like in a restaurant, I generally talk about those that are continually fiddling with ingredients available only at a specific time of year. But that said, I hope Rebecca's never changes its menu. Or at the very least that the jerk chicken skewers, camarones con mojo, cumin-cilantro red snapper, and caramel flan are here to stay, whatever the season. I want to enjoy them every time I go there.

title: Will Managers Relate To This Gripping Tale?
description: A DECADE or so ago, Dennis N. T. Perkins, president of the Syncretics Group in Branford, Conn., brought us ''the moose on the table,'' the disarming metaphor that companies use to mention the unmentionable. He devised that impish but effective image as a way of coaxing business people into talking openly about the sensitive issues that hang heavy over a discussion but that no one dares mention.

title: Music and Cooking The Louisiana Way
description: AT Waterloo Village's music and food festival next weekend, Marcia Ball is likely to stand out -- for two reasons. The first one is that her powerhouse New Orleans-styled rhythm and blues performance fits perfectly with the Cajun and zydeco theme.

title: Making Room For Newcomers
description: Weeds and unwanted seedlings from self-seeding annuals and perennials are formidable competition for transplants and should be pulled out when spotted.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-28-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Clearwater, Fla., Pier 60, March 14, 2000

title: It's Hard to Predict What Admissions Office Wants Each Year
description: ARE you a high school senior who can debate the pros and cons of such controversial issues as cloning? Then Georgetown University wants you. Can you deftly handle the basketball at point guard? Try Princeton University. Or maybe soccer is your game. In that case, head to Dartmouth College.

title: INVESTING WITH: Mayer Offman; Carlin Equities Group
description: LAST March, after attending synagogue morning and evening for nearly a year, Mayer Offman decided to take a break from his devotions.

title: Art Under The Influence
description: For their millennial celebration, the people at the National Gallery in London decided to tap back into their origins. Founded in 1824 as a study collection, the museum was the sort of place where generation after generation of young artists studied at the feet of the masters, often copying masterworks virtually verbatim. But then something happened -- when was it? The 60's? The 70's? Young artists seemed to stop looking at, or at any rate copying from, the old masters. Indeed, for a time, if you came upon someone slaving away at an easel, dropcloth spread, face to face with a great predecessor there at the museum, you took him for a Sunday painter, certainly not cutting edge. Things have been changing again, though. Artists seem to be looking at prior art more intently nowadays, and in the spirit of that regard, the National Gallery and its guest curator, Richard Morphet, decided to lure 24 of the world's leading contemporary artists back into the museum's precincts, inviting each of them to choose one work and to respond with some creative work of their own. The sources the artists drew on for this ''Encounters'' show range from Duccio, in the early 14th century, through Monet, who was still alive when the oldest of the invitees, Balthus, was already copying Poussin at the Louvre. The contemporary artists, in turn, span three generations, from Balthus (b. 1908) through Francesco Clemente (b. 1952).

title: The Way We Live Now Poll
description: I was overwhelmed by your special issue (May 7), with its remarkably positive, incisive look at what we think and how we feel at the start of the new millennium. We appear, on the whole, to retain belief in something bigger than ourselves.

title: A Battle Brews as Iran's Reformers Take Over Parliament
description: Iran's new reformer-dominated Parliament opened today in Tehran, the first since the Islamic revolution to include a majority of members who appear eager and ready to challenge the conservative clergy's dictates over daily life.

title: The Way We Live Now Poll
description: What struck me were the boxes of facial tissues in your photographs of psychiatrists' offices (''What's Couched in a Couch?''). Equipped for weeping, I presume. Willard Gaylin has a box under the end table next to his minimalist couch; Arnold Richards has displayed his flowery box prominently on the table next to the couch pillow; Mary Fitzpatrick has her tissues popped and ready to go, next to her plush, ladylike couch; Sonya Rhodes has what looks like a black wood tissue holder within arm's reach of her 1964 Eames chair.

title: Jennifer Koen, Mark Horowitz
description: Jennifer Mara Koen and Mark Joseph Horowitz were married last evening by Rabbi Jerome Davidson at the TriBeCa Rooftop, a party space in Manhattan.

title: A Most Unlikely Star
description: OUTSIDE a concert by Katey Red at the Factory, a teenage club in East New Orleans, fellow musicians are raving. ''A lot of things wouldn't be going on in this town without her,'' said Mankind, a producer. ''She's hot right now.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHAT'S NOT TO LOVE?

title: FIRST PERSON; Choppy Waters at the Pool
description: GROWING up in Brooklyn, I never swam in an outdoor pool. Our neighborhood had a pool ''club,'' but my parents refused to join. The men there played pinochle and drank. The women played mah-jongg and wore frosted nail polish. The daughters shaved their legs and made out with boys. The boys smoked cigarettes.

title: Ideas & Trends: Antitrust Annals; The Uncertain Art Of Legal Remedies
description: IN a court filing last week Microsoft called the government's proposal to break the company in two ''the antitrust equivalent of the death penalty.''

title: Keeping an Eye Out for Beetles
description: BECAUSE the Asian long-horned beetle has been found to be spreading in the New York metropolitan area, Connecticut state scientists are urging property owners to inspect their trees, particularly their maple trees, for the beetles.

title: Meals for Pigeons Mean Messes for Us, Residents Say
description: Last Thursday morning at 5:15, a gray mass of pigeons walked wing to wing across several concrete paving stones while downing their daily meal: five pounds of birdseed freshly spread on the Rabbi Kirshblum Traffic Triangle at Main Street and 73rd Terrace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURST, SIDNEY S.
description: FURST-Sidney S. The family mourns his passing on May 26, 2000. Beloved husband of Ina, and father of Jonathan, Daniel, Jed and predeceased by Seth.

title: Menu From Yesteryear, River Traffic Views
description: THE River Grille and Bar in Westport, which recently changed its name from The Mooring, doesn't seem like it's in a time warp, until you start reading the menu. In looks alone, it has the simplicity of a waterside restaurant (which is what it is), its wall of windows facing a small marina on the Saugatuck River.

title: Confessions of a Satellite TV Addict
description: I GREW up in a family where ''remote controle'' meant the person closest to the television set, so my current status as a satellite TV subscriber is as oxymoronic as a Web site called Luddite.com. It was just too tough to resist the advertised offerings of this new technology - from sharper picture to expanded channel choices to superior sports coverage - that have already lured more than 12 million subscribers nationally.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; For the Love of Pita
description: I must confess, yes, I really must. My conscience demands it. I took ''outside'' food into a movie theater. But how could I be expected to help myself? The scent of falafel wafting out the door of Beyond Pita on Church Street here on a warm spring evening was simply too, too much for me to resist. So I didn't. And while all about moviegoers me were grinding their teeth to nubs on last year's popcorn, I was delighting in my fat little pita of delectably fried ground chickpeas and mixed bits of cabbage, tomato and pickle doused with a piquantly complicated white sesame sauce. ''The falafel is my mother's recipe, and there's nothing like your mother's food,'' the owner, Nassar Allah Arsheed (his friends call him John), 30, said of the woman who taught him to cook in his boyhood days in Israel. Indeed, food is a matter of family, and religion, for Mr. Arsheed. His St. John sub (mozzarella, roasted peppers, romaine and sun-dried tomatoes) and St. Christopher sub (portobello mushrooms, mozzarella and arugula) are listed on the menu under ''Hala's Vegetarian Specials.'' ''I dedicated these to my sister, Hala,'' he said, adding that saints were involved here because ''we are Christian.'' The shop is too small for tables so diners eat outside on nearby benches or, like me, transport the treat elsewhere. Along with falafel and subs, Mr. Arsheed sells hummus (falafel's boiled and mashed cousin), baba gannouj (roasted and pur'eed eggplant) and breakfasts like cheese omelettes and eggs, any style. (''I don't push breakfast,'' Mr. Arsheed said. ''I just serve it because I'm here cooking anyway.'') ANDREA HIGBIE

title: Our Trip's Long Enough as It Is, Commuters Tell M.T.A.
description: Mildred Gregorio rises at 5:45 every morning. After showering and dressing, she trudges to the Pelham Parkway stop of the No. 5 (Dyre Avenue) train, fights for a seat and settles down for the 90-minute ride to her office near City Hall, where she works as a secretary to a judge.

title: Big Money, Cheap Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Studios Nurture the Starry-Eyed and Twinkle-Toed

title: Program to Benefit Shakespeare Festival

The program of popular songs will be performed at 8 p.m. on Friday at the Parish House of St. Philips Church in Garrison. The suggested donation is $10, free for children.

Jim Florio in his bid for the Democratic Senate nomination in New Jersey against Jon S. Corzine. It is a classic ''soft money'' ad, in that it does not explicitly advocate voting for or against anyone. The commercial began running on Wednesday on television stations in New York City.

title: Vikings Return to Newfoundland
description: A thousand years ago, Leif Ericson and his crew of Vikings rowed their longships to the rocky shores of Newfoundland, where they founded the first European settlement of North America. This summer, Newfoundland is host to ''Vikings! 1,000 Years,'' a provincewide festival centered around L'Anse aux Meadows, the only authenticated Norse settlement in North America.

And for a good part of her 24-year career as an actress, that's exactly what she did, giving finely detailed performances in small roles on stage and screen, treating her entire body of work as a kind of private repertory theater in which she would act whatever part she was called upon to play.

Having traveled to Kenya and Tanzania four times in the past 20 months, also with Abercrombie & Kent, I am now preparing for a five-week trip to the Masai Mara for the great migration this summer.

title: Jeter's Back. Just a Nice Day at the Park.
description: The Yankees desperately missed Derek Jeter, his run production, his confidence that seems to stick like lint on his teammates. But Jeter rejects the notion that the team is built around him, that he is the difference between victories and losses. The Yankees are the type of team, he said, that must have donations from all parts of its roster to succeed.

description: INVESTORS in stocks have endured a lot of pain since the markets peaked a few months back. With the Dow Jones industrial average down 10.42 percent for the year, and the Nasdaq composite down more than twice that, investors are probably wondering when all this agony will be over.

title: Two Trees Grow in Brooklyn
description: Q My mom lives in a Brooklyn condominium. She has owned her ground-floor apartment with a backyard for 12 years. She has two fruit trees: nectarine and mulberry. Both trees are big, and she loves them. Recently, she got a letter from the board asking her to cut down one of the trees because it was ''imposing itself in the parking lot.'' The board added that if she did not respond to its request within 30 days the board would hire a tree-removal company to have the work done and then bill my mother. Can the board do this? . . . Christine Mark, Brooklyn.

title: CITY LORE; Wonder of Wonders
description: THERE is a story, perhaps apocryphal, that a hot-dog vendor named Denos Vourderis proposed to his wife on top of the Wonder Wheel and promised to buy it for her when he could afford it.

description: As the clock neared zero yesterday and an odd Indiana Pacers' comeback began to materialize, Game 3 started to take on the feel of a Reggie Miller moment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIGAN, WINIFRED (WINI) NAOMI
description: COSTIGAN-Winifred (Wini) Naomi, died peacefully in Lake Worth, FL on May 24 after courageously fighting cancer since 1996. Mrs. Costigan, 88, a graduate of Syracuse University, was a teacher at Long Beach High School and cofounded Camp Costigan with her late husband, the Hon. George B. Costigan, Sr., of Long Beach, NY. Wini was the proud mother of Linda Lederman, Ph.D. and the late George B. Costigan, Jr., Esq. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Joshua Lederman, Tracy and Michael Costigan, daughter-in-law, Fran Costigan, and brother, Jules Gilbert. Wini was the companion of the late Morty Blankstein.

title: Montauk Skirmish: Lawmen vs. Baymen
description: IT began on April 30 at Liar's Saloon, a Montauk tavern. That night, local residents say, some fishermen got into an argument with enforcement officials from the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, in town to attend a state-sponsored training course at the nearby Montauk Yacht Club. The next morning, a bunch of tires were found slashed on a bunch of police cars parked at the yacht club.

title: Polite, Plaintive Signs Urge Truckers to Stop Honking
description: It may seem obvious to those who call Bond Street home. But earlier this month, just to be sure, Mort Starobin printed out a simple plea and tacked it to trees along his leafy, residential block.

description: It has been a year since the Westchester Arts Council moved into the former Chase Manhattan Bank building on Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, amid hopes of livening up the declining neighborhood. Superficially, not much has changed, but the elegant brick and stone building now flies its cultural banners proudly.

description: IN November, more than 100 employees of Calico Commerce were millionaires, at least on paper.

title: From Children to Medicine, a Particular Look at the World; First Novel Delves Into Dark Passions
description: SUSAN MERRELL does much of her writing wearing a coat -- out of necessity rather than eccentricity. Her office, in the basement of her house in Sag Harbor, is chilly. But the temperature guarantees that when she wants to concentrate on her work, interruptions from her family will be minimal.

description: THIS spring, the one-two punch of ''Walking With Dinosaurs'' and ''Raising the Mammoth'' heightened the visibility of the Discovery Channel. But the public was already watching.

description: Most Westchester residents are optimistic about their financial future despite turbulence in the stock market, according to a survey released last week by Iona College's Center for Social Research.

title: Think You're Being Neighborly? Think Again, Pal
description: THE quaint little village of Antwerp, N.Y., seemed like an ideal place for Stephen and Vici Diehl to escape the noise and nuisance of city life and to indulge their passion for nature photography.

title: The Required Deceptions Of 'Il Postino'
description: THE large, flappy ears fooled everybody. Viewed from afar on a bicycle or up close from behind, everything about the man suggested Massimo Troisi in the role of Mario, the humble letter carrier, budding poet and ill-fated political banner-bearer in the Italian film ''Il Postino'' (''The Postman''). The ears perfectly resembled Troisi's and so did the hair and the back of the head, the tall, spare build and gangling movements. In reality, as the director Michael Radford explains on a new DVD from Miramax, Mario was often a stand-in.

title: Heineken Decides To Stay in White Plains
description: After coming to White Plains from Manhattan five years ago, Heineken U.S.A. is moving its headquarters again: to White Plains. The short hop from 50 Main Street to 360 Hamilton Avenue will double the floor space for the importer of Heineken and other brands of beer and means just a few blocks' difference in commuting for the company's 113 employees.

title: His Father's Son
description: EXPERIENCE

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Michael Caruso; Second Happiest Guy
description: EARLY Tuesday night, at a party for Maximum Golf, a new magazine dedicated to the proposition that golf is a beer-and-babes kind of sport, Michael Caruso could have used a mulligan. The skies above the Central Park boathouse were threatening rain. Guests were arriving, as frantic workers were still constructing a 100-foot AstroTurf green, on which partygoers would be given the chance to putt for what seems to be the only way to get attention these days: a $1 million cash prize. Mr. Caruso, the magazine's founder and editor in chief, had first planned for the green to be floating on an artificial island in Central Park Lake. But chipping balls into the water was not approved by the Parks Department, resulting in last-minute chaos. The beleaguered editor sidled up to the bar. ''Sorry, Buddy, the bar doesn't open for five minutes,'' the bartender told him.

title: Curtain Up! A New Season For Hedonism
description: STEVEN AVILES, 25, a cosmetologist from Queens, didn't need a wig. He scooped his shoulder-length, curly reddish hair into a ponytail on top of his head and fastened it with a sparkling rhinestone wrist cuff. Rummaging through his makeup bag, he peered into the dressing room mirror and outlined his sultry lips, then added one more coat of mascara to his already impossibly thick fake lashes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, ROSE Y.
description: COHN-Rose Y. Of Paterson, NJ, on Friday, May 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David Cohn. Devoted mother of Betty Ann Weintraub and Albert L. Cohn. Sister of Ida Abramowitz and Frances Sanders. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey Weintraub, Andrew Weintraub and Lisa Bridges, Melissa Paprin, Joshua Cohn, Priscilla Karnovsky, Liza-Faith Wallach and Thaddeus Cohn. Great-grandmother of Rachel, Alex, Caleb, Noah, Eliza, Julian, Bernadette, and Sarah, Samantha, Sydney, Nicholas, Benjamin, Augustus and Rebecca. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 1301 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Shanghai
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Shanghai'' (April 16) reawakened memories, as my husband and I were there last October, just in time for the 50th anniversary celebration of the Communist takeover. We stayed at the Peace Hotel and ate in the Phoenix Restaurant. The delicious dinners were accompanied by a performance on traditional instruments by three fine musicians. We were seated at the window with an excellent view of the fireworks, which were spectacular. We were surprised, however, when many parents rushed over and placed their young children on our table so that they could see the display.

title: The Way We Live Now Poll
description: Polls are wonderful for many things, including gauging reactions to events. But they are poor windows onto the complexities and ambiguities of public opinion. If you want to know what's on the minds of Americans, you ought to engage them in conversation that would give them a chance to do more than select from among canned answers to rigidly structured and limited questions.

title: The Dealmaker; Iris Kalt Says She Won't Be Happy Until She's Sold Every House in Scarsdale
description: THE fire engine-red Mercedes convertible zipped up Chase Road into Scarsdale village and parked cross-grain over two diagonal parking spaces. Out hopped Iris Kalt with her pet boxer, Diesel, in tow. She breezed into the Prudential-Centennial real estate office hot on the trail of her latest listing.

title: How Do I Love Thee? Let Me Count the Words
description: THE best-selling author in the world managed to ignore both the sexual and the technological revolutions. She survived the whole of the 20th century keeping her love scenes chaste and dictating her work to a secretary.

title: Mt. Shasta's Powerful Mystique
description: BLANKETED with snow until midsummer, Mount Shasta's Upper Panther Meadow was warm early last September and bright with Indian paintbrush, yarrow and cliff penstimon. From the trailhead at around 7,600 feet, my husband, Karl, and I had walked gently uphill along a grassy creek to the source spring considered sacred by Indians, who still conduct ceremonies there. It is a small sandy pool rimmed by flowers and rocks, with lovely cold water bubbling out. After tasting the spring water we joined several others who sat nearby meditating. Then we climbed a bit higher for another view of the snowy slopes rising above us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISAN, LILLIAN (BRAHAM)
description: WISAN-Lillian (Braham). Died April 16 age 93. Wife of the late Jesse H. Mother of Mark. Grandmother of Liz and Anne. Motherin-law of Jane. Sister of the late George Braham. Memorial service at Temple Beth Elohim, 8th Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn on June 4 at 10:30AM.

title: Darwinists Meet Orwell In a Summer of Voyeurism
description: ''THE 1900 HOUSE'' comes with the appeal of a literary dream come true: you are about to walk into a lush Victorian novel. In this four-part series, a real English family moves into a house equipped with turn-of-last-century conveniences and lives as they would have a hundred years ago. So imagine how surprising it is when the mother of the family looks into a camera hidden in her closet (the better to record the video diaries each family member makes) and says: ''I've just had my first bath and a miserable affair it was, too. About four inches of hot water.'' Her face and voice filled with weariness, she adds: ''I was just so desperate to wash myself properly. I've come to the conclusion that Victorian cleanliness is just nothing like the standards of cleanliness that we have today.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, HAROLD
description: ABRAMSON-Harold. In his 96th year on May 25, 2000. Beloved husband of Dorothy for 73 years. Loving father of Carol Sahn-Dorfman and Susan Schwartz. Dear fatherin-law of Robert R. Schwartz. Devoted grandfather ''Pop'' of Mitchell and Karen Sahn, Robert Sahn, Eric and Diane Schwartz, Amy and John Tanenbaum. Great grandfather of Jennifer, Courtney, Ryan and Trevor Sahn; Mitchell, Jeffrey and Allison Schwartz; Daniel and Samuel Tanenbaum. Dear brother of Ethel and Belle, and the late Clara, and Arthur and Cele. Services were held on May 26, 2000. You will always be in our hearts.

title: Seeking an Early Edge Into Elite Colleges
description: PARENTS have long jockeyed to get their children into the top colleges, from sending them to the right prep schools to hiring tutors for the College Boards. In an environment where high grades don't guarantee admission, parents are always looking for an edge. Lately, they have found that edge in the game of squash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAB, FRED
description: SCHWAB-Fred, 82, of 411 East 53 Street died on May 13, 2000. Mr. Schwab was born educated and resided in New York. He served in World War II as a photo journalist. He was a retired graphic illustrator for the New York Times and a freelance cartoonist. Mr. Schwab was the widower of Barbara Frick and is survived by his niece Rosemarie Sankowsky of Wayland, Massachusetts. A private family service was held last week.

title: Salt Lake City
description: Mormon pioneers came to this once desolate, high-desert valley to get away from the rest of the world. But 153 years later, the roughly one million people living at the base of the Wasatch Mountains are preparing to welcome the world for the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Joni Mitchell Recreates Her Classics and Polishes Her More Obscure Gems
description: FOR the fans of Joni Mitchell, there could have been no more surprising news than to learn that the reclusive singer-songwriter was going on tour.

title: POSTINGS: At the Intersection of Routes 440 and 278; A Hilton for Staten Island
description: Ground has been broken for a new hotel, the Hilton Garden Inn, at 1100 South Avenue, near the intersection of Routes 440, the West Shore Expressway, and 278, the Staten Island Expressway. The hotel will include 150 guest rooms and 9,000 square feet of banquet space and is scheduled to open in July 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, ESTELLE
description: ZIMMERMAN-Estelle. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of the Milton and Bernice Stern Department of Pediatrics in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Estelle Zimmerman, beloved wife of our late colleague and friend, Morris Zimmerman, M.D., a member of the pediatrics staff for close to 60 years. To the entire Zimmerman family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Henry Singman, M.D. President, Medical Board Andrew P. Mezey, M.D. Chairman of Pediatrics Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assn.

title: Ingenue for the 00's, and, Oh, Those Eyes
description: Like a lot of her friends in the fashion world, Gina Garan, a video producer and photographer, identifies with dolls. Her muse is Blythe, a collectible retro doll made for one year only, in 1972, who has the eyes of a waif painted by Margaret Keane and is now the subject of Ms. Garan's book, ''This Is Blythe'' (Chronicle Books). This homage is a collection of Ms. Garan's photographs, with Blythe as the latest in the pantheon of ingenues to turn innocence into chic.

title: May 21-27; Famous for 24 Seconds
description: After decades of rejection, Danny Biasone, the bowling alley proprietor from Syracuse, who invented professional basketball's 24-second shot clock, was finally elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame last week.

title: A Field Trip Veteran Adds Some Pointers
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebration of Sailing On the Fourth of July
description: In 1938, in the final days of the great era of trade and exploration under sail, an 18-year-old Englishman named Eric Newby signed on as an apprentice seaman aboard the four-masted sailing ship Moshulu, bound from Europe for Australia to take on a cargo of grain. A dozen more ships embarked on the same mission. The first one back to the continent would command top money at market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, IRVING
description: GOLDSTEIN-Irving, Queens College class of 1960, beloved member of the Board of Trustees of the Queens College Foundation since 1986. He served as Chairman of the Foundation from 1987 to 1991, when he became Chairman Emeritus. He was a devoted supporter of his alma mater, giving his leadership, remarkable energies and profound insight to ambitious projects to advance the institution. He was the architect of today's Foundation, and his visionary guidance has been an inspiration to all of his fellow trustees. Irving Goldstein was an irreplaceable mentor whose wise counsel will be greatly missed. The Queens College Foundation, Inc.

title: A Tale Of Art In Two Romes
description: FOR years, the problem of how to be both relevant and imaginative in the first summer of the new millennium has nagged at curators the world over. But nowhere, to my knowledge, has that problem been solved as nimbly or as persuasively as in an exhibition in Rome called ''L'Idea del Bello'' at the Palazzo delle Esposizione on the Via Nazionale, on view through June 26. (The title can be read in English as ''The Idea of Beauty'' or ''Beauty as an Idea.'')

title: A Modest Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Have an Interest? Join a Plant Society
description: If you fall madly in love with a specific plant genus, you may want to join a plant society.

title: Lament for Karla
description: I WENT to Russia not too long ago and it wasn't there -- at least, not the sinister, Soviet-era Russia that writers of cold war spy thrillers had prepared me to find behind the Iron Curtain. For that matter, the Iron Curtain wasn't there.

title: T-Bird Watchers Can Snare a Rare Old Species
description: THE official announcement took no one by surprise: Ford said last week that it would bring back the Thunderbird, this time as a two-seat roadster closely modeled on a concept car that was a sensation at auto shows last year.

description: NEW HAVEN schools sponsored a field trip recently -- not for students, but for prospective teachers.

description: Filling up for the Memorial Day weekend, drivers paid as much for gasoline as they did at the height of the oil price spike in March.

title: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly
description: In ''The Silent Generation Seeks Its Due (May 7)'' Fred Brock looked at Americans who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers. Members of that age group, in their mid-50's to early 70's, often feel overlooked by employers, marketers and the popular culture.

title: Footlights; State Theater to the Nth Degree
description: Brace yourself, New Brunswick: ''the funniest man on television,'' ''the world's most celebrated choir,'' ''the Baryshnikov of Irish dance'' and ''the world's favorite turtle'' all plan to be visiting soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, ELIZABETH ANN
description: CAREY-Elizabeth Ann. On May 26, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward Michael Carey. Loving mother of Edward C. Carey, Diane M. Cunningham and Jane E. Haswell. Mother-in-law to Moreen Carey, Myles Cunningham and Thomas Haswell. Adoring grandmother of Christine, Michelle, Elizabeth, Edward, Carolyn, Timothy and Genevieve Carey, Myles, Charles, John and William Cunningham & Laura Haswell. Great grandmother of Caroline, Lucy, Caitlin and Owen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. John the Evangelist Church, First Ave. at 55 St., Tuesday 10 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. title: A Twisted Victorian Love Story That Won't Die Out
description: THE COUNTESS,'' a drama about a sensational sex scandal involving three prominent Victorians -- John Ruskin, the most famous art critic of his day; John Everett Millais, Ruskin's protege and an artist who would later gain his own fame, and Euphemia Gray, the beautiful Scotswoman who came between them -- has quietly defied theatrical convention. With little fanfare and limited financing it has become the longest-running new drama of the 1999-2000 season and is now ensconced at an Off Broadway theater four times the size of the one where it started.

title: Cell Phones Proliferate on Highways, Raising Safety Concerns
description: As millions of Americans travel this Memorial Day weekend they are joined by family, friends and what has become for many an indispensable companion on a car trip, the cellular phone.

title: Tales of Flying Cars and Trees
description: Like most things in life, commuting is in the eye of the beholder. Most of the time, it's an obligation, a habit, no more than a repetitive journey from home to workplace and back again. But once in a while, commuting becomes high adventure, a source of laughter and the stuff of lasting memories.

title: A Largely Traditional Show at Silvermine
description: IT is not mere consolation when the Silvermine Guild in New Canaan tells artists who didn't make the cut in its annual competition, ''Art of the Northeast,'' to try again next year. Every year the show has a different judge. Though all are prominent in the art world, the judges' tastes differ markedly, and for viewers, each year's edition has its own distinctive tone.

title: Present, Nervously, At the Birth
description: PREMIERES are unnatural births. Humans, unlike Greek gods and new operas, enter the world helpless and barely formed. In that first frail state are strong hints of what we shall become, but a minimum of 20 years is required before the qualities we take through life are actualities, not promises. An opening night, especially one preceded by fanfare, speculation and promotion, has no chance at childhood and adolescence. Often its midwives are inept and its expectant parents unprepared. The new piece happens all at once and fully formed. It relies on the wisdom and charity of audiences, critics and performers faced suddenly with an odd phenomenon: the grown-up infant.

title: Crime in California: Taking the Stern Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; About Last Night
description: Al Gore is desperate to get chicks.

title: De Ferran Wins Grand Prix
description: Gil de Ferran of Brazil won the Bosch Spark Plug Grand Prix today at the Nazareth Speedway, ending a three-year drought for Roger Penske and giving his team its 100th victory.

title: African 'Talking Drums' Silenced By Park Visitors Seeking Quiet
description: For the past two years, Wali Collins, an actor and comedian, has been joining friends in Central Park each weekend for a rare kind of conversation. He plays the djembe, a Senegalese drum, and he meets with others who play different African ''talking drums,'' which call fans to Bethesda Fountain.

title: Mining 'Diamonds' at the Jersey Shore
description: Cape May ''diamonds'' have probably been washing up on Sunset Beach at the extreme southern tip of New Jersey for as long as the Delaware River has emptied into the Atlantic Ocean. But only in recent times have the quartz rocks, which can be polished and cut for jewelry like diamonds, have been prized. The rocks, in raw or cut form, are a popular souvenir for tourists who visit Lower Township beach for the sunset and a ceremony in which the American flag is lowered -- the tiny beach is one of the few places on the East Coast where the sun can be viewed going down over unobstructed water.

Split-level haircuts were chic in 1976, but Mary's was special: a classic Louise Brooks bob with tightly wound pigtails attached. I remember her wardrobe (mini-skirted jumpers and puff-sleeve blouses) and her kitchen (avocado countertops, a floor suffering from waxy yellow buildup). I can still see her at the end of the first episode, trying to get off the telephone with Dennis Foley, the police sergeant who has just called to report that her grandfather has been arrested for indecent exposure. title: Led by a Will-o'-the-Wisp Into the Wilderness

There are couples who come here for the first time to get engaged or even marry; some feel more in love in Paris and never recover from the hangover once they go. If you fall for Paris first, you might find love among the natives, for what is a native but another part of the scenery? But a Frenchman can't share your Paris dream, and it might be his incomprehension that drives you into the arms of a starry-eyed Englishman -- who tells you why he came to Paris in a sidewalk cafe on your first night together by motioning in the amber-lit air: ''For this.'' Dreamers of the same dream -- heroin addicts, mountain-biking fanatics, husband-and-wife political teams as well as expatriates -- often find themselves tied as much to the dream as to each other, all the edges of loyalty and desire blurred and inextricable.

The camp, run by St. Hubert's Animal Welfare Center at its headquarters in Madison, includes the usual activities like scavenger hunts, arts and crafts and outdoor games, but all of them relate in some way to animals. And each features a visit to one of St. Hubert's animal shelters. This year, the shelter is offering a Petting Sitting Basics workshop for those aged 11 to 14. Topics include animal behavior, safety with animals, grooming, handling emergencies with animals, pet law and pointers on starting a pet-care business. The Kritter Kamp sessions, $200 a week, are offered July 24 through 28; Aug. 7 through 11 and Aug. 21 through 25. The pet-sitting workshops, $125, consist of three parts, from 9 a.m. to noon, and are offered June 27, 28 and 29 and July 11, 12 and 13. title: WETLANDS FINES

They were fined $10,000 for dumping fill on a combined acre of regulated wetlands, another $10,000 for digging a 150-foot drainage channel on the wetlands and $5,000 for failing to install and maintain erosion controls at the site, the Town Planning Board reported. The Clarks did not have a building permit. The two lots were originally part of a subdivision, but Wetlands laws are now stricter than they were then. The Planning Department did not know what the Clarks planned to do with the property, officials said. ''It's one of the worst cases I've seen in my six and a half years on the board,'' Vincent A. Vetrano, chairman, said. ''When the violations are egregious and when the violators are aware they are breaking the law, our board takes a very, very tough stand.''

The idea, however, is not new. Yorktown, Mamaroneck and Montrose in Westchester County, Garrison and Cold Spring in Putnam County and about 20 departments in Rockland County have retirement plans for volunteer firefighters. In Harrison and Valhalla, the superintendents and school boards will propose reduced budgets, while Elmsford -- whose budget was defeated by two votes -- intends to try again with the same budget. description: Though Russia's new president, Vladimir Putin, has yet to chart a clear course on most domestic fronts, he made clear last week that he intends to move aggressively to mend the economy, ending years of meandering policies. The Putin government asked parliament to replace the country's progressive but largely dysfunctional personal income tax with a simple flat tax. By radically simplifying the code and slashing rates, Mr. Putin hopes to raise collections by cutting down on the corruption that has left his government starving for revenue. If the plan works, Mr. Putin would not only have the money to provide badly needed public services, but also establish the credibility to push for further economic reforms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIERIOT, CHARLES H.
description: THIERIOT-Charles H. of Locust Valley, LI, on May 24, 2000, age 85. Beloved husband of the late Edna T. Thieriot, devoted father of Charles H. Thieriot, Jr. of Los Angeles, CA, Julia D. Thieriot of Round Hill, VA and Frances T. Thieriot of Santa Monica, CA. Step-father of Jeff Carpenter and Katherine Carpenter Schulte both of New York City, C. Nicholas Potter of Mill Neck, NY and Mary Carpenter Zagorin of Washington, DC, grandfather of Cary Potter, Christopher Potter, Jennifer Potter, Revell Schulte, Dashiell Schulte, Edmund Zagorin and Oliver Zagorin. Great-grandfather of Macy Potter, Nina Potter and Nicholas Potter. After graduating from Harvard College in 1937 he joined R.H. Macy and Co. From 1941 to 1943 he was in the Civilian Pilot Training Program in Amarillo, Texas where he served as a flight instructor. From 1943 to 1945 he was First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps. His service included flying ''The Hump'' in the China-Burma-India Theatre. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, The Air Medal and The Chinese War Memorial Medal. In 1945, he joined the securities firm of Carlisle & Jacquelin. He served as senior partner of its successor firm, Carlisle, DeCoppet & Co., until its sale in 1976. In his retirement he was, with his late wife, an enthusiastic owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses. He was a Trustee of The New York Racing Association and The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga, NY. He also served for many years as a Fire Commissioner in Locust Valley, NY and as a Trustee of the Incorporated Village of Matinecock, Locust Valley, NY. Of his many chairtable and community interests, he was particularly devoted to St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA and the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City, both of which he served as a trustee for many years. Funeral Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Wednesday, May 31st at 11:00 A.M. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Church of the St. Sacrement, Box 1185, Bolton's Landing, New York 12184.

title: Singer, Songwriter
description: Fur and feathers may be the signature style of many women in hip-hop, but Dawn Robinson prefers a more offbeat look inspired by punk and rock. Lately, on the street and on stage, Ms. Robinson, a singer and songwriter in Lucy Pearl, has been wearing black leather boots by Sky because their S-curve platform heels are unusual. ''Everyone in R&B is into high couture,'' said Ms. Robinson, who was in the glamorous girl group En Vogue from 1989 through 1997. Divas like Lauryn Hill, Madonna and Jennifer Lopez have already discovered the sculptural footwear sold at Jeffrey, at 449 West 14th Street. It costs $230 to $380. Ms. Robinson dresses down the high-style boots by wearing them with a black, asymmetrical Goth skirt by Martin Margiela and an old Sting T-shirt on which she performed a few alterations, cutting off the sleeves and tapering the waist with safety pins. ''The rock T-shirt is antifashion, and I like that the skirt looks like they took it off the bolt,'' she said. ''It's unfinished. It's not perfect. I'm a little punk. It's the Deborah Harry thing. She just did what she wanted.'' ELIZABETH HAYT

description: Americans are eating better than they were in the 1980's, but the diets of 9 out of 10 still need improvement, federal officials said today.

description: THE public hasn't heard of the 25 pianists who are to compete this week in Ridgewood. That's because ostensibly they are not pianists; they all have day jobs.

title: Kayaking With Attitude
description: HANGING upside down, I'm suspended in a translucent green world. As I hope for rescue, my hands stroke the sides of my kayak and I hold my breath for what seems an eternity. I'm vaguely aware of the pressure of the current sweeping me downstream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, RANDOLPH ST. GEORGE
description: WALKER-Randolph St. George. Manhattan Playhouse mourns the tragic loss of our cousin and colleague Randolph Walker. He brilliantly gave life to numerous, complex, sensitive roles, balancing consummate technique with emotional adventure, thrilling every audience. We miss you, Ranny. Diana Walker and Bill Van Horn

description: Kristin Ashley O'Connell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. O'Connell of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to J. Rexford Hampton, a son of Elizabeth E. Hampton of Arlington, Va., and the late Wade H. Hampton. The Very Rev. John F. McCard performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church on Marco Island, Fla.

title: From Start As a Tot To No. 1 Girl Golfer
description: THE best female high school golfer in New York State weighs 110 pounds -- spikes included -- and drives the ball 240 yards.

title: Style & Entertaining; Tea and Geometry
description: You've heard of celebrity homes; here is the home celebrity. On June 8, Christie's International Realty will offer to the highest bidder (estimate: $3.5 to $5 million) a house at 242 East 52nd Street that was designed by the architect Philip Johnson and completed in 1950 for the art collector and philanthropist Blanchette Rockefeller at a cost of $75,000. In fact, this is the house's second time on the auction block. Its current owner, Anthony d'Offay, a London art dealer, bought the house at Sotheby's in 1989 for $3.5 million.

title: Fan of a Masked TV Swashbuckler Makes His Mark
description: When Guy Williams Jr., son of the dashing, swashbuckling actor who played Zorro in the television series that began in 1957, learned that his father would be inducted posthumously into the Bronx Walk of Fame, he decided to make a trip to the city his father had spoken of fondly.

title: A Comeback and Much More
description: WHEN a stroke at 24 left Tim Podell partially paralyzed and unable to speak, the sadness of his hospital visitors seemed to him to be oddly misplaced.

title: Ground Breaking: A Retreat Recasts the Building Blocks of Peace; . . . As It Rethinks Its History
description: THE television screen snaps into focus on a Tel Aviv army recruitment office in 2015, where a strapping Israeli raised in the United States has come home for his military service. ''I'm here to defend my country,'' he says, resonating with classic Zionist conviction.

title: The Soft Money Explosion
description: Last Wednesday, at the MCI Sports Center in Washington, the Democratic Party raised an astonishing $26.5 million at a dinner headlined by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore and attended by about 12,000 loyal Democrats, some paying a half-million dollars for the privilege. This staggering sum surpassed what until then had been the record, the $21.3 million raised less than a month before by the Republicans and George W. Bush.

title: Make Room On Olympus For Today's Sacred Monsters
description: LEONTYNE PRICE, the reigning diva of the 1960's and 70's, was chatting with National Public Radio during intermission in a broadcast from the San Francisco Opera. Who, the interviewer asked, were the singers who had shown Ms. Price the way? The last of the names she rattled off in the tones of an empress was ''La Callas.'' She had turned opera into something people really cared about, Ms. Price said, ''like baseball.''

title: The Man Who Came to Dinner
description: THE MEASURE OF A MAN A Spiritual Autobiography. By Sidney Poitier. Illustrated. 255 pp. San Francisco: HarperSanFrancisco. $26.

title: Building Character
description: NEW JERSEY today has a once-in-a-century opportunity. When the state Supreme Court ordered the construction and rehabilitation of schools in the poorest districts, it opened the way to the largest public works program in the state's history, even bigger than building the New Jersey Turnpike two generations ago.

title: The D.J. Moves Into a New Arena
description: SEVERAL months ago, I followed a rabbit into a hole and had a musical encounter of a most magical kind. Entering 56 Walker Street in TriBeCa, better known as the Electric Church, I passed through a bright orange passageway to enter a dark, cavernous room with a low stage weighed down with all manner of mixers, turntables, CD players, wires, computers, samplers, drum machines, keyboards and gadgets I've only seen in science fiction flicks. Alone stood Graham Haynes, known to most jazz fans as the avant-bop master of the cornet and fluegelhorn, mixing beats like a mad scientist. A video artist projected random clips that moved in unison with the music on the 30-foot wall behind him. After a while, Mr. Haynes was joined by Val Jeanty on electronic percussion and turntables, Craig Taborn on keyboards, Steve Hall on soprano and tenor saxophone and Imani Uzuri on vocals. Mr. Haynes grabbed his fluegelhorn and retreated to what looked like the master control board.

title: Cultivating Their Songs Down on The Farm
description: THE top echelon of contemporary singer-songwriters will converge at the Appel Farm Arts and Music Center next Saturday for a festival that will feature the best the genre has to offer.

title: Paying Proper Homage To Avant-Garde Treasures
description: It is a simple wooden crate, with an Indian River Citrus label and, in the artist's handwriting, the words ''Magic Box'' on a piece of masking tape. Inside are plastic insects, blue skulls and a toy snowman, images that appeared frequently in the work of David Wojnarowicz, a downtown artist whose writings and photographs rebelled against bigotry and the status quo.

title: BOOKEND; Let a Hundred Isms Blossom
description: Don't believe everything you read in the newspapers. The revolution in criticism is over. Departments of literature are no longer in disarray. In the late 1970's and early 80's, of course, there was a lot of blood on the tracks, the price an earlier generation had to pay for today's intellectual abundance and sometimes perplexing freedoms. The old boys, particularly the biographers, took very badly to anything with a French name or an ''-ology'' attached to it. You had to watch your flank. But by the mid-80's, you could say ''Jacques Derrida'' or ''Harold Bloom'' at dinner and your colleagues didn't get heartburn; they got hip. They hired the onetime offenders.

title: Weill's Big Wireless Bet
description: Sanford I. Weill, chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, is known for his smart financial maneuvers. After all, through mergers and acquisitions, he has famously parlayed the old Commercial Credit Corp. into successively bigger corporate entities -- first Primerica, then Travelers Corp. and now Citigroup.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Happiness Is A Tube of Macaroni
description: IN eating, as in life, style counts. So I will say this straight out: I'm not the sort of guy who willingly eats meals-on-a-stick.

title: A Speedier Cleanup Sought at Brookhaven
description: A federal cleanup at Brookhaven National Laboratory should be accelerated to reduce its cost by about $18 million and remove contaminants sooner, Senator Charles E. Schumer said at a news conference at the laboratory.

title: Krakow History
description: To the Editor: Eve Schaenen gave us an inspiring and informative history in ''Krakow Maintains Its Regal Mien'' (March 12). That city was spared by both the Kaiser and Hitler because it had no military value and no industry. As a result, it is one of the best preserved cities of Europe.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Mercedes to the Rescue

title: Even More Mel Brooks Than Before
description: MEL BROOKS, bless him, has never grown up. After three decades of making movies, his sense of humor has remained as broadly silly and gleefully infantile as ever. Beginning with ''The Producers,'' Mr. Brooks has sent up show business, and particularly movies, with an abandon worthy of applause even when the films are unsuccessful.

title: Where Boys Can Learn to Shape Up
description: EVEN some of the harshest critics of Peter Martins's regime at New York City Ballet troop eagerly to the annual workshop performances of his company's academy, the School of American Ballet. Year after year, in the dancing of the latest crop of advanced students, the workshops present a glimpse of ballet's ideals.

title: Making a Brand Statement
description: Logo clothing is a favorite with women on the cutting edge of the revived interest in the low-key, Park Avenue style of the 1950's. The trend for logo clothes began when European luxury leather goods houses hired name designers to expand their brands. The designers, many of them Americans, immediately exploded the signature logo fabrics of each house into clothing collections, injecting a homegrown practicality into the European high-fashion scene at a time when striking silhouettes were in decline. Top, from left, Burberry, Fendi; left, Jeremy Scott; right, Gucci. Bottom, far left, Dior, Below, Louis Vuitton.

title: Jets Learn the Practices Are Tougher Under Groh
description: The consensus that emerged from the Jets' four-day minicamp, which concluded Friday, was that even though the transition from Bill Parcells to Al Groh, the new head coach, has seemed seamless, Groh's minicamp was more intense than any Parcells held.

title: Gov. Ridge Derides Critics on Religious Right
description: Of all the things he is being called lately by his critics, ''liberal'' and ''dove'' make Gov. Tom Ridge laugh out loud.

title: Franco's American Foes, Now Aged, Feel Forgotten
description: When it comes to American military lore, certain names have a powerful resonance in the minds of young and old alike -- from Gettysburg to Pearl Harbor to Vietnam. Every Memorial Day, people gather at monuments that honor American soldiers, and gaze at the fields and beaches where they fell.

title: A New Link to Island's Aviation Heritage
description: THE East Northport eighth graders invited to preview the American Airpower Museum at Republic Field had all witnessed war before. Some had seen the movie ''Battlefield Earth.'' Others remember the Persian Gulf war from television. But most, like 13-year-old Hassan Nagvi, get their notions from video games.

title: Jennifer Leffel, Andrew Goldberg

title: The Columnist And His Parents
description: This time moms are on know-it-all David Bouchier's hit list [''Here's What Mothers Are All About,'' May 14], despite his weak effort to say ''Shame on you'' for remembering Mom only on Mainstream Mothers' Day. Again he shows that subtlety is not his game. Last Fathers' Day, in his usual unfunny wail of a pooh-bah, Mr. Bouchier took on fathers who conveyed feelings. Alas! Mr. Bouchier must have had a bumpy childhood.

title: Commercial Property/666 Fifth Avenue; For Tishman Speyer, a Homecoming of Sorts
description: WHEN Tishman Speyer Properties and an investment group recently bought 666 Fifth Avenue, the 39-story, 1.3-million-square-foot building at 52nd Street, it was more than just an investment. For some Tishman Speyer executives, it was a return home and the latest episode in a multigenerational family history.

description: The Nassau County Legislature voted 11 to 8 in favor of zoning powers for the Village of Atlantic Beach, but both supporters and opponents say there are still hurdles ahead.

description: THE world hailed the coloratura soprano as the ''Swedish Nightingale.'' Phineas Taylor Barnum came to know and affectionately dub her the ''Divine Jenny.''

From George Bush and Al Gore down to aspirants for state and local office, all politicians have embraced the cause of high standards and excellence. The bad news is that the remedy everyone but teachers and pupils wants to prescribe is more testing.
