title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOS, BETSY THOMAS
description: BLOS-Betsy Thomas. Our beloved gift from God, returned to God, May 20, 2000. She will be eternally missed. Born in York, SC, Betsy was one of six children of Dunnie and Elsie Thomas. Betsy moved to New York City after receiving her Bachelor's Degree from the University of South Carolina. She received her master's and Ph.D from New York University and a M.S.W. from Yeshiva University. Betsy was married to Peter Blos, renowned adolescent Psychoanalyst, now deceased. Betsy taught in elementary schools and later joined the Institute for Developmental studies at N.Y.U. There she taught preschool in the research, experimental classes that later lead to the development of the Head Start Programs. She also served as a teacher trainer for Head Start and Follow Through Programs throughout the country and the Virgin Islands. Later in her career Betsy became a Psychoanalyst after completing her psychoanalytic training at the New York Freudian Society. Betsy is survived by her brother, Dr. Benjamin Thomas, and her sister, Wilma Florence and her devoted niece, Lea and other nieces, nephews and extended family.

description: Shannan Lee Maher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Harms performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass.

From art to history -- Art Gallery of New South Wales, Museum of Contemporary Art, Hyde Park Barracks, Museum of Sydney -- the city offers a wealth of enriching experiences.

description: BINDSEIL-William F. Jr. Of Setauket, Long Island on May 25, 2000. Friends may call at the Bryant Funeral Home, Inc. 411 Old Town Road, Setauket, LI. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-10 PM. Memorial services Wednesday 1:00 PM at the Setauket Presbyterian Church.

title: Dance Has Africans Shaking Behinds, and Heads
description: The night was getting wild, the air tense with expectation, as the crowd at a military academy here waited for the show's top act, three female Ivoirian dancers known as Les Tueuses, or The Killers. Until last December, Les Tueuses, the queens of a suggestive dance craze called the mapouka, had been banned from television, judged too vulgar by the government, which was subsequently toppled in a Christmas Eve coup.

title: Those Whom We Honor
description: There are three of them now in New Jersey, three surviving recipients of the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest award for valor in combat: two from World War II, one from Vietnam.

title: Ideas & Trends; Getting Hyper Over Convenience Food
description: EVERYONE knows America is a nation in a hurry -- especially the makers of packaged foods. First there was the TV dinner. Then came fast food for meals on the go. Now, with the pace of life approaching warp speed, it's time for something marketers call hyperconvenience food, portable comfort cuisine and dashboard dining.

title: Syracuse and Princeton Survive to Reach Final
description: The wet ball spurted through legs and sticks and scrambling hands as the seconds spun off the clock. Virginia had blown an 11-9 edge in the semifinals of the men's national lacrosse tournament with a series of careless miscues, letting Princeton snatch a 12-11 lead. Now five seconds were left in the game.

description: THE change in squash equipment has helped ignite interest in the game for younger players, said Craig Brand of the United States Squash Racquets Association of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: The World: U.S.-Europe Relations; Tiffs Over Bananas And Child Custody
description: ACLOSE aide to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder was recently astounded to find a cabinet meeting devoted to the divisive issue of child custody in German-American relations. Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer weighed in; so did Mr. Schroder himself. There was much agonizing as they reviewed the family difficulties of Lady Catherine Meyer, who is the wife of the British ambassador to Washington.

title: Local Celebrities, Real and Imagined
description: SOME of them lived on Staten Island and others were born in the minds of Staten Islanders. So among the celebrities featured in the exhibition ''Famous People From Staten Island'' are such varied figures as Dorothy Day and Cornelius Vanderbilt (both at right), Donald Trump and Mr. Clean.

title: Too Much, Too Soon Halts Assisted-Living Boom
description: FUELED by favorable demographic trends, strong consumer demand and a robust economy, the assisted-living industry was supposed to be mounting record profits this year while expanding rapidly and reaching new stock market peaks. That, at least, is what analysts were predicting three years ago.

title: Technology And Timing Can Outfox The Bears
description: OVER the years, investors in technology stocks have become accustomed to coping with mini-bear markets in the sector once or maybe twice a year. But the bear they are looking at right now is no koala.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon; Big Enough for a Trek to Texas
description: FIVE years ago, when General Motors ran its huge Suburban through a buzzsaw, cutting a 20-inch slice from its length, it created the Chevrolet Tahoe and the GMC Yukon: shorter, more manageable sport utilities with major V-8 power that could seat up to six people and practically tow a mountain.

title: Ravelstein Knows Everything, Almost
description: THERE are two mistakes about music in Saul Bellow's new novel, ''Ravelstein.'' Although what constitutes a mistake in a work of fiction is something that will require a little commentary. As readers may know, the title character is based on Allan Bloom, Mr. Bellow's friend and colleague at the University of Chicago, who became an international celebrity with the publication of ''The Closing of the American Mind'' in 1987. Bloom died in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PSAROUDIS, JOVANKA
description: PSAROUDIS - Jovanka, passed quietly at her beloved ''home with a view'' in Northport, New York, on May 24, 2000. Jovanka was a breeder, exhibitor and fancier of Scottish Terriers. Loving wife of Nicholas. Her funeral service will be held at noon on Tuesday, May 30, 2000, at St. Paraskevi G.O. Church, Greenlawn, New York. Her interment will be at the Cedar Grove Cemetery, Flushing, NY. For information contact The Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, NY.

description: The Silicon Valley of the Deep South? With Israel's help, that is what Bernard Marcus, co-founder and chairman of Home Depot, wants Georgia to become.

title: Summer Rental: No Cachet, But Comfy
description: WE decided not to compete for a summer rental in the Hamptons this year. All the best properties have already been grabbed by the nouveau riche dot-com crowd, who have wisely decided to dance as hard as they can before the music stops. The only places now on the market are small rooms in shared houses, at about $10,000, and tiny cottages with teacup-size pools for a mere $25,000 a season. The rich may have more money than you and me, but they will have less living space than well-fed battery chickens.

title: Karen Roll, Edouard Trabulsi
description: Dr. Karen May Roll and Dr. Edouard John Trabulsi are to be married today by the Rev. John Kroschel at the Ascension Lutheran Church in Snyder, N.Y.

description: ALMOST nine years ago, Carlos Daniel Grullon confronted his estranged wife in the basement of the Tarrytown Hilton Inn, where she worked as a chambermaid. Believing she had dishonored him by her independent behavior, he shot her twice, the police said.

description: WESTCHESTER readers didn't hesitate to take the pyrameter challenge presented by this section's editors May 7.

title: ATLANTIC CITY EXPRESSWAY
description: The first new interchange in the 37-year-history of the Atlantic City Expressway opened at milepost 41 in Gloucester and Winslow Townships last week. Tolls at the new interchange, 25 cents (20 cents on E-ZPass) are charged for traffic traveling to and from Philadelphia; traffic going to and from Atlantic City are not charged. The configuration for the interchange was changed during planning to save a 250-year-old oak tree that is near the expressway. About 12,000 cars are expected to use the interchange each day. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Jeanine Basmajian, Erwin Bulan
description: Dr. Jeanine Hermine Basmajian and Dr. Erwin Joseph Bulan are to be married today by the Rev. Dominick J. Lagonegro at St. Columba Roman Catholic Church in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

description: Al Simon, who helped create some of early television's most successful sitcoms as well as the technical wherewithal to save them on high-quality film for summer reruns and syndication, died on Tuesday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, CARL E.
description: HAAS-Carl E., 87, of Sarasota, FL, on May 5. Formerly of Jamaica, Great Neck and Manhattan, NY. Beloved husband for 60 years of Roslyn (nee Schachne). Much loved and loving father of Edward J. of Rhinebeck, NY and David S. of Riverdale, NY, grandfather of Gregory J. of Boston, MA, and Elizabeth J. of Kitty Hawk, NC, greatgrandfather of Nicole Fegan, brother of Charlotte Reiss of Portland, OR, Bernard of Somers, NY and Phillip of Oceanside, NY. He obtained his Chartered Life Underwriter designation in 1938 and had a long and distinguished career in the life insurance industry as a general agent for the Continental Assurance Company. He was a former president of the Brooklyn Life Managers Association, the Great Neck Square Club, and the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club; former Master of the Rufus King Masonic Lodge 1091, Jamaica, NY, founder and charter member of Steppingstone Masonic Lodge 1141, a member of Temple Beth Sholom in Sarasota, and since 1981 was a member of Sahib Shrine Temple in Sarasota. Memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: My Classmate the Candidate
description: I haven't seen Rick Lazio this much since high school. Back then, he and I were in classes together in boring West Islip, N.Y. He was barely memorable, not a star athlete, scholar, artist, actor, surfer or class clown. He was simply decent in a way that makes you not want to give someone the time of day as a teenager. Now, of course, since he announced his race for the Senate in the West Islip High School gym last Sunday (''I'm no celebrity,'' he declared), the entire country knows who he is. And I'm not the only former classmate reminiscing about the lackluster impression he made back then.

description: THE Candace Perich Gallery in Katonah, which specializes in photography, is observing its fifth anniversary with a commemorative group exhibition that sums up its director's enthusiasms.

title: City of Light Makes A Claim to Music, Too
description: Vienna has long been called the City of Music, but Nigel Simeone, a lecturer in the department of music at the University of Wales in Bangor, makes a case for sharing the distinction with Paris. His book ''Paris -- A Musical Gazetteer,'' scheduled to be published by Yale University Press on Tuesday, suggests hundreds of sites associated with composers and performers who have lived in Paris in the last 400 years, including such non-Frenchmen as Chopin, Donizetti, Liszt, Mozart, Prokofiev, Rossini, Stravinsky, Verdi and Wagner.

title: Tests Show a Suspect's Pistol Was Used to Kill 5 at a Wendy's in Queens, Police Say

She is survived by four sons, Stephen, Mark, Ian and Keith, their wives Margaret, Sally, Donna and Anne, grandchildren Eric and Kevin, and her companion of many years Sidney Gardner.

title: Finally, a Treatment for a Scourge Of Riverside Park's Stately Trees
description: It arrives in early April, as reliably as rain showers. Just after healthy leaves sprout from the sycamores and London plane trees that line Riverside Park, they become disfigured and blotchy, and develop lesions. It is not unusual for a tree to lose half its leaves when it attacks, and in some cases, a whole tree defoliates.

title: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly
description: In ''The Silent Generation Seeks Its Due (May 7)'' Fred Brock looked at Americans who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers. Members of that age group, in their mid-50's to early 70's, often feel overlooked by employers, marketers and the popular culture.

title: Searching for an Identity, Finding Room to Resonate
description: Cut from its moorings at the 92nd Street Y, the New York Chamber Symphony has been working the past few years toward a new identity and a permanent sense of home. Much of what was good remains. The core of principal players survives, as does Gerard Schwarz, the music director. Mr. Schwarz is still a thoughtful and adventurous conductor, and the tendency to micromanage -- to fiddle with details seemingly for the sake of fiddling -- seems to have subsided.

title: It's All in the Family as Princeton Goes for a Title

title: Detroit Journal; Introducing Techno Sound to the City That Spawned Motown

title: Martinez Stands and Delivers for the Red Sox
description: They all knew by the second inning, all the hitters. Pedro Martinez was pitching and Roger Clemens was pitching and, on this night, there did not seem to be a bit of difference between the two, except that Clemens happened to be striking out batters with more frequency. Everybody knew by the second inning that one run could win last night's game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Knicks' Resilience Gets a New Test
description: They are reputed to be the kings of adversity, the team that grows incredibly strong and resilient when its roster and room for error are chopped short. Whether overcoming the loss of its star center, making a huge halftime deficit disappear or ignoring a pronounced height disadvantage to block a jump shot, the Knicks seem to morph into basketball's version of the little engine that could whenever necessary.

description: The New York City Ballet honored its founding choreographer on Friday night with a program at the New York State Theater that celebrated George Balanchine's extraordinary creative versatility.

title: Corrections

While he opposes a proposal made by his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, to register new handguns and license new gun users, he supports the Brady Bill, which requires background checks for gun buyers, and a ban on some forms of assault weapons. He does not oppose all forms of gun control.

title: The Pacers Gave the Knicks a Gift, and They Want It Back
description: The Indiana Pacers want to squeeze life from the Knicks this afternoon in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals at Madison Square Garden. If they can push a 2-1 series lead into a 3-1 advantage, the Pacers believe the Knicks could become breathless, introspective and numb.

title: A Ceaseless War Leaves Trail of Death in Eritrea

title: The Constancy of Memorial Day
description: This is the first Memorial Day of the new millennium, and thus an appropriate moment to examine the meaning of past Memorial Days and to speculate on what Memorial Day, besides its role as summer's tribune, may mean to us in the future. It is, first and foremost, a day of remembrance and commemoration, when we honor those who have fallen in war. It is also a day of reconciliation, and whether we give credit for inventing the holiday in 1866 to the men of Waterloo, N.Y., or the women of Columbus, Miss., the original idea in both places was to honor the war dead from North and South, and thus heal the wounds of a bitter civil war.

description: Two men facing an avalanche of evidence in last week's execution-style massacre at a Wendy's restaurant stood silently at their arraignment as a prosecutor described in chilling detail how the victims were bound, gagged and blindfolded, their heads covered with plastic bags, and shot one by one as they knelt in a freezer room.

description: HAAS-Carl E., 87, of Sarasota, FL, on May 5. Formerly of Jamaica, Great Neck and Manhattan, NY. Beloved husband for 60 years of Roslyn (nee Schachne). Much loved and loving father of Edward J. of Rhinebeck, NY and David S. of Riverdale, NY, grandfather of Gregory J. of Boston, MA, and Elizabeth J. of Kitty Hawk, NC, greatgrandfather of Nicole Fegan, brother of Charlotte Reiss of Portland, OR, Bernard of Somers, NY and Phillip of Oceanside, NY. He obtained his Chartered Life Underwriter designation in 1938 and had a long and distinguished career in the life insurance industry as a general agent for the Continental Assurance Company. He was a former president of the Brooklyn Life Managers Association, the Great Neck Square Club, and the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club; former Master of the Rufus King Masonic Lodge 1091, Jamaica, NY, founder and charter member of Steppingstone Masonic Lodge 1141, a member of Temple Beth Sholom in Sarasota, and since 1981 was a member of Sahib Shrine Temple in Sarasota. At Sony Classical, for example, film scores, crossover projects and topical works dominate the contemporary music releases. New music was never a priority at BMG, and it is unlikely to fare well as the company reconsiders its classical music lines this spring. And at Universal Classics, the Argo label, which had recorded American composers like Aaron Kernis and Michael Daugherty, was scuttled.

title: At Life's End, Many Patients Are Denied Peaceful Passing

She signed a ''living will'' outlining her wishes, informed two nieces and gave one of them power of attorney to make medical decisions for her if she could no longer make them herself.

title: Campaigning on Social Security
description: Social Security has emerged as a critical issue in this year's presidential campaign, but neither candidate seems prepared to address the system's long-term financial problems. Instead, Gov. George W. Bush wants to let individuals invest a small part of their Social Security contributions in the stock market, where he thinks they will earn a better return, and Vice President Al Gore proposes to keep the system largely intact with an infusion of general tax revenues. Neither proposal would really stabilize the system in the long run. In truth, though Social Security is projected to become bankrupt in four decades, the system is not all that far out of kilter. It would not be hard for bold politicians to devise a fix.

She was the loving mother of John Hale (Jack), 5; Charles Edward, 4; and Grace Helen Wollmuth, 2. Laurie was raised by her beloved parents, Jody and Edward P. While Laurie loved her career in finance, she loved her family more and chose to spend full time with them. A bright star has burned too quickly. Wake at Fairchild & Sons, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Tuesday and Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Thursday at 2PM at St. Paul the Apostle, 2534 Cedar Swamp Road, Brookville. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Laurie H. Wollmuth Foundation, C/O Frederick Kessler at Wollmuth, Maher & Deutsch, LLC, 500 Ffth Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, NY 10110, 212-382-3300.

Though based in Virginia, Chromatis was founded in Israel in 1997 and maintains research operations outside Tel Aviv. The company's flagship product, Metropolis, is a switching system for fiber optics networks.

He oversaw its operations and participated actively in its scientific projects. He taught, inspired, wrote and published, all the while conducting a distinguished practice. His affability and intelligence colored all of the Fund's activities. We are grateful for his participation in our endeavors. We share his loss with his family. Mortimer Ostow, President Peter B. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNBERG, EMANUEL (LICA)
description: GRUNBERG-Emanuel (Lica), the love of my life, my husband God gave me for 55 years has left me on May 28, 2000. Evelyne (Evy) nee Wechsler. Born in Roumania, he was, during the difficult years of war, a pillar of the Jewish community-their pride. Not allowed to practice the law he had studied, he went into the educational field. At the Moria Gaster School where he was principal, he was instrumental in establishing the ''Micul (Little) Gulliver'' Children's Theatre, writing and directing plays that brought so much to young and old. They all respected and loved him dearly for the gift he gave them when they needed a smile on their sad faces. He left for Israel in 1949, where his talent as a playwright and stage director was appreciated when he joined the Li-La-Lo and Do-Re-Mi Theatres. He also published his poetry in the Roumanian newspaper ''Viata Noastra.'' They were pearls of wisdom. In 1967, he came to the United States. His love for books made him choose the career of editor with the Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Division Academic Press, publisher of scientific books, where he worked for 20 years. He was a remarkable human being. His wit, his humor, his sensibility, his integrity, his modesty were unique. The Wechsler, Kastner, Kimmel, Cherches, Finkelstein, Nagler, Auer and Sebastian families and his many friends in Israel, France and Brazil mourn his passing. Services Wednesday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIERIOT, CHARLES H.
description: THIERIOT-Charles H. of Locust Valley, LI, on May 24, 2000, age 85. Beloved husband of the late Edna T. Thieriot, devoted father of Charles H. Thieriot, Jr. of Los Angeles, CA, Julia D. Thieriot of Round Hill, VA and Frances T. Thieriot of Santa Monica, CA. Step-father of Jeff Carpenter and Katherine Carpenter Schulte both of New York City, C. Nicholas Potter of Mill Neck, NY and Mary Carpenter Zagorin of Washington, DC, grandfather of Cary Potter, Christopher Potter, Jennifer Potter, Revell Schulte, Dashiell Schulte, Edmund Zagorin and Oliver Zagorin. Great-grandfather of Macy Potter, Nina Potter and Nicholas Potter. After graduating from Harvard College in 1937 he joined R.H. Macy and Co. From 1941 to 1943 he was in the Civilian Pilot Training Program in Amarillo, Texas where he served as a flight instructor. From 1943 to 1945 he was First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps. His service included flying ''The Hump'' in the China-Burma-India Theatre. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, The Air Medal and The Chinese War Memorial Medal. In 1945, he joined the securities firm of Carlisle & Jacquelin. He served as senior partner of its successor firm, Carlisle, DeCoppet & Co., until its sale in 1976. In his retirement he was, with his late wife, an enthusiastic owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses. He was a Trustee of The New York Racing Association and The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga, NY. He also served for many years as a Fire Commissioner in Locust Valley, NY and as a Trustee of the Incorporated Village of Matinecock, Locust Valley, NY. Of his many chairtable and community interests, he was particularly devoted to St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA and the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City, both of which he served as a trustee for many years. Funeral Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Wednesday, May 31st at 11:00 A.M. Contributions in lieu of flowers to Church of the St. Sacrement, Box 1185, Bolton's Landing, New York 12184.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH PURCHASES 12 PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS
description: Universal Health Services Inc., the third-biggest United States hospital manager, agreed yesterday to buy 12 psychiatric centers and real estate for $105 million to become the largest owner of mental health hospitals in the country. Eleven of the hospitals will be acquired from Charter Behavioral Health Systems L.L.C., a unit of Ramsay Youth Services Inc. that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February. A 12th hospital and real estate will be purchased from a limited partnership owned by the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company. Universal Health, which is based in King of Prussia, Pa., operates 70 centers, including 23 mental health sites, in 20 states, Washington and Puerto Rico.

For the first time, ABN Amro will also add two non-Dutch executives to its management board. The reorganization is ABN Amro's second within a year.

title: Demanding New Elections in Peru
description: The national howl of protest against President Alberto Fujimori's illegitimate re-election victory in Peru is a welcome sign of the country's political health, but it also poses a danger. Mr. Fujimori or his backers in military intelligence may feel cornered and strike back with violence. To prevent bloodshed, the international community must strongly support the protesters' goal of a legitimate election to choose a democratic government in Peru, and prepare to isolate Mr. Fujimori if he refuses, or uses violence.

title: EURO RISING
description: The euro strengthened to its highest level in a month against the dollar, fueled by speculation that the European Central Bank might intervene on its behalf and by signs of stronger growth in Europe. Though many analysts doubt the euro is about to reverse its long-term decline -- the currency has fallen nearly 25 percent since it was introduced in January 1999 -- a growing number of foreign-exchange traders seem to think it may have hit bottom. The euro hit its all-time low of 88.5 cents on May 19 and has since rebounded to an exchange rate of more than 94 cents. Adding to the momentum was new data showing that the German economy, Europe's biggest, could expand by 3 percent or more this year. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, DORIS
description: FREEMAN-Doris. Bar-Ilan University and its American Friends mourn the passing of Doris Freeman, one of our most cherished benefactors and friends. Together with her late beloved husband Maurice, she was deeply devoted to Bar-Ilan for a quarter of a century and served with distinction as Vice President of our Women's Division. The Freemans were Presidential Founders of the University and established the important Freeman Family Scholarship Fund in memory of their beloved son Stuart, which now also bears the names of his dear parents. Few have the charm and elegance that was theirs. The Freemans provided a regal quality to all our events in both New York and London. Their friends were legion, and with them we will greatly miss the Freemans. We share with their daughter Carole Gliedman, her husband Richard, and the entire family inspiring memories. May they be comforted among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman Chancellor Charles Dimston Chm. American Board of Trustees Mr. Melvin Stein President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy Vice President, Bar-Ilan University

title: A WISCONSIN UTILITY WILL PURCHASE ANOTHER FOR STOCK

Investors in Wisconsin Fuel and Light, a gas utility, will swap each share for 1.73 shares of WPS. The agreement values Wisconsin Fuel at $54.82 a share, more than double its most recent stock price. WPS, based in Green Bay, Wis., had 1999 sales of $1.1 billion. Wisconsin Fuel and Light, based in Wausau, Wis., had sales of $43 million last year. WPS fell 56.25 cents, to $31.6875. Wisconsin Fuel and Light last traded, at $24, on May 16.

title: DE BEERS CHANGES POLICY
description: The company that controls two-thirds of the world diamond trade, De Beers, said it had stopped buying gems on the open market, a policy that props up prices to lower inventory costs. Under its chairman, Nicky Oppenheimer, the company has been reviewing some of its policies. For 70 years it has bought and hoarded competitors' stones to curtail supplies in the $7 billion uncut-diamond market. Late last year, De Beers limited its supplies to those from its own mines and mining partners and stones bought under contract with Russian and Canadian producers, electing not to buy gems in Antwerp. By buying other miners' output, De Beers was forced to store billions of dollars of gems, a practice that limited investment elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, ROBERT
description: BRILL-Robert. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend, Bob Brill, who has been an integral part of the AJC family for more than three decades. Bob, a nephew of our former National PResident Elmer Winter, was a member of our national Board of Governors and a past President of our Milwaukee chapter. His wisdom, humor, and hands-on style made him not only a successful businessman, but a cherished and trusted civic leader in his home town and within the larger Jewish community. His desire to foster more positive and constructive intergroup relations inspired much of his professional and communal work, and will surely be one of his lasting legacies. We are greatful for Bob's generosity and his tireless commitment to AJC as we sought to build these human bridges of mutual respect and understanding together. We send our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Marian, his three daughters, five grandchildren, and the rest of his grieving family. Bruce M. description: The Bay View Capital Corporation, the parent of Bay View Bank, said yesterday that it had retained Merrill Lynch & Company to help in evaluating its options, including the sale of some or all of its units. The company, based in San Mateo, Calif., said that its share price did not reflect the intrinsic value of the company. Its shares jumped $1.3125, or 16 percent, to $9.50, but were still well off their 52-week high of $20.75 reached last July. At the current price, the stock is worth a total of $309 million. The company's principal subsidiary, Bay View Bank, is the largest deposit franchise exclusively serving the San Francisco Bay area, with 58 full-service branches.

title: For Weddings, Four-Star Flair With the Beauty of Economy
description: So many wedding cakes are more like sculpture than pastry: dry layers mortared with dull fillings, a plaster of sugary icing and a price worthy of a Chelsea gallery. Now Martin Bernier, a partner in Food Attitude, a wholesale bakery based on Long Island, has set up weddingcakeonline.com. Mr. Bernier and his partners, who include a former pastry chef at Le Bernardin, streamlined the process to keep the prices reasonable, at $4 or $6 a portion. Their showroom, at 235 East 25th Street, displays more than a dozen designs. Couples can choose the type of icing and its color: only roses are available for decoration. But what really distinguishes the cakes are the flavors and fillings: they are delicious, with combinations like vanilla-almond meringue with cassis cream and chocolate ganache or chocolate dacquoise with hazelnut cream. The cakes can be ordered with a week's notice. Visits to the showroom are by appointment only: (212) 686-4644.

description: Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is in many ways a stunning departure from most narrative ballet. MacMillan made use in his 1965 staging of some theatrical effects in an earlier version by John Cranko. Even more, MacMillan was inspired by the great dramatic dancers Christopher Gable and Lynn Seymour. His ''Romeo and Juliet,'' presented by American Ballet Theater on Friday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House, still has considerable dramatic impact.

title: Work-Release for Battered Women
description: Under New York State law, prisoners convicted of violent crimes are not allowed into the work-release program. In 1995 Gov. George Pataki, concerned about crimes committed by inmates on work-release, made violent offenders ineligible for the program. While that prohibition makes sense in most cases, there should be an exemption allowed for battered women who have been convicted of violent crimes against their abusers.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: Who Put the Beet in the Mousseline?
description: JOAN HAMBURG, the talk show host on radio station WOR, had not eaten beets since she was a child, until she encountered them a few weeks ago at Blue Hill in Greenwich Village. ''Some people have phobias about bridges, some about elevators,'' she said. ''I had a beet phobia.'' Yet, when she didn't recognize her nemesis hidden in beet ravioli with her braised cod, she ate it and discovered: ''It was spectacular. I may have gotten over my phobia.''

title: GUILFORD AGREES TO ACQUIRE A MAKER OF MEDICAL DEVICES
description: Guilford Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Gliatech Inc., a manufacturer of medical devices, for $203 million in stock. Shareholders will get 1.38 Guilford shares for each Gliatech share, valuing the deal at more than $203 million. Gliatech makes absorbable medical devices to limit surgical scarring, while Guilford develops drugs and diagnostics for the treatment of neurological diseases. Shares of Guilford fell $1.375 each, to $14.125, while Cleveland-based Gliatech jumped $2.375, to $18.75.

title: Insanity! Communism! Indolence! The Works!
description: One of the real heroes of ''Grass,'' Ron Mann's punchy and enjoyable new documentary on the history of marijuana in the United States during the 20th century, is Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York. While Harry J. Anslinger, the federal government's first drug czar, spent his career looking for a way to pin as many evils on marijuana as he could, and punishing those who disagreed with him, La Guardia calmly commissioned a study on marijuana use. The study concluded that ''the sociological, psychological and medical ills commonly attributed to marijuana have been exaggerated insofar as the City of New York is concerned.'' It's no wonder that an airport was named after him.

title: Vegetarian Everything, Downtown
description: A bright, friendly new source for dried, canned and frozen vegetarian foods is Vegecyber Gourmet, 210 Centre Street (Canal Street). ''Squid'' and ''shrimp'' made from yams, and a seaweed product called meat fluff are among the imitation meat and seafood items that line its shelves and freezers. The market also carries rice, noodles, teas, sweets and snacks, both Western and Asian. The manager, Louisa Wau (in light jacket) and her assistant, Judy Chan, are ready to help. A 20-ounce bag of quinoa is a bargain at $4.39. Packages of 36 frozen vegetable spring rolls, $7.50, can be deep-fried for quick and delicious hors d'oeuvres. And the fluff? It's $5.99 for a 16-ounce container.

title: FREESERVE'S STOCK JUMPS ON RUMOR
description: The stock of Britain's largest Internet service provider, Freeserve P.L.C, rose 24 percent after it was reported that T-Online International A.G., Europe's biggest Internet service provider, wants to buy Freeserve from Dixons Group P.L.C. for $:6.5 billion ($9.7 billion). T-Online, which is majority owned by Deutsche Telekom A.G., plans to offer about 650 pence a share for Freeserve, The Sunday Times of London reported. T-Online declined to comment on the report.

title: Special Twists This Year in the Competition Called Tony Madness

But in his visit to Moscow, he will encounter that reality face to face, when he is greeted by President Vladimir Putin, a former colonel in the K.G.B., the son of a party apparatchik as well of the grandson of a trusted member of Lenin's and then Stalin's personal detail.
